column2: NJ has a very broad definition of what a tenant is.  In this case the LL has been aware of your partner's presence for years, unless they are in the habit of issuing access cards to strangers. He is entitled to a card in my opinion.   You should send notice to the LL as required by the lease and ask for the reinstatement of cards. Alert them that you will escrow the rent if they do not reactivate the card.

I think you mean your brother is "schiizophrenic."  Depending on what he did when he exposed himself (masturbated, touching himself in a lewd manner, etc.), he could be charged with a serious felony called lewd and lascivious conduct with a child under 14 years old, a violation of Penal Code section 288(a), to a misdemeanor offense called "annoying or molesting a child," a violation of Penal Code section 647.6.  The 288(a) carries a maximum of 8 years in State Prison, while the 647.6 has a maximum term of 1 year.  His mental illness would play a big role in deciding how to address what happened and what needs to be done to prevent it from happening again.  If criminal proceedings were initiated, they'd kick your brother out of your house to protect your 7-year old from additional acts of exposure, and your brother will wind up having to register as a sex offender for the rest of his life.  He may come to be labeled a mentally disordered sex offender.  If his exposure was or will be reported to the police, he needs or will need a lawyer immediately to protect his interests.

I suggest that you hire an attorney who is not from the Dutchess County area.  Lawyers from out of town won't be intimidated by a judge who they don't routinely appear in front of because they don't have to fear reprisal.  A judge is only intimidating if a lawyer thinks that a judge will take things out against him and his clients in the future. (Even then most lawyers still won't be intimidated) But if a lawyer has little or no chance of seeing this judge again, what reason would they have for being intimidated.

The answer is that we have to convert what would have been powers from the power of attorney into an administrator if no will appoints an executor, or to the executor if the will leaves unnamed executor. We do that through our state's Department in order to empower our client to bring the wrongful death action. I wrongful death actions involve both Supreme Court for the underlying litigation and Surrogate's Court to empower the client to bring the action initially. We also have the power to negotiate a settlement and go back to one of the two courts, depending on the circumstances, to ask for approval of a wrongful death settlement-so just because we agreed in trial the case does not mean that it has to end in trial-although we do try many cases.  Bob Brenna Jr   Brenna Boyce pllc

Relocation with a child is determined by the factors in ARS 25-408(H). The reason for the move, how it affects the non-moving party's parenting time, how it affects the children's quality of life, and the stability of the home are the primary considerations. You should expect to modify the parenting plan to ensure that your ex-wife's access to her children isn't diminished (perhaps she will see the children every summer instead of every other summer?), but as long as you act in good faith to preserve her relationship with her children, you should be allowed to move. If you do not already have counsel, you should consider speaking with a local family law attorney regarding the strength of your position in more detail.

It sounds like they might be interested in you, but there is no way for me to say for certain.  If you know of any reason why would be investigated, talk to a lawyer about it.  If an officer or detective tries to ask you questions about a crime, you should remember you have the right to remain silent and the right to have a lawyer present with you during questioning.  They don't always have to tell you your rights, but you still have these rights nonetheless.  Exercise them--police don't ask questions about your involvement in crime unless they've already decided you are guilty and they just want you to incriminate yourself before they arrest you.

You are talking about a partition.  Any one or more owners of the property can file a partition action. The complaint describes the land, the owners and the interest of each owner. The suit can be filed without regard to the manner in which property is owned, except that property owned by a husband and wife as an estate by the entirety is not subject to partition during the joint lives of the spouses and while they are still married. In a partition action, the court is asked to divide the property among the owners. If the property is not subject to division (like your house), the court can order the property sold and the proceeds distributed among the owners.

As each of the attorneys have stated, you absolutely can represent yourself. We call it pro se`. The Florida Supreme Court approved Family Law Court forms are available right on the Duval County Clerk of Courts website. Just download them, check your boxes, and there you go. Easy peasy...or is it? Many people find the forms confusing and depending on their issues, too difficult to fill out. When they do see a lawyer they realize they have failed to include an important issue.   My question to you is WHY would you want to do that when you know you are going to hire a lawyer anyway after she responds? I'm not getting your angle here and I don't really think it's about costs. Becareful, even though the other attorneys have advised you about how we go about Amending a Petition and fixing it after the fact, there is also the chance that you may not get a "do over" and the court denys your Motion to Amend. Wr have really sharp Judges in Duval County. I would strongly suggest you retainer a lawyer right from the start and leave the games for the ball field. Good luck.

I think you want to create a sculpture by literally taking parts of dolls and compiling them together in an artistic expression of "the repetitive use of V-forms."  You're creating art -- not a commercial product.  If that's correct then I suggest my colleagues have missed the issue.   The First Amendment strongly protects expressive works -- even those created by compiling bits of other people's property. The analysis, I think, is NOT copyright "substantial similarity" because the dolls, if they're protected by a copyright at all, are not being reproduced [only parts of the actual dolls are being used].  The only IP right that could be at issue is trademark / trade dress if the portions of the dolls being used are still brand-recognizable. And even then the test would not be "likely to confuse" but, rather, the Rogers "artistic relevance" test.  In short, speak with your own intellectual property attorney to discuss the specfics of your plan. IF you intend on mass-producing the sculpture then that adds even another layer or two of analysis. Good luck.

You can drive any car in Illinois if you have a valid driver's license. If you are the person who inherited the automobile you should attempt to process the title at your earliest convenience. You will need letters of office from the probate court or a small estate affidavit to the Illinois Secretary of State to transfer the title.

In North Carolina, a judgment is valid for ten years and may be renewed once for another ten year period. These technically aren't statutes of limitations, but they are a limitation on how long someone can try to enforce a judgment. Right now, you're well within the lifespan of judgment.   Your options are fairly limited. Your time for appealing the judgment has long since past. There is a procedure which will allow you to obtain relief from the judgment under Rule 60 of the N.C. Rules of Civil Procedure; however, based on the facts you've recounted, I don't think you'd have a good basis for obtaining relief. Ultimately, I'd suggest going to the judgment creditor and perhaps making some sort of cash settlement offer in exchange for the creditor mark the judgment paid in full in the public record. Perhaps offer them $750 or $1,000 cash now to release you from future obligations. They may decide that a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

SPREAD THE WORD: Workers Comp is (basically) a No-Fault System.  (there's a little reduction if you show up drunk, and there's a little extra if the employer sent you into gator-infested waters.)    No-fault insurance sucks because somebody can do a major negligence and pay almost nothing, and you get all the suffering for nothing.  YOU MAY have misunderstood your attorney;   since you're good at legal research, check out Labor Code 3208.3:   3.The employee must prove that the actual events of employment are the predominant cause of the psychiatric condition (51% or more).     PLUS permanent disability add-ons for psychiatric injuries resulting from physical injuries are limited to "catastrophic" injuries and cases in which the injured worker was either the victim of a violent crime, or witnessed a violent crime.  That was new effective January 2014, wiping 'stress' claims.   YOUR ASSEMBLY AND STATE SENATE AND GOV. BROWN VOTED TO LET YOU BE HARRASSED UNFAIRLY UNTIL YOU GET FIRED OR QUIT.  Why injured workers don't actively campaign against everyone in the state senate and assembly is a mystery.

A mortgage secures the obligation of a borrower under a promissory note. If the spouse has no ownership interest in the real property, they cannot give the bank a security interest in the property. The promissory note would be a secured note against one spouse and an unsecured obligation against the other.

There are formulas that take into account many factors. Do you have a liquidated damages clause? You also mentioned pain and suffering and punitive damages.  I would need more details to be able to better answer your question.  I would not leave it to the court to determine the amount of damages your seeking. You must support you actual damages with facts. Here is the basic info. You should look at: Compensatory Damages  The most common type of personal injury damages are compensatory damages. This type of damage is meant to compensate the injured victim and to help make him whole financially. Some major types of compensatory damages include:  Medical Expenses.åÊThis can include the cost of your hospital bills and medical treatment. This can also include costs associated with follow-up visits and any ongoing therapy you receive. This type of damage amount is usually easy to determine as you have medical bills and other receipts. Property Damage.åÊIf you were injured in a car accident, you may have auto repair bills and other estimates for property damage. Similar to medical expenses, this type of damage amount is typically easy to determine. Lost Wages.åÊIf injuries or follow-up treatment cause you to miss time at work, you may be entitled to seek lost wages. Lost wages can include both the money you already lost as well as the wages that you may lose in the future from not working. You will need to calculate how much time you already missed and make a reasonable estimate of how much time you may need to miss in the future. Pain and Suffering.åÊBesides financial harm, you may also experience pain, suffering, and other emotional injuries. This can include emotional distress, psychological harm, and even the loss of enjoyment that you may have from pursuing your hobbies or spending time with your loved ones. As you can imagine, this can be difficult to quantify.  Punitive Damages  Along with compensatory damages, you may also be able to seek additionalåÊpunitive damages. Punitive damages may be awarded when a defendant's conduct is particularly willful, wanton, malicious, vindictive, or oppressive. Punitive damages are awarded not as compensation to the victim, but as punishment to the wrongdoer.

The government is free to add whatever charges they like provided that the probationary period has not expired (and tolling obviously precludes natural expiration).  I have seen this happen, but, because Judge's enjoy wide discretion in VOP sentencing,  it is extremely rare.  The simple fact is that even on the most basic of VOP's the probationer can be sentenced up to the statutory max, so, if the government believes that the Court is going to fire the rockets and launch the probationer into sentencing space (most prosecutors and PO's "know" their Judges and have a pretty good feel for how they sentence) then there's no need to tack on additional VOP counts.    I hope that I have been helpful in answering your question.

You may be eligible for humanitarian reinstatement. You will need to submit a request to the USCIS office that approved the petition. You will also need a substitute sponsor. The substitute sponsor must be (1) aU.S. citizen, national, or lawful permanent resident; (2)  at least 18 years old; and (3)  your spouse, parent, mother-in-law, father-in-law, sibling, child, son, daughter, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law, grandparent, grandchild, or legal guardian.  I encourage you and your family to work with an attorney on the humanitarian reinstatement request.

Well, first off, it sounds like you were constructively evicted from your apartment, due to the uninhabitable conditions.  So, from the moment those problems were found, onward, you can get back rent.  Also, you can sue them for any doctor bills.  You can also sue them for breach of contract, breach of warranty of habitability, and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.  As my colleague mentioned, you can sue them for personal injury, but there are so many more ways to come at them.  Basically, if there was mold in your apartment, and it was bad enough that you got sick, please, put boot to butt to this landlord.  I am guessing this building is very old.  It sounds like it might need to be condemned.  Get an attorney and go after this guy.  Good luck!

You can work while you collect early retirement, but you have to be very careful about it. For any full-year that you are retired after reaching age 62 and before full-retirement age, you can earn up to $15,480 (in 2014, the number changes each year). If you elect retire early mid-year (any time after January), and you have already earned more than the annual limit, you can only receive retirement benefits in any month that your earnings are less than $1290 (again this number changes each year). If you go over $1290 in any month, you are not entitled to retirement benefits in that month. (See retiring mid-year rule: http://www.ssa.gov/retire2/rule.htm).  If your retirement is starting in January of the calendar year (or for any year after your first year of retirement), and you are under full-retirement age, you are permitted to earn up to $15,480 for the full year in 2014. Once you make more than $15,480, $1 is deducted from your benefit for ever $2 you earn. Social Security will ask for an estimate of your earnings for the year (and if you are remaining at the same job and number of hours as before retirement, will use your prior year earnings), and if you are over $15,480, they will withhold the money from benefits payable in the beginning of the year.   So if you plan to make $25,480, you would be $10,000 above the earnings limit for the year, so $5,000 will be withheld from your benefits. Instead of waiting for you to actually earn the money during the year, the first $5,000 of your Social Security retirement benefits would be withheld. If you are entitled to $1,000 per month, this means that you would not receive benefits for the first 5 months of the year, and although you are retired, you would only receive benefits starting in June of the year based on your estimated earnings.   My recommendation is to schedule an appointment with Social Security to discuss retirement with a claims representative. Have your most recent pay stub available, and also have an estimate available of the amount that you plan to make after you retire. Based on this information, a representative should be able to explain how your retirement would be impacted. Once you have that information, if you still have questions, contact a financial planner/estate attorney to decide what makes most sense for you.  Sorry for the long answer, but this is a much more confusing issue that it would initially appear. Once you reach full retirement age (age 66 if you were born in 1947 or 1948), you are able to make up to $41,400 in that calendar year in the months prior to your birthday, and an unlimited amount after your birthday. Again, please remember that these numbers change each year. All the dollar amounts I have provided are for 2014 only.

What is your court order monthly or is it just to enter into negotiations? your original contract governs the terms of your loan until you have another lawfully entitled to different monthly amount. What right do you have to any other amount at this time? The court cannot change the mortgage payments on your residence on a first mortgage that will exist following plan completion. Thus, you don't indicate any right you have to a lower monthly plan payment than the mortgage. Why would your attorney put in an amount also different than the contract payment..I don't understand! Good luck. If two parties cannot agree, absent any right to a different monthly payment, the contract governs.. You cant buy a car and then demand your payments be lowered!

Your number one priority is to try and get your daughter back right away.  You need to figure out a way to obtain funds to go pick her up.  After this, you will need to get an attorney to file a case and get court orders in place regarding parenting time.  It is much better for everyone involved if there is a set parenting schedule so that you are never worrying about whether or not the other parent will follow through with agreements made.  If he is unwilling to give her back, you need to file a case immediately in Colorado, and it would behoove you to use an attorney to do this.  The more time that passes, the less likely it is you will get orders in your favor.
There is no statute regarding drive time for parenting time. If the two of you cannot agree, the judge will make the decision.

I am sorry for your medical troubles. You should know that there are strict deadlines for filing a medical malpractice claim. Gather your medical records and consult a MO personal injury ASAP.  Best of luck,  Doc Shah  Zaheer A. Shah, MD, JD Attorney-at-Law, Physician shahinjurylaw.com

Unless within the last 6 years the friend or her  husband has promised in writing to repay you, your right to sue expired many years ago if this event  happened in WA.  In WA, generally, a lawsuit based on a written agreement must be brought to court within 6 years of the last triggering event. A lawsuit based on an agreement that is not written down must be brought within 3  years. When the time starts and stops running is often a main dispute in a lawsuit.  Moreover, you likely has a statute of frauds problem. That is, in your type of case, the agreement must be written down or the court will dismiss it.  You can review the specific facts with your attorney to see whether you have any legal options.

Since your ex-husband was not party to the case originally, he will need to be served with the lawsuit and given the opportunity to respond to the lawsuit, before any judgment can validly apply. He will have the defense that he was not on the contract, which may mean the landlord cannot get a judgment against him. Thus, the outcome you desire is unlikely to occur, because then the landlord would get nothing for the unpaid rent.  Your brother in law should consult with an experienced debt collection defense attorney to get this resolved and behind him. The judgment presently hangs over his head, making him unable to buy any real estate, refinance a home he may own, and always worried that the collection attorney will levy the funds in his bank account or garnish his wages with this unpaid judgment. The judgment can last for many years, even decades, until satisfied.  By: Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)  CONSUMER LAW OFFICE OF ROBERT STEMPLER  A Professional Law Corporation

Most likely, if you have not ever made payments on either of these in the last 6 years, the Statue of Limitations has expired . You certainly do not want to make any payments now . You may actually have a claim for a violation of the Fair Debt Collections Practices Act, if you received a demand letter threatening to do anything which the collector can not legally do ( such as threatening to sue, if the Statue of Limitations has expired). You should consult with an experienced local attorney practicing consumer debt collection defense before making any sort of payment or resolution. You can also request that the attorney provide verification of the debt , including the dates when incurred and any payment history.  It maybe that they filed a complaint against you and got a judgment , a judgment is good for 8 years and can be renewed. If they already have a judgment  you may benefit from a consultation with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney.

Your fact pattern left out an important fact that may change things.   Did you pay the security deposit and/or first months rent?  If you did not pay the security deposit and have not given the landlord a penny, AND YOUR LEASE also says a security deposit is required, you may not have yet completed the terms of the lease so the lease   might not yet be valid.   So you still might have a way to get "out" if you have not actually gotten "in" to the lease fully.   It truly does depend on all the terms of the lease.   Otherwise it is best to explain the situation as soon as possible to the landlord so they can try to get someone else in there ASAP to mitigate the situation.   Hopefully that helps!

If your family is overseas, then you are correct in not filing form I-485 for them. After the I-130 is approved, the NVC will send you the instructions for the next step in the process. After you have complied with that, then your family will be called in for an interview at the consulate/embassy. You mention that you are overseas too, as I understand. Make sure you have proof that you are domiciled in the U.S. not to create problems. For affidavit of support purposes you must be domiciled in the U.S. Also, watch out for "age out" issues for the child(ren) who are about to turn 21. I would highly recommend that you talk to a competent immigration attorney to safeguard all your and your children's rights.

I take it he was convicted after a trial and not by entering a plea of guilty or no contest.  Mr. Dane is correct about the timing for filing the appeal.  Usually, a judge will inform you of your appellate rights after the sentencing.  Often the lawyer who represented him at trial will offer to file the Notice of Appeal for the client, listing the client as "pro per" as the appeal is not part of a trial retainer.  If he used the Public Defender, they may be appointed to do the appeal.  Remember, there has to be grounds for the appeal, such as an error by the Judge in admitting evidence or improperly instructing the jury.   If he pled to the charge, it is an entirely different process as he will have to file a Motion to Withdraw the plea; again needing some legal grounds, such as ineffective counsel.   Appeals can be expensive as the appellate lawyer has to read the entire transcript to find the errors. It would be helpful to know what the charge was and how long the trial lasted, not including the jury deliberations.

If not then you may get TTD depending on whether the insurance carrier accepts the qme's findings.  You should sit down and talk to an attorney about your options.

Virginia does not have anything called an Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal.  However, Virginia does have the same concept (deferral with terms followed by an eventual dismissal), it is just known by a different name and does not apply in all cases.  This sort of disposition is extremely favorable, as it essentially allows for a dismissal even though the accused is in fact guilty of the alleged offense, and it is the sort of outcome that an experienced Virginia Criminal Defense Attorney can work out in certain cases.  One thing you should know is that in Fairfax County the prosecuting attorneys do not speak with unrepresented people so there is absolutely no opportunity to negotiate the case with a prosecuting attorney unless you hire counsel to represent you.  In a few select types of cases, the Court may offer this type of disposition to folks without counsel, but I strongly recommend having the assistance of counsel to ensure you get the best possible result.    Best of luck to you.

Sounds like you went to a settlement mill to me. There is no way to get policy limits unless the defendant insured agrees or to file suit. I always request an affidavit from an insurance company before accepting their representation of policy limits.

That is a standard provision in many contingency retainer agreements.  Some attorneys will advance the costs for you and then deduct them from any later recovery.  Some attorneys won't advance costs.  It most likely depends on the case and the amount of work involved.  It is impossible to say whether the associate leaving the firm had anything to do with the attorney asking for costs now.   This attorney was willing to take a chance on your case by putting in his time and effort to get some money for you both.  He is asking you to contribute by paying some of the costs.  Not an unusual request.  If you don't like it, you could try and find another attorney to take your case.

You should prepare a lodger agreement with your boyfriend and have him sign it.  The lodger agreement grants him use of the premises as a lodger, and gives you rights to summarily have him removed if the time comes and you need him out of your house.  This way he cannot claim some kind of cohabitation or domestic partnership exists.  This is an Australian version, but its sufficient to do the job quite frankly. A lodger is someone who rents your home while you live in it. A tenant typically has exclusive possession of the premises. See like below:  https://www.uow.edu.au/content/groups/public/@web/@accomm/documents/doc/uow072147.pdf

There is no such time restriction on testing. It would be entirely unworkable. There aren't enough labs in the whole country to test the alleged drug samples pick up in a single state. Even if the substance itself is not admissible. The officer can testify that you told him. In any interaction with the police you should keep two things in mind: (1) police can, do, and allowed to lie to you; and, (2) the only intelligent thing you can say to the police is that you are exercising your rights to silence and counsel. Then, be quiet.   Whether an attorney is competent has nothing to do with whether the attorney is a public defender. There are bad eggs in both camps. If you have the means to hire your own attorney, it's generally a good idea. That way you can vet them and make sure you get one you trust.

Generally employers must show they made a legitimate business decision to discharge the employee. If the employer thought the material was inappropriate for the workplace then that is probably good enough. The stronger argument for you is likely that the employer did not follow its normal disciplinary procedures by discharging you over this single issue.
Under Tennesse law , there is no set period that the police can hold you before making bond. It varies by each county .

You can contest the debt with the credit bureaus. If the debt cannot be verified, it will fall off earlier.  You can wait the full 7 years and it has to drop off at that point.  With respect to settling, two things will happen:  1. The debts you settle for less than what's owed will be reported as paid less than what's owed on your credit report, UNLESS you dispute the debt and make an offer in compromise, and the creditor agrees to report it as discharged through payment.  2. If you settle for less than what's owed, they will issue a 1099C for all amounts over $600 and you may owe taxes on the amounts not collected and paid. Unless its reported as a compromise and discharged through payment.  Many attorneys can negotiate a resolution for you. Click on "Find a Lawyer" above to locate an attorney in your area who handles debtor/creditor relations.

Illinois and most states deny benefits to employees in three situations: 1) if the unemployment is caused by the person going out on strike in a labor union situation (this is not you); 2) where the person voluntarily abandon's their job (except in certain limited circumstances) (again this is not you), and 3) where the employee has engaged in "misconduct." Misconduct means something really bad - like not following a safety rule, and doing something like theft, or embezzlement - something really awful. it sounds like they are going to assert the theft defense against you. So you will have to show that you did not steal anything and that employee theft was not the real reason you were terminated. That you were fired for some other reason - personality conflict, something along those lines.

I am sure that a lot of the contract uses boilerplate terms and provisions already "borrowed" from other contracts, so most of it would not be subject to any sort of copyright.  Those which were specifically drafted to address a unique set of circumstances may arguably be subject to some sort of claim, but my experience is that you will only face a lawsuit if you copy the contract, formatting, logos, conceptual imagery and marketing look wholesale and pass it off as your own--in such circumstances, you are essentially stealing their branding and may cause consumers to confuse you with them.  You should meet with a lawyer and spend a little money to set yourself up and address the legal issues unique to your business where you wish to operate.  Then, you will end up with a contract all your own.

What should you do?  Run, don‰Ûªt walk, to a maritime attorney.  Really!  You cannot afford to wait because there is a short period during which you can limit your liability to the value of your wrecked jon boat, motor, gear, and equipment.  That period started when you first received written notice that the "buddy" had a potential claim against you and that the amount of this claim could exceed the value of your wreckage.  Your question was posted at Green Cove Springs and asks about the St. Johns River.  Green Cove Springs is located on that river about half way between Jacksonville and Palatka.  The St. Johns River and its tributaries are subject to the ebb and flow of the tide all the way to Lake George just upstream of Palatka.  That makes it part of the navigable waters of the United States for Admiralty and Maritime Law purposes.  Even if the accident happened upstream of (south of) Palatka, the river is navigable in fact (thus part of the navigable waters of the United States) at least to Lake Harney where the NOAA/NOS navigation charts stop.  The lawyer letter you received is certainly enough to trigger the start of this period (be very certain to bring to your lawyer‰Ûªs attention anything else you may have gotten in writing from the "buddy" or anyone representing him).  Asking for your insurance information suggests to a reasonable person that the "buddy" is contemplating making a claim against you.  You wrote that your vessel "was totaled" and that the motor sat underwater for two weeks.  You did not mention lifejackets, fire extinguishers, or other gear or equipment (radio, fish finder, trolling motor, etc.).  Nevertheless, it is reasonable to conclude that "soft tissue damage, pain, lost wages, and all kinds of other stuff" will end up amounting to several times the scrap value of the wreckage and the fair market value of the waterlogged remainder.  A maritime attorney will know how to file an action for Limitation of or Exoneration from Liability; it can only be filed in the federal district court, as state courts do not have jurisdiction over limitation actions.  You will either have to surrender the vessel (and its gear, equipment, etc.) to the court, or post a bond equal to the value of the vessel after the allision.  (An allision is like a collision, but it involves striking a fixed object like a dock; a collision occurs when two vessels run into each other.)  The "buddy," your neighbor (if his eye was injured), the dock owner, and everyone else who claims damages from this accident must bring them into this one proceeding or they are forever waived.  The judge, without a jury, will decide whether the accident was caused by negligence or fault.  If not, the case is over and you will not have to pay any damages.  If there was negligence or fault, then the judge will decide if you played some role in that (they call that privity or knowledge).  If not, your liability will be limited to the scrap value of the wreckage and the fair market value of the waterlogged remainder.  You absolutely must retain an attorney who is thoroughly knowledgeable and experienced in Maritime Law, one who can give you specific legal advice based on the particular facts and circumstances of your case. You can find such an attorney through the Florida Bar Association, the Southeastern Admiralty Law Institute, or the Maritime Law Association of the United States at the links below.  You can also use the "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this web page.

Unfortunately, without having all the specific details the answer is: "probably not, but there is a possibility that you might be."  Generally speaking, you are a resident of the state in which you are domiciled, which in plain English means where you have all your stuff and where you go to bed most nights.  However, under some very narrow circumstances it is possible to have two different states each treat you as a resident of that state.  The odds of that are very small, but if you're facing a situation where someone is claiming you're a resident of more than one state, then I would strongly urge you to consult with a competent tax attorney.

This is a 'loaded' question, meaning it is frequently asked, and frequently answered in ways that can cause problems for people.  You are wise to reach out for some (hopefully) better information than you might get from your friends or co-workers, but you would be wiser still to speak personally with an experienced family law attorney in Oregon where you live.    I'm writing a response to you, even though I'm not an Oregon attorney, because of the obvious urgency and because this question is not necessarily something that depends on local law in Oregon, but rather, is handled in similar ways by most family law courts around the country.     First, Family law generally directs that parents are to follow valid custody orders, and that parents are the ones who have the responsibility for minor children, to see that the children's actions are consistent with the order.   If the Custody Order is wrong or mistaken, or out of date, it is the responsibility of the parent who believes it's wrong to return to the court with information and proper documentation to request a change in the order, rather than just ignoring the order.    But sometimes when there are emergencies, there's not a lot of time to go back to court, or because the process can be expensive, folks sometimes fail to do what they're "supposed" to do to change the orders (although now days there are forms online widely available to present requests to the court in the proper way, without an attorney).  What are referred to as "refusal to visit" cases with older kids represent some of the most difficult and contentious cases which family law courts and lawyers have to deal with.   "Why" a kid is refusing to visit is always the question, and the inherent difficulty in trying to make an older teen do something they don't want to do makes these cases especially tough.   If, as you seem to be saying, there are obvious safety issues for the kids, you may have grounds for an immediate Order or relief from the court along the lines of an "Order of Protection" or "Protection from abuse Order" which you should investigate immediately if you fear for your children's safety.  But more generally, if there's no safety problem, but rather, it's just kids who have become so oppositional that they won't visit at all, here's what I have seen in 30+ years of doing these cases.  Judges do not like the idea of giving kids "the right to refuse visits" and will not do that, typically.  They're reasoning is based on the fact that kids don't run the show.  One reason they shouldn't "run the show" is they can be easily manipulated, and putting them in the middle of parental conflict is a terrible idea, so asking or allowing them to "refuse" a visit is universally regarded as a bad idea.  But.  If a child is genuinely in danger, what should you as a parent do?   Certainly it is unlikely that any law enforcement agency is going to get involved, and no law enforcement agency that I've ever talked to is EVER going to take a child from one parent and forcibly give them to the other parent, without a SPECIFIC court order for that to occur (which does not exist in your situation).  Also, a parent who is legitimately seeking to protect a child from harm will normally  be able to avoid prosecution for the variety of statutes which exist in many states for what is called "custodial interference."   Plus, even if the dangerous parent is intent on getting law enforcement involved, the most that would be reasonably expected would be for them to cite or charge the parent who is allegedly not complying with the visitation.   And if that parent (you) can show they are protecting the children from harm by not sending them to visitation, as I say above, most prosecutors are not going to pursue that.    So, I realize this is a longer answer than what you may have expected, but I will close with a repeated request that you seek out and speak to an experienced family law attorney regarding this matter.

If your case is still alive after the MSJ, at trial you have to again lay the foundation for the evidence that you are trying to use to prove or defend your case.  Only admissible evidence may be used at trial.  Having said that, if a party does not properly assert objections, said objections are waived.    The documents will be part of your Exhibit List at trial (unless used for impeachment), and you will use your witnesses, stipulations, discovery, etc. to lay proper foundation for the documents.    You should really consider consulting with an attorney, if not retaining one, as the simplest mistake may be fatal to your case at the MSJ or Trial stage.

For any criminal prosecution to take place, a law enforcement agency needs to file charges against some or all of the individuals you are having an issue with. If the prosecution is approved either a summons or a warrant is issued to bring the individuals to court to answer to the charges. You, personally cannot get anyone "jail time."  That is a function of the criminal process involving the government. Other than reporting your issue to the police, you can possibly pursue a civil action against these individuals and ask for an injunction prohibiting further slanderous behavior etc. However,  these are not easy cases to pursue. This is going to depend on the specific terms of the lease, although generally a landlord is required to mitigate his or her damages from your breaking of the lease, by re-letting the premises.  This would suggest that your "re-let" fee will be charged where the landlord rents to someone else on equally or more favorable terms, but that you would not be charged for rent.  This is fairly typical.  However, if the landlord can't re-lease for the same or better terms, or it takes a while, you would generally be liable for the rent until such time as it is rented, or the end of your lease, whichever comes first - as well as the re-let fee.  But you might want to schedule a short consultation with a lawyer who can look at the document.

I disagree, to some extent, with the answers from some of my colleagues.  You ARE correct in that under the existing regulations, an individual whose case has been deferred is eligible to receive employment authorization for the period of deferred action IF he or she can demonstrate "an economic necessity for employment."  Having said that, the question is "do you have an economic need to be able to LEGALLY work in the United States?"    So far, these determinations appear to be made liberally, however, they are reviewed on a case by case basis, and there is never a guaranty.  Similarly, there are no statistics available on these types of adjudications.  As a result, there is no way to answer your question with specificity.  I always provide some documentary evidence with the work permit petitions (at least a written statement when there is no other documents - ex. a high school student supported by his parents).

Generally, an appraisal is exactly what the courts look to for a fair market value or a reasonable value.  If an independent and impartial appraisal is done, then that is the price at which a reasonable person would be willing to pay for the home, and that is what the Executrix can sell the home for.  Your personal feelings as to the value, whether sentimental or otherwise, have no impact on the value.  The value NOW in its current condition, not its potential value if fixed up would control.  If the appraisal seems too ridiculous, you may ask the Executrix for another appraisal to be done by someone of your choosing,, probably at your own cost.   If the appraisals differ greatly, then you may have a reason to ask the Executrix for a different valuation or notify the probate court.  The Executrix, if granted the power to sell the property, is adhering to her fiduciary duty to seek the best possible value by getting the appraisal.  There also seems to be some additional information required that you should share with an attorney in your area.

A power of attorney does not have anything really to do with a lawyer - a power of attorney is a document where a person (the principal) names an agent (sometimes called attorney-in-fact, agent, surrogate) to act for them (stand in their shoes) in certain situations.  For example, I could nominate my wife as my agent to sign a deed if we were selling our house and I was travelling.  Or I could nominate my father to be my agent to handle my financial affair if I become incapacitated and cannot do those things for myself.

This really is not a legal question, but a question for your accountant or financial adviser. The deadline for making contributions to a SEP is the due date for the filing of that years federal taxes. Contribution limits depend on whether the contribution is for the employees or the employer. For employees, an employer cannot exceed the lessor of 5% of the employee's compensation, or $51,000 (for 2013, $52,000 for 2014).. For the employer, there are formulas one must follow.   For more information, you may want to refer to http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Choosing-a-Retirement-Plan:-SEP.

Well. We tried to answer this for you before. Lets try again. You have two potential problems to deal with. First is the unlawful presence. If you have more 365 days of that and leave the country, you would be barred from reentering the USA for ten years, Canadian or not. Second, is the status violation. That gives the US government the reason to deny your entry even if you are not barred. Since you stayed and overstayed while on D/S status and assuming there was no formal finding of the status end by either USCIS or Immigration Judge, you should not have unlawful presence. Hence, the other problem is the more prominent for you.

If your doctor disagrees with the claim manager's determination, he or she needs to respond with their opinion. Regarding the percentage of PPD, that will all depend on the rating examination by your doctor. He or she will give you a rating in percentage and based on that and your date of injury, it will be assigned a dollar amount by a formula. This amount changes from year to year. However, if you still need treatment, claim closure is not the way to go. I suggest you speak with an L&I attorney about your case to discuss your options. Also, if the Department has determined that you are able to work and your doctor disagrees, he or she needs to clearly state this in response. You will likely have a closing order on your doorstep soon which only has a 60 day appeal period. I'd start getting your ducks in a row now and talk to a lawyer. Good luck to you.

Actually, it was a relatively long nine year period of time, from 1997 until 2006, when there were no time limitations on prior offenses to constitute a felony DUI. From 1980 until 1997, there was a "five-year look-back" provision in the state‰Ûªs DUI law. When Act 97-556 was enacted to add a $100 additional assessment to all DUI convictions to fund the state‰Ûªs Impaired Driver Trust Fund, the words "within a five year period" were deleted from sub-sections dealing with third and fourth offenses. Shortly thereafter, third and fourth offense DUI arrests were prosecuted without reference to the time the previous DUI conviction had been entered. See, e.g., Ex parte Boyd, 796 So. 2d 1092 (Ala. 2001): No time limitation applied to prior DUI offenses for third and subsequent DUI arrests.   In 2006, the Alabama legislature re-wrote the Alabama DUI statute to reverse the Supreme Court‰Ûªs decision in Ex parte Bertram and added the new sub-section (o) that stated: "A prior conviction within a five-year period for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs from this state, a municipality within this state, or another state or territory or a municipality of another state or territory shall be considered by a court for imposing a sentence pursuant to this section."   Is there anything you can do about your felony record?  Possibly yes. You may be eligible, under certain conditions, to file a Rule 32 petition pursuant to Rule 32, Alabama Rules of Criminal Procedure, to attach the validity of your prior convictions. In the leading case of Ex Parte Bertram, 884 So. 2d 889 (Ala. 2003), the Alabama Supreme Court construed the term "conviction" as used in Code section 32-5A-191 to mean only convictions entered by a court within the state of Alabama, and specifically held that out-of-state DUI convictions could not be used for purposes of enhancement of sentence under Alabama‰Ûªs DUI statute then in effect. This line of reasoning was later applied to municipal court convictions. See, as example, Holbert v. State, 4 So. 3d 410 (Ala. 2008):  Holbert was part of the continuing litigation that originated from the Ex parte Bertram decision from the Alabama Supreme Court in 2003.  In Holbert, the defendant had four (4) prior DUI convictions - two of which occurred in a municipal court and two had been entered in a state district court. Holbert was subsequently indicted for felony DUI after his latest DUI arrest. Holbert then moved to dismiss the indictment for felony DUI based on the fact that two of the four underlying convictions were violations of a municipal ordinance and not violations of 32-5A-191. Applying the Supreme Court‰Ûªs legal analysis expressed in Ex parte Bertram, Holbert argued his prior offenses in the municipal court were not violations of "this section" as required by 32-5A-191 (h). Consequently, the felony in Holbert could not have reached the fourth offense requirement unless all three previous DUI convictions were entered in a state district court; municipal court convictions cannot, as a matter of law prior to the 2006 amendment, constitute prior convictions under 32-5A-191.   Your best course of action is to consult an attorney that is thoroughly familiar with Alabama DUI law and practice as well as post-conviction remedies.

Welcome to the world of estate litigation.  If your father is competent and under no undue influence, he is free to give his assets to any child.  If he is not competent, or is under undue influence, then you have to decide if you are going to act or not.  It would be advisable for you to retain an attorney who is experienced in the Orphans' Court to advise you, as if you decide to act it will have costs.  This attorney can assess the situation with you and there are several options.  You could file a petition to have your father declared legally incapacitated and have yourself named as his guardian.  You could work with the state dept. of aging if you feel he is being abused.  There are other options, but you need to give your lawyer all the facts.  This will be unpleasant, and expensive. Also, if your father is not incompetent, he may be upset that you are saying that he is.  Get a lawyer who works in this area to help you.

I don't see a provocation defense here, but the other owner could attempt to assert it.

DO NOT PAY THE CIVIL DEMAND!  It has nothing to do with court.  This is most likely a violation of municipal ordinance and even if there is a court date, your "child" (how old is he?) will not go to jail. You need to consult with an attorney in the other state for more definite information.  There is law in most states, including the state of Illinois, which allows for civil action collection when there is a retail theft. Most people choose to ignore the demand. This demand is for money over and above any fine you pay in compliance with a court order. People may get a few more letters, each time asking for more, and then they stop. While the retailer can sue you, it is extremely rare for anyone to actually be sued. You do not owe any money unless you are sued and the retailer wins. This is a common ploy. Do not pay. If you do, you will be in the national retailers database which could affect your ability to get a job and could impact your life in other ways. If you are uncomfortable, hire a lawyer and have the lawyer write a cease and desist letter. That should be the end of it.   Here is a good article: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB120347031996578719.html   The National Retail Theft Database is actually a voluntary list put together by different individual retailers. Further, any member that published the information on the list, can thereafter, remove it. Therefore, if you wish to have the entry removed, as you apparently do, your best bet would be to write a letter to the manager of the particular store and inquire as to what it would take for them to remove the entry.  Please go to this link: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/should-i-pay-the-civil-demand-letter

If your landlord filed for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy without the inclusion of any non-exempt assets, that debt is likely discharged which means that you would not be able to pursue your security deposit claim against him. If your landlord filed for Chapter 13 or 11 bankruptcy petition, you may still not be able to pursue the claim depending on what income/assets he has and/or what plan he has for repaying his creditors.   For a more complete and comprehensive answer, you need to consult with a bankruptcy attorney who can gather all the facts and give you a targeted response based upon the type of bankruptcy your landlord filed.

I don't think you appeal DHR decisions to EEOC.  Rather, you appeal to state court.  DHR is a state agency.  EEOC is a federal agency.  You appeal from state agency to state court (as of right), and from federal agency to federal court (as required by law).  I believe there are sixty days from the no probable cause determination to appeal to state court.

In Wisconsin the Probate Court keeps on top of the progress of the case. However, it is not unusual for a probate to go over a year. Often the sale of the decedent's house is the critical factor. Also, tax returns must be filed and a closing letter received from the Wisconsin Department of Revenue. You can also go online to the Wisconsin courts system using CCAP to find out the progress of the case. With an attorney involved in the case you should be OK, in spite of the Personal Representative's (we no longer use the term "executor" in Wisconsin) poor communication.

It's complicated.  You would first need to establish residency in Indiana before you could apply for a driver's license, here.  If memory serves me correctly, that means that you need to have a stable address in Indiana for at least 6 consecutive months.  After that, Indiana will check your interstate driving record for any holds or suspensions.  Indiana will NOT issue you a driver's license while your license is subject to a suspension in another state.  Additionally, Indiana's hardship license statute would not help you, since they will only issue a hardship license to a person who has had a valid Indiana driver's license in the past.  You may not be able to get any type of driving privileges in Indiana until your suspension in Virginia expires.

It's almost impossible to answer this question with the information provided.  First off, if he was sentenced as a youthful offender, the most he could do would be 4 years in prison, followed by 2 years probation or community control.  Additionally, youthful offenders are not subject to the 85% rule.  The Department of Corrections, whether youthful offender or not, determines any gain time and the out date for any inmate.  Youthful offenders can get out in as little as a year on a four year sentence in some cases.  Youthful offenders are treated specially.  Judges do not determine the length of stay in prison and, except in a few circumstances, cannot shorten it or lengthen it.  Wait till your boyfriend gets to prison and they will classify him.  At that time they will tell him his expected release date.  Attorneys are warned constantly to not tell their clients when they will get out, because they are almost always wrong.

I would certainly consult with an experienced family law attorney about this situation.  Best of luck.

The answer is:  it depends.  Alimony is subjective and totally dependent on the facts of each specific case.  Sometimes alimony is awarded on a  temporary basis -- to allow support to be made pending a suit for divorce -- and then sometimes it is also awarded beyond the trial.  In awarding what's called "merits" alimony, the court considers certain factors including: 1.  the ability of the parties seeking alimony to be wholly or partly self-supporting; 2.  the time necessary for the party seeking alimony to gain sufficient education or training to enable that party to find suitable employment; 3.  the standard of living that the parties established during their marriage; 4.  the duration of the marriage; 5.  the contributions, monetary and nonmonetary, of each of the party to the well-being of the family; 6.  the circumstances that contributed to the estrangement of the parties; 7.  the age of each party; 8.  the physical and mental condition of each party; 9.  the ability of the party from whom alimony is sought to meet that party's needs while meeting the needs of the party seeking alimony; 10.  any agreement between the parties; 11.  the financial needs and financial resources of each party, including: 12.,  all income and assets, including all property that does not produce income; any monetary award concerning property and award of possession and use of the family property 13.  the nature and amount of the financial obligations of each party; and 14.  the right of each party to receive retirement benefits  All these factors will be taken into consideration by a court in determining whether to award alimony.  You should consult a family law attorney for a thorough review of the specific facts of your case.

All that being said, the other advice is correct:  the executor of someone's will cannot change the terms of the will once it's effective.  If she tries to pressure your parents to sign a new will, you may consider contesting the will's validity.  Good luck!

Your post has several subparts. Assuming that was a written rental agreement, any violation of that written agreement, like not paying rent, is subject to a four-year statute of limitations. It would appear then that your former landlord still has about a year and a half before they must file suit. Many rental agreements require the tenant to provide a 60 day notice. The statute only requires a 30 day notice. There is no good case law on whether the 30 day  or 60 day notice Would be operative. The real issue here is the apparent failure of your former landlord to properly account to you for your security deposit, something which must be done within 21 days of the surrender of the apartment. That failure has given you the right to sue them for its return. This is all complicated by the fact you are now out of California, and the value of your suit and/or The value of their suit is not great enough to involve most attorneys. The proper court for this to take place, assuming this happened in Ontario, would be to San Bernardino County Superior Court located in downtown San Bernardino.

False allegations against the other parent and emails showing proof of withholding the child are both strong indications that parental alienation is occurring.   It has to stop now.  It's probably best if you take a co-parenting class and complete it before the next court hearing.  You should also communicate in a business like manner at all times - especially emails and text messages as they are evidence.  The Court will give the child to the person who will be more likely to promote frequent and continuing contact with the other parent.  A strict custody sharing schedule is usually best in situations that are heated with exchanges occurring at a child care (am Mom drops off; pm Dad picks up) or at a 3rd party's home or place of business, or a police department.   Although you want full custody, you may have to settle for sharing custody.  It doesn't sound like your ex is bad enough to warrant losing custody and you stand a good chance of losing custody if you continue to alienate Dad.  Sorry, but all studies show children do best when they are able to have quality time with both parents (absent dangerous situations).

If you are asking whether you would be entitled to a divorce, in Ohio, the court of common pleas may grant divorces for the following causes:  (A) Either party had a husband or wife living at the time of the marriage from which the divorce is sought;  (B) Willful absence of the adverse party for one year;  (C) Adultery;  (D) Extreme cruelty;  (E) Fraudulent contract;  (F) Any gross neglect of duty;  (G) Habitual drunkenness;  (H) Imprisonment of the adverse party in a state or federal correctional institution at the time of filing the complaint;  (I) Procurement of a divorce outside this state, by a husband or wife, by virtue of which the party who procured it is released from the obligations of the marriage, while those obligations remain binding upon the other party;  (J) On the application of either party, when husband and wife have, without interruption for one year, lived separate and apart without cohabitation;  (K) Incompatibility, unless denied by either party.

If you have been performing the same job, with the same responsibilities, the same hours and same pay, your income from working is averaged over the months that you work in the calendar year (http://www.socialsecurity.gov/OP_Home/cfr20/404/404-1574a.htm). This is because Social Security realizes that your some jobs, like your, will result in 3 pays for 2 months out of the year. So if the only reason you go over in one month is because of the extra pay, and not because of a change in hours, pay, or position, then your earnings are supposed to be averaged.  Now the important thing to remember is that the $1070 Substantial Gainful Activity Earnings limit does not go into effect until after you have used your trial work period. A trial work period is provided before Social Security looks to see if you have made Substantial Gainful Activity.   In 2014, you use one trial work month whenever you earn $770 or more from working. You have 9 trial work months in a 5 year period of time. If you have not yet used your trial work period, then you do not have to worry about Substantial Gainful Activity. If you still have trial work months left, it doesn't matter if you make $775 in a month, or $2000, you get to keep your Social Security benefit, and you have just used one trial work month. If you have already used all nine of trial work months, that is when you have to worry about Substantial Gainful Activity, which in 2014 is the $1070 per month you mentioned.  I would caution you, that even if you fit into the criteria to have your income averaged, you must still be careful. Social Security does not always properly apply its own regulations. You may be required to prove that your income should be averaged. You would do this by providing copies of all your pay stubs. Your pay stubs should show that you are working the same number of hours (or substantially the same) every pay period, your pay has not changed, and should demonstrate that there is no reason not to average.  I would recommend that to be careful, schedule an appointment with the Social Security Administration now, take in all your pay stubs for this year, and indicate that you are concerned you may have made too much money, but need to know if your income will be averaged. This should at least create a record that you have notified the Social Security Administration of the potential issue.

A Workers' Compensation "pretrial" can be many things, and really depends upon the arbitrator and the attorneys as to how it is conducted.  They can be terribly informal--nothing more than asking the lawyers their sides of the case in about 30 seconds each (if that) and trying to evaluate the value of a case or determine how the arbitrator likely would rule on an issue.  Sometimes they involve the injured workers being present.  The most important thing to remember is that a pretrial is not a determination. NOTHING HAPPENS AT A PRETRIAL UNLESS THE PARTIES AND THEIR ATTORNEYS AGREE TO IT.  A judge/arbitrator might suggest that he/she would rule against you or for you at a pretrial.  Let's say the arbitrator thinks, based upon the brief recital of possible evidence, that he will likely find your case should not be denied.  That may spur the Respondent employer to begin paying you benefits.  Then again, it might mean the employer tells you or your attorney to take a hike.  If that happens, you'll likely have to go to trial to try to prove your case.  If you have a lawyer, I suggest you contact them to discuss what might occur at a pretrial and why the case is being denied, as well as the likelihood of winning.

One thing is clear. YOU DON'T understand what you think you understand.  While there might be a gray are factually, the legal principles are not really all that gray. Under 17 USC 101 a work based on a copyrighted work is a "derivative" work and under 17 USC 106, the copyright owner has the exclusive right to make derivative works, and violation of that exclusive right is copyright infringement under 17 USC 501 for which there can be serious damages.  And, under trademark law, if your "silhouette of fan-made art" is likely to be confused as to source with the brand owner, you are probably committing trademark infringement under 15 USC 1114 and unfair competition under 15 USC 1125. That is you are likely breaking federal law.  You are also likely violating a number of state laws. In fact, there are also criminal laws that can come into play in many cases.  You will only get that small business about an inch off the ground with this infringement stunt unless you work closely with an IP attorney. Consider it for what it is, a necessary cost of doing business when attempting to make products that rely on the IP of other people for their appeal.

Use the same forms as any Request for Order.  But naming ALL the forms you will need ,and where to find them, and explaining how to fill them out is beyond the scope of an AVVO short answer.   Call the other side a FULL 24 hours in advance and advise them when, where, and what time the hearing.  You cannot make the phone call, it must be a 3rd party.  If the other side is represented call his/her attorney not the party. Call the court clerk for the hours the court is currently hearing expartes.  After the call, the 3rd party must write a declaration about the notice they gave.  In the declaration on page three of the RFO you must state (1) what it is you are asking for, (2) good reason for asking it, AND (3) why it must be heard on an emergency basis - why it cannot be heard with a standard 3 weeks notice to the other side.  Show up at the courthouse on the hearing and see the clerk just past the xray machine who will tell you where to go next.   Have 3 extra copies of your forms with you for the clerk.  You should seek an experienced local family law attorney.  Thomas Neil is a Sacramento attorney, with 20 years experience, representing clients in Sacramento, the Bay Area, and surrounding counties.  Or, if you cannot afford full representation then Mr. Neil can instead write you the forms and declaration you need, help you serve them, and tell you what to say and you can go to court by yourself. A well written declaration by an attorney, supported by proper evidence, will GREATLY increase your chances of success in court.  Our office takes credit cards.  Thomas A Neil 3224 El Camino Avenue Sacramento, CA 95821 (916) 446-4153

Unless your motion is a total dud (in which case you wouldn't have brought in the first place), I would NEVER waive oral argument, especially on a motion that I took the time and expense to prepare and file.  Just because the tentative is against you doesn't mean you'll lose.  There are many reasons for a tentative to go against you.  Perhaps the person who worked up the motion missed an important case cited, or misunderstood an important point of law and/or fact.  Or one of the papers you filed never found its way to the judge.  Those things happen all the time.  Many times I have arrived in court for a hearing to find a tentative ruling against me, that I was able to reverse through oral argument.  Judges today are overworked, with large caseloads and light staff.  Go into oral argument and, at minimum, press the main points of your motion.  That alone may cause the judge to see the matter differently.  It may also invite discussion into the finer points of your motion that might have been missed during the court's preparation for the hearing.  If nothing else, it will give you an opportunity for some face time with the judge, as well as an opportunity to 'tell your story' and remind your judge what your case is all about.  That's very valuable in the big picture.  No matter what the final outcome will be at the hearing, I believe you absolutely should appear and argue your motion.  Let's face it, the tentative is against you so have nothing to lose and everything to gain by appearing.

We do have the right to travel.  Like most rights it is not an absolute right.  States may put reasonable restrictions on this right.  Requiring a license has consistently and repeatedly been ruled to not be a violation of the right to travel.  There is a lot of information on the Internet on how to argue the unconstitutionality of the State's requiring a license.  They usually contain lots if case quotes.  The problem is these arguments usually take quotes out of context or come from cases that are not relevant. More importantly, as far as I know none of these arguments have been presented successfully.  I'm not saying that there's not a good argument against the constitutionality of required drivers licensing.  I'm just saying that I've seen many angles argued but no winners.

You can invest, create a company, own real estate, and many other things, all as long as you don't actually work and derive an income, other than through your H1B job. A debt owed to a governmental unit like a traffic fine is NOT discharged in a ch 7 but IS in a ch 13. You need to sit down with an experienced bankruptcy attorney or discuss on the phone. Most , like us, do NOT charge to talk to you . Some, like us, are open early and evenings also. Compelling one to support a religious enterprise, or to attend its services, when one does not share the tenets and teachings of that religion, is tyrannical.  It attacks an essential aspect of human liberty protected against infringement by the government by the Establishment Clause and the Free Exercise Clause of the Constitution.  The insistence on attending services, coupled with the dire consequence of confinement in the hole, is the essence of coercion.  And coercion is at the heart of most clear and direct violations of the Constitution.  I think that pursuing an action against County and those officers responsible is something to consider.  At the same time, I would not forget that the enterprise of suing others can be expensive, difficult, and not always rewarding.  In the case of these kinds of violations, however, there are federal statutes, the Civil Rights Act and the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act, that make it possible, if you prevail, to recover the costs of the suit.  I would recommend contacting the ACLU in Ohio or the Rutherford Institute.  I've included links for both below.  Both work on issues related to religious freedom, and, of course, the ACLU maintains a program regarding prisoners' rights.

What you have described constitutes the charging of excess time price differential (what laymen would refer to as interest) What you would be able to recover depends upon how much the actual interest rate charged turns out to be.  The extra $3,000 is interest.    If the amount of interest charged is less than twice the legal rate, but more than is allowed, you may recover two times the amount of excess interest plus attorney's fees.  If the amount charged is more than double the lawful rate, you may recover three times the excess amount charged, plus the principal balance, plus attorney's fees.  In order to determine which applies it will be necessary to review the documentation associated with the purchase of your car.  You can send me the documents if you will like an opinion on this issue.

If you were rear ended it is not going to be an argument about who is at fault.  The argument is going to be about the amount of damages.  Insurance companies have a deliberate and carefully orchestrated plan to minimize how much they will pay out and it starts with the adjuster for the other car calling you and saying she or he is so sorry to hear about your injuries and they will take care of you - all you need to do is give them a statement and sign some documents so they can view your medical records.  This is a trap designed to carefully document your post accident progress in a way that most favors the insurance company (for the other driver).  Their goal is to pay you as little as possible.  They play on your emotions so you think they are being helpful and you will cooperate with whatever they ask for.  Every case they can lowball means more profits for them and means they can throw up statistics at attorneys like myself to tell us our future cases aren't worth anything.  In the early 1980's I used to get offers of $10,000 pretty regularly to settle soft tissue injury cases like yours.  Now 30 years later I am lucky if I can offers of more than $1,500 to $3,000 and the insurance company will battle like crazy to avoid paying a dime more.  We PI lawyers fight vigorously to stop the trend of low ball offers and are willing to take cases up on appeal when necessary to protect the legal rights of consumers like yourself.  We fight for new laws that protect your rights by hiring lobbyists and going head to head with the well paid insurance lobbies every legislative session.  So by hiring a PI lawyer, preferably on that is a member of the Oregon Trial Lawyers Association (just ask) you will not only get a better settlement then you would on your own, even after paying a percentage as attorney fees, you will also stand up for your rights and the rights of other accident victims to get a fair and full settlement.  Understand that you have PIP coverage under your own insurance policy.  This is a no-fault additional to your policy so what the other insurance company does or thinks doesn‰Ûªt effect your right to this coverage nor will using it effect your insurance rates. This will pay for your medical treatment up to $15,000 and up to a year of treatment.  If you need to take time off of work, you may qualify for the lost wages that PIP will pay which is additional.   Your PI lawyer will see to it that you take full advantage of your PIP coverage, so you can get the treatment you need and your lost wages while you recover.  You should not even consider settling your case until your injuries resolve.  You have up to two years before a case would needs to be filed in the court so this is usually enough time to allow your recovery period before trying to settle.  As for car damages, if you have full coverage you can address the car repair or replacement by using your full coverage.  If you have a deductible you may need to pay it but it will be reimbursed later on.  If you don't have full coverage, a fairly new law (lobbied for by OTLA), now requires that the other driver's insurance company make you a fair offer immediately for the amount of your repairs or the replacement value of your car.  Your PI attorney can help you facilitate this.  Just don't be deceived that the other insurance companies willingness to settle your car damages is due to anything other then the fact that they are now obligated to do this under Oregon Law.  It is not a sign that your case will be settled easily without legal representation.  In fact, if they try to total your car they still play all sorts of games trying to argue that your car isn't worth much. Your PI lawyer should be able to help you establish the fair market value of your car if it is totaled.

I have had several issues with cars being in accidents that were not initially reported or never reported on car history reports like carfax and autocheck.  I would advise you to get the reports from both of them and then to call the companies about the issue.  If you relied on a carfax report at the time of your purchase, you may qualify for a payment or repurchase of the car under the carfax buyback guarantee.  You could also have a claim against the dealership if the dealership gave you the carfax.  Some dealerships buy cars knowing that they have damage, fix the damage in house without reporting it, and knowingly misrepresent the vehicle's history using an inaccurate report when they try to sell it.  Other times the dealership doesn't know of the damage, but still may be legally responsible if you relied on statements they made about the vehicle's history when you purchased it and those statements turned out not to be true.

We would need a few more facts to be able to provide more detailed guidance.   The items you listed are: 1. Your dad's burial plot. This is an excluded item per section 440.5 of the Medicaid Long Term Care  Handbook. So it is okay to purchase a plot.  2. Add more money to the prepaid funeral. If the amount in the prepaid funeral is more than 125% of the local average cost of a funeral you may run into some problems. Ask the local County Assistance Office what their limit is on pre-paid funeral allowances. For example, Montgomery County is $15,000.00 and Lehigh is $12,500.00 so it changes based on each county. Try to make sure the prepaid funeral stays within the county limits as the CAO will review it.  3. Mother's headstone. Technically no, you can not use it for your mother's headstone. While this may seem harsh under Medicaid rules, it is important to understand that the CAO will look at what he spent the money on. If your parents will be buried together after your father passes and he happens to get a stone to mark his grave, that would be perfectly acceptable. The intent is what counts. If you intend it for your father and it is for him, then it is okay. If you happen to later on add otehr inscriptions to the stone that is your choice, but the initial purchase must clearly be for the benefit of your father. Beware - if you covered his stone or costs in the prepaid funeral you can not go ahead and pay again a second time. The CAO checks for these things.   I know that answer on the marker is not necessarily what you want to hear, but it is important to understand you do not want to take any action that causes eligibility issues for your father. If the stone is not that costly it would not likely cause and long term problems, but you have to understand that the paperwork involved in the determination could be endless and cause more stress to your family that simply finding a different way around it.   Sorry to bring this type of news to the discussion.   I hope this answer helps.

This is a good question. If you were charged with a felony, you are exposed to a sentence of imprisonment of over one year. If you're charged with a misdemeanor or several misdemeanors, you are subject to a sentence of up to one year in the local county jail, per charge or count.  The judge is legally empowered to give you consecutive prison terms if your cases are felonies, or consecutive jail terms if your cases involved misdemeanors.   Consecutive means one year followed by another year. Thus, if you are convicted of five first-degree misdemeanors, you can conceivably serve five years consecutively in the local county jail, and never go off the state prison. Further, this does not make you a felon nor do you lose your civil rights as would a convicted felon.  Florida statutes define what crimes are classified as felonies and what crimes are misdemeanors. Just because you serve five or ten years consecutively on multiple misdemeanors, does not make yours a felony conviction.

Just because the debt has been charged off and the SOL has run doesn't mean that you do not owe this debt anymore. This common misconception happens all the time. You can attempt to settle the debt so that it is reported as satisfied on your credit report instead of outstanding. You can wait until the debt eventually drops off of the report since you do not have to worry about a lawsuit if the debt is really past the SOL. Or you can attempt to dispute the accounts listed on your credit report with the respective credit bureaus if you feel that they are being improperly reported. The bureaus may even remove some of these accounts.
