With a trial date of August 25, your discovery cut-off (e.g., your discovery completion date) is 30 days before the trial date, or July 26.  Discovery is deemed "complete" when both the requests AND their responses have been served within statutory time limits.  Assuming from your facts that the document demand was served by mail on June 25, you would have a total of 35 days from the date the demand was served to respond (30 days plus five additional days for service by mail) which means your deadline to respond is July 30, four days AFTER the discovery completion deadline.  The inspection demand is untimely because it cannot be completed (e.g. served and responded to) on or before the July 26 discovery completion deadline.  Therefore you need not respond.  Out of an abundance of caution, however, you may wish to serve a general objection to the demand as untimely.  Best of luck to you.

Trademark rights arise from use in commerce, not registration.  A trademark is enforceable even if it is not registered.  Thus, if you found someone else using the trademark o n Etsy, and if you would be competing with this company or person in the same industry, geographic area, and/or for the same customers, you could be liable for trademark infringement because your use would create consumer confusion.   You are the junior user even if this other company did not  yet apply for trademark protection.  Thus, your best bet if you want to avoid a law suit is to find another brand name.  Of course, you can try to register the name and use it---and you might get away with it.  But the risk is very high----unless you have a large war chest for litigation, it is not a risk you should take.

Tricky situation.  Oregon and Washington have entered into a reciprocal agreement whereby the state in which a person is HIRED TO WORK has jurisdiction.  Although the intent was to simplify things, it really doesn't.  If your sister's husband was hired in Oregon to work in Oregon and other states, he probably is an Oregon worker.  Though I usually don't advise this, it might be prudent to file in both states.  Also, heart attack claims are extremely difficult to prove.  Just because he was at work doesn't automatically establish that his work was a cause of the heart attack.  You should have your sister consult with competent Washington AND Oregon attorneys to sort out the situation.  Don't delay as Oregon has a fairly short time to file a claim.  I'm sorry for your sister's loss and she is fortunate to have you helping her.

As other attorneys have correctly noted in this forum, federal firearms laws (18 U.S.C 922(g)) bar almost all convicted felons from possessing firearms, and because it is a federal statute, the ban applies in all states. Most states also have their own laws concerning felons in possession of firearms, so unfortunately, a person could face problems if confronted by either state or federal law enforcement. In some cases, even a restoration of rights or certificate of rehabilitation under a state's laws may not remove the federal ban. Of course, general information in a public forum is no substitute for advice of counsel, so a citizen with questions about the impacts of a prior conviction if best advised to review the case and applicable laws with a local lawyer for specific answers.

A drug dog alert provides probable cause for a longer detention than normally would have been allowable.  However, once the dog alerts, there are two choices - detain you and your vehicle while a warrant for search is obtained from a judge, or just go ahead and perform the search knowing that if anything is found it may be suppressed because there was no warrant.  Some cops are such cowboys that they cannot wait even for a judge to sanction what they intend to do and blunder ahead.  Suppression, if something is found, is the imperfect method for teaching cops like that to not be cowboys, that citizens have rights they cannot infringe.  In cases where the cowboys come up empty, the citizen is left without recourse unless they take action on principle.  I would certainly see a local civil rights attorney who can examine all the facts involved here - such situations are so exactingly fact specific that to say anything without all the facts would be foolhardy, and who can research the latest case law on vehicle searches under these or similar circumstances.  At the very least you may be entitled to have your vehicle repaired and maybe you can help teach the police to think twice before going ahead without the sanction of a warrant.  As a side note - consider that they had sought a warrant.  It would have likely been granted and the search proceeded.  In such a case their action would have been insulated by judicial immunity and you probably would have been out of luck.   See an attorney, get a repair estimate for your truck, and good luck.

At common law, if a lawyer's services are involuntarily terminated, he or she could file a charging lien.  If the lawyer withdrew from the case, then the lawyer may or may not be entitled to reasonable value of services rendered.  The lien is not an order or judgment. So no due process is involved until the court hears the lien and then decides whether the lawyer is entitled to the lien, and if so, the amount. So there is a legal issue and a factual issue, both of which are decided at a later time.  Consider the lien a motion or petition to the court. All that is required is service of it on you, and at some point a notice of hearing on it.

When a person dies, their estates may be handled under a Will through the probate process; under a trust in accordance with the death distribution provisions of the trust, or, where there are both probate and trust assets, by both methods. In the probate area, there can be litigation over a multitude of matters: Will contests, issues about who can be PR, whether all the property has been inventoried, whether the PR is doing the right thing, whether an accounting is accurate, etc. Some attorneys will handle minor litigation issues in the Orphans' Court, but would not consider a Will contest jury trial in the Circuit Court, much less an appeal to one of our appellate courts. If an attorney indicates "contested wills" I would expect that attorney to be willing and able to handle a Circuit Court jury trial. But, that's not necessarily true because Martindale allows us to pick the categories. The solution is for you to ask the lawyer. A contested trust issue goes to the Circuit Court. So, I expect that an attorney who lists that, would have no hesitation to do either a contested probate (Will) or trust matter. I think "contested wills" would in most instances be a subset of "conested trusts and estates" as would "probate litigation" I expect some attorneys would consider "contested wills" to be a subset of "probate litigation" and some would consider it wholly different. Many "litigation" attorneys handle probate and trust litigation but you'll find that very few concentrate (we MD attorneys cannot ethically us the word "specialize" except for limited practice areas) their practice in that field. There are many differences between an Orphans' Court and the Circuit Court. Simply put, the litigation that occurs in the Orphans' Courts is generally far simpler with relaxed (and sometimes) no rules of evidence. (Many MD Orphans' Court judges are lay people without legal training). Your 4th question is the most difficult because it depends upon the lawyer - some would say yes to all areas and some would say yes to fewer than all and ask which court. Once you've selected at least 3 candidates, I suggest you call each and ask them for their experience. Also keep in mind that there is far more to selecting an attorney than simply experience. The chief complaint by clients to disciplinary bodies about their attorney is lack of communication. An attorney well experienced in all of these fields who is a bad communicator would lkiely be a bad choice.

It sounds as though there are a few steps missing in the information you provided.  In order for a garnishment to be put in place the collection agency would have had to file a lawsuit against you to collect the money for the medical bills.  You would have been served a summons and complaint and given an opportunity to file a response with the court and request a trial in front of the judge.  If you ignored the summons then the collection agency would have been granted a default judgment for the amount requested, and that is what would have allowed them to proceed with garnishment.  The time to dispute your responsibility for the medical expenses would have been in court.  Depending upon the amounts involved, you may want to consider meeting with a bankruptcy lawyer to determine whether that might be a reasonable solution for you.

There is information I need to accurately answer this question.  However, since you did not mention an order regarding custody I am going to assume that neither party has established custody or visitation in court.  As such, yes, she can take the children and so can you.  Until the court establishes which party is entitled to custody (often it is both) and sets a visitation schedule then there are no hard and fast rules.  However, if the children have been living with you it is likely that Oklahoma is their home state and "taking" the kids could be considered kidnapping in certain circumstances.  In either case, you need to get an attorney and file a divorce/paternity action.  The second part of your questions asks whether or not she can get child support when she does not have the kids.  The answer is probably not but it depends on what you mean by "does not have the kids."  Child support is calculated according to a formula. based on the number of overnight visits and the income of the parties (among other factors).  If you have the children more often than not, the other party should be held responsible for child support.

Buying a home at a foreclosure auction is certainly a risk. There is the possibility of liens being attached to the property and the new titleholder becomes liable for the liens. Utility liens are generally superior to the mortgage foreclosure case and surive, but it's hard to tell without seeing the lien itself.  As far as the HOA lien, Florida Statute 720.3085 is where to look. There you will find that 720.3085 (2)(a) states "A parcel owner, regardless of how his or her title to property has been acquired, including by purchase at a foreclosure sale or by deed in lieu of foreclosure, is liable for all assessments that come due while he or she is the parcel owner." You may want to see if you can negotiate and settle with both the HOA and the Utility to acquire clear title. You also may want to consult with an attorney to help you with this. Best of luck to you!

There is no way to answer this question with the information you have provided. Only your lawyer has a firm enough grasp on all the facts to advise you as to whether settlement is advisable. As a general rule, though, you should know that class action lawsuits seldom result in significant substantive relief to the class members.  As a separate matter, the prosecution of a class action lawsuit tends to be very lengthy and very expensive. If your attorney is not in a position to fund the litigation, your odds of success are pretty low. And getting another attorney to take the case over may be difficult or impossible.  One last thing - you say that the settlement involves "a lot of risk for the class and me." But that statement seems to ignore the risk on the other side of the equation: that is, the risk you will lose. Even if you have a good case on the merits, you have to win a class certification motion. And those motions are denied far more often than they are granted.  You need to have a frank discussion with your attorney regarding why he is recommending this settlement and what the result will be if it is accepted. But you also need to look at your claims from a very practical perspective. If you fail to obtain a class certification, if you fail to prevail on the merits, or if the costs of suit exceed the amount ultimately recovered from the landlord, you will be even worse off than if you accepted a settlement.

Hello,  Once you marry and apply for adjustment of status based on the marriage, if you also apply for employment authorization, you can use that employment authorization to obtain a social security card and use both of those documents to sign up at your local DMV office for the driving test.  However, you would need to take and pass the test and obtain your license in order to drive here legally (unless you have an international license that continues to be valid, and even then, there are risks involved in using an international license when actually living in the U.S.).    The employment authorization generally takes about 4 months to get, though, as you first must have your biometrics appointment (fingerprints and digital photo), and then it may take up to an additional 90 days beyond that appointment.  Thus, some of my clients end up receiving their appointment for their residency interviews before they actually get their licenses.  So yes, it's possible to get a driver's license while your residency application is pending, but it also is possible that you might complete the residency process before you have time to complete the licensing procedures and requirements.  Best wishes, Jennifer

The most important thing to understand about Probation Violations is that the offender does not have the same rights as when they are charged with a crime.  Probation violations are considered "post conviction" issues and offenders actually have very few rights.  They can often be stuck in jail waiting to see a judge for a long time as the law does not mandate timeframes for probation violators.  The law simply says that they must see a judge in a reasonable amount of time, which can be defined very loosely in some counties.  So, it may be 10 -12 weeks before they get in front of a judge (which happens in my county all the time).  Also, once in front of a judge, it is critical to understand that several things can happen and it is all up to the judge to decide how they want to handle the situation.  First of all, the offender can lose their first offender status because it is a privilege that can be revoked.  This would mean that he could be convicted if the courts revokes this status.  Second, it does not matter how much probation is left on his original sentence.  Even though the Prosecutor negotiated 5 years in the plea negotiations and the Judge accepted those negotiations at the initial plea, the risk of taking first offender and violating is that if they violate, teh judge could sentence the offender to the maximum sentence for the charges which the offender plead guilty.  So, if his initial charges total 25 years as a max sentence, the judge could sentence him to exactly that.  This is rare for first time probation violators, but it is how it works.  He needs a lawyer to expedite a court date, to try to preserve his first offender status to prevent a conviction, and to try to keep him from being sentenced to something more severe than the original sentence.  Best of luck to you both.

You need to read the Maryland Rules of Appellate Procedure. Appeals need to be formatted in a specific way. You also need to know how to use case citations and how to present an argument. You need to order transcripts from the lower court. In an appeal, you cannot introduce new evidence, but you need to look for legal errors that occurred in the trial level. You can contact the clerk's office for information on ordering transcripts, docket entries, etc. to assemble your record for the appeal. You should also receive a briefing schedule. That is when your brief will be due.

Court ordered alimony and child support "debts" - debts owed by a bankrupt debtor to another party - are known as Domestic Support Obligations (DSO) under the bankruptcy code.   DSOs may not be discharged in any bankruptcy case. The Debtor must disclose any DSO in the Petitions and to the appointed Trustee.  The Trustee  appointed is under a duty to contact the DSO recipient and confirm with them their rights.

Your property settlement does nothing to change the rights of third party creditors.  They may choose to go after your ex-spouse (or not).  Your ex-spouse should be listed as a  co-debtor.  It is not clear that you have any obligation to your ex-spouse but it would be prudent to list them as a potential creditor.  The bankruptcy will discharge your obligation to the third parties and as long as any debt you have to your ex-spouse is not "in the nature of support" and they do not object to the discharge of any potential obligation, your bankruptcy will discharge any debt to them as well.  There is the potential for an objection by your ex-spouse which could create a situation where the burden of proof could shift to  you regarding any hardship created by the discharge of debt to your ex-spouse.    This is a complicated area of the law and a free consultation with a qualified attorney would probably help your planning and peace of mind.

You may want to talk with a local collections attorney.  First, unless this is somehow going to be alleged to be a theft, the District Attorney has nothing to do with it and any action against you would have to be in civil court, not criminal.  Second, even threatening to have the District Attorney, police, or other form of law enforcement deal with it may violate California or Federal debt collection laws, depending upon the exact facts and circumstances, this person's status as you previous "employer" etc (does she work for a corporation? Is she the owner or merely another employee, albeit perhaps an ex-boss?).  So you may want to review everything with a local collections attorney - or, if you do owe it, just pay her being sure to get a receipt and perhaps a written acknowledgment that you are paid in full.  For $181, how far is it worth fighting over?

When going to court for a support modification the only thing that can be heard are the things plead by the parties.  Your ex-wife has plead that there has been a change of material circumstances such that the court should revisit and revise the support payment.  It is unlikely that the judge will allow you to stop paying support prior to 23, but you must answer your ex-wife's complaint and file a counterclaim, which then must be served with the answer. Also, the fact that you have taken additional financial burdens will have no real weighing on the case, and if you owe back support, you will continue to owe it.    If you are looking to terminate your support obligations, I would recommend consulting with an attorney, as the odds of you winning this matter on your own are almost nill.

IRC s. 61(a)(12) defines discharge of indebtedness as income. Loan proceeds are not on s. 61's list, so they're not income. But when you're not going to pay them back, then they're income.   That being said, the penalty on the lender for not doing a form 1099-c is $50 if they're caught. So raising your offer by $50 should be more than enough to get them to decline to issue one. A recitation that the debt was doubtful and disputed inserted into the settlement agreement should be enough to immunize both sides from any further inquiry.   Remember, it's a hassle for them to prepare it and issue it ... they're hard to figure correctly and the collectors that actually issue them are usually large Junk Debt Buyers that the IRS watches closely, or collectors that you have annoyed mightily so that they do it on a retaliatory basis.   A form 982 can reduce or eliminate the effect of a 1099-c form, provided you're really more or less broke.

No, you should not have to pay, except for any incidentals the landlord had to pay because of you breaking the lease.  This could include advertisement costs, overtime to handle the situation, etc.  If there aren't additional costs, he shouldn't charge you.  When you break a lease, you are responsible for paying damages.  However, your landlord has a duty to mitigate his damages.  If he is able to find a new renter at a higher rent, he is not out any money and can't charge you the other $1,000.  The other attorney is speaking of liquidated damage clauses.  This is a part of some contracts, but not all.  It basically is a way for damages to be calculated early, instead of waiting until the damages occur and having to calculate them later.  However, they are not always enforceable.  If your lease don't have this section, you don't have to worry about it.

BBS, like all other California licensing agencies, has a statutory right and power to deny an MFT (or any other)  license based on improper conduct or conviction of any crime. A "wet reckless" is a crime for these purposes. Further, CA licensing agencies can deny a professional license based on improper conduct that does not result in conviction, or is not criminally prosecuted, although the agency's procedural burden is higher where there is no conviction.   There is substantial useful info on this issue available to you on the BBS web-site. I encourage you to read the Disciplinary Guidelines and terms and conditions of license probation (drug and alcohol conditions) carefully, and also to read through several years of BBS license denials (decisions are on-line).  That info gathering will give you a sound idea of the scope of your problem here.  Your internship can be terminated based on this offense, although I would not necessarily expect that to occur.   In all events, when you prepare your application for license, you will need to disclose this matter and to provide a full narrative statement of the underlying facts and circumstances of the offense. Take great pains with the narrative statement. The Board is looking for a very specific and particular kind of insight and information there. As to whether the Board will deny the license based on this conduct, each case is judged on the individual merits of the facts and the applicant. You may want to consult with an attorney who practices professional licensing law for assistance in preparing the strongest possible application to overcome this issue. In all events, make every effort to avoid beginning your career on license probation. That is a very fraught and risky circumstance with many perils not immediately apparent to the licensee.

Ask her to reimburse you for what seems fair, then accept that amount minus a reasonable amount that you would incur to fight her.

You have received very good answers already. I will only try to shed some light on actually getting your portion of a retirement plan, because I only do work related to the division of retirement assets during a divorce.   1. When a portion of a spouse's pension is given to the other spouse during a divorce, a document known as a QDRO (qualified domestic relations order) will need to be prepared. For the preparation of a QDRO on your behalf, or to review a QDRO that the opposing party may have prepared, I will strongly encourage you to find a QDRO attorney to do it. Preparing these documents for the division of retirement assets in a divorce has to do more with retirement plan law than family law. A divorce attorney could be great to have on your side when you are divorcing or in any divorce situation (and you should hire one in your area), but when it comes to the enforcement of the division of a retirement asset, a QDRO attorney with experience working with retirement plans could be a better option for you than a divorce attorney who may not be as familiar with retirement plan law.  2. Each party is at risk of losing a lot of benefits ($$$) when the QDRO is not properly written. Little words make a BIG difference in the world of QDROs. Also, a lot could be lost if the QDRO is not drafted promptly within a reasonable time after the divorce.  3. You may do your divorce pro-se and also file the QDRO in court by yourself (you don't need an attorney to file the QDRO for you) BUT, for anything that has to do with WRITING or REVIEWING a QDRO, I would strongly encourage you to find an attorney, with experience in, and knowledge of, retirement plans and high sophistication with QDROs to do the actual preparation of the QDRO on your behalf (or to review a QDRO prepared by opposing party).   4. You don‰Ûªt need a local QDRO attorney because most federal law regulates the 401(k) plan to which the QDRO applies so any QDRO attorney in the country can help you. There are a few well-qualified QDRO attorneys across the country. Focus on finding a QDRO attorney, not just a family lawyer to do the actual preparation (or review) of the QDRO. Do your research before hiring.   5. QDROs are NOT neutral documents. You need your own QDRO attorney to draft or review the QDRO prepared by the opposing party‰Ûªs attorney. You need somebody who will look after your interests. I would be wary of anybody offering to prepare a QDRO for you and the other party, "representing" you both simultaneously.   6. Hiring a QDRO attorney in addition to your divorce attorney does not necessarily mean it will cost you more. QDRO attorneys usually charge a flat fee. The cost is worth it if you hire somebody who is a QDRO attorney with background on retirement plans. The flat fee cost is outweighed by the fact that your benefits will not be lost.   7. The Plan administrator may easily have approved a QDRO that complies with legal requirements regardless of whether the QDRO actually protects your interests. The Plan approval of a QDRO does not mean that the QDRO was properly drafted for your benefit. It only means the QDRO meets a few basic requirements mandated by law. You really need to sit down with a bankruptcy lawyer on this one.  First of all Michigan has homestead exemptions and under bankruptcy law, there are other exemptions. You can choose which scheme to use, but you cannot use both the state and bankruptcy exemptions.  In Michigan each homeowner and his or her dependents may exempt up to $37,775 of his or her interest in his or her home or other property covered by the homestead exemption. If the homeowner is age 65 or older or is disabled, the exemption amount is $56,650.  If you are married, then you can double the exemption amount if you own the home as tenants by the entirety or as husband and wife.  Please click on "Find a Lawyer" above and retain a bankruptcy lawyer. Many bankruptcy lawyers do not charge any fees up front to consult with you so its worth your while to shop around.

In order to get into the SD-FL LMM Program, you'll need to dismiss your current CH 14 and file a new one.   However, given what you've said above, that might be the smarted move for you. We have had significant success with this program.

The issue is whether the unemployment decision will be given collateral estoppel and/or res judicata effect.  	Res judicata and collateral estoppel are related doctrines that are designed to limit or preclude relitigation of matters that have already been determined. People v. Evans, 94 N.Y.2d 499, 502 (2000). Res judicata generally precludes relitigation of claims, while collateral estoppel precludes relitigation of issues Id.    These are not easy legal doctrines to master. The critical issues will be whether the defendant had an opportunity to litigate and whether the same issue is being litigated now.

The amount owed on a judgment is not static, it often increases by accruing interest, post judgment court costs ( including the garnishment) and in some cases post judgment attorneys fees. The creditor can go back to court to formally augment the judgment amount for post judgment costs and fees but this may incur additional fees.  You should consider your overall financial situation, if you have significant other debt you may benefit from a consultation with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney.

Absent a contractual agreement, most employment in New York is considered to be employment at will. In an employment at will situation, a person can be terminated at any time, without reason. However, there are a number of exceptions to an employment at will termination. If someone is being terminated and that person's civil rights have been violated in any way, such as age discrimination, sex discrimination, sexual harassment, race or gender discrimination, etc. Also, if termination is any way retaliatory for whistle blowing or some other act, an employer may be liable for wrongful discharge. Further, there may be reasons why you have been terminate that your ex-employer would never state to avoid liability. Based on what you have described, it appears that you may have been terminated and retaliated against because you filed a sexual harassment report.  Since it appears that you have been discriminated against because of your filing, to fully vet the facts that led up to your termination, it would be in your best interest to consult with a labor and employment attorney. Such vetting would give you a full understanding of your legal rights. Most Attorneys will give you a free initial consultation.   Best of Luck!   William J. Lasko   Law Office of Wm Lasko  482 Summer Street, 2nd fl  Stamford, Conn. 06901  tel 203 3129-6602

Generally, when an employee signs a severance agreement which includes an affirmation that the employee voluntarily resigns in return for the severance amount, that employee will be ineligible for unemployment benefits.  Certainly, you can alter the document. However, from an employer's point of view, the voluntary resignation is a critical element of any severance agreement and it is very likely that the employer will decline to accept an altered agreement and pay the severance amount.  Good luck.

Since Florida is a judicial foreclosure state, Deutsche Bank's "final judgment in foreclosure" is a judicial determination that its assignment is valid and it is entitled to sell your property at a foreclosure sale.  As others have said, you need to list Deutsche Bank and its attorney(s) in your bankruptcy petition, and file a Notice of Bankruptcy in the Circuit Court foreclosure action.  It is always best to list every entity that might have a claim, since the failure to list a creditor might lead to its debt not being discharged in your Chapter 7 filing.

The law in Pennsylvania is that the 30 days run from the last day of the term of the lease (or the date the tenant surrenders possesion of the rental property with the landlord's acceptance).   The Landlord has to pay you the money on that date, too, not just provide you a letter telling you how much of your security deposit he's going to send you.  You are correct -  your landlord should have gotten the letter and money to you right before the stroke of midnight on July 30th. Here's the statute (Title 68, Section 250.512):  "Every landlord shall within thirty days of termination of a lease or upon surrender and acceptance of the leasehold premises, whichever first occurs, provide a tenant with a written list of any damages to the leasehold premises for which the landlord claims the tenant is liable.  Delivery of the list shall be accompanied by payment of the difference between any sum deposited in escrow, including any unpaid interest thereon, for the payment of damages to the leasehold premises and the actual amount of damages to the leasehold premises caused by the tenant."
You might be able to appear by telephone. Get an attorney in the same county that the FL order is in.

Assuming that your unit is covered by the SF Rent Ordinance (building built before June 13, 1979), you can only be evicted for certain specified reasons.  One of those reasons is  "The tenant,  . . .  after written request or demand by the landlord to execute a written extension or renewal thereof for a further term of like duration and UNDER SUCH TERMS WHICH ARE MATERIALLY THE SAME AS IN THE PREVIOUS AGREEMENT; provided, that such terms do not conflict with any of the provisions of this Chapter" (Emphasis added). Since the landlord is asking for terms that are materially different than your old terms, you cannot be evicted for refusing to sign the agreement.   Save EVERYTHING! Keep a copy of the new proposed agreement, so that landlord cannot later lie and say it was not different than the original agreement.  Talk with an experienced tenants attorney before you talk with your landlord again about this issue.

You have gotten good advice already.    An attorney cannot settle a personal injury case without the client's consent.  It sounds like you consented.  That it was verbal and not written does not matter.  In that case, the attorney has earned their fee.  You are free to get another lawyer but that will come out of your share of the recovery, if any, not his.    If you are saying you did not consent to the settlement, then the attorney may have breached their duty to you.  But it is not clear from your post that any duty was breached.  They probably could have explained to you how LOPs work, but if you got medical treatment neither you nor your insurer paid for then you should have known that someone had to pay (or agree to pay) for it.    Another lawyer will need to review the documents to advise you on whether their was breach or any reason to undo the settlement. I think the best defense comes from RCW 46.61.100(3)'s use of the term "limited access roadway." I could not find a definition for this term in the RCW itself, but using Wikipedia to explore the general definition of a limited access roadway reveals that these types of roads are to be distinguished from controlled-access roadways (commonly referred to as freeways). Since I-5 is a freeway, I would argue that it does not fit the definition of "limited access roadway." This argument is further buttressed by the rest of RCW 46.61.100(3), which goes on to state that a person can drive in the left lane if turning left. Obviously, the legislature could not have intended I-5 to count, since freeways do not have left turns.   Good luck.

There are several ways to document and prove unauthorized occupants:  (1) Are they receiving mail in the occupants name at the residence?  Verify this by checking with the mailman or the post office; (2) Is the occupant's car frequently parked at the residence for long periods? (Dated & timed photos of the car at the residence;  (3) Is the occupant seen coming and going to the unit when the tenants are not home? He has his own key. Document this with a log of dates/times of coming and going; (4) Check with utility companies for any utility bills in his name, or for a sudden increase in utility usage; (5) Obtain statements from neighbors or other tenants in the building. (6) Give notice of an annual inspection.  Go in and inspect the entire unit, checking all systems for issues with water leaks, electrical, plumbing, heating, smoke detector batteries - a complete inspection. You will need to open closets and cabinets to do this (but not drawers or doors of their personal furniture). Look for signs that the occupant lives there (e.g., gender-opposite items if the person is not the same gender as the authorized tenant, shoe/clothing sizes that would not fit the tenant, etc.)  (7) Check common areas for signs of the extra occupant, e.g., shoes left outside the door, clothing left hanging to drip dry in the laundry, etc.  If it continues despite warnings and you want to document these items, it would be hard for a judge to ignore your logs of dates and times, statements from neighbors, photos of the car, inspection reports, utility statements, and the US postal service delivery.

Yes, she can sue you under the CC&Rs.  Civil Code Section 5975 provides that an owner in an HOA can sue another owner and/or the HOA in a dispute arising from the CC&Rs (called 'declaration' in the statute).  I have handled several of these cases and what generally happens when a person's view is impeded and he/she has the resources to file and fund a lawsuit, is that he/she will sue the owner impeding the view (for violating the CC&Rs) and the association for failing to properly apply the CC&Rs.  The HOA‰Ûªs decision would be a complete defense to the action against in and you only if the applicable restriction and/or rule was properly applied and is reasonable in light of the interests of the entire community.  There is no protected right to a view or light in California unless it is created by private agreement or equitable servitudes (which is what the CC&Rs are considered).  These cases can become very expensive very quickly.  I recommend you meet with your neighbor and see if things can be worked out before any lawsuit is filed.  If you cannot agree, then hire an experienced HOA lawyer immediately.  You will be glad you did.

After reviewing your question and your comments it appears that you are having communication and trust issues with your attorney. The following should provide you some guidance.   First, you need read your retainer/contingency agreement to find out what you agreed to. If you do not have a copy of it, then request one from your attorney. He is required to provide you a copy.   Second, your attorney should provide you a statement of how the settlement funds will be distributed. Usually, an attorney would want to reach an agreement with all the medical providers BEFORE accepting a settlement offer because he/she will have more leverage as opposed to negotiating liens and bills after accepting a settlement offer.  Moreover, most medical bills and liens can be negotiated depending on the settlement amount, what the settlement covers, type of medical lien, the medical service provider,  applicable statutes, and some other factors.   Third, depending on how the settlement check is made out, your attorney may or may not be required to get your endorsement before depositing the settlement check into the client trust account.  Fourth, if your attorney requires that you sign the release before he/she contacts or negotiates with the medical providers, I would suggest you seek new counsel. This is a very inappropriate tactic.   I hope this helps.

While a written (and signed) agreement will generally control this situation, even if there is not a written agreement, the sitter may be liable for breach of bailment. A bailment is a special kind of contract where the owner of property (called the "bailor") agrees with someone else (called the "bailee") to have that person hold the property temporarily. When the bailor comes to reclaim the property, it must be returned in the same condition (or better). If it is not in the same condition, then the bailee is liable for the loss, unless the bailee can demonstrate that he or she could not have prevented the loss.  Pet sitting is a perfect example of a bailment. The good thing about making a bailment claim is that you do not necessarily have to prove negligence. I agree that you should wait until you have completely treated your dog, and also should consider having your insurance cover the bill. You also should contact a local attorney familiar with animal law or bailments for more detailed advice.

As my colleagues have noted, criminal records do not disappear after a period of time. This is a common urban legend. If it was an M1 offense of violence or an M1 and the victim was a child, it cannot be sealed. Good luck. Don't hesitate to call one of us.

Generally speaking, your domestic partner isn't entitled to a partition or division of property under the legal framework that applies to marriage, so she isn't entitled to get a portion of your inheritance or money you had prior to your partnership simply because of your domestic partnership.  She is also not entitled to have the house divided as per marital law.  That being said, if the two of you were to end up in court, the case would most likely be decided under the general law of partnerships, and under that she might be entitled to some interest in the second home you mention, depending on her contributions to it, and any agreement express or implied between the two of you on how the home would be treated in the event your partnership terminated.  Whomever gets custody of your daughters would probably also be eligible for child support.  In other words, she won't be entitled to have your property divided as if the two of you had been married, but she may be entitled to credit for some of the things, like the second home, under the general law of partnerships, and she might be entitled to reimbursement or payment for contributions she made to your joint lives; while that wouldn't be a mandatory claim on your inheritance, it might require you to dip into it to pay something like that.  However, any sort of details are merely speculative in the absence of all the details of your lives together.  That should only be done with a competent local attorney you've retained for the matter.  For that I would suggest you consult with a family law/divorce lawyer in NYC since those lawyers almost certainly have experience with terminating domestic partnerships.

There are state-to-state variations in unemployment laws,  but in general:  you can be penalized for refusing suitable work, or for being fired from a subsequent job,  but not for failing to be hired.   So if you are paid, you should report the remuneration as pay for attending an orientation for a prospective job that did not pan out.   The agency may ask the company why, and the company may divulge the reason, but you don't know whether any of this may happen; don't borrow trouble.   If you do get notice that the state intends to end your benefits, contact a qualified lawyer or other advocate right away to represent you at the hearing.

You can only get the tax returns he provides. It is unlikely he is falsifying them just for you: it may be he does file s false returns with the IRS. If so, and you tip them off, and they recover anything, you can get a cut.  He must provide tax returns with an Income and Expense Declaration per F 355amily Code Selection 3665 and 3552.  CALIFORNIA FAMILY CODE  Division 9. SUPPORT  Chapter 6. MODIFICATION, TERMINATION, OR SET ASIDE OF SUPPORT ORDERS  Article 2. Discovery Before Commencing Modification or Termination Proceeding  Family Code section 3665      (a) A copy of the prior year's federal and state personal income tax returns shall be attached to the income and expense declaration of each party.      (b) A party shall not disclose the contents or provide copies of the other party's tax returns to anyone except the court, the party's attorney, the party's accountant, or other financial consultant assisting with matters relating to the proceeding, or any other person permitted by the court.      (c) The tax returns shall be controlled by the court as provided in Section 3552.   Division 9. SUPPORT  Part 1. DEFINITIONS AND GENERAL PROVISIONS  Chapter 2. GENERAL PROVISIONS  Family Code Section 3552      (a) In a proceeding involving child, family, or spousal support, no party to the proceeding may refuse to submit copies of the party's state and federal income tax returns to the court, whether individual or joint.      (b) The tax returns may be examined by the other party and are discoverable by the other party. A party also may be examined by the other party as to the contents of a tax return submitted pursuant to this section.      (c) If the court finds that it is relevant to the case to retain the tax return, the tax return shall be sealed and maintained as a confidential record of the court. If the court finds that the tax return is not relevant to disposition of the case, all copies of the tax return shall be returned to the party who submitted it.

Disorderly conduct is a little general and doesn't really fit exactly with the California Penal Code.  The two principal sections associated with disorderly conduct are Penal Code Section 647 (f) and 415 (1), (2) and (3).  PC 647 (f) makes it unlawfull to be in a public place in such a state of intoxication that the person is unable to care for their own safety or welfare or that of others.  Experienced defense attorneys often refer to this as "con tempt of cop".  A person engaging in the behavior descibed is likely to become a victim of false arrest under this section.  The officer oberves the gesture and makes other observations he uses to justify a welfare check or investigation.  Upon making contact, he oberves evidence of intoxication.  When the person becomes argumentative trying to assert their rights, the officer forms the opinion that they are too intoxicated to be safe and makes the arrest.  PC 415 prohibits disturbing the peace by loud and unreasonable noise, fighting and challenging to fight.  Case law and the constitution protect the right to gesture or say offensive things to officers.  However, in the real world there can be consequences and the need to fight false charges.

The officer often includes one of the several possible reasons that your license is suspended, on your citation for driving while license suspended. A financial responsibility suspension is one of them.  Financial responsibility or FR suspension, means that your license is suspended either for canceling an insurance policy and not renewing it, having an accident or a DUI conviction or a points conviction without sufficient insurance coverage as required by law, or having a judgment relating to an accident against your drivers license.  You should immediately hire a criminal defense attorney to defend you on the driving while license suspended charge, which may carry jail time.   Your attorney can help you negotiate your way out of the financial responsibility suspension as well.   There maybe other reasons that your license is suspended and your lawyer can investigate those and may be able to help you with those as well.  Call a private criminal defense attorney for a free consultation on your drivers license issue and case today.

However there are other asylum-like protections available.)  Even if you don't win asylum the first time around, you will get a second chance to make your case when you are in removal proceedings -- plus two levels of appeal.  You will be able to get work authorization along the way.    Staying here illegally without doing anything about your status really doesn't give you much of a future.  Ultimately, only an attorney familiar in detail with your circumstances can help you evaluate your options.  Asylum is a complex area of law, and very dependent on the particular facts of your case and the evidence you have available to you.  Good luck!

If your arrears are being paid through the Office of Child Support Enforcement Agency (OCSE), you  should talk to them to see if they would be willing to modify the arrearages (subject to what is in the best interest of the child), if you are receiving state assistance.    If you are not paying the arrears through OCSE, but are paying them directly to the other parent, then you and the other parent can reach an agreement as to whether to reduce the arrears owed.  However, even if the two of you are able to reach an agreement reducing (or even vacating any arrears), you must explain to the Court why it is in the child's best interest to reduce/vacate the arrears owed.  If the Court agrees that it is in the best interest it can then enter an order incorporating your agreement with the other parent.   I  would  recommend speaking with an attorney to weight your options and to fully understand what possible outcomes can occur.

Most likely you have legal claims that can be enforced here, but you may be able to improve the situation by utilizing your school's administrative grievance process. If you have informally sought the intercession of the department chair without success, you may need to rely on your school's administrative appeal process.   Most schools have an admin process for student challenges/appeals of grades, course credits, and other faculty and administrative decisions that impact the student's record. Get a copy of your school's admin grievance process and make your appeal according to the specific rules and requirements of the process. Failures to comply with all specifics of the process are generally held to constitute waiver, so your compliance needs to be meticulous. Act quickly because time limits for these admin processes are always very short.   All states require such admin processes to be utilized and exhausted before there is any recourse to legal process. Once the admin process has been completed, you may have rights to judicial review of the results of the admin process, but that review is generally very limited: did the school substantially comply with its admin process? was there any evidence to support the school's findings in the admin process. If the reviewing court finds that the school failed on either of these grounds, the court can order a new course of the admin process.   Under no circumstances will a court impose a different judgment in your dissertation process.  Be clear about that: NEVER happen. And you will not be able to successfully sue for damages on these facts, either. But the admin process will allow the school to cause a correction in the situation if the school is persuaded that a correction is appropriate. There is no downside to you making recourse to your school's admin process.

This is going to sound harsh and I don't mean it that way. Stark reality sometimes sets in.  My advice to you is that you find another place to live. If things are this bad with a lease, or rent paid, they are much worse without.  And frankly, if you want to live a functional life, being away from dysfunction is much healthier.  Your parents are adults, and so are you. None of you owe support to the others. If they want a divorce, let them get one.  If you want to find happiness in life, you have to find it within yourself and part of that is moving on from the situation you're in.   Finally, your dad gave you a five day notice to move out. With or without a court order, you are better off moving out anyway.   And as the others pointed out, its simply a tough sell to try and stay in a house with that kind of drama going on.

You have a problem that requires court attention.  As long as he is attorney of record, all pleadings and notices are going to him, and he if he is not relaying them you may not have a clue as to what is going on.  First thing, check the Clerk's docket on-line--NOW, so that you will know what has been filed.  Second, bring a Motion to Discharge the Attorney.  Indicate that you discharged the attorney but the attorney has not moved to withdraw, and set the Motion for hearing.  As soon as possible.  Like, tomorrow would not be too soon.  Also, you may want to check out Rule 2.516 of the Florida Rules of Judicial Administration.  It allows unrepresented persons to "opt-in" to receive pleadings by email.  I realize you are represented, but it could not hurt for you to do so at the same time you make your Motion to Discharge.  Worst that happens is Plaintiff ignores it because they are entitled to ignore it, but maybe they just add your name to their service list.  If I were the Plaintiff I would do that so that I could show the judge later on that I sent pleadings to anyone and everyone, your attorney, you.  Better than having to redo something because you weren't provided something.

Was there any balance owed after the sale?  If not, or if there was and you paid it, the tradeline should show a zero balance, and it could refer to the repo as long as it also shows that it was later paid (if you did pay it off).  If there was a balance after the repo that remains unpaid, they can show the balance in their tradeline.  I suggest showing the reports to a consumer law attorney to see if they believe the way it is being reported on your Trans Union report is accurate.  If it is not, you should send a dispute to Trans Union, which includes proof that the tradeline is not accurate. You should also send a copy to Capital One.  If the tradeline is not corrected after your dispute, you can pursue your rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act with a consumer law attorney.  Most take good FCRA cases on a contingency basis.

I work for insurance companies as outside counsel and worked for an insurance company for 6 years.  I would hold off singing the release until they pay for the rental reimbursement.  Most insurers will set up the rental with you over the phone and direct bill the rental company.  Should not be much harder than making a quick phone call to your adjuster to make sure the direct bill was set up.    Generally speaking most insurers will not require you to sign a release for a property damage claim.  Part of the reason for this is that when they start to tear down the vehicle they can find additional unseen damages.  As an example, your bumper has a cover that goes over a foam/cushion, but without taking the cover off the adjuster cannot know if it was damaged and will not be able to write it up.  They are usually called out to do a supplement that covers any additional unseen damage.  I can't see how they can ask you sign anything until the repairs are completed.

As Ms. Erlich stated, you would have a defense to a 2nd case filed after the Statute of Limitations would bar such a refiling.  One thing you should be made aware of.  Ordinarily, the running of a Statute of Limitations is an Affirmative Defense, which means you have to assert it when you file an Answer to the Complaint.  However, there is case law in Florida that says that if the SOL can be determined from the face of the Complaint, then a Motion to Dismiss is proper.    Example:  law suit is based on breach of a contract and there are no specific dates as to when the money is due--well, then all of the facts have to be fleshed out during the course of the litigation.  But if there is a bill attached that says payment is due on MM/DD/YEAR and the case is filed after the SOL has run from that date, then you can move to dismiss the case, not wait til you Answer to try to get the case tossed.

It is possible to do this before your divorce is finalized.  However, I would not quit claim the house to him without an agreement in place.  There are many potential issues that will need to be addressed in the agreement and you definitely want to make sure you are protected.  In addition to protecting your interest in the equity in the house you will need contingencies in the agreement in the even he is not able to refinance.  All of this should be worked out before the agreement is finalized and you sign the deed.  It is also possible to enter into an agreement on just the house before you have a comprehensive separation/divorce agreement completed.  But, yes, you do want an agreement in place and enacted before you sign the deed.  I also would not finalize an agreement entered into at mediation without having private counsel review it for you.  This is a routine practice and family counsel generally will act as review counsel for parties who have gone through a mediation.  A reviewing counsel will review the agreement with you and look for potential issues in the agreement and make sure you understand the nature of what you are agreeing to.  The clear benefit of a reviewing counsel is that this is an attorney that is looking out for your best interests versus someone who is acting as a neutral at the mediation.

You should file a complaint against this dentist with the dental practice Board in your State.  Complain about his lack of skill and rough treatment.  Well-placed filling should not come out in 2 weeks.  Many fillings need to be polished and checked for appropriate bite.  His failure to do this is probably a deviation from the accepted standard of practice.  However, this is not a situation for a medical malpractice claim, as it would be too expensive to pursue for the little damages you have.  If you have another dentist repair the fillings, you will need to pay that dentist.  You can always ask your first dentist to reimburse you for this cost, however, this does not warrant the expense and time of a malpractice lawsuit. It's the same for all medical negligence in Illinois.   Any action must be filed with an accompanying 2-622 affidavit from a medical expert alleging malpractice within two years of the date of malpractice. There is an exception that allows this to be extended to four years in cases of late discovery, disability, or lack of adulthood.   Do not even think of starting such a case without a lawyer.

You need to meet with an employment lawyer that has experience representing employees in your area. You did not note or allude to any wrongful termination. If you are an "at will" employee, it means that you can be terminated for any reason or no reason at all, just like you can quit for any reason or no reason. This is so even in the very employee friendly state of CA.   You can only file an EEOC claim if you have reason to believe  your dismissal was based on protected class matters, such as race or religion. Doing so out of spite is not only selfish it can backfire pretty easily.   Unless you have a contract that stipulated just cause, there is likely nothing you can do outside of filing for benefits, but you only your own lawyer can advise after all the details are disclosed.   I suggest that you consult with a lawyer in private and discuss your objectives and options  in more detail. You can start by calling around to several for a free phone consultation, get some insights then pick the best fit to work with.   Best regards,  Frank Natoli-Lapin, LLC

Yes, you would need to subpoena them (for all the good it will do). These subpoena's are often ignored. It's all you can do. Also, you would have to subpoena a person (a witness). There is no document (record) that is normally kept by a property management company that says who doesn't live there. You can only subpoena documents that are (or you believe) to be kept by the business. You cannot subpoena someone to "create" a document (e.g. a letter that you never resided at the residence). You need to subpoena a witness to testify to that fact.    Normally, a debtor would provide proof of where they were residing at the time. That is usually the easier path.  Good luck.

First, talk with your son about whether or not he has given the lawyer permission to talk to you about his case.  If not, the lawyer cannot tell you anything that is not in the public record.  It does not matter who paid the lawyer; your son still has the right to confidential advice.  Second, read over the written contract that you or your son signed when the attorney was hired.  It should provide some information, such as what services were included in the "everything" you say it covered.  If it does not include work on an appeal or other post-conviction legal work, then from the attorney's point of view you are just complaining about the result in a case that is over.  Personally, if I were the attorney, I would make or accept one phone call from you just to explain things, which probably includes explaining that the case is over.

You should stay away from any potential inference that you are a "Law Firm" or anything that may suggest you are or have a relationship with an attorney.  As the other response indicates, a non-attorney cannot own a law firm or have a stake in one as a general rule.  However, you could offer "Doe Paralegal Services" or "Doe Document Prep", etc.  Two rules you should abide by and you will likely be safe:  1)  Do not, in any way, shape or form, make any suggestions that you are a law firm/attorney if you are not actively licensed.  2)  As a non-attorney, you cannot, by law, offer legal advise.  That is considered the unauthorized practice of law.  If you a document preparation company, this means that you cannot advise indivduals of which documents to prepare.  You simply must ask them what they need prepared and do that only.  You cannot make recommendations based on their situation - that is practicing law.

If she were prosecuted for insurance fraud, the State would have to persuade the Jury, beyond a reasonable doubt, that, at the time she made application for and accepted death benefits pursuant to the life insurance policy contract, she knew the husband was not dead.   The Judge would instruct the Jury before it deliberated that, any member not so persuaded, should vote Not Guilty.   In order to reach a binding verdict, all members of the Jury must all vote the same, i.e, all Guilty or all Not Guilty.    Regardless whether the beneficiary  were criminally prosecuted or convicted, upon learning that the husband faked his death, the life insurance company might commence a civil case against the beneficiary seeking rescission of the insurance contract and return of the benefits paid on a theory of "mutual mistake" and/or "unjust enrichment."

The actual physical letter, the paper and ink, is owned by the recipient. However, the sender of the letter still owns the copyright, unless the letter/an agreement says otherwise. Thus, the recipient can sell it, donate it, destroy it, etc but he would not be able to publish the letter in its entirety without the sender's (in this case, his heirs) consent.

With your prior felony record and the nature of the charges here, you're probably not going to avoid another felony here. It's difficult to evaluate your chances at trial, since I can't see any of the evidence. If the prosecution's case relies upon the testimony of the alleged victim, and the alleged victim is uncooperative, recanting, or nowhere to be found, then your chances are relatively good. If you have some credible defense, like self defense, to present at trial, your chances are decent. Of course, any defense that has to be presented through your testimony is going to be hindered by the fact that you can be "impeached" with your prior felony if you take the stand. But if the state doesn't have witness of other proof problems, and you don't have a strong affirmative defense to present, then you'll probably be convicted at trial. If I were your attorney, I would be trying to get you probation with drug and/or mental health treatment. I would not be anxious to roll the dice and go to trial under the facts you've presented here.

Good advice from Mr. Rasberry; let me expand on it briefly.  There may be a more powerful remedy available to you, which you should discuss with your attorney. If the texts from your ex are threatening to the extent that they place you in fear of physical harm (and the texts would cause a reasonable person in your situation to believe that they were in danger of physical harm), you may be able to obtain an Order of Protection.  Same applies if the texts from your ex can reasonably be read to subject you to, threaten you with, or place you in fear of, the offense of stalking.  Definitely seek the advice of experienced counsel on this; you do not want to seek an Order of Protection without solid, provable grounds, and even if your case warrants the issuance of an Order of Protection, there are other important considerations to factor into the mix, before deciding that the Order of Protection is/is not the best way to proceed.  Good luck to you and your children during this harrowing time.

California does not have a true "expungement" statute. What we do have is a dismissal under Penal Code 1203.4. If granted, it doesn't wipe the case off your record, but it adds a notation that the case was dismissed. That allows you to tell most employers that you have not been convicted of the crime, but it remains on your record and still counts as a prior conviction.   If you want that relief, you have to apply for it - it's not automatic. It's also not an overnight process. It can take weeks or months, depending in the county.   Keep in mind that the 1203.4 dismissal does NOTHING to your DMV records. It will remain there.   You're just under the 7 years, unfortunately and according to the terms of your application, you'll have to disclose this. If you don't and they find it later, they can (and probably would) fire you for lying on your application.   You may want to consider disclosing it, but being open and as convincing as you can that Ymir was an isolated incident and boy, did you learn your lesson.

First of all, I think you should ask your professors this question, and I am surprised there is no class on the subject of ethics in your curriculum.  However, once you answer a question in regard to a specific legal issue, and give specific advice, that would be UPL.  Imagine that you give such advice, and then the issue blows up, and the person finds out that your advice was incomplete, or insufficient, or just plain wrong for their full circumstances.  They would likely complain about you, and then you would be investigated by the Bar.  Is it worth that to not tell someone that what they really need is a lawyer? There is a case where a lawyer once went to a party hosted by a friend to celebrate her opening a fashion warehouse.  The lawyer and the friend chatted, and the friend said she was thinking about getting additional insurance.  The lawyer, as a friend, noted the extensive sprinkler system and wondered if that was needed.  Then there was a fire.  The friend sued the lawyer for malpractice and the Bar found that the lawyer had given legal advice by not making it clear that he wasn't giving legal advice.  So, while this is not your situation precisely, you can see that the boundaries are quite easily traversed, and there is danger for both you and the person you advise when there is confusion or a difference of opinion later.  Ask one of your instructors, or call the Florida Bar for specific advice, but always err on the side of caution.  This answer is for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice nor make you a client of this firm.  See how it works?

Mr. Dugan is right.  But the system is a bit silly.  So they do the SSI first and pay you from date of application to the present, presuming no other substantial income.  So you get ALL those months of SSI.  Then the work on the SSDIB:  the 4 or 5 months from your accident (onset date) you can't get SSDIB, but you got SSI.  That is yours to keep, no effect/offset.  But by month 5 or 6, you were (with hindsight now!) eligible for SSDIB. But, you got SSI for that month, as if you didn't have other income - but now they are PAYING you for that month with SSDIB, so you DID (hindsight) have income.  So it turns out you were NOT eligible for that welfare check due to SSDIB that month.  So from the SSDIB amount that is owed you, they will take out for the SSI they clumsily paid you for that month.  It is not so much a "loan "as it is a reversal and correction of which fund should have been paying you - not SSI, you weren't poor enough (in hindsight).  Why they don't just spend an extra 20 minutes working out the corrections before paying out is beyond me - but claimants are routinely surprised and upset when they erroneously think they will be getting both benefits each month - when that is entirely not true.

My condolences on the loss of your friend. In order for his Will to be legally effective, it has to be offered for probate and admitted. If your friend was a Georgia resident, that means that his heirs must generally receive notice that the Will has been offered for probate (unless the executor files in common form, which is not preferred because it does not bind the heirs for four years), and given a chance to object to having the Will probated. That in itself takes a while sometimes. The next step, once the Will has been admitted to probate and an Executor appointed, is for the Executor to determine what assets and debts exist. Even if there are no known debts, the Executor must file a Notice to Debtors and Creditors. That runs for 1 month in the official legal newspaper for the appropriate county, then there is a three month period in which unknown possible creditors are supposed to make themselves known. The Executor is given 6 full months after being appointed (that means the Probate Court has admitted the Will to probate and issued letters testamentary, not that the death occurred) before he has to pay most debts or make any distributions. The Executor's job is to protect the estate during that period: this means that locking the house and changing the locks, preserving the personal property, and keeping the car in a safe place is all very likely to be the correct actions to take at this point. Once the Executor has had a chance to determine what assets there are, make sure any debts are paid, make sure any needed tax returns have been filed, and do all the other tasks needed to property administer an estate, then, if the house is still in the estate and did not have to be sold to pay debts or higher-priority items, it should eventually be distributed to your brother. If he thinks that things are not being done correctly or are taking too long, he is also free to hire his own attorney to represent him. The Executor's attorney cannot provide your brother with any legal advice.   Nothing you've said seems weird from my perspective, although I can see why it might if you're not used to dealing with estates. Until the Will has been fully admitted to probate, your brother's interest isn't even enforceable, so that is likely one reason he's not being given a lot of information yet. It sounds like it's still very early in the process. Even once the Will has been admitted, there are a lot of tasks in any estate, even a simple one, which need to be addressed before distribution of assets can begin. But I don't hear anything in your post which sounds suspicious.

Hello,  First of all, U.S. citizen children must be at least 21 years of age to sponsor a parent.  Even then, there are potential complications where a parent is inadmissible, since children are not qualifying relatives for most inadmissibility waivers.  Also, there is no guarantee that any executive action, or even C.I.R. if it passes, would just "erase" a prior removal order.     If someone ignores a removal order, then files an application for adjustment of status with the Immigration Service, rather than approving the application, the Immigration Service very likely will detain that person and try to remove him/her from the United States.  Indeed, even without filing anything, someone with a removal order is subject to having it enforced at any time.  In certain, rare cases, it is possible to reopen old removal orders or request waivers. of the prior removal/deportation.  However, these cases are very fact-specific and challenging, and not everyone is able to qualify.  Thus, I would encourage your friend to consult with a licensed, experienced immigration attorney about whether he may be able to do either of those things, or possibly have some other remedy, or whether he should try to keep waiting.  Best wishes, Jennifer

Unless his mistress is married to someone else, the child will not be legitimate when born.  He will need to file a Petition to Legitimate this child or marry his mistress after you divorce.  The only ramifications it will have on you are that the child born of his mistress will probably be a "qualified child" when calculating support awarded to you (although it wasn't exactly clear in your fact pattern whether or not you had children).  Certainly it should have an affect on your divorce because adultery is grounds for divorce and when establishing divisions of property and alimony, the court looks to conduct of the parties as a factor.  It sounds like his conduct wasn't very good.  There are, however, many other factors to be considered.  Also, he can still sign the birth certificate when the baby is born if you are still married.

In addition to the concerns that are expressed in the prior answers, you must also keep in mind that even if you are approved on a new claim, your benefits do not start immediately. On any new claim, the earliest that you can be found disabled is one day after the ALJ decision. So if you were denied July 9, 2014, the earliest you can be approved on a new claim is July 10, 2014. Even though you can be approved as of July 10, 2014, SSDI has a mandatory five month waiting period before any payments can be made after the date an individual is found disabled. If you are found disabled on any day other than the first of a month, your payments cannot begin until the next full month.  This means that if you are found disabled on July 10, 2014, your five month waiting period takes you December 10, 2014, since that is not the first of the month, your first possible month of eligibility would not be until January 2015. So in actuality you give up a lot of potential past-due benefits by not appealing.  My other concern in filing a new application so close to the date of an ALJ denial, is that you cannot be found disabled until the day after the decision, sometimes Social Security takes that to mean that they will only look at medical evidence since the new onset date. If you immediately file a new application, that means that their may only be a couple of months of medical evidence to review at the time a decision is being made. If nothing really changed since the ALJ denied, normally, even on a new claim, they will look at the ALJ decision and still determine you are not disabled.  There may be very good reasons that your attorney is recommending that you not appeal your ALJ decision (such as not having enough evidence to prove you were disabled in the first place), but I always look at what will be different on a new claim. If I am not willing to appeal an ALJ decision, I normally suggest that my clients receive additional treatment, or obtain more supportive medical opinions before I will proceed with any new claim. I typically also suggest that they wait until there is at least 6 more months of medical treatment, and that during that time there are multiple visits with specialist to establish why your condition is worse than the ALJ determined.  I would suggest that you talk to your attorney again and determine why he/she is recommending you file a new claim instead of appealing, and also determine if there is anything that you can do before applying to make your claim stronger.

See California Family Code Sections 2102 - 2105.  The Parties must exchange Preliminary Declarations of Disclosure which include (1) an Income and Expense Declaration and (2) a Schedule of Assets and Debts.  See Family Law Form FL-140.  Note that the Declaration of Disclosure is not to be filed with the Court, simply served upon the other Party.  A Final Declaration of Disclosure with updated information must also be exchanged prior to Trial or Settlement of the matter, unless the Parties mutually agree to waive that requirement.  Once the Declaration of Disclosure is served, the Party must file with the Court a "Declaration Re Service of Declaration of Disclosure and Income and Expense Declaration" which is FL-141.  This is the form that states that you served the other Party with your declaration of disclosure.  Hope this helps!

Absolutely a scam - don't pay them a penny.  Yes, it violates Federal (and most likely local) debt collection practices laws but beyond that, think about it. Beyond the illegality of their trying to do either, just on a practical basis, no law enforcement organization notifies the person they are going to arrest ahead of time! Very nice to hear your daughters are being signed by a label. This must be a very exciting time for them (and for you, too). This is where experience really counts, but I do understand the "price tag" on legal services is often prohibitive to those who need it the most. In my experience as an entertainment & licensing attorney, I often meet aspiring talent / clients who have unfortunately entered into recording or licensing deals that end up suffocating emerging opportunities because they couldn't afford an experienced attorney. If I'm impressed at their showcase or with the licensing concept, I'll enter into a blended-fee arrangement that meet attorney ethics requirements/standards. There are many ins & outs regarding the licensing agreements, but licensing deals tend to be more straight forward since they are very susceptible to common licensing drafting trends. It's important to make sure you work with an attorney who understands the recording industry as well as complex licensing agreements. Not always an easy mix to find since they are quite different legal practices. Try structuring a blended-fee arrangement with the attorney you select to work with & seriously consider having the attorney fee arrangement reviewed by another attorney prior to signing.
