Short answer to the deed - no.  Short answer to the DPOA - no.  That being said, the deed is a very important legal document that needs to be drafted properly so that when it is filed with the local recorder of deeds they will: 1. Find it acceptable in format; and 2. The recorder of deeds will accept it for filing.   A deed has several very important components and words that are needed to properly convey ownership of the property from one party to the next party. If the proper wording is left out or used incorrectly, the conveyance (transfer of ownership) to the next partly could be defective (either immediately or in the future).   This defective transfer could trigger an avalanche of legal claims and the liability for such claims will likely be directed to the drafter of the document.   So, using an attorney to draft a deed is not that costly when you think about it.   The added cost of filing the deed and handling the paperwork could be saved by you doing that part yourself, but you should leave the deed drafting to someone skilled that area.   As for the DPOA, it is much the same thing. You could go to a big box store and get a form or could get a computer program and download and complete the form, but then you are on your own.   If someone goes wrong with a transaction for the agent/principal and their is a challenge in court, the self drafted DPOA will not be viewed positively (it might be "legal" but not looked upon with favor) and could end up costing you more. Believe it or not, a DPOA is not that expensive and an attorney who knows how to draft them can make sure you are getting what you need and may be able to give you advice on do's and don'ts so you can keep yourself out of trouble (now and in the future).   I hope everything works out for you.

My guess is that the PO is taking the position that your security cameras can be used to alert you if you're at home doing something you shouldn't be doing and the PO drops by, thereby allowing you to possibly avoid detection of whatever hypothetical illegal activity you're engaged in.  The PO probably isn't going to back down on the issue, so to avoid any chance of getting violated and revoked, you can do one of two things: (1) take down the cameras; (2) file a motion to modify the terms and conditions of your probation.  Why?  Because the judge has the ability to set and change the terms and conditions of probation at any time pursuant to NRS 176A.400.  There is no specific term or condition that directly addresses the issue, so the issue is ambiguous.  An additional term would resolve the ambiguity and make it clear whether or not you can have the cameras.  What you want is for the judge to add the condition that you may use security cameras.  Security cameras are for home security.  So are locks.  Would the PO take the position that you having locks on your doors prevents you from being supervised because you can lock yourself in your house to avoid detection of illegal activity?  Of course not.  So what's wrong with cameras?  It's just another home security measure.  Good luck!

You can, but it will take some work.  First, however, I would immediately and personally deliver a demand to preserve evidence letter to the self-storage unit to demand that they save the security camera video.    Under California law, the self storage business is unit a duty to preserve all audio and/or video recording(s) once notified, as your letter does, concerning an incident that may lead to a lawsuit or prosecution.  In California, in a civil context, a failure to preserve evidence after being given notice to preserve it may result in terminating sanctions to the party in possession of the evidence. Cedars-Sinai Med. Ctr. v. Sup. Ct. (Bowyer) (1998) 18 Cal.4th 486, 494-97.    In a criminal context in California, the failure to produce such evidence may also lead to dismissal of the case.  California v. Trombetta (1984) 467 U.S. 479, 488, 82 L.Ed.2d 413, 104 S.Ct. 2528 and Arizona v. Youngblood (1988) 488 U.S. 51, 58, 102 L.Ed.2d 281, 109 S.Ct. 333; see also People v. Medina (1990) 51 Cal.3d 870, 893, 274 Cal.Rptr. 849; see People v. Zamora (1980) 28 Cal.3d 88, 96, 167 Cal.Rptr. 573.  I would then contact the police, make a claim with the self-storage unit's insurance and contact a civil litigation attorney to follow up.  That attorney should demand the video and simply take the time to look at them.  It just has to be done.

First, I would first seek medical attention for yourself and children to address any injuries from the accident.  Second, I would seek a local criminal traffic attorney to address your potential (1) administrative driver's license suspension and  (2) pending traffic citations.   A conviction or a plea of guilt to these traffic citations can have be potentially used at a later time as evidence if you are sued in civil court for damages by the other party of the accident. An experienced attorney could assist in exploring other alternatives.  Do not drive until your suspension is reinstated.  Driving on a suspended license is a Georgia misdemeanor requiring:  2 days in jail, $500 to $1000 fine, 6- month driver's license suspension, and possible probation. Generally, notice is a requirement for a person to be charged with the misdemeanor of Driving on a Suspended License. You did not state why your license was suspended.     Generally, a conviction can be supported by: (1) sufficient  written notice given to, signed by, and explained to the party by the police; (2) formal notice by mail to correct address through the Department of Driver Services; or (3) by operation of law (DUI). Agg assault while DUI is a felony of the second degree with a maximum possible sentence of 10 years.  The specific circumstances of your case and any prior record will determine actual sentence, and needs to be reviewed with an/your attorney as soon as possible.    If the only substance in your blood was a metabolite, you are guilty of DUI, but agg assault while DUI requires proof that the DUI was "the cause of the injury."  Some marijuana metabolites are incapable of causing impairment, so you might have an argument that the DUI was not the cause of the injury.  This would likely require both an experienced DUI and traffic law attorney in your area and a medical expert to prove.

If an employee complains about a co-worker or supervisor discriminating against that employee based on gender, national origin, race, disability, age, religion, sexual harassment, etc..., then the company is required to prevent/correct the situation (not necessarily fire the "harasser" or separate you from him). You used the term "harasser", but your description is vague. If you simply mean "bullying," then the company may not be required to do anything to improve your work situation. If, however, you mean that based on a protected category, the supervisor is "harassing" you (i.e. making comments about your age), then if the supervisor begins to retaliate against you, the company may be liable for the supervisor's actions. If you merely complained about the supervisor "bullying" you, then the supervisor's potential response (treating you worse) won't technically be (from a legal perspective) retaliation either, since again, bullying isn't a protected category.   You should speak with a lawyer and provide him/her with more specific details as to what specifically you complained about to your employer. Only then can a lawyer determine if you have a valid case, or what to demand in terms of "better treatment."

When you say that your child's father has "full custody," I assume that you mean that there's a court-ordered judgment granting him legal custody of the child. It is surprising to me that a court would have awarded primary legal custody to someone in the country without immigration status, but it is possible. If you do have such a judgment on file with the Court, it probably contains a provision that prohibits either parent from moving the child more than 60 miles further distant from the other, without the other parent's written approval or the order of the Court. Such a move would be a basis for modifying the child's custody. In order to get a Court's permission to move a child away, the moving parent must prove that the move is in the child's - not merely the parent's - best interests. Because courts presume it is in the best interests of a child to have regular and ongoing contact with both parents, and because courts disapprove of parents interfering in the ongoing relationship between a child and their other parent, this is a hard standard to meet. So either parent is free to leave at any time - they just aren't supposed to bring the child with them.  That said, all this only describes what courts expect people to do, or order them to do - not what they actually do. The fact of the matter is, there's nothing you can do to physically stop your co-parent from moving away with your child. If he does, you can file an immediate motion with the Court to modify custody, and seek a 'temporary protective order of restraint' that requires that the child stay where they are. You'd have to serve it on him for it to be effective, and then you'd have to enforce it. If he totally disappears, or goes to a country that won't honor American States' custody orders, this will not really be possible. The only way to try to prevent this from happening is to seek an award of primary physical custody yourself before it happens. Without knowing the details of your case history, we can't say how likely that is to succeed. You may want to discuss this with a family law attorney in private.

A spouse does not have to wait until the divorce is finalized to start receiving alimony.  You can request temporary alimony which is alimony that is paid to you during the pendency of the case.  In some judicial circuits a party will need to attend mediation and reach an impasse (that means no agreement is reached) in order to receive a hearing date for temporary relief.  In other judicial circuits there is no requirement to attend mediation prior to receiving a date for temporary relief.  You will want to file your financial affidavit and comply with mandatory disclosure (the production of certain financial documents) in order to prove to the Court that one spouse has the need to receive temporary alimony and that the other spouse has the ability to pay temporary alimony.

In the simplest scenario, if she just kicked a door in and moved herself in, then you could treat her as a trespasser and call the police. But, if she' been there for some time, then it get's a little complicated where you might want to have a discussion with an attorney.

Generally, felony cases that involve forensic evidence or testing will take several (3-5) months to complete pretrial conferences, motion hearings, and bargaining. A felony trial with multiple witnesses presented by the state (including co-defendants, forensic scientists, and witnesses) will take several days, and longer if the Defendant chooses to present evidence on his own behalf. An estimate would be 6-10 days for such a trial. After the presentation of the case, the jury or bench will deliberate, and there really is no estimate for how long a jury will take - hours to days. If convicted, sentencing could be immediate, or it make take place up to a month after conviction. Even then, the Defendant may appeal his conviction, and the appellate process usually takes about a year (12 months or more.) Thus, a very general estimate would be 2-4 years until the process is completely "over" in the legal arena. I hope that helps give you a general idea. Good Luck.

Other answers posted to the "bypass" question are correct.  Basically a "bypass" is a tool within a trust that shifts taxable estate value into a pot (subtrust) in order to avoid federal estate tax.  A bypass trust usually is part of a revocable or living trust.    HOWEVER, an asset protection trust is a different creature altogether. In Nevada a typical asset protection trust is IRREVOCABLE, so the grantor can't change the trust--not directly anyway.  The  basic idea is the grantor can "control" assets but no longer "owns" the assets.  The trust is designed to protect the grantor's assets from his or her creditors.  Nevada has probably the BEST asset protection laws in the US.  The trustee administering the trust money is often a professional trust company.    An asset protection trusts is ADVANCED estate planning tool.  So if you are serious, study up on the topic, ask questions, do a consult or two w a sophisticated trust/estate planning lawyer and understand what you're dealing with. Most trust lawyers do a free initial consult.  After that, plan to spend legal fees and trustee fees--but having said that, the advantages of a good asset protection trust can far outweigh those initial costs.  Good Luck, Greg J. Reno

Technically you should be out by the day your lease ends. Do you need extra time? If so, I'd recommend trying to negotiate with the landlord to pay for an extra day at a pro-rated rate. If you can't negotiate that, then do your best to be out. That being said, if you're not out, your landlord may have a claim for an extra months rent owed by you / may keep a security deposit (or a portion thereof). He/she CANNOT exercise 'self-help.' That means, he/she cannot come barging in at 12:00 on the night of and try to physically kick you out. He/she cannot change the locks, etc. If you're not out, he/she can claim you owe more money and will have to go through the legal eviction process.  Best of luck.

Your question cannot be answered with a simple yes or no.  When you are accused of DUI in Colorado, there are 2 separate actions, a DMV action and the Court action.  Both of these are separate, meaning the DMV may have revoked your licenses outside of the court case.  For example, if your BAC was above a .08, the DMV may have administratively revoked your license outside of any court action.  If this is your situation, a plea to DWAI will not disturb or change the fact that the DMV revoked the license. If the plea to DWAI, which is 8 points put your license into a point suspension depends on any previous accident or tickets that generated points within the last 12 to 18 months. I would recommend contacting the DMV directly to determine if your license is revoked, the reason for the revocation, and what you need to do to get it back.  Good Luck! Laurie

As a psychologist, you have experience and a good understanding of the impacts that certain neurological conditions may have on polygraph test results.   First, I'm sure your defense attorney has shared with you that you are not required to submit to one under the protections afforded by your 5th Amendment rights of self-incrimination;. Next, in Arizona courts , polygraph test results may be admissible under stipulation that both the prosecution  and defense agree upon it, as well as the examiner being accredited, as well as other requirements.  If the prosecution is requesting you submit to one, it is usually to gather evidence against you.  However, according to your question, it is your attorney that is recommending it.  Not knowing the details of your case, (which I share concerns of peers, that you not provide any further sensitive details here),  your criminal defense attorneys must have reasons why they are recommending the test.   Those reasons may or may not include helping you establish innocence or challenging accuracy of the prosecutions evidence.   So before you raise any further objections or make a decision,  I would definitely encourage you to discuss your concerns and the reasons your attorney is recommending it directly with them.  As a word of caution, if you and and your attorney agree that the polygraph test will prove to be exculpatory in nature (prove you are innocent), you do not want to give the prosecution another reason to argue that the polygraph evidence is inaccurate.  This is definitely a question for you and your defense advocate to discuss and agree upon based on the criminal defense case your attorney is building on your behalf, and the sensitive details of your case.  Best regards.

Only a very, very small percentage of inventions are ever converted into a commercially successful product. Filing a provisional patent application that describes an invention does not change that reality.   What you have to sell is not the patent application but: (1) INFORMATION about your invention is made, how it's used, and how it works and  (2) the very unlikely POTENTIAL that after three years and about $15K in patent application costs a patent will issue with commercially-useful claims describing a commercially-attractive product that can be made, distributed, marketed and sold for at least half again its cost, AND you will have to find a buyer who values the patent protection AND has the financial wherewithal to enforce the patent if need be.  All of the above is not meant to dissuade you from trying to sell the INFORMATION and the POTENTIAL for patent protection. Your sales pitch, however, should be focused in the invention and not the provisional patent application [which, yes, can be sold].  Good luck.

Only the prosecuting attorney has the authority to file charges against your ex. Until charges are filed, a warrant cannot be issued. The prosecutor cannot file charges until they receive a case from the detective. As a former domestic violence prosecutor, I can understand your frustration with the process. The judge who issued the order is relatively powerless to do anything that would satisfy you and make you feel safe, so you are left waiting for the detective to finish his investigation and then waiting for a prosecutor to make a charging decision. Even when a prosecutor decides to charge him, don't expect that it means he will go to jail to await trial. Most defendants are released while they await the outcome of the case. Even domestic violence defendants. If you are already working with advocates, I commend you. They can help you with services to safety plan for your family regardless of what happens to the criminal case. At this point you can keep up contact with the detective so he knows you are still in fear, work with your advocates and call 911 if there is any indication he is violating the order again or if you feel you are threatened. Good luck.

I am assuming when you say "owner" you are referring to the landlord and not a tenant on the lease.  That being said, the general answer is that a tenant has an expectation of privacy in his/her dwelling and that police need a warrant or exigent circumstances to enter.  This is why several attorneys have indicated they need more facts to assess your question.  We would need to how the police justify entrance into the apartment.  So, for example if there was a reason to believe that a fleeing felon had entered the property or evidence was being destroyed, a court may find the entry was justified.  Most landlords reserve the right to enter for maintenance, but that would probably not justify allowing police to enter and search.

First, you don't want to do a "motion" for discovery.  You just "request" discovery.  You file a "motion" when you want the courts to order something to happen.  The prosecution has a responsibility to provide you discovery, so you just request it from the appropriate authority.  If it fails to give you discovery, you can motion the court to "compel production of discovery" and/or "motion to dismiss for failure to provide discovery."  So, you won't want to combine your discovery request and your motion against the ticket.  You'll want to get discovery, do your own investigation, and determine whether you really have a viable motion against the ticket for failure to meet all the conditions precedent to citing you.  What exactly would the motion be called?  Well, often in criminal defense you create your own animal when challenging the sufficiency of state actions.  You can probably entitle it "motion to dismiss for failure to issue a valid ticket."  Or something to that effect.  I don't know that you'll find forms for such a motion.  You can, if you want, look up the Uniform Trial Court Rules and the Supplementary Local Rules of the jurisdiction you are in to determine how such motions should be formatted.  But I wouldn't really recommend that you do that on your own.  What I would recommend is that you consult with an attorney for at least an hour.  If you want to handle your case on your own, but would like help drafting your motion, it could very well be worth whatever that costs to ensure that your motion is properly formatted.  Many attorneys will offer free consultations, and it shouldn't take too many hours to draft such a motion (though I haven't actually seen your case file or fact pattern, so I really don't know how many hours it would take to draft it).  You are going about this correctly so far.  You should also look at ORS 810.439 for extra conditions precedent.  Best of luck!

Having dementia does not automatically mean the person is incapacitated. What you describe is called a springing power that requires some specific evidence, usually a doctor's letter (or 2) that she is no longer capable of handling financial business. If you don't have that, then she would still be considered competent and may be able to sign the sales contract and possibly the deed. I would further suggest that if she is still capable, you talk with an estate planning attorney to get a properly worded and executed durable power of attorney, as well as review her other estate planning documents. If she doesn't have any other estate planning documents, the attorney can advise you on those needs as well.

Are you saying that your client wants to sue you for what your independent contractor did?   Without seeing what your agreements are with both the client and the independent contractor, it's hard to give a detailed answer, but generally speaking, your obligations to your client would be spelled out in your agreement with the client. If you have someone who is working for you as an agent (your independent contractor), you may be liable to the client for damages caused by your agent. (Whether they're an agent is a question of fact, and how your contract with the independent contractor is phrased might not be enough - it depends on how you control their actions).   If you do get sued by your client for what your independent contractor did, you'd want to seek what's called indemnification from that independent contractor. That means that if they do something that you end up on the hook for, they're required to reimburse you under your contract with them. Does your contract provide for indemnification? However, the question is whether that indemnification clause means anything from a practical perspective - i.e., do they have the money?   Bottom line, however, is no one WANTS to sue. Litigation is costly for everyone, so make sure that you're timely responding to communications with the client and keeping an open and honest dialogue. If you think that's not working and this might be headed towards a lawsuit, hire an attorney for guidance.

This event is made available for use at the end of a Chapter 13 plan, as part of the process of determining whether or not a mortgage is current. A trustee is supposed to file a Notice of Final Cure Payment when, during the Chapter 13 plan, they believe that a mortgage is current. In WA the trustee is guaranteed to know this as if a mortgage is in arrears (behind) mortgage payments are required to be made through the plan. In a district like your own, this isn't guaranteed and therefore the debtor is required to take an extra step. The Notice must be filed by the trustee within 30 days after the debtor completes all payments under the plan.  If the debtor believes that the final cure payment has already been made and that all plan payments have been completed; the debtor can 9but is not required) to file and serve the Notice if the trustee does not do so within the 30 day period.  The mortgage holder is required to file a Response to Notice of Final Cure Payment within 21 days of service of the Notice; this means you. Even if you do not dispute the Notice you MUST file this response. If you dispute the notice, a Motion for Determination of Final Cure and Payment can be filed by you or the trustee to request that the Court set a hearing in order to make a determination on the status of the mortgage.

A person who represent herself has a fool for a lawyer.  You enjoy the same 3 options that anyone cited in Florida for a non-mandatory court appearance traffic citation enjoys:  A) Pay it (in which case you will get points assessed on your driver license); B) Elect driving school (in which case points will NOT be assessed, but you can only do this 5 times in your life and cannot do it 2 times within any 12 month period); or C) Set it for Court and challenge it.  In all 3 events you face fines ad court costs on top of what I have outlined, and, regardless of which you choose, in all 3 cases you must make an election within 30 days of issuance of the citation.    That said, in my opinion, the best defense for any traffic citation anywhere is to hire a local traffic ticket lawyer.  I can't speak to the 954 per se but in Miami, Fl, where I have been a practicing criminal defense lawyer for 22+ years, for $49-$99 you will get a lawyer who knows the law, the procedure, the Judge and probably the cop.  In short you will almost certainly get both competent representation and a better result for a relatively small fee / investment.    I hope that I have been helpful in answering your question.

We're increasingly seeing this scenario, particularly in the Inland Empire and surrounding areas - banks are waiting for extended periods of time before attempting to address debts.  As other responses have highlighted, your personal liability to pay the debt was discharged in the bankruptcy so you'll not have any obligations for the mortgage paymets. And the bank can foreclose on the security at any time (so long as they've given you proper notice) but cannot attempt to recover any mortgage payments or pursue any other fees against you. If they choose to let you stay, they can't later try to recover costs.  Keep in mind that the bank can foreclose and at some point someone at the bank will decide it's time to do something about the debt. Once that occurs, you may get another foreclosure notice and may have to find alternative living accomodations.  We've seen these types of situations go on for 4-5 years in some cases.

We here are really not a research pool where we field questions about terms of art and then expound on them. You are entering an arena of statutes written as a result of federal mandates and state-level compromises arrived at to implement the federal mandates. So the statutes are convoluted and have driven you here for an explanation of a meaning.  The "bar" appears in FCA å¤451:     2. (a) The court may modify an order of child  support,  including  an order  incorporating  without merging an agreement or stipulation of the parties, upon a  showing  of  a  substantial  change  in  circumstances.  Incarceration  shall  not  be  a  bar to finding a substantial change in circumstances  provided  such  incarceration  is  not  the   result   of non-payment  of  a  child  support  order,  or  an  offense  against the custodial parent or child who is the subject of the order or judgment.  The section empowers the family court to have continuing jurisdiction to increase or decrease its orders of child support throughout the life of the support case.  In order to increase or decrease the amount of the order, the litigant has to show a "substantial change in circumstances" for the court to increase or decrease the order. Even jailing does not stop the possibility of a finding of a substantial change of circumstances to increase or decrease the order. The two exceptions to this are 1. that the jailing arose from a violation of an order of support and 2. that the jailing occurred as a result of domestic violence against the other parent or the child.  I am not certain how this can help you. You appear to need assistance in overall representation because you may not realize what you are doing in court. The other parent apparently beat you up and landed in jail because of that and you agreed to drop the child support payment to $25 per month. Many litigants tell me they cannot afford me. They then go to family court and demolish their chances at obtaining fair and adequate support for their child. The less they pay me, the more they lose for their child.  You have no need to know the statute because you voluntarily reduced the amount of support the other parent is supposed to pay to the New York State minimum -- $25 per month. His jailing was not a substantial change of circumstances to decrease or increase the order of support (because apparently he beat you up) but you reduced it any way, voluntarily. An order on consent requires a higher burden to vacate. You helped him out enormously in spite of FCA å¤451 which a jurisdictional statute affecting the ability of the court to enter orders. Your consent allowed the court to do so waiving the jurisdictional bar.  I do not see the terms "certain conditions" in FCA å¤451 and I do not see them in the Domestic Relations Law Section 236B so I cannot opine on this now. In the end, the more you represent yourself, the more money you will lose over the twenty one years of the life of the New York child support order.

Dear Hopewell Junction Landlord:  Without a lease provision authorizing self-help in the event of nonpayment of rent, locking out your commercial tenant would be considered a breach of lease, void the obligation to pay rent, and subject the landlord to a lawsuit for damages by reason of the illegal eviction, breach of lease, loss of business opportunity and perhaps far more.  No New York landlord is allowed to conduct an eviction without the use of the court where there is no lease based on nonpayment of rent. Were that not the law, then no landlord would ever face the consequence of an eviction done without a court proceeding.  If you want to end the tenancy, serve a termination of tenancy notice as provided in New York Real Property Law Section 232-b, and at the end of the period set in the notice, commence the summary holdover eviction proceeding.  Or, proceed in the manner most landlords would undertake when the tenant fails to pay the rent. Serve a proper written rent demand, and on the expiration of the three day period provided in the rent demand, if the tenant does not pay or does not move, commence your summary nonpayment proceeding.   Good luck.

You can file a lawsuit in Superior Court for replevin. You can ask the Court for an order to allow you access to the property to collect your things. You start a lawsuit like this with a letter, and you have it delivered by mail, and posted on his door and with any luck have the letter handed to him. It needs to tell him, very clearly, that you want your stuff back and if you have to go to court to get an order so you can get it back, the court can make him pay your reasonable attorney fees and costs of suit for acting so badly and putting you to so much trouble over your personal property. The Court can tell the police to give you a civil standby if necessary.   Make a list of what is yours before you go. Give your ex the opportunity to hand it over voluntarily. If he does not hand over your stuff voluntarily, make it cost him money. In a replevin suit, if things of yours are missing and he doesn't hand them over to you, then he can pay you the value of what he refused to hand over.   Elizabeth Powell

Lockouts are always unlawful. You can be asked to leave - usually a 20-day notice. a 20-day must be served within the first ten days of the month to be effective the last day of the month. If you are served with a 20-day, make other plans to reside elsewhere. If you think your roommate owes you money because you paid all the rent for four months, you can sue your roommate. But an unlawful detainer is a series of trick questions: Did you stay after you got a proper 20-day notice? If yes, you are going to be evicted. That's it and there is no point arguing with the calendar.   There is no counterclaim allowed in unlawful detainer. There is nothing for you to file. If you stay, you will have a permanent black mark on your rental history. Don't do that.   You can move out and sue him for trying to evict you without the benefit of a judge and a sheriff, but you cannot do this while you reside in his property. Elizabeth Powell

It is unfortunate to hear of your troubles with your landlord. Without knowing more facts about your situation I feel as though any opinion I would give regarding your questions about named parties on the 3 day notice or service might not be on point.    With that said here is some information that the courts provide on the 3 day pay or quit notice  There are 3 ways to serve the notice:  Personal service: You or someone else gives the notice directly to the tenant in person. Substituted service: If the tenant is not home, you can leave the notice with a member of the household, at least 18 years old, where the tenant lives AND then mail a second copy to the tenant at the property. Posting and mailing ("nail and mail") service: If there is no one home to leave the papers with, you can tape or nail the notice to the front door or somewhere where it can be seen easily AND send a copy by mail to the tenant at the property.  You can find more information on what is required from the landlord at  http://www.courts.ca.gov/1288.htm  As far as the Demurrer it is an option to file but in order to give my opinion I would need additional facts, such as where you ever mailed the 3 day notice or was anyone, not a minor, at your residence ever given the notice.   Good luck to you.

You have to financially qualify for a public defender.  The court will ask for your financial information and determine whether you qualify or not.  If you do, they'll appoint the PD.    A couple of considerations before deciding what to do:  First - you only have 10 days from the date of your arrest to request a hearing with the DMV or they will automatically suspend your license for four months. The public defender cannot and will not be involved in the DMV proceedings as they are administrative and not criminal in nature. Besides, by the time you go to court, your timeframe to contact the DMV will have come and gone.  A private attorney, on the other hand, can and will assist with the DMV hearings. There may be strategic maneuvers and questioning done at the DMV hearing that set you up for a better outcome in criminal court.  Before deciding that you cannot afford an attorney, use your time wisely and contact a few good local criminal defense attorneys to discuss your case, any possible defenses and payment arrangements.  What I have written in no way is meant to suggest that public defenders cannot or will not do a good job on your DUI case in court. It's just that you have things that happen quickly and before the court case starts that are just as important to you.

Many of your complaints are the reason that the Appeal process exists. Since you indicated that you expect to finally be approved, it sounds like the appeal process has finally provided the type of relieve that it is meant to. The clerical errors that you mentioned unfortunately occur, and are part of the reason that Social Security places so many checks and balances. I do not believe that you will have any type of claim that would provide you with any financial recourse because of the errors that were previously made by the Social Security Administration, DDS, or the Administrative Law Judges. The best thing that you can do is to notify your congressional representatives of the obstacles that are face by individuals that are going through this process.  In terms of your Legal Representatives, you allege some serious accusations of ethical violations. Falsifying contracts and failure to prepare for your hearing are both serious matters. Social Security has a code of conduct that attorneys and non-attorney representatives must follow in order to be permitted to practice before the Social Security Administration. Violation of the Code of Conduct can be reported to the Social Security Administration by following the instructions on its website (http://www.ssa.gov/representation/conduct_standards.htm). If the representatives are also licensed attorneys, most states also have a State Disciplinary Office that complaints of attorney unethical behavioral can be reported to (Texas: http://www.texasbar.com/Content/NavigationMenu/ForLawyers/GrievanceInfoandEthicsHelpline/OfficeOfCDC.htm). Finally you can also contest the attorney fee agreement if it is approved by the ALJ. When the decision is issued, you will have 15 days to file a request to review the attorney fee if you feel that your attorney did not provide you with adequate representation. It is also possible to file a malpractice claim against your attorney, but you might find that there is not a case for malpractice if you are approved for benefits and have no real damages.  I wish you good luck. Before pursuing any other remedies, I would agree with the other attorneys that caution that any further action may be for nothing. Sometimes accepting the positive (the eventual approval) and moving on from what has occurred is the best course of action.

Are you thinking about asylum?  You can apply for asylum in the US if you have a "well-founded fear of persecution" in your country based on (1) political opinion, (2) religion, (3) race, (4) nationality, or (5) membership in a particular social group.   There is no government filing fee for applying for asylum.  If you are outside the US, you may apply for refugee status based on these same criteria. Your fear of persecution must be either by the government of your country or by a group that the government is unable or unwilling to control.   If you are able to establish past persecution, a presumption arises that you have established a well-founded fear of persecution. The burden of proof shifts to the government to demonstrate that circumstances have changed and that you no longer have a well-founded fear of persecution or that you could avoid persecution by relocating in another part of your country and that it would be reasonable for you to do so.   If you are in lawful immigration status, you can submit an application for asylum (Form I-589) directly with the appropriate Asylum  USCIS Service Center specified in the instructions. Should your application be denied, you will remain in lawful status.   However, if you are not in lawful status, should your asylum application not be approved by the USCIS, you will be placed in removal proceedings. If you are in removal proceedings before an Immigration Judge, in addition to applying for asylum, you may be eligible to apply for withholding of removal and for relief under the Convention Against Torture (CAT).

It is impossible to answer this question without reviewing the actual court order.  Many times when lawsuits involve land, they apply to anyone who owned the land and who was involved in the lawsuit, but then the court order binds other interested parties or successors-in-interest -- this means, anyone who later purchases the property or whose property is served by the right of way.  Many times these orders are recorded in the land records to give people notice of what restrictions affect the land.    Unfortunately, the devil is in the details in this instance -- we'd have to see why the lawsuit was brought about in the first place and why the judge crafted the order the way he did.  I wish I could offer you more information, but any lawyer would have to sit down and review the order as well as other documents filed in the case to give you an answer.

To become a public defender you have to first become a lawyer.   To become a lawyer in Florida you have to obtain a 4 year bachelors degree in some course of study, preferably social sciences of some kind.  Then you take a law school entrance exam call the LSAT.  If you receive a high enough score you apply to various law schools for admission.  Once admitted to a law school you study law for 3 years or so in order to receive your degree in law call a Juris Doctorate.   After graduating from law school you are required to take a set of exams given by the Florida Bar to determine whether you learned enough law in law school to be admitted to practice law in Florida. But it isn't enough just to pass the bar exams, you will also be screened for character.  People who have arrest records or mental or substance abuse problems will usually not be admitted to the bar.  So don't get into any trouble on your road to becoming a lawyer.  If you pass the bar exams and the screening, you will then be sworn in to practice law by the Florida Supreme Court.  You are a lawyer.   Next, you have to apply for a job at a public defender office.    I believe the associates degree in liberal arts offered by Polk State College is your first step.  There will be guidance counselors there at Polk State College.  Find one and tell him/her what you are trying to do.  Talk to people there and get as much information as possible.  Be prepared to study hard and to dedicate the next 7 or so years of your life to your dream.  It's not as hard as it sounds.  Its done all the time by young people like you.  And when you are sworn in don't lose your idealism.  Ours is a service profession, make it proud of you.  Good luck and God bless.

If you have entered into a sublease agreement you are bound by the contractual terms contained in the sublease.  The sub-lessor cannot just demand you leave the property.  If you are not paying your rent or you have broken any of the other terms of the sublease your sub-lessor would have to give you a 3 day notice (in Ohio) and then file a complaint for forcible entry and detainer.  You may want to consult with an attorney in your area if you think the sub-lessor is taking this course of action without the right to do so.

I agree with Attorney Moss.  On the surface of things placing a camera in the common area to monitor a pool is considered a reasonable step to monitor the compliance with the association's rules.  At the board meeting you may want to ask what the date was that the cameras were approved and ask for the minutes of that meeting.  The minutes should provide the reasons for their placement and reveal if any board member voted against the proposal.  Other questions you may want to know the answer to: who monitors the recordings and when; what happens to the recordings (do they expire after a certain amount of days) and can the board determine who has access and whether downloading of has occurred.  Submit these questions in writing at least 7 days before the meeting you are going to attend and ask that they be put on the agenda.  Without being on the agenda the board is not allowed by law to answer the questions until the issue is put on an agenda.  Good fortune!

Your son is now of majority age so any agreement he signs will be binding.  If the 2 documents he signed already state not only that he owes your the money and will pay you back, but that he also agrees p and directs- his personal injury attorney to withhold out of any settlement or verdict funds that amount owed to you and that the attorney is to tender those monies to you, then you should be protected as the attorney can be pursued for the money were he to not withhold the funds and your son winds up "blowing it".   If the 2 agreements do not contain such language, have him sign another document that does.  Alternatively, and particularly if it is a substantial sum, you can sue your son and obtain a judgment for the amount owed, then file a motion with the court/judge in charge of his personal injury case asking for an Order directing the monies he gets from the case to be withheld and paid back to you before any balance is turned over to him.

I respectfully disagree with the previous answers that were provided to you.  It is certainly true that "waiting time penalties," from Ca. Lab. Code å¤203, do not apply to your situation. They apply only when full payment has not been made upon termination of the employment relationship.  However, Ca. Lab. Code å¤204 requires that you be paid twice a month (with some exceptions, which you should examine whether they apply). Although it doesn't come with its own penalty provision, the California Labor Code Private Attorneys General Act ("PAGA") applies a penalty to such improper payment. It's not much: $100 for the first violation, and $200 for each successive violation. Since the statute of limitations is 1 year for penalties, the most you could recover would be $2300.  But if there are numerous employees in the same situation, the value might become attractive to an attorney.  I hope this information is helpful to you.  Sincerely, Craig T. Byrnes

Don't give them anything. Period. See your 2 goals below...giving the companies info does NOT help your 2 goals! Good luck on that. Do tell them you are meeting with a bankruptcy attorney shortly and to wait one moth before contacting you and hang up!    Enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what. Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can. You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

The real value of this question is that it teaches lessons, although the lessons carry consequences that are very harsh.   The first lesson is, "No good deed goes unpunished."  This refers of course to your generosity in "ending things amicably," by giving her half your personal injury settlement, thinking, perhaps, what?  It's only fair?  Or, Why spend money fighting in court?   Or, I think she'll get half anyway, which I suppose now you realize isn't correct.   But then, her answer to that was "drop dead," when time came for her to be generous, so your good deed was well punished.  Second, I bet you did all this without the help of a lawyer.  When you choose to do that, you're actually acting as your own attorney, and the applicable lesson is:  "He who represents himself has a fool for a client and an incompetent for a lawyer."  Your lawyer would have had much better answers on what she would get of your personal injury settlement, although not all the lawyers on the site agree with each other about that, (or with me).  Still, they're all giving you better advice than you got from the lawyer you had, which we now know was you.  When you go to court without a lawyer, you pay the consequences.  Tough lessons, right?   Hard to tell if you've got "any recourse" because I can't tell the stage of the proceedings.  Why don't you see a lawyer now and ask him/her?  If the answer is, "I can't afford a lawyer," ask yourself this:  How much did it cost to represent yourself?   You may end up paying more to NOT have one than to pay one up front.  Last lesson:  Pay now or pay later.

You need to contact an attorney that handles probate matters and arrange to open an estate for your grandfather (This will need to be done in the county where he resided at the time of his death.) and then for your mother.  When you meet with the attorney, bring a copy (or ideally the original of your grandfather's will) as well as a copy of any will that your mother signed.  You should also bring a list of your grandfather's relatives who were alive at the time of his death and all of your mother's living relatives.  After you meet with the probate attorney, ask for an estimate of the cost of handling both matters and only hire the attorney, if you are comfortable with the fee arrangement.  If you don't reach a satisfactory agreement with the first attorney, keep contacting attorneys until you find one with whom you want to work, but don't let this wait any longer for resolution.
For most injuries or damages to person or property in the State of Washington, you have three years to settle or start your lawsuit.

Are you asking whether you will be notified of "the person's" VOP court date or the court date for the assault case?  If you mean the assault case in which you are the victim then yes, the State should notify you of that court date because you are a witness they will likely need to testify on that court date.  If you mean the VOP case then you will probably not be notified of the court date unless you are a witness for the State as to the grounds for the VOP charge.

If there is equity in the house it is money and that is what the woman wants. Any interest your husband has directly or indirectly and any interest which he has transfered to you or into the trust within the last several years could be set aside. Your state may have exemptions or other laws which limit a creditor's ability to take an interest in a home. You should consult an experienced local bankruptcy or dent collection attorney who will be able to help you understand exemptions,  fraudulent transfers and avoidable transfer and evaluate what if any thing your husband owns or has owned or transfered that could be reached by creditors.

If you live in IN for more than 6 months, then IN has jurisdiction over this matter.  If the father wants visitation and the child is only 5 years old, he may have to travel to IN instead of expecting the child to travel to his residence - especially since he hasn't seen the child in 3 years.  It's unlikely the child even knows the father at this point.  He will have to file a Modification Petition in WA which will be returnable in IN and you will have to respond in IN and then the IN Magistrate or judge will make a decision regarding visitation for the child.  Noramlly, such visitation will be limited until the child is older and it should remain in IN rather than the child traveling to WA.  Since he moved in the other direction, then it is his obligation to travel to see a child of such tender years.  By the way, has he been supporting the child all this time or not?  That will also play a part in the overall determination of the Court.  You may want to make a counter-Petition seeking child support at a higher amount at this point, even if he has been supporting the child if either or both of your circumstances have substantially changed.  Good luck to all three of you.

In most states a minor who is under the "legal age" for that state can almost always get out of a contract as long as they can give back what they got out of the contract (if you bought a motor vehicle, and it is still in basically the same condition as it was when you got it, then you have to give it back, for example). It may not even matter if you are happy with your purchase or not. That‰Ûªs because most states consider a minor as being unable to fully understand and appreciate the legal consequences of their decisions. To find out how your state law works though, you need to talk to a local attorney who deals with this kind of case. Call your local attorney's Bar Association and ask for a referral to an attorney near you. When your problem involves a motor vehicle, can call Jon Rogers or James Taylor in Salt Lake City. For their contact info, you can go to this web site page for a Free Online 50 State National List of Consumer Law Lawyers http://tinyurl.com/ConsumerAttys (lawyers don‰Ûªt pay to get listed here and most of them are members of the only national association for Consumer Law lawyers, NACA.net). But act quickly because for every legal right you have, there is only a limited amount of time to actually file a lawsuit in court or your rights expire (it's called the statute of limitations), so don't waste your time getting to a Consumer Law attorney and finding out what your rights are. An out-of-state creditor must domesticate a foreign state court judgment under Pennsylvania's Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act before executing against the debtor's property. (I assume this is a New Jersey state court judgment. However, a creditor with a federal court judgment from another state may domesticate a judgment by registering the judgment in the debtor's district.)  Creditors have somewhat limited enforcement ability in Pennsylvania. There is no wage garnishment in Pennsylvania for most debts, other than domestic support obligations, some fines, federal student loans, some taxes, and rent. However, a judgment creditor can levy or garnish a bank account or collect against personal property.   There are some other protections, such as tenancy by the entireties and exemptions for certain types of income (e.g., social security, government benefits, etc.) under Pennsylvania and federal law. You should speak to an attorney who understands debtor defense, debt negotiation, and bankruptcy to review your legal options for dealing with this matter.

You absolutely should speak with an attorney ASAP to discuss your options.  It is possible you can go after your mother for breach of fiduciary duty and fraud.  To get the property back, the 3rd party must have known or should have known that your mother had no right to sell (partition).  This is going to be time consuming and complicated, and if you wait, you may lose your rights to pursue the matter.  If what you are saying is true, you at least have a strong case against your mother for damages.  It would be interesting to see if you could get the property back based upon the facts of the partition.

You can do counter-surveillance on your neighbor, but do not do so to the extent he/she has been doing it.  If they are watching you as much as you say they are then take pictures, record video with date stamp or daily newspaper in the shot.  If they are acting like peeping toms in any way you can have that restrained.  As my colleague stated however, be over prepared in your hearing to present as much evidence as possible.  You might need legal help in drafting the proposed order though.  Although you have rights, so does your neighbor.  Your neighbor can't use his home as a vantage point to make observations about you that are unreasonable.

How far out was your trial set from the date of filing the complaint?  Some counties have backlog and trials are set as much as 18 months out from the trial setting conference.  If this is the case then it is very unlikely that the judge will give you an extension unless you have a very good reason for not completing discovery in such a long period.  However, some court assign trial dates very quickly.  I had a case where the trial date was set for only four months away.  The judge agreed to continue the trial so that we could complete discovery in order to file a motion for summary judgment.    You need to take a critical look at your timing to determine whether a judge will agree that you have a reasonable excuse for not completing discovery in time.  Perhaps you should also consider continuing the trial date by stipulation with the other parties.  Finally, there is likely a deadline imposed by the local rules of the court regarding continuing trial.   Take care of this as soon as you can.

There are some holes that need to be filled. Public Defender's may not have the time to get back to their clients due to their high caseloads, but that does not mean that they are unreliable. If the Riverside County District Attorney filed the charges, that is where you will need to defend.There may be attorneys that would be willing to take payments, but that means taking a risk of not being paid, and once they become attorney of record, they may be locked into the case by the court whether or not they are compensated. If you truly have no money or job, the Public Defender is probably your best bet, and in my observation they are typically very reliable, they just may not have the time to be as attentive as private counsel.

Its a bankruptcy question and not a teal estate question.  If younsigned a forma Reaffirmation Agreement that was filed with the court then you agreed to pay the mortgage in spite of the bankruptcy. That means that not only can they now foreclose,  they can now sue you for any balqnce due after the foreclosure.  Since a creditor is prohibited from contacting you about your debt after bankruptcy unless you did sign a Reaffirmation Agreement and the mortgage company is still contacting you, it looks like you did sign that Agreement. If you did, I think you should try to bring your payments current unless you just give up.  If you find out that you did not sign the Agreement then your mortgage payments after the bankruptcy were just "gifts" and you can just walk away from it now.

SR is an abbreviation for Safety Responsibility.   The Texas Department of Public Safety administers driver's licenses in the state of Texas.  It sounds like you were required to have specialized insurance AKA SR-22.  DPS can be contacted and they will tell you how to clear up your license.  This may mean paying surcharges, obtaining specialized insurance, taking Driver's Safety Course and or other hoops to jump through.  You may even have to file for an occupational driver's license.  Call DPS, visit one of their offices, or go to their website.  IF you still feel overwhelmed and confused, you can hire an attorney to find out answers for you. FYI this is probably more expensive.

Although it may be annoying, your neighbor is allowed to install cameras that cover areas that would be open to public view.  The camera facing the street is allowed. Most likely the camera facing the side of your house is also allowed.  If that part of your house is visible from the street, sidewalk, alley, etc., then it would be considered to be within a public area.  There is probably not much you could do about this. Since the mother is falsely accusing you, this may actually be a blessing.  The cameras may conceivably establish that you did not trim the backyard vines.   By the way, if the vines intrude onto your property, as long as you do not harm or kill them by doing so, you can trim the parts on your side of the fence.

While I generally agree with Mr. Harvey, things are somewhat more lax in the California Employment Development Department (EDD) and the Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board (UIAB) hearings. More often than one would expect, a UIAB administrative law judge will grant relief for "good cause," as that term is defined by the the UIAB Precedent Benefit Decisions.    The Notice of Determination stating your claim was denied includes information about the appeal. You MUST file your appeal within 20 days of the date stated in that letter. Do not miss the deadline. In the appeal, make a brief statement saying why you believe the denial was incorrect. Save your detailed argument and evidence for the hearing. For example: "I had good cause to miss the deadline or not notify EDD of my interest in training."   In a few weeks, you will receive notice of an appeals hearing with the date, time and location. At the hearing, be prepared with as much evidence as possible to establish good cause. You should also know the law the administrative law judge will consider. You can get a lot of helpful information on the EDD website.  Home page http://www.edd.ca.gov/Unemployment/ Eligibility requirements http://www.edd.ca.gov/unemployment/Eligibility.htm Summaries of the law (Benefit Determination Guide) http://www.edd.ca.gov/UIBDG/  Appeals http://www.edd.ca.gov/Unemployment/FAQ_-_Appeals.htm Precedent Decisions (law the administrative law judges rely on) http://www.cuiab.ca.gov/precedent_decisions.shtm  Frequently asked questions http://www.edd.ca.gov/unemployment/FAQs.htm Filing a claim for unemployment benefits http://www.edd.ca.gov/unemployment/Filing_a_Claim.htm  You can be represented by anyone at the hearing. If your appeal will be difficult or you are uncomfortable speaking, you may wish to retain an attorney to help you prepare or to represent you. For training, expect the attorney to need approximately three hours. For hearing representation, expect the attorney to need three to seven hours to prepare, depending on the complexity of the case, witnesses, documents and other evidence, and allow two hours for the hearing itself. Unemployment hearings usually last one hour or less, but you must arrive early to look at the file and there is a possibility you will have to wait for the previous case to finish.   Generally, as of 2014, plaintiffs employment attorneys in California charge between $250 and $700 per hour for legal services. The amount varies based on experience, location, attorney availability, attorney interest in the case, complexity of the matter, and more. To find a plaintiffs employment attorney in California, visit the California Employment Lawyers Association (CELA) at www.cela.org. CELA is the largest and most influential bar association in the state for attorneys representing working people. You can search for attorneys by location and practice area. Many CELA attorneys represent clients throughout the state.  Marilynn Mika Spencer  San Diego, CA

You have struck one of my pet peeves.  Federal Court judicial officers usually prepare their own orders.  The Court for your case might have "local rules" addressing the procedure for this, and http://www.courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index.cfm?title=five&linkid=rule5_125 sets forth the State procedural rule for this.   In the San Diego Courts, attorneys often default on their obligations in this regard and often enough are allowed by the Court to withdraw from these cases without having completed their obligations and enforcement is lax.  However, the State is insolvent and now doesn't have the staff to do this work.  Perhaps clients and attorneys alike should be more frugal on the burdens they impose on our underfunded Courts.

I agree with the previous answers and the company must be licensed in Washington to contact the residents to collect debt, furthermore you are not responsible for anyone's debts but your own. You need to consult with a consumer protection or bankruptcy lawyer locally for private and specific advice on your particular issues.    Many lawyers on this site offer a free consultation and you can find one near you, make an appointment for legal counseling, and take your paperwork and a written chronological summary. 1. Keep a detailed log of all calls and letters and a paper file of all information.  Because persistent violations of the FDCPA are punishable by statutory fines and attorney‰Ûªs fees under federal law, but you need hard evidence.    2. Make a written demand that all further communications from creditors is in writing under 15 USC 1692 (c).  The letter should also contain a dispute of the validity of the charges and include a demand for a complete accounting with signatures, and all contents of their file.  The creditor then has 30 days to reply and they may take no action until you have been sent the validation.  Remember this may be motivation for the collector to work your account when the file comes to them from the original creditor with new information pressure from the original creditor to collect.  3. Do not give them any personal information because that is how collectors decide on which accounts to recommend suing.  Remember they may not tell the truth and will say just about anything to get a payment from you and that payment reaffirms the debt, gives them information about you and your bank and ability to pay.    4. If you will make payments use money orders only and never personal checks, wire transfers, money grams, or "check by phone." If the collector finds a bank account, the collector will be more likely recommend a lawsuit to their legal department.   5. Collections are negotiable; the original creditor has given up and is losing up to 50% on the face value already either by splitting any return or selling at a huge discount.  In addition, the costs of a lawsuit although discounted still are a factor in the decision to settle with you. If you will settle mark the check "settled-in-full" at the very top back of the check and include a letter explaining that you are offering a settlement, keep copies of everything.  6. Get written confirmation of any payment plan the agency will accept before making a payment. 7. Specify in writing that all payments shall apply to principle first. If you‰Ûªre ready to throw in the towel, go see a local bankruptcy attorney and explore your options for federal protection.  The protection will even look back 90 days from filing, take back money by the collectors, and apply it fairly.  DO NOT use a paid debt settlement service; most are scammers.  Links to your  rights; http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/edu/pubs/consumer/credit/cre27.pdf  Debt validation template http://www.credityoda.com/debt-validation-letter.html  Look for a qualified consumer protection attorney for a low cost or free consultation:   http://www.naca.net     If this answer was helpful, please mark as helpful below. Indicate the best answer.  Good Luck  You can search the Avvo web site under the Find a Lawyer tab. Act quickly because for every legal right you have, there is only a limited amount of time to file a lawsuit in court or your rights expire (it's called the statute of limitations), so don't waste your time getting to an attorney and finding out what your rights are.   Washington collection agency complaint form: http://www.dol.wa.gov/forms/600006E.pdf   Washington statute regulating collection agencies: http://apps.leg.wa.gov/rcw/default.aspx?cite=19.16   Consumer rights in Washington: http://www.dol.wa.gov/business/collectionagency...  Good Luck

Is there a court order in place defining the terms of custody? if so, does that order specify drop off and pick-up locations?  If he has made physical threats, you may want to file for a restraining order, (which does not physically protect you, it is just a piece of paper, so be careful). Often, pick-up and drop-off transfers can be ordered to occur at public places or at police or sheriff stations to insure that things do not get out of control.  The bottom line is that there needs to be more specific information, and there is a good chance that you do not need to disclose where you live if you can establish a fear for your safety. I would suggest that you get the court involved and have an order issued to establish the facts. And by all means, if you think you and/or your child is in danger get into court immediately to modify the shared custody. If you cannot afford an attorney, check with the court's self help center.

If it is an actual lien against the property, it never "expires" - the lien has to be paid, or the lien holder can assert their rights (like demand payment at closing, which is your current dilemma). If you are, they'll have to be paid at closing by you.  Condo liens in FL expire after 1 year, but that doesn't apply to HOA liens on homes.  It could become uncollectable due to the SOL expiring. I'm very sorry you're going through this.  And as if things weren't already hard enough, her estate will need to be probated before the property passes to you.  Had you owned as joint tenants, the property would pass directly to you but as tenants in common, her å_ ownership is subject to the probate process.  If she had sufficient funds and other property to cover any debts and expenses that have arisen or may arise, then you should be able to receive the property outright fairly soon.  But if she has debts and expenses that exceed her available funds, the property may have to be partitioned and sold to cover her debts from her å_ ownership in the property.  If you feel that this may be the case, or if you simply want help probating her estate, you should obtain a free consultation with a probate attorney. Usually a DOJ rap sheet will show all arrests, whether they result in convictions or not.  This "should not" be accessible to anyone other than you, and law enforcement and court.  Technically, if you never pled guilty nor were found guilty, and were not sentenced, then you should not have to disclose this incident, as it is certainly not a conviction.  Also there are various statutes that prohibit asking re arrests instead of convictions, since an arrest is not proof of anything, and should not be used against you  Good luck, Joel

In Massachusetts, a landlord may not evict you for reporting a suspected lead paint violation or any other health code violation to the Board of Health or other agency. Such action is generally considered a retaliatory eviction, and it can have serious consequences for the landlord. Broadly speaking, if a landlord tries to evict a tenant within 6 months after the tenant has complained to the Board of Health or other such similar agency regarding the existence of code violations at the rental unit (e.g. lead paint where a child under 6 is living in the apartment) there is a presumption that such action is retaliatory in nature, and the landlord could be liable to the tenant for up to 3 months rent, plus attorneys fees and costs, pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186 s. 18.   The presumption can be rebutted if the landlord shows that he or she was evicting the tenant for justifiable reasons such as nonpayment of rent, but based on your question it appears that you are current on rent, and in any event you may be entitled to withhold rent if there are significant code violations in existence at your apartment. Also, you may have a separate cause of action for discrimination if the landlord is attempting to evict you because you are asserting your rights as a tenant under the law, particularly based on the facts you outline.   If the landlord has filed a complaint to evict you, also called a summary process action, it is important that you file an answer and/or counterclaim to avoid a default judgment if you seek to contest the eviction. Such a filing is very time sensitive and you should ensure that you act quickly to protect your rights.

Convicted felons cannot own or possess firearms. However, hope is not lost. Post-conviction relief may be available to you. Second degree burglary is a wobbler, which means it can be charged as a misdemeanor or a felony. An attorney may be able to successfully petition the court, pursuant to Penal Code 17(b), to have the felony reduced to a misdemeanor. If this is your only felony conviction, and you have no misdemeanor conviction carrying a 10-year ban that currently applies, then this should restore your gun rights. There are a number of qualifications and exceptions to this, so you need to speak with an attorney. Get an attorney who will fight to restore your gun rights. Good luck.

If a termination happens before the filing of the joint petition, then you file requesting a waiver or other alternative ground.  If there is a termination of the marriage after the filing of the joint petition, the government will convert the petition in to a waiver case if the termination is completed before the government addresses the petition.   If the divorce is still pending and USCIS acts, you will have to start a new while facing the prospect of the government commencing removal proceedings against you too.

Most lawyers advise people not to bother paying civil demands sent related to alleged shoplifting. You haveto maintain continuous residence for five years (3 if married to American) and 30 months pysical presence (18 if married to American). Physical presence is accumulated, as long as you have the 30 months at any time during the five years, while continuous residence is interrupted by absences of more than 6 months. Therefore, you are correctly stating that if you are not out of the U.S. more than 6 months at a time and are physically present at least 30 months, not necessarily 6 months every year, you will be OK.

It's both a workers' compensation case and personal injury. There is an exclusion in workers' compensation cases for horseplay, but it does not apply IF you were not participating in the horseplay. In other words, if your co-worker just bear hugged you and you did nothing to provoke him, the horseplay defense cannot be used against you. I would not pursue the case unless you are going to be out of work for a significant amount of time while you recover. In terms of money damages in the personal injury case (it's actually the tort of battery), the amount would be determined by a jury, and could include pain and suffering. However, if this man doesn't have any assets (you say he is a poor man), recovering anything from him will be difficult (insurance wouldn't cover this type of action in most cases). Before you hire a workers' compensation lawyer, make sure you ask them what impact filing a claim will have on your job.

YES. That program has a big plus and a big minus. The plus is that you get priority examination if you include a "glossary" of the terms that are used in the claims of your software patent application. The minus is that you have to limit the scope of your claims when you include a "glossary" of the terms that are used in the claims of your software patent application. You should have a patent attorney explain why plus and why minus.   In superficially simple terms, the glossary will be used against you in litigation to restrict the scope of your claims by every defendant seeking to obtain a finding of noninfringement of those claims, as well as for you during examinations to restrict the scope of your claims for purposes of avoiding the application of prior art to those claims. So, using the glossary is a double-edged sword and should be done only by a skilled patent prosecution attorney.  I suggest you go to www.USPTO.gov and type "glossary pilot program" in the search window at the upper right-hand corner of the home page in order to obtain more information on this.

You can make a demand for exchange of expert witness information pursuant to CCP 2034.210. This will obligate the opposing party to provide you with (1) A brief narrative statement of the qualifications of each expert; (2) A brief narrative statement of the general substance of the testimony that the expert is expected to give;  (3) A representation that the expert has agreed to testify at the trial; (4) A representation that the expert will be sufficiently familiar with the pending action to submit to a meaningful oral deposition concerning the specific testimony, including any opinion and its basis, that the expert is expected to give at trial; and (5) A statement of the expert's hourly and daily fee for providing deposition testimony and for consulting with the retaining attorney.  In order to obtain more information than this, you are going to have to depose the expert.

Did the trial court provide a reason for denying your motion? I ask because it is, in my experience, unusual for the court to issue a denial.    As for remedies - a writ petition might be overkill.  I would consider simply filing a motion in the court of appeal asking it to direct the trial court to grant the motion.  Whether that succeeds, of course, will depend in part on the reason, if any, for the trial court to do what it did.    Finally, please remember that you cannot rely on my post as legal advice.  The idea of filing a motion is only a suggestion, and there may be reasons why, after all, you should pursue a writ or reasons why you do not need the a summary of that hearing at all.  These are decisions that even experienced appellate lawyers think long and hard about.

Similar inquiries have been posed to the IRS in the past and the IRS has responded. A taxpayer may deduct a contribution that is to or for the use of a church (or other charity). However for the contribution to be deductible, the church must have full control of the donated funds and discretion as to their use. This ensures that the church will use the funds to carry out the church‰Ûªs functions and purposes. In this case, it appears that the church has established a fund for the specific purpose of accepting donations to benefit the Pastor, so it would appear that the funds are being placed within the church's control as opposed to a designated gift where no such fund existed and the donor was directing the use of the funds.  However, the IRS clarified that to deduct a contribution, the donor‰Ûªs intent in making the payment must have been to benefit the church and not an individual recipient. An individual church member‰Ûªs contribution to the church that is designated for the benefit of the minister is not deductible as a charitable contribution. It is unclear to me that the establishment of this fund by the Church makes any difference to the deductibility of the gift, although clearly it will go where you intend.  When a church member wishes to provide funds for a pastor, it is best to make the gift directly to the pastor. The gifts may not be tax-deductible for the donor, bur are generally not taxable to the pastor.

I agree with everything my colleagues have already written.  Thus I will not repeat.    However, there are a few things my colleagues have left out.  First you will one year to file an action under the Private Attorney General's Act for civil penalties against your employer.  Additionally in my experience, some employers will also deduct 30 minutes from your time, even though you have worked all day, when they alter the computer records to make it appear as if you taken all your breaks.    Outside of employing a computer expert to go through the change logs on the computer, there are ways you prove you worked through your breaks.    First many fast food restaurants make you punch a number into the cash register.  This number not only appears in your timecard but also on the receipt of every customer you ring up.   Thus a receipt with your personal identification number, and  the date and time   the transaction occurred is created by the cash register. Forward transactions you ring up during your "lunch breaks", the cash register receipt is proof you are working. Either save the receipt or take a photo of it with your cell phone.  I agree with the other attorneys, you need to speak to a lawyer experienced in wage and hour law as soon as possible. I hope this helps.
