If the will was probated, it should be in the court's file.  In Tarrant County, you have to go in person to the Tarrant County Clerk's Office - Probate Section and request a copy.  There is a small fee for a "regular" copy and a larger fee for a "certified" copy.  If the will was probated in another county, the procedure is most likely the same, but call the county clerk's office and ask.

In New Jersey a life insurance policy with no beneficiary passes into the estate.  This means if your son had no Will, someone will need to open his estate with the Surrogate as an Administration.  If he had no spouse and no children, both parents will have equal chance to open this estate, so you had best retain an attorney who focuses his practice on Probate and Surrogate's work, as their may be a fight.  Whomever is named will first use the funds to pay his debts and creditors, which includes reimbursing whomever paid for his funeral. Then the assets will likely be divided equally between you and his dad.  If you are seen as trying to exclude the father, the Surrogate may decide to not allow you to be the Administrator, so even though you may not like it, it is best if you move forward having your attorney take the position that you understand the situation and will abide by the law.  As the Administrator, you also will receive a fee, so you can at least get that much more than his father.  I would move quickly, as the father is likely thinking of doing the same thing.

A person is not entitled to a tourist visa. The decision to issue a tourist visa is discretionary. Something in your background has triggered further scrutiny. Unfortunately, there is not enough information to try to assess why your request for a tourist visa has to be reviewed by Washington, D.C.   I encourage you to schedule a consultation with an experienced immigration attorney.

I complete all documents to sign within 1 or 2 days always after client provides all . Some attorneys do  not do that quickly as they may do other areas of law, or be in court. It is up to your contract. Once filed. , the case is discharged about 105 days later approximately.   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later

Whether you are the plaintiff or defendant will not make a difference in terms of what happens in a divorce.  You do have a very short term marriage so there is most likely little or any alimony that will be paid, but that also depends on the specific facts of your case.  As for equitable distribution what usually happens is that any funds accumulated during the marriage, whether in joint names or one party's name, are subject to being shared.  So the fact she saved money in her name during the marriage does not mean she gets to keep it.  You are most likely entitled to a portion of what is in her bank account.  However, you really need to consult an attorney to discuss the facts of your case, but it is impossible to give you the advice you need with the limited information that is provided.

You cannot recover emotional distress in small claims. Even if this was not small claims, you cannot get emotional distress for failure to pay money damages. When someone owes you money and they do not pay, you get interest. Not money for emotional distress.

You need to consult an experienced dependency and neglect lawyer as soon as possible.  There are too many dynamics in the situation you describe for me to provide you a complete and comprehensive answer without knowing a lot more about the case.  You should be advised that anything you say to the caseworker, or anything that you post on public internet forums like this one (if discovered), can and will be taken down and used against you in court if DHS decides to open a dependency and neglect case.  Accordingly, you should not make any sort of admissions about drug use or anything else to the caseworker or the police.  You are likely being investigated because a confidential informant reported that you are using drugs or that you appear to be under the influence around your children.  As long as there are no court orders preventing you from leaving the jurisdiction and no court case open on your children, you are free to go anywhere you wish without government interference.  Once a court case is opened however, you will not be free to take your children out of the jurisdiction without leave of the juvenile court judge or magistrate.  Additionally, you have the absolute right to not discuss anything with the department of human services and or the police, and you have the right not to consent to any searches of your home or person (including drug testing).  With that said, it is important for you to understand that should you choose not to cooperate, the caseworker will likely attempt to get an order to place the children from the juvenile court, and open a dependency and neglect case on your family.  Whether such an order is issued will depend on how much evidence the caseworker has already acquired and whether it is legally sufficient to persuade the judge to grant authority to the department of human services to place the children.  Those are your rights.  Mr. Leroi is quite correct in his answer in suggesting that child protective services has a great deal of power.  You should retain an attorney without delay.  Hope that helps.  Good luck!

The agreement may obligate the employer to provide you with at least one year of employment. However, in order to be sure the entire agreement must be reviewed. If the agreement is ambiguous (as to the employer's commitment to employ you for a specific duration) then the agreement is at will, and you are free to resign at any time. As for the ability of the employer to enjoin you from working elsewhere (if you do not complete the one year) a covenant not to compete must be found necessary to protect an employee's legitimate interest, such as protection of trade secrets, protection of confidential customer information, protection of an employee's client base or protection against irreparable harm where an employee's services are unique or extraordinary. Otherwise, such a restriction on your right to work will not be likely upheld. Good luck.

Question 21 on the I-130 is very straightforward: write the last address where you and your wife last lived together. If you are living together with your wife now, write the address of the place where you currently live.  Generally, when a form asks for your "residence address," it is asking for the address of the place where you live. If it asks for "mailing address" and you would prefer that you receive mail at a place other than where you live, then enter that address. If, however, you receive mail at the same place where you live, you can write the same address for both residence address and mailing address.

If that was your first criminal conviction then it's possible you were placed on diversion (a form of probation for first time offenders that when successfully completed allows the charge to be expunged.).  If so , then all you have to do is go to the court clerk's office and pay an expungement fee to have the charges removed.  If you were not on diversion then you must wait 5 years from the conviction date and then apply to have it expunged.   The Nashville Court Clerk has a great website that explains the process.      http://da.nashville.gov/portal/page/portal/da/expungementsUnder40-32-101g/   If you don't qualify for that procedure then the only other likely option would be to apply for a pardon from the Governor of TN or the President of the United States.

If the judge found that your ex was a danger to you, but not to your children, the plenary order would properly name you as a protected party but not your children. The purpose of the domestic violence act is to protect persons at risk of abuse (as defined by the act). If you feel that your children are in danger and that the judge should have named them as protected persons, you can file a motion to reconsider and ask the judge to name them as protected persons. There are certain procedural hurdles you may face in prevailing upon such a motion and such hurdles may reflect the amount of time that has lapsed between the entry of the plenary order and the date of filing of your motion. You should consult with an attorney to assess the merits of such a request.

You very likely need no permission.  A building habitable or useable by humans and created after December 1, 1990 is, under copyright law, an "architectural work" to which copyright may attach.  Buildings created before or which are not human habitable or useable are not copyright-protected.   The scope of that copyright protection extends to "the overall form as well as the arrangement and composition of spaces and elements in the design" but does NOT include  (1) "individual standard features" nor  (2) the right to prevent the making, distributing, or public display of pictures, paintings, photographs, or other pictorial representations" of the building if it's located in or ordinarily visible from a public place. See 17 U.S.C. sections 101 and 120(a).  Moreover, ornamental features of a building that are integrated so as to further the purpose of the building design and so form "part of the functional and architectural vocabulary of the building" fall within the building‰Ûªs copyright and are NOT separable works.  See, the court decision cited to via the link below.  So ‰Û_ only some buildings qualify for copyright protection and of those that do if they‰Ûªre in or ordinarily visible [i.e., not via Google Earth, etc.] from a public place it‰Ûªs lawful to sell photographs of those buildings.   The visual depiction of some buildings serve as a trademark to brand a product or service. But not many. And, in any event, a photograph of any such building would very, very likely not display the same perspective of the building or be anywhere close to presenting the same visual appearance as that used as the trademark. And even if it did, selling the photograph would very, very likely not infringe the trademark because the photograph is not the product or service being branded or one related [unless the branded product is postcards and posters in which case you shouldn‰Ûªt turn your photographs into those products].  And, moreover, a photograph is an artistic work which has its own First Amendment protection which the trademark owner would have to overcome to prove infringement. In short, there is very little risk from trademark law.  Your own intellectual property attorney must evaluate your plan, however, before you put it into action because there are always more facts in play that need to be discussed in private. Good luck.

You hold a remainder interest in your father's home, behind your father's life estate.  Your bankruptcy lawyer advised that this had no value because it is a future interest.  I agree with all the answers provided so far, that it is a present interest that a trustee can sell.  I'll add two points.  First, I use a 50% "marketability discount" factor when valuing your remainder interest.  For example, property is worth $400,000 and has a $100,000 mortgage, leaving $300,000 equity.    Perhaps the IRS mortality tables suggest the life estate in the $300,000 of equity is worth $100,000 (mostly depending on your father's age). This leaves $200,000 for you and your three siblings' remainder interests.  I repeat what you've been told:  Your remainder interest is a present interest that can be sold even though you don't have any rights to possess or occupy.  $200,000 for all four siblings means your remainder interest has a "book" value of $50,000. The folks who will buy these interests use a 50% discount rule of thumb, meaning they might actually pay about $25,000 for your interest.  Your trustee likely will accept this from you or your family instead of trying to auction off your interest.  $25,000 is the starting point for measuring any malpractice damage - and you might ask your bankruptcy attorney to pay it.  Still, malpractice is not an easy analysis.  How much debt did you get rid of.  Could you have re-transferred your remainder interest back to your father and wait out the four year fraudulent transfer period?  The real point is whether you would have filed bankruptcy knowing that the remainder interest was at risk.  Your bankruptcy attorney did not cause that risk.  Would you have filed if you knew all this beforehand?  Good luck.

Generally if his last known address was in county A that is where the publication is run.  If you know the other parent has moved away to state A but not the county, then the county of the case.  "Service by publication on party that cannot otherwise be served. - A party that cannot with due diligence be served by personal delivery, registered or certified mail, or by a designated delivery service authorized pursuant to 26 U.S.C. å¤ 7502(f)(2) may be served by publication. Except in actions involving jurisdiction in rem or quasi in rem as provided in section (k), service of process by publication shall consist of publishing a notice of service of process by publication once a week for three successive weeks in a newspaper that is qualified for legal advertising in accordance with G.S. 1-597 and G.S. 1-598 and circulated in the area where the party to be served is believed by the serving party to be located, or if there is no reliable information concerning the location of the party then in a newspaper circulated in the county where the action is pending. If the party's post-office address is known or can with reasonable diligence be ascertained, there shall be mailed to the party at or immediately prior to the first publication a copy of the notice of service of process by publication. The mailing may be omitted if the post-office address cannot be ascertained with reasonable diligence. Upon completion of such service there shall be filed with the court an affidavit showing the publication and mailing in accordance with the requirements of G.S. 1-75.10(a)(2), the circumstances warranting the use of service by publication, and information, if any, regarding the location of the party served. The notice of service of process by publication shall (i) designate the court in which the action has been commenced and the title of the action, which title may be indicated sufficiently by the name of the first plaintiff and the first defendant; (ii) be directed to the defendant sought to be served; (iii) state either that a pleading seeking relief against the person to be served has been filed or has been required to be filed therein not later than a date specified in the notice; (iv) state the nature of the relief being sought; (v) require the defendant being so served to make defense to such pleading within 40 days after a date stated in the notice, exclusive of such date, which date so stated shall be the date of the first publication of notice, or the date when the complaint is required to be filed, whichever is later, and notify the defendant that upon his failure to do so the party seeking service of process by publication will apply to the court for the relief sought..."

This sounds like a spot delivery or conditional sales contract conditioned on approval of a finance company. Its sometimes called Yo-Yo financing, sign and drive, and a host of other names.  They are also sometimes called "Bushing Contracts". This seems to be the latest marketing ploy to get people into a car, without any regard to credit worthiness. Your deal generally has to be financed within a certain period of time or else the dealer is stuck financing the deal him or herself, or you end up with a higher interest rate or more onerous terms.  In all probability you already qualified for a loan, but the dealer is angling for a higher origination fee and a higher interest rate which translates into additional gravy.  There is an article on this here:  http://www.lemonlaw.com/spotdelivery.html  You should review your contract and see if there is a cancellation clause in it. The dealer can request the car back. If so you should get your down payment and any trade in back.  If you encounter issues like this its best to contact a consumer protection lawyer in your area. Many of these contracts violate a host of state laws, including consumer protection acts and the state and federal Reg Z requirements and disclosures.

First of all, sorry about your loss.  In order to be successful in any medical malpractice case you have to prove that the conduct of the medical practitioner fell below the standard that was/is expected of medical practitioners of like position, place, circumstances, etc. AND that the conduct caused the death of your husband.  I am not sure how the physician could have caused the emphysema or how the doctor could have (or should have) treated your husband any different.   Additionally  you will have to make a claim with against the federal government which requires compliance with Federal Tort Claims Act.  The Federal Tort Claims Act prescribes a uniform procedure for handling of claims against the United States, for money damages only, on account of damage to or loss of property, or personal injury or death, caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of a Government employee while acting within the scope of his or her office or employment, under circumstances where the United States, if a private person, would be liable in accordance with the law of the place where the act or omission occurred.  A claim against the United States, predicated on a negligent or wrongful act or omission of an employee of the Department of Veterans Affairs acting within the scope of his or her employment, may be filed by the injured person or his or her legal representative using Standard Form 95, Claim for Damage, Injury, or Death; however, use of the SF 95 is not mandatory, so long as the requirements are met that there is a signature of the appropriate claimant, sufficient information to investigate the allegation, and a sum certain demand.  The completed and signed claim should be submitted directly to the Regional Counsel having jurisdiction of the area wherein the occurrence complained of took place.  A tort claim must be filed within two years of the date the claim accrued. This generally means that the Regional Counsel must receive the completed claim form within two years of the accident or injury which gave rise to the claim, but may run from the time when the claimant knew or should have known of the injury.  You can also file a 1151 claim.   Title 38 U.S.C. Section 1151 allows VA to pay compensation for death or disability "as if service-connected." Don't be confused with this subtle difference. The disability is not considered service-connected. Under Section 1151, benefits may be paid for: - Injuries incurred or aggravated while receiving VA-sponsored medical treatment.  - Injuries incurred or aggravated while pursuing a course of vocational rehabilitation under 38 U.S.C. Chapter 31 or participating in compensated work therapy under 38 U.S.C. 1718.  If eligibility is established under Section 1151, the disability is considered service-connected for payment purposes ONLY.

You need to get to the bottom of what happened by showing your receipts. Without video evidence or tape recordings or conclusive documentary evidence showing that they acted intentionally, you would not have a case against them because they enjoy immunity so long as they act within the course and scope of their employment.

The information B of A may give you literally cannot be trusted.  Their corporate bureaucracy is so massive and disorganized that no single person you talk to will know much about your whole file, and the information they have may be out of date or conflicting.  Even if the person on the phone says they know what's happening, they may not understand the information they are looking at and be misinterpreting it.  Do not trust that your loan modification process will postpone or halt the foreclosure.  They may just auction your house while you are working on the loan mod - they are not required to postpone foreclosure.  The loan mod department and the foreclosure department (actually a subcontractor) are separate and do not seem to coordinate well.  The only thing you can trust regarding your foreclosure are the documents that are recorded with the county.  Keep an eye on the recorded Notices of Trustee's Sale, and cancellations of those notices.  That's the only solid way to tell whether they might auction your house soon.

It sounds like you parted with the "executive rights."  The executive right is the exclusive right to grant mineral leases of specified land or mineral rights.  Unless restricted by contract it includes the right to retain bonuses and rentals.  The owner of the executive right may lease the land or mineral rights over which he has power to the same extent and on such terms and conditions as if he were the owner of a mineral servitude.  2006 Louisiana Laws - RS 31:105

Hello,  I had a client in CA go through the same thing, and though the rules may differ in TN., the bottom line was that the final accounting had to be completed to the county clerk's satisfaction. Finally, we met with the county clerk and went through everything item by item to insure that we got it right -- the way she wanted it -- and after 3 years, she closed the conservatorship.  I recommend that you try the same -- you cannot fight "city hall"  Good luck.

If he sues you, hire a hungry young lawyer if you can't afford an older experienced lawyer.  Damages in this type of case are typical to prove, i.e., bystander liability or third party lawsuits.  A lawyer would need more details on the facts, but here is the generral law in bystander cases with the warning that there may be more specific law to your facts that might help you or might help your opponent  ...I am assuming that the father is alleging he watched the altercation and is emotionally damaged, etc. from it: Duty owed to "bystander" plaintiffs - Bystander plaintiffs need not show a duty owing from the negligent defendant to themselves. Rather, they must show defendant breached a duty of care toward the bystander plaintiffs' family member, which caused emotional distress to the bystander. The bystander's claim is essentially derivative of the family member's claim for negligence. [Thing v. La Chusa (1989) 48 C3d 644, 668, 257 CR 865, 881.]  The case site is to the main case precedent in California that all other appellate cases site first.

Under the statute for child support in Massachusetts, all child support stops at age 23.  The statute does not have any set of circumstances that allows child support after age 23.

Unfortunately, it appears that you should have consulted an experienced landlord-tenant attorney before sending out the notice to quit, because the situation you have described requires that prior serving such a notice, the landlord must first serve a Notice To Cease.  Under New Jersey's Anti-Eviction Law, there are 17 enumerated causes for terminating a lease and many of them require both notices be sent before a landlord can begin eviction proceedings.  When a tenant is being accused of breaching the terms of the lease, as you are alleging here, both notices must be served in the proper sequence.  Therefore, you must first serve your tenant with a Notice to Cease, which must specify the behavior that is in breach of the lease and must demand that the tenant cease said behavior within a specified amount of time.  Once that notice is served and the time for performance has passed, then the Notice to Quit with Demand for Possession must be served.  Unless you have followed the law to the letter, the court will not have the authority to grant a judgment for possession.  Therefore, your father will have to start the process again, serving the proper notices in the proper order.  Once said notices are properly served and the time for compliance passes without cooperation from the tenant, a Complaint for Summary Dispossess can be filed with the Middlesex County Special Civil Part, Landlord-Tenant Section.  The court will serve the tenant(s) and schedule a trial date, which is usually set within 2 to 3 weeks after service.  If the landlord is granted a judgment for possession, it will at least another 8 days before lock-out can occur.  A warrant for removal can be requested 3 days after judgment is entered and then it takes the court-appointed officers who are the only persons authorized to lock out tenants another 5+ days to actually put out the tenants.  Regarding your ability to access the property to assess damages while the tenants are still in possession, such access must be done upon reasonable notice, which is usually considered to be at lease 24 hours in advance.  If such access is perceived to infringe upon the the tenants' right to the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in every rental lease, you could be in for claim of breach of contract on your part, so be careful not to abuse the access process.  Your father can certainly file a collection action against the tenants for whatever damages they have caused to the property and/or for unpaid rents that exceed what you are holding as security deposit.  It is not always a question of the possibility of winning that is important; the question regarding the possibility of collecting on such a judgment may be more important factor to consider in deciding whether to move forward with such an action.    Most attorneys will charge an hourly fee for such cases, the rates for which vary from attorney to attorney, so you must ask each attorney that you consult for their fees.

Choosing to handle this on your own would be a mistake and could severely jeopardize your ability to make a full recovery for your brother's death.

I wish there were a law requiring fairness at work, but there isn't.  Unfortunately, employees and job applicants have very few employment rights, and employers have a lot of leeway in how they choose to run their businesses. In general, an employer can be unfair, obnoxious or bad at management. And an employer can make decisions based on faulty or inaccurate information.  An employer has no obligation to warn an employee that he or she is not performing as the employer wants. It‰Ûªs not a level playing field. An employer hires employees to provide work for its benefit, not for the benefit of the employees. Don't expect the employer to take care of its employees; it doesn‰Ûªt have to and it rarely does.  There are some limitations on what an employer can do, mostly in the areas of public policy (such as discrimination law or whistle blowing), contract law, union-employer labor relations, and constitutional due process for government employees. Please see my guide to at-will employment in California which should help you understand employment rights: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/an-overview-of-at-will-employment-all-states.  After you take a look at the guide, you may be able to identify actions or behavior that fits one of the categories that allows for legal action. If so, an experienced plaintiffs employment attorney may be helpful.  Employment rights come from the state and federal legislatures. One of the best things people can do to improve their employment rights is vote for candidates with a good record on pro-employee, anti-corporate legislation. Another way to protect employment rights is to form or affiliate with a union, or participate in a union already in place.  I hope there is a good resolution to this situation.

The ADA only requires a "reasonable accommodation," and allowing you to work remotely via telecom from another country due to cancer treatment that you could just as easily get in the US does NOT sound like a reasonable accommodation. This does not sound like a viable case.  However, to be sure, consult with an employment attorney.  I will also point out that if you were working in the US on an immigrant visa, and additional visa charges, tax issues and related matters would arise from this "accommodation,"  it makes it look even less reasonable.  If your cancer treatment is a treatment not available in the US because it is not recognized as medically viable/necessary/approved by the FDA, then it is wholly unlikely that their failure to accommodate is unreasonable, but speak to an attorney to be sure.  Think about it from the company's perspective:  Your disability period is over, so you need to come to work now.  "Oh, I'm sorry, I cannot come back to work, I am out of the country.  You need to make arrangements for me to work from out of the country."  You've basically refused to make any effort to come back to work.  Consult an attorney.

Your question is actually somewhat complex, and you may need a lawyer. You can always request a police report under WI Open Records law. You can review statute section 19.35 for some guidance. However, certain records and information in the records may be denied or redacted. WI passed the "Monfils" law to protect individuals who report alleged crimes. As for a defamation case, WI does give immunity to individuals making statements to police officers, so the person may be immune from a defamation suit even if they lie to the officer. However, the immunity is not absolute, and there are exceptions depending on the circumstances. The first step may be for you to get the reports and then have an attorney review them.

I usually do not disagree with my colleagues but I respectfully do so with this question. First, you could have used a Diversion Expungement which would have allowed FDLE to expunge your record. You may be time barred from using that method now. However even juvenile records have shown up on level 2 background checks. For instance, the Florida Bar, Department of Education, Department of Children and Family services all may have access to your record regardless if you seal it. When you turn 25, the Department of Juvenile Justices has their own internal procedures for expunging the case but I do not think it will ever be 100 percent off your record. You can hire a lawyer to expunge your juvy charge but i would not do it I i was you bc you only get one "adult" expungement.  Good luck. I know many kids who make the same mistake but have gone on to successful careers.

The administrator may or may not be overstepping. It depends on what the plan's QDRO Procedures and the Plan provisions say about this type of issue.   To find out whether the plan administrator is overstepping, you need to ask them for a copy of their "written" policies and procedures about QDROs and see in there whether they can ask for the divorce decree and whether they can ask for the notarized statement. If they don't have written procedures or policies in place that clearly state they have that authority to demand those documents, then they don't have it and they are overstepping.   Also be careful that their written policies and procedures about QDROs may say that they have discretion to ask for all necessary documents - in that case they would not be overstepping.   Press the plan administrator demanding a copy of their written QDRO Procedures and/or Policy. By law they are required to have something in writing. Then, press them to comply with those procedures (so, they cannot do what the procedures do not allow them to do). If the plan administrator does not have anything in writing, or anything that supports their position that you have to present the notarized statement and the divorce decree, then they would have to accept the advisor's letter.   Some plan administrators would plow over people and overstep the line if you don't stop them. Demanding something in writing that supports their requests is a way to stop them from overstepping the line. By law plan administrators are required to have that in writing, otherwise they cannot make up things on the fly and demand different requirements from different people. The legal requirement to have their procedures in writing serves that purpose, that they treat everybody the same, based on consistent policies. Since you are asking what to send in with your I-485, I will limit my response to only that application. Although, there may be some overlap with what you have already sent in with your I-130.   As to "proof" of your marriage, I recommend providing to the USCIS documents that demonstrate that the two of you have been living as husband and wife. Examples include bank account statements with both names, leases, deeds, life insurance policies showing the spouse as the beneficiary, photos of the two of you together, health insurance policies, retirement accounts with spouse as named beneficiary, invitations to events listing both of you, church announcements.   Trying to prove you are married sometimes is tougher than it would appear. However, if you just look at your normal everyday life with your husband and think of the documentation surrounding your life, that's what is needed.  If in doubt, contact a lawyer. Good luck!

The answer to both questions depends more than anything on the cooperation of the child in question. Without her active assistance in the case, the parents have no chance of success at either objective.   The second question first: Because the child is an adult now, the parents have no right to force their "help" on her without her consent. Her parents can certainly reach out to her, offer assistance in material or emotional terms; but whether to accept is her choice. That's what adulthood means.   As for the first question, for the most part, any cause of action against a state agency for this would belong to the child, again, not to the parents. She might have a cause of action against the agency, and certainly against the individual who abused her. Normally such a suit could be barred after a period of time by the statute of limitations, but this statute can be tolled for torts against a minor, until the minor reaches adulthood. So if she did want to make a claim, she'd have to act promptly.   The parents face a serious problem with the statute of limitations (depending on how long ago this happened), and unlike the child, they don't enjoy this tolling of the statute based on the child's age, as they themselves were adults when the abuse occurred. They may have an additional problem based on their previous suit: if it was dismissed "with prejudice," then they are prohibited from filing suit again on the same issue. If it was dismissed "without prejudice," then they are not. A lawyer would have to review the case file to determine which occurred.   But the parents also face an even more serious fundamental problem: without the child's cooperation, proving these allegations would be almost impossible (unless the agent in question were to actually admit to the conduct, which seems very unlikely).   I am sorry to bring such bad news. I have to urge you - that is, the parents - to remember that sometimes children, and abuse victims, want different sorts of resolutions to abuse than their families do. Survivors may well just want to move on, or to not be subjected to others' offers to help, however well-meant. Each survivor has to cope with their experiences in their own way. The best thing families can do is to be available and supportive, but give them the space and freedom they need. Insisting upon taking legal action could be terribly retraumatizing to an abuse victim.  People have this notion that suing someone will be this glorious redemptive process, where their every injury will be avenged and all their feelings validated. This belief is staggeringly wrong. Lawsuits are intensely unpleasant. They force the parties to live through whatever injuries they originally suffered, for months or years. You have to answer tons of difficult questions, over and over again, and if you change your story even a bit, you can be sunk. They rarely go perfectly - the law often produces results that one side or another considers to be unjust, for technical reasons - or just because "justice" is a pretty subjective concept. The other side has every motive, and every right, to attack your honesty, your conduct, and your motives. For a victim of abuse, this can be far worse than the original abuse was. I'm not saying these remedies should never be pursued, but these issues should be considered before you embark upon litigation.

Most decisions are made within 2-6 weeks after a NOID is issued. The majority of NOIDs end in denial, even if you provide the right evidence however. Unfortunately, unless you have an underlying immigration status, you will fall out of status when you file you appeal of their denial. Unlike a NOID response, an appeal can easily take 1 year to process.   If you receive a denial it's time to admit that doing this yourself is not going to work and it's time to hire a professional. Most immigration lawyers will provide a free consultation to you to explain what you did wrong and how they can help. Hopefully your case will still be approved, but if not you may find yourself in a very bad place where you would need to pay more to correct it than if you just hired a lawyer to do your case right in the first place.  Good luck.

First, if I were representing you, I'd have phoned the DAs office before today and learned the status and, of course, called you off from appearing.  The DAs office would have replied either 1) We have nothing on this case (meaning cops have yet to deliver it to them);  2) we've rejected the case for filing (there will be no case because of insufficient evidence) or 3) the case has been referred to the City Atty for misdemeanor filing.    There is no need to appear if no case is on calendar for the judge to call.  Second, the turnaround time from your recent arrest date until today is relatively quick for a felony.  I'd normally expect them to take more time, especially on a narco case where lab results may be pending.    If a filing occurs down the line, a letter will be sent.  No need to write CYA letters to the cops or DA that may cause them to locate a misplaced file.    Last---if the DA eventually files a case before the statute of limitations runs, there still may be a valid motion to dismiss for a due process violation if you can show that the delay in filing somehow prejudiced your ability to defend yourself.  Discuss these points, as well as your bail issue, with your lawyer.

I think that I understand your question. Your name is still on the title to the property, thus, you still have liability issues if someone is hurt, etc. on the property. You want to relinquish title to the lender and want to know the best route to do this. If the property is currently the subject of a foreclosure action you (or your foreclosure defense counsel) can contact the bank and agree to a CONSENT JUDGMENT. That is where you basically agree that you have no defenses to the foreclosure action and you are informing the court that you agree to allow the Plaintiff lender to proceed with the foreclosure as you will not be raising any defenses. This allows the Plaintiff lender to ask the Court to shorten the time frame in which a foreclosure sale date will be issued. You are also correct that you can request that the lender agree to a deed-in-lieu ("DIL") but I find that lenders are not well equipped to proceed with a DIL. Remember, they don't want your property, they want money. Therefore, your best bet, where you will have the most control over the process, is to list the property for a short sale and submit a short sale application to your lender. Even though you don't need to do the short sale (because you don't need the deficiency waived) it will allow you to speed up the process of getting the title to the property out of your name. I hope that I have answered your question. Good luck with whichever route you take.

California Civil Code Section 1954 provides that a landlord may enter a dwelling unit to show it to prospective buyers, but the landlord must provide specific notice to the tenant beforehand.  The notice must include the purpose of the entry and the date and approximate time of the planned entry, which must be during normal business hours, unless the tenant consents otherwise.  You should give the tenant WRITTEN notice of those three things at least 24 hours before you plan to enter.  If you choose to mail the notice (rather than hand-deliver it), you must mail the notice at least 6 days before you plan to enter the unit.  Now, here is the key:  Once you give WRITTEN notice to the tenant that you will be "showing the unit to prospective or actual buyers", then you are free to give 24 hours VERBAL notice to the tenant for the 120 day period following the written notice.  If your lease agreement provides that you will not enter the unit without her being present, you should add something to your written notice stating that you have offered to schedule the showing on X number of occasions to accommodate her schedule, but she has refused to allow you to enter on each and every one, then ask her to please be reasonable.  You need to establish and keep a record proving that you tried in good faith to comply with the lease provision in case she brings a claim against you for violating it.

So, you need to verify 1- that mom has not relocated more than 50 miles without your consent; 2- that the children are presently enrolled in Mom's school district and 3- if they are not presently enrolled in mom's who's school district are they presently enrolled at? If for some reason they have been enrolled in your school district and this school is better (better rating) than the one Mom intends to move the children to, you may have grounds to request a modification to the parenting plan.  Please keep in mind all of this is not so cut and dry, so seek out the advise of counsel to make sure you meet the requirements necessary to seek a modification of the parenting plan. Without knowing the specific facts of your case, I cannot say for certain.  You should have a candid discussion with your attorney about the statute and rules governing consecutive sentencing, meaning the imposition of one sentence after the other. Section 40-35-115 provides that the court may order sentences to run consecutively if the court finds by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) The defendant is a professional criminal who has knowingly devoted the defendant's life to criminal acts as a major source of livelihood; (2) The defendant is an offender whose record of criminal activity is extensive; (3) The defendant is a dangerous mentally abnormal person so declared by a competent psychiatrist who concludes as a result of an investigation prior to sentencing that the defendant's criminal conduct has been characterized by a pattern of repetitive or compulsive behavior with heedless indifference to consequences. (4) The defendant is a dangerous offender whose behavior indicates little or no regard for human life and no hesitation about committing a crime in which the risk to human life is high; (5) The defendant is convicted of two (2) or more statutory offenses involving sexual abuse of a minor with consideration of the aggravating circumstances arising from the relationship between the defendant and victim or victims, the time span of defendant's undetected sexual activity, the nature and scope of the sexual acts and the extent of the residual, physical and mental damage to the victim or victims; (6) The defendant is sentenced for an offense committed while on probation; o (7) The defendant is sentenced for criminal contempt. Rule 32 (c) of the Tennessee Rules of Criminal Procedure provides: (c) Concurrent or Consecutive Sentences. (1) Multiple Sentences from One Trial. If the defendant pleads guilty or is convicted in one trial of more than one offense, the trial judge shall determine whether the sentences will be served concurrently or consecutively. The order shall specify the reasons for this decision and is reviewable on appeal. Unless it affirmatively appears that the sentences are consecutive, they are deemed to be concurrent.  You need to consult with your attorney about this statute and rule to see if you are subject to consecutive sentences.  If so, you could receive a sentence of more than two years.

In California? Good luck.   Most people refer to an "expungement".  California does not have a true "expungement" statute. What we do have is a dismissal under Penal Code 1203.4. If granted, it doesn't wipe the case off your record, but it adds a notation that the case was dismissed. That allows you to tell most employers that you have not been convicted of the crime, but it remains on your record and still counts as a prior conviction.   You cannot seal adult records unless you are NOT convicted and you are found to be factually innocent.

I suggest you meet with a local family law/child custody lawyer asap. Once you know what you might be legally entitled to if you pursued legal intervention, it might help you put the issues between you into perspective.  Even if you could "force" your ex to take your son to his Saturday activities, you should consider if that would be in your child's best interests if his father is complaining to him or not enthusiastic as he is dragging him to his Saturday activities. Bottom line is that you should meet with a lawyer to find out all of your options and the likelihood of a judge granting a motion if you filed it, and weigh the costs and advantages and disadvantages of doing so. If you have filed suit against the US Government, the government gets an extended period of time to respond, and, you have to make sure your summons is served on the correct person and agency.  Assuming your summons gave the government the requisite time period to respond (which is more than 25 days), and served it properly, then you file a motion for clerk's default.  A clerk will enter your default for you once you file the proper form.  However, if you did not properly serve the lawsuit, the default may be set aside.  You may or may not get a full win. But once the default is entered you must file a motion for final default judgment. And file a proposed judgment.  The judge will review the file and make sure that it was properly served and the time to respond was afforded to the defendant agency. If the judge is satisfied with the well-pleaded allegations of the complaint, you get your final default judgment. If not, you may be ordered to amend or re-serve the complaint.

This question requires further facts than you have provided to give you a better picture of your legal rights.  Many states have statutes similar to the one in Washington State regarding whether an inventor is under an obligation to assign IP or not.  If your new employer is NOT located in WA state or a state that has a such a statute, some of your legal rights might change.  For example, CA has such a statute, Cal. Labor Code Section 2870.  Most employers do not want to rely on these types of statutes alone so they ask all employees to sign agreements assigning IP to the company AND they ask R&D professionals, engineers,and other professionals working in technology development, such as software development, to sign more extensive agreements related to "Inventions and Other Intellectual Property".  Your new employer will likely require you to sign such a document.  It is critical that your new inventions be listed as exceptions to this agreement, including the new development work that has not even taken place yet.  Your new employer may or may not be supportive of this development, especially if this work is even remotely related to their business.  These are serious issues that could potentially affect whether you should even take this new job.  You should contact an intellectual property attorney, preferably one comfortable with these types of cross-over employment law issues in the state where you will be living and working with the new employer.  You should do this BEFORE you accept this new position and definitely BEFORE you sign any inventions agreement with the new employer.  Good luck!

Sorry, Babu! That scheme will not work. First of all, having been "selected" is not the same as the employer having had its H-1B "approved." It seems as if several aspects of your question went unanswered..  The designation "fugitive of justice" sometimes accompanies the issuance of a felony warrant when the police have searched for someone in state and cannot locate them . The term is not a criminal charge and is actually pretty meaningless.   There are no additional sanctions if a person is designated a fugitive.  At a bail hearing it can be established that the person did not "flee" at all.   As to the second part of your question.  If a person is arrested on a felony fugitive warrant in a state that did not issue the warrant - they will be brought in custody to the appropriate local judge to be advised of the warrant - and at that point a lengthy and complex extradition procedure kicks in for a formal return to the warrant issuing state.  I am including an article that explains the process.. I hope this helps.

The attorney represents the agency and the agency retains settlement authority.  This is parallel to all attorney - client relationships; decisions to settle are the right and responsibility of the client (the agency in your question).  An attorney can and should present his or her client with the options for resolution and the consequences of not settling.  The attorney can and should make recommendations.  But the decision lies with the agency, always.  Some agencies or some personnel within agencies will listen to the recommendation of the attorney and others will blow off the recommendation.  I've represented many clients against federal agency employers and have found that most agencies welcome the advice of their attorneys but still make their own decisions.  It varies greatly how much they weigh the legal advice they receive.

You really would have to know what the specific rules are for his agency, perhaps the union rep could help. Police officers generally are expected to maintain high standards of ethics in both their public and private lives, so it could be an issue if he lives with or dates someone who is violating the law, but you would really have to check those rules for his department.  As an aside, and as advice for the future when writing anywhere where you need a professional thoughtful and intelligent response, we attorneys volunteer our time to give advice to people on AVVO in order to help.  If this question is important to you (and it obviously is) and you respect and appreciate the free guidance (and you probably do and should) is it too much trouble to actually take the effort to spell out the fifteen to twenty words in your question?  Its just a bit disrespectful/ungrateful to me.

Your question is pretty involved. It may be prudent to get a CFI (Child and Family Investigator) involved in this case so that a proper report can be submitted to the court. Generally speaking, however, å¤14-10-124(1.5)(a)(II) states that the court shall consider "the wishes of the child if he or she is sufficiently mature to express reasoned and independent preferences as to the parenting time schedule".   You will notice that a specific age is not enumerated in the statute for purposes of your question, however, we usually see a court giving weight to a child's preference at the age of 16 and 12 -- the 8 year old is a little harder, but the court may still give weight to his preference as well. It is advisable to look into a CFI so that person can interview your children and express their feelings re: parenting time in his/ her report and thus, you would avoid hearsay objections and other issues that may arise.   You can also consider filing a motion for the Judge to interview the children, but this is completely up to the Judge and most Judges do not grant these motions.

I am sorry for your loss.  In order to answer your question, I am going to guess you are trying to figure out who will take any equity in the property in the absence of a will.  In California, in the absence of a will property passes through a process called intestate succession. This depends on factors you haven't resolved in your question - so I can't give you a firm answer.  However, typically, this succession goes first to the spouse (either in whole or in part depending on certain factors), then to the surviving children in equal shares.  The rules are a bit different if the mother's spouse pre-deceased her, the former spouse died within 15 years of her, they owned the property together, and her children were not his children.    Brother in law isn't a class of persons who takes by intestate succession - but if he is married to your husband's sister, she may be entitled to a share.    So, with this in mind, you should probably meet with an attorney to address your rights based on all of the information available.  I hope this answers your question.

If a party (such as you) wishes to introduce docs at trial, they are required to have sent them in response to discovery requests. If they could not be found at the time, better late then never, but the court may want you to explain why these were produced so late and close to trial and why not provided timely in response to discovery. The fact that discovery is closed means that neither party may ask for more discovery or take depositions, but this cutoff date can be waived if both sides agree or if the court orders it waived or more discovery.  The court could also continue the trial and order discovery reopened.  Trial exhibits that were not requested in the course of discovery can also be used at trial, so long as the exhibits are prepared as part of the pre-trial preparations, per the local rules or the judge's rules for trials. Truly sorry to hear to hear this.  At your age (and any age for that matter), losing the consort of your spouse for that significant amount of time can be quite devastating and destabilizing.  I hope you are both doing much better now.  Yes, proving Loss of Consortium can be quite a challenge as it is an abstract thing for the most part, but generally, you want to show the defendants how badly the injury affected the quality of your life together.  This may include showing them 'before and after' pictures, videos, events, even testimonials from friends and other documentary evidence of what you both did together before the injury, that you couldn't do while spouse was hurt and perhaps still can't do today.  Don't let the adjuster pigeon-hole you into what they consider to be loss of consortium.  It is a lot broader than sex or intimate moments alone.  The documentary and testamentary evidence can be considerable in quantity, considering your ages and time together.  A lifetime actually.  I know you have considered seeking legal help which is why you posted this question on AVVO, but maybe you should also consider a face-to-face free consultation with a personal injury attorney.  Good Luck and God Bless, Edwin I. Aimufua

A contractor is only allowed to use licensed subcontractors or employees for whom he pays workers compensation insurance.  If the worker is not licensed he is considered to be an employee and he must provide workers compensation insurance for that employee.  If he fails to do that his license is automatically suspended and he cannot validly sue or record or enforce a mechanics lien for that work.  Liens usually must be recorded within 90 days of the "completion " of a project.  If they are not they are not valid.  If a contract for work on a residential property does not meet certain statutory requirements it may be possible to cancel that contract and avoid some or maybe all payments thereunder  If you have further questions or need representation contact an experienced construction attorney !

I am sorry to hear you were hurt. I hope you are better soon.   You ask a good question. You don't want to have medical expenses that the at fault car insurance later refuses to pay. It's a difficult question to answer, however, because Georgia law does not prohibit the insurance company from telling you one thing now and doing something altogether different later. In fact, in my experience, it is common for claims handlers to lull folks into a false sense of security by promising to pay all related bills early in the case but later breaking that promise.   You might want to keep in mind that the insurance company has a massive advantage over you in this situation. They have deep pockets and extensive experience navigating these claims. They are a business and their business is to settle claims for low dollar amounts whenever they can. The claims handler you are dealing with has been trained in techniques to manipulate you and the claim in order to keep the insurance company from having to pay full value.   One technique the claims handler will use is to try to discount any medical bills you present. They will "audit" the bills, which is their way of telling you that the bills were unreasonably high. They often do this even when the bills are reasonable. The $2500 coinsurance expense you mention is unlikely to be reimbursed in full by the insurance company, no matter what assurances the handler gives you.   To try and answer you question as directly as possible, telling the insurance company about all of your treatment won't accomplish much because you can't trust what they say. It won't necessarily hurt to tell them but don't put much stock in what they say and be careful what you say. Get the treatment you need. Assume you may have significant out-of-pocket costs that are not reimbursed. Prioritize getting better. Let the insurance chips fall where they may. That's about the best you can do on your own.   Or you could ask an attorney to help you. We are trained to fight these battles for you. We often can get you the treatment you need on a lien (no out of pocket). It costs you nothing to hire an attorney because of contingency fees. I've never had a client end up owning one cent to a doctor - always get the bills paid and almost always there is something left over to compensate my client for all they went through.   Please consider talking to a local attorney who specializes in injury claims. I think you'll be glad you did. Whatever you decide, best wishes to you.

There is no legal duty for you to trim (personally or by hiring someone) your plants that protrude into the neighbor's land. The neighbor has a legal right to trim the plants to the property line as long as the neighbor does not cause the plants to die. Once the neighbor trims, the neighbor must find legal ways to dispose of the trimmings. The neighbor cannot throw the trimmings onto your property.  Legally, how young or old or how capable of physical work you and the neighbor are is not relevant. The law applies to everyone equally.  Legality aside, it is your hedge. Unless you do not mind that the neighbor trims it in an ugly way, you should hire someone to do the work so that you can control the quality of the work.  If you hire someone to do the work, your neighbor is not legally responsible for any payment to the person you hire. Your neighbor also does not have any legal duty to allow you onto their land to do the work.  If the hedge needs ongoing maintenance, perhaps it is time to cut it down and plant something that does not require as much maintenance.

I am sorry about the difficulty your wife is having.  Being the Personal Representative of an estate is quite a responsibility and having the other beneficiaries lined up against the PR makes it that much more difficult.  There are several issues involved in your question and you've mentioned two different possible court matters--Petition for PR Commissions and Petition for Removal of PR.  My first question to you is:  has she filed her Petition for PR commissions?  If so, I'm sure you realize that the Interested Persons only have 20 days to respond to the Petition.  From what you've said, I can't quite tell whether they've already testified in a hearing and you want to bring a defamation or slander suit; or whether you are anticipating their testimony in the hearing regarding her Petition for PR Commissions.  You also discussed the possibility of the other beneficiaries trying to remove your wife as PR.  Have they filed a Petition for Removal of Personal Representative?  If so, again, you only have 20 days to respond to that Petition.  The hearings for PR Commissions and for Removal of PR all occur in the Orphan's Court for Montgomery County, Maryland.  I have experience in these types of matters so I can try to advise about how these things happen generally.  Have these hearings already happened?  Your questions is formed as a "yes" or "no" question, but I want to make sure you're asking the right question.  If there have been hearings and persons have lied in those hearings, then, "yes," you can file suit against them for causes of action such as defamation of character or slander.  When you talk about wanting to impeach a witness's testimony--that happens in court on cross-examination.  So, "yes," you can try to impeach their testimony during the hearing.  That leads me back to my confusion--have the hearings taken place already?  I recommend that you meet in person with an attorney who has experience in litigation before the Orphan's Court for Montgomery County, Maryland.  I offer free initial consultations, so I'm sure many other attorneys would as well.  I understand your frustration and it must be difficult for you and your wife.  The statute is clear, however, about PR Commissions and Removal of PRs.  The appointment of a PR is a right that the Courts do not easily take away without good cause.  The Orphan's Court is the judicial body that ensures that the deceased's last wishes are followed, and that includes honoring the deceased's choice for Personal Representative.  Best of luck.  And please check your limitations periods if Petitions already have been filed.

First, sorry about the situation you are in.  Based on the immediate family interest and potential financial outcome, it appears this Judge should recuse himself.  Two sections of Title 28 of the United States Code (the Judicial Code) provide standards for judicial disqualification or recusal. Section 455, captioned "Disqualification of justice, judge, or magistrate judge," provides that a federal judge "shall disqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned." The same section also provides that a judge is disqualified "where he has a personal bias or prejudice concerning a party, or personal knowledge of disputed evidentiary facts concerning the proceeding"; when the judge has previously served as a lawyer or witness concerning the same case or has expressed an opinion concerning its outcome; or when the judge or a member of his or her immediate family has a financial interest in the outcome of the proceeding.  Best of luck!

You are correct in that you can receive $20 cash without losing any of your benefit. After the first $20, you lose $1 for any $1 you are given by another person (this gift income is considered unearned income). However, there are other ways that people can help you. For example, if someone pays a utility bill, insurance, or car payment on your behalf, that income is not attributed to you. The important thing is that the person must pay the bill directly. If they give you cash, and then you pay the bill, it is considered unearned income. Please see the following Social Security website for more information: http://ssa.gov/ssi/text-income-ussi.htm.

You neglect to mention if other party filed a mere "objection" to your motion OR did they file and "objection and cross-motion"? This is important because if there is a cross-motion you get to file an objecting response to the cross-motion and therein you can advise the court there never was a previous CIS. If there was not a cross-motion, you need to request oral argument to advise the court of this and if the court refuses to give you oral argument, you need to call the judges law clerk and advise them there never was a previous CIS and do it before the motion is decided. You must advise the court there never was a previous CIS or your motion might be denied on procedural deficiencies.

The laws of our country and in California can be harsh.  Unfortunately, employees and job applicants have very few employment rights, and employers have a lot of leeway in how they choose to run their businesses. In general, an employer can be unfair, obnoxious or bad at management. And an employer can make decisions based on faulty or inaccurate information.  An employer has no obligation to warn an employee that he or she is not performing as the employer wants. It‰Ûªs not a level playing field. An employer hires employees to provide work for its benefit, not for the benefit of the employees. Don't expect the employer to take care of its employees; it doesn‰Ûªt have to and it rarely does.  There are some limitations on what an employer can do, mostly in the areas of public policy (such as discrimination law or whistle blowing), contract law, union-employer labor relations, and constitutional due process for government employees. Please see my guide to at-will employment in California which should help you understand employment rights: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/an-overview-of-at-will-employment-all-states.  After you take a look at the guide, you may be able to identify actions or behavior that fits one of the categories that allows for legal action. If so, an experienced plaintiffs employment attorney may be helpful.  For example, if there is evidence that your boss harasses only female employees, or all the female employees, you may be able to move forward with a claim.  Unlawful harassment is a form of discrimination.  To be unlawful, the harassment must be must be based on a protected category, such as race, sex, religion, disability, age (40 and over), pregnancy, or genetic information.  Harassment is also illegal if it is based on whistleblower status, taking or needing family leave, or some other protected category.  An employer is required to provide a workplace free of unlawful harassment.  Harassment can include verbal conduct, slurs, derogatory comments, comments or questions about a person's body, appearance, religious, or sexual activity, or indication of stereotyping. Harassment can also include offensive gestures, sexually suggestive eye contact or looks, mimicking the employee in an insulting way, and derogatory or graphic posters, cartoons or drawings.  Harassment is unlawful when the conduct is either severe or pervasive enough to create an abusive environment.  Severe conduct would include most physical contact and many types of threatening, vulgar or degrading conduct.  Pervasive conduct is widespread, happens frequently and/or in many situations.  One offensive statement is not pervasive, but the same comment made over and over again may be pervasive.   You should know that attorneys who handle discrimination cases must be very selective in the cases they accept.  Just an ordinary discrimination case (if there is such a thing!) can easily run up over $100,000 in attorney's fees due to the large number of hours an attorney must put into such a case.  With that kind of time expenditure, attorneys must choose the cases they take carefully, and they usually select those that have a strong likelihood of success.    That said, not all attorneys see things the same way so it doesn't hurt to try. To find a plaintiffs employment attorney in California, please go to the web site of the California Employment Lawyers Association (CELA).  CELA is the largest and most influential bar association in the state for attorneys who represent working people. The web site is www.cela.org. Click on "Find a CELA Member" and you can search by location and practice area. Many CELA attorneys represent clients throughout the state.  I hope there is a good resolution to this situation.

This would probably be a good time to consult with an elder law attorney so that you can make fully informed decisions.  There are a few issues here.  First, you are saying "assisted living facility."  Are you sure that it is an ALF and not a skilled nursing facility?  It would be unusual for someone to be in an ALF for rehabilitation.  The usual progression is hospital to SNF and then either home or to an ALF.  Medicaid does not normally pay for Assisted Living care, only skilled nursing.  The family MIGHT qualify for State-County Special Assistance (which is sometimes erroneously called "Medicaid" but is actually a waiver program).  The income limits are low and many people do not qualify.  In any event, with Medicaid or Special Assistance, the patient's income is typically paid to the facility (minus a small personal needs allowance) and the program makes up the difference between what the patient has paid and the cost of care.  There would not be an allowance to permit the patient to continue paying the mortgage.  And as a prior poster paid, if the mortgage is not paid, then there is a risk of foreclosure.  Speaking with an elder law attorney may help the family make some decisions here, including whether a family member can/should pay the mortgage...  Medicaid benefits paid out are recouped by the State through estate recovery when the patient dies.  Again, this is a MAJOR reason you need to talk with an experienced elder law attorney because there are many issues here.  Depending on several specifics that are not clear from your question, yes, the house COULD be at risk.  We'd have to be confident about the level of care, the public benefit being used or sought and several other issues to give you fully accurate advice.  I strongly suggest contacting an elder law attorney right away since you are saying that this admission may become lengthy and possibly permanent.

I want to provide more insight to your answer but am a bit confused by your comment to Counselor Borah, wherein you essentially state that you received no formal termination and are happy to take your leave to pursue other positions, since you are now receiving permanent disability and not able to do the work that you previously performed.  Before you read the rest of my comment, confirm whether you are receiving temporary disability or permanent disability.  If you are receiving temporary disability, just peruse my answer and seek counsel if you have not done so already.  As you probably know, "PD" is an acronym for permanent disability.  Your permanent disability payments/advances will not cease if you separate from the company with whom you sustained your industrial injury.  If you're receiving additional income in addition to permanent disability during your "leave" then it sounds like you hit an unusual sweet spot with your situation.  If you are simply receiving permanent disability (advances) and not temporary disability, I would demand that my employer offer me modified work or fire me; this should not impact your ongoing permanent disability payments.  In fact, you may apply for unemployment and receive such payment (insofar as money is available to you for unemployment) on top of your permanent disability payments if you are fired AND are ready, willing and able to work but cannot find employment.  In addition, your termination may give rise to an employment law claim for which you would need to speak directly with an attorney who is well-versed in employment law.

Unfortunately, this is a much more complicated problem now than it was before judgment was entered.  I have explained here on a number of occasions to people that, when their names are included as defendants in foreclosure cases, even if they are no the borrower(s), unless they take the right action to ensure that the judgment does not impact them improperly, they are at risk for serious consequences, exactly as you are describing.  Examples of this problem are tenants like yourself, non-borrower spouses, heirs of deceased borrowers, etc.  Foreclosure cases are typically filed by factory like "volume firms", who use generic complaints and even more generic judgment language, which compounds the problem. Frustratingly, I see responses from non-borrower defendants telling them not to worry...  It might still be possible to seek to vacate the judgment, and perhaps even to seek sanctions against the foreclosure firm, depending on the details.  However, it will be tricky, and not "typical" defense, so you need to make sure to retain the services of an attorney who really understands how to do what I am describing.  We have been successful with situations like you are describing, which is why I KNOW it is a problem for non-borrower defendants.

If the case is handled properly, you may be able to keep it off your record.  You need the help of a good criminal defense attorney.  Theft 5th is a simple misdemeanor, which carries a maximum jail sentence of 30 days and a maximum fine of $625.00.  But a theft conviction may keep you out of certain forms of employment, and may make you ineligible for some types of professional licensing.  A deferred judgment would allow you to avoid a permanent stain on your record.  You need to hire a lawyer to assist you.  If you can't afford one, ask the court for an application for court appointed counsel.  Some municipal judges may try to force you to proceed without appointing an attorney to represent you--on the theory that you are only entitled to a state funded lawyer if you risk going to jail--where they do not intend to send you to jail if you are guilty.  If this happens, you should (1) enter a plea of not guilty; (2) request a jury trial; and (3) sell something to get the money to hire a private attorney.  The criminal justice system is difficult to navigate, and unless you want this incident to be a permanent stain on your record, you need the help of an attorney.

To prove the conspiracy, the State need just present evidence showing that you were involved in planning, organizing, or taking part in the crime of distributing marijuana, along with evidence that SOMEONE in the conspiracy group took a step towards the commission of the crime.  They need not show that you actually did anything, only that you discussed it with others and that they took a step towards completing the crime.  I believe it would be an affirmative defense, on your part (and your burden), to show that you had removed yourself from the conspiracy AND that you communicated that to the others PRIOR to any of them taking any steps toward the commission of the crime.  So, to answer your question more simply - you MAY have the ability to show that you removed yourself from the conspiracy, but that is probably going to be something YOU have to prove.  I don't think the Court would require the State to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that you did NOT remove yourself from the conspiracy.  They would need only prove that you were involved in the initial discussions/planning.    Keep in mind that conspiracy is a separate charge from the underlying crime itself.  It can be illegal to plan a crime, as long as one participate takes a step towards completing the crime, even if the crime does not end up being completed (i.e. planning a bank robbery could constitute conspiracy as soon as someone gathers the gun to be used in the robbery, even if the robbery isn't actually carried out ... the crime is in the planning ... it would be a separate charge for the actual robbery if one of the participants then carried it out).  Good luck!

I see this question all the time. In fact, that is the main defense to many workers compensation and personal injury claims. People can recover from a per-existing injury and that resulting condition makes them more susceptible to an injury in the future. In Florida, you have to prove the accident is the major contributing cause of the need for medical care and resulting disability. The insurance company will fight that in order to avoid paying the claim.  They fight the claim by contending the condition pre-existed the accident and, therefore, they should not be held accountable to pay for the treatment.  I recently won a case involving the need for back surgery.  The adjuster contended the back condition pre-existed the accident and refused to authorize the surgery.  I deposed the treating doctor and he agreed the accident caused the need for the surgery and won.  It's not easy to win these cases, so you have to be aggressive.  Good luck.

Grandparent visitation rights are allowed under Alabama law (30-3-4.1 Code of Alabama) for the parent of a deceased parent of a minor.  You qualify for that.  Alabama also allows the parent of a deceased parent to intervene in an adoption proceeding when a step-parent is trying to adopt.  This does not mean the adoption will be stopped but you may get visitation rights. Many of the grandparent rights have been eliminated by the US Supreme Court.  I do not recall a USSC decision dealing with a case like yours.  If you are being asked for consent, which is not required, I think that is a good sign.
