I assume the police arrested you for resisting without violence under Fla.Stat. Section 843.02. This is often used as a catch-all charge when citizens exercise their First Amendment rights to record police in public. (Google my name and you'll see that I've handled many of these cases.)   FLA. Stat. Section 768.28 does not apply to federal civil rights violations. When you bring the case in federal court, there are no damage caps. I can assure you, though, that you don't want to handle a federal or state civil rights case on your own.  You must first prevail on the resisting without violence charge. If you take a plea, then you torpedo your civil rights case. You need to hire a criminal defense attorney who is familiar with the constitutional law issues as well as Florida criminal case law regarding Section 843.02. That's why I prefer to handle the underlying criminal defense case myself before I agree to accept the civil rights case.   You have four years after defeating the criminal case to file a lawsuit in state or federal court, but if you intend on filing in state court, you need to file a notice of claim within the first three years. The sovereign immunity statute has several steps that you must strictly obey or your case will fail on a motion to dismiss.   Good luck. Choose your attorney wisely.

You definitely want to consult with a trust attorney.   That being said, if you are talking about real property, don't be surprised to find out that you do not need to take any action. The trust owns the property and it is simply titled to the trustee as representative of the trust and not in their personal capacity. So if the trustee changes, the ownership did not change, just the representative of the trust. So the trust still owns the property. When the property is sold/transferred to the next person (after the trust) the new deed simply lists the succession of trustees in the document so that the new owner has a deed showing what occurred and why the names don't match.   This is similar to when a married couple owns a property and one of them passes. The other still owns the property and does not need to change anything. If the living spouse sells the property the new deed says that one of the last owners deceased on specific date and time.  If both the couple pass away then the estate sells the property. There is no deed to the estate and them from the estate to the new owner. The estate simply prepares a new deed upon sale with a statement that each of the previous owners deceased on specific date and time and that explains why the names don't match.   You do want to make sure that the taxing entity knows the new address of the new trustee (if it is different) so they can send the tax bill to the proper location.   If you are talking personal property such as a care or truck, the new trustee can go in to the transfer location with the document and their ID (and any resignation of the past trustee or their death certificate if they are deceased) and have the vehicle title updated (but not necessarily have the ownership transferred). Again, the trust owns the property so there is no change of ownership, just a change in the representative of the trust. Either way, make sure you don't pay the ownership transfer fee for nothing.   Be sure to call the transfer location to see what forms they may need.   Hopefully this will give you a starting point to talk with your trust attorney about.

Under the federal Fair Credit Reporting Act, Fair Credit Billing Act, and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, only those items that are reporting accurately and who have complied 100% with the back-end record-keeping may report on your credit. Auditing them under those laws is specific and can be complicated because they will reject anything that does not adhere to form. Companies like White, Jacobs & Associates specialize in consumer programs that target inaccurate derogatory items on a credit report and hold the bureau's feet to the fire (they are, after all, money-making institutions and that means that the threat of litigation for Damage to Credit Reputation is a real concern). The audits will require the original creditor and entity reporting to provide a detailed billing history tracing the account from zero to its present reporting balance and provide a copy of the original signed contract within 45 days. Without that, the FCRA says that the item must be deleted.  FCRA audits can be tricky and overwhelming. If you choose to hire a company to do it for you, when searching for a national credit repair organization, pick one with good results, with positive consumer reviews, and that has an attorney attached to it.

With the limited exception that an attorney may, but is not required to, reveal confidential information relating to the representation of a client to the extent that the member reasonably believes the disclosure is necessary to prevent a criminal act that the attorney reasonably believes is likely to result in the death of, or substantial bodily harm to, an individual, "A member shall not reveal information protected from disclosure by Business and Professions Code section 6068, subc (e)(1) without the informed consent of the client.  (See Rules of Professional Conduct Rule 3-100(A).  Because individuals (potential clients) come to lawyers in order to determine their rights and what is, in the complex of laws and regulations, deemed to be legal and correct, and because a lawyer needs a potential client to communicate fully and frankly even as to embarrassing or legally damaging subject matters, a lawyer may not reveal information relating to the representation, even if that information comes before a client formally retains the attorney.

If the child has been in Florida for six month or more then Florida has jurisdiction and Florida law applies, so what they NY lawyer tells you would not apply.  If Florida law applies you have to file an action for paternity to establish your paternity.  The birth certificate gives you a presumption of paternity, but it is not an "order."  However, you could file it as part of your action for paternity if you chose.  In Florida, without any prior order, this would not be child abduction.  If the child has not lived in Florida for six months or more then you would have to determine what the child's home state is before having a productive discussion.

First of all,  all attorney fees actually incurred before you file are DISCHARGEABLE..but for WORK done after you file the courts have allowed a collection for such under Quantum Meruit Theory for work done. But some attorneys new to this charge like $100 down and $1400 after filing...those are DISCHARGEABLE! You can ask your attorney to itemize for work after you filed, or if you don't pay, that is the mess..will they do anything about it? Don't know..probably not but who knows! That is the problem an attorney creates if not paid for all before filing.   Second, you do NOT have to ANSWER anything. They simply filed motions. You do nothing. Then, after your case is closed you have options as follows:   Third, on the house options:  you should call the court and see if your case is closed about 10 days after you get a discharge or after the hearings set, whichever is later, as until closed the trustee can still sell your house. "Closed" is not the same as "Discharged", so call and ask if closed and if so, you might add that to your listed facts also.  Under your state law, if the actual foreclosure has not yet taken place, then you have options (1) live there as long as you can for free instead of paying rent somewhere else; (2) if closed, move out and rent your place until the renters have to finally leave; (3) move out and leave it vacant (you wont receive any monies or save any though); (4) move out and let someone you know live there till they have to leave; (5) see if the bank will pay you for a Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure (maybe they will pay you $2,000 or whatever you agree to..try for $3000 first and see what they say (they may not want to accept such a deed if there are underlying mortgages or liens that they can eliminate by conducting a formal sale.   Please remember that if in fact there are any Homeowners Assocation Dues (HOA), that any such HOA due and payable post petition until the property is not in your name are not discharged (only prepetition HOA past due dues are discharged). Technically you could also keep living there until you commit an unlawful detainer and then they can proceed with going through the law to force a formal eviction but in such case you may end up possibly owing fees and costs for unlawful detainer. Most lenders would rather NOT just have property left vacant as it often invites vagrants or persons vandalizing. Good luck and I hope my answer assists you.

In PA, a person arrested will go before the issuing authority/judicial body for a preliminary arraignment.  At this hearing, the defendant will be informed of the charges and will have bail set.  The rules require this hearing be held within a reasonable amount of time and without undue delay following an arrest.  As you may know, the criminal justice process isn't the most efficient and often delayed.  I would be somewhat surprised to hear that your friend has been in custody for a month without being told the nature of the charges filed against him or other basis for his detention.  You must also be aware that a new arrest will often prompt the issuance of a probation detainer that will hold a person in custody despite bail being set and paid on the new case.  Your friend needs a lawyer immediately.  The lack of information contained above, the length of detention to date, and a 7 year probationary sentence could be more problematic than a simple technical violation for taking a sip of alcohol.  I recommend that he retain counsel immediately.

Some basic rules.   1. California is a Community Property (CP) state.  2. All property acquired during a marriage, when contemplating or engaged in a divorce, is considered CP.  3. Your spouse cannot sell the property without your signature if its a significant asset, and if its your principal residence, it cannot be sold without your signature either.  4. If there was a mortgage taken out on the property, then the debt is marital debt, hence a CP debt.  5. In a divorce, its likely that all the equity  in the home would be presumed to be all CP. The reason why is that once Separate Property is commingled with CP, its all presumed CP and its your spouse's burden to prove that the $50,000.00 in equity in the home was intended to be her property alone.  There is a recent case from the CA Supreme Court, In re Marriage of Valli, link here:  http://caselaw.findlaw.com/ca-supreme-court/1666906.html  In the Valli case the supreme court explained that title in the wife's name alone was insufficient to make it her separate property.   Your spouse would have to prove that her $50,000.00 was not a gift to the community. She would also have to prove any remaining equity is also not CP. Finally, she would have to prove that the CP would not be liable on the underlying real estate note in the event the lender chooses to sue under the note and surrender the property.  Personally, I think she has a tough sell on this one.

Assuming your son is an adult and also assuming that there was no reason to refuse him permission to drive the car registered in your name (addictions, epilepsy or other diseases, suspension of license due to a pile of past accidents, etc.)  everything said by both counsel is correct. Your(and your wife's)  liability as the registered owners is limited in California to 15/30/5 thousands. See Vehicle Code Section 17151. Your policy exceeds this limit.  While you are not in a position to judge the nature and extent of injuries sustained by other vehicle occupants, they may be less and more that your policy limit. If after litigation the court determines that your son caused damage beyond the policy limit and enters judgment against him to that effect, he will be a judgment debtor and generally such a debt can be discharged in bancrupcy.  When my clients are aware that the injury is serious and they have assets (your son does not) I recommend that they write to the liability insurance company and ask them to offer the policy limit(s) to the other party. This has to be in writing and I always tell them to send it certified and to keep a copy in their file. This way if the verdict or judgement is in excess of the policy they have some protection against the insurance company due to its failure to tender the policy limit if the other party asked for it. I agree that you do not have to assist the plaintiff in getting your LLC served and if no service is the end result you may be okay.  This is a process, however that I have seen backfire on clients that I have represented over the years.  Thus I would recommend that you at least consult with an attorney and monitor the case docket at least every few weeks.  First issue is where is the Registered Agent?  Under Florida law, this person must be at this address during certain hours each business day.  If the agent is no longer at that address or is not present when required, process might be served on a number of people at the LLC's place of business, on others involved in the LLC and even in some situations on the person at a business like Mailboxes, etc. If those fail and the registered agent isn't available as required by law, process might even be served on the State of Florida and if your last known address for the LLC is no longer functioning or providing you with information about mail received, a judgment could be entered against the LLC after serving the State.  Hence the need to monitor the case.  You may believe that if the LLC is belly up, you don't have to worry about a judgment, but there situations that require an extensive attorney conference, where the veil of the LLC separation between it and your assets can be pierced to get at your assets and once there is a judgement against the LLC, the defenses to the lawsuit can't be raised if the veil is pierced.  Thus don't ignore this lawsuit and obtain the advice of counsel, to avoid some unintended consequences that you won't be able to undo when you are ultimately attacked to collect the judgment.

Dear Far Rockaway Tenant:  You have the right to ask that your landlord conduct a walk through while you are in the apartment and before you leave, but unless the lease mandates the inspection as part of the process of lease surrender, the landlord is free to decline. New York State does not provide by statute a right to a walk through or an inspection and allows landlords and tenants to come to their own terms relating to the security deposit and the end of lease as long as those terms do not conflict with State law.  You must be on your own guard to preserve the evidence that the apartment was turned over in an undamaged condition.  How do you plan to get the keys to the landlord? If the landlord will come to the apartment to receive the keys, then that seems to be the time for the inspection. You must remove all possessions, and sweep the apartment (broom clean is the ancient term used in most New York residential leases). If the landlord will not look around, you cannot force the issue. So you need to document completely the moved out condition of the apartment in case you need evidence down the road to reclaim the security deposit if the landlord claims damage.

As well as under the  laws of several states, there is a Federal law called the "WARN" Act (an acronym for "Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act") at 29 USCS å¤å¤ 2101 et seq.   The purpose of the WARN Act is to give workers and their families some transition time to prepare for the prospective loss of employment, to seek a new job, and, if necessary, to seek training in a new skill or retraining in an existing skill that will allow the workers to obtain replacement work. Basically, it provides that companies with 100 or more full-time employees must provide 60 days advance notice of a "plant closing" or a "mass layoff." A mass layoff occurs when one third or more of the work force is laid off, with a minimum of 50 employees. While there are some narrow "faltering businesses" exceptions, the WARN Act generally requires most employers with 100 or more employees to provide employees, bargaining representatives of the employees (i.e., unions), and specific government agencies at least 60 days notice of any plant closing and mass layoff. Alternatively, an employer may pay 60 calendar days of wages in lieu of notice.    More specifically, it applies to any business enterprise that employs (A) 100 or more employees, excluding part-time employees; or (B) 100 or more employees who in the aggregate work at least 4,000 hours per week (exclusive of hours of overtime).    The Act defines a "plant closing" as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees excluding any part-time employees. WARN doesn't just apply to business closings, but to the sale of all or part of the assets of a business.  In that case, the Act provides that the seller is required to provide notice up to and including the date of the sale.  After that date, the buyer is responsible for providing notice, unless the buyer re-hires seller's employees at the time of the sale.  Under WARN, an employee gets prior notice and little else.  Except perhaps under a State law (Pennsylvania is not one of them) an employer is not required to pay any kind of severance at all, unless it is required under the company's written employee handbook, or under a provable policy of always paying severance. A fairly common type of severance policy among larger employers provides for one week of pay for each year of service. Thus, if an employee with 25 years of service is laid off in a plant closing, the employer‰Ûªs policy might grant that employee 25 weeks of pay.  There is nothing to prevent an employee from personally approaching the employer and negotiating  for a higher rate of severance than that offered.  An employer who violates the WARN Act notice requirement is liable to each affected employee for an amount equal to back pay and benefits for the period of violation up to 60 days. An employer who fails to provide notice as required to a unit of local government is subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $500 for each day of violation. The penalty may be avoided if the employer satisfies the liability to each affected employee within 3 weeks after the closing.   Normally, there is no specific time (other than a "reasonable" time) that an employee must be allowed to consider or reject an offer to release claims. However, if you are asked to waive an age discrimination claim under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, you are entitled to a written statement giving you 21 days to consider the agreement before signing, and 7 days after signing the agreement during which you may revoke your signature. Typically, to be qualified to apply for and receive state unemployment  you need to have lost your job "through no fault of your own."  If you turn down the severance offer, unemployment compensation should be available depending on all the facts.

You don't have to trademark your company name, but if you plan to do business across the U.S., whether physically or via the internet, it is always a good idea to go ahead and trademark your business name. The process isn't extremely difficult or expensive, compared to the amount of protection you would receive as your business grows in the future. Although certain common law rights are conferred, trademarking a name with the USPTO is best and gives the most protection to pursue infringers in the future. You can theoretically do it yourself, but hiring an attorney who is well-versed in the art of trademark law and has practiced extensively before the USPTO would be better practice, especially if you receive any Office Actions that need to be answered. You should consult an intellectual property lawyer in your area.

There is no way to assess the likelihood of a conviction with any certainty. The Judge will assess the credibility of the witnesses, and the testimony they give. Can you be convicted? Yes. Can the Judge decide that the case has not been proved? Yes. Criminal charges need to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt, but no prosecutor is going to dismiss the DV-related charge if the complaining victim insists on going to trial. Provide the prosecutor with a copy of the time cards, and the name of your witnesses. Bring your witnesses and your evidence to the trial, and be prepared to present the defense case in the event that the Judge does not dismiss the case after the State completes it's case. I strongly suggest that you at least consult directly with (if not retain) an experienced criminal trial attorney BEFORE you go to Court.

I agree with my colleague.    The total time it will take depends upon what the tenant does.  If the tenant ignores your 3 day notice to cure, once the 3 days have run, you cand expect the following:     File and serve the eviction complaint (unlawful detainer) Tenant has 5 days to file an answer.  (figure 7 days considering weekends.     If no answer is filed:  A request for default and a clerk's judgment for possession.  Depending upon your clerk's office this should be processed fairly quickly and then a writ will issue.  Once the writ is issued it goes over to the Sheriff to be posted for another 5 days.   Again add a couple days for weekends.       If the Tenant files an answer, you will have all of the foregoing steps plus waiting for a trial date.  The code gives you priority,so you should be in court within 3 weeks... hopefully.  Good Luck  Disclaimer: I am licensed to practice law in the state of California. Therefore if your case in not in California, the information contained herein may not apply. This answer is provided as a public service and as a general response to a general question, it is not meant, and should not be relied upon as specific legal advice, nor does it create an attorney-client relationship.

When you are dealing with a CDR, you typically do have to come up with a retainer, and this is because most people will be collecting their benefits pending the CDR and a possible appeal if they lost the initial review - i.e. there is no potential back benefits from which the SSA could calculate a 25% award, nor from which it can be the attorney.  As such, usually the retainer is between $2000-$4000, and it typically only gets paid to the attorney if you win your CDR.  You may want to consider in the future using a pre-CDR service to help you make sure your ongoing evidence (in preparation for that future CDR) is as strong as possible.

I understand that your situation is very difficult, and the loss of the Medicaid that she is receiving because of the SSI can often be more costly than actually losing the payment. Unfortunately, there as the attorneys have stated, there is very little that can be done to preserve her Medicaid when your earnings will cause her to lose her benefit.   My suggestion would be that you look into the changes that have occurred with Healthcare coverage since the Obamacare provisions have went into effect earlier this year. It is possible that even if your wife loses Medicaid based on her SSI eligibility, she may continue to be eligible due to the expansion of the program as a result of the Obamacare changes. If she is not eligible for Medicaid, if your income is the only income in the household, it is likely that you both would be entitled to substantial subsidies for purchasing healthcare coverage through a healthcare exchange.  Although most employees never want to thing about this, the other option is to ask your employer to limit your hours so that you do not exceed the maximum allowed, or if you are absolutely needed for the hours that you are working, determining if your pay can be decreased. Maybe offer your employer to take a pay cut if you are provided with more vacation time in exchange.   If your wife was the one that was working, she would have many additional options available to her. She could use Impairment Related Work Expenses to reduce the impact of earnings on her SSI amount, or continue to be eligible for Medicaid while she returns to work. For more information about the programs available for your wife, see the following: http://www.ssa.gov/ssi/text-work-ussi.htm.   I am sorry that none of us have been able to provide more helpful information to you, but I wish you and your wife good luck!

There are several different interlocks, with different error messages, that are approved for use in Michigan.  You should have a booklet or user's manual for your interlock, and it may have a section in it describing the meaning of each error message. It may be happening at other times and you are not even aware that it is happening.  I suggest that you go to your installer and have the unit checked.  The Secretary of State is getting very strict about interlock problems, seeming to take the approach that you are doing something wrong and re-revoking you, and then you have to have a hearing to try to convince them that the interlock was messing up, and that you didn't do anything wrong.  Get it checked out.  Sincerely,  Frank B. Ford

The answer to your question is "It depends" It is correct that all assets acquired during the marriage are subject to division pursuant to Mass General laws ch 208 sec 34 however the court considers at least 18 different factors when making an equitable  division of  property. One important factor is the length of the marriage. If you got married two years ago under this scenario it is likely the court would try and put the two parties back into the position they maintained at the commencement of the marriage. If it is a marriage of 20 years the court would probably consider that the assets had become part of the fabric of the marriage. Was this the second  marriage for you ? Did you have a prenuptial contract? Your best thing to do right now is consult with experienced divorce counsel.

The answer depends on whether you already accrued the leave, or if accrual is capped at a certain maximum number of hours.  An employee cannot be forced to forfeit vacation time, as this is considered wages under the Labor Code. An employee can be made to forfeit sick leave. If you have a PTO plan, then you cannot be forced to forfeit any of those hours; because vacation and sick leave are combined, and an employee cannot be made to forfeit vacation, you get to keep the whole thing.  In contrast, if the employer allows a maximum accrual, then it can maintain that limitation. For example, if vacation accrual is capped at 100 hours, the employer may stop adding to the accrual for employees when their accrual reaches 100 hours.  The Division of Labor Standards Enforcement (DLSE) is a sub-agency within the California Department of Industrial Relations.  http://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/.  Some people refer to the DLSE as the Labor Commissioner.  The DLSE enforces California's wage and hour laws, including those pertaining to overtime, rest and meal breaks, and more.  Here is what the DLSE Enforcement Manual says about "use it or lose it" polices: Vacation plans may not have a "use it or lose it" provision as such provision would be an illegal forfeiture. However, a variant of a "use it or lose it" policy whereby a cap is placed on the amount of vacation which may accrue if not taken is acceptable. (Henry v. Amrol (1990) 222 Cal.App.3d Supp. 1; see also O.L. 1986.10.28, 1986.11.04, 1986.12.30, 1988.08.04, 1991.01.07, 1998.09.17)  One important caveat to this:  If the reason you have accrued a substantial number of hours is because the employer will never allow you to take vacation, then the employer cannot enforce the cap.  I hope there is a good resolution to this situation.

Most Massachusetts employers are prohibited from asking any criminal history questions on an initial job application and thereafter can only obtain limited criminal history during any follow-up interviewing or hiring procedures.  Since late 2010, Massachusetts law has prohibited employers from asking any criminal history questions on initial employment application forms. The law is designed to prevent employers from screening out candidates based criminal history information included in their completed application forms.   This law does not prevent employers from asking certain criminal history questions later in the interview process.  Limited criminal history questions can be asked during an interview and applicants may be required to answer limited criminal history questions in writing  after submitting an initial application form and interviewing for a position.  In those circumstances, an employer still cannot ask about, (a) arrests, detentions, or dispositions where there was no criminal conviction, (b) first convictions for drunkenness, simple assault, speeding, minor traffic violations, affray, or disturbance of the peace or (c) misdemeanor convictions more than five years old, (unless the incarceration ended within the last five years or the applicant has been convicted of another offense in five years before seeking the job).  Employers should make sure that their written application forms and hiring policies comply with these restrictions or they could be subject to suit and enforcement proceedings.

I suggest you contact an attorney to see if you met the criteria for filing a petition to modify your child support payments and have them lowered due to you unemployment.    Regarding the past due child support, your husband can file a motion for civil contempt for your failure to pay child support.  He would then have to set that motion for a hearing.  To be found in contempt, the court will have to determine if your failure to pay the support was willful and wanton, and if you had the ability to pay it.  Although courts do have the power to incarcerate you for failure to pay child support, they often will not resort to that for a first offense, especially if they don't find you in contempt. They may come up with another option first, such as paying a purge amount or distributing the past arrears over the next several months in addition to the current amount of child support.  However I would strongly suggest you speak to a lawyer about both the contempt issue and a modification, because if you qualify for a modification, and the court grants it, this can help prevent contempt issues in the future.

Your fiancÌ©'s other petition doesn't matter. You as a US citizen have the right to petition to allow you husband or husband-to-be to come here and live with you.  If he is over 21 then his mother's petition involves a long wait. If he is younger, and they class him as an immediate relative (unmarried child under 21 - even if he is slightly over 21 - it depends on his age when the petition was filed) - then mum will probably get him here quickly.  You will file an I-129F for your fiancÌ©. You have to prove the bona-fides of the relationship, and when the petition is approved, he will get an interview at the embassy, and if all goes well, he will be able to come here on a K-1 visa, you can get married within 90 days of his arrival, and then he can apply to adjust his status. I say "apply" - because they will look closely at him to decide if he is admissible.  Alternatively you can get married abroad, and then either file for the K-3 to bring your spouse over and adjust, or file for him to come as your spouse and then do consular processing when it is approved. I think you're misunderstanding what a motion for summary judgment is.  After both parties to a lawsuit have had an opportunity to review evidence from both sides, a party can file a motion for summary judgment.  The motion essentially tells the court this:  "Your Honor, we do not dispute the important facts.  A jury is not required to determine what the facts are.  Since we all agree on the important facts, can you decide this dispute we are having on the law alone?"  The judge can agree that there are no "genuine issues of material fact" in dispute and rule on the motion (you may win, or you may lose), or may rule that there are genuine issues of material fact, and the case will go on.  The dates set are for the filing of the motions.  There is a date the motion will be filed by the party seeking to move for summary judgment, a date set for filing a motion in opposition to summary judgment (which your lawyer will do), and another date, maybe, for the moving party to file a reply brief.  Then you will wait for months, perhaps a year or maybe even more, for the judges decision.

Lying under oath is perjury, which is a crime under California Penal Code å¤118.  Only the District Attorney can file a criminal case.  You could file a police report or contact the DA's office; however, most prosecutors will only file perjury charges that are very easy to prove. For instance, if someone fails to disclose a criminal conviction on an application for welfare benefits, which clearly states  that is is signed under penalty of perjury, it is very easy to present the court documents that prove the person was convicted.  Penal Code å¤118 also says that a person cannot be convicted of perjury based on the testimony of just one person who says they lied. There must be some other evidence to prove the sworn statement was false.

First, a 5K is different from a Rule 35. A 5K is applied at sentencing, based on a defendant's cooperation to date.  If the government makes a motion under 5K1.1 of the sentencing guidelines, the judge can impose a sentence below the guidelines to reflect the value of the cooperation. If there is a mandatory minimum, the defendant needs a motion under 18 U.S.C. 3553(e) to give the judge authority to impose a sentence below the mandatory minimum. These are issues that get negotiated as part of the plea.  Once sentence is imposed the judge has no authority to reduce the sentence under 5K1.1 or 3553(e).  However, if the defendant provides cooperation after sentencing, the prosecutor can bring a motion under Rule 35 to allow the judge to resentence the defendant to reflect the post-sentencing cooperation.  When this happens depends on when the cooperation is complete. The rule requires that the motion be brought within one year of sentencing unless the cooperation is based on information that was not known at the time of the first sentencing.  So, the answer depends on the nature and timing of the cooperation. But if the cooperation has been provided before sentencing, it should be reflected then with a 5k.  Finally, the defendant has a right to be present when being sentenced, so he would be brought back before the judge for a Rule 35 reduction.

A good traffic ticket defense attorney would file a motion to dismiss the citations for lack of proper service.  The citation should be served in person for the Court to have jurisdiction over you.  In the past, your signature was required for service.  Recently, the statute was amended to allow for service of a citation without your having to sign it, however, the officer must certify that you were handed the tickets.  Failure to certify as such has led to a dismissal in many of my  client's cases.  The amendment does not mean that you can refuse to sign a citation at the request of an officer.  Failure to sign the citation at the request of an officer may lead to your arrest.  However, the officer may not just "mail you a citation", unless it is a Toll or Red Light Camera ticket, which are exempted.  Your tickets may lead to higher insurance rates for years to come, not to mention the fines.  Hire a traffic ticket attorney today by checking the "Find A Lawyer" feature for "Speeding Ticket Attorney" right here on Avvo.com, and selecting one.

To add to the discussion, there is a capital gain tax matter you need to consider prior to having the property put in your name.  Others have mentioned the gift tax, but that really only matters when the donor has assets above 5 million dollars.  The capital gains tax is real and can be significant to you.  When your mother transfers the home to you while she is still alive, you take her tax basis in the property.  If you later sell the property you owe capital gain tax on the difference between her tax basis and the sales price.  Let's look at hypothetical numbers:  Mom and Dad bought the house in 1990 for $120,000.  When dad died the house was worth $180,000.  Mom's tax basis in the property is $150,000 (her 1/2 at $60,000 and Dad's 1/2 at $90,000).  If you sold the property immediately after her passing you would owe capital gains tax on the difference between her tax basis ($150,000) and whatever the property sold for.  However, if she held the property until her death and passed it to you under a will or trust, then you would be entitled to a step up in basis to the home's value at her date of death.  This can be a considerable tax savings to you.  Before you do anything, please consult with an attorney or your tax advisor!  Best of Luck!

Slow Speed Minimum Wake zones are boating restricted areas that the State of Florida has established to protect the public safety or manatees.  In Florida, only the state and federal authorities can regulate boat speed on the Intracoastal Waterway.  Within tight limitations, cities and counties can regulate vessel traffic on other waters within their respective jurisdictions.  Regardless of who created the restriction or where it is located, "Slow Speed Minimum Wake" is defined by rule in the Florida Administrative Code.  It means that a vessel must be fully off plane and completely settled into the water.  Once it is fully settled into the water, it must proceed at a speed that is reasonable and prudent under the existing circumstances to avoid creating an excessive wake or other hazardous condition.  Because you were operating on a plane, even minimally so, you were not proceeding at Slow Speed.  Even a vessel that is coming off plane and settling into the water or just beginning to come up onto plane is not proceeding at Slow Speed.  Even if a vessel is fully settled into the water, if it creates a wake that unreasonably or unnecessarily endangers other vessels, it is not proceeding at Slow Speed.  Only vessels that are completely off plane, fully settled into the water, and proceeding with a reasonable and prudent wake are proceeding at Slow Speed.  The officer was wrong about the 5 knots.  There is no numerical speed limit associated with the Slow Speed Minimum Wake restriction.  He may be saying that because hydrodynamic forces start to make very small vessels rise in the water column at around 5 knots.  Larger planing hull vessels start to rise in the water column at between 7 and 10 knots, depending on their size and hull configuration.  Displacement hull vessels are always fully settled into the water, no matter what their speed of operation ‰ÛÓ for such a vessel, the question is whether or not its wake is reasonable and prudent to avoid endangering other vessels (including vessels at anchor or moored along the shore).  If you decide to retain an attorney to fight this citation, I suggest you choose one who is thoroughly knowledgeable and experienced in Maritime Law and can give you specific legal advice based on the particular facts and circumstances of your case.  You can find such an attorney through the Florida Bar Association, the Southeastern Admiralty Law Institute, or the Maritime Law Association of the United States at the links below.  You can also use the "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this web page.

You are not going to find any lawyers with Dyck O'neal experience.  For the same reason that prior to the 2008 meltdown, outside of legal aid offices there were not lawyers defending foreclosure actions.  In 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013 Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for the most part sat on their hands and were not pursuing deficiency claims in Florida.  Then the Florida Legislature amended the statute of limitations with respect to deficiency claims, which imposed a July 1, 2014 deadline to file the claims that were more than a year old.   In the two months before the July 1, 2014 deadline Dyck O'neal using the Consuegra firm filed approximately 10,000 of these cases across the state.  All of the cases are brand new.  Some lawyers have handled other deficiency claims but the Dyck cases are brand new.  Nobody has more than two months experience with these cases because until June of 2014 they did not exist.  You will either find somebody who will tell you what you want to hear, but likely exaggerate their experience or somebody who will tell it to you straight.     What you really need is a lawyer with a proven track record defending consumers in consumer litigation matters (which includes but is not limited to Foreclosure cases) in the Space Coast who will offer you a fee structure that makes financial sense.  We do these cases on a partial reverse contingency where the amount of our fee is primarily determined by how much we save the consumer.    What would really be sad is you paid ton of money only to have a lawyer lose the case, surrender, or not have the stomach to fight it to the end.

Strictly speaking, it is the "contents" of the safe deposit box that "may" be fair game. A creditor with a judgment could obtain a write of attachment for the contents of a safe deposit box. At which point, the debtor would need to go to court (the court that issued the garnishment ) and claim an exemption if an exemption would apply to the contents. If no exemption applies, then the contents are turned over to the creditor.   However, I am with Robert...just deal with the "REAL" problem, resolve the debt. Pay it, settle it, declare bankruptcy. Living this cat and mouse game and living a life of creditor avoidance is no way to live. I am guessing your life wasn't always like this.   Lastly, the "reality on the street" is that safe deposit boxes are rarely hit by creditors. Two main reasons why (1) few people have them, and (2) those that do generally only keep important documents in them. The rest of the people who have safe deposit boxes are either wealthy, spies, or white collar criminals :)

You received good advice from the attorneys that responded to your question.  With regard to the release, at least in Pennsylvania the court must approve a settlement for a minor --which typically is a formality--and the money must be placed in a restricted, interest bearing, insured account until the minor is 18.  If the same is true in CA then that is what should be done--no reason to wait until your son is 18 so he can sign the release--interest may not be a lot but why let the insurance company benefit from your son's money. If the policy limits are $15K and there are no other possible "defendants" and the person responsible has no "real" assets then $15K is obviously the most your son can recover.  However, if they are offering the policy limits then the value of the claim exceeds the policy limits.  There may be another source to compensate your son for his injuries.  You may have underinsurance coverage on your auto policy.  Underinsurance provides benefits to you--covered individuals--which may inclued your son if the person who causes the injury does not have enough insurance to cover the claim.  If you have it, you bought it to protect your family for just this circumstance.  Use it.  Check your DEC sheet to see if you purchased it--in your states--I think most states--it is not mandatory and if you have it, you paid for it.    My suggestion is to contact a personal injury lawyer near you and pay for an hour of that lawyer's time to review the settlement/release, review "your" policy, review the potential for any other additional claims than can be brought.  In this way you can feel comfortable that you did everything you could to protect your child.

However, you need an attorney to carefully consider whether they even have evidence to convict you.  Additionally, even if they can prove there case, there are other ways of resolving the case that can save you from having an embezzlement conviction.  A theft/embezzlement/fraud conviction is one of the worst possible things to have on your record, and can affect your life, including employability, for years to come.  Please consult with a northern Virginia lawyer as soon as possible about your situation.

If you waived time, you waived your speedy trial rights.  You could pull your waiver and start the speedy trial clock starting again.  But, that might not be the best idea if your attorney doesn't believe he is ready to put on a defense, yet.  If your public defender questioned your competence to stand trial and you were subsequently found competent, I would argue that the public defender's office now has a conflict of interest in that it cannot give you zealous representation if it does not believe you are competent.   The conflict defender or whatever office they have in Santa Clara county to handle indigent cases when the public defender has a conflict (and, they most certainly have one) should be appointed.  Tell the judge you do not believe the public defender can adequately represent you as they have already declared a doubt about your mental competency and ask for conflict counsel to be appointed.  Of course, if you can afford your own attorney, that is always the best course of action.

Most large companies now use nationwide background check companies that will find a prior conviction, even for a misdemeanor offense.  The best advice is typically to disclose such prior offenses, as an employer will likely look even less favorably on someone caught being dishonest than someone who is candid about the prior offense.  An interviewee with such an issue should also prepare an explanation of the offense, and of any efforts at rehabilitation and moving forward, so as to be ready to answer questions in a positive way.  For some (but certainly not all offenses), it may be possible to seek expungement of the prior offense, so it may also be worth consulting with a lawyer in the jurisdiction of conviction to determine whether that is an option in a specific case.  Many people have successfully overcome prior convictions to find employment and otherwise move on with their lives, so no one in this position should lose hope.

First you need to read 17 USC 105 which prohibits copyright for such works by Government employees. That limits your power to enforce any exclusivity.  But, receiving awards and honorariums is not problematic. Official do it frequently. Even legislators take honorariums. It's an accepted form of graft and corruption.  As to your specific 4 questions, here is my take: 1. Could I enter the composition into a competition that has a monetary prize, and legally accept the prize if I won? Yes. 2. Could I perform the piece with civilians at a concert, making money from the ticket sales? Yes, if structured properly as reimbursement of expenses. 3. Could I record the piece and sell CD's? Yes, but anyone could copy any Government version and sell in competition with you. Whether you could get a copyright on your personal sound recordings of a public domain work depends on a more complex analysis beyond the scope here. See a copyright attorney to have this structured to mitigate risk and enhance copyright protection, if any, available to you. 4. Could I sell the score and parts to schools for them to perform? NO. You should not do that as the score and parts thereof are public domain, UNLESS you work closely with an IP attorney to make the items you sell have significant original content not produced in your capacity as a Government employee. And, even then, you need to check with the General Counsel (or the GC's delegee) as to the Government's position on this, as you don't want to get disciplined  for violation of some Government agency policy.

Under Oklahoma law, a judge need not sign a subpoena in order for it to be valid. In a criminal case, both the state and the defense may have subpoenas issued by the court clerk (see 22 O.S. å¤ 701 et seq.). Similarly, attorneys can have subpoenas issued by the clerk of the court in civil matters (see 12 O.S. å¤ 2004.1).  If you feel that you have a legal defense to complying with a subpoena, you can have the subpoena judicially reviewed. You will need an attorney to assist you with challenging a subpoena.

The default answer is the applicable SOL will be the state where you reside when you are sued. For "planning purposes" that is what you use. However, the legal answer can be far more complex and is beyond the scope of this forum (books and articles are written on the subject). The note may have a provision for the SOL, and when you are sued, your state's laws will have a say on which SOL to apply. The more relevant question is when does the SOL clock start to tick. I do student loan law for a living, every debtor I have ever consulted with on this issue (private student loans and SOL) got it wrong as to when they "thought" the SOL would expire. The main problem with private student loans are the voluntary forbearance and deferments you may have used. The SOL clock is not ticking when you have any sort of forbearance or deferment in place.   Lastly, keep in mind, SOL is hollow victory. If the SOL expires, the debt doesn't go way. All the SOL gives you is a defense to a lawsuit. You can still be sued after the expiration of the SOL, and unless you appear to raise the SOL as a defense, they can still get a judgment against you. They can still call and send letters demanding payment, etc.   Bottom line, you borrowed $150,000 and haven't paid it back. That is not going to go away on it own.

As a general matter, the upside of a bankruptcy is that it provides you with a relatively clean start.  In a Chapter 7, most of your debts will be discharged (meaning you will no longer have any legal obligation to repay them) and you will have to surrender all of your non-exempt assets.  You will need to speak with a lawyer to determine if you have any non-exempt assets.  Once your discharge is granted, your credit score will begin to rebound remarkably fast.  In a Chapter 13, the process is a little different.  You will not have to surrender any assets, but you will be required to make a payment (to be determined by a formula) for 3 - 5 years before you are granted a discharge.

You have two options, you can file a lien or commence a breach of contract lawsuit. Even if you pursue the latter option, you may want to file a lien first and assert a cause of action for lien foreclosure. If the amount in dispute is large enough (>$20k), filing a lawsuit may be justified. If not, filing a lien is relatively simple and inexpensive, and you could always prosecute a claim in small claims court for breach of contract if the contractor just files a bond to discharge the lien pursuant to Lien Law 19(4) rather than paying you.

Presumably your daughter has insurance on the car. Unless the driver was specifically excluded from her policy, the fact that he did not have insurance is probably irrelevant, since your daughter's insurance policy will provide primary coverage.   If the driver was at fault, your daughter is also individually liable as the car's owner. But that liability for bodily injury is capped at $15,000. If she is found to have negligently entrusted the vehicle to the driver (for example, if she knew or should have known that he had been drinking), her liability is not limited by statute.  The best thing to do is to promptly report this loss to your daughter's insurance company. They will indemnify and defend her and the driver.

As an injured victim, you are entitled to a variety of damages under the law, including all medical expenses incurred due to the injury, lost wages, pains and suffering, and loss of normal life. The amount of damages you are entitled to will depend on the nature and extent of your injuries. And there's no way to know that until you have completed your medical treatment and have recovered as much as possible to your pre-accident condition.  No one can speculate as to your damages one week after the accident when you still have a lot of pain. The insurance company for the other driver is going to low ball you and do what they try to do with every claim pay as little as possible. You need to hire an attorney to help you get maximum compensation. With your type of injuries, it's not appropriate to handle this on your own and battle a large insurance company.  Most attorneys in this area offer free consultation and you should hire an attorney you feel comfortable with.   Insurance companies usually don't make more than one payment to an injured party and only after everyone agrees on an amount.   Until that time, they may make payments to your medical providers if you authorize such payments.  I wish you a speedy recovery and that you get the compensation you deserve.

You can't sue for negligence because the Fair Credit Reporting Act preempts state law relating to credit reporting.  If you had disputed their tradeline with the credit bureaus, and they failed to correct it, you could have sued them under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, assuming the statute of limitations did not expire.  Unfortunately, a lot of people do not realize they need to send a dispute to the credit bureaus in order to preserve their rights in this type of situation.  If you did not send a dispute, the other possible claim you could have would be under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.  The FDCPA has a shorter statute of limitations (one year, as opposed to 2 for the FCRA).    If you had some proof they knew the bill had been paid, and they did not correct their reporting, you might have a decent FDCPA claim, but the problem is you are not likely to have that proof if you never informed them of the error (and it sounds like they did correct things once you did tell them).   Consult a consumer law attorney to discuss all of the facts, to get a more precise answer.

Noncompetition agreements are always illegal in California. That is to say, you can never be prevented from working for anyone, even a direct competitor of your previous employer.  Nonsolicitation agreements -- that is, agreements that prevent you from soliciting your former employer's clients -- are also usually illegal. This is a special area of interest of mine, as my first published case, Thompson v. Impaxx, Inc., addressed this very matter.  You are free to take your former employer's client's away, even to solicit them, so long as you do not use trade secrets in doing so. Contrary to what some of my colleagues have said, client lists are rarely trade secrets. It is usually pretty easy to establish that they are not, but you will want to get on top of this quickly.  A significant point is the location of your previous employer and whether your contract had a choice-of-law provision. A choice-of-law provision provides that some other state's law will apply instead of California's. If you had such a provision, then what I've said here may not apply, and you will want to be examine your contract very closely to determine your next steps.  I hope this information is helpful to you.  Sincerely, Craig T. Byrnes

What everyone is saying is fine.  Legal objections are proper, and objections to the "form" of the question are waived unless made at the eposition.  That means that if you don't understand the question, the witness might not understand it either, in which case an objection based on "vague and ambiguous" is proper, if not required to preserve the same objection to the time of trial.  Likewise, many lawyers like to ask "argumentative" questions.  An "argumentative" question is one not being asked to obtain information from the witness, but rather is deliberately calculated by the questioner to make some key point in his or her case, that is damaging or embarasing to your case or to the witness.  (e.g., "isn't it a fact that you no longer beat your wife?")  Its "argumentative because  no matter if the witness answers "yes" or "no" the net result is the same-- he did beat his wife at some point in the past.  The next question will be "when, did you stop?"   Hence, the proper objection is "argumentative".    What I do, and most other competent lawyers would do in the case of a "friendly" witness (such as your former business partner (presuming you're still on good terms),, is to interview the witness first (before the  deposition) and find out what he's going to say at the deposition to the "key" questions, or "sensitive" issues.  That way you will not have to constantly object at the deposition itself, if you already know what the answer is going to be, and it is favorable.  If you don't know what the answer is, or if you know the answer could be unfavorable, you might put in a "vague and ambiguous" objection to make the questioner clarify his or her question, which may have the effect of deflecting the question away from the potential "bad" testimony.    In fact, my ususal practice is to not object at the deposition unless i don't understand the question, or think the manner in which it is asked will lead to a "bad" answer.  Defending depositions is an "art", it comes only with experience.  But everybody has to start someplace.  In my earlier years, my rule of thumb was "when in doubt, keep it out"  (that means if you don't know, object.  It's a lot easier to make the objection and preserve the issue for trial, then to keep quiet, and risk a subsequent ruling that  you waived the objection by not making it at the deposition.  Hope this helps. Good luck.

A conditional green card cannot be renewed, and the process for "extending" it is to file the I-751 petition to remove the conditions on residence.  Once the I-751 is accepted, you will receive a letter extending the conditional status for up to one year while the petition is processed.  If your wife received her green card in September 2013, it should not expire for two years -- the two years is not based on the date of your marriage but the date the green card was issued.  If you have concerns or the green card is about to expire soon you should consult with an immigration attorney who can guide you through the process of maintaining permanent resident status -- Don't lose it!

First, you should be aware that charges could be filed against you whether you speak with the police or not.  Your friend's statement that you were with him COULD be enough to support a charge of trespassing (possibly theft, if the police believe you took part in helping him remove items).  If you speak with the police and confirm that you were there, that could be used against you as a confession to having "trespassed".  On the other hand, you certainly would not want to lie to the police and claim you were not present, as that would open you up to possible obstruction charges if they could definitively prove that you were there and lied about not being there.  The best bet would be to either decline to speak with them or to hire an attorney prior to speaking with them.  An attorney could try to arrange for you to share your details of what happened, without that information being used against you.  It would be best for you to not answer any questions without having an attorney on your side.  If you need additional time to obtain an attorney, you could politely advise the investigating officer that you are willing to speak with them but only after you have counsel with you.  That would hopefully keep them from moving forward with charges against you until after you and your attorney could arrange for some kind of agreement.  In the end, however, YOU have no requirement to speak with them, but THEY do not have any requirement to hold off on filing charges.  Just be very careful if you choose to speak with them without an attorney, as they could possibly (1) record the conversation, (2) report your statements inaccurately, and/or (3) use any number of tricks to try and get you to admit to something that could be used against you.    Without a confession from you, the only evidence that they would have is (a) the picture from the school, and (b) your friend's statement.  They could only use your friend's statement if he actually agreed to testify for the State in Court.  Otherwise, that is hearsay and the picture alone may not be enough to prove it was you.  Just some things to ponder.

If you are subject to the 2 year home residency requirement of the J visa category you cannot change status to F-1 status within the USA.  You will have to apply for an F-1 visa from your home country and then can enter in that status.  If you are not subject to the 2 year home residency requirement then you can apply to change status within the USA itself.  The best way to find out if you are subject is to write to the Department of State for an advisory Opinion.  Entries on the visa are not always accurate.  A competent immigration attorney can help you with this.

Your green card is like a passport - just because it expires does not make the status disappear or expire - you just can't USE it. You stated you are in the US. If you were defaulted you have two options. You can wait and hope the sheriff doesn't show up, or you can ask the court to vacate the default order.  If the sheriff has not yet showed up to post the writ, you have at least three judicial days before the sheriff can return to execute the writ. Sheriff's deputies are busy and have challenging schedules. The risk is that if you sit back and think, "they won't get here before the 24th" - they COULD. Then all your stuff would be locked up or disbursed to the winds.   If you have a lease that has not by its terms expired, you have FIVE judicial days. See RCW 59 18 410. But if you don't contact the sheriff and point this out, they have no way to know this.   Elizabeth Powell

TN status does not lead to a "green card" and nor does TN status permit one to have a "dual intent".  An employer can initiate employment employment-based green card proceedings on your behalf, but that can take 4 years or more to complete. Once that starts, you will not be able to renew your TN status. Thus, it is best if you can first obtain H-1B status before any employer starts GC petitions on your behalf.

As disgusting as it sounds, unless it is a violation of OSHA to require an employee to clean up vomit with bare hands, there is nothing unlawful about what you post.  An employer can make an employee do any lawful act, no matter how disgusting.  Your friend should make contact with Cal-OSHA to determine if cleaning up vomit with bare hands is a violation of one of its regulations and if so, the employee can refuse to do so in the future.  There is no cause of action the employee can bring for such a violation unless there is an adverse employment action triggered by such a violation.  In other words, if asked to do it again and she refuses and gets fired, she MIGHT have a claim.  If she gets sick, she has a workers compensation claim - that's it.  Good luck to you, and to her.

Although I agree with both answers already submitted, I might offer some additional information.  First of all, all Alabama Courts are monitored by AOC (Administrative Office of the Courts).  This Administrative function is based in Montgomery and primarily exists to handle the Court's affairs in all 67 Counties.  Your case was actually tried I'm assuming in Houston County Circuit Court.  All Alabama Judges are familiar with the term "time standards".  That term is used by AOC to keep a finger on the pulse of each pending action in Alabama for the purpose of grading the efficiency of case management (movement), and in actuality the efficiency of each Judge.  Most Judges would like to get cases off of their working Dockets and ; therefore, enter Final Orders when cases are over.  Sometimes when an unusual delay occurs, you may need to "respectfully remind" the Court that an Order needs to be entered.  In many cases, a Final Order is necessary to satisfy financial obligations or convey real or personal property.  If you have fulfilled your retainer obligation with your trial attorney, a simple phone call requesting that a motion to to enter Final Divorce Decree be filed with the Circuit Clerk.  If that doesn't work, you can always call or visit the Circuit Clerk's office at the Courthouse and speak with the person who handle the domestic relations case load.  That person might ask you to sign a motion asking the Judge to enter an Order or simply pull and flag the case for the Judge to see an Order has not yet be entered.  Be mindful if you file anything on your own (pro se) that Alabama Rules Of Civil Procedure require you to copy the opposing counsel by signing a certificate of service and mailing the copy to him/her.  The clerk will be able to help you with this as it is a very simple process.  I hope this helps you resolve this issue.   Trey Norman

The term "joint suspended" usually refers to when the "Execution" of sentence is suspended as opposed to "Imposition" of sentence suspended.  If your sentence says "Imposed sentence suspended" you are not considered to have "joint suspended."  That means that if you violate your formal probation you can be sentenced to local jail and not automatically sent to prison. If this was for a DUI, any future DUI can be a felony also.

Q: Why do I have to designate one of us as the custodial parent when custody is clearly shared? A: The court normally requires this designation, even in a 50-50 parenting plan. However, I have seen some Commissioners say in that paragraph "Both parties shall be designated as the custodian ..." Q: Would one of us lose rights/privileges if one of us is named as a non-custodial parent? A: Normally it does not seem to impact rights; but if a later motion is filed, there is often some advantage to having been identified as the custodial parent. Q: Does it really matter who is named if custody is already shared at 50-50? A: See the previous comment. Q: Is the Federal reference in regards to the filing of our taxes? A: I have never had this question arise, and do not know the answer without further research.

1. Is having a Trade mark enough to protect the IP?   A trademark does nothing to protect potentially patentable material. A trademark is a method of identifying and distinguishing your protect from all others out there.   2. Can the Trade mark be on my name since i have a signed agreement with the manufacturer for exclusive distribution in the US?   If you are the one producing the product or service here in the United States, yes, you own the rights to the trademark.  3. Is obtaining a Trade mark enough for potential investors?   The question is a little vague, but most potential investors are going to be very worried if the product can be made and sold by competitors, especially if it is in the start-up period. A trademark is not going to exclude competitors the way a patent can.  It is very much in your interest to discuss this in greater detail with an intellectual property lawyer in the Los Angeles area. Avvo's "Find a Lawyer" tab above can be very helpful.

I agree with the other two attorneys who responded before me. If in the POA, one of your powers is to conduct transfers of real property (that is typical in most financial POAs), then you should be able to have the current occupants removed so long as the owner of the property (the person on whose behalf you are acting) would have the power to do so. So, for example, if the current occupants have a valid rental contract on the property, they are timely in making their payments and have not breached the contract, you may not be able to have them evicted. However, if they are squatters, you most likely would be able to have them removed. I agree that you should contact an attorney to help you understand the powers you hold and any other legal rights. Good luck!

In this particular situation, a person who is selected by a majority in interest of the persons entitled to the estate OR a devisee under the will can serve as the personal representative of the estate.  If more than one devisee applies to serve as personal representative, the Court may select the one best qualified. There are certain things that will disqualify an individual from being able to serve as personal representative, such as: (a) if they have been convicted of a felony. (b) if they are mentally or physically unable to perform the duties. (c) if they are under the age of 18 years. Also, nonresidents of Florida can only serve if they are: (1) a legally adopted child or adoptive parent of the decedent; (2) related by lineal consanguinity to the decedent; (3) a spouse or a brother. sister, uncle, aunt, nephew, or niece of the decedent, or someone related by lineal consanguinity to any such person; or (4) the spouse of a person referenced in (1), (2), or (3) above.

It is truly not possible to evaluate a specific case or sentence in a general discussion forum,as an attorney would need to review the specific judgment, sentence, revocation petition and hearing, and more, to determine exactly what occurred and (for example) what jail credit may be denied or applied in a specific case. A defendant who believes a probation revocation or sentence was improper or excessive does have a right to appeal, but there are strict deadlines for such an appeal, and the best advice would be to immediately request that the attorney who handled the revocation file a notice of appeal, or to quickly retain a lawyer to file such notice. Courts have wide discretion over probation revocations, and many such appeals are unsuccessful, but there may be hope in a specific case. Probationers are typically not given jail credit for time spent in the community while on probation, but may receive credit for time spent in custody on a sentence that is later revoked.  It will depend on the circumstances, which are difficult to evaluate in a public forum. Good luck to anyone in this difficult situation.

Leishmaniasis is a disease that once was relegated to impoverished third world countries, but it is now being seen in the US. Both humans and dogs are reservoirs for the disease and the sandfly is the vector that transmits the parasite to a new host. In order to prove negligence, typically a plaintiff must show a duty owed. Here, it's reasonable to conclude that an apartment complex owes you a duty to provide reasonable pest control. Second, a plaintiff must show a breach in such a duty (perhaps you can) and then yolk the breach in a causal relationship to the damages claimed (here the acquisition of Leishmaniasis). The achilles heel of your case is causation. Since soldiers returning from the middle east reside in your complex, a reservoir may exist. What level of pest control could have prevented this transmission? A potential case will pivot on this point. Consult a personal injury attorney in WA for further clarity.  best of luck,  Doc Shah  Zaheer A. Shah, MD, JD Attorney at Law, Physician  shahinjurylaw.com

Virginia will not expunge convictions. Your only options to overturn these convictions would be either a Writ of Coram Nobis or a Wirt of Habeas Corpus. For a Writ of Coram Nobis, there must be an error in fact or an error in the record which, in your case, led to the conviction. Generally, a Writ of Coram Nobis is limited to a narrow set of circumstances. A Writ of Habeas Corpus is designed to challenge the validity of a detention. Unfortunately, neither of these tools will likely to be available to you in this matter. Furthermore, Virginia treats a third offense of a violation of a protective order as a Class 6 felony . Good luck.

The wording of the order controls your obligation.  If you are ordered to pay $500, then that may be the extent of your financial obligation.  If the order states that each of you is to pay the restitution of $1500, and that it is joint and several, then it is all due from each of you.  Obviously, once any portion is paid by any of you, the debt is reduced.  I would recommend that you pay your $500 as soon as you can and then seek advice from your attorney or your probation officer as to whether the court would consider releasing you from further responsibility.  It is possible that the court might do just that, but probable that they won't.  If you pay the full $1500, you can sue the other two defendants in small claims court to recover the $500 each that they should have pitched in.  Good luck.

If he has been here almost 9 years and was 14 when he came, then he probably came before 6/15/2007 and is likely eligible for DACA.  The lawyer's advice to a couple who say they are fiance/fiancee is good.  And he may think "if there is an easy solution, why look for harder options." Because Congress does not want to punish a US CItizen spouse, they forgive unlawful presence an working without authorization - actually the statute is carefully worded so they don't forgive, just that these inadmissibility factors don't apply - when a couple gets married and then the alien applies to adjust status. Assuming he came in from Canada through a checkpoint, and not secretly across the northern border (do they have coyotes up there?)  then he is eligible for adjustment. My advice to people is you choose how to live your life, who you want to be with and what your personal commitments are, and then deal with immigration. Even for people who are being removed, the world is a big place, and what matters isn't what the paperwork says - it's how you want to live your lives.

In general, the statute of limitations on collecting unpaid taxes is 10 years.  Your installment payment plan should have been structured to make sure the full amount is paid before that time.  If you die before that 10-year period ends the tax debt will still be a valid debt against your estate and will have to be paid from the assets of your estate.  The statute of limitations on the FBAR penalties is a little more complicated.  Under the law, the government has 2 years from the time the FBAR penalty is assessed to file suit in court to collect the penalty through a judgment.  If judgment is given against you, then the government has basically twenty years to collect under that judgment.  Again, if the judgment is still outstanding when you pass away, it will be a debt against your estate that must be paid from the estate's assets.  It will only be your estate that would have to pay these amounts.  While that would reduce the inheritance your children would receive, they would not have to pay out of their own pockets if the assets in your estate were not enough to pay them off.

To be a bona fide tenant, you have to have been paying the full rent on time. If "The landlord skipped town," to whom have you been paying rent? If you have not been paying rent, you are not a bona fide tenant.  Once the ownership of the rental property changes, you need to continue paying rent to the new owner. If you do not pay rent, you would be subject to being evicted from the rental.  While there are federal and state laws that restrict the new owner from evicting you after the purchase for up to 3 months if you are a month to month tenant, the laws require that you were and continue to be a bona fide tenant. If you have not been paying rent and do not continue to pay rent, I do not see how you can be a bona fide tenant.  If the rental property is within Seattle, the city's just cause ordinance may give you additional protection.  You should review the specific facts with your attorney to find out your legal options.

If you wish to enter the rental property, you must give two days' written notice.  The notice must describe the date and time the entry will be conducted (a range is ok, but you must cover the entire period of the entry) and a phone number the tenants can call you at if they need to reschedule.  In general, giving more than the minimum notice is a good practice to keep the tenants happy.  You can refuse to rent to someone for any reason or no reason at all, provided you are not discriminating or retaliating for their exercise of their tenant rights.  If their current lease converts to month-to-month, and most do, you must give at least 20 days' advance notice before the end of a month that you are terminating the tenancy.  If the lease ends without such an option, no notice is required, but a courtesy notice is a good idea.  The tenant has an obligation to keep the premises clean during the tenancy and restore any damage before vacating.  Inspecting during the tenancy may give you an idea if you want to sign a new lease, but you will need to show the condition when they moved in if you wish to charge them for damages after they move out.

You definitely will need to consult a Family Law Attorney that handles appeals. I don't know what the issues are, but I gather it is too complicated to address here. If the second judge was in a probate proceeding, he may not have revisited any factual or legal questions from the divorce. Usually, the probate court would rely on the Family Court orders that are in place. My colleague answered correctly- I just wanted to add to a couple of your questions. First, any incompetence of the first attorney would not likely be imputed to the second attorney. If either attorney was incompetent, you may or may not have a claim against them. However, that is a different and specific area of practice. Also, prevailing in such claims can be quite challenging, and probably would not give you the relief you need. But talking to an attorney that handles malpractice would be necessary for you to evaluate your options there. Sending letters and documents to the second judge would not help. A judge cannot evaluate such things because they are considered informal ex parte (without the other party) communications. The judge would not even look at it.  You MAY be able to file a motion to reconsider; however, if the second ruling occurred in 2012 it may be a little late for that. Unfortunately, to answer all your questions, you may need to talk to a probate attorney, a malpractice attorney, and a family law attorney. The good news is that many attorneys offer free consultations, which may be all you need to answer some of your questions. An appellate Family Law attorney is likely to be your best bet.
