Oregon's expungement statute is long, complicated and always changing.  Currently, the crime of Assault 4 is eligible for expungement.  So the question becomes whether you are eligible for expungement.  If it has been less than 3 years since the date of your conviction, you are not eligible yet, and you will need to wait until at least three  years have passed.  If you are not yet in full compliance with your sentence - meaning having paid all fines, restitution, served all time, including probation time and any extra punishments for probation violations - you are not yet eligible, and will have to wait until you complete absolutely everything.  If you have another conviction on your record within the period of the day you file for expungement and 10 years prior to that day, you are not yet eligible.  In that case,  you will have to wait until 10 years have passed since the date of the earlier conviction.  This, by the way, is where I would think you might have the most trouble.  If you were convicted of the DUII as well, it would likely be around the same time, and you would have to wait out the 10-year period, not just the three-year period.  On the other hand, if you successfully completed diversion, no DUII conviction would be on your record to cause a problem.  Once you determine you are eligible, you have to file a "Motion to Set Aside Conviction," pay the required fees ($240 filing fee / $80 to have your fingerprints taken); and possibly present a case to a judge.  Once you file, a hearing date will be set.  If the prosecution does not object, it's generally smooth sailing, but there is always a chance that the prosecutor will object, and argue against you.  Your victim will also have the right to make a statement.  The best thing you can do is make an appointment to consult with criminal defense attorney and go over your whole case.  Determine your eligiblility, and how much of a legal battle it will be.  If you are eligible, it is very worth your while to go for it!  Best of luck!

Dear Lancaster Tenant:  I am an attorney licensed in New York State. I do not practice in Pennsylvania. The lease you claim you signed under duress may be your lifeline. Your landlord (co-worker, friend) cannot claim from you any rent greater than the rent you agreed as written in the lease,. So if there is a shortfall in income because your friend lost  a roommate, if the lease does not make you liable for the extra rent, your friend cannot legally claim you owe  money. That is how a lease provides protection against an arbitrary rent increase which your friend could impose if you did not have a written lease limiting the rent.

You should get an attorney to review it, but you're going to have to decide if you want to risk getting fired to have time to do so before you sign.  If you sign it first, have an attorney review it afterwards anyway.  Since the Reliable Fire Insurance decision from the IL Supreme Court, it's hard to say that any given contract is intrinsically enforceable, or unenforceable, but this one seems pretty aggressive, and prior case law indicates that a world-wide noncompete is unenforceable in itself.  Also there are now stricter requirements for consideration, a quid pro quo, for such a contract.  If you're an at will employee, you won't have much recourse if they do fire you for not signing, so think carefully about it.  If they're not paying you anything to sign, and you don't keep working there for a substantial period after signing, however, you'll have a decent argument that there was no consideration and it's not enforceable.  So if you're going to find another job and quit after signing, don't delay too long.  Talk to a lawyer first though.  Not having time to read the contract and consult a lawyer may in theory be a defense to enforcement, but don't count on it.

It sounds like you are on felony probation. If so then the Judge probably will violate your probation. The Judge will most likely take you into custody and set a probation violation hearing two to four weeks later. On that date the DA and your defense attorney will negotiate a disposition for you. There may be a probation report generated with a recommendation. If you are on felony probation you could receive anything from 180 straight time or State Prison, depending on your record. The sooner you take care of it the better. If you wait until the cops pick you up on a warrant that will make things worse for you. If you are on misdemeanor probation and you turn yourself in to do straight time the most you will get is 365 days at half time. Once again it depends on your record and if you turn yourself in or get arrested on a warrant or new case. There is a chance your lawyer will be able to convince the Court that you should just do the 180 that you owe.

You are citing this, "If the registered owner is unable to request or appear for the hearing, someone authorized by the owner can do so. An attorney can act on behalf of the registered owner by providing a copy of his/her attorney credentials by mail.  He/she can also present the credentials at the time of hearing to an Information Aide at one of the Payment Centers. All other individuals must submit or present a notarized letter of authorization to represent the registered owner. Notarized letters are valid up to 30 days from the date of notarization."  I also found this.http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/ah/supp_info/the_hearing_process/what_to_expect_atahearing.html  "You may represent yourself, hire an attorney to represent you at your own expense, or in some instances have an authorized representative attend the hearing on your own behalf. Your representative may be a friend, family member, employee or agent. In cases such as boot or vehicle impoundment hearings, the registered owner of the vehicle must appear in person unless an affidavit permitting a representative to appear is submitted. In police cases such as disorderly conduct, the accused must appear in person...no exceptions."  I can see why you think a non-lawyer can assist someone in traffic court. The language certainly makes it look as if this is the case. Based on the second passage I found, it seems that a non-lawyer may assist the defendant in some cases, but not in others. Neither passage makes it completely clear in which types of cases a non-lawyer may participate, however. I did not look further to see if I could find additional information.  The default in legal proceedings is that only a lawyer can represent another person. But there are exceptions from time to time. Therefore the answer to your question is that more research is required.  If I were you,  I would call the traffic court and ask for clarification as to whether a non-lawyer may assist someone in the specific kind of traffic court case you are looking into. That will quickly resolve your issue.  Best of luck.

This depends on the local rules of court applicable to your case. Each jurisdiction has their local rules available on their county website. That being said, you typically do not need to, but the question is also making sure that your particular judge does not let you know that you should have on the day of trial, leaving you out of luck. Because Contempt hearings are quasi-criminal they can be broken up into as many as three hearings: the arraignment phase, the pre-trial phase, and the trial itself. At the time of the arraignment, the pleadings are considered to make sure they set forth a cause of action and the defending party advises the court as to their plea, i.e., guilty or not guilty. If the Court sets the case for pre-trial, in my experience judge's tend to look favorably at exhibit lists (and oftentimes the exhibits themselves) and witness lists being provided. The reason for this is tied to the quasi-criminal nature of a contempt (which I referenced, above). In a criminal hearing, the District Attorney is required to voluntarily provide the Defendant with a copy of their discovery. Likewise, at least in theory, that should happen in family law contempt hearings as well. I also find it handy to bring a number of copies of the exhibits to court for use at trial. The rule of thumb is bring 4 copies - one for the Court, one for the opposing counsel/party, one for yourself, and for the witness. You can also pre-mark them if you'd like. Regardless, you can always use an "undisclosed" exhibit for the purposes of impeachment. Technically, impeachment exhibits do not come in as substantive evidence for the truth of the matter asserted (although you can't un-ring the bell!), and are geared toward undermining the credibility of the witness and, as an offshoot of this, the weight of their testimony. Good luck with your case! Armed with this information, I'm sure you will do great!

n determining whether an award of alimony is appropriate and, if so, what type, duration and amount, family court judges are guided by the following statutory factors: (1) The actual need and ability of the parties to pay;  (2) The duration of the marriage or civil union;  (3) The age, physical and emotional health of the parties;  (4) The standard of living established in the marriage or civil union and the likelihood that each party can maintain a reasonably comparable standard of living, with neither party having a greater entitlement to that standard of living than the other;  (5) The earning capacities, educational levels, vocational skills, and employability of the parties;  (6) The length of absence from the job market of the party seeking maintenance;  (7) The parental responsibilities for the children;  (8) The time and expense necessary to acquire sufficient education or training to enable the party seeking maintenance to find appropriate employment, the availability of the training and employment, and the opportunity for future acquisitions of capital assets and income;  (9) The history of the financial or non-financial contributions to the marriage or civil union by each party including contributions to the care and education of the children and interruption of personal careers or educational opportunities;  (10) The equitable distribution of property ordered and any payouts on equitable distribution, directly or indirectly, out of current income, to the extent this consideration is reasonable, just and fair;  (11) The income available to either party through investment of any assets held by that party;  (12) The tax treatment and consequences to both parties of any alimony award, including the designation of all or a portion of the payment as a non-taxable payment;  (13) The nature, amount, and length of pendente lite support paid, if any; and   (14) Any other factors which the court may deem relevant.    Governor Christie recently signed alimony reform legislation. One of the big changes was placing limitations on the duration of alimony in marriages that are less than 20 years. Since your first marriage is less than 20 years, the new law does not permit the length of your alimony to exceed the length of your marriage. However, it important to note that judges still have discretion to deviate from this rule in the case of exceptional circumstances. It is important that you discuss the specifics of your situation with an experienced matrimonial attorney to learn what your rights are, how to protect them and how the changes to the alimony laws can affect your case. Additionally, below are links to articles and information that may assist you with your case.

Yes, in Florida, when the court notices a case for a hearing on dismissal based on Lack of Prosecution ("LOP"), the plaintiff has a period within which to file papers constituting record activity in order to avoid the dismissal. If plaintiff filed a Motion for Summary Judgment prior to the deadline, that would surely constitute sufficient activity. If plaintiff missed the deadline the court might conduct the hearing as scheduled anyway, and plaintiff would have to show good cause for neglecting the case for so long. If you are unsure, consult a lawyer and check with the judge's office to see if the hearing is still set for this case: usually, LOP dockets are set with multiple cases all at once; some will be removed when record activity appears in advance. Good luck to you.

Most debt buyers cannot present competent evidence of the debt, their ownership of the debt, or the amount of the debt.  The consumer is well advised to hire an attorney experienced in defending such cases in the particular court.  An attorney familiar with the rules of evidence and local procedure can often exclude enough of the debt buyer's "evidence" to win the case or force a dismissal. For example, it is not necessarily a good idea to ask for a lot of documents and discovery, as this may only force the plaintiff to prepare a case it would not otherwise prepare.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act covers these issues.  In order to maintain a claim under the FCRA you have submit a written dispute to each of the Credit Reporting Agencies that show the debt. Unless you have a contract with the employer that limits the employer's ability to fire you, you are an at will employee. As an at will employee, you can be fired by the employer at any time for any reason with or without notice as long as the employer is not breaking some other law in firing you. You have the same right to quit at any time.  The employer would be breaking the law if the employer fired you because of your protected characteristic (such as race, gender, sexual orientation, age, etc.) or protected activity (such as union organizing, filing a worker's comp claim, serving on a jury, etc.). More information about unlawful discrimination is at www.hum.wa.gov .  Looking for an employer closer to home is not a protected characteristic or activity.  Firing you due to a mistaken belief that you were moving on is also not unlawful. The law does not require the employer to be correct in its assumptions. Firing an employee who may or may be looking for other employment is not unlawful in itself.  The employer cannot keep your personal belongings. You can contact someone at the employer to arrange for the return of your personal belongings.  If you qualify for unemployment benefits, you can apply at www.esd.wa.gov . Unless the employer can prove that you were fired for misconduct, you may be eligible for unemployment benefits. Looking for another job is not misconduct that would make a person not eligible for unemployment benefits.  If  you believe the employer did something unlawful, you can review the specific facts with your attorney to see what your legal options are.

You will need to retain a lawyer to review your case and determine if its worth pursuing. Its impossible to predict or evaluate your claim in a public forum like this. There are too many fact-dependent issues to address. But generally here are my thoughts.  This is a very tough question to answer because it involves the intersection of (1) contract law (2) intellectual property law and (3) potential tort law in two areas (i) invasion of privacy and (ii) possible defamation (a straight tort) and false light (another invasion of privacy tort).  1. Contract law: When you volunteer to perform a duty without consideration, you are considered exactly that, a volunteer. There is no consideration supporting your performance other than your altruistic intentions of helping someone or the mission of the organization out.  Concomitant with your waiver of consideration in performing gratuitous services, the organization that you did the work for at no charge, owes an obligation to hold you out in the light most favorable to the general public in a truthful manner. In other words if you support saving trees, then the organization can hold you out as a "tree hugger". That's fine. That is the intent and purpose of your gratuitous association with the organization.    What happens is sometimes that contract is breached when, after you have performed gratuitously, the organization trash-talks you, which is contrary to the consideration of your performance. That is, they are no longer saying you're a "tree hugger" but instead calling you a tree molester.   At that point they are using your name and likeness for a purpose that it was not intended to be used for. At that point they have exceeded their license to use your name and likeness.  (A.) The production company may have a release from you, but if you were not provided a copy or signed it without having the opportunity to read it, or take it to a lawyer, it may not be worth anything. In California releases are scrutinized very carefully by the courts.   For instance in an actor/talent release form, you have the right to withdraw your consent at any time, if after signing the agreement, the performance you render is used in a manner that you no longer approve of. Since the consideration for the release is gratuitous, its very hard for the party using the performance to continue its use without your permission.  If you disassociate yourself with this non-profit, you do have a right to withdraw your consent.  Whether this right is enforceable depends on what you signed. I suggest you contact the company that handed you the paper to sign and get a copy of it.  2. Intellectual Property Law:  California has a good statute protecting you from unauthorized uses of your image and performances.  Cal. Civil Code 3344-3346 protects the unauthorized use of your image and performance. What consists of "unauthorized" is dependent on how your contract with the production company is interpreted by the courts.  However, as I said, when rendering gratuitous performances, there is no consideration involved other than altruistic motives, you can withdraw your consent.  In a gratuitous performance you are licensing your rights out to someone. But since there is no consideration, the license MAY be revocable. So if you revoke your consent, they may not be able to continue to associate you with the non-profit.  3. Tort Law:  (a). Invasion of Privacy. If the non-profit "blacklisted" you, that may be cause for a suit against them for defaming you and invading your privacy.  1.  Slanders or libels occurs if someone knowingly makes a false statement that is of and concerning you which is false or is known to be false at the time the statement is made, which a third person heard or read, and reasonably believed it, which ultimately causes damage to your reputation. There are legal and technical defenses to defamation.   2. False light is similar to defamation only its a true statement but spins it in a false light.

Under Washington Law, if you  are the primary residential parent, and wish to move, you have to give sixty days notice to the father.  He has thirty days to object.  If he objects, the matter needs to go to court as a relocation proceeding.  In that proceeding, there will be a presumption in favor of your being able to relocate which the father will have to overcome.  There is a ten point test that is employed.  If you would like more information, you may call me at (360)426-2928 and set a phone appointment.  As an aside, you are contemplating moving back to Seattle to co-parent with the person who kicked you out?  If I were you I would seek an attorney where you currently live and speak one in Washington, to see what your rights are.  It sounds to me like you do not have a parenting plan.  You need a custody case and get one, before you do anything else.  TALK TO A LAWYER.

The H-2B process is employer driven, i.e. your employer files an application for a temporary labor certification and upon approval and H-2B visa petition.  Additionally, an employer must establish that its need for an employee's services are temporary in nature.  You and your employer need to consult with an immigration attorney who has experience handing H-2B cases.  This should be done immediately as time is of the essence.

The property must be habitable and must have, among other things, working plumbing and a supply of hot and cold water.  RCW 59.18.060(8), (11).  In a recent development in Washington, a court ruled that if a residence is so obviously defective that it is uninhabitable at the commencement of the tenancy, the tenant can refuse to take occupancy and be released from the lease.  From your description, this property meets that standard.  You should document the condition when you attempted to take possession in case you need to prove it in court if the landlord sues for non-payment or other damages.  Take as many photos as possible and keep contact information for any witnesses you may have.  Make sure you clearly notify the landlord, in writing, that you will not be moving in because of the defects.

While it is understandable that the modification of child support has triggered your renewed interest in seeing your daughter the fact that you went for two years without making an effort to fix this won't be perceived very well by the court.  The courts see child support as getting money to support the child and visitation or parenting time as putting time into raising the child and the courts don't like to see the payment of support cross referenced with parenting time.  These are two different functions in the court's mind.    You need to be very careful not to let the court perceive that the increase in support is your motivation to demand time with your daughter.  That said you are not the first parent to be driven away but a former partner and miss time with their child and you are entitled to the court's sympathies.  Just keep the child support matter as a something separate when it comes up in conversation.  If you already have a parenting plan that is not being followed, go to the court house and fill out and file the form requesting enforcement.  If a detailed parenting plan was never set up, fill out the form to request a modification of the custody/parenting plan situation so that you will have a detailed plan as to when you have time with your daughter and once it is spelled out on paper you will have more enforcement rights.  Your daughter needs you and surely misses you - so put a rush on this.  (My experience is that the more that one parent bad mouths the other parent, the more the child wants to spend time with the other parent and resents the negative comments.)

More information would be useful - are you on a term lease or a month-to-month?  Is there any sort of rent control that governs your area or rental?  Undoubtedly a New York licensed landlord-tenant attorney will respond and can tell you definitively but if you have not gotten at least 30 days advanced written notice terminating your lease (maybe more since you have been there over a year - here in Oregon it would need to be 60 days notice), you cannot be forced out.  However, if or when you do get proper notice, lawfully served, your time will start running and you will have to be out within the time frame or face a potential eviction on your record and if you think it is hard to find another rental now, it will be considerably harder if you have been evicted by your last landlord.  Otherwise, no, a landlord is not obligated to pay your moving expenses or rent money.  On the other hand, if they really want you out soon, they may well contribute towards your expenses in order to get what they want.  You can't force it but they can voluntarily cut such a deal with you - it happens quite frequently actually and assuming things are not terrible between you and your mom, she might particularly be willing to help out in this situation.  Good luck.

Employers have no duty whatsoever to determine if you have vacation plans.  When you go to work for an employer, you serve at their pleasure, and previously made vacation plans get no legal consideration.  If your employer made knowingly false statements to you about being able to take the vacation you might have a legal claim for some kind of misrepresentation or estoppel, but then you are at odds with your employer - something that you likely do not want to do.  It is unfortunate that your employer is not able to accommodate your vacation needs.  However, it is not advisable to sue your employer over a lost vacation.  That is up to you.  Good luck.

I'm not sure I understand your question.  Many small firms refer out larger cases to larger law firms.  The issue of the expert is puzzling.  You can get any expert to review medical records if you pay them.  I think what this attorney is actually saying is that he isn't comfortably spending the kind of money he needs to on an expert until he gets someone elses opinion about the viability of your case. Your attorney needs to get your consent to partner with another law firm (unless the fee agreement specifies that they may do so).  If your attorney does work with another firm it should not cost you any additional money since the fees to be split by the attorneys should be based on the percetange specified in your fee agreement.  In other words if your fee agreement says the attorney is to get 1/3 of the amount recovered then the two attorneys have to divide up the 1/3 and you would still be entitled to the 2/3.  Medical malpractice and wrongful death claims are difficult and expensive and take years to get done.  Don't let the initial evaluation stage drag on too long.  You should have some answers about the viability of your case after a year.

I agree with Mr. Hines.  Hidden fees, if they are not in the contract, are usually illegal. Texas I am sure follows the same basic framework that other states follow, in that there is a standard landlord/tenant act.  There is also a consumer protection/unfair and deceptive trade practice act on the books which may apply since a lease if this is residential, is a consumer transaction. Hidden fees are usually fraudulent or illegal and so the landlord is simply intimidating to keep the deposit and dissuade the tenant from suing, just as you pointed out.  Click on "Find a Lawyer" above and try and find a landlord/tenant attorney to set up a consult with. Most states that have a landlord/tenant act also have attorney fees provisions, as likely the written lease does too. If the landlord is clearly in the wrong, its possible the landlord will have to pay the deposit back and get socked with damages and attorney fees.

First of all, I'm sorry to hear that your friend was hurt and hope that she makes a full recovery.  Where a person like your friend is harmed as the result of the negligent conduct of another person, the injured person can make file a lawsuit seeking compensation for personal injuries and damages, including medical bills.  Probably the most important part of your friend's case is going to be proving that the driver did something wrong, or was somehow negligent.  You haven't alleged that the driver was cited for speeding, or was texting, drunk, failed to stop at a stop sign, went through a red light, or violated some other rule of the road.  You should not expect that a driver who is traveling the legal speed limit will be able to stop safely when a pedestrian is in the middle of a road at night.  Based on the reaction you are getting from lawyers, my guess is that your friend crossed in the middle of the road at night, without the benefit of a crosswalk or walk signal, which may make her responsible for her own injuries.  In other words, your friend had no right to be in the middle of the road at the time she was struck, and that may prevent or severely lessen any compensation for her injuries.  As her friend, you want to see her receive as much help as possible, but the law will generally not make another person pay your friend's injuries unless they are found to have done something wrong.  I wouldn't give up entirely, and I would probably pursue a claim with the hope of receiving some compensation, but I think, depending on the facts, you may need to dramatically lower your expectations.

It is within the school's discretion to have a policy mandating purchase of its policy for student health insurance. There are a number of factors that go into that decision making process and I would expect the number of schools doing this will decline, but there is nothing unconstitutional about it on its face. If your school is a public school, the policy must meet muster in terms of implementation, but if it is a private school, I cannot imagine any constitutional prohibition. Look at the student handbook to determine if there are any avenues for waiving the requirement. That is the only possible solution that I can see.

There are a lot of factors that determine whether you will receive alimony or not in your divorce:   - each spouse‰Ûªs earning capacity, separate estate, financial resources, and debts - each spouse‰Ûªs contributions to the marriage, including homemaking, child care, education, and career building for the other spouse - the marital standard of living - each spouse‰Ûªs age, and physical and emotional condition - any time necessary for either spouse to obtain education and training for appropriate employment, and - the length of the marriage.  Your answer talks about a few of these (length of marriage and current educational needs), but the other factors should be discussed confidentially with an experienced attorney to see what the likely outcomes will be.    Whether you file first or your spouse files first is not one of the factors in determining alimony.    Obtaining an alimony award with a short marriage is not as easy as with a long marriage.  So, you will need a lawyer experienced at helping people like you get the results that they need.

There are hundreds of "bankruptcy" attorneys in Arizona.  Of those just a few will fit the criteria set forth above.  Again, bankruptcy is a very complicated process and you want to use an attorney who will be there when you need them. It sounds as if you are seeking to sue a former attorney for an adverse result you got in a prior legal proceeding.  Such cases are handled by attorneys practicing Tort law (ie-personal injury) but you should look for one who has experience handling legal malpractice cases, who will work on a contingency fee basis - meaning you do not pay a fee unless you are successful.  Be aware that legal malpractice cases generally require you to prove two critical things:  First, you must prove that the attorney failed to properly represent you in the former case, by not meeting the standards of legal representation that was necessary or required under the facts or circumstances of that prior legal matter.   The fact that you lost or got an adverse result does not, by itself, prove that the attorney did not properly represent you.  Also, an act of an attorney based on a tactical decision or judgment does not automatically prove malpractice just because that decision did not produce a successful result.  Secondly, you would have to prove that you would have won your prior legal matter (gotten a favorable result) had the attorney acted properly in representing you.   In other words, if the attorney committed malpractice but it can't be shown that you would have likely prevailed in the former matter regardless of that malpractice, then your legal malpractice claim will be dismissed.

What you really need to do is find an experienced bankruptcy attorney other than the one who filed the ch 7. Look on AVVO. Then I am not saying you should file unless you cannot afford all your debts. But you want to defend yourself in that adversary lawsuit or in the civil lawsuit. If liable, then there are other issues as follows below   You may  need, depending on outcome of that lawsuit or likelihood of winning to file a bankruptcy  and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!  That civil lawsuit on fraud they will discuss with you. THE GOOD NEWS: FRAUD IN BANKRUPTCY COURT IS NOT THE SAME..MAKE SURE THE ATTORNEY CAREFULLY EXPLAINS EACH OF THE ELEMENTS !   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Any time an attorney-in-fact uses a POA to do anything that provides a benefit to the attorney-in-fact, it's subject possible scrutiny.  That doesn't necessarily mean it's void, but, as I'm sure you can understand, on its face it presents the possibility that the attorney-in-fact took advantage of the principal.  From what I can tell, the threshold question will be whether the deed was prepared before or after your mother's death.  If after, the deed is no good because a power of attorney does not survive the death of the principal.  Assuming the deed was prepared before her death, the language of the POA itself, read in tandem with the POA statute, may have a lot to do with the results.  For example, a POA will sometimes expressly authorize the attorney-in-fact to make a gift to himself, but sometimes within limitations. On the other hand, they sometimes expressly prohibit self-dealing or making gifts to the AIF.    If the language of the POA itself doesn't shed enough light on the question, there 's always the duty of the AIF to act in the best interest of the principal, and that does not always mean following the instructions of the principal (such as instructions to prepare a deed in favor of the attorney-in-fact), because sometimes the principal is not capable of deciding what is in his or her best interest.  However, you stated your mother did not have dementia, so her instructions may well carry a lot of weight, but once you're down to determining whether the AIF acted in the best interest of the principal, it's difficult to predict where a court will come out on the question.

If you have satisfied the judgment in full, then you should be entitled to each of the following: (a) Plaintiff's counsel must file in the case an Acknowledgment of Satisfaction of Judgment in Full (see forms below, EJ-100); (b) the judgment on your credit report should be updated to reflect fully paid, even if you need to contact the consumer reporting agencies directly, such as using a letter of dispute (see link below); (c) any writs of attachment, bank levies, and wage garnishment orders should be withdrawn and recalled to the court; (d) any funds collected in excess of the full judgment must be refunded to you promptly.  See Cal. Code of Civil Procedure (CCP) sections 724.010 to 724.100. In particular, CCP section 724.050 states that you should serve personally or by mail a written demand to the attorney of record with the warning that they must file the acknowledgment within 15 days of receipt or the judgment debtor may institute court proceedings, which can include recovery of the debtor's attorney's fees plus damages, if the failure is without just cause.  Moreover, collecting more than is permitted by law may be a violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), if this was a mostly consumer debt (not mostly business purposes), for which you and your consumer attorney can file suit within a year and seek and award for damages and attorney's fees. Consult an experienced consumer attorney promptly.  By: Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)  CONSUMER LAW OFFICE OF ROBERT STEMPLER  A Professional Law Corporation

The creditor probably hasn't sent a garnishment summons directed to any particular account. Rather they have sent a Summons to a bank for all property belonging to the judgment debtor whose social security number is xxx xx xxxx.  The bank dutifully freezes all accounts with that name and/or SSN attached to them.  Then the account holder, if it is not that individual has 14 days to contact the judgment creditor's attorney and complaint get it's bank account unfrozen.  If the business is incorporated, or is an LLC, the business' lawyer should write to the creditor's lawyer, provide  a copy of an account statement showing it is the company account, not the individual's account, and demand that they release the money.  If the business is not an LLC or a corporation, then it is not a legal entity capable of having a bank account, and the money belongs to the individual who opened the account, or if it is a joint account, to the person who deposited the money.

There is a federal statute that MAY apply in your case.  The statue prohibits the possession of a firearm by those convicted of crimes ofa misdemeanor crime of  domestic violence.  Here is the relevant language. A "misdemeanor crime of domestic violence" means an offense that: is a misdemeanor under Federal or State law; has, as an element, the use or attempted use of physical force, or the threatened use of a deadly weapon; and was committed by a current or former spouse, parent, or guardian of the victim, by a person with whom the victim shares a child in common, by a person who is cohabiting with or has cohabited with the victim as a spouse, parent, or guardian, or by a person similarly situated to a spouse, parent, or guardian of the victim. However, a person is not considered to have been convicted of a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence unless: the person was represented by counsel in the case, or knowingly and intelligently waived the right of counsel in the case; and in the case of a prosecution for which a person was entitled to a jury trial in the jurisdiction in which the case was tried, either ‰ÛÓ the case was tried by a jury, or the person knowingly and intelligently waived the right to have the case tried by a jury, by guilty plea or otherwise. In addition, a conviction would not be disabling if it has been expunged or set aside, or is an offense for which the person has been pardoned or has had civil rights restored (if the law of the jurisdiction in which the proceedings were held provides for the loss of civil rights upon conviction for such an offense) unless the pardon, expunction, or restoration of civil rights expressly provides that the person may not ship, transport, possess, or receive firearms, and the person is not otherwise prohibited by the law of the jurisdiction in which the proceedings were held from receiving or possessing firearms. [18 U.S.C. 921(a)(33), 27 CFR 478.11]  Be careful and speak with a lawyer before purchasing a firearm.  The federal authorities aggressively pursue these cases and jail sentences are harssh.

There are a number of factors that could affect sentencing in this situation. Since your husband has a prior charge, he clearly won't be eligible for a diversion program. The real question is whether the State will seek jail time or probation (or some combination thereof). If the theft is charged as a second degree misdemeanor, then the maximum sentence could be up to sixty days in jail or six months on probation. On the other hand, if it's charged as a first degree misdemeanor, the maximum is up to a year in jail or up to a year on probation. You should definitely seek counsel for him for this case. An experienced defense attorney can advise you on how to proceed.

You need have a consult with a tax attorney. What you posted is ill-advised because you are mixing concepts of profit and non-profit entities.   A profit making entity (smaill business) is for your beneifit. A non-profit entity is for either the benefit of the public or its membership, but you cannot have as its "non-profit" purpose you sole benefit.   Soliciting "donations" for your personal benifit is not only a profit making venture, it could also be deemed criminal. Statements like"I am thinking of starting it with a nonprofit license so that I pay a lower tax and collect more of what comes in so that I can actually make some money." and "I am also thinking of starting it as a nonprofit to qualify for a grants and for added credibility that could make my website more likely to turn an actual profit." are dangerous statements to be publishing on a website.  If you cannot afford a consult with a tax attormey review the publications on businesses and non-profits at irs.gov. IN addition, there is more to forming non profit than get a "nonprofit license."  Educate yourself and Good Luck! Phillip M. Smith Jr. Los Angeles Tax and Business Attorney Licensed in the United States Tax Court Call: 855 IRSTAXBIZ

The issue of a small estate is probably independent of the trust.  If there are assets in the trust (which it actually appears from your description there are not), they pass via the trust.  If there are non-probate assets (the joint accounts and beneficiary designated IRA) they have nothing to do with the trust or will.  If the will pours assets over into the trust, you have to decide if it is worth it to deal with those funds.  The one issue I would want to know about is how will this HELOC be treated - if it is due from the probate estate AND/OR the living trust you'll have to deal with it at some point so whether its through the estate or trust it might not matter - a living trust is not a debt-avoidance tool so "estate statutory" debts can still be due even though you say there are only $600 in the estate.  My advice is to see a lawyer so you know how to handle this properly.

It can be either a 4th degree crime or a DP offense, depending on the specific nature of the location you are accused of trespassing onto. Given your facts, it appears that it is graded as a DP offense, still within the criminal code, but not a crime. In addition, if it is being handled in the Municipal Court it is a DP, as the Municipal Courts cannot handle charges graded as crimes. The problem will be whether the prosecutor and the Judge will both agree to a criminal offense being downgraded to a charge under the municipal code. Some courts are being very restrictive about this type of downgrade, while others seem to be more willing to consider it if the facts support the downgrade. I agree with my colleagues that this is something you should discuss with an experienced NJ criminal defense lawyer before you go to Court, and you may want to consider retaining the lawyer, as the atty will be in a better position to negotiate this with the prosecutor and if needed, to try to convince the Judge to accept as a disposition.

CCP 437c (g) requires the court, upon granting a MSJ, to set forth the reasons for its determination, and to make specific references to the evidence supporting and opposing the motion to show that no triable issue of fact exists.  The court is permitted to do this by making an oral record by court reporter, or by a written ruling.    If the court made his statement of decision in open court, with a court reporter present, then that's probably your "statement of decision".  If no oral ruling setting forth the court's reasoning and evidence was made, and the court requested parties to submit proposed rulings, and that has not been done, then you can probably file a subsequent motion requesting a "statement of decision" asking the court to set forth its reasons and evidence relied on in a written order.    Bear in mind, the court is not going to be pleased with your request because it will make him do more work.  He (or she) will probably adopt whatever the other side proposes.    Then, you take that up to the Court of Appeals.  If the court does nothing in response to your request for a statement of decision, then that will be another ground for your appeal.  Having said all of that, I would also join in the suggestions that you hire an attorney immediately to evaluate your problem.

At most hearings, oral arguments are heard. It is also possible that testimony will be received by the court at such a hearing. Oral arguments at hearings are most often concerning a particular matter in a case rather than the entire merits of the case, the latter of which occurs mostly at trial. A summary judgment hearing is a little different than other hearings because an entire case may be disposed of. A summary judgment hearing decides whether the undisputed facts can serve as a basis which, when coupled with the law, can result in a judgment. A court may decide whether the judgment being made will be partial or resolve all the issues in the case. On such a motion, there will often be oral argument at a hearing, particularly if the court, after looking at the written arguments, is disposed to grant the motion. At a trial all facts are found based on the evidence adduced, and the law is applied to the entirety of those facts resulting in a judgment being entered. At the appellate level, written arguments are submitted to the court in what are called "briefs" accompanied by pertinent parts of the record from the proceeding that is the sublect of the appeal. Then, the court will in many instances hear oral argument from the opposing sides. You should be aware that the hearing and oral argument phrases that you ask about are somewhat interchangeable, especially in casual conversation, even among lawyers.

Yes, copying that information is a violation of copyright.  Furthermore, you are doing yourself a great dis-service by not contacting your own lawyer to help you get your ducks in a row.  The TOS is your contract with your visitors.  Using your own lawyer will allow you to make your visitors do what you want, and will shield you from many liabilities.  Here is what I tell my clients about their web sites:  There is much you need to know as you begin your new business.  Further, your web site will need legal policies.  I suggest you do not attempt to write your own legal policies.  This is not where your training and background lie, and though you are probably as smart as an attorney, you do not have their experience.   Below is a checklist for legal issues I use for new e-commerce clients.   1. Business Model ‰ÛÒ Is your idea viable as a web based business?  Do you have a business model written out?   2. Business entity - Are you going to be a C corp, a sub-S, an LLC or a sole proprietorship?  There are liability and tax issues that can dramatically affect how your business prospers and selecting the proper entity is a critical first step.   3. Terms of Service - This is your contract with your visitors and is the most important item for any e-commerce site. A little work here brings big dividends in the future.  The absence of a written "Terms of Service" can expose your business and possibly you to both criminal and civil liability.   4. Privacy Policy - Every e-commerce site needs a Privacy Policy!  Operating an e-commerce site without a Privacy Policy exposes you to civil and criminal liability.  Further, the absence of a Privacy Policy will cause a red flag for many legitimate visitors who will not deal a web site not professional enough to have a Privacy Policy.   5. FTC guidelines - The FTC has been regulating business advertising for almost a century.  All of their advertising guidelines apply to e-commerce sites. The FTC negotiates with established e-commerce businesses but new ones are frequently sanctioned with fines, etc.   6. Domain Name issues?  Is your name available?  Can you create a Trademark? Domain names, trademarks and service marks can become valuable assets but the failure to properly protect them may deprive you of much of their value.   7. Trademark - Do you have a brand name free from conflict? Should you start with just common law rights? When Should you register the mark?      8. Copyright - If it is on the web, it already belongs to somebody. Did you buy a license for the images you are using?  Using copyrighted materials without proper licensing  is not only expensive but under some conditions criminal.   9. Do you need a DMCA policy?  This is a very inexpensive "insurance policy" which gives you a "safe harbor" from liability if your visitors post copyright material on your web site.   10. Web Site security issues?  Ask Target, etc. if this is an issue.   11. Do you need and have an EIN? You can get that for free.  If your business is a corporation (C or S) you need an EIN.  Even if you‰Ûªre a single member LLC  or sole proprietorship, you‰Ûªll need an EIN to open your bank account.   12. Do you need an arbitration clause?  Arbitration is not always pleasant but it‰Ûªs cheaper and quicker than litigation.  Further, an arbitration clause will create a barrier against any class action being brought against you.   13. Do you have employees?  If so you need written policies regarding their authority and use of the internet.   This can be part of your employee manual.   14. Do you know the difference between a "browser wrap" and a "click wrap" and which do you need?   Using a click wrap will greatly decrease your liability.   15.   Are you abiding by the Child's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) rules?  There are serious repercussions if you run afoul of COPPA.

Each divorce case is different.  There is no magic formula for determining how property is divided.  In fact, TN law provides 11 factors to be considered. They are:  (c) In making equitable division of marital property, the court shall consider all relevant factors including:     (1) The duration of the marriage;     (2) The age, physical and mental health, vocational skills, employability, earning capacity, estate, financial liabilities and financial needs of each of the parties;     (3) The tangible or intangible contribution by one (1) party to the education, training or increased earning power of the other party;     (4) The relative ability of each party for future acquisitions of capital assets and income;     (5)  (A) The contribution of each party to the acquisition, preservation, appreciation, depreciation or dissipation of the marital or separate property, including the contribution of a party to the marriage as homemaker, wage earner or parent, with the contribution of a party as homemaker or wage earner to be given the same weight if each party has fulfilled its role;        (B) For purposes of this subdivision (c)(5), dissipation of assets means wasteful expenditures which reduce the marital property available for equitable distributions and which are made for a purpose contrary to the marriage either before or after a complaint for divorce or legal separation has been filed.     (6) The value of the separate property of each party;     (7) The estate of each party at the time of the marriage;     (8) The economic circumstances of each party at the time the division of property is to become effective;     (9) The tax consequences to each party, costs associated with the reasonably foreseeable sale of the asset, and other reasonably foreseeable expenses associated with the asset;     (10) The amount of social security benefits available to each spouse; and     (11) Such other factors as are necessary to consider the equities between the parties.

Assuming you work for a private employer and you are not under an employment contract, the answer is yes.   North Carolina is an "at-will" state, which means that a private employer can generally discharge a (i.e., fire) an employee for any reason or no reason at all.    While there laws that protect employees from being fired for certain prohibited reasons (e.g., race, ethnicity, national origin, gender, disability, retaliation), none of those  reasons appear to be relevant in your case.   With that being said, if they do end up firing you, you should nevertheless be entitled to your unemployment benefits.   Mind you, the Division of Employment Security may initially deny your claim for unemployment; however, if your claim is denied, you should appeal and ask for a hearing.  In my experience, based on the facts above, if argued correctly, you should be able to win your unemployment benefits.

You're under no obligation to act as a reference for this person to the bar association.  That is voluntary.  If you make false statements to the bar association about this person, then you would be liable for any defamatory remarks.  It sounds like this "friend" is merely worried that you might say something negative to the bar association that might affect their approval to become licensed.  If you have valid concerns about the person's character and wish to voice them to the bar, then I would caution you to speak only about facts and circumstances about which you have direct and corroborable knowledge.  The mere fact that the person is making these threats related to their admission to practice law sounds like a grounds to believe they are not of the good, moral character that the rest of us practitioners would aspire to, although I am not in possession of all of the facts, here.  Bottom line:  speak only the truth, and don't worry about being sued, because in a defamation case, the truth is an absolute defense.  It sounds like an empty threat from someone with personality issues.  And one last thing:  keep a record of any phone calls, emails or other messages you receive from this person in case you ever need to present them as evidence (either in your own defense, or as evidence of the person's bad character).

If you have a valid POA that authorizes you to engage in financial transactions for your son, you can endorse the check to yourself by signing his name on the back and deposit it into your bank account.  When it clears (which could be 7 days) you can withdraw cash and provide it to your son.  Personal checks don‰Ûªt expire. But they do become what is known as "stale dated." Simply put, a check becomes stale dated six months after it was written. After six months, banks have the option of refusing to deposit or cash any stale-dated checks.   The check is still valid, however.

Staff attorneys with the SPD's Office and private attorneys who accept SPD appointed cases often take cases to trial.  You have an absolute right to a trial by jury.  You are the only one who can waive that right.  If you are not happy with the attorney you have, you may ask that attorney to withdraw from your case and request that a different attorney be appointed.  This, however, is not an unlimited option.  Once you have asked for a different attorney one or two times, expect the judge to tell you that if you fire the next one you will be representing yourself.  Also be aware that while YOU may think you have a good chance to win at trial, an experienced attorney might have a very different view of the case.  Attorneys know about the rules of evidence (what can come before the jury and what cannot).  Attorneys also know what generally works with a jury and what doesn't.  If your attorney is telling you that you don't have a very good case and you disagree, you may want to have a different attorney appointed so that you can get a second opinion.  If the next attorney doesn't think you have a very good case, you probably don't have a very good case.  That said, you still can tell your attorney that you want a trial.  Understand that the sentence you receive when you take a case to trial and lose, is usually not as good as the sentence you get by accepting a plea offer.  This is especially true when you elect to testify on your own behalf and the jury's verdict indicates that they didn't believe you.  In that case, the judge believes that you lied to the jury which is an indication of your character.  The character of the defendant is one of the main sentencing factors that the judge must consider when deciding your sentence.

Yes, you must be legally married (or be registered domestic partners).  In addition to providing a marriage certificate (or registration), the person seeking to adopt will undergo a criminal background check; a court investigator will make a report/recommendation to the court; the child must be at least 10 years younger than the person seeking to adopt; and, a consent or termination of parental rights is required.  These are the highlights of the requirements and it is a good idea to speak with an attorney in your area for specifics of your situation and any additional local court rules that may apply should you become married.

If you are looking for a recommendation of a good lawyer, I would speak to the Federal Defender's Office in Richmond, who can recommend good criminal defense lawyers in the area. If you are looking for someone to handle your 2255 for free, that is going to be hard to find.  Litigating a 2255 is a huge undertaking, especially when you have pleaded guilty. Essentially, you need a lawyer to prove that you are innocent but pleaded guilty anyway.  If you are unable to afford a lawyer to help you, you may have to file it yourself and ask the court to appoint counsel.  The court will only do so if your papers present a legitimate claim.  The 2255 is not drawn to a judge randomly. It goes back to the judge who handled your case originally.  Good luck.

Mediation is a fairly informal conference where the parties meet (with attorneys if you have them) with a mediator who attempts to facilitate a settlement or agreement between the parties.  The only expectation is that you act professionally in discussing the issues of your case.  Your mediation notice likely has details about how long mediation lasts, and how much it might costs, and you could mediate together in the same room or with each of you in separate rooms.  The mediator does not make decisions and cannot give you legal advice.  Also, keep in mind that negotiations that take place in mediation and most discussions held in mediation are 100% confidential.  The 'jargon' basically says that in the event that you both reach an agreement, then either of you are responsible for submitting your agreement to the court for approval.  Mediation can be a good way of resolving your differences and reaching a mutually beneficial agreement.

You are not obligated to sell it if you don't wish to. There are no rules about property abandoned to roommates. The landlord/tenant laws are written concerning property left with landlords. If she brings a claim against you, or you want to ensure that you handle the disposition of the property properly, consult with one of us directly.

Since you are on the other side of the "corporate veil," the creditor may be able to get at your corporation. The legal fiction of a corporate veil protects you personally from certain liabilities of your corporation, but it does not work the other way. If the creditor obtains a judgment against you personally, one of your assets would be your ownership interest in this corporation. If the creditor is able to get control of your shares, he or she essentially controls the assets of the corporation. And keep in mind that trying to transfer ownership or assets at this point may be considered a fraudulent conveyance. Talk to a litigation attorney (or several) to help you determine the proper course of action.

Frankly, I recommend NOT putting it in a bank account.  Once it is in a bank account, which is generally not protected, the rule against garnishing against the SSA, your moneys, doesn't apply, since SSA no longer has those moneys, but you do in YOUR account.  While there are rules now that tell a bank to double check where the money came from, banking employees are known to err in that - being human and all. If I were you, and have judgements (or even pre judgment creditors) I'd use the SSA's debit card to receive and hold my benefits:  USDirectExpress.com.

A settlement in workers' compensation can take on multiple forms.  If you are referring to what is known as a section 32 settlement, the insurance carrier may demand that you waive your right to future medical benefits as well as your weekly payments.  The amount of the settlement depends on multiple factors, and also depends to a certain extent on whether you are collecting social security benefits and are medicare eligible.  However, a settlement can also simply be a stipulation regarding permanency.  In your situation, you and the carrier may agree to a certain percentage of permanency, which would not effect your right to future medical care.  However, your case is complicated somewhat by the fact that you have a serious leg injury.  As such, your permanency could either take the form of a percentage loss of use, or in the alternative, a classification.  A classification will also require a determination regarding your loss of wage earning capacity, which in turn determines how much you will receive per week and for how long.  Obviously, these are fairly complex issues, and I would suggest that you consult with an attorney who specializes in workers' comp matters.

Be sure that when the issues is presented to a Judge, that you provide comprehensive information about your work history, finances, medical condition-in short, anything that will impact on the Court's determination of both child and spousal support. You will need to comply with the Court rules regarding the provision of information and evidence to the other side and the Court.

I practice in Stillwater.  What you should do depends on 2 things.  First, which time is up?  Either your "requirement" date or your "off deferred" date?  If it is your requirement date, then you should contact your probation (either DA or Okla Court Services) and show them proof of what you have done (including your 1/2 completed and paid for ADSAC), they will usually extend your requirement date upon this showing.  If it is your off date, your attorney may attend in your absence and request an extension of the off date - to try and prevent the bench warrant from being issued, (this gets tricky).  In some cases, a bench warrant can be recalled (for example if you complete your probation requirements) but it is easier if it never gets issued to begin with.   I'm wondering how you are currently taking ADSAC while in South Carolina - my understanding is that this course is only offered in Oklahoma.

You could withdraw the I-140 by writing to USCIS, and apply for a change of status from H1B to B2.  You can stay here while the change of status is being decided, which will take 2.5 months.  So even if it is denied, you will get the time you need.  If it is denied, you must depart immediately to avoid unlawful presence.  If you leave before it is decided, you don't need to do anything, since it will be deemed abandoned.  An attorney can investigate these options further with you and make sure your papers leave you in a good position to get a tourist visa in the future.

First, let me say how sickening and sad it is to hear stories of abuse against innocent children.   Determining if the daycare can be held liable for the employee's acts turns, in part, on whether the employee was acting negligently or intentionally.  It is difficult to hold an employer responsible for the intentional acts of their employees that are not within the scope of their employment.  If the child sustained the injures due to the employee's negligence rather than intentional conduct, then daycare may be held liable.  Also, an argument could me made that the daycare was negligent in the hiring/retention and/or supervision of this caregiver.   Whether those facts exist is unknown from your post.  If no such facts exist, you may be left with a claim against the employee only.  If the employee did indeed act intentionally there may be no insurance coverage for her actions.  The parents of the child should contact an attorney to discuss the merits of the claim.

If you get married, your spouse would have to wait approximately two years from the time you file your I-130 petition until a visa number will be available for her to come to the U.S.  She cannot stay here all that time on a visitor's visa, which is usually only for six months'  stay in the U.S.  It will also be impossible for her to get a visitor's visa (or legally extend her stay if she is already here) after she is married to you because it will be clear that she intends to immigrate and is not just visiting.

Each independent alleged violation of probation is enough to cause a probationer to be sentenced to the statutory maximum that s/he could have received when s/he was first placed on probation.  There will be a hearing held. If the judge decides by a preponderance of the evidence that a probationer willfully and substantially violated any material term of the probation then the probationer can (and will) be sentenced from a low of reinstatement to a high of whatever the statutory maximum punishment could have been before the probationer accepted probation. From what you describe, I would recommend hiring an attorney. I do not know what kind of litigation is involved, so I cannot get too far into specifics. In general, if you have the original documents, and the other side is offering edited copies, there are three steps for you t take. First, you will need to submit the originals, supporting the offer of evidence with testimony (live or by affidavit, depending on the circumstances) showing that they are the originals, how they have been maintained, and how they were obtained. The second step is to move to strike the evidence offered by the other side using the Original Source Rule (see Rules of Evidence 1000 and following). The final step is to ask the court for sanctions on the basis of spoliation of evidence, which means tampering with evidence while litigation is anticipated or pending. This step is only appropriate if the other side really did change the documents. Good luck.

Unfortunately it is hard to sort through the players and what they did in your question.  However the subjects of your question are  voyeurism, disseminating voyeuristic material and misappropriation.    You may have a claim here, but it would be helpful if you posted a comment on this question to clarify 1) who had their picture taken 2) if the person who took the picture had permission, 3) who took the picture, and 4) if the Facebook page is used for business.   Contact a Connecticut attorney who handles personal injury cases.  Since two of the "wrongs" here are crimes, you can also file a complaint with your local police department.  In the meantime you can read about the law in my answer.  VOYEURISM: Under Conn. Gen. Stat. å¤ 53a-189a. Taking a picture of someone 1) with malice, 2) without that person's  knowledge and consent, 3) while that person is NOT in plain view and 4) under circumstances where that person has a reasonable expectation of privacy is voyeurism.  For you to sue, or for the State to prosecute under this statute, it would have to be proven that the subject of the photo had a reasonable expectation of privacy in order to prove voyeurism and that the photo was taken with malice.  Malice: To act "with malice" means to act with some improper or unjustifiable or harmful motive including, but not limited to, the desire to cause pain, injury or distress to another.  Privacy: A person has a reasonable expectation of privacy when (he/she) has shown a subjective expectation of privacy and the expectation is one that society considers reasonable.  The subject of the photograph may be able to get past malice and privacy by showing that he did not want the photograph taken that after asking to have the photo removed from Facebook, the photographer refused.  Voyeurism is a class D felony and caries up to 5 years in prison.  DISSEMINATING VOYEURISTIC MATERIAL: Conn. Gen. Stat. å¤ 53a-189b the photographer who posted and refused to remove the photo from Facebook might be guilty of the class D felony of disseminating voyeuristic material.  The subject of the photo could sue under these statutes.  MISAPPROPRIATION:  When the subject of a photograph who's photograph is used in an advertisement without his consent files suit and asks for punitive damages, he must prove malice reckless indifference to the rights of others or intentional and wanton violation of those rights to recover damages. Venturi v. Savitt, 468 A.2d 933 (Conn. 1983).  Misappropriation can occur when a photo is used, without the subject‰Ûªs permission, for advertising purposes. Korn v. Rennison, 156 A.2d 476 (Conn. Super. Ct. 1959).  Again--you will need to hire an attorney.  Since two of the "wrongs" here are crimes, you can also file a complaint with your local police department.

I would discuss this situation with another attorney and see whether your perceptions are reasonable and fair.  Sometimes when presented with a litigation situation, there may be many possible responses and tactical maneuvers one could take given enough time, creativity and thought.    Some of these responses may not be immediately apparent, and perhaps you may not have asked the right questions and your attorney may have not exhaustively done research on the finer legal points of the claims or facts, nor may there have been money in your budget, retainer agreement or scope of services for his to pursue some "leave no stones unturned approach".  The question may hinge on whether an attorney of normal expertise in this area WOULD HAVE or SHOULD HAVE known about this option which now seems to have been feasible.  Hindsight is always 20:20.  Clients may not appreciate that many tactical responses in legal conflicts are far from clearcut, and might not be listed in some laws or commonly available "checklists".  The fact that your attorney did refund part of the retainer could indicate that he is trying to be fair with you and "meet you halfway" or that he did make the big whoopsie you are accusing him of and is making a refund in the hopes you'll go away quietly and not pursue action against him.  You should speak with a different attorney and get a feel for how an action for malpractice or sanctions would work out for you.  If the error is not blatant, and there are some "grey areas", probably not well.  For you to prove malpractice, you have to show that BUT FOR the attorney's error, you would have certainly won a case you lost.  Quite frankly, from what you are saying, I have doubts you could meet that burden.

I'm sorry to hear this happened.  Depending on when your letter to the warden was sent, it may still be under review, or at the next level for review.  Under Arizona Department of Corrections  - Department Order Manual i911.06 beginning on page 25. It can be found on the web.  It includes the causes for suspensions; time maximums for suspension depending on the reason for it; and the appeals process procedures.  I believe you have correctly taken the first step in the request for lifting the suspension process.  The first step is to write a letter to the Warden or Unit Deputy Warden.  If you know the reason for suspension, you can explain your side of the story, including in steps you have taken assure there will be no future misunderstandings.  After the Warden reviews it, he then must send it on to the ADC Regional Operations Director, to make the decision.  You should receive a letter or documentation which outlines their decision as to whether or not the suspension will be reversed and the grounds for their decision if it will not be.  There should also be an appeals process if you do not agree with the decision included in the manual.   If it has been more than 30 days since you wrote the letter to the Warden, I would suggest you send a second request. Attach your original letter to the second request, in case the first was not received, or lost in the mail. Check to make sure the addressee information is current and correct.  I imagine it is difficult for both of you.  But try to be patient with the process.  I hope it works out for you.   I've added the link to the Arizona Department of Corrections - Department Order Manual.  I hope you find this helpful.

I strongly urge you to hire a patent attorney ASAP as your question reflects that you do not understand the reasons for the filing of a provisional application and what is required to be included.  The simple answer is that if you want to cover an invention, you need to file a complete provisional application (i.e. one with ALL of the necessary information, language and description) -- otherwise, you will not have what you call "prior art advantage." If someone uses B and only B is claimed in the utility patent application arising from the provisional application, then the answer is, most likely, yes.  If someone uses B+C and B was before and C was after, then B+C possibly could be used as prior art against your application.  Without reviewing the exact facts and circumstances, no patent attorney can really assist you.  Good luck.  A patent attorney anywhere in the country can help you.

You may be entitled to the raise promised if the promise did not contain any conditions such as "maybe" or some time in the future, or if this happens, then you will get a raise, etc., and you are able to prove that you were promised a raise and then did not get it.   If the reason you were not given the raise is BECAUSE of any characteristic you have which is in a protected class (age over 40, race, religion, gender, pregnancy, disability, etc.) you may have a case for unlawful discrimination.   Otherwise, as the other responses state, as an at-will employee (no written contract for hiring an employee for a specified time), your employer is only legally required to pay you minimum wage (in CA $9.00 per hour currently) and any overtime if you are a nonexempt employee.

You are dealing with a case involving the Uniform custody act which all states have adopted.  There is a procedure in that statute that details the documents you have to file in your new state and the requirements for serving the father of the children. A parent's liability for the support of his or her children is limited to children under the age of 21 years. In the absence of an express or implied contract, parents have no duty to support an adult child after he or she turns 21. It is unnecessary to go to court to terminate child support under that circumstance; termination is automatic. For custody, visitation and other purposes, the age of majority is age 18, but for purposes of the child support obligation the age of majority remains at 21.

If he does not return your son then you need to file for and get an ex parte pick up order from a judge.  Ex parte means that the father has no knowledge of it, so he cannot move your son if he knows you are coming.   Once the ex parte pick order is granted, you will need to present it to the local law enforcement agency where your son is.  They will review the order and then go with you to pick up the child.  Without a specific ex parte pick up order, the police will not get involved. If you just present them court papers showing you are the residential parent, they will just consider it a civil matter.  You need an ex parte pick up order. All states, with the exception of MA, follow the UCCJEA regarding this.  MA just requires one extra step, which is for a local judge to review the ex parte pick up order.  It is best to retain an attorney to file this for you and argue it to the judge. Your mother would have received a life estate on the house no matter your age at the time of his death under homestead statutes. They have since revised the statutes to allow a wife to receive a 50% share; however, I think that revision happened after your father's death. In any event, upon reaching the age of 18, you can quit claim to your mother any rights you have in the property. If you were the only child this should allow her to sell the home. For title purposes, a better plan may be to have her place the property for sale and then when the home is sold you sign the deed of transfer in addition to your mother. It is between you and your mother as to whether or not you receive any of the proceeds for the sale. I do not suggest you do any deeds on your own. You should consult an attorney in your area to prepare the correct documentation or have the closing company do so at the time the home is sold.

Mr. Gibney, the other lawyer who has answered this question, despite the handicap of a Florida Law License, has given you a fine answer.  My answer will serve only to give some Alabama flavor to his.  Getting the other parent's consent to the adoption is very important in Alabama.  While it is possible to terminate parental rights based on a failure to provide support and a failure to maintain reasonable contact with the child, it's difficult.  The non-custodial parent always tries to blame the custodial parent for cutting off the relationship or interfering.  This gets messy.  So it's much cleaner if the father consents to the adoption.  A real incentive for the father to consent to the adoption would be the prospect avoiding child support.  If your husband adopts the child, the father no longer has a support obligation!    I need to emphasize one other thing that Mr. Gibney said:  Get a lawyer. Don't try to do this alone.  There are too many ways it can get screwed up.

You can't sell a car you don't own.  And if the title was never transferred to your name, you never owned the car.  The car belongs to whoever is named on the current title (plus whoever that title is signed over to).  New Jersey also requires you to re-title the vehicle in your name right after you buy it.  If you did not do that, you are in violation of New Jersey law.    Do you have a contract of sale with either party?  I guess not.  Which basically means that nobody is in a good situation. You might be better off just donating the car to a service and moving on (at least with the part about where you will store scrap vehicles - many municipalities won't let you store a scrap vehicle outside - and you have a scrap vehicle).
