The child is also entitled for benefits for the same retroactive period as the parent if the child was named on the parent's application for benefits (or their is enough information to establish intent). See https://secure.ssa.gov/apps10/poms.nsf/lnx/0200204010. The exception would be if you waited too long to file for benefits after an approval. Typically a child has 6 months after the Notice of Award to apply for benefits without losing potential benefits.  So if you applied for benefits for your son within 6 months of your son's father being approved, you should be entitled to past-due benefits. If it were more than 6 months after the Notice of Award, you would not receive the retroactive benefits.   If you cannot get Social Security to acknowledge the mistake, you should ask your child's father for a copy of his Social Security Disability application, and take a copy of the the webpage I linked above to your Social Security office, along with the receipt showing when your filed for the dependent's benefit. If Social Security still indicates that you are not due the additional money, I would recommend contacting your United States Representative or United States Senator for help.

I would have to see the code sections you were convicted of to make sure, but it sounds like your felony convictions are not reduceable and you are therefore barred for life from possessing firearms. Only so called "wobblers" can be reduced to a misdemeanor (these are crimes that could have been charged as a felony or misdemeanor). If the crime is a straight felony (which I believe yours are) they cannot be reduced. Also, if you were sentenced to state prison,  you cannot reduce your conviction, even if it was a wobbler. The way to be 100% sure is to fill out and submit this form to the CA DOJ: http://oag.ca.gov/sites/all/files/agweb/pdfs/firearms/forms/pfecapp.pdf   Hope that helps, sorry to be the bearer of bad news.

The girlfriend can try to muck up the proceedings, but she is not entitled to anything unless she can produce a Will that names her as a beneficiary, or an account with a Payable on Death designation or a Promissory Note signed by your father promising to "repay" her "loan."  With respect to probate and the credit cards:  One of the main purposes of probate is to make sure creditors get paid.  If the probate process starts, you will be obligated to list all debts and to notify the creditors.  However, once the creditor claim period has passed, creditors can no longer make a claim on probate assets.  If I were in your situation I might just sit tight for a few months to wait and see if the credit card companies do anything about the unpaid credit card bills ... but make sure you keep the truck and boats off the road and water so there are no accidents while you are waiting.   The first priority creditors are the funeral home, the estate Administrator and the lawyer.  That could eat up much of the value of the estate, leaving the credit card companies with little reason to pursue their claims once the probate estate is opened, but if you wait six months they will be too late with their claims.

Yes, you disclose the losses. It would be a crime not to.   By itself, having gambling losses is not a basis for denial of discharge. The issue is whether you used credit (e.g. cash advances off of credit cards) to gamble. Careful planning and strategy can usually overcome these issues and allow you to have a successful bankruptcy. These can be complex cases that take a lot of time, so don't expect a cheap bankruptcy.

There also may be problems of collecting a judgment if you get it, because if the person you are suing is broke it may be difficult to collect.  I believe you should consult with a lawyer right away to look into your options and take action if it appears you have a chance of winning and collecting on a judgment large enough to be worthwhile for you and the attorney,

Do you feel that you are at the same medical condition that you were before the accident? As a basic premise I wouldn't handle your claim by yourself. Make your life easier and call an attorney today, you won't regret it.

You have already raised several issues here that will affect how long this person is facing - the main two are: 1. past record, and 2. probation.  Fel. Maintaining is a Class I felony and Fel. PWISD MDA is a class H felony.  The maximum sentence is 24 months and 39 months respectively, so the maximum time he is facing is 63 months in the Department of Adult Corrections or Prison.  However, several factors come into play as to what he will actually get and more information is required to answer that.  First would be the number of record level points he has, as the sentence changes from level to level.  Two, an additional point can be assigned for violating his probation. Three, another point can be assigned for similar charges on his record, if any.  As you can see, all of those have the potential of affecting his record and therefore his punishment.  Since he does have a prior history, he will be eligible for no less than a minimum of a Level 2 punishment, which carries a minimum of 3-13 and 4-14 months respectively, although those are both minimum sentences, and he is more than likely to receive a higher punishment than that.  The other issues in sentencing involve whether or not he pleads or is convicted of both charges, and whether or not they are sentenced concurrently or consecutively.  If concurrently, he will only serve one sentence, although usually the higher level charge.

Fines, court costs and probation the possible punishments you are facing.  I don't see you getting jail time based on the information you posted above.  Why wouldn't you take 7411 though?  I would take the 7411 with possession rather than use.

1) Is it necessary to hire a lawyer who specialize in ecommerce when I create my own website for my own business?   As someone who does a lot of work for websites, I think the experience can be quite helpful, and that makes it both cheaper and more efficient for you. However, a lawyer may not be the best investment of limited funds. While lawyers are valuable and important, an accountant or at least bookkeeper would be your first stop.  2) what kind of service does an ecommerce lawyer provide?   We can provide advice on things like privacy notices (required in California), terms of service, help with copyright and trademark issues, and many, many other things.  3) what is the price range for the service?   A lawyer with experience in the area will charge at least $250 an hour, up to as much as $600 an hour.   4) can I hire a lawyer from a different state than Where my business registers/operates?  I am a California lawyer, so I have a conflict of interest, but I would have my concerns about how much the lawyer from a different state knows about California law -- and they probably cannot practice here anyway. There is no advantage to being cheaper if he or she doesn't know the law.  There are a lot of great lawyers in the Bay Area that know a lot about ecommerce and other issues with being online. Meet with two or three who give free consultations to see who you feel most comfortable with.

A news headline, standing on its own, is not copyrightable, generally because it's too short to really be a "creative work."  That being said, content owners have become more aggressive about suing news aggregators and have sometimes won against those who post not only the bare headline but also the "lede".  For a cautionary tale, here is a little story about the parent company of the Wall Street Journal suing a news aggregator:  http://www.burrellesluce.com/freshideas/2014/01/copyright-matters-dow-jones-sues-news-aggregator-ransquawk-for-misappropriation/  Best practices would be to obtain permission from the content owners whose content you would like to link.

First, Maryland confers absolute immunity on witnesses in judicial proceedings.  Hunckel v. Voneiff, 69 Md. 179, 187-188 (1888).  So absolute is the privilege that it applies even when the witness making the allegedly defamatory statements does so maliciously, despite known falsity, or under otherwise unreasonable conduct.  Reichardt v. Flynn, 374 Md. 361, 367 (2003).  Further, Maryland follows the minority rule, which recognizes the privilege irrespective of the statement‰Ûªs relevance to the proceeding.  Reichardt, 374 Md. at 367.  Second, Maryland has extended testimonial immunity to ancillary statements in judicial proceedings, which now include: to include: statements made by witnesses in the courtroom during the course of trial, Korb v. Kowaleviocz, 285 Md. 699, 704 (1979); statements contained in pleadings, affidavits, or documents related to litigation, Keys v. Chrystler Credit Corp., 303 Md. 397, 403-404 (1985);  and statements prepared for possible use in an action, but not actually introduced, Adams v. Peck, 288 Md. 1 (1980).  Lastly, Maryland has extended the absolute testimonial privilege to administrative and non-judicial proceedings subject to a two-prong test iterated in Gersh v. Ambrose, 291 Md. 188, 197 (1981): (1) the nature of the public function of the proceeding; and (2) the adequacy of the procedural safeguards which will minimize the occurrence of the defamatory statements.  Since that test was created by in 1981, it has been discussed and applied by the Maryland Court of Appeals six times: Miner v. Novotny, 304 Md. 164 (1985)(false complaint of police brutality absolutely privileged); McDermott v. Hughley, 317 Md. 12 (1989)(report by psychiatrist to employer not privileged); Odyniec v. Schneider, 322 Md. 520 (1991)(false allegations of medical malpractice absolutely privileged); Imperial v. Drapeau, 351 Md. 38 (1998)(false allegations of medical malpractice against EMT absolutely privileged); Reichardt v. Flynn, 374 Md. 361, 367 (2003)(complaints of sexual misconduct against teacher absolutely privileged); and Smith v. Daneilczyk, 400 Md. 98 (2007)(false statements made in search warrant not privileged).  As you can see, the jurisprudence is nuanced, and factually driven.  I highly recommend that you consult with an attorney.

Q: "Can I use journal articles on a topic to develop web application based on them ... ." R: Depends on what you mean by "use."    If you mean that the articles simply describe a web application and you intend to write the code for and brand that application then, yes, you can lawfully "use" the articles for that purpose [so long as you do not copy anyone else's code or infringe anyone else's trade dress or patent, if any, that protects that or a similar application].   If you mean that you want to literally re-publish the articles or parts of them or create an application that embodies parts of them then, no, you may not lawfully do any of those activities without a license from the owners of the copyright in those articles.   You need to speak with an intellectual property attorney before you pursue this business plan. Good luck.

Texas is an employment at will state. Typically, unless an employee has an employment contract, or is employed under a collective bargaining agreement through a union, the employer can modify or terminate the employment at any time with or without cause. An employer can alter schedules, compensation, and other the terms of employment for any non-discriminatory reason.  However, an employer generally cannot alter or terminate employment for prohibited discriminatory reasons (such as racial discrimination), or in retaliation for certain protected actions (such as whistle-blowing).  The description of the situation which you have provided does not include the elements of prohibited discrimination.  Additionally, employers are not required to treat all employees the same, so long as the disparate treatment is not part of prohibited discrimination or retaliation (as described above).

First, the personal liability will be discharged. However, the secured status will NOT change by you filing bankruptcy. It will still attach to your house. Sorry for the bad news. Thus, eventually, if there is equity (value minus 1st mortgage - remaining to protect 2nd mortgage) the 2nd mortgage will eventually possibly foreclose! If the value of house is LESS than 1st mortgage then you could do a ch 13 to avoid the 2nd mortgage. Or if close, you could possibly negotiate with 2nd mortgage to possibly try and reduce it too in a  ch 7. Good luck.   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

In PA, there is no guarantee of alimony.  Here are the factors the court considers determining alimony:  In determining whether alimony is necessary and in determining the nature, amount, duration and manner of payment of alimony, the court shall consider all relevant factors, including: (1)  The relative earnings and earning capacities of the parties. (2)  The ages and the physical, mental and emotional conditions of the parties. (3)  The sources of income of both parties, including, but not limited to, medical, retirement, insurance or other benefits. (4)  The expectancies and inheritances of the parties. (5)  The duration of the marriage. (6)  The contribution by one party to the education, training or increased earning power of the other party. (7)  The extent to which the earning power, expenses or financial obligations of a party will be affected by reason of serving as the custodian of a minor child. (8)  The standard of living of the parties established during the marriage. (9)  The relative education of the parties and the time necessary to acquire sufficient education or training to enable the party seeking alimony to find appropriate employment. (10)  The relative assets and liabilities of the parties. (11)  The property brought to the marriage by either party. (12)  The contribution of a spouse as homemaker. (13)  The relative needs of the parties. (14)  The marital misconduct of either of the parties during the marriage. The marital misconduct of either of the parties from the date of final separation shall not be considered by the court in its determinations relative to alimony, except that the court shall consider the abuse of one party by the other party. As used in this paragraph, "abuse" shall have the meaning given to it under section 6102 (relating to definitions). (15)  The Federal, State and local tax ramifications of the alimony award. (16)  Whether the party seeking alimony lacks sufficient property, including, but not limited to, property distributed under Chapter 35 (relating to property rights), to provide for the party's reasonable needs. (17)  Whether the party seeking alimony is incapable of self-support through appropriate employment.  There are many factors to consider in a divorce.  I strongly suggest that you consult with an experienced family law attorney to discuss your specific situation.

The 20-day notice is a "not-later-than" deadline. It doesn't mean that you have to serve the notice exactly on the 20th day. But you are correct when rent is payable on the first day of the month. To avoid next month's rent, you must deliver written notice of termination not later than the 11th day of this month when this month is a 31-day month, or not later than the 10th day of this month when this month is a 30-day month. And, of course, you have to be completely out of the unit by midnight on the last calendar day of this month. There could be exceptions in particular fact situations, but developing those exceptions could involve more attorney fees than can be justified by the problem. Even when the departing tenant has not given enough notice, the landlord can't just sit around and let the unit remain unrented. The landlord is required to mitigate the problem by re-renting, or trying to re-rent. If a new tenant is procured right away, the landlord can't charge the whole month against the departing tenant.

Un-insured motorist coverage would have nothing to do with paying the other adverse vehicle's damages.  Un-insured motorist pays out when other driver, who was at fault, did not have insurance.  You were not clear who was at fault, but if your family member was at fault for this accident, it would be your liability coverage that would pay the adverse driver for their damages.  Whether they had a driver's license or not does not matter, as long as you gave them permission to drive your vehicle. Any case involving the resolution of questions of federal constitutional law, in a proper case, come before the Supreme Court of the United States.  Decisions of state courts of last resort that decide questions on the meaning and application of federal laws, regulations and the Constitution all are within the pool of potentially interesting matters for the Court.  Review is sought by the filing, in the US Supreme Court, of a petition for a writ of certiorari to the California Supreme Court.  In Hill v. Colorado, I filed such a petition twice; in the first instance, the petition sought review of a decision against my clients by the Colorado Court of Appeals; in the second instance, after the Colorado Court of Appeals decision was vacated by the US Supreme Court, the Colorado Supreme Court also ruled against my clients, and I filed a second such petition.  There are a number of considerations governing review at the Supreme Court.  These are quite important and inform judgments by experienced counsel about seeking such review.  The first such consideration is the one you raised:  does the matter raise an issue of federal law (statutory, regulatory, or constitutional)?  Where a state supreme court decides the meaning or application of a state law or constitutional provision, and there are no federal law aspects to the decision, then the Supreme Court will not grant review.  The second of these considerations is whether review of the decision below is necessary.  The principal reason the Supreme Court grants review on certiorari is to fulfill its role in synthesizing the applications of federal law across the Nation.  Supreme Court practitioners refer to the question of conflicts in the Circuit Courts, or in the State Courts of last resort.  In the Hill petitions, we suggested that the Court exercise its power of discretionary review by granting our petition because the decision of the Colorado Court of Appeals, in the first instance, and of the Colorado Supreme Court, in the second instance, stood in stark conflict with decisions of other State Supreme Courts and certain federal appellate courts.  Another reason often cited, but not nearly so often granted on, is that the decision below conflicts with decisions of the US Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court does not take the view that its job is to correct erroneous factual findings or clear legal errors below, if that is the sole reason for granting review.  That being said, some petitions seem to be granted, an infinitesimally small number, on such grounds.  There are many practitioners on Avvo and elsewhere that could assist you with this matter.  The costs, however, can be exorbitant.   Just printing the petition and reply alone can run to Three to Five Thousand Dollars, not mentioning legal fees.  I have seen fee awards, following victory at the Supreme Court, in cases where fee shifting statutes allow for an award of attorneys fees to the prevailing party, that range upward of 250,000.00.  Finally, all the considerations are not meant to suggest that you should simply forget about it.  Seek legal counsel if you can.  If not, use the Court's website to access the rules of practice for the Court.  There are thousands of nonpaid petitions filed at the Court each year.  Few are ever granted, but some are, and important principles of law have resulted from such cases.

I'll leave it to my colleagues to give you the attorney at law answer to your question; my answer is as counselor at law.  No, it is not okay for your mother to hold you down and cut off your hair. I suspect she is threatening that as an exaggerated response to how she feels about your wearing dreadlocks. I would hope she would not actually attempt that; if she did you could both be in more trouble than either wants, with the police and with family services.  At 16, you are not fully mature emotionally and intellectually. But neither are you fully mature at 18, nor 21, magical ages at which you're suddenly vested with permissions to do all sorts of things which may harm your development. You are mature enough right now, however, to make many decisions on your own, and I believe parents ought to support you in those kinds of decision. I suspect how you wear your hair is one of those. It isn't a decision that threatens your health or well-being, and you should be allowed to find for yourself what does and doesn't suit you.   You are at your age, and should be, differentiating yourself from your parents. Your parents' ideas are not yours, and while it may be painful for a parent to discover their child has independent thoughts and tastes and ways of living in the world, it is a pain worth bearing, because allowing you to find for yourself who you are, what you like, is a wonderful uncovering. I have seen it in my own children, and your mother should not miss seeing it in hers.  You are not in total control of your life, but neither is your mother. The fact that we feed and clothe and shelter our children is our privilege and responsibility, and not a weapon to be withheld if they don't do as we say.  A lot of people have worn dreadlocks with no apparent long-term harm. Is there anyone who doubts Bob Marley's gifts to our species? Whoopie Goldberg's? Lauren Hill's, Erykah Badu's, Johnny Depp's? (Well, maybe Johnny Depp's.)  There are dreadlock traditions throughout history and cultures. Spartans wore dreads. So did Aztec priests. Hindus, Buddhists, Christians have worn dreads. Ain't nobody gonna hold a Maasai warrior down and cut off his hair. Doctors, lawyers, and probably Indian chiefs have worn dreadlocks.   There are worse looks. Albert Einstein looked like he stuck his finger in an electrical socket. Abraham Lincoln apparently cut his hair with a hatchet. Henry David Thoreau must have sprayed chocolate cool whip on his head. What was Ben Franklin thinking, anyway?  It's not about what's on your head; it's what's in your head.  If it's true for you, tell your mother that what's in your head is love for her, and love for you, too, and that your wanting to dreadlock your hair is an expression of that love for yourself, for the self you want to try on for a little while, and see if it fits. Maybe it does, maybe it doesn't. But you want to try, and you want her to help you try, and you hope she can do that.  I hope so, too. Not just for you: in two years you can do what you want, that's true. But I hope your mother doesn't find herself in two years, if you've left the shelter of your home, wishing she had let you do some of the things you wanted to try at no harm to either.

An innocent person can plead guilty to a crime they did not commit.  If they voluntarily and knowingly tell the judge what they did to be guilty and if the judge determines it is a crime and accepts the guilty plea they then face disposition.  To try and undue a guilty plea later is very difficult if the judge accepted the guilty plea.  The lesson here is don't plead guilty with the expectation of later changing your mind. It would be very important to discuss a guilty plea with a lawyer before you do it.

Attorney Berkus articules the math to determine. And if you further deduct the sales costs if property is sold your asset is worth even less. How long you have lived in CA makes a difference and whether or not you live in the home. SOme persons I speak to would lose a value equity in a house unless they move into it before we file also. Below I set forth the issues for you..But no one can say which chapter here on AVVO as it takes knowledge of all the facts of income, assets, liabilities, and MORE! But no one files a ch 13 for fun..as you are in there 3 to 5 years..and only 95 days in a ch 7..so always see why NOT do a chapter 7 first!   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof! That includes your portion of that house!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

If you are looking for the law, try RCW 72.09.270 which deals with reentry plans.  That law states, in part, "in determining the county of discharge for an offender released to community custody, the department may not approve a residence location that is not in the offender's county of origin unless it is determined by the department that the offender's return to his or her county of origin would be inappropriate considering any court-ordered condition of the offender's sentence, victim safety concerns, negative influences on the offender in the community, or the location of family or other sponsoring persons or organizations that will support the offender."    There's certainly far more to the law than that passage, but if you look at RCW 72 in conjunction with DOC 350.200 it may help answer some of your general questions about how DOC works and the legal foundation for how they operate.

Mediation is NOT binding on anyone. If either you or your ex don't like it, it is thrown away and you start again in court - with the risk that the mediator's opinion is taken into account by the judge. Don't risk a large percentage of your future earnings without a lawyer.  Neither of you has an "imputed" income. You have an "actual" income that they will use. Your lawyer will argue this for you as well. (perhaps she is arguing that you have some "under the table" income that you have to defend). Since mean salary is 146, half make less. If she is younger than the average age, again a lower average. Your lawyer will argue that if her salary is lower because she doesn't work 40 hours, for example if she is working 25 hours, then 146 should be imputed. Let the lawyer work - there are too many things you will have to deal with that the OTHER lawyer will come up with as well. Like getting a medical opinion from a doctor or the guy who runs the newsstand and thinking the guy who runs the newsstand will be right more often, don't defend a lawyer without one. Since you just started working full time, that is the salary that should be used, and as you gain experience and make more then she can take you back for a change. USE A LAWYER TO ARGUE THIS - you will likely find it hard to  be calm about it.  For example, the argument culd be that you need 45,000 to live on and she needs 45,000 to live on, so your contribution should come out of her paying 90 percent for everything. Not a likely result but the kind of thing that you can move the argument toward.  If the ex has the right to decide schools, and Stevens is the school that she decided is better, and the judge agrees, it is Stevens. The argument is how much you can afford to pay, not whether somehow the difference in cost between Rutgers and Stevens magically disappears. This is another argument and fight for a seasoned lawyer who examines all the finances.

Mr. Powell has given you an excellent link. Here is one for the 22nd Judicial District which includes a flow chart for how a bill becomes law. http://www.22ndjd.org/leg.html  There are a few "inside" things that may be of some interest. I'm the senior attorney in the Louisiana Legislative Bureau (note its presence on the flowchart), which is an arm of the Louisiana Senate, and read every bill that comes out of the 33 standing committees. Each bill must contain the introductory phrase: "Be it enacted," or in the case of a resolution, "Be it resolved." The bill must also have a "one-liner," a short summary of what the bill intends to do, and a "title," which is not what one thinks of as a title in the ordinary sense, but instead a more detailed explanation of what the bills intends to do. You refer to a "finding of fact." That's a term from trial practice, not legislative procedure. However, fiscal notes are provided on some bills by the Legislative Fiscal Office.

I am guessing operating a vehicle without a license is 46.2-300 which is actually driving without a valid license.    The previous attorneys are correct about the range of punishment so I won't go into that.    The big difference between 46.2-300 (Driving without a license) and 46.2-301 (Driving on Suspended) is  that First in 46.2-300 --> you must be driving and in 46.2-301 --> you can be driving or operating (keys in ignition)  Second difference is for 46.2-301, the Government must prove that you knew you were suspended where in 46.2-300 they just need to prove that your license was not valid.  So you can be convicted of 46.2-300 if you never had a license or if you were suspended and didn't know it was suspended.

Appreciate the question.  If by ERC you mean Resolution Management Conference then for the most part, yes.  The court either on its own volition or by request of one of the parties will set a Resolution Conference.  Again, the majority of conferences, by court order, require each party or together to submit a resolution statement to the court.  The resolution statement informs the court of those issues which the parties agree and disagree.  It is an instrumental submission that helps posture the position of the individual parties or the entire litigation.  Many attorneys offer free consults and document review on issues such as the RMC and resolution statement.  The no cost discussion can take place in the East Valley, such as Gilbert.

If you file a summary process on 9/1, you will be in Court approximately 4 weeks later.

Everything he says is untrue.  First of all, a lawsuit must be filed with the court.  You can check the party index at your local courthouse to see if you are being sued.  If they do file a lawsuit, it will be a civil lawsuit, not a criminal proceeding.  They will pay a court filing fee, usually between $225 and $435.  Then, you do not need to sign anything in order to be served.  All that a real process server does is say, "Mr. Smith, I have legal papers for you." and hands you a copy of the court Summons and other papers.  Then the process server leaves.  If you are not home, you are not home and you are not served (unless someone else who lives at your home accepts the papers.)  Who are "appropriate authorities" -- in this case, no one.  I really doubt that a lawsuit was filed.  If they wanted to invest in a lawyer, court filing fee and a real process server, you would not have received this phone call.  I'll bet that the caller will not give you his actual street address and, if he does, it is not in California.

While we normally want to know about all assets, when working on an estate, bank accounts that are payable on death, are not part of the estate and should not be part of a 3% calculation (if that is the basis for his fee - note that it is not the only way a probate fee can be determined.  Most pets unless pedigree and fairly young have no significant value and normally, if listed at all (usually adopted out quickly after the death), are shown at a nominal ($10 - $25 at best) value. When working on an estate, it is essential that you have a working relationship with your attorney.  You select the attorney who will represent you, not the other way around.  If after trying to work with this attorney, you find at the outset of representation that you can't work with him, then don't hire him.  If you are just at the stage of determining what assets are in the estate, it sounds like the estate has not been opened yet.  If this is the case, you may owe him a small fee for his initial review.  If the estate work has gone on further, you may owe more, but if your relationship isn't working out, it is time to hire someone else and end your relationship with him.  People may find themselves in an abusive relationship in a marriage (and even that has remedies), but this has no place in an attorney/client relationship.  You are the boss.  Remember that.

If the foreclosure action was "dismissed" (for lack of prosecution), then the house is not under any current foreclosure sale threat.  That means that it could not be sold in an auction.  But I would double check to make sure a dismissal of the case did, in fact, occur.  Many clients will "describe" their version of the circumstances and, not knowing all the steps, arrive at a wrong conclusion.  Now presuming the case was dismissed, the case law has been unforgiving in this context to the extent that, generally, a lender can simply re-initiate the process by sending  a new acceleration letter.  This letter would highlight a "default" on the basis of a later installment payment that was missed.  And thereafter, they can refile a foreclosure action and start the whole process again.  Based on the case law, there's not really a limit.

Do you live with anyone else?  Do you live in a neighborhood where there have been incidents (i.e. break ins or other property crimes) recently?  There could be a variety of reasons why the police have been in your area that would be difficult for a lot of people, including attorneys, to speculate on why the police are in your area.  It could be just as simple as you appear nervous, which is sometimes a factor police use in determining if they should investigate further.  I wouldn't go to the police station and ask if they are investigating you.  If they are, they won't likely say "yes, you got us, we're on to you for X, Y or Z."  If they aren't investigating you, they may wonder if they should be based on you asking.  If you are truly concerned the police are following you (for reasons you have not disclosed here on this forum - and you shouldn't), you may want to consult with a criminal defense attorney in your area.  Otherwise, I would recommend trying to relax.  Good luck to you!

The lien is filed only to protect the hospital in the event you have any sort of settlement in your bodily injury case.  The hospital bill is still as valid as any other unpaid bill.  They have the right to seek recovery from any legal means available to them, including filing a lien, referring to collection and even filing a lawsuit, if necessary.  My only recommendation is that, if the the collection agency wants to settle with you on the account, make sure it is a settlement in full and final release of the lien (and make sure all of this is in writing). Dear Huntington Home Owner:  You may be certain that your tenant's lawyer believes you are the crazy side of the relationship. You really do need an attorney since you did not know a verbal notice has no legal value in New York. A NY landlord has the free right to end a verbal month to month tenancy with a one month notice. You missed the "window" to end the tenancy on August 31 and any notice made now, cannot act to end the tenancy earlier than September 30, 2014 (if the rent due date is the first day of the month.)  Your tenant's acts are destructive and dangerous; and you have a claim against the locksmith as well.  Allow your attorney to advise you whether you need to provide cable service when the tenant has negated the verbal rental agreement?  And, when you ask for rent, there is no need to do that face to face. New York law allows for a landlord a right to serve a written rent demand (without the rent demand and proof of service you will not be able to sue for unpaid rent.) Your lawyer is also likely to advise not to demand rent, as that only creates again a monthly tenancy, since a tenancy must exist to sue for rent. A landlord of a month to month tenant who misses one month rent, will likely never see rent again, and may as well leap direct to tenancy termination. See a lawyer.

Retaining private counsel is a very difficult question.  Most court-appointed attorneys are really very good (disclosure - I do court-appointed work as well, so I'm obviously biased on that point), but you're really only entitled to court-appointed counsel if you can't afford to hire someone.  So, from that consideration, if you can hire a private attorney you probably ought to.  It seems likely to be indicted and appears to have some complicated issues which will probably require extensive pre-trial litigation and favorable disposition short of trial could be difficult for any attorney.  Thus, when you're considering whether you should hire someone, you should assume that private representation for this case will probably be quite expensive.  It's obviously a very personal decision as to whether you (or your family) can afford that and if being able to choose your own attorney instead of having to accept whoever was appointed is worth it to you.  Also, it is very doubtful you would find an attorney to represent both of you because that is strongly discouraged by our rules of professional conduct.

You absolutely can fight this! You did not surrender the premises simply because the electricity was off at 6PM. You had not delivered the keys. You were returning home to continue cleaning. You did not know the electricity would be off. Absent an agreement to the contrary, 10/31 ends at 11:59:59PM. If you want to clean in the dark, that is your right. The fact that you were at work and planned to clean upon returning home is further support of the argument that you did not surrender the property.   If the landlord intends to keep the security deposit, he must send you a notice, in writing, within 30 days of your moving out. If you have not received that notice by 11/30, the landlord loses his right to keep the security deposit. That does not mean that he cannot sue you for any damages, but he will have to be the one to go to the expense of doing that. Likewise, just because the landlord sends a notice, that does not mean he gets to keep all that money. If you DO receive the notice by 11/30, then you have 15 days to make an official objection (do not cash the check if one is included with the notice). I STRONGLY recommend you contact an experienced landlord-tenant lawyer to discuss the case at that point.                        DO NOT WAIT UNTIL THE LAST MINUTE!  It is important to note that even if you do not object within 15 days, you can still sue the landlord for keeping too much money. I know you do not want to spend tons of money on a lawyer just to get back a few hundred or thousand dollars. Find an attorney that offers a contingency fee for tenants. We routinely offer such fees to tenants because we understand the financial strain of enforcing your rights as a tenant. If you do not win, you do not pay attorneys' fees. If you are successful in getting just $1 more than what the landlord wants to give you, you are considered the winner and the landlord will have to pay your attorneys' fees AND taxable costs. That means that you never have to pay your attorneys' fee. The risk is that if you lose, you would have to pay the landlord's attorneys' fees and costs in addition to your own costs.  It is important, therefore, to have an experienced landlord attorney evaluate your case before proceeding.

A blue ticket is just what the charge was written on (traffic ticket).  There are a number of scenario's in these types of cases so it's impossible to say what will happen without an agreement before hand.  The maximum jail time he can be given is 30 days and will get credit for  the time he has served so far, he may also be subject up to a $2,000 fine.  One of the most important decisions your fiancÌ© should make is whether to plead guilty at all to the charge.  Does he have a lawyer representing him?  Has he requested the discovery against him so he knows what the evidence is against him.  Is he interested in getting any type of counseling to help his position, or any other mitigating factors.  There are serious consequences to pleading guilty to a CDV charge.  One of them involves a persons right to lawfully own a firearm (federal law) so if he does plead guilty and lawfully own a gun(s) he will have to get rid of them or be subject to further prosecution with a CDV conviction.  If he doers not have a lawyer he really needs to talk to someone that can advise him on all of these factors and more, Dale Savage

Florida law provides varying retention schedules for various agencies, depending on the type of record/item to be stored.  The Div. of Library and Information Services ("DLIS"), of the Dept. of State, establishes the minimum retention schedules for various agencies.  The schedules are located at: http://dlis.dos.state.fl.us/recordsmgmt/gen_records_schedules.cfm .    An efficient way to have the records preserved is to gain access to the records and preserve them yourself.  This can be accomplished through a public records request, which if properly written will require the responding agency to cite any exemption to your request.  If an exemption is claimed by the responding agency, you then may request further information such as the agency's retention schedule, which may be identical to the DLIS, or may provide more storage time.  A follow-up request may then be made once the exemption expires or a Court Order may be applied for.  Other remedies are available but due to the limited space of this forum and the in-depth nature of this topic (Florida's public records laws are the broadest in the world), all cannot be explored.    Best Regards,  Koberlein Law Offices provides legal services to Counties, Cities, and Citizens.

Just because it is Small Claims does not mean that ALL of the laws regarding lawsuits are different.  As Mr. Chen stated, the Plaintiff still has the burden of proof to established that they had been harmed in the amount of $10,000.  As for you suing, the luxury of living in CA is that anyone can sue for any purpose.  I can sue you because I hate Angelinos (I do not).  That being said, your only claim - that I can think of based on the facts provided - is for malicious prosecution or abuse of process.  These are VERY difficult to win in Small Claims AND they can give rise to an entirely different set of problems for you should you lose (anti-SLAPP motion.)  I would consult with a lawyer who knows about Small Claims.  The lawyer cannot go to court for you, but can give legal advice.  Further if you lose, you can appeal and have this lawyer represent you on the appeal.

A missing item in your factual recitation is whether the "team" agreed to the 50/50 split. You do not say that it was agreed to by the "team" or even that you sent the proposal to them. It seems to me that you have earned somthing for the listing and the work that you did on it. Imagine that the "team" was at another real estate company and the listing was yours, you would be the listing agent and they the selling agent. What is the custom as to the split in such a case? At a base, it would seem that you are entitled to at least that. It appears  that there was a foul-up at the management level of your company. That the assistant has left should make no difference. If it was company policy to report matters of this kind to the assistant, then you followed policy. Since you don't mention the "team" being told of the 50/50 split, I wonder was it the assistant's job to finalize the arrangement? If it was and she did not and the manager decides to give you less than you would otherwise be entitled, then you likely have a claim against your company. But, making it may lead to having to voluntarily move to another office or even not so voluntarily. You could also face some stigma if the real estate broker community is a tight one. What may very well be appropriate is for your company to take the entire commission and interplead you and the :"team", pay the commission into the court and let the court decide the split. That relieves you of filing the suit. Ay least, your company should be holding the commission in an interest bearing account.Undoubtedly, all of the sales people involved are considered independent contractors and not employees.   Finally, in your business, certainly you know lawyers in the community. You should consult with one about this.  As to arbitration, unless there is an agreement to arbitrate, you cannot force arbitration after the fact.  How much it costs depends on the forum in which you arbitrate. Often retired judges are willing to arbitrate disputes.  Of course, he or she will have to be paid. This case could be arbitrated in a half day.  All parties could agree to make the arbitration binding and adopt the rules of some outside forum like, for example, the American Arbitration Association. Good luck

You are free to enroll the child in any lawful activity as long as the other parent is not paying for the activity and the other parent's scheduled time with the child is not impacted.  "ex says i pay child support so i should have say on what money is spent on". That is not true. Does the ex have a say in what foods the child eats while the child is at your house? Does the ex have a say in what color the paint is in the room where the child sleeps in your house? The basic child support that the ex pays covers food and housing (among other necessities) for the child. No court is going to allow the ex a say in what foods the child eats when the child is with you or the paint color in the child's room at your house.  However, if you are expecting the ex to pay for the class or the class will be held during the ex's parenting time, you will need the ex's consent to enroll the child in that class unless the court order provides that you get to make the decision by yourself.  "i put child in a martial art that had no chance of anything happening". I am not sure that there is any activity that has "no chance of anything happening", especially when the actor is jumping, kicking, punching, and doing other physical activities.  If all this class switching is happening within a few weeks or months of each other, the ex is likely thinking that you are trying to game the system somehow. Perhaps (he thinks) you are trying to jack up the child support the ex pays. Perhaps you are trying to interfere with the ex's parenting time.  "better value for money" is not always the best criterion upon which to decide things. Perhaps the child does not like the new class you want him to take. Perhaps the child will do better in his current class even if it costs a little bit more.  You should review all the court orders to see what the court orders both parents to do.  You can review the specific facts with your attorney to find out your legal options.

I agree with previous answer completely.  I have been handling Medicaid Fraud cases for the part 2.5 years since the first letters from Human Resource administration went out.   The letters come from 2 places: 250 Church Street and 151 West Broadway, 7th floor.   Those letters should be taken very seriously as investigation is of the fraudulent information which was submitted to HR administration over the years and investigators usually have serious proof.  They visit your home and take pictures, talk to your neighboors and ask for your employment information from your employer.  If you put down that you are separated from your husband or wife they will visit the alleged place of residence and place or work for the separated spouse and take pictures.  Most of the time the fraudulent activity can be proven and it's really dangerous if you appear at this interview by yourself.  Most of the time I will ask a client not to appear at all and will go in their place.  I attend about 5 such interviews each single week and have been very successful in being able to solve this cases without further criminal charges being brought against such clients.  If you received a letter from HR administration contact my office and at least receive consultation of what you can expect based on the facts of your case.  At this point I will be able I tell you what will happen at your interview. If you feel comfortable with what I am telling you, I will be able to represent you as well.

How were you made aware of the dealer's BK filing?  When you signed "purchase documents" at the dealership, the dealer usually will assign the purchase contract to a financing company, CU, bank, etc.  Absent such an assignment, the contract remains an asset of the bankruptcy estate of the dealership.  This the case irrespective of what kind of bankruptcy was filed.  I doubt a 13 was filed, so it is either a 7 or an 11.  Since your purchase contract is an asset, the Chapter 7 trustee should be getting in touch with you.  If the case is an 11, the BK lawyer for the dealership should be getting in touch with you.  Keep the vehicle insured, but eventually, you will have to commence payments pursuant to the contract.  Under a Chapter 7, you may be able to negotiate a lump sum payment less than what you owe on the contract.   You probably can't get the vehicle registered, but contact DMV to extend your temporary paper registration, if you have one.  If you want, send me the name of the dealership and I can search PACER to get specific details on the case and give you a report.

You generally can not bring a personal injury lawsuit against your employer if your claim is made under  workers compensation. You could contact a qualified workers compensation attorney.

The DA has an extra 30 days to file a Complaint to Revoke a Deferred Judgment and Sentence after the date that it is set to terminate. The DA does NOT have that 30 day time period if the person were given probation, instead of a deferred judgment and sentence. It is only for a DJ & S. You can't file a Motion to Compel. That is for civil cases. No, you can not terminate a D J & S early without the DA's consent, because it is a contract with the DA and not modifiable.

This is one of the difficulties in dealing with oil companies concerning royalty payments.  The oil company often takes the position that they will not make any changes without a court order on the matter.  They don't want the liability of making a mistake interpreting the powers of a trust, assignments of interest, etc., so they make the mineral owner jump through hoops.  At the end of the day, they don't care how much it costs you to have these interests transferred as long as they are protected.

You need more than just the doctor, who will testify what treatment was given and what your injuries were. You're going to need an expert to testify that the treatment was reasonably necessary, and another expert to testify as to the reasonable value of that treatment. Without all three of these experts, you are unlikely to recover.  Hire a lawyer who can protect your interests, who knows what experts need to be retained, and who will advance the costs of their fees. By attempting to represent yourself you are irreparably damaging your case. You need to immediately retain qualified counsel.

That's a complicated question.  Many practiced lawyers are terrible brief writers, and not necessarily due to lack of experience or education.  Effective brief writing depends on an attorney's ability to analyze legal precedent and refine persuasive arguments applying said analysis to shed favorable light on the facts of the case.  It is unlikely that anyone, holding a law degree or otherwise, will be able to simply glean this skill from a book.  That being said, the Eleventh Circuit mails all new members a copy of Strunk & White's "The Elements of Style" upon admission, but this may be more for humorous effect than anything else.  Your best bet may be to search legal briefs and judicial opinions on the internet to get a feel for how this is done.

I live and work in California and deal with accidents like yours all the time, so I am happy to answer your question. The answer to your question is your gut instinct is right in that you are not certain about your rights. First step to take is not to talk to the Walgreen's claim department because they will try to pin down your statement of what happened and where you are injured.  There goal is usually to hurt your case, not help it. You're going to need to hire a lawyer in order to get results. You are entitled to have your property damage, medical bills and future medical expenses PAID FOR BY THE OTHER PARTY'S INSURANCE. The attorney you hire will handle the claims process from start to finish.   But you are going to need to see a specliast to even get a shot at getting future medical treatment from the Defenedant. Moreover it sounds like the accident is completely the other persons fault so you don't want this case to become a difficult one because of lack of inattention. The insurance company will make you believe that your case is worth very little... Regarding pain and suffering, you need to speak to an experienced attorney that can strategize your case. Just because you were in an accident doesn't mean you have pain and suffering, at least thats what the insurance companies think. Make no doubt about it you have a great case, but you need help from a professional. You are entitled to your medical bills being covered as well.   Do you feel that you are at the same medical condition that you were before the accident? As a basic premise I wouldn't handle your claim by yourself. The attorney you hired can likely refer you to a doctor, if you ask for one, who will see you with no upfront payment! I've done this many times to help my clients out. You should not wait a single day to hire a lawyer, we will advise you on the strategy of your case. There is no upfront cost to hire an attorney.   With a case like yours it seems like you have some good facts in order to get a high settlement, but your case definitely needs to be developed further to corroborate your story. The most important thing when building your case are: liability (were you at fault); how bad are your injuries to your body. A lot of these things sound like they are not complete yet in your case so its something that is worth hiring an attorney for in order to get a sense of whether you have a case and what the strategy would be for you to build a strong case! I've handled cases and/or spoken to clients in the Daily City, CA area.   Its very possible that your case is worth more than the $$$ that the insurance company will offer you by yourself. Make your life easier and call an attorney today, you won't regret it.

You need to seriously read Family Code 3047 concerning military deployment and the ability of your extended family to be able to exercise your visitation during deployment. Ms. James and Mr. McGinnis are correct.  There is nothing inherent in a generic life estate that would keep you from purchasing your father's life estate interest, or renting the home from him during his lifetime, but a life estate can be granted with a broad variety of governing provisions.  Your best move is to sit down with an attorney with experience in real estate and estate planning and review the life estate documents.  Your attorney can help you determine if and how your father's rights can be transferred, and if there is a way to proceed regarding the interests of any other remaindermen.

You have two issues - how to stop the harassment, and what to do about the judgment debt. The other attorneys are correct in that you need a consultation with an attorney to assess the big picture.  In order to stop phone calls from an attorney collecting this judgment, you can mail the attorney a letter telling him or her not to call you. Mail it certified mail, return receipt requested, and keep the green card proof. You cannot stop a collector from mailing you letters asking for payment of the judgment, but it would be a good idea to have your own lawyer look over those letters to make sure there are no Federal or State law violations in the letters.  Be sure and promptly respond to any "Notice of Right to Claim Exempt Property" which you may receive by mail or from the Sheriff. There is only a 20 day window to file your response. Seek legal help immediately if you receive one of these. If you ignore this, the creditor may be able to take your property including your car, or freeze your bank account, because your judgment exemptions (protections) are waived.  Options for dealing with this long term include settlement, payment in full over time, and bankruptcy. Which option is best for you depends upon your specific circumstances and cannot be answered here. Please consult with a qualified attorney. Most attorneys who handle these kind of matters will give a consultation for a very affordable fee. Even if you decide to leave things the way they are for now, your mid will be eased by knowing about the specific options available to you.

As I'm reading this, you had an attorney in your original case and, when you sought assistance from them at this time for a modification proceeding, they requested another $2500 retainer.  That is not actually a reasonable amount and, if you can manage it, you know yourself that things will go smoother with an attorney's assistance.  As to whether or not you "have to" send out those interrogatories etc., no you don't "have to" but why wouldn't you?  There is mandatory disclosure which both parties have to do and then there are these interrogatories and additional requests for documents.  If they are asking you to complete them, go ahead and make him do the same. But, you don't "have to."

It's likely they could, but they would need to be unusually smart and aggressive. Typically the statute will give sixty or ninety days for a creditor to make a claim after being notified that some form of estate administration has begun. Or, if the family doesn't administer the estate then liability will be cut off after say two or three years.   In the meantime, it's possible the family could just go on renewing the tag and insurance. That may not be the *right* thing to do, but I'm saying it likely could be done.   They really should consult with an Oklahoma estate practitioner in order to determine whether there is a form of administration (or distribution without administration) that can be done affordably so that the car has the best chance of not going to the creditors.

Wow! Sorry to hear of your circumstances. I recommend that you file a supplemental petition for modification of of prior court order. It is not a motion. Rather it is a supplemental petition. If you have a security interest in a Note that is secured by a deed of trust that is referred to as "Chattel Paper". (meaning of the person who is indebted to you gave you as security, his or her interest as the creditor on another secured Note that a 3rd party is paying).  Look at Article 9 for perfection of Chattel paper. Basically it's like anything else, you describe it in the UCC-1 and record it at the Secretary of States Office. However you must have possession of the original Note. There is no other way to have a security interest in a mortgage. Sounds like you need an attorney consultation to even determine what you have based on this and your prior similar question and determine what the issues are you are trying to resolve.

Mr. Dane and Mr. Marek are correct. (1) There is no true expungement statute in California. What's often called "expungement" is actually dismissal after the fact. (2) You cannot dismiss felonies unless they are wobblers.  If they are, you first need to get them reduced to misdemeanors under penal code section 17(b).  You can then get them dismissed under penal code section 1203.4.  You will need an attorney's help to do any of these things.  Consult one ASAP.

Merhaba Zeki, That was not the right question, Zeki. As the spouse of a US citizen you are deemed to be an "immediate relative" ("IR").  IRs do not need to maintain valid non-immigrant status (for you that means you don't need to apply for the GC before your F-1 status expires), nor do IRs ever get penalized for having engaged in unlawful employment.   But just watch out, and as my esteemed colleague suggested there are many things that could go wrong with that green card application if not properly prepared and filed with professional help by an experienced immigration attorney.  Any error and/or omission has the potential of setting you aback by months and even getting your case denied.  Kolay gelsin!

If the plaintiff dismisses the lawsuit without prejudice while your demurrer is pending and without your agreement for a waiver of costs, then this will probably be considered by the court to be a favorable termination on the merits for you. This means, you could probably successfully apply as the "prevailing party" for an award of costs against the plaintiff, which would be your filing fee(s), process service fee(s), and any motion costs or fees. So, we are talking about five or six hundred bucks.  As a practical matter, the plaintiff should not need to dismiss and re-file because most judges liberally grant plaintiffs leave to amend their defective complaints. It is not until there have been two or three attempts to get it right that the court is likely to sustain a demurrer without leave to amend.  I hope this answers your question.

I have to make some guesses. I'm guessing you and your mom entered without inspection, that is, you didn't enter with a visa or border crossing card. You came across the border in secret and avoided capture. I'm guessing you were over age 21 when your mom adjusted status, so you were too old to adjust with her. I'm guessing you are not married to a US citizen, and I'm guessing your mom is not yet a US citizen. Because you entered without inspection, you are not eligible to stay in the US and apply for a green card. Even if your mom has petitioned for you, the only way you can get legal is to go back to your home country and apply for an immigrant visa there. Once you leave the US however, you will be barred from reentry for ten years because you have been in the US for over one year without authorization. You may soon be able to apply for a provisional waiver of the ten year bar, if you can show it would be an extreme hardship to your green card holding mother, if you had to go back to your home country for ten years. Note: depending on when your mom filed a petition for you, and what country you are from, you may still have to wait a very long time before an immigrant visa quota number is available to you. If any of my guesses are wrong, then the answer may change. Make an appointment with an immigration lawyer. See the link to AILA below for help in finding an immigration lawyer near you.

Corporate squeeze-outs are particularly vicious types of litigation matters. Because they involve issuance of securities, the applicable fraud provisions my extend to "failure to state", not merely "material misrepresentation". Your being induced to move to California raises a little-known statute potentially providing for triple damages on any employment law claim.  You need an in depth analysis with an attorney, way beyond Avvo. You need to assemble a narrative of your entire history with this company, annotated with labeled documents that back up your factual recitation. The more organized you are, the better an impression you will make on the attorney(s) that you interview.   If your only problem is "vesting" that may be a function of the permit to issue securities, but I suspect it is a delaying tactic and part of a "squeeze-out" I alluded to above.

Your mom does not need your social security number to become a citizen if she is already a legal permanent resident. She would need that information to become a permanent resident. There are many other issues that need to be dealt with.  Does your mom have unlawful presence?  You should consult immigration counsel for your mom.

There is no waiting period to get your hardship when convicted of fleeing to elude like there is with certain drug offenses, however you will be required to complete the Advanced Driver Improvement course before being considered for a hardship license. If you have any further questions or want to set an appointment to determine whether you are eligible for a hardship license after taking the course, contact your local Bureau of Administrative Review office and they can assist you further.  The following is a list of offices and their contact information in the state of Florida: http://www.flhsmv.gov/ddl/forms/hsmv78015-2.html.  Hope this helps. Best of luck to you.

It is not the Department of Labor who characterizes terminations.  That's up to the employer.  The standard is that you can only be denied unemployment benefits if you intentionally violate a known work rule.  Mistakes and accidents don't count.  Neither does negligence.  So if you forgot the procedure and there is no evidence that you did it on purpose, you cannot be denied benefits.  If the DOL has made an initial decision against you, then you must file for an appeal within 15 days.  At the hearing, the employer has the burden of proof and the above standard applies.  Based on your version of what happened, you should be awarded benefits.

This was a terrible idea and I assume you were not represented by counsel.  You NEVER underestimate a workers comp claim because if you do, your trustee can and may object, or if its later determined it has value, your trustee will go after every penny of it that was not declared. So if you valued the exemption at zero, and you get 1 dollar, the trustee may go after it anyway. Not that the trustee would succeed, but if you're unrepresented a trustee could succeed if you don't know how to respond.  You should have placed "undetermined" or "unliquidated" in the area instead of listing it with zero value. And you should have claimed it in Schedule C as exempt under the workers comp statute.  Fla. Stat. 440 .22 says:   "benefits shall be exempt from all claims of creditors, and from levy, execution and attachments or other remedy for recovery or collection of a debt, which exemption may not be waived. " and the exception is alimony and child support debts which can be levied against those claims.  There is no exemption for personal injury under Florida law. You have standard exemptions pursuant to Fla. Stat. 222.  Nonetheless if you don't know what you're doing, Ch. 7 is not a great do it yourself project and if you did not properly claim your exemptions in Schedule C, you could get screwed.  Click on "Find a Lawyer" above and retain counsel who is competent to list and exempt your assets properly.

The landlord must return the deposit or a list of damages within thirty(30) days of the end of the lease or surrender and acceptance of the leased premises. Social Security does make errors from time to time. If you believe that you were denied benefits, but they are indicating that you still have a claim pending, it would be important to understand more of what happened. There are times that Social Security pulls denials for quality review. In those situations, a decision is not supposed to be issued, but sometimes is sent out by mistake. If the case is pulled for quality review the decision is not supposed to be sent out until after the quality review is completed.  The other situation that I can think of is after an Administrative Law Judge Hearing. The Appeals Council selects a portion of all claims (including approvals), to review on their own motion. Even if you did not appeal, your claim can be reopened in this situation.  If you were approved benefits, and Social Security indicates that the claim is still open, it could always be because you were approved for one disability program, but your eligibility under another program is still pending (for example you are approved for SSI because they can easily determine that you are disabled as of now, but your Social Security Disability Insurance claim is still pending to determine if you were disabled before your date last insured).  I would suggest that you contact the Social Security Administration to learn more information. If a representative cannot answer your question, consider meeting with an attorney with all letters you have receive from Social Security to determine if they can help. Your US Representative or Senator may also be a good resource.  Please feel free to clarify your answer, and hopefully someone can provide you with more information.

The successor trust language of the trust should be reviewed to make sure that only one person is to serve as successor.  If that is the case, the successor individual is the only person entitled to act and the only person entitled to compensation.  Compensation of an individual not entitled to act as a trustee could be a breach of the the trustee's duties.  You should ask the trustee what authority authorizes the administration by cotrustees.  You may also wish to have an attorney review the trust in order to determine whether the trustees are acting pursuant to the provisions of the trust.

As a full-time professional family mediator, I absolutely hear that part of you is attracted to the idea of mediating your divorce, and that part of you has substantial reservations. That is sensible given your description of your marriage. As with all important issues, there are many tradeoffs and a decision may be nuanced and not clearcut.  I think it fair to observe that my profession once believed, mediation was never appropriate for parties with big issues of power and control. Some modern researchers note, however, in some of these cases, the benefits of securing a partner's voluntary compliance and more immediate disengagement can outweigh the loss of certain legally protected economic or other gains. I recommend you speak, perhaps in person, with several professionals before making a final decision. Good luck to you!

There is no law in WA that requires a living person to record, file, or do something else with the government for the person's will.  The county's recorder's office does accept a will for recording if someone wants to have the will recorded.  WA superior courts have a program in which the clerks of the courts will accept original wills of still living persons for safekeeping. The clerks charge a fee each time the will is put in or taken out of the clerk's office.  Wills must follow statutory procedures to be accepted by the court.  You should review the specific facts with your attorney to make sure your will will be accepted by the courts when needed.

One thing none of my esteemed colleagues mentioned is that you cannot seek through a 237 Notice to Produce at Trial any information or documents that you have not previously sought through the discovery process, whether pursuant to a 214 Notice to Produce or otherwise. This is a very important procedural requirement and since you are held to the same standard as an attorney, if you serve your opponent with a 237 notice without prior discovery requests, your opponent will be within his rights to object.

I agree with Attorneys Shields and Elder.  The county welfare department cannot unilaterally determine your mother's mental capacity and they cannot grant anyone the power to handle her finances. If someone does not have capacity to make financial decisions for themselves and there are no estate planning documents in place that address this issue, the proper procedure  is for a Probate petition for Conservatorship to be filed. Even if a Conservatorship petition is filed, the proposed Conservatee (your mother, for example) has the right to her own attorney and to object to the Conservatorship. Additionally, a determination of capacity is made by a doctor, not the county welfare department.   Ordinarily, if a bank suspects financial or other elder abuse, they would make a report to Adult Protective Services asking them to investigate. If their investigation warrants, the case may be referred to the Public Guardian for a determination as to whether a Conservatorship (for example) is needed.   I agree with Attorney Elder that your mother should contact an elder law attorney as soon as possible.

Motions are simply a legal way of asking the court to do something:  for example, dismiss your case, suppress or exclude certain evidence, prevent the prosecutor from arguing or mentioning something to the jury, or allow your side to present certain evidence at trial.  They must be filed in good faith (with factual and legal grounds to seek the relief sought), and then scheduled for hearing at a later date, allowing the other side a chance to respond with legal authority and perhaps an evidentiary hearing.  You should ask your lawyer to explain what motions are being filed (request a copy), and what he or she hopes to gain by doing this.  Obviously, the goal most times (if you can't get the case dismissed outright) is to make the state's case weaker and present difficulties of proof, which could result in a better chance at trial, or a better offer for you.

'Yes' the state may use witnesses whose stories don't match.  The jury/judge will have to decide if the misalignment in stories is material to the charges or not.  MANY have been convicted of serious crimes with witness statements that completely conflict each other.  FWIW, witnesses are are among the most unreliable of sources in a criminal case, despite our general belief that a witness is key.  Best if luck to your friend.

Your question is far too broad to be given an accurate answer.  No reputable employment attorney could conclusively answer one way or the other just based on these sparse facts, nor should such a response really be expected.  Your employer must pay the promised agreed upon wage for a particular employee.  However, California is an at-will state which not only applies to termination and hire procedures but wages as well (so long as it does not fall minimum wage), as you correctly stated.  Threatening to lower someone's pay is not illegal.  However, it depends on why and under what circumstances.  For instance, if your employer is threatening to lower someone's wages or fire them for something considered protected conduct such as a "whistle blower" statute issue then you have a case.  However, if he is relating the pay to performance, that is not illegal.  A customer complaint depends on what type of complaint and why your employer is saying what he's saying.  None of these things can be learned from your general question.  You or your "friend" should speak with a qualified employment attorney.  Most of us offer free consultations to go through a deep dive of the facts.  You may find some on here or the calbar.org website or cela.org which is specifically for employment attorneys who represent employees on these type of actions.  Good luck to you.

There is no set timeframe for holding a revocation hearing once a probationer has been incarcerated on a probation warrant.  Dekalb Superior Court is very busy and it might take a while for this to reach a revocation calendar.    More importantly, your husband is ultimately facing revocation of his First Offender status and prison time on a resentencing.  120 hours of community service can be done in a year at the rate of 2-3 hours a week, so he must have not done community service for a while in order for the probation department to be requiring him to do 8 hours in one day/week.  Therefore, his defense will be difficult and will depend largely upon convincing the judge to give him another chance.  This might be accomplished by his employment status (holding down two jobs) and family circumstances.  I would probably ask for his community service to be commuted into the time that he is serving right now.  Then the question becomes whether he gets to keep his First Offender status.  He really needs to retain counsel to help him try to keep his First Offender.  An attorney will know what evidence to present (and more importantly, what not to present) in order for him to have the best chance of retaining his First Offender status.  Call me if I can be of assistance.
