There's one other element of things that hasn't been mentioned that you should be aware of, and that's filling out applications for federal public aid to pay your tuition (FAFSA).  Under the federal laws that govern the program, the government calculates how much aid you are eligible for based on how much income your parents make.  The federal law assumes that your parents will provide you a certain amount of help and limit how much aid you can receive based on that assumption.  It seems a bit odd--limiting the amount of aid YOU can get even though it doesn't require anything of your parents, I know.  Usually, both parents need to cooperate and assist you in filling out your FAFSA application.  If you have no contact with your dad and aren't able to do this, there are ways of letting the program know this.  I've included a link to the handbook on Federal Aid so that you can familiarize yourself with it.  You may also want to set up a meeting early in the year this year with the school guidance counselor to talk about the application process.

Hello Oshkosh,  While you can file for a fiance visa for your fiance, the question is whether the previous deportation order will prevent him from using the visa, even if approved.  For example- if he was ordered to remain outside the US for 10 years, the fiance visa will not cancel that out.  He would need to apply for permission to be re-admitted to the US first to deal with the underlying order.  It is a good thing that he complied with it and has stayed out so long- those are all favorable actions.  If he or you still have the original immigration court paperwork, including the order/sentencing portions, consider bringing or sending those to an experienced immigration attorney for review on how best to move forward in the case.  I hope that helps clarify the issues.

The Nashville Bar Association's legal help hotline will probably point you in the right direct for finding a plaintiff's attorney that practices legal malpractice. It is difficult to tell whether you have a good claim based on the facts you have given.  It can be very difficult to win a legal malpractice case, just like a medical malpractice claim, because you must show not only that the attorney made a mistake, but that this mistake was unreasonable when judged by a reasonable attorney standard. In addition, you must show you actually suffered damages because of the mistake. You will need to give a full recitation of the facts and all of the filings to an attorney for review of the merits of this case.  You can also reach out to the Tennessee Board of Professional Responsibility if you feel that an attorney has taken action in your case without your permission.  While it will not entitle you to damages, a breach of an ethical obligation to a client can provide vindication with a lower standard than a full legal malpractice litigation.

How long was your wife in Arizona before she filed? If it was less than 90 days, jurisdiction probably was improper and you should consult with a local family law attorney whose experience includes post-decree matters.  Jurisdiction is a term that broadly refers to the power of a specific court to issue a ruling. In your case, there are two relevant types of jurisdiction. The first, personal jurisdiction, is the court‰Ûªs authority over the parties. By defending against the case here, you consented to personal jurisdiction and waived the right to challenge it now.  Conversely, subject matter jurisdiction can never be waived. Historically, Arizona courts treat the marriage itself as a property. The court must find that either party resided in Arizona for 90 days prior to filing the petition in order to establish its authority to dissolve the marriage.   I strongly encourage you to speak with a family law attorney as soon as you can. You‰Ûªll be able to quickly discern whether or not jurisdiction was properly asserted. If you find that it wasn‰Ûªt, you can file a motion (ARFLP Rule 85/FRCP Rule 60) to set aside the judgment.

First of all, if you want a divorce you do not need your husband to agree or consent to a divorce, though it would make it easier, less expensive, and faster. You also do not need a basis for the divorce ‰ÛÒ the fact that you are convinced it‰Ûªs over is enough for the courts to conclude the marriage should be dissolved. As for abuse, there are many different kinds of abuse, but I assume you are talking about physical abuse. Physical abuse can be addressed either: 1) as a criminal matter by filing criminal charges or calling the police to intervene during an outbreak of violence, 2) the matter can also be addressed as a civil matter by filing for a "no abuse" order under mgl 209A. If addressed as a criminal matter your husband will likely be arrested and have to face criminal charges and jail is a possibility depending on a variety of circumstances, including past history and severity of assault. The fact that he is mentally ill or on medication may be a mitigating factor, but not conclusive, and the courts are not noted for their sensitivity to mental illness. To file under mgl 209A you will have to convince a civil court that your husband poses a threat to you that places you in fear of immanent physical harm. If you convince the court (and the threshold is low), the court will order your husband not to abuse you. They may also order that he have no contact with you and that he vacate the marital home. The order is a civil order and there is no chance of incarceration ‰ÛÒ unless your husband violates the order which is a criminal infraction. The civil court will be even less understanding or forgiving of your husband‰Ûªs mental illness than the criminal court. It sounds as though your husband is already attempting to address his problems, but he is not very successful. The 209A order may convince him that he needs to make a stronger effort or seek alternate treatment. The criminal approach will do little for your husband, but it may offer you more protection. There are a number of domestic shelters and programs in Massachusetts and it would behoove you to consult with one of them and develop a sound safety plan.

We couldn't possibly answer this question with any intelligence, because there are enough holes in the facts to drive the Titanic through: 1.  What was the child arrested for? 2.  How old is the "child?" 3.  Is the "child" being charged as an adult? 4.  Does the charge involve Disability Fraud, SSI Faird, Medicare Fraud or some other kind of benefit fraud? 5. My colleagues may be correct...or maybe not.  First, I doubt she can just disclaim responsibility for maintenance/repair.  She can, perhaps, exclude the use of the pool from the lease but if it is not specifically excluded, I don't think she can include it in what you rent and then deny responsibility to maintain it.  Secondly, ORS 90.320 provides that a landlord must provide, keep, and maintain all buildings, grounds, appurtenances safe for normal and reasonably foreseeable uses...does that cover repairing a pool in the yard?  Or perhaps a mandatory removal of the pool and it's frame if it is not going to be repaired?  Hmm...I think you at least have an argument depending in part upon how "portable" this pool is - can it be taken up and down relatively easily or is it pretty much a "fixture"?  Most of all, I would want to be sure there is no reasonable way to interpret her proposed new lease to mean that you are responsible for the maintenance/repair of the pool - either now or as a result of future deterioration.   There may not be a definitive answer, known ahead of having a Judge or Jury decide the issue, but if pressed, you may want to at least discuss the issue with a local landlord-tenant attorney.  Good luck.  Greg Abbott Consumer Law Northwest 6635 N. Baltimore, #254 Portland, OR 97203 503-283-4568 gregabbott@consumerlawnorthwest.com "Practicing Landlord-Tenant Law in Oregon for Over 20 Years"

It depends.  If you are receiving the income generated by a trust, that income is taxable as ordinary income to you.  However, if you are receiving the principal of a trust, that is excluded from your taxable income (gifts and inheritances are specifically excluded from taxable income under Section 102 of the Internal Revenue Code).  If you are not sure whether you are receiving trust income or trust principal, ask the trustee.  Washington State has no income tax, so neither trust income nor trust principal would be taxable at the state level.

A private employer may decline to hire one with a criminal record.  However, doing so can't be used to mask an illegal purpose.  For example, an employer cannot reject a candidate because of race, but use a criminal conviction as the reason.  Obviously, this would be hard to prove in most cases.  There is some guidance from the EEOC on this issue that may interest you.  More and more employers are not rejecting candidates on a blanket basis because of a prior criminal record.  Even the President has addressed this issue -- in his State of the Union address.  Public employers are probably more likely to follow this EEOC guidance than private employers.

My take on the matter is that the lawsuit should be dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) for failure to state a claim. Your own copyright attorney, of course, needs to evaluate the matter based on all the facts.  The general rule is that a party who did not have standing to sue, or who did not satisfy a precondition to suit, may NOT manufacture standing or satisfy the precondition during the proceeding.  The suit must be dismissed whole cloth, without leave to amend, even if an amended complaint is subsequently filed that pleads facts satisfying standing or the precondition.  The Reed Elsevier case does not alter that rule.  The Supreme Court held in Reed Elsevier that "Section 411(a) thus imposes a type of precondition to suit that supports nonjurisdictional treatment under our precedents."  The Court expressly chose to "decline to address whether å¤ 411(a)'s registration requirement is a mandatory precondition to suit that ‰Û_ district courts may or should enforce sua sponte by dismissing copyright infringement claims involving unregistered works."  The case was taken to resolve the circuit courts disagreement over whether the registration requirement in Section 411(a) was "jurisdictional" or merely established a precondition to suit. Contrary to one responding attorney's assertion otherwise, the Court did NOT hold that a trial court may adjudicate infringement claims of unregistered works  -- that is, works that do not satisfy the precondition set forth in Section 411(a).  Because Reed Elsevier did not alter -- or even address -- the rule that Section 411(a) imposes a mandatory precondition to bringing a copyright infringement claim, it leaves intact all the prior case law dismissing suits brought by copyright owners who did not at least apply to register the allegedly infringed work before filing suit. Those suits have historically been dismissed ‰ÛÒ and, yes, sometimes re-filed once the registration application was submitted  [or actually issues, depending on the rule in that particular jurisdiction].  But that would be a NEW lawsuit, not a continuation of the previous one.   Again, speak with your own copyright attorney. Good luck.

The question is: what makes you think he is "retired?"  From your statements, it does not seem like he is "retired." If your association was truly optional, you cannot be made a mandatory member without your consent.  I have seen a number of communities work to convert from optional to mandatory, and it takes time and effort.  Keeping the amenities in the area up to date usually enhances your property value whether you pay dues or not, so that is something to consider.  Also, a number of associations I have worked with have addressed situations sucy as yours by obtaining a delayed consent - that is the owner consents to have his property covered by the mandatory covenants as of the sale of his home - that way the owner is not paying current dues, the association knows it has a mandatory member in the future, and the eventual purchaser of your home can't be shut out of the HOA or charged a high fee to join at a later date.  Consider all your options and all the ramifications, not just payment of current dues.

Disregard thew $100 fee.  It was part of a civil demand which you were not obligated to pay and in fact should not have paid.  You are probably off the hook but if you want to know for sure if you have any criminal record, go online and pay a service to run a background check.  It will not be very costly.    Here is some information about civil demands:  There is a law in the state of Illinois which allows for civil action collection when there is a retail theft. Most people choose to ignore the demand. This demand is for money over and above any fine you pay in compliance with a court order. People may get a few more letters, each time asking for more, and then they stop. While the retailer can sue you, it is extremely rare for anyone to actually be sued. You do not owe any money unless you are sued and the retailer wins. This is a common ploy. Do not pay. If you do, you will be in the national retailers database which could affect your ability to get a job and could impact your life in other ways. If you are uncomfortable, hire a lawyer and have the lawyer write a letter. That should be the end of it.   Here is a good article: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB120347031996578719.html   The National Retail Theft Database is actually a voluntary list put together by different individual retailers. Further, any member that published the information on the list, can thereafter, remove it. Therefore, if you wish to have the entry removed, as you apparently do, your best bet would be to write a letter to the manager of the particular store and inquire as to what it would take for them to remove the entry.  Please go to this link: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/should-i-pay-the-civil-demand-letter

My answer varies from that of my colleagues, in that the date the statute of limitations begins to run for credit card debt can vary depending on what the credit card agreement specifies, and if no date is indicated, typically is 180 days from the last date payment was due. Also, payment of any amount, even if made after the statute of limitations has expired, restarts the statute of limitations all over again, so beware of offers to pay just a penny or dollar, as it will revive a cause of action that has passed, or give another 4 years of time to a statute that has not yet expired.  If a debt collector is contacting you as opposed to the credit card company itself, my advice would be to wait until contacted by the debt collector before taking any action, and then, have a consumer lawyer review the communication with the collector for potential violations of law that might prevent you from having to pay some or all of the amount demanded.

Illinois courts have concluded that the aggravating factor held unconstitutional in Aguilar is separate from the aggravating factor of no FOID card and that the FOID card requirement is not an unconstitutional limitation on our Second Amendment rights. That being said, the sentence would, in theory, remain the  same regardless as to weather they were originally merged because you are still left with sentencing on 1 count of Agg UUW, its just a different factor being used to convert the charge from UUW to Agg UUW.  You should call the attorney who handled the original matter in the trial court and make an appointment to sit down and discuss this in detail so that you can get a full understanding of what your facing and if there is any argument that may sway the state to reduce your charge to simple UUW but the remaining sections of the Agg UUW statute have been held constitution but have not been heard by the supreme court so additional arguments might exist  based on the specific circumstances of your case.  Discuss everything with your lawyer during a scheduled sit down and not in the courtroom on the day of court.

You will need to find out what the laws are in Louisiana.  They may have a relocation statute like the state of Florida.  In the State of Florida, you have to ask for consent from the other parent or get permission from the Court before moving more than 50 miles away.  However, in Florida if the biological father has not established paternity in a family law court he has no rights.  So the mother can move if she wishes.  However, if the biological father files a paternity action before the mother meets the residency requirement of the new state, there is a potential for the mother to be required to bring the child back to the state of Florida.  This is Florida law however.  You need to find out about the relocation statue in Louisiana if they have one.  Good luck.  Sincerely, B. Elaine Jones, Esq.

As this is a very sensitive case, the wording of the settlement agreement must be carefully read.  First, if I were you, I would insist on a confidentiality provision in the settlement agreement (assuming the matter settles at the global settlement conference), which would prevent any parties involved in the conference from discussing the specifics of the settlement, including the amount.  Second, you should be sure the settlement agreement states that the insurer and its insured is "not accepting any liability or fault" and that the settling of the matter "is not an indication or admission of fault."  That would have no real effect except that any other defendants cannot point to it and say "Oh look, she settled with that insurer.  That means their insured was at fault!"  Third and most importantly, you must make sure that the settlement agreement does not say anything about waiving your claims against third parties, namely, the physicians and hospital against which you have filed suit.  If you cover those bases, I don't see how the doctors/hospital will be able to hold that settlement against you.

Unfortunately, when you lose your job you are no longer in L-1B status.  However, it is possible for you and your wife to file change of status applications to B-2 status for medical care reasons - just make sure that your applications are RECEIVED at USCIS prior to your last day of employment (hopefully your company will give you some advance notice of this).  Also, include a letter from your wife's physician stating that she cannot travel due to the late date of the pregnancy (or if you are laid off after the baby is born and you cannot leave the US because the baby cannot yet travel, the letter from the doctor can state this reason instead).  You should also provide evidence that you have the ability to cover the health care expenses with the application - such as health insurance cards or bank statements if you are paying out of pocket.  You should also state that you intend to leave the U.S. as soon as the doctor has cleared your wife and child to do so, that you are only staying here to deliver because you have to for medically necessary reasons, etc.  If your company has an immigration lawyer, perhaps they will be kind enough to have that lawyer prepare the applications for you as needed.  Good luck!

Yours is a very complex situation, because there are state and federal laws that protect "tenants," but none that protect "squatters."  A "tenant" is simply a person who leases a piece of property from its owner or a designated agent of the owner. To be a tenant entitled to protection under Chapter 83 of the Florida Statutes, or the Protecting Tenants at Foreclosure Act of 2009 ("PTFA"), the people occupying the premises would have to provide documentation to prove that (1) they had a valid lease with the previous owner, (2) they paid an amount of rent that was not substantially less than fair market value, and (3) they are not related to or in some advantageous relationship with the prior landlord.   If the occupants can provide proof of the above, then they must be given at least 90 days' notice from you to vacate, if you intend to personally occupy the property. If you do not intend to make the property your primary residence, then the tenants have either 90 days, or until the expiration of their lease.  If, however, the occupants cannot provide such proof, then you have a couple of options, including asking the Court which presided over the foreclosure to issue a Writ of Possession, or calling the Sheriff's Office and asking them to remove the people as trespassers. Because they are not "tenants," an eviction action could be defended by them on the ground that there is no landlord-tenant relationship, so the options stated above are probably your safest, most direct routes.  You can speak with the people in your house, but many tenants are under the mistaken belief that once a house is sold at foreclosure, they acquire some right to simply remain in the property and not pay rent. They may even become belligerent and dare you to take them to court, so I would suggest sending a letter to the property introducing yourself, providing them with an opportunity to prove they are bona fide tenants, advising them that they will have to pay rent to remain in the meantime. To do this properly, I would advise you speak with a real estate attorney, however, as you want to furnish a notice that complies with the PTFA. A few hundred dollars would be a reasonable fee, and the time frame can range between a few weeks to a few months, depending on how you proceed.  I hope this information has been helpful, and wish you the best of luck.

It is possible that your husband would qualify for Disability Benefits from Social Security. However, the Social Security process is not immediate, and it normally takes from 3 to 8 months for a decision in the Philadelphia area. In order to potentially qualify for benefits, your husband has to be able to prove that his medical conditions are severe enough that they have either already prevented him from working for 12 months, or will prevent him from working.  Luckily for your husband, his age puts him in the easiest category to be approved for benefits. If he were under 50, he would need to be able to establish that his condition prevents him from performing all full-time work. Since he is 60, the most important question is whether his condition will prevent him from performing the work he has done during the past 15 years, and whether he retains any transferable skills that will allow him to perform easier work.  It is important that your husband discusses his condition with his physicians. If they feel that he could return to his past work, it would be difficult to be approved, and if they release him back to work, it would probably be in his interest to try to return to work. If his physicians agree that he is unable to work, and he is significantly limited in his lifting and standing, and he agrees that he cannot return to work, he should definitely consider applying for Social Security Disability Insurance.  It is important to realize that even if he does qualify for Social Security Disability Insurance, an individual is not eligible for payments for the first 5 months that they are unable to work as a result of the disability. This 5 month waiting period normally becomes closer to 6 months, if he became unable to work after the 1st of the month. If the disability begins after the first of the month, there is a 5 month waiting period from the day he became unable to work, and then since eligibility for payments cannot begin in the middle of the month, payment eligibility does not begin until the 6th month. This means that if an individual last worked January 5, 2014, are found disabled on that date, their disability eligibility doesn't actually begin until July 2014. Since Social Security doesn't pay you until the month after your eligibility, a July payment would not be received until August. This means that for someone found disabled, their first payment is not usually received until 7 months after their disability began at the earliest.  I would recommend that your husband immediately speak to an attorney to determine if his is a good candidate for disability. If he potentially qualifies for SSI, it is important to apply as soon as possible, as individuals sometimes can be found disabled and be qualified for SSI payments even during the waiting period for SSDI. I wish your husband good luck!

Easy..you tell the truth. You list the vehicle in Schedule B and after year make and model, I would add" I own vehicle equitably, but legally in anothers name , but I make all payments on it and $    is owed". Then  In Schedule D list the family member as in reality your agreement with them is a debt , and you list them as secured on vehicle as they own it legally, you own it equitably, and list the amount owed. Normally, your vehicle may be worth less than is owed on it and thus no equity in Schedule C; if equity, list it there too. Then , in the statement of financial affairs #14 list the vehicle also and state you own it equitably, they legally.   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

A case is dismissed, not a judgment.  A judgment can be set aside if it was improperly obtained, but your time to do that has passed.  You are beyond dealing with the Plaintiff's entitlement to have the judgment.  What you must now do is become aware of what the Plaintiff's rights are to use the legal process to collect money from you.  I hate to use the cookie-cutter answer that you should consult with an attorney, but here I will.  The particulars of your situation, what you own, what your income is, what your source of income is, and so on, that should be discussed face-to-face with a lawyer.  Your being the only source of income in your household would tend to have significance, but that too would depend upon the particulars of your household--who else in the household, if anyone? what is their relationship to you? do they receive government benefits? do you receive child support from a parent? and so forth.

Under Oregon law, it is a crime to have sexual contact with anyone who is under age 18, because the law assumes that someone under that age cannot effectively give consent. However, if both partners are over age 15 and are within 3 years of one another's ages, then their ages can be an 'affirmative defense' to a charge of a sexual offence if that charge is based solely upon lack of consent due to age. An affirmative defense is not, strictly speaking, a bar to prosecution. It is a defense that the defendant must raise if a prosecution does occur.   That said, it is relatively common for relationships of this sort to occur and prosecutions are rare. Prosecutions cannot be brought about just because parents are angry. Private citizens have no legal authority to compel criminal charges. Charging crimes is the sole province of the police and district attorney. Private persons, including crime victims (or parents of crime victims) can report alleged crimes to police and can cooperate with the DA in their investigations, but that's all they can do. There is no such thing as "pressing charges" for most citizens.   Note also that none of this protects someone from prosecution for other sex-related crimes. So while sexual contact between an 18-year-old and a 16-year-old may be legal in Oregon, it requires both to freely consent. Practice enthusiastic consent, use protection and birth control, and be honest at all times.

It's not strictly a "double jeopardy" issue, but what they may be referring to is a Kellett issue (Kellett v. Superior Court (1966) 63 Cal.2d 822).  Essentially, that case says that if there has been a prosecution that results in a final judgment, then any charges arising from that same incident should not be allowed.  That applies to any charges that were known or should have been known about at the time of the first prosecution.    This has been litigated previously (see In re Dennis B; People v. Arellano) and fails.  Because the prosecutor plays little to no role in the filing of an infraction that is not an included offense to a DUI, it's unlikely that this argument will prevail.  Would your case be different?  Maybe.  Could there be something on/connected to your citation that indicates there was a DUI?  There's at least an argument that the government (or at least some branch of it) knew that the DUI was in the same incident as the citation.  The problem is that an infraction for the tags is not an "included offense" to DUI.    Would it confound the prosecution?  Perhaps.  If you really want to pursue this avenue, you'll need an attorney to be on board with this and may want to start your case right with a plea of "Once in Jeopardy" rather than a straight not guilty.  (See Penal Code 1016)

As some of the other attorneys mentioned - finding an attorney who handles DUI often gives you a better chance to reduce the charge. The plea doesn't just get better because you have no past. It gets better because you're attorney made legal arguments that may weaken the states case.  Most firms offer free consultations. It's at least worth your time to consult with an attorney before deciding.

The short answer is yes, a lawyer in one state can draft a contract between a client and a third party in another state. In fact, this happens all the time--probably every day. Consider Google, headquartered in California, and IBM, headquartered in New York. Does it seem likely that the only way a lawyer could draft a contract between Google and IBM is if the lawyer is admitted in both California and New York? Definitely not.  The question is whether the lawyer is competent in the area of law, and if the lawyer is licensed in the jurisdiction where he or she is practicing. Where the client resides doesn't matter.

In Ohio, to successfully prove a defamation claim, you would have to be able to prove: 1) that the person made a statement, reported as fact, to another person; 2) that the statement was false; 3) that the statement caused damage to you; and 4) that the person was negligent in making the statement.   Remember, however, the person cannot be held liable for voicing their opinion, only for making untrue factual assertions.

A therapist is a mandated reporter which, unfortunately, means they are not to be trusted.  Their primary interest is protecting their license, not protecting your confidences.  When a therapist begins to suspect that a patient is about to engage in criminal behavior, the therapist must make a decision as to how serious the threat is and act accordingly.  A therapist would not report that you are bi-polar, but if you are and you tell the therapist you are planning to kill your wife, then the specific threat will be reported.

A second conviction or PBJ will result in the MVA attempting to suspend your license for 30 days.   You can request a hearing to fight the suspension and the judge can reduce or modify the suspension to allow you to drive to work or school.   If you plead guilty,  you will end up being found guilty or with a PBJ.  You should therefore plead not guilty.   If the officer does not appear,  you will be acquitted.   If the officer is present, you will almost certainly be convicted unless you have an attorney.   In summation,  there are two ways to avoid the suspension.   You either have to be acquitted of the speeding ticket or you must fight the suspension at an administrative hearing.

I know it is a tough situation to need a lawyer and not be able to afford one, but it is one of those emergency situations which people should try to save for. I am sorry to hear that you are going through this incredibly frustrating situation.  The good news is that you certainly do have rights.  I will attempt to give you a brief overview of what you can try to do on your own and how the law can help if you want to file a lawsuit.  Due to the different parties involved (dealer and manufacturer) and the complexity of Ohio and federal law on "lemon" RVs, my guess is that you will most likely need to engage an Ohio lemon law attorney to negotiate with the manufacturer and/or file a lawsuit on your behalf.  First, it will be helpful to have as much documentation of every problem with the RV as possible.  So keep a diary of sorts in which you note every problem as it occurs, including all pertinent details.  Keep a "log" of your communications with the dealer and/or manufacturer.  Keep all your repair paperwork every time the dealer comes out and any time any other work is done on the RV.  You can try to negotiate with the manufacturer on your own.  I would write a detailed letter to the manufacturer explaining all the issues with the RV and all the attempts that have been made to fix those problems.  Also state in your letter (generally referred to as a "demand letter") what you are requesting.  State whether you want a replacement (of the same model or a different model) or whether you simply want your money back.  It will take the manufacturer some time to respond to your demand letter, so you may want to follow up by phone (though I understand your efforts to communicate with the manufacturer so far have not been successful).  Complain as hard as possible and see what they are willing to offer you.  If they do make you an offer, they may want you to pay a "mileage" fee and/or pay the difference in sticker price between your current model and the new model.  Ohio's Lemon Law does not require you to do either of those things, but of course that will not stop them from trying to negotiate that with you.  Ohio's Lemon Law applies to RVs (though it only covers the "chassis" portion and does not cover things like the refrigerator, for example).  I would need more information to tell you whether the Lemon Law would apply to your situation.  Additionally, there are other legal claims you can make against the dealer and/or manufacturer - violation of the Ohio Consumer Sales Practices Act (Ohio's most significant consumer protection law), violation of the Magnuson Moss Warranty Act (sometimes referred to as a "federal lemon law"), breach of contract and breach of warranty (depending on the warranties you received when you purchased the RV).  Some of these laws allow you to recover attorney fees from the dealer/manufacturer if you sue them in court and win.  As with the Lemon Law, I would need more detailed information from you in order to give you more complete feedback on your potential legal claims against the dealer and manufacturer.  Not a lot of lawyers practice in this area, so you would be best served by finding a consumer protection attorney with experience in lemon law and warranty law.  There are a few of us who practice throughout Ohio and would be happy to review the case for free.  If you want to take legal action, it is important that you move quickly because of the "statute of limitations." You have likely heard that term; however, if you haven't, it basically means that you only have a limited amount of time in which you can file a lawsuit, and after that time run out, your rights expire.  For lawsuits under the Ohio Consumer Sales Practices Act, the statute of limitations is two years.  So however you decide to proceed, move quickly.  Good luck.

I hate to say this, but as an adult, your record is likely NOT being "expunged and sealed".    California does not have a true "expungement" statute where they will wipe the case off your record.  Similarly, you cannot seal adult records.    Licensing agencies, such as the BRE, can look at arrests and the conduct, not just convictions.  You'd be well served to sit down face to face with a licensing attorney to discuss your status, your application and how to best proceed.  The worst thing you could do would be to fail to disclose this and get rejected because they think you falsified the application.

The police investigate criminal offenses and submit reports to prosecutors.  The prosecutors file formal charges with the court.  The court signs an arrest warrant ordering the cops to go pick you up and bring you to court if everything submitted by the prosecutors to the court adds up to "probable cause" that you committed a crime.  So the detective doesn't file formal charges himself, but the paperwork he submits will eventually lead to criminal charges in most cases.  So chances are, you're eventually going to be looking at a criminal charge and an arrest warrant.  Hire a criminal defense attorney as soon as you can and you may be able to avoid getting picked up on the arrest warrant.

Keep in mind that the crude fraud you describe was actually carried out by you.  The burden of showing you did it at the behest of your lawyer will be on you.  You might not want to start down that road without a writing or email showing the advice.  Do not add to your own pain.

I think you've asked this once before.  If not, I apologize...  Unless one of these charges carries a life sentence, he is NOT facing 25-life under the three strikes law for catching 3 strike offenses in this one case.  The potential 25-life sentence is for someone who already has 2 prior strike convictions and then gets convicted of a new strike offense.    Most strikes carry a presumptive prison sentence.  That means that it is presumed they will be going to prison.  But like every presumption, it can be overcome and the judge can grant probation on *most* offenses.  Whether they will or not depends on the facts, the charges and the circumstances of the offenses.  It also matters what his attorney can do for him to convince the DA or judge to give him probation (assuming he's convicted at all).

You raise a couple issues here that need to be addressed:  1. To answer your explicit question, no, they cannot issue a withholding order against your soon-to-be-spouse's wages. You would be entitled to a reduction of child support because your daughter lives with you. Of course, you can always give more money for the boys as you wish but your court-ordered amount could be reduced.

Jurisdiction is the power of the court to hear a matter.  There are roughly two parts to jurisdiction: subject matter jurisdiction and personal jurisdiction.  Subject matter jurisdiction is the ability of the specific court to hear the type of case or to adjudicate matters against one of the parties.  Personal jurisdiction is the power of the court over the individual defendant.  In your case, they most likely held that the Court lacked personal jurisdiction over the defendants, as in they lacked minimum contacts with the forum jurisdiction and dismissed the case so you could bring it again in a place where the parties could be sued, such as federal court or a court in one of the defendants' forums.  Venue is the distinction as to which court, in a jurisdiction, should hear the case - in New York, for example, the specific county or specific type of Court (Civil v. Supreme).  As you can see, this is a relatively complex area of law and you should speak to your attorney if you have questions.

Q: Can I motion default before or the states court date, or do I did it before? A: It depends on what the "court date" is. Normally a motion for default can be filed 20 days after filing and service. Q: Also, the other party never showed up to court or responded. We still don't know where they are. Do I have to serve them the default paperwork? A: If you don't know where they are, you have to get court approval to serve the Summons and Complaint per statute. I am assuming they were properly served and then dropped out of sight. If that's true, you normally don't have to give prior notice of your motion for default. Q: How do I do that if I don't know where they are? A: Whenever you are required to serve someone, you have to do so following the court state and local (county) rules. There are statutes and rule books that describe this procedure. Q: Do I have to do the parenting class before all pf this default, Dismissal stuff? A: look at your county's local rules. Normally the courts require the parenting class before entry of the final orders. See my AVVO Legal Guides on parenting plans, custody, default orders, and vacating default orders for more information about the legal issues raised by your inquiry. Yes.  Landlord can sue you for the two months that you did not pay.  The law suit would be for damages and not for eviction as you already moved out. If landlord does not send this letter he or she forfeits the right to impose a claim against the security deposit. In other words, you could actually sue the landlord for the security deposit. Generally, the USCIS can be expected to issue Receipt Notices withing approximately 10-15 days of filing;  to issue a biometrics appointment Notice within a few days to a couple of weeks later, scheduling an applicant for fingerprinting/biometrics;  and to issue a Notice scheduling a marriage-based adjustment of status interview approximately 5 - 7 months after date of filing.  If an application package has not been properly prepared or fully documented, however, the USCIS may send Requests for Additional Evidence, and that can cause significant delays in the adjudication process.  The USCIS is inconsistent in these time-frames, and it appears you already are aware of this.         David N. Soloway      Frazier, Soloway & Kennedy, PC      Atlanta, Georgia

While you can always agree to the assessment, it is much more difficult to change your mind later than to continue and pursue the matter now. First, talk with your tax lawyer (or retain one) about the legal fees to file an appeal, if you have not already done so. The legal fees may be less than the additional amount the IRS says you owe. Owing a little bit to a lawyer is better than owing a lot to the IRS.   Second, look at your options right now. You can appeal the results of an audit to the IRS appeals division and it will be reviewed by a fresh set of eyes. IRS appeals is independent from the examination function, so if you had trouble with the auditor, you have a fresh start. If you've already appealed, you can file a petition in Tax Court. Remember, run a cost/benefit analysis of the legal fees versus the tax liability in controversy. And, you may obtain legal fees in your case. If you submit a qualified offer, the IRS rejects your offer, and the Tax Court determines that your original offer is correct, you could recover attorney's fees.  I would have a hard time telling someone to give up and pay unless the amount in controversy is so low that it is not worth the legal fees. There are many more avenues to pursue to dispute your tax liability than in this answer.

There is a presumption of paternity in favor of the mother's husband.  The mother has to rebut that presumption if she seeks for you to be deemed the child's father.  The genetic marker test would have to be done to determine paternity on your part too.  The court is probably seeking to determine what the relationship between the husband and child is.   If the child knows only the husband as his father, the court may find that the husband is estopped from denying paternity.  On the other hand, if you are found to be the biological father of the child and have maintained any kind of relationship with the child, the court may find you to be the child's father.  It's a very fact sensitive type of case dependent upon the relationship between the child and alleged father(s).  You should be discussing these issues with your lawyer.

When FMLA and ADA are involved the long story is very important. Issues involving these laws are complex and fact-specific. You certainly have issues whether your STD will be affected by employment elsewhere and whether employment elsewhere conflicts with your employer's rules regarding outside employment. Both of those issues are likely addressed by the STD plan documents and your employer's handbook, respectively. However, the most immediate issue is that the company's doctor is not releasing you back to work. That creates a problem not only for not being able to work but also an issue whether your employer has effectively terminated you because they will not let you return to work. That could implicate your rights under the ADA and your state's anti-discrimination laws. You need to talk to an employment lawyer about the long story and let him or her advice you regarding your next steps.

Under California law, only your father's legal heirs at law may bring a case for Wrongful Death.  You are an heir, and your Uncle is not. Now obviously a claim for Wrongful Death contemplates just that, a death; it it must be shown to have been caused by the negligence of the nursing home staff.  As a right heir, you indeed have the legal right to bring such a claim, and so too would your siblings (they too could bring a claim).  But regardless of your fathers will/trust/estate, your uncle could not bring a claim for Wrongful Death. He would have no "legal standing" to bring such claim.   You should consult an attorney who handles matters in the area of nursing home abuse/neglect.

First of all, they have not accomplished legally valid personal service on you by leaving it on your doorstep. They would have to have given it to someone over the age of 18 and is a family member, etc.  The bottom line is, without going into all the possibilities of effecting service, leaving it on the doorstep is NOT valid personal service in Colorado.  Second, if you are correct and it was the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs who left it on your doorstep, they cannot do that since they are parties to the action.  So, based on what you have said, you have not been personally served and, therefore, the Small Claims Court cannot exercise personal jurisdiction over you.  Now, here comes the tricky part, if you do ANYTHING with regard to the pending case except object to personal jurisdiction, you will be waiving the fact that the Court has no personal jurisdiction and will be submitting voluntarily to its jurisdiction. For example, and this is what Mr. Harkess is pointing out, if you simply show up at Court and begin to argue the merits of the case, you will have waived any objection to the Court's lack of personal jurisdiction.  If you do object to jurisdiction, the plaintiffs, if they are smart, will simply have you served then by a deputy in the Courthouse, or the Clerk, etc. So all you have done is postponed the inevitable.  Your best option is to simply face the complaint and get it dismissed. It sounds like they have no viable action against you anyway - are they seeking money damages in Small Claims Court for you testifying against their son? If they think you lied under oath, then they should be making a report to law enforcement for the crime of perjury. But filing a money damages lawsuit in Small Claims Court seems like quite a stretch.  Hope that helps.  Best of luck to you.

No, failure to pay a consumer debt is not a crime and does not subject you to criminal prosecution or punishment.    If a creditor wants to sue you for collection of a debt, the creditor must first file a lawsuit and then personally serve you with the summons and complaint.  If that happens you must respond to the lawsuit within 30 days.  Even if you do not respond to a collection lawsuit, you would not be guilty of a crime.  But the creditor could then seek to enforce the judgment in various ways, such as a levy on your bank accounts.    If it's been more than 4 years since you made any payments on these credit cards, its likely that the statute of limitations has run, and therefore it isn't likely that you'd be sued by the creditors.  Check other questions on this site regarding credit cards and the statute of limitations for collection lawsuits.

If this person has already entered a plea to the charge, then it is very likely that the court will proceed to sentencing after the warrant is executed (withdrawing the plea is not a likely option).  In many instances, where a person remains on bond (or ROR status) between the plea and sentencing hearing, the State will usually put on the record that the plea agreement is based on the defendant appearing for sentencing with no new law violations.   This means that whatever agreement was reached may no longer be on the table.  Also, when a person fails to appear for a mandatory court date (in felony cases), the State will usually file a subsequent felony charge for failing to appear.  This person should ask the court to appoint a lawyer (if h/she cannot afford one) to resolve both matters concurrently.  Good luck.

First, taking what you say at face value as true, your rights have been violated and you are due compensation and penalties.  What is apparent are your meal breaks.  The law says you get one hour of pay for every violation.  The law requires your employer to give you a 30 minute duty-free meal break for every 5 hours of continuous work.  Aside from that if you are working 6 or 7 days per week, you are probably due over-time and also double-time pay as well as penalties.  The best thing to do is document.  You need some proof that you are not the one clocking out.  If your manager is clocking you out, on paper it could appear as if you are clocking yourself out.  Thus making it difficult to say that you didn't clock yourself out.  If on the other hand, you can prove you were elsewhere (making a delivery, not at work, etc...somehow through text...photos...time stamped emails... etc.) then you cannot be at two places at the same time.  Get creative.  The point is you have to document and prove that you didn't clock yourself out.  Don't worry if this becomes an issue.  There are other things that can be done...it just wouldn't hurt to have more evidence to back up your version of the story (because their version is probably going to sound a lot different).  Employment attorneys usually give free consultations.  Find one on here or through CELA.ORG.  Good luck to you.

Dear  ?,    The purpose of the first brief on appeal is for the appellant to convince the 3 judges on the court of appeal that there was one or more legal errors which made the proceeding in the superior court basically unfair.  The appeal court reviews only legal error, not factual error.  The appeal court is required to assume any factual dispute in the superior court was resolved in favor of the side that won the case.  That is, if your witness testified to one thing and the opponent's witness testified to the opposite, the appeal court is required to assume that the fact-finder, whether judge or jury, believed the witness for your opponent.. So, to recap, the appeal court will not decide credibility issues and will not overturn any explicit or implied factual findings of the court below.     What the appeal court can do is find that a legal ruling against you was in error and so prejudiced your case that you did not get a fair hearing.  BUT, the reviewing court cannot consider any legal issue unless you or your counsel objected to the ruling or the evidence or whatever in superior court.  If there is no objection on the record, you have not preserved your issue(s) for appeal.   With this background in mind, the selection of issues to argue on appeal is crucial.  I never raise more than six and it is rare for me to raise more than 2.  This is because, while there may well be more than six legal errors in a case, it is extremely rare for a case to have six prejudicial errors. Plus, the judges on the appeal court don't believe there can be six prejudicial errors in the same case.  How to choose the errors to make an issue out of on appeal is a skill it takes a long time to develop and I can't give you any help with that.     As far as outcomes, if you had a trial, the only thing the appeal court can do is reverse and remand for a new trial if it finds basic unfairness.  In rare cases, it can reduce the amount of damages awarded. If you lose, the judgment is affirmed and you have a right to petition the state supreme court to review the decision of the court of appeal.  This is not a right to have the high court hear your case as they can refuse to hear any case except a death penalty appeal.  If you win, you get a new trial.  Yours sincerely, Tim Provis Appellate Counsel Member: U.S. Supreme Court Bar

Much more would need to be known to fully answer your question.  For instance, your job and the kinds of seminars you are attending are important.  For instance, it is not unlawful for an employer of a professional, like an attorney, to require the employee to pay for seminars the attorney wishes to attend to improve the attorney's abilities because those seminars benefit the employee as much as the employer.  On the other hand, if you are required to attend a seminar by your employer that is a prerequisite of performing your job, your employer is required to reimburse you for those expenses that you incur.    There are several nuances to these laws.  If you want to know for sure, your only choice will be to locate and consult with an experienced employment law attorney as soon as possible to explore your facts and determine your options.  I would suggest you look either on this site in the Find a Lawyer section, or go to www.cela.org, the home page for the California Employment Lawyers Association, an organization whose members are dedicated to the representation of employees against their employers.  Good luck to you.

Based on your comments following Mr. Pedersen's answer, you may have a remedy in the Fair Employment and Housing Act (FEHA). If your employer has at least five employees, it must comply withe the FEHA. Among other things, the FEHA forbids an employer to discriminate against or harass an employee BECAUSE OF his or her sexual orientation or disability.  This can be difficult because, of course, you do not know for sure what is in someone's thoughts or what the motivation is for the bad treatment. Is your boss treating you this way because you are a lesbian? Because you are a person with a disability? Or because the boss just doesn't like your personality?  Proving that the different treatment is due to your orientation or disability may be easy or may be difficult; without knowing details of your working conditions, it is impossible to speculate. If there are negative or teasing comments regarding your lesbianism or about homosexuality or LGBT issues in general, that gives you and an attorney something to work with.   If not, sometimes discrimination can be shown by differences in the way employees are treated, provided there is a large enough workforce for statistical differences to be significant.  For example, if there are 100 employees and 50 of them are out lesbians, and you are the only one who is receiving the bad treatment, it will be hard to show you are being treated differently because you are a lesbian. However, if there are 100 employees, 50 are women, 2 of you out lesbians and only the 2 of you are receiving adverse treatment, then there is something to pursue.   It is the same kind of inquiry with respect to your disability. Essentially, you need to rule out every other reason for the adverse treatment other than your lesbianism or disability.    Please look at my guide to unlawful discrimination:  http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=what-is-unlawful-employment-discrimination--california-law which should help you understand lawful and unlawful discrimination, how to enforce your rights, and time limits.   In addition, the FEHA requires an employer to provide an employee with a disability (as defined by the FEHA) with a reasonable accommodation for that disability. Please look at my Avvo guide on the ADA: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/disability-discrimination-in-employment.  http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/employment-disability-protection-under-californias-fair-employment-and-housing-act-and-federal-ada?published=true   It also possible you are being treated badly because your boss is a jerk. Unfortunately, employees have very few employment rights and employers have a lot of leeway in how they choose to run their businesses. In general, an employer can be unfair, obnoxious or bad at management. An employer can make decisions based on faulty or inaccurate information.  An employer has no obligation to warn an employee that he or she is not performing as the employer wants. It‰Ûªs not a level playing field. An employer hires employees to provide work for its benefit, not for the benefit of the employees. Don't expect the employer to take care of its employees; it doesn‰Ûªt have to and it rarely does.  There are some limitations on what an employer can do, mostly in the areas of public policy (such as discrimination law as indicated above, or whistle blowing), contract law, union-employer labor relations, and constitutional due process for government employees. Please see my guide to at-will employment in California which should help you understand employment rights: http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/an-overview-of-at-will-employment-all-states.  After you take a look at the guide, you may be able to identify actions or behavior that fits one of the categories that allows for legal action.   (continued in Comment below)

The Texas Arbitration Act (Texas Civil Practices and Remedies Code section 171.001, et seq.) provides the following:  (a)  A written agreement to arbitrate is valid and enforceable if the agreement is to arbitrate a controversy that: (1)  exists at the time of the agreement;  or (2)  arises between the parties after the date of the agreement. (b)  A party may revoke the agreement only on a ground that exists at law or in equity for the revocation of a contract.  Here is a link to the Arbitration Act:  http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/CP/htm/CP.171.htm.  Except in very limited situations dealing with preemptive federal statutes (such as ERISA), arbitration agreements related to employment are enforceable in Texas.  An employee who has signed a valid employment agreement and then tries to initiate litigation relating to the subject matter of the arbitration agreement may have his/her lawsuit dismissed or stayed in favor of compulsory arbitration proceedings.

Litigation is a specialized skill.  Often, self-represented litigants make procedural mistakes that cause them to lose their case without even getting to the merits.  Trial procedure is not intended as a trap for the unaware; it is an evolving, time-tested method toward the goal of a a fair trial.  Filing and serving a lawsuit is not all that one needs to do.  There is a discovery, motions, and subpoena process with their own deadlines.  If yours is a jury trial, there needs to be jury instructions and voir dire preparations.  Lawyers are expensive, but if the problem is worth suing over, it is worth using a lawyer.

Tennessee prosecutors will often pursue a case, even if the alleged victim wishes to drop the case.  This is a common issue in domestic violence cases, in particular, as alleged victims often wish to drop such charges.  However, the State often believes the alleged victim is in need of protection, and will thus move forward despite the victim's lack of cooperation.  An alleged victim in this situation may be able to work with the defendant's attorney to help get the case dismissed, by explaining what happened to the attorney, providing favorable facts about the defendant, and otherwise assisting in the defense.  In some cases, it is advisable for an alleged victim to retain her own attorney to advise about any issues with false statements to the police, about refusal to comply with a subpoena, and about other matters.  It is certainly possible for prosecutors to "drop" or dismiss a case where the alleged victim is uncooperative, but it also by no means automatic.  The best advice here would be to work with the defense attorney, and possibly even with the alleged victim's own attorney, to achieve the best outcome possible for all concerned.  General information in a public forum is no substitute for personal advice from an attorney familiar with the facts of a specific case.

Dear asker,  No attorney will estimate your chance of success at obtaining non-marital assets in a divorce with a paragraph posted on a public forum.  It would be irresponsible to do so.   Your spouse is correct that child support is warranted since you share a child together, but making the case that you need his non-marital assets for support (especially in light of your higher earning potential and your medical degree) is going to be a hard case to prove.    You should also be aware that MDs and Attorneys in NY who divorce their spouses after medical school or law school have had part of the value of their licenses awarded to the other spouse as part of marital asset distribution in NY.  In other words, he might be able to claim that you owe HIM support for carrying you in medical school if that is what happened.  In EITHER case, whether he did or did not, you should sit down with a family law attorney for a full consultation on your options.

This is a great question for a law school exam because in order to answer it, you'll need to have a complete understanding of the equitable distribution statute and the hundreds of relevant cases that interpret that statute, and you'll also need to know all about the evidence code so you'll know what will come in during trial and what will be excluded and don't forget the rules of civil procedure.  In short, in order to answer this question you need to be an experienced, accomplished family law lawyer!!   I would not hazard any guesses or engage in speculation about how this will come out.  I would not dare.  Way too much is at stake for guesses in this case.   You deserve a studied, researched and reasonable analysis based on all the evidence.  When nothing is at stake, it may not be worth hiring a lawyer.  You have thousands at stake, maybe hundreds of thousands of dollars and years to suffer if it's screwed up.  If you don't have a lawyer, you are very, very  foolish.  If you do have a lawyer, ask him all this stuff.  It's very important.

Under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, if a woman is temporarily unable to perform her job due to a medical condition related to pregnancy or childbirth, the employer or other covered entity must treat her in the same way as it treats any other temporarily disabled employee. For example, the employer may have to provide light duty, alternative assignments, disability leave, or unpaid leave to pregnant employees if it does so for other temporarily disabled employees.  If your friend has been treated differently than other temporarily disabled employees she may need to file a complaint with the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

First, "fraud " as defined by the bankruptcy code is a narrower concept than many state definitions as it requires a subjective intent normally also. But first, you must list the debts. Second, as long as you have valid addresses, then you sit and wait and see if an adversary case is filed. Third, if they do, at least you can discharge the other dischargeable debt, whatever it might be. At some point,  I would imagine the $3 Million in debt will be gone as a result of the statute of limitations or the expireration of the enforceability of judgments! Good luck.   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Obviously, the most important thing at this point is for your mother to get the right kind of medical care.  Her health is the priority.  She is lucky to have you helping her.  There may have been malpractice but not enough is known.  It will require an expert review by another doctor, who will review all of her medical records.  Once your mother has stabilized and her long-term health is better known, you should talk to a lawyer in your area who specializes in medical malpractice cases.  One thing you could do now is to have the home nurse write out what she has observed about your mother's condition when she has come to the home. If there is a warrant for your arrest, you would be smart to find out which judge is assigned to your case and appear.  When bail is set for such a low, low amount, it is likely that bail will be waived and you'll be simply ordered back to court on your own recognizance (OR).  If you paid back the amount stolen, a good attorney can ask for dismissal of the case based on a civil compromise under Penal Code section 1377 and 1378.  One requirement of such a motion is showing that the "victim" (your former employer) has been "made whole" (paid for the losses) and is no longer interested in prosecution.  The last element may be difficult to show, but a good attorney can speak to your former employer and perhaps, if unsuccessful, persuade the judge to exercise his discretion to give such a requirement little weight.  The special program that is referred to sounds like a form of diversion where you may "earn a dismissal" by taking a course about theft called a theft-prevention course.  However, it would be probably better for you if the case were simply dismissed and you did not have to hassle with such a class.  Find a good attorney who has experience in a motion for civil compromise.  Good luck.

As a juvenile, he will most likely face adjudication proceedings in a juvenile court.  Sex offender registration requirements are a distinct possibility.  With the nature of such charges, you will need an attorney experienced in fighting both, sexual assault and juvenile proceedings.  By avoiding an adjudication, you may well preserve your child's future.  In addition to having to register, he could be required to attend sex offender counseling and or be required to stay away from other children.  I recommend that you advise your child to NOT TALK TO ANYONE about ANYTHING regarding this.  THAT INCLUDES POLICE, CHILD ADVOCACY CENTER PERSONNEL, DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE, JUDGES, TEACHERS, etc.  He is ONLY to talk to his attorney about this and if anyone tries to interrogate him make sure he understands to tell them that he will not make any statement without his attorney and that he is exercising his right to an attorney.  You might also face child protective services intervention.  He quite possibly will face detention in a juvenile facility.  Get an attorney as quickly as possible.  If he is adjudicated, he may have to attend alternative education classes and no longer be eligible for sports teams and such.  Depending on any restrictions he may be placed under, he may have to be home schooled.  That is why it is so important that you not try to "talk your way out of this" or have him "talk his way out of this" as most likely it will impair his defense.  GET AN ATTORNEY pronto and DON'T make statements, talk about this or even try to call the girl or her family.  DO start trying to save social media posts (Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, etc.).  Print them out/Save them to disk or other media for your attorney.    Good Luck

Fill out the Affidavit in your role as Successor Trustee of her living trust.  Make sure to clearly identify the asset in question, i.e. the name of the life insurance company, and the policy number as well as the death benefit.  Fill in all the blanks.  Sign it in front of Notary.  Make a copy before you mail it, registered mail, to the insurance company.  Call the insurance company after 5 days or so to follow up on receipt of the Affidavit and what their process is.  Keep calling and checking as they document each call, and that will keep them pushing the file forward.  It will also document that you are the only one interested in the policy as further verification of the Affidavit.  Note:  If the check comes back to you in your role as Trustee, i.e. James Madison, Trustee etc., you will need to open a checking account to cash the check.  Make sure the account is non interest bearing to avoid having a Form 1099 issued for interest paid.  Lastly, you may want to fill out the Affidavit in your individual role instead of as a Trustee so that the check will be issued to you directly.

As another attorney has already stated, a couple can agree to file for divorce in any county in Alabama, even if neither of them live there. If you did not agree to the divorce being filed in Jefferson County you could have filed a motion with the court objecting to the venue since neither of you lived in that county and I am *assuming* that you did not live in Jefferson County when you separated. If you did live there when you separated then it would be the proper venue since a divorce can be filed in either the county where you separated or the county where the other party now lives, if they live in Alabama. At this point it is too late to object to the venue, but I am somewhat confused as to why you feel as though you were "cheated" or "screwed" because the divorce was in Jefferson County and not Madison County. If it was an uncontested divorce, as it appears it was, then you agreed to all of the terms (including venue) when you signed the paperwork and I would assume the terms would have been the same whether it was filed in Jefferson or Madison County.

The period on which a collection account can be reported on a consumer credit report is 7.5 years from the date of the default.  That period is known as the period of obsolescence for a collection account.  If the debt is not a collection account, then a debt with derogatory history can only be reported for 7 years from date of the default.  If the credit reporting agency has the correct information from the furnisher, then the debt will no longer be reported after the period of obsolescence expires.  I have a sample letter, linked below, which is specifically to dispute a debt after the debt's period of obsolescence has expired. I suggest you use it, as instructed on my website, to dispute this reporting on your credit reports, after it should no longer be allowed on your credit report.  If the account was only opened in 2008, then it still has several years of reporting before it must be removed.  You may be correct that it is not reported accurately, so use one of my other letters if this or any information in your credit is false or inaccurate.  By: Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)  CONSUMER LAW OFFICE OF ROBERT STEMPLER  A Professional Law Corporation

Typically if they did not contact the police right then, they won't in the future. No, they haven't relinquished any criminal case. The prosecutor's office and not Nordstrom makes that decision in whether or not charges are filed. The most nordstroms could do is file a subsequent police report.   The toll free number they want you to call is to pay a civil demand. If you ignore their invitation to call, you'll likely get a few letters from them asking for hundreds of dollars. The loss prevention folks at the store may have said that you'd have to pay a "fine."    It's not a civil "fine" - it's a civil demand letter. California law allows a merchant to demand up to $500 following a theft incident. These letters are typically sent by the store or a law firm acting on their behalf. They are all bark and no bite.   If you ignore the letter, they have to make a choice - let it go or file a small claims case against you. I have never heard of anyone actually being sued if they ignore the letter. Why don't they do anything? Because lawyers cannot get involved in small claims cases and it isn't worth the store's time to pursue a small claims case over such a minor amount.   There is one law firm in Florida that does nothing but these kind of civil demand letters on behalf of stores. They were quoted in a Wall Street Journal article as sending out over one and a half million letters a year, but they filed less than 10 lawsuits. Not ten percent. Not ten thousand. Ten. The odds are overwhelming that they won't do anything.   If you choose to pay their demand, it just means they won't sue you, but it will have no impact on any criminal prosecution. Paying it won't stop criminal charges from being filed and not paying it won't make a criminal case worse or cause charges to be filed if they weren't going to be in the first place.

You do want a lawyer with divorce expertise.   So you don't want someone who dabbles in it now and then.  Having said that, many divorce attorneys, myself included, do handle some other areas of law.  Nonetheless, probably around half my cases are divorce and domestic cases.  That is the type expertise that you should want and expect.  No attorney can be up on every area of law - that is why, for example, I don't do immigration, tax, patent and products liability cases.  But some areas of law are complimentary to family law (including wills and bankruptcy) and to provide good service to my clients, I cover those complementary fields.   Here is what I would ask a lawyer.  Find out what he charges (since you do have to be able to afford him).  Find out if he has done divorces for a long time as opposed to a couple years or less.   And be sure some of his practice is in the court you will be in.

You need to contact the IRS office that is managing your installment payment plan for 2012 to discuss the problem with them and to see if you can get yourself into a new installment plan that includes both the 2012 and 2013 taxes.  One of the reasons for this is that the unpaid 2013 taxes will most likely be treated as a violation of your installment plan for the 2012 taxes, which means that the IRS could resort to enforced collection again - like levying on your bank accounts - if you don't take steps to get into a new installment plan.  Not dealing with it now and just trying to fly under the radar and keep doing what you've been doing before is not a good idea; it's definitely a bad idea when it comes to the IRS and unpaid taxes.  If you had an attorney help you set up the first plan, I would suggest you contact that attorney to get the 2013 problem taken care of as well.  If you didn't have an attorney, I would strongly urge you to consult at least briefly with a competent tax attorney or CPA in your area to get a better sense of the likelihood that you'll be able to get a new payment plan without too much trouble.
