I too am sorry to hear of your grandmother's condition.  The above advice is all correct--but just to sort of consolidate it a little: 1.  Yes, it is too late for her to sign a power of attorney as she must be of sound mind. 2.  As Mr. Luthmann said, the solution is to seek legal permission to be her guardian.  Mr. Bianchi's suggestion to contact the Senior & Long Term Care office would be a good place to start--at least to learn more about what the Guardianship proceeding is and the proper steps you need to take.   3.  Other sources to find attorneys who may be able to help:  use the "Find a Lawyer" and search for NY attorneys in the Guardianship practice area (as well as Elder Law area) or seek out a legal services organization who may help connect you to an attorney willing to do the work for little or no cost. 4.  Just a few points about the process:  after you file a petition the court will assign a hearing date and ask you to notify all other close family members about your intent (e.g., any living children of your grandmother (your aunts & uncles), any other grandchildren, and any living brothers or sisters of your grandmother) about the hearing (so they may have an opportunity to contest your request).  The court will also appoint a "Court Examiner" who will conduct independent research about your grandmother's condition and render an opinion to the court to be considered at the hearing.  In some cases, the court will appoint an attorney to represent your grandmother.  You will need to provide "clear and convincing evidence" about your grandmother's lack of capabilities to care for herself.  Also--providing she is able, your grandmother is also expected to attend the hearing to speak on her own behalf about whether she wants a guardian.      Fortunately, the fees are low to submit the petition to the court ($20) and, if your grandmother is unable to afford an attorney, the court will appoint one for her (if required) at no charge.  Finally, most of the information I provided was from the link attached below.  Good luck!  It is good to know someone is looking out for your senior relative!

Assuming that the divorce judgment does indeed award a portion of your pension to your ex wife, then you can do two things (I listed them in random order, but it may be easier to start with #2 and if you don't get any information then do #1).   1. Get your divorce file in the court (AZ) and see what QDROs if any were filed. There should be one QDRO for the 401(k) Plan and another one for the pension. I highly doubt that even if the same employer sponsors both the 401(k) and the pension that a single QDRO would be allowed for both plans. Each plan needs its own QDRO. That is how it is usually done.   2. You can call the plan administrator of the pension plan. As a participant you have a right to receive information. Ask them if there was a QDRO filed with respect to your benefits under that pension plan.  Even if the pension plan administrator tells you that there is no QDRO on your "file" with the plan, that does not mean that a QDRO was not filed in court. It may happen that a QDRO was filed in court but then it was never submitted to the plan administrator for approval. It happens sometimes when somebody drops the ball with the QDRO process. Did you put the decimal in the wrong place? NOONE files for less than at least $5000 and some attorneys say $10,000. If in fact higher then other issues exist.   You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts.  If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans.  But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!   Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!   Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.   But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.   Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.   You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later

When a credit card company (or debt buyer) gets a judgment against you, they are allowed to do what is called "post-judgment discovery."  Basically, this means that they can ask you questions to help them locate your assets so that, when permitted, they can take and liquidate the assets to get paid on the judgment.  What shows on your credit report is not determinative.  "Charged Off" just means that you defaulted on the credit card account and remained defaulted for 6 months.  In fact, the account has to be charged off before they can file a lawsuit against you on the debt.  In Texas, judgments CAN be renewed indefinitely.  Judgments are valid for 10 years, and can be renewed for another 10 years after that and then another 10 years after that and so on.  And the judgment can remain on your credit report for as long as it is "active," i.e., not expired.  You can still settle the judgments for reduced amounts.  Or, you could file bankruptcy, if you are eligible based on your income and assets, and discharge the judgments.  We can help you with either one of these things.  We have offices throughout Texas, including San Antonio.   Hope this helps.

You have to be careful how you come to the US because you have the intent to immigrate. So the "easy" routes are closed to you. Don't be tempted by "but they won't know" - they may not at the time - but it might be obvious when it comes to an interview for your resident benefit. It might be worth a conversation with an attorney to see if you had more than LPR status as a child but don't know it. If your bf is resident here, then he can petition for you with an I-129f fiancÌ© visa. When his side of the work is done, you then have an interview at the embassy, and then are given 90 days to come get comfortable and get married - after which time you adjust status. If you have established residence in the UK, your interview will probably be in London, otherwise back in Canada. Your question hints that maybe you want more than a 90 day window - so you are sure you want to get married - and if so, and you have a degree and work in an in-demand field - you could always come to the US on a work visa where they allow "dual-intent" (the intent to immigrate as well as the other reason for the visa). The best way to facilitate things is to make your decisions first as life choices, and then look at how to make these choices work within the immigration rules. Good luck.

Hello neighbor from St. Louis. This is actually a much closer question than my lovely colleagues indicate. Your strategy book is a form of commentary on the videogame and it is really impossible to make that commentary without using at least a few screenshots. So I think you do have a fair use right to use a few screenshots. I think the four factor test under 17 USC 107 leans your way, particularly the key fourth factor, namely any adverse effect of your use on the market for the game. I would think your use would increase the market for the game not decrease it.  The devil is in the details on this. How many screenshots you use and for what purpose and whether you really need screenshots or whether you could serve your purpose without having to use actual screenshots. In order to get a better feel for this need to consult an intellectual property law attorney, preferably one from here in the St. Louis area where you are located, as this question is a close legal question that cannot really be answered in the abstract.

I would file the Proof of claim for all NOW. Attach proof of all parts.   Then, you can still proceed if you desire in civil court. But why? First, the stay of filing bankruptcy does not stop a filing by you in civil court for the establishment or modification of child support. If the court ordered bills are deemed to be "child support" which they likely are, then you can file anytime.   Secondly, why spend the money to go to court now? If you file your proof of claim for all, and list all as priority, then  they may get paid in full in the bankruptcy case. If paid in full, why waste time and possibly attorney fees to file the same in civil court when the same debt can be paid in full in the bankruptcy court. ? I see no reason. The act of obtaining a judgment does not change the "priority" of the other debts owed into anything new....they will still be a priority. ! Good luck and great question.

I agree with the others who have advised you to have your daughter consult with an experienced  probate attorney in the greater Metro-Phoenix area (Maricopa County), preferably when offices will re-open after the Labor Day Weekend. The conduct of your grandson's father should not make you lose sight of your objective--to get competent legal counsel for both your daughter to preserve her rights and, somewhat separately, the best representation for your grandson. A court will be appointing someone to be probably both a legal guardian/representative, as well as a conservator, for your grandson. Your daughter will have to decide whether she is content to have the young man's father appointed by the court, or whether she wishes to seek to be appointed herself, and thereby oppose the likely attempt by the father to be so appointed. Essentially neither will be compensated for their role if appointed by the court, and neither would have access to use any money that may be recovered other than as ordered by the court. A third option, depending on the circumstances, would be for the court to appoint an officer of the trust division of a local bank to act as conservator of any funds recovered on your grandson's behalf.  The entire matter is complicated further by the potential likelihood of your grandson requiring long-term (possibly lifetime) governmental benefits, the value of which could dwarf any potential insurance recovery for his personal injury claim or claims. NO ONE should enter into ANY settlement agreements, arising out of the motorcycle crash, without first evaluating the impact such settlement(s) may have on your grandson's financial qualification for future governmental benefits. I know of a number of well-qualified probate attorneys (I am not one of those), should you care for referrals. I am located in Chandler, Arizona--within Maricopa County. I hope for the best possible lifetime outcome for your grandson, but also for the emotional fortitude, dispassionate action and spirit of cooperation necessary for ALL of your grandson's loved ones, who each in his or her own way are filled with grief, fear and concern at this very stress filled time!

Dear asker,  What you have presented is a vague, unsubstantiated list of nonspecific complaints.  In order for you to determine whether you have a current claim for any legal harms or any ongoing legal harms, you need to organize your statements for an attorney, and make clear what has happened from A-Z.  That is NOT the type of thing we would be able to provide for you in an online forum.  I suggest that you make an appointment with a personal injury attorney, and that when you show up at the attorney's office, you have the following pieces of information ready: 1.  A chronological list of what happened and when it happened; 2.  A list of all of the accounts affected by the alleged identity theft. 3.  A list of all bank transactions or credit card transactions that you attribute to false charges 4.  A list of the dates and times of all medical/psychological treatments related to the alleged legal harms 5.  Any records regarding restraining orders, orders of protection, domestic violence charges, etc.  Once you have organized these items in a clear, and coherent fashion, then an attorney might be able to review your claims with you.

In every county in which I have represented foreclosure defendants at settlement conferences held pursuant to CPLR 3408, I have found that cases are released from the part and allowed to proceed to motions once a loan modification is no longer being pursued. While I agree that this does not comport with the language of the CPLR, the courts have consistently maintained that the purpose of the conferences is to help preserve home ownership through modifications- as a short sale also results in the borrower losing the home, the court does not feel it is an adequate reason to delay a foreclosure. However, I have often found that if a potential short sale has advanced to contract, and is awaiting approval from the Plaintiff bank, a judge will usually stay any sale at auction of the subject premises pending a determination on the pending short sale application.

First, I am terribly sorry for your loss.  Although an autopsy does help in some cases, it is not the end all.  The key is making that link, that causal connection between the neglect and the cause of death. If the death certificate gives a reason or cause of death and is directly linked to the neglect, most of the work is already done, thus an autopsy would only bolster an already perfect storm.  In the scenario you have presented, there is not enough information get a clear understanding of the facts, to give quality personalized advice, however an autopsy is usually needed to rule out other causes of death that the defense may want to use to cast doubt in the mind of the jury.  If the cause of death is known to be a result of the fall and the fall can be linked to neglect rather than an unfortunate, unavoidable accident, then it is far from a disaster to not have one.  There are many wrongful deaths cases we have been involved with and have been successful proving, without autopsy's.  A good quality medical expert will be bale to make the connection Also, you did not mention when this happened so you need to be mindful of the statute of limitations on wrongful death cases in Maryland.  if there is one.

I realize it sounds unfair, but the law allows the plan to go after retirees to recover overpayments. The plan trustees actually have a fiduciary duty to try to recover overpayments and that is why they are asking for the repayment. However, it is common in these situations that if you follow the appeals process indicated in the letter you received about the overpayment, and you prove that you have financial hardship to pay that amount back, the plan will forgive the repayment.   It's just that the plan is caught in between fulfilling their fiduciary duties to correct the mistake and to try to not cause undue hardship to the participants by asking them to repay the overpayment. In the end it will come down to how well you can prove to the plan that it is pretty much impossible for you to pay. If you cannot prove that, it will be hard for the plan to find a reasonable basis to forgive the overpayment.   Good luck. No, it is not correct.  You are entitled to receive overtime any time you work more than 8 hours in any defined workday, or more than 40 hours in any defined workweek.    A word of warning.  If you were to file a lawsuit in superior court today to get overtime earned and not paid, you would only be able to go back 4 years from today.  In other words, every day you delay in filing a lawsuit is costing you overtime pay you would have been entitled to receive but which should have been paid more than four years before the date of filing.  You therefore need to move quickly.  You are losing money every day.  Please note that the only way you can even go back four years is if you file a superior court lawsuit and allege the failure to pay was an unfair business practice.  Otherwise, if you file an administrative complaint with the California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement, also known as the Labor Commissioner's Office, you can only go back three years.  An employer violating this law is likely violating other Labor Code provisions.  You may be losing more money that you know.  Locate and consult with an experienced employment law attorney as soon as possible to explore your facts and determine your options.  I would suggest you look either on this site in the Find a Lawyer section, or go to www.cela.org, the home page for the California Employment Lawyers Association, an organization whose members are dedicated to the representation of employees against their employers.  Most employment attorneys who practice this area of law work on a contingency basis, meaning you can hire an attorney without paying any money until the matter results in a positive outcome for you. Many advance all the costs of the litigation as well. Do not let fear of fees and costs keep you from finding a good attorney.  Good luck to you.

There was a similar question answered today. You might find it helpful. The issue is whether you work in the United States when you are not authorized to. These are just general comments based on a fact pattern. It is not advice to you or anyone The comments should encourage you to go see a business-minded immigration attorney to see whether your plan smells good to her as well. Good luck.

Now that you filed for the N-600 Certificate of Citizenship, I wouldn't worry about renewing your green card.  If you qualify, e.g. if one of your parents became a US citizen with you still under 18, then you are automatically deemed a US citizen and that's why you are filing the N-600 Instead of bothering with filing an I-90 to extend your green card (which might be even denied after collection of the fee, on grounds that you USCIS may already know you are a USC), it is a US passport you should be applying for.  Take all the documentary proof you submitted when filing the N-600 to the passport office: if you qualify for the N-600, the passport office will issue you a US passport much, much faster than your N-600 interview will be scheduled & you'll have the thrill of going to your N-600 interview with a US passport on hand!

As a general matter you can always bring money into the country, provided that it's not the proceeds of some illegal conduct (which shouldn't be a problem based on your description).  If the money is already yours then there is no tax simply for bringing the money into the country.  In fact, if you're moving here to live here permanently, it would be a good idea to move your money to a bank in the US and close your overseas accounts because that way you won't have to file the annual Foreign Bank Account Reports (FBARs) to report your foreign account balances to the IRS.  However, given where you live you would be well-advised to consult with a competent immigration attorney who can give you a better idea of what you need to do.

So many people find themselves in this predicament. Accept the poor service for the duration of the agreement or terminate early and eat the fees...neither is a good option, and realistically, they're often your only options, unless of course you count the provider's inevitable offer to upgrade your service at a reduced monthly fee. The catch with the latter is that those offers almost always entail a new 2 year agreement and the reduced rate is rarely locked in for more than a few months, at the end of which you suddenly find yourself in this same position; because like the first agreement, the new agreement contains a provision enabling the service provider to change the rates without prior notice to you, the consumer.   So, assuming you are not in fact interested in changing your plan and extending your service term, we're back to options 1 and 2 above. Troubleshooting your way through the next 6+ months of shoddy internet service doesn't sound too pleasant, so alas we arrive at your original question: can you terminate service? Short answer is yes, of course you can. BUT, they are going to charge you for it. Pursuant to your agreement, the amount of the termination fee likely depends on the number of months left on your agreement.   Termination fees can be high, VERY HIGH,  particularly with satellite service providers, so the first thing you will want to do is find out how much that fee is going to be. If it's an amount you can find it within yourself to stomach, go ahead and pay it and be done with it. You may be out a few hundred dollars but it may be well worth the money to have avoided the headaches you will encounter trying to battle for a reduction in, or release from, the early termination fee.   Now, should sheer principal or the balance in your checking account require that you fight the fee, there is one approach that might be of use and several tips that can help you along the way. First, a sometimes successful approach: if they want to enforce the early termination terms of the agreement, they, in theory, are going to need to be able to produce the agreement. This often overlooked principal of contracts proves difficult for many a service provider.  Can they show you the document you signed agreeing to a 2 year service contract? It will probably take them 7-10 business days to find out, and if it turns out that they can't produce it, well, now you're in a much better position to contest that "early termination fee." That's one approach you can start with. Now, the tips: 1) If you are going to try and fight the fee, go ahead and see if your provider allows you to freeze or pause your account for a period. If so, you can go ahead and pause service such that you do not have to pay a monthly bill while you battle it out with them. The paused period will not count towards your 2 years, but if you're ultimately successful with the approach discussed above, you'll have saved yourself the money you would have paid for a couple of months of service you didn't want, and the lost time credit won't matter.  2) If you authorized automatic payments, go back and remove that authorization or you will continue to be charged regardless of your grievance status. 3) Document EVERYTHING, write down the date and time of each conversation you have with the provider (there will likely be many), the name of the representative you spoke to, their company id number, and their direct line. These things are important as those handy little "notes" they make concerning your conversations have a funny way of disappearing from the system before you get back to them about the copy of the contract that still hasn't arrived. 4) Ask for everything in writing and request confirmation emails for any action taken on your account. 5) In the event you terminate before working something out, know that rather than bill you, they are going to auto-draft the termination fee from your checking account. Best of luck!

Not necessarily.  As long as you are clearly identified in the estate planning documents.  A reference to "Judy Smith, my daughter born July 9, 1975" should be fine if "Judy Smith" becomes "Judy Jones."  If the reference is not so clear, your parents can add a Codicil to their Wills or Amend their Trusts to change your name. You can certainly file for bankruptcy apart from your husband even though you are married. You are not required to to attend AA.  The Administrative rules says a petitioner may present evidence of a structured support program such as a 12 step program like AA.  That being said the hearing officers love AA because they know what it entails.  They can interrogate or in the case of a review see details that support sobriety.  Hearing officers do not typically do background searches on witnesses, particularly out of state.   I would not worry about this..  They can call witnesses.  This is why the rules require a daytime phone number with community proof letters.  The issue is not your sponsors sobriety but yours.  Relapse is often a part of recovery, you must consider getting a new sponsor for your own sobriety.  Remember this is an under oath statement credibility is not only important it would be a criminal violation to not be straightforward.   Finally, if this is your third attempt it is safe to say you need expert help at this point.  You could have had your license by now, with a lawyer.  There is so much more to this and we help out of state drivers all the time.   Fees for lawyers in this area start as low as $500, at least at my office and a we have successfully represented clients in this practice area for twenty plus years.  Your obviously missing an important part of the puzzle.  Also the review does not have to be the final word you can appeal a hearing officers decision to the circuit court.

If you walked away from the job, or if you told your employer that you no longer were going to work there, you quit.  If you did neither, and the employer stopped scheduling you to work, or told you that you were fired, you were terminated.  There are situations in some areas of employment law, where you can quit and it would still be considered a termination.  Constructive discharge is where the employee quit under such conditions that no reasonable employee could tolerate them.    Your former employer has no duty to inform you if you quit or were fired.  However, it can tell you how it has recorded your departure if it wishes to do so.  A sure fire way to get a position out of your employer is to file for unemployment benefits.  The employer will likely take a position after you apply, and you will know if the employer believes you voluntarily quit or were terminated.  Good luck to you.

Nothing wrong with such provisions per se.  Any addendum will require additional consideration as would any contract or modification, and there may be issues as to what or how much evidence is adequate to trigger forfeiture but that goes to the content of the provisions rather than its enforceability per se.  I doubt a court would allow an automatic complete forfeiture without proof of the amount of actual damages and a clause such as "evidence of smoking will result..." is poor draftsmanship in my opinion.  Smoking is either allowed or it is not and any attempt by you to penalize a tenant for doing so will presumably require evidence but it is the smoking that triggers the penalty, not the procurement of evidence.  You should, of course, just incorporate all this into the original lease you have new tenants sign.  Good luck.  Greg Abbott  Consumer Law Northwest  6635 N. Baltimore Ave., #254  Portland, OR 97203  503-283-4568  gregabbott@consumerlawnorthwest.com  "Practicing Landlord-Tenant Law in Oregon for Over 20 Years".

A motion to set aside a judgment must be brought within three years of the entry of the judgment complained of; a judgment void for lack of personal or subject-matter jurisdiction may be attacked at any time.   The Supreme Court has expressly limited judgments  void on their face under subsection (a) to "those judgments which lack either personal or subject matter jurisdiction."  If you were not properly served, then the Court would not have personal jurisdiction over you, unless you made a general appearance by showing up in Court and litigating the case, for example. I believe your question has been thoroughly answered very well by the responding attorneys;, however, there is one more factor that should be considered.  I know Attorney Patrick Mahaney very well and hold great respect (and agree) in  his opinion, but there is an added element that should be considered when deciding on whether or not to use a public defender.  Generally, the public defender has a very good relationship with the prosecutor and the Judge simply because they spend so much time together in the courtroom.  A public defender will know how the Judge thinks and feels about various offenses or defendant's criminal records (repeat offenders).  I have been a public defender and now primarily handle cases where I have been privately retained.  I would say use your instinct and gut feelings concerning the demeanor exhibited by the attorney when discussing the case.  Is he/she listening, making eye contact,  communicating with you in a genuine attentive state regarding your specific case.  If you get a "comfortable feeling" about the attorney, he or she will most likely be able to achieve an optimal outcome for you or your family member using his ability and relationships in that particular court.  During my nearly 20 years of practice, I have many times convinced perspective clients to stay with their appointed lawyer rather than take a fee, if I knew that appointed lawyer to be competent and effective in the courtroom.  I hope this helps.  If you aren't comfortable or feel "too rushed", by all means hire an attorney that you have confidence in.  Trey Norman Trey@treynorman.com

You ask an interesting, but complicated and fact intensive question.  Your project may qualify as a "transformative use." Your project may qualify as a "parody." Your project may qualify as a "commentary." However, there are not enough facts presented to allow a determination to be made.   The problem with most of the situations where you use someone else's work and create a derivative work is that the copyright infringement determinations are almost always "close calls" and very subjective. So, the question to ask yourself is whether or not you are willing to take a chance and spend the time/money/energy necessary to create and sell your video, knowing that you could be sued for copyright infringement?  While your use may qualify as "fair use" you probably won't know until you get to litigate as a defendant in federal court.  I've included a link that you may find useful.  My recommendation is that you get with an attorney who understands copyright law, "fair use," and "transformative use" prior to embarking on this project.

There are many ways in which a decedent's family can learn about assets that were owned by the decedent.  One way is for an executor or administrator to request a copy of the person's most recent income tax return -- that will provide a wealth of information (although, in a spirit of full disclosure, I should tell you that the IRS is not usually terribly fast in providing the tax return).  If you know the name of the decedent's accountant, that should speed things up.  Other ways are pretty much common sense, such as going through the decedent's mail; most assets will leave "traces" every month or every quarter.   Most important, make sure that you retain an attorney experienced in estate matters.  Good luck to you.

A key fact which you left out is whether or not the new agreement of 4 weeks in the summer, 2 weeks at a time, is in writing or just a verbal agreement.  It is easier to enforce a written agreement even if it has not been made into a court order.  Courts enforce written agreements all the time because Courts understand there is a need for great flexibility in custody and visitation matters.  Or perhaps you have a verbal agreement, but you have text messages and emails which specify the terms of this verbal agreement.  This would be another way to prove you have such an agreement.  In any event, file for a modification of custody or visitation, or both, present your evidence, and at court be ready to testify to the truth.  I highly recommend you consult with an attorney to make sure you do all of this the right way the first time, because you might only get one shot at this.  I recommend you not file for Contempt if there are no Court Orders that have been violated.  Although it is true that a Contempt action will get you in court together with the other party, if there are no Court Orders being violated here, this might make you look foolish, and could give the other party incentive to paint you in a very negative light.  On the other hand, if the other party is clearly violating a Court Order, then a Contempt of Court proceeding could be quite effective.

Apparently, based on your description of the events, proper CPLR procedure to substitute the new plaintiff was not followed. Moreover, you say that the plaintiff is not registered in NY. In order for a foreign corporation doing business in New York to maintain any action or special proceeding in this state it must obtain a certificate of authority to do so and pay all state fees and taxes [see Business Corporations Law å¤1301 & å¤1312(a)]. The failure of a foreign corporation doing business in New York to register precludes that entity from "maintaining" an action or special proceeding until such authority is obtained [BCL å¤1312(a)]. As one of attorneys has said (Mr. Rothstein) you should file a motion to reargue. The filing of a motion to reargue does not stay the time you have to appeal. I agree with my colleague and would add that just because an attorney was suspended does not automatically mean you have a viable malpractice case. I hope this helps.

The house is yours until it is not yours.   That means you would have to transfer it to someone else (e.g. sale, DIL) or have it taken from you (e.g. foreclosure). The good news is that you get to live their rent/payment free until at least foreclosure occurs.   You might take this time to save up money as a down payment for a new home. There is no actual minimum investment required by law but there are other requirements that need to be satisfied. For example, the business cannot be set up just to provide support for you and your family, it can't be a marginal business. From the cases I've dealt with, although no minimum investment is required, you have to make a substantial investment, probably around $100,000, my figure, which can include equipment, materials, inventory, etc., and the less money you invest, the more you are expected to be either the sole owner of the business or a substantial part of it.  Your country has to be on the Treaty Country list, which Canada is for either E-1 or E-2. This is somewhat complicated and you should discuss it with an immigration attorney.

When your husband was arrested the first time he wasn't convicted of the crime. An arrest may have little or no immigration effect. A conviction can have significant immigration consequences. Once he was convicted ICE may have picked him up again because the conviction now has a direct consequence on his status and could make him subject to being held with no bond. You need an immigration attorney who is very skilled in removal defense.

Its an old, sleazy lawyer trick. Sleazy lawyers will treat pro se litigants with a grain of respect at best.  So they serve you with documents that they know they have to serve you with, because if you don't get them you will know they didn't send it.  They file a certificate or proof of service that says they served you, but didn't.  What you do to correct this is you make arrangements for either electronic access to your docket and check it every other day, or you make routine trips to the clerk's office and check the file.  Carefully make a list of all documents that you received and a list of all documents the court docket says were served on you, and then note the ones you did not receive.  Then you file a motion with the court, requesting that the opposing attorney be sanctioned for intentionally refusing to serve you with court papers as required under the rules and by law.  You can also file a bar complaint.  Another way is to associate with outside counsel, maybe a lawyer who will file a request for notices.  I am sorry to say but some lawyers feel they have to cheat to win; and this can happen.

As a car accident lawyer, I'm typically on the other side of this type of case so while I wont give you advice, I will tell you what I would do for the boy's family.  The child's family has a 'wrongful death' action against you and I would expect you to turn their claim over to your car insurance company.  If covered, the insurance company will investigate the claim, defend you, and seek to protect you by attempting to settle the claim.  If settled, the claim will be resolved by a 'release' whereby once the settlement is concluded, your assets are no longer exposed for collection including your ERISA.  However, because the claim against you is a large one, I would investigate the ability to collect against you in addition to your auto insurance policy because there are circumstances where the policy limit of insurance is insufficient but the collection of additional funds over the policy is economically viable.  I would also see if you have additional protections available such as taking the lid off of your policy or seeking the addition of Cumis counsel.  If you had collectible assets in excess of your policy, I would likely seek a stipulated judgment from you that required you to make payments over time and in excess of your policy limit in order to satisfy the terms of the stipulated judgment.  If convicted, I would also look into seeking restitution from you through the criminal process.  If a settlement is not achieved and the wrongful death action results in a judgment against you, first indemnification would become payable from your insurer without your release.  Then your assets would be exposed to collection proceedings.  In order to perform collection, you could be brought back into court for a judgment debtor's examination wherein you would have to divulge all of your assets, holdings, interest, and wages.  With this information, I would seek writs to collect and garnish your assets and wages, including your ERISA holdings.  Upon the service of the writ or levy against your ERISA account, you could seek court intervention to prevent the execution of the writ and levy.  At that time, a judge would determine if your ERISA is safe.  ERISA affords statutory protection against this type of collection and you are likely protected so long as the account qualifies as a ERISA Plan account.  However, there are exceptions as the ERISA protections are not iron clad.  See: http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/can-judgment-creditors-go-after-my-retirement-accounts.html Nonetheless, there would remain exposure for collection.  Just because the ERISA account cannot be pierced by a CA writ does not mean the res is not exposed.  Once you withdraw money from the ERISA account and place it outside of the ERISA account it is exposed to collection and attachment. Aside from your question, you mention that the boy was in the middle of the street at 9pm.  In the wrongful death action, you have the same comparative fault defenses that you would have in a motor vehicle negligence action.  Your auto insured should be investigating this portion of the loss as party of their duty to investigate.

You have received very good answers already. I will only try to shed some light on actually getting your portion, because I only do work related to the division of retirement assets during a divorce.   1. When a portion of a spouse's pension is given to the other spouse during a divorce, a document known as a QDRO (qualified domestic relations order) will need to be prepared. For the preparation of a QDRO on your behalf, or to review a QDRO that the opposing party may have prepared, I will strongly encourage you to find a QDRO attorney to do it. Preparing these documents for the division of retirement assets in a divorce has to do more with retirement plan law than family law. A divorce attorney will be great to deal with bringing him back to court to force him to pay you the past installments (and you should hire one in your area), but when it comes to the enforcement of the division of a retirement asset, a QDRO attorney with experience working with retirement plans could be a better option for you.   2. Each party is at risk of losing a lot of benefits ($$$) when the QDRO is not properly written. Little words make big differences in the world of QDROs. Also, a lot could be lost if the QDRO is not drafted promptly within a reasonable time after the divorce.  3. You may need a local divorce attorney in the city where the divorce takes place to help you with going to court and represent you on the issues related to the divorce. BUT, for anything that has to do with writing or reviewing a QDRO, I would strongly encourage you to find an attorney, with experience in, and knowledge of, retirement plans and high sophistication with QDROs to do the actual preparation of the QDRO on your behalf (or to review a QDRO prepared by opposing party).   4. You don‰Ûªt need a local QDRO attorney because most likely federal law regulates the retirement plan to which the QDRO applies so any QDRO attorney in the country can help you. There are a few well-qualified QDRO attorneys across the country. Focus on finding a QDRO attorney, not just a family lawyer to do the actual preparation (or review) of the QDRO. Do your research before hiring.   5. QDROs are NOT neutral documents. You need your own QDRO attorney to draft or review the QDRO prepared by the opposing party‰Ûªs attorney. You need somebody who will look after your interests. I would be wary of anybody offering to prepare a QDRO for you and the other party, "representing" you both simultaneously.   6. Hiring a QDRO attorney in addition to your divorce attorney does not necessarily mean it will cost you more. QDRO attorneys usually charge a flat fee. The cost is worth it if you hire somebody who is a QDRO attorney with background on retirement plans. The flat fee cost is outweighed by the fact that your benefits will not be lost.   7. The Plan administrator may easily have approved a QDRO that complies with legal requirements regardless of whether the QDRO actually protects your interests. The Plan approval of a QDRO does not mean that the QDRO was properly drafted for your benefit. It only means the QDRO meets a few basic requirements mandated by law.   8. Also see the articles in the link below about the RISKS of using Model QDROs.  Please let me know if this has been helpful to you by clicking the "Mark as Helpful" button at the bottom of this answer. Or choose a "best answer" if you wish. This does not take long and it would mean a lot to me.   * I am not your lawyer until you and I have signed an Engagement Letter. This and other similar posts by me on the Internet are for informational purposes only. They are not legal advice. Nothing I post online should be taken as legal advice for any individual case or situation. This answer is not intended to create, and receipt or viewing of it does not constitute, an attorney-client relationship. While I do provide my best effort to be accurate, I do not guarantee accuracy given the general nature of these posts, answers and comments.

I'll answer your second question first;  Yes, there is another way, other than garnishment, to collect on your judgment. You can execute on the judgment. This essentially means the sheriff goes out and siezes property or accounts owned by the judgment debtor (and, if necessary, sells them) until an amount sufficient to satisfy the judgment is collected. You'll need to make sure that the judgment is "docketed" in each county where the judgment debtor owns any property.  A second way to "collect," in a manner of speaking, is that you can wait. Once you docket the judgment in the county it serves as a lien against all property (located in that county) in which the judgment debtor has an interest. So, for example, if you know the judgment creditor owned some land that he would be likely to sell, you can docket your judgment and wait. When he tries to sell your lien of judgment will need to be paid off in order to give clean title to the purchaser. Your judgment is a valid lien against property for 10 years (Why would someone decide to wait so long? Post-judgment interest  at 10% beats the return on keeping it in a savings account.) There are some exceptions to what property can be executed on.   As to your first question:  The previous answer as to how to go about the Garnishment was correct. You're going to want to get in touch with an attorney. This is an area with technical requirements and where mistakes can be costly. If you'd like, I can help you out with this or put you in touch with a good friend of mine who does a ton of this type of work.

I appreciate the other attorneys' concerns. However, the actual question has not been answered. What if the questioner is in a jurisdiction where euthanasia is legal, for example, has a terminal illness, and wants to work with an attorney to set things in order? Or if the questioner is asking because someone else in his or or family had already committed suicide, and they want to know if they can get information from the decedent's attorney?   I will answer the actual questions posed.  Anyone can get legal help. Lawyers in PA have to do their best to maintain a normal attorney-client relationship. Everything discussed between the lawyer and the client would generally be confidential and/or privileged if there is nothing else which placed it in jeopardy (e.g. if the discussions between the client and the lawyer were to further some criminal scheme like bring drugs to jail, etc.). There is also no rule which requires a lawyer to reveal anything about a client, except in very limited circumstances like the client lying to a judge. However, a lawyer can choose (and also choose not to) reveal things which he believes might prevent "certain death or substantial bodily harm", the client from committing a crime, etc.  However, if the case were that a client walked into a lawyer's office and said I want to commit suicide, make me an estate plan, this would be a very tough scenario in reality. Very few lawyers will say, "Oh, sure, sign here, pay the retainer, give me time before you go through with your plan."  Because there is an ethical requirement for a lawyer to make sure they represent the client's interests, if it were me, off the top of my head, I would be very cautious and see that interests other than estate planning -- namely, the life of the client -- is first and foremost protected.  Hope this helps. If you like my answer, please vote it as "best answer".

I would tend to agree with my colleagues here.  Permitting can be an extremely fact intensive issue in litigation.  Generally, in Florida, if the contract required the contractor to pull a permit and he or she failed to do so, you would have a claim for breach of contract, and would of course have to establish damages stemming from the breach.   If the contract is silent, the work either requires a permit or it does not.  If the work required a permit, the inquiry shifts to whether the contractor substantially completed his or her work, and, if so, they may still be entitled to the reasonable value of work performed minus any damages you suffered due to the permitting issue.  The purpose of laying all of this out for you is to give you an idea what a lawsuit would entail, and that's why the best case scenario for you is to avoid a lawsuit.  I would highly recommend retaining a construction attorney to prepare a demand letter to the contractor to pull the necessary permits and finish the job.  Have you paid in full?  In the event the contractor refuses, you can hire another contractor to finish the job and go after the prior contractor for damages which would be, at a minimum, the amounts you paid beyond the original contract price.  One way or another, as mentioned above, the failure to pull a permit can result in some issues with selling the house in the event the City fines you for non-compliance or requires the permit and additional work before signing off on the job.  I am happy to answer any other questions you may have.  Good luck.

If the letter is typewritten, and the party's signature is witnessed by 2 witnesses, and the letter states the party's wishes about estate distribution, and there is no quesiotn about the party's capacity to make a will, or that the signature is in that the party's, then that letter is a "testamantary" document, i.e., a will.  If the letter is all handwritten ("holographic"), signed and dated by the party, and expresses wishes about estate distribution, then that letter is admissible as a will even without witnesses.

Non-probate assets are not generally addressed in a Will, since the Will has no power over such assets.  For example, if there is an IRA designating decedent's wife to be the beneficiary, but decedent's Will says the IRA goes to decedent's brother, wife will get the IRA, and the provision in the Will will be ignored.  So there is not reason to mention non-probate assets (except for tangible personal property) in a Will.  Non-probate assets do not become a part of the residuary estate for distribution purposes.  If the Will specifies that all estate and inheritance tax and estate-related expenses be paid by the residuary estate, the non-probate assets would not be responsible for contribution to those taxes and expenses unless the residuary estate was inadequate to cover those expenses.  If the beneficiary of a non-probate asset predeceases the decedent, it would fall back into the residuary estate unless there was a backup beneficiary designated (for instance, on a life insurance policy).  Please note, however, that if a non-probate beneficiary survives the decedent, but dies before the non-probate beneficiary receives the non-probate asset, the asset would then become a part of the Beneficiary's residuary estate.

The client should always be there at a law and motion hearing. If he/she is making a request and is absent, he risks having his request dropped from calendar. If he/she is opposing a request and absent then the risk is an adverse ruling.  In family law, it really depends on the judge and the county. Some are more liberal or strict then others. It also depends on your attorney or yourself if you are self-represented to hold the offending party accountable. They are after all ignoring a court order to be present. Regardless of the county, most judges will view an unexcused absence unfavorably and will consider requests for sanctions.

Generally, you can file a Application and Order of Wage Assignment for child support any time after the support order is made.  If you are concerned, you can file a motion for determination of arrears and ask for wage assignment in that motion too--but you will still need to submit your Child Support Case Registry form and issue Wage Assignment forms to the paying parent/spouse's employer.  The only limitation might be that if the wage assignment was stayed in the original orders, you might have to file a motion to get the stay vacated and then issue the wage assignment.   You can file any of these documents with the court via U.S. mail (with an extra copy to conform and a self-addressed, stamped envelope).  You can serve them on the employer and employee via U.S. mail too.  Otherwise, you can retain counsel to help you and they can get the paperwork filed and served or contact and hire a local process server to get your paperwork filed for you--they can generally use faxed copies for filing.  Some courts allow fax or email filings directly, but you will need to check with the court where your case is to find out their rules and restrictions.    As another attorney indicated in their answer, you can also go through the Department of Child Support Services (DCSS).  They were created and designed to help collect child support payments and have even more powers regarding collection efforts than the family court (because they can revoke driver's licenses and seize IRS tax refunds before the payments are issued and revoke passports).  In most cases, DCSS does not charge filing fees for collection efforts either.  So saving money is helpful.    Your case generally remains where it was opened.  If the supported child and both parents have all left the jurisdiction where the matter was initially filed, you can ask the court to change venue and move the case to another state where jurisdiction requirements are satisfied.  DCSS has the ability to connect to other DCSS courts throughout the U.S. if parties have moved and enforcement is complicated by multiple-relocations.    Hope this extra info helps a little.  Good luck.

It is not possible to know whether there has been a deviation in the standard of care which was a substantial factor in your injuries based on your post.  Generally medical malpractice attorneys will look at the abdominal surgeries and see whether there were any surgical techniques or procedures that were done below the standard of care.  This could result in a bowel injury , from a trocar or mono-polar cautery, or from loss of blood supply causing ischemia.  It is also possible that the surgical technique was impeccable and above the standard of care and that partial or full bowel obstruction developed simply as a consequence of the underlying condition or the extensive abdominal surgeries in the first place.   The second area of review will be whether post operative care was appropriate or whether there were delays in recognizing a bowel obstruction which led to necrosis (death) of the bowel at a particular area requiring a resection of bowel and colostomy.  Again, this requires a detailed review of the entire medical chart including nurses notes, intake and output records, blood culture results, review of serial abdominal imaging, the abdominal physical exam, the progress notes, and many other factors.  Colostomies under the best of circumstances are difficult and it sounds like your placement may have been less than optimal which doesn't mean there was malpractice, it could mean that they were doing the best with what they had.  Another issue will be whether a colostomy was necessary from the get go because of the underlying condition or whether a delay made the colostomy necessary.  Again the variables are endless and only an attorney with a full command of the medical records and a full statement of all relevant facts will be able to evaluate this for you.  I hope that you can get your colostomy reversed and in a timely fashion and that you heal well.

Without an attorney handling this for you, it's guesswork.  Generally, the rules that apply to how an award or settlement is arrived at in workers' compensation is that the arbitrator must take into account several factors, among them: your age, job description, medical treatment, opinions of medical providers or experts, AMA rating (if any), and permanent restrictions (if any).  The settlement won't be approved unless the arbitrator reviews the medical and it jibes with the settlement.  So if you had a SLAP tear and they settled it for 1% of a person as a whole, hopefully the arbitrator would find that extremely low and not approve it.  Likewise, if the rate calculated is not aligning with the wage rate, then they will flag that too.  Hard to know what's fair.  Fair is what you get offered and what you can prove. I have been an appellate attorney in Michigan for 25 years.  A probate appeal in the Michigan Court of Appeals normally takes approximately 18 months from the time the claim of appeal is filed.   This time period can be expedited by motion if there is a good reason.  Once the Court of Appeals makes its decision, the parties have an option to seek leave to appeal in the Michigan Supreme Court.  This can typically take an additional 12 - 18 months.  There are several extremely good, very experienced attorneys in Michigan who, like me, do nothing but appeals.  I strongly recommend that you talk to some of them so that you can determine how to best protect your interests on appeal.

Read your lease.  If your lease provides for 'pet rent' that is based on the number of animals then you can charge the pet rent against the security deposit.  If, on the other hand, your lease provides for a pet deposit then I do not believe you can charge a deposit against the security deposit unless you can establish actual damages.  You do have the option to post a 3 day notice requiring the cats to be immediately removed from the property.  However, you would then have to evict which will take you longer than 8/1 to complete.
If you have a lease you owe the balance of the lease unless the landlord lets you out, which you should get in writing.

You should do your best to get an attorney. Since this is your first offense, an attorney may be able to negotiate a diversion program with the prosecutor and the court. In diversion programs the defendant is required to complete a period of probation with various conditions such as completing community service and theft deterrent programs, finishing school and staying out of trouble. If you successfully complete the program, the charges are dismissed.  If you are adjudicated delinquent, the record will not automatically disappear when you turn 18. Juvenile records for all but the most serious crimes can be sealed and later expunged (destroyed). The record can be sealed 6 months after you complete whatever punishment the court imposes and expunged 5 years after it is sealed. You will want an attorney to verify this is done, if you are adjudicated delinquent.   In cases like yours, the most common punishment is probation, but you should understand that petty theft is a first degree misdemeanor and the maximum possible punishment is up to 90 days confinement in a detention facility. The maximum fine is $250. Court costs are generally a few hundred too.   As far as picking a lawyer. Call a few for consultations. Most of us will do a free consultation. Choose one you like, one you feel comfortable talking with and who is responsive to your questions.

Dear Buffalo Home Owner:  The police come and yell at you every time because until they investigate the complaint of an open burning, they cannot determine that again, you are preparing food at your fire pit. It is your right and privilege to cook outside with fire, and the duty of the police to respond to a complaint and investigate. You are caught in a cycle with a foreseeable outcome, since you know every time you cook s'mores over a fire, your neighbor will complain and the police will show up.  New York State does not have a legal civil lawsuit based on harassment. It would seem you cannot even complain to the police about the neighbor because you are burning outside. Just because the conduct is not a violation does not mean the police should ignore the neighbor's calls. You should realize that the police may become feel caught up in a neighbor vendetta and that you know exactly what will occur when you exercise your right to burn by making some s'mores. Each time the officers are dispatched to your home, they must hit the road and of course, devote time to you.  If your neighbor does not tell the other neighbors you are a drug dealer, the neighbor has not defamed you.

Code of Civil Procedure sections 435-437 govern your situation.  CCP 436 authorizes the court, upon a motion brought pursuant to CCP 435, to strike out any irrelevant, false or improper matter inserted in "any pleading."  Generally, an answer is a pleading.  Specifically, CCP section 435 defines "pleading" as "a demurrer, ANSWER, complaint or cross-complaint.  Pursuant to CCP 435(b) and Rule 3.1322 of the California Rules of Court , you have 10 days from the date of service of an answer to file a responsive pleading such as a demurrer or a motion to strike.

Property division in a divorce is left to the discretion of a judge and based on the principles of fairness and equity. Once a gift is received, such as the house in this case, it becomes marital property subject to division by a judge. Just like you, your husband has a unique interest in the home, meaning he will get some value out of it in a divorce. Given his faults, if proven at trial, you have a greater possibility than not of keeping the home, if you so request, with some reasonable payout, or equity payout, to him. Regarding the children, supervised visitation is likely, if sufficient evidence of drug use and physical abuse is presented at trial. The trial judge will look closely to the children's best interest and how to best protect them and ensure they are safe. Drug addiction and/or physical abuse are classic facts to request supervised and limited visitation until such time as he keeps clean, rehabilitates and can prove his is fit to take care of the children without a threat to the wellbeing of the children.

Your problem is very simple; one of the simplest issues that I regularly run into in my practice (which focuses on cross-border business and tax law from a global perspective).   This general analysis assumes that the freelancer will indeed be providing independent personal services solely from France (and never from US) as a non-US person who is a French contractor when he returns to France:  When the freelancer is back in France, freelancer should tell the US boss that freelancer will be a foreign contractor performing services from France. The US company must FIRST enter into an agreement with the freelancer as a French contractor that complies with French labor law. My firm works with a top-notch French labor lawyer; we have assisted many US companies with drafting and executing the French contract at a VERY reasonable rate. This will protect the US employer from French labor law risk and corporate tax law risk, which will be very important for the US employer! A very small price to pay to comply with French corporate, employment, and tax laws!  SECOND, after executing that agreement, the freelancer should tell the employer that the US employer needs to get a W-8BEN from the freelancer. The freelancer just fills out name and address and the employer keeps this on file. This proves that the freelancer is not a US person. The employer does not need to file it with the IRS; the employer should however keep it on file in the event of an audit. THIRD, the freelancer should also prepare and sign a statement that the freelancer will perform all work from OUTSIDE the US.   With that relationship in place, the boss will compensate the freelancer as a foreign contractor, non-US person, performing work from outside the US. In that situation, the employer will not need to make any withholdings to the IRS, nor will the freelancer owe any US taxes on the compensation. The non-US freelancer will of course owe individual income taxes to the French tax authority.   That's it. Too easy!

If it is just you or a couple of yous or a few of yous then you should be good.  If you want to know for sure what might happen, just call the police department and ask them before you go just to get their take on it.  It doesn't matter if they are right or wrong as their being right or wrong would only be tested by a judge later on. If you want to make a point and be sure that the police is not going to try to prevent you from picketing, call them first.

If you have agreed to a child support increase and signed the court order, you should start paying the increase regardless of when the paperwork is filed.  If you wait until the paperwork is signed by the court to send the increased amount, you will be in arrears and that can cause a mess if you have a child support case open. You will receive letter stating you are behind, they can try to take more out of your pay check, and report on your credit. I would be contacting you attorney to find out status of why the paperwork is not filed.  If the paperwork is not filed, the case could be dismissed by the court and then at that point you would have overpaid your child support.  It is better to be overpaid then behind.

I live and work in Los Angeles and deal with accidents like yours all the time, so I am happy to answer your question. The answer to your question is your gut instinct is right in that you are not certain about your rights. Premises liability cases are always TOUGH.  They are KNOWN for not settling cases.  Moreover, I've handled cases against Walgreens and I already see some wholes in your case.  One big thing that jumped to my mind is that the parking lot is made of concrete which makes it tough to "slip" regardless of what substance is on the concrete.  More facts are needed to come to a final conclusion, but make no doubt about it, you should definitely hire a lawyer.   At our firm we always refer people to all kinds of doctors and chiropractor and our clients never pay anything upfront, not even a copay. The doctors are willing to do this because an attorney is on board. You are entitled to have your property damage, medical bills and future medical expenses PAID FOR BY THE OTHER PARTY'S INSURANCE. The attorney you hire will handle the claims process from start to finish. I've handled cases and referred clients to great doctors in the Los Angeles, CA area.   But you are going to need to see a specliast to even get a shot at getting future medical treatment from the Defenedant. Moreover it sounds like the accident is completely the other persons fault so you don't want this case to become a difficult one because of lack of inattention. The insurance company will make you believe that your case is worth very little... Regarding pain and suffering, you need to speak to an experienced attorney that can strategize your case. Just because you were in an accident doesn't mean you have pain and suffering, at least thats what the insurance companies think. Make no doubt about it you have a great case, but you need help from a professional. You are entitled to your medical bills being covered as well.   Do you feel that you are at the same medical condition that you were before the accident? As a basic premise I wouldn't handle your claim by yourself. The attorney you hired can likely refer you to a doctor, if you ask for one, who will see you with no upfront payment! I've done this many times to help my clients out. You should not wait a single day to hire a lawyer, we will advise you on the strategy of your case. There is no upfront cost to hire an attorney.   With a case like yours it seems like you have some good facts in order to get a high settlement, but your case definitely needs to be developed further to corroborate your story. The most important thing when building your case are: liability (were you at fault); how bad are your injuries to your body. A lot of these things sound like they are not complete yet in your case so its something that is worth hiring an attorney for in order to get a sense of whether you have a case and what the strategy would be for you to build a strong case! I've handled cases and/or spoken to clients in the Los Angeles, CA area.   Its very possible that your case is worth more than the $$$ that the insurance company will offer you by yourself. Make your life easier and call an attorney today, you won't regret it.

I agree with Ms. Lowry. Have an attorney in your area review the order. Without knowing the exact terms of your order it is difficult to say whether the child has to go with his father. In addition, sometimes in a situation like this, the answer is a matter of subjective opinion. Usually, no - a parent is not allowed to flip flop dates. If so, then the other parent would effectively never be able to make plans. However, it would be better to avoid any allegations that you denied him possession. If the issue was before the Court, the Court may consider (1) the reasons if any he gave for changing the visitation dates multiple times, (2) when you made plans that now conflict with his newly elected dates, (3) whether his dates fall within July which is part of the default period in a Standard Possession Order, and (4) what are your plans with your son.

You said the landlord did not sign "at the time", did the landlord sign afterwards sometime? It's important to know if you have an enforceable lease.  If there is no signature, you are likely leasing month-to-month. You can give notice to the landlord 15 days in advance of your next rent due date that you will be leaving.  If there is a signature, there is an enforceable lease agreement. If you leave it is possible that the landlord could pursue the back rent.  My recommendation is to speak with your landlord about cancelling the lease. Explain the circumstances. Chances are the landlord will just let it go.

This is a gift to you. The only person taxed on gifts - is the person making the gift (your grandmother). However, she has a lifetime exemption amount of $5.3M. If she has made other gifts exceeding that amount or if this gift to you will cause her to breach that threshold then, she will be taxed on the excess. But you, my friend, are safe. Alternatively, if she leaves you the house in her will, and you get it upon her passing, then you will get a stepped up basis, which means the deemed cost to you will be the fair market value on the date of death. That means that if you choose to sell the home at a later point in time, your gain will be [sale price] - [fair market value of the property on the date of death]. If she deeds it to you while alive, then for the purpose of a later sale, your deemed cost (basis) will be whatever she paid for it. And assuming she bought it a long time ago, you will have a large gain to recognize. So these are some of the things to think about. Obviously these are general statements. The precise solution will require exploring the details. Contact me if you want a more precise answer tuned to your exact facts. Thanks. If it helps you to resolve an issue that's great but do not rely on it as legal advice because it is not based on the facts in your case and it is not based on any specific legal research. Answering this question creates no relationship between the writer and reader of the writing. I am not your attorney now, nor have I been on the past.)

Mr. Rothrock is correct. Most cases in Superior Court are ordered to mediation. A Judge only reviews a case if the case is scheduled for a hearing on a pending Motion or at trial. There is no "screening" process. You would be pretty upset if a Judge "screened" your case and threw it out without allowing you the opportunity to develop more evidence and present your case, wouldn't you? The system allows both parties time to conduct discovery. Getting the first 30 day extension of time to answer written discovery is standard. All either party has to do is file a Motion for extension of time with the Clerk before the initial 30 day period expires and the Clerk will grant that motion. I also agree that you should have an attorney look over your pleadings and the opposing party's pleadings just to make sure everything looks proper.

Your employer can suspended if you were treated equally with other employees. It does not matter whether you are working full-time or part-time. However, your employer cannot discriminate against you because you have a disability or are 64 years of age. Your employer must also accommodate you due to your disability. If you need further assistance you should contact an employment lawyer in your area.

Your nephew cannot attend a public high school on F-1 student visa. An F-1 student cannot attend a public secondary school unless (1) he attends the secondary school for a period not in excess of 12 months and (2) demonstrates that he reimburses the school board the full, unsubsidized per capita cost of the education. Here is a link to further info on Foreign Students in Public Schools.

My first question is "how long ago did your ex's attorney take on the QDRO?"  My second question is:  "did your ex's attorney hire out the drafting of the QDRO or is he/she doing it him/herself?"   If it's been in the ex's attorney's hands for more than three months, I would file a motion to compel or simply do the QDRO myself.  You would have to sign the QDRO before it goes to the court for approval.  The process is this:  Attorney contacts retirement administrator's attorneys and gets their requirements; drafts QDRO and sends to your attorney and administrator's attorneys for review.  You should get a copy of the draft.  Upon approval by the administrator's attorneys and you and your attorney, it gets sent to the court for judicial approval and filing.  Seems simple, but can be a bear if the draft QDRO doesn't pass muster with the administrator's attorneys and ERISA rules and laws.    Again, if nothing has happened for a few months you can either (1) have your attorney draft the QDO; (2) hire an outside company that writes QDROS; (3) file a motion to compel the drafting of the QDRO.  Before a motion can be filed, a good faith letter and attempt to get information must be made.

If you want to stay on the safe side, then your best course is to secure licensing or not to use the logos.  Sports licensing is among the most litigious specialties in the trademark field.  Even if you have an arguable "fair use" defense, or other rationale for not paying licensing royalties, still, the expense of arguing your pet theory in court can be very expensive, and the goal of any team or league suing you will be to put you out of business by burying you in legal bills, without even having to take the case all the way to trial.  If you do want to approach potential licensors, with a pitch about your proposed app, I would recommend that you use the services of a lawyer; they still may not necessarily want to do business with you (or they may just steal your idea and do it themselves), but your chances of them taking you more seriously are improved if you work with someone who is a known quanitiy in the licensing field.

The key here is WHERE you work - you said you were working at the UPS at the Richmond, Airport.  TSA has and is responsible for all security within the boundaries of federally controlled airports, i.e., where commercial planes to include cargo, fly in-and-out of.  As such, it may have been a condition of your employment to "consent" to such searches while WITHIN the boundaries of the airport.  If you are a union member, contact your steward immediately.  If not, talk to your supervisor and find out exactly what the problem is and if worse-comes-to-worse, can you accept another UPS position at another location not under TSA's control.  You should contact a Plaintiff's Employment Attorney - go to the NELA (Nat'l Employment Lawyers Ass'n) website and look for a member near you.  Good luck!

Is this a rehab which requires it to be in writing in Illinois?  If not, then you do not have to have it in writing.  Yet, without a writing, you and the homeowner have a disagreement. When you set up your LLC, it becomes a living entity.  Get it an EIN.  If it is multi-member LLC, you will need to file a Form 1065 Partnership Return and issue yourself a K-1, which follows to your own 1040 Income Tax Return.  If it is a single-member LLC, it is a pass-through entity, and you simply file a separate Schedule C on your 1040 Return for the LLC.  Even if the LLC does not earn any income, be sure to file the 1065 or Schedule C (showing expenses as well, if any) this spring.  As I recall, there is no minimum filing requirement threshold for an LLC.  You need to file your 1065 of Schedule C next year.  Be sure to speak to an accountant.

As already stated, your friend would have to file for a Sentence Modification.  I can tell you that typically, the Public Defender's Office will not do this.  A sentence modification is not a stage that is considered critical to the defense of a charge that the public defender is meant to handle.  Therefore, she would either need to file on her own behalf or hire an attorney.  Further, the wait time for a female to get into the RSAT program ranges anywhere from 4-8 months.  The courts that sentence and the prosecutors who recommend this type of sentence typically understand this when they agree to the sentence and have probably taken the "dead time" into account.  While it is within the court's discretion to modify the sentence, my experience is that they will not modify these sentences until at least 6 months have passed and the person is still waiting for a bed.  The time your friend is spending in jail while waiting on her bed in RSAT will count toward any probation that she may have to serve when released.

If you do not pay the water bill and the lease requires you to, then you would be liable and the landlord could collect from you. Unfortunately, your ex is in the right here.  I'm not saying that he didn't hit your daughter, but it doesn't appear that you can PROVE he did so.  Just because you claim it happened doesn't mean social services is going to do anything about it.  The worker went to your ex, didn't see anything dangerous, and told the court as much.  I'm guessing you didn't take your daughter to the doctor, call the police, or otherwise generate any kind of objective proof of the incident.  That is where you made your mistake.  The problem is that many times one parent will make up a fake story against the other parent to mess with them - it happens all the time.  So, the standard you have to meet in order to restrict his parenting time is quite high.  You didn't meet that standard, and now you're in trouble for improperly restricting his parenting time.  You have to PROVE it happened, not just say it did.

Life is not always fair.  Children do not have a right to inherit under a will. If the will expressly states "I disinherit my son, Joe," the chances are good that Joe is out of luck unless he can prove that Dad action came as the result of fraud or undue influence or because Dad lacked the mental capacity to make a will. On the other hand, if Joe is not mentioned in the will, Joe may argue that he has a right of inheritance under the Omitted Child law and receive a fractional share of the assets.  As for the house -- Joe is out of luck. Property passes to a joint owner automatically at the death of the other owner, unless you can successfully prove that the deed is the product of fraud or undue influence..  The prisoner should try to find a probate attorney who will make a house call for further assistance.
