I agree with both comments the preceded, but I  also wanted to make sure I'm understanding your question.  A police report and an investigator report are two different things.  A police report is the incident report and is generally completed immediately following a citation or arrest by the arresting police officer.  An investigative report often means person is being investigated for a crime, by local, state, or federal authorities.  They work closely with police, and the prosecution to determine if criminal charges should be brought.  Its a one sided report by the investigator.  It's not like the police report that you can request to review for accuracy.  In fact, you rarely if ever get to see it.  If an investigator calls the suspect, it's important that they do not provide any documentation, or answer any questions.   The exception to this is if there is subpoena or warrant.  Instead, find out who is investigating, what agency, and why.   All states made can be used against the suspect.   So it's important to consult a criminal defense attorney if the person is under investigation.  The attorney will need the information about who is investigating and why.  If hired for pre-indictment charges, the attorney's role is to protect the suspect from self-incrimination, and they will act as a wall between the investigator and the suspect.   The investigator will be contacted by the attorney, who will  let the investigator know that all communications need to go through them. In some cases the charges are never brought with those protections.  But in some cases, they still are.but often rights and defenses are well protected to use for the suspects defense in court.  The Attorney will usually request the investigative report once completed as part of the discovery and evidence gathering process.

You always have the option of applying for the R-1 visa stamp at a US consulate in either Canada or Mexico as a "Third Country National" ("TCN").  Most, if not all of the U.S.consulates in both of these countries, which are known as and popularly referred to as "border posts" will entertain your visa application there.  You need to got into the website of each consulate in question and read the special rules that apply for TCN applications and learn how to schedule a visa interview appointment. In your particular situation, both Vancouver and Tijuana will be good choices, with each having pros and cons. Depending on your nationality, you might also need to obtain a visitior's visa to Canada (their SF and SJ consulates are particularly nasty, LA is no big help either). You will be allowed to enter freely to Mexico, on foot or by car from San Diego, but should your visa be ultimately denied there, or submitted to "security name check clearances" that could last weeks or more, you will not be allowed back into the US side of the border and will need to fly back to your home country from Mexico. That is why if Mexico is what you elect, better apply for and obtain a Mexican visa prior to embarking on that adventure. Also note that with the R-1 category being fraught with (very) high perception of fraud, better discuss this with an attorney prior to making any such decision and perhaps you will be better off applying in your home country..

Expungement is actually only for juvenile records. Adult records can be sealed, but not expunged. If you were not convicted you can apply to have the record sealed, provided you don't already have a significant record.   If the court grants the application, many employers will not be able to see the record any more. However, sealed records are open to some employers such as schools, hospitals and law enforcement agencies, and certain licensing agencies such as the pharmacy board.   While you can do this yourself, you should get a lawyer if you want it done right. That will maximize your chance of success. The court is not required to seal your record simply because you are eligible and apply.

Most estates with a will are independently administered and never formally closed with the Court.  The Executor continues to have power to disburse the estate, and generally to sell most assets, regardless of the passage of time.  So, with an independent administration, the estate is usually closed by paying all debts, liquidating and distributing all of the assets.  No further court action is normally required.

You have to file an intestate probate estate in Washington. As executor or personal representative you will have access to the account and you will report it in a probate inventory. A pregnant woman has the right to move wherever she wants. Until the baby is born, the father - whoever he may be - does not have any say. If he chooses to pursue a paternity (parentage) action and request custody, he will (1) have to wait for the baby to be born, and (2) have to pursue it in the jurisdiction where the child/baby lives (assuming you meet the residency requirements at that time). For now, you are free to go. Good luck.

You certainly need an agreement granting you the right to the shares, which could be a Share Purchase Agreement, assignment of shares or even an option agreement.  The key is that the agreement should grant you the right now to execute/purchase at a later date, and expressly indicate that it is not conditioned on employment.  However, you also mention that you will both be on the same vesting schedule -- how these shares vest needs to be expressly set forth in your purchase agreement, but alos in an agreement between your partner and the company.    Separately, you absolutely will need By Laws and a Shareolders Agreement, which together will set forth the rights and obligations of the partners, management and control issues, restrictions on transfer, co-sale rights, perhaps a non-compete and other key provisions.  Lastly, and especially if there is intellectual property being contributed by the partners, each should sign an agreement assigning the IP rights to the Corporation.  As you can see, this is not a simple issue, and you should retain a corporate/business lawyer well-versed in these matters.  You also should review with counsel your hesitation to become a shareholder now based on the immigration issues as this may not be a reason to hold off from becoming a shareholder.

Long Island and Brooklyn are both in the same USCIS district, which is New York City, District 3, so a move between Brookyn and Long Island is not a move to another district and will not affect your 3 month residence requirement.

Dear Buffalo Tenant:  I take it that your security deposit (or portion of the full security deposit) is held by the landlord as dictated by the terms of the lease. The lease likely does not allow for the landlord unilaterally to release any portion of the total deposit until the lease and tenancy are over.   If you and other persons are the named tenants on the lease, and you all agree to release you from the lease, that is best done with a written lease modification signed by all the existing tenants, the landlord and the replacement tenant. That agreement may provide for the new tenant to assume your interest in the security deposit in exchange for paying you that share with his own good funds.  Otherwise, he is not obliged to you for anything. If you want to create a binding agreement about the security and the tenancy it must be written and all affected persons including the landlord must sign. Otherwise, even were he to pay you for your share of the joint security deposit but the landlord is not in on the arrangement, when the lease is over, and the apartment is turned back to the landlord assuming no damage to the apartment, the landlord would return your share to you and not to your replacement.

Fortunately, most of us medical malpractice types offer free consultations and take such cases on contingency no matter where the case is in California, so there is nothing to fear in calling us.  - Paul   Paul J. Molinaro, M.D., J.D.  Attorney at Law, Physician

If you were Not married, you may be able to sue the other owner in quiet title or partition.  But by taking a deed as Husband and Wife there is an argument that you have held yourself out to the public as husband and wife and there is, therefore, a chance that a judge will not grant partition or quiet title.  In that event, you may be compelled to petition for divorce/annulment.

The range of sentences for sales is a minimum of two years in state prison and a maximum of four years.  Transportation is a minimum of sixteen months in state prison and a maximum of three years.  if the acts are part of a single event, Penal Code section 654 applies to sentencing wherein the maximum term of the target offense is added to 1/3 the midterm of each of the other offenses.   Sentencing enhancements can also apply to increase the sentence based on your friend's prior criminal history and whether or not weapons were involved or gang membership is involved.  Probation, however, might still be an option.  Get an attorney to look into Fourth Amendment violations.  Best of luck.

Contact an experienced personal injury attorney in CA for a free consultation. Aside from the fact that we don't know what you signed, we also don't know why you fell. Even if the paperwork that you signed does not foreclose suit against the property, if there was nothing wrong with the stairs/staircase, then you don't have a claim. If you fell because you just accidentally tripped, that would not be the hotel's fault. If you fell because of something that the hotel did/didn't do and the doc you signed does not waive right to bring suit, then you may have a claim. Were the stairs defective? Was it dark? Was there water on the stairs? There are a lot of unanswered questions b/c not enough facts in your post. Also the paperwork you signed needs to be reviewed. If it was a waiver of right to bring suit, maybe that would be considered as against public policy but without seeing the document, there is no way for any of us attorneys to know.

Personal injury settlements, whether from the at fault driver or your own UIM insurance are determined to be for your pain and suffering for purposes of the IRS, meaning you pay no income tax on the money you receive.  The $25,000 you received will be subtracted from your UIM limits so that the maximum you can receive is $25,000 from your UIM coverage.  It doesn't matter whether the damages are evidenced by medical bills or lost wages, they are looked at as a combined total.  In addition, you are entitled to general damages for pain and suffering in an amount that is always variable depending on the type of injury and the degree of pain suffered.

It sounds like you are the one that is moving.  You need to file a Notice of Relocation with the Court 90 days before your expected move.  He will have 60 days from when he receives the notice to object to the move.  If he objects a hearing will be held to determine if the move was made in good faith and if it is in the best interests of the children.  If he does not object then you may move without the court holding a hearing.

Why do you assume it is worth less? Any case with any injury lasting more than 6 months may be worth more than that.  Cases like yours can vary. Some lawyers build cases from the bottom up- meaning they start with the amount of bills and expenses. Or start from the top down- focusing on those intangible losses you have suffered such as loss of enjoyment of life, mental anguish and pain.  No calculator will add those up. We've seen people who have given up active play with their children, gardening, motorcycles and many other things that make a hard life good or a good life great.   Insurance carriers try to negotiate every dollar they can, because every $100 means millions in the end to the Board of Directors. Even in soft tissue injuries, those tissues stretch and scar, or cause corresponding pressure on nerves in the spinal cord, leaving behind permanent problems for some. I have had clients need surgeries years later because of a bulging disk and have their entire world collapse for what seemed inconsequential at the time. Insurance companies want you to settle as soon as possible and treat as little as possible. Attorneys matter. Carriers change their gameplan when a lawyer is involved. It seems like your injuries are more serious.   For that reason - and the misinformation by TV lawyers and referral services- is why people should consult lawyers who take the time like on sites like this. Because of the economy, more lawyers are jumping into personal injury and should stick to what they know. Personal injury law REQUIRES knowledge about medical science and biomechanics (the forces on a body in a wreck) far greater and more specific than you'd think. The other side has doctors and millions on their side to say nothing is wrong or fight the claim.   The more a law firm advertises, the less likely it is to give personal attention. If you order a cheeseburger, you don't often meet the chef. If you buy a shirt, you virtually never meet the designer.  But hiring a lawyer is different. A lawyer is your spokesperson. Unlike a burger or a shirt, it can be a relationship which will last a lifetime.   Give one of us a call to discuss this confidentially and for free.

Yes, you can fly domestically on a valid national passport, that is still possible, even in TX, except in small border town airports.  A flight to Hawaii is considered to be a domestic flight and all you'll need is your valid Mexican passport to cross the TSA airport security lines. Don't even think of showing your Matricula consular... That is not a recognizable or acceptable form of ID anywhere, let alone at an airport security line.  TSA agents are accustomed to regularly seeing international visitors traveling on their foreign passports, no problem, as long as valid and you look like in the picture.  A matricula will immediately alert them that there might be something wrong with your ID (and legal right to be in the US).  Indpendently of your upcoming travel, I strongly encourage you  to apply for DACA if you qualify.

I agree you should get a consult.  Do you really need to do an adoption (a very formal, lengthy proceeding), or would simply receiving custody do it?  Receiving custody can be done by filing a complaint  (and "FD" or "non-dissolution / non-divorce" complaint), along with a consent order (assuming both mom and dad will sign), is much simpler and quicker, and might address your concerns (ability to provide medical insurance, legal residence and authority, etc). The law regarding HTO and subsequent DWLS changed about a year ago and is quite complicated. You need an experienced criminal defense attorney.  It depends on what the basis was for your HTO suspension. If you were HTO'd for 3 or more DWLS and the sole basis of your original license suspension was financial - (unpaid tickets, child support, no insurance, etc.) then a subsequent DWLS starts over again as a misdemeanor, not a felony.  There are some other exceptions to this law, such as having certain prior felonies on your record, whether you have DUI, fleeing eluding convictions, etc.  The point is that your new DWLS may not be able to be classified as a felony. A thorough review of your drivers license record and criminal history is required.

The first thing I'm going to say is that most MA family law attorneys offer free initial consultations and you should really take advantage of this.  Having an attorney talk to you about all the relevant details and fully assess your situation is the best way to get a realistic picture of your rights and obligations so that you can set reasonable expectations.  Based on what you've provided, I'd say it would be much more likely for a judge to enter orders that result in a "walk away" (everyone keeps what they came in with) than for a judge to order you receive any substantial portion of your spouse's assets.  Where two spouses haven't intermingled their financial lives and aren't financially interdependent, there's very little justification for splitting things up.  This is especially true where the spouses are young and have substantial future earning potential.  Where you two will be in one another's lives forever due to a child in common, there are a lot of very long term consequences to consider when making litigation decisions.  You should definitely strongly consider mediation or conciliation to try and resolve your differences amicably.  And because it's this important, I'll end on the same note I started: at least consult with a few attorneys so that they can explain the costs and benefits of seeking this split of assets.

Although I agree with the other lawyers responding that a material witness recanting his trial testimony is grounds for relief from the verdict, it is unlikely that a motion for new trial will be timely.  The deadline for a motion for new trial under Rule 3.590 is 10 days after the verdict.  If your brother has already been sentenced, it is probably too late for a motion for new trial.  I suggest that your brother consider filing a motion for post-conviction relief under Fla. R. Crim. P. 3.850.  That is not an appeal, but is filed in the court that tried him

"Petty" disputes are not generally addressed well by the courts, and if you constantly complain about them, the court can look at your like a litigious parent stirring the pot and complaining about "silly" things. Now, I'm not saying these behaviors aren't annoying, and at times, wrong. However, you need to be careful, and understand the potential affect complaining about them could have on your custody, especially if you are the primary custodian. Complaining too often could result in a "Peter and the Wolf" situation, where you complain too much, and when he does something really bad, the court won't believe you right away.  What you're dealing with now requires patience and time. If you gather yourself and plan, you can have the court address these things, but you will have to hire a good attorney and plan ahead if you really feel it is necessary to address them, and it would be done by filing an action against him for contempt of the custody order.  I suggest that you consult with a reputable attorney who understands how to be careful in these situations without running off and irritating the court.  Good luck!

It depends on who foreclosed.  If it was a first position mortgagee that foreclosed, the HOA was in junior position and the lien was extinguished at the foreclosure.  However, the underlying debt is still a personal obligation to the homeowner and the HOA can still sue on it.  Also, any unpaid assessments that accumulated after the foreclosure automatically constitute a new lien against the property under Arizona law.  HOA liens are senior to nearly every other kind of lien.  So, if it was not a first position mortgagee that foreclosed, the HOA liens are likely still good.

But even with a lawsuit, the rising tide is in favor of turning multi-family dwellings smoke free as quickly as possible.

You may or may not be liable for this debt.  First, check the written agreement you entered into with the 3rd party vendor for credit card processing.  More than likely, since this is or was an S-Corporation, the third party vendor required you to sign an individual guarantee on behalf of the corporation when you signed up for its service.  Most reputable banks will generally require an individual to guarantee any sizable loan or indebtedness on behalf of an S-Corporation.  This is done to protect the rights of the bank in the event of a default.  After all,  an S-corporation can be easily created or terminated.  Many have little in the way of tangible assets.  If you did guarantee the debt, you are on  the hook irrespective of the corporation's dissolution.  If you did not sign as an individual guarantor, you may still not be off the hook.  The vendor's alternative course of action could be to attempt to pursue you individually by "piercing the corporate veil".  This is a much more difficult and costly route.  Basically, to pierce the corporate veil, the creditor would have to prove in court that:  1) there was no real distinction between the corporation and you, as its owner;  2) you engaged in wrongful or fraudulent conduct;  and 3) the creditor suffered unjustly as a result of your conduct.  Given the amount of the debt we are talking about here, it would probably not be cost effective for this creditor to go to such great lengths to pierce the corporate veil.  If, however, there were more money at stake and/or other vendors similarly situated,  that could increase the likelihood of such a proceeding.   Piercing the corporate veil is neither cheap or easy to do.  You probably do not need a lawyer for this.  Just check the language of the agreement you signed with the vendor.  If you did not retain a copy, they should be able to produce a copy of the signed document to validate the debt.  I suspect that will answer your question.  Good luck!

Questions about the statute of limitations are quite common on general information sites such as this.  Unfortunately, it is very difficult for attorneys to state with any authority whether a charge is truly behind a person, and relying on the statute of limitations is very perilous.  Regardless of the specific statute at issue for a specific jurisdiction and charge, the real problem is that a suspect cannot know from what date the statute may run.  For drug conspiracies, the statute typically will not toll until the end of the conspiracy or acts in furtherance thereof, and federal or state investigators may well have continued to investigate criminal acts related to the marijuana possession long after the initial stop, thereby arguably giving them more lawful time to file formal charges.  Some federal investigations last for years after a traffic stop. The best advice for anyone concerned about possible charges in a specific case is to speak to retained or appointed counsel, who can advise about these and other issues, in a confidential setting. Good luck.

This is a bad idea, and is in violation of the law.  Unless the workers are working directly under the control and direction and supervision of the owner and are paid by the owner, they cannot be used as "independent contractors" on such a job.  If you find them and hire them and give them work to do, they are your employees unless they each have of the group has their own contractor's licenses.  The Labor Code makes them your employees for purposes of workers compensation insurance and payment of hourly wages, and you would be liable if they were injured if you did not provide workers compensation insurance for them.  If you have employees and do not have workers compensation insurance for them, then your license is effectively suspended by operation of law, even if it otherwise appears that you have a valid contractor's license.  If that happens, then you could not collect money owed you in court, and the owner may be able to sue you for the return of all money they paid you, even if your work was perfect.  The License Board can also suspend or revoke your license for this conduct.  (See the Legal Article on this topic on our website)  Plus you may owe withholding etc to the State and the IRS on these workers.  Trying to skirt the law and hiring of unskilled "independent contractors" is not a good way to start out in the construction business, and could  result in a very short career as a contractor!

Charges involving prescription drugs in Tennessee can be quite serious, but they can also be successfully defended and reduced in many cases. 28 min and still no answer, must have been a tough question. My personal perspective, I rarely find defense work worth doing, quite often the overall financial situation is suitable to a bankruptcy filing, so why waste resources on a piecemeal defense when you could resolve all of the issues at once. However, bankruptcy filings have been in decline for nearly 3 years and have dropped as much as 30% of the last 3 years. Immediately prior to that, say 2009-2011 the bankruptcy attorney market was flooded with new attorneys who facing a tough job market  just hung out a shingle and became "bankruptcy" attorneys. To their credit some of the new folks are very good at marketing, even if they haven't take the time to learn much about practice.   Nevertheless there are appropriate cases for consumer defense, and consumer rights, and there are lots of potential clients that need good attorneys.   First piece of advise, get paid for your work. Don't take the case without retainer or other means to pay you. You have to pay your bills to stay in business and you can't do this if you are always putting out fires for free.  Give clients a fair and accurate statement of anticipated expenses for the proposed course of action , show the value in your services for that cost, and then let them decide to pay for it before you agree to work. You can always have more than enough work to keep you busy way more time than you can work. The key is to have work that pays you for working. If you are over burdened by cases that do not pay the bills by necessity , things will not get done right or timely and you will get in trouble, legally, ethically, and financially.  It may be difficult to find someone who wants to train the competition, especially in a formalized consultant arrangement. However there are many competent attorneys who are willing to share their knowledge.. Look for local and specialized bar organizations/chapters , join trade associations,  online forums, and of course spend a substantial amount of time  reading the applicable statues and case law. As you meet experienced attorneys in the area,  ask specific questions  that show you have studied the underlying statues, rules of procedure, etc and put some effort into it. Do not fall in to the trap of just posting questions all the time for a quick answer. Anybody can get an answer, a good attorney knows why it is the correct answer and when /how it might change based on the circumstances.

This is a complicated question and what you do here really turns on whether you do, in fact, owe the debt or whether you dispute it.  If you do owe it, making a payment now can be counter-productive to improving your credit.  If you dispute it, you have rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA).  This is the federal law that controls everything that can be on your credit report.  As a general rule, negative credit can stay on your reports for 7 years from the date of last activity.  As a result, if you do owe the debt and make a payment now, that will actually re-start the 7 year time period.  These blog posts may help you.  Get your free credit reports first as described below before you do anything so you have a full scope of your situation.    Best wishes.    http://www.bondnbotes.com/2012/12/11/fair-credit-reporting-act-fcra/ http://www.bondnbotes.com/2012/12/24/how-can-i-get-my-free-credit-reports/ http://www.bondnbotes.com/category/credit-report-disputes-and-errors/

Send the real estate agent a certified letter and state that you object to the refund of the earnest money.   The buyer is obligated to use best efforts and good faith in seeking financing based on circumstances that existed on the date the contract was signed.  If the buyer finds out after the date of the contract that he is being relocated, that does not eliminate his obligations under the contract.  You can sue to compel specific performance and require the buyer to complete closing and combine it with a claim for damages if the buyer does not complete the closing.  And then apply the security deposit to your damages; but you DO NOT refund the earnest money now.   If your buyer is relocating, the practical problem is one of collecting even if you get some judgment in your favor. Your current practical remedy is to agree to release the buyer from the contract and you keep the earnest money. The real estate agent is NOT entitled to keep any part of that earnest money deposit.

Hi, Your mom's execution of powers of attorney is not a loss of her rights; instead it is an exercise of her rights.  The people appointed under powers of attorney (agents) are supposed to act in furtherance of her wishes and interests, unless her wishes would cause harm to your mom or others.  Just as your mom created the agency, she can terminate the agency if she no longer believes they are acting according to her wishes (they are working for her, so if and when she wants she can fire the scoundrel(s)).  She can appoint whomever she wishes (and who will agree) to act on her behalf as long as those individuals meet the legal requirements to act as agents in Florida.  If your mom is no longer competent, then guardianship proceedings may be necessary (a legal action where a Judge substitutes his/her judgment in the place of your mother because of her disability).  Your mother needs personal and confidential legal assistance.  You would be well served to hire one of the fine attorneys from your area who take the time from their busy schedules to answer your question or if you prefer you can use the search function here at Avvo.com to gain access to some of the finest attorneys in the country.

If you are in a California Appellate Court, you are entitled to file a Reply Brief, but your time to do so is very limited - 20 days from the date the Respondent's Brief was filed.  Oral argument is not required.  However, if the Respondent shows up and you do not, they will get a chance to convince the appellate court that their position is righteous.  Keep in mind that oral argument rarely changes the outcome on appeal, but there are cases where it is critical.  Good luck to you.

Landlord has 30 days from the day you vacated the property to either return the security deposit or return less than the full amount of the security deposit with an itemized statement of expenses that were deducted from the security deposit.  Unfortunately, many landlords in Butler County are not experienced landlords, and they have little knowledge about what the law requires from them upon a lease termination.  Even worse, many do know what their obligations are but choose to ignore them and take money from the tenants they are not entitled to.  They do this because they frequently get away with because very few tenants ever take their landlords to court.  This is exactly why Ohio's statute regarding returning security deposits provides for the landlord to pay the tenant's attorney's fees if they tenant wins.  This provides tenants an opportunity and leverage.  You should seek an attorney to get your security deposit back, especially if you have evidence that the property did not suffer beyond reasonable wear and tear since you moved in.

The important statute discussing guardianship is: NRS 159.191 and the Court should also be considering NRS 125.500(1). The important cases are: Litz v. Bennum, 111 Nev. 35, 38, 888 P.2d 438, 440 (1995); and Locklin v. Duka, 112 Nev. 1489, 1495-96, 929 P.2d 930, 934-35 (1996).  Essentially the argument is this: In Nevada, there is a parental preference meaning parents have preference over anyone else.  To overcome the presumption, a person seeking guardianship instead of leaving the kids with the parents must  show that the parent is unfit or other extraordinary circumstances. In Nevada, extraordinary circumstances sufficient to overcome the parental preference presumption are those  circumstances which result in serious detriment to the child. Factors which may be considered in evaluating whether such extraordinary circumstances exist include: abandonment or persistent neglect of the child by the parent; likelihood of serious physical or emotional harm to the child if placed in the parent's custody; extended, unjustifiable absence of parental custody; continuing neglect or abdication of parental responsibilities; provision of the child's physical, emotional and other needs by persons other than the parent over a significant period of time; the existence of a bonded relationship between the child and the non-parent custodian sufficient to cause significant emotional harm to the child in the  event of a change in custody; the age of the child during the period when his or her care is provided by a non-parent; the child's well-being has been substantially enhanced under the care of the non-parent; the extent of the parent's delay in seeking to acquire custody of the child; the demonstrated quality of the parent's commitment to raising the child; the likely degree of stability and security in the child's future with the parent; the extent to which the child's right to an education would be impaired while in the custody of the parent; and any other circumstances that would substantially and adversely impact the welfare of the child.    You and the parents should consult an attorney who practices in this area immediately to discuss your options for a trial.

Yes, you can be sued for more than your deposit if you caused damage to the property that will cost more to repair than your deposit. The best defense is *always* pictures. Detailed fussy pictures, not real estate listing pictures. Open the cabinets and show under the sinks(s). Open the fridge and show it is clean. Landlords will frequently use emotion-evoking words, e.g. "filthy" and "vermin-infested" or "urine-soaked" in order to generate a sympathetic response from a court.   Facts are the best possible counter. Pictures show facts; adjectives evoke responses. Judges want to make decisions based on facts, not conclusions. Elizabeth Powell

I'm not sure from your posting what stage you're at in the divorce proceeding.  Usually the "non-monied spouse" gets to ask for interim counsel fees from the monied spouse.  If the monied spouse paid some voluntary fees, but didn't sign a stipulation saying, essentially, "this constitutes interim counsel fees with the ability of the non-monied spouse to request add'l fees at trial," then the non-monied spouse wouldn't be precluded form filing a motion asking for additional interim fees.  That's not to say s/he will get it, but they can ask.  Schedule a consult with a Bronx Divorce attorney for a full assessment.

In the strictest sense of the word, SD does not "require" employers to provide worker's compensation insurance. However, in effect -- it's basically required.   Virtually all employers are required to "secure the payment of compensation to the employer's employees...." That's almost always done through what you've called worker's comp insurance. Some employers may be excluded from the insurance requirement if they prove to the state that they are sufficiently solvent to qualify as a self-insured employer. Technically that's not "insurance" but it accomplishes the same thing. Also, there are some employers that are exempt, for example, the state and municipalities aren't required to carry workman's comp insurance (but can if they choose).  There are also some types of employees who are exempt from the workers' compensation laws, (farm laborers, some real estate brokers, some owner-operators of trucks).  You should contact the Workers' Compensation program within the Division of Labor & Management if you have concern that your employer is not providing the required coverage. They can be reached at 605-773-3681.

To begin with, it sounds like the estate does not have sufficient assets. If that's true, you should consider whether to pursue the claim. It sounds like throwing good money after bad. But generally speaking, the claim survives the death of a party but nonetheless there are rules. In Georgia, once notice of the death is made on the record the surviving party has 6 months to assure the estate has been properly substituted. I recommend that you not wait on the estate's administrator. It's up to the plaintiff to cause the substitution and if the plaintiff fails to timely substitute, the claim will be dismissed.

The best advice in such a situation is almost always for the individual to retain a good local defense attorney, so as to discuss options in a confidential setting.  In a general information discussion forum, it is not possible to evaluate specific cases and details, or to provide the best strategy moving forward.  In some cases, it may be possible to avoid criminal charges by demonstrating remorse and paying back any misappropriated money.  However, if a person makes admissions and repays the money without a lawyer, those admissions and repayment could certainly be taken as admissions of guilt, which could form the basis for a criminal prosecution and conviction.  An attorney may be able to resolve the case without such actions being deemed as admissible evidence, and thus without losing the leverage to possibly fight the case if charges are filed.  An individual in this situation who makes admissions without an attorney may be able to avoid charges, but he or she is then really placing her fate in the hands of the employer and alleged victim(s), and local prosecutors, who may pursue criminal charges notwithstanding efforts to make it right.

Unless your HOA is using a lawyer or debt collector, no one is obligated to do anything other than send you an invoice for your monthly dues or assessments, and indicate on there all late fees, and accrued balances.  Will you have to pay attorney fees and late fees? Probably. Almost all CCR's in an HOA include provisions for late fees and attorney's fees if you're late or in default.   You can try negotiating with the association, request mediation with the court, etc.  There is no stated time limit on service, only that the process server sign the return of service and file it within the same time in which a defendant must answer.  If you are served on July 1 and have 30 days, then the process server must file the return of service stating you were served by July 31.   In federal court there's a 120 day rule but most courts allow the plaintiff several extensions of time to serve if its a difficult serve.  Click on "Find a Lawyer" and locate an attorney in your area and see if you can find someone who may be able to negotiate this for you.

In each of the boroughs of New York City, a home improvement contractor's license is required for work that falls into the definition of home improvements under the NYC regulations.  For commercial work, you do not need a home improvement contractor's license nor do you need a general contractor's license.  In fact, there is no "general contractor's license" for commercial work in NYC.  Instead, you should register as a general contractor with NYC DOB.  You will not be able to file any documents with the Department of Buildings without your registration number.  So, in short, you need a registration for commercial work but not a license.

Did he pay any informal or formal child support? Did he live close by you? etc etc. How did he make sure he remained in your life as your dad. That's what they want to know. Good luck!!!!

If it is your computer then it is probably legal.  If, however, she is given temporary or permanent possession of the computer and you do not immediately remove the keylogger, then you risking very serious criminal charges.  It is possible that the District Attorney will prosecute such a case.  I have seen this happen.  I have no idea what kind of "evidence" you think you will learn that will be helpful to you.  It is unlikely you will find anything that a Court will actually pay attention to and you are taking a huge risk with your freedom (prison is not a fun place to live).  Perhaps if you discover that she has large hidden bank accounts or other assets hidden away that she is not disclosing you will have something that a judge would be interested in hearing about.  If, however, your goal is to catch her cheating on you or putting up personal ads on Match.com, you need to know that you are wasting your time.  Colorado divorce law is "no-fault".  This means that infidelity has no legal impact on a divorce settlement.  The judge won't even listen to the accusations.  By far the people most excited about Colorado law in this regard are judges.  Any evidence related to her social life or her sex life will be completely worthless to you.

Meet an attorney no matter what you do as most do not charge for that first meeting. They can help you enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not found one yet and finding a PRO BONO may be hard.  You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what. Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can. You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of  waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then!   The collection proceedings IF they resulted in a judgment may affect you IF you own a house or real estate. Otherwise, it does not affect much if you were not sued yet as the debt owed is a debt owed, no matter who they assign it to!   Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Well, it kind of depends on your Marital Estate's relative wealth and how substantial this sum is.  The court would have made an "Equitable Division" of your assets.  An Equitable Division, by definition, is made by considering the magnitude of the marital estate.  You marital estate was inflated by this deposit.  You share of the marital estate was probably overstated (money in "your" account) so your share was probably impacted.  In other words, your entire marital division was based upon a giant, good faith, mutual mistake.  How much that cost you is relevant to how the cost of repayment should be borne.  There is no question you and ex are liable for the amount.  The circumstances exclude all presumption of "gift".  I think you need to make a real effort to go back to  your original divorce lawyer and find out how to retrofit this thing.  Now, if your marital estate was $500,000. and the mistake was $50,000, that's a significant distortion.  If your ME was two million and the windfall $10k, not so much.  At a minimum, you, ex and accountant should all sit down and decide how to share the pain, but not before you have talked privately to a lawyer.

You are not permitted to do a cross motion to the other side's cross motion.  You are permitted under the court rules only to do a reply certification to their cross motion, which must be filed with the Court and delivered to the adversary at least 8 days prior to the return date.  Also, pursuant to the Court Rules you should have attached to your original motion any agreements, judgments or orders that you were relying on as part of your application.  In addition, you should have attached any evidence that you wanted the court to consider.  In your reply certification you should attach any documents, orders and other evidence you want the court to review.  If you have additional relief that you want the court to decide then you will have to file a new motion that will be heard on a different return date than the one you currently have scheduled.  I suggest that you immediately consult with an experienced family law attorney to discuss your matter and what is the best way for you to handle it.
The speed with which your case will proceed depends largely on what county you are in.  You need a local attorney who knows how the game is played there to answer this kind of question.

I think you have things backwards: The person who initiates a patent infringement lawsuit [in your vernacular, "infringment plaintiffs"] IS the inventor or the manufacturer who licensed the patent from the inventor. They cannot be accused of patent infringement because they own or license the patent. It is they who accuse others.  SOMETIMES a company that is making, selling or importing a product is accused by a patent owner of infringement and, in response, the company files a "declaratory judgment" lawsuit to put the infringement issue before a court. In that situation, the accused infringer IS the plaintiff -- but in name only. The burden remains on the patent owner to prove the infringement.   SOMETIMES a company that is making, selling or importing a product is sued for patent infringement and, in response, the company "counterclaims" against the patent owner, and perhaps joins others into the case, accusing that patent owner or those others of doing bad things -- like infringing THAT company's patents or interfering with THAT company's business. In that situation, the proper counterclaimant may be the inventor of whatever is claimed in the patent that started the lawsuit if that inventor participated in any of the alleged wrongdoing [like stealing trade secrets and using them to invent whatever was patented].  So the short answer to your question is, no, it is not common for an inventor to be sued in a patent infringment lawsuit. But maybe. Speak with your own intellectual property litigation attorney to discuss the specific facts of your situation.  Good luck.

There are very significant differences.  A 5K motion is a motion to reduce sentence filed by the government, based on a defendant's "substantial assistance" (cooperation) with the government in investigating or prosecuting other cases. Such a motion can allow a court to sentence below a mandatory minimum term or applicable guidelines.  The "safety valve" guideline (and statute) applies to defendants with minimal criminal history, and it permits a court to sentence a defendant below a mandatory minimum term, and provides a reduction under the sentencing guidelines.  Typically, a defendant need not provide "substantial assistance" in other cases to qualify, but must give a truthful statement about the defendant's own involvement.  Federal sentencing is complex, and there is truly no way to discuss all the different aspects of the safety valve provisions in a general discussion forum.  Nor is there way way to determine whether a particular defendant would qualify in this forum.  Anyone facing a federal prosecution should be working with experienced defense counsel to review all sentencing options, including safety valve and possible 5K.  Many other sentencing considerations will also come in to play, and will need to be discussed with an appointed or retained attorney.

A federal probationer does need permission to travel outside the jurisdiction of conviction, and outside of the United States.  Experienced federal criminal defense attorneys routinely file such motions with the court, and they are often granted where a probationer has a track record of success and legitimate reasons for the travel.  A probation officer can grant permission on his own, but some probation officers insist on a court order for international travel.  Moreover, where a probation officer denies permission,  a petition to the court will be needed.  An attorney (whether a newly retained attorney, appointed attorney, or most likely the attorney who originally handled the case) will give the probationer the best chance at success with such a motion, as opposed to the probationer pursuing it on her own.  There may also be issues with travelling across the Canadian border, as that country is very strict about admitting felons and those on supervision.  Dual citizenship will likely make this much easier than for an American, but it is likely wise to contact the Canadian Embassy for advice, or an immigration lawyer in the area.  Good luck to anyone trying to complete federal probation and trying to remain in compliance with all conditions.  Working with an attorney -  and with probation - will give a person the best chance at success.

Your first priority should be to pursue your L&I case.  Presenting a case on appeal, especially for reopening, can be very complex and you should consult with a competent local workers' compensation attorney.  In order to reopen a claim you must prove that [1] your medical or psychiatric condition has worsened since claim closure and [2] that your present condition is a direct result of your original injury or occupational disease.  You can draw both social security disability and L&I benefits, BUT there is a cap on total benefits of 80% of either your highest one year's earnings or the average of the highest five consecutive years.  If your high year(s) were not the year when you are injured, you  will receive more money total.  SSI is a needs-based system, and you would need to establish family income to be eligible.  You don't indicate whether you were denied because you didn't prove your disability or denied because your income is too high.  Big difference.  Please do yourself a favor and contact an attorney for an appointment.

. Dear Merrick Home Owner:  How did you provide information to the tenant to "make up the money or move." All you really needed to do was serve a rent demand (a statutory three day notice) and that would cover both options. A landlord may afford the tenant more than the minimum allowed three days to pay the back rent (and may need more if required by the lease) but the form of notice demands the rent is paid or the tenant moves out. Whatever information or notice you gave the tenant about paying or moving may be a proper notice or not, but you will need a lawyer to let you know, for sure.  Generally, the nonpayment summary proceeding is seen as the swiftest method to bring a tenant to court. And, should you be so lucky as to have the tenant come up with money from another source, if you still have a right to end the lease early, for personal use, you could do so. Another helpful aspect of the nonpayment proceeding is that you get into court, quickly. Then you and your attorney and the tenant and tenant attorney may make a deal. Typically, a judge will not mind if a landlord and tenant decide to settle a nonpayment case with the tenant agreeing to move out and the landlord agreeing to give up the rent.  These are strategies to discuss with your lawyer. This is not to do on your own considering your plans and the amount of money owed.  A holdover proceeding may exist in relation to a tenant only when the lease or tenancy expired or when the landlord exercises a right reserved in the lease where early termination is allowed. That presents a so-called "winnable" lawsuit, but all your rights depend on doing the legal work correctly.   If the lease provides a right to give notice of accelerated expiration of the lease based upon owner's need for personal use, then assuming the landlord adheres to the lease notice requirement, then a holdover proceeding may be proper.  Otherwise, the landlord must rely on a default term of the lease. Or seek possession by nonpayment proceeding.  Since the lease controls your rights, allow an attorney to help you decide on the form of summary proceeding.

After reading your question, I am a little confused by the facts. You indicated that your Social Security Disability was approved and you were found entitled to benefits when you were covered by an LTD policy. Did you receive LTD benefits at some time in the past? If you received benefits, and you failed to file an appeal, you would likely be well beyond the deadline for appealing at this time. If you never filed a claim, and your LTD policy is no longer effective, it is unlikely that you are still covered by the policy.  If you applied for LTD benefits, and filed an Administrative Appeal after being denied, it is possible that you may still be able to file a federal lawsuit, but it would depend on the terms of your policy and your State's Statute of Limitations for filing a contract claim.  Normally LTD claims are governed by the Federal ERISA statute (if this was a policy offered by your employer). I would suggest searching for an attorney that handles ERISA claims. However, even if there is a valid claim to still pursue your LTD benefits, the additional question is the benefit that you will be eligible for if you can prove your are indeed eligible.  If your LTD benefit was an employer offered benefit, it is likely that any amount you receive from Social Security, reduces your eligibility for LTD. Normally LTD policies have terms that indicate that you are required to apply for Social Security Disability, and if you are approved, you must repay any amount that you entitled to from Social Security Disability to the LTD company for up to the full amount of your LTD benefit for any months that you are eligible for both payments. There is normally a minimum benefit payable from your LTD company if your Social Security Disability amount is the same or higher than your LTD benefit. LTD companies also normally limit payment for mental health conditions to 2 years, and limit payments because you cannot perform your past work for 2 years. After 2 years, if you are disabled as a result of mental health, or you have the ability to perform any full-time work, your benefits are normally terminated.   If your LTD policy has these clauses in it, although it is possible that you may still have some rights to pursue a claim (if you were denied, properly appealed, and are still within your Federal Appeal deadline), there may not be a lot of money for you if you are successful. It is possible it could cost you more to pursue than you would ever receive.  I would recommend that you collect all relevant information and contact an attorney in your state that handles ERISA claims. It is important that you have a copy of your LTD policy, and any documentation that you have if you previously received benefits, or filed a claim and you were denied.

It's difficult to give you a certain answer as to what specific amount you should settle for. Ultimately, the decision will come down to you taking into consideration all factors and circumstances surrounding your injuries. Many personal injury attorneys will try and obtain a settlement that pays off an individual's medical bills, accounts for their pain and suffering, and compensates them for any lost wages. For the most part, a personal injury attorney will calculate an individual's pain and suffering by taking the sum of their medical bills and lost wages and multiplying that amount by a certain number. However, insurance companies are not required to value pain and suffering in the same manner. Instead, insurance companies will look to various factors such as the length of time you received medical treatment and the specific type of injury you suffered. For example, if you have suffered a permanent disability or disfigurement, you may want to consider increasing the value of your pain and suffering. If you haven't already done so, be sure to contact a personal injury attorney in your area to provide you with more advice regarding this matter. Best of luck to you.   Emery Ledger  Attorney At Law  www.LedgerLaw.com  800-300-000

Prior to the change in the banruptcy laws in 2005 a person could keep their car after a bankruptcy discharge by making the required monthly payments.  This was called a "ride trhough."    The post 2005 Bankruptcy Code takes away the "ride through" option.  A debtor must either redeem the car (that means pay the fair market value of the car in a lump sum) , or surrender the car to the lender or reaffirm the debt.  If the debtor does not reaffirm or redeem the vehicle but he is current with his payments the lender can still repossess the car.  Some lenders, especially Ford, were very agressive about enforcing this provision.  Even if payments were current, if the debt on the car had not been reaffirmed, then Ford and others were repossessing cars.  To reaffirm the debt on the car you will have to become current with your payments, then sign a reaffirmation agreement that says that you are keeping the car and will make all payments under the contract.    Talk to the bankruptcy department of your lender.  See if they will work with you concerning the missed payments.  They would rather get the payment stream than take the car back and have to sell it to a wholesaler for a possible loss.

If your brother has proven irresponsible and his irresponsibility is resulting in (a) problems in providing the care your mother needs and (b) wasting her resources, you have only one option:  Guardianship.  Unless she is competent to execute new documents, in which case she can merely revoke the authorities she has given him, and give those authorities to you.  Guardianships are expensive to create (probably $3,500 to $7,500) and require ongoing legal services for the required reporting by the Guardian to the Probate Court.  Those periodic reports may add another $1,000 to $2,000 in annual cost.  And everything that happens in Probate Court is public.  If your mother does not have the resources to afford these services, you may be able to access legal services through Legal Aid, the Columbus Bar Association or the Capital University Law School clinic program.

Prior post contains misleading statement & should be discounted.    You seem to have a good head on your shoulders !!    One 'good thing' about your problem seems to be that but one county is involved.  Based upon my many years of professional work & interactions with people facing open warrants & 'hiding' from the law, a common thread is that such people tend to be very much on-guard 24-7, typically 'afraid of their own shadow', wary of all, constantly nervous & experiencing unending emotional stress. Also, in my years of work, when I interact with such people they tend to be fearful of trusting anyone at all:  Please know that USA law holds as a value that people are able to confer with their attorney counsel absent fear of the breach of confidentiality.  Private attorney and client communications are protected by law and by att'y rules of professional conduct fyi.     I urge you to choose a very well-experienced attorney right away, one of us who is a member of the MN State Bar Assn. Criminal Law Section. View a few att'y websites, read bios', look for the very rare entirely unsolicited comments of present & past clients. I urge you to choose an att'y who imparts to you a sense of great trustworthiness, understanding & compassion; the attorney and client relationship is an extraordinarily personal relationship.  No one here could responsibly predict outcome, but offering general odds for the fact pattern you described would definitely be reasonable. The state in which you presently reside may be a factor to the ultimate resolution.  I note to you that the odds of a person being alcoholic are very near 100 percent when one has had two DWI's.  Statistically when a person winds up with a DWI, he/she has 'gotten away' with driving drunk or otherwise impaired for 75-80 or well over 100 times prior.  I support participation in a healthy 12 Step group or other recovery program that is not fee-based.  The MainStreeters group in the Mpls. suburbs meets every day of the year in 3 locations; the MainStreeters group is held in high esteem throughout the USA & beyond.  MainStreeters is an Open AA group which means everyone - no limits - is welcomed.  Should you think you may have a 'drinking problem' or other chem' dep' or use or abuse issue, worry or concern, simply show up to group, arrive early & plan to stay late as there is 'a group b4 the group' & 'a group after the group'.  Offer to be one of the lucky ones to help clean.  I urge you pay close attention & approach one or more people of your same gender who have many years of recovery:  It is to you to ask for help.  Ask to speak 1 to 1 & in privacy.  Choose people who with years of recovery who demonstrate kindness & humility:  A good rule of thumb then is 'do as directed', not do what you think make sense.  Active alcoholics and other active addicts & drug users & abusers tend to be very, very ill people, & liars by definition.  Urge: Be wary of 'free advice'.  Best to you, & I trust you will feel tremendous relief once this matter is laid to rest & long behind you.  You can do this !!      Tricia Dwyer Esq

You absolutely need a criminal defense lawyer.  Also, be very careful what you post on websites, texts, emails and social media.  What you said here is self serving (which means it probably won't hurt you later), but if you say/write the wrong thing and it gets misinterpreted, the prosecution will print it up, mark it as an evidentiary exhibit and use it against you at trial.  Even if you do not intend actually to proceed with a lawyer, you should still invest the money for a consultation because there are a lot of dynamics in play in these types of cases you may not know about, and the prosecution will take full advantage of your lack of familiarity with the law.  For instance, if you take any type of plea bargain that involves entering a straight plea of guilty, you have just given up your right to possess a firearm anywhere in the United States.  This is a big problem for Soldiers, security personnel, law enforcement, and I would suggest any woman who lives in a large city and wants to keep open the option of protecting herself from being assaulted by criminal predators.  Additionally, in many jurisdictions, threats of jail time for a minor first offense may be empty threats used as a scare tactic to get you to take a deal; or if the alleged victim is not cooperating with the prosecution and isn't showing up to court as you indicated, the court may end up dismissing the case for lack of evidence.  But the prosecution likely won't tell you that.  You need to find out about all of these things before you talk to the prosecution, and how the criminal courts work up in Denver.  Leroi, Bryans and Rosmarin (who answered your question earlier) are excellent attorneys who operate in your area.  I would suggest you contact one of them and educate yourself fully as to your options and the legal implications involved with each.  Good luck!

Whatever is left in the Pot after, is then given back equally to all three.  This is a great way to go on vacation with friends or family.

The determination of spousal support is somewhat multi-layered.  There is a temporary spousal support award, then a possible permanent spousal support award depending on the duration of the marriage.  For starters, to give you a basic guideline for temporary spousal support, take 40% of the high wage earner's net monthly income, subtract 50% of the lower wage earner's net monthly income and this should approximately equate to temporary spousal support.  The court looks at expenses, but it really doesn't come into play much.  I hope this is helpful.  John N. Kitta Fremont

There are any number of reasons the ALJ might not ask hypotheticals of a VE at hearing, some good and some bad.  On the good side, if someone meets a Listing at Step 3, their RFC does not matter at all, because the ALJ never reaches questions about PRW at Step 4 or transferable skills at Step 5.  On the (possibly) bad side, if the ALJ thinks she might find an RFC that fits the Grid (i.e., a full range of sedentary work, or light work, etc.), then there is often no need to pose a hypo to the VE, because the answer is dictated by regulation.  You don't need a vocational expert to tell you that someone who can do a full range of sedentary work can do any unskilled sedentary job available.  I want to elaborate on the transferable skills thing, though - there is only a very, very small number of cases where transferable skills FROM sedentary jobs TO sedentary jobs matters to the outcome of a case.  For people under age 50, it doesn't matter.  For people over age 50, it only matters if they're found NOT able to do their old sedentary job, but ABLE to do a different sedentary job that they have transferable skills for.  This is a very rare case - I think I've had this come up once in a few hundred hearings.  I'll give an example: a 52 y/o phone salesperson (sedentary) develops a mental condition such that she cannot work with people.  That gets incorporated into her RFC, and she can't do that PRW at Step 4.  At Step 5, we determine if she fits the "Grid."  If she's limited to sedentary work, the Grid says she wins, even if there are sedentary jobs she can do - unless she has transferable skills to a sedentary job.  Then she loses.    Like I said, this only matters for people over 50, who can't do their old sedentary jobs, who have transferable skills to other sedentary jobs that their RFC would allow them to do.  If you're under 50, transferability doesn't matter.  If you're over 50 and the ALJ finds you can do PRW, transferability doesn't matter.  If you're over 50 and the ALJ finds you can't do any sedentary work at all, transferability doesn't matter.  Best of luck.  Please remember that we're all just giving best guesses here, and that your own representative is best placed to give you accurate and detailed answers based on your circumstances.

I am sorry to hear about your troubles.  PTSD and symptoms of a nervous breakdown can qualify as mental illness; do not deny yourself treatment for fear of stigmatizing yourself.  Get the help you need to stabilize your life. To determine if a conservatorship is necessary, an interested party (such as a family member or in some cases, your attorney) must petition the probate court, and that court (not the criminal judge) asks a doctor to examine you and make specific diagnoses.  The court does not simply rely on statements made in your criminal case.  The doctor must give the probate court the following information under ARS 14-5303. 1. A specific description of the physical, psychiatric or psychological diagnosis of the person. 2. A comprehensive assessment listing any functional impairments of the alleged incapacitated person and an explanation of how and to what extent these functional impairments may prevent that person from receiving or evaluating information in making decisions or in communicating informed decisions regarding that person. 3. An analysis of the tasks of daily living the alleged incapacitated person is capable of performing without direction or with minimal direction. 4. A list of all medications the alleged incapacitated person is receiving, the dosage of the medications and a description of the effects each medication has on the person's behavior to the best of the declarant's knowledge. 5. A prognosis for improvement in the alleged incapacitated person's condition and a recommendation for the most appropriate rehabilitation plan or care plan. 6. Other information the physician, psychologist or registered nurse deems appropriate.

It is time for the executor to do what should have been done 5 years ago. The decedent was a NJ resident, so the will need be filed in the county where he/she died with the Surrogate.  Then, because there is NY property, the NJ executor will need to file for ancillary probate in NY.  This will take some time, and it would be wise to retain a lawyer who does probate in both NJ and in NY...NY is a pain, NJ is pretty easy.  There are many reasons to get this done...one of which is that the insurance company insuring the property may refuse payment if they find out that the deceased is no longer alive.  Often insurance companies will require a new application, especially for the NJ property which sounds like it would now be considered a rental property.  If there is a fire, flood or if someone gets hurt the executor might find themselves drawn into litigation.  Time to get this one done!

I am confused on why you collected SSI, but an application was not filed for Social Security Disability Insurance. When you apply for SSI, the claims representative is supposed to determine if you are eligible for any disability program offered by Social Security. The only thing that I could determine, is that you have worked since 2008, and at the time you applied for SSI, you did not yet have enough work credits to qualify, but as of recently, you had acquired enough credits. My answer is going to be based on that assumption, and also on the assumption that your SSI benefits terminated in 2010 when you were awarded VA compensation.  So if that is the case, your new application for Social Security Disability Insurance can only pay retroactive benefits for at most 12 months prior to the date of the application. If your prior application was not reopened for any reason, then unless your current application for SSDI was filed at some point prior to January 2012, your benefits would not be reduced for SSI that you receive throughout any time in 2010 (that is because there would be no period of time that you would be receiving SSDI for, that you have already received SSI payments).  My major concern really is why you only got SSI to begin with after being discharged from the military. If it was because you worked and earned work credits to qualify for SSDI after being discharged from the military in 2008, than it is not really a concern. It is a little unclear what you are asking.  If you are asking whether you can travel while you are on short term disability, the answer is probably yes, but check the terms of the policy to be sure. I suggest that you not call the insurance company and ask that question, as they might decide to conduct surveillance. Rather, call them or your human resources and ask for a copy of the policy.  If you are asking whether it is legal to travel while on pain medication, the answer is different. If you will be taking narcotic pain medication, it is probably illegal to operate a vehicle while taking this medication, as it probably is considered operating a vehicle under the influence. I cannot think of a reason why having someone drive you, or taking a boat, plane, or train to travel where you are not operating the vehicle would be illegal. However, it might be wise to consult with a criminal attorney in Colorado who will know the laws there just to be sure if that is your concern.

A secret (or sealed) indictment is an indictment whose existence has not been released to the public. All proceedings before the grand jury are done in secret. When the District Attorney (in Massachusetts) presents a case to the grand jury the DA presents the Grand Jury with a letter. The letter is called a bill. The bill is a written request that the grand jury charge a specific person with a crime. If the DA is not certain who the person is they present a "John Doe" letter. If the grand jury votes to charge the person the grand jury marks the bill as a "true bill". A "true bill" is an indictment. If the Grand Jury votes not to charge the person the grand jury marks the bill as a "no bill". The "true bills" or indictments are then delivered by the Grand Jury to the presiding judge in the Superior Court. This is done in open court and the foreperson of the grand jury literally hands the true bills (and the no bills) to the Judge. It is at this point that the District Attorney can ask that a "true bill" (indictment) be sealed or impounded so that the public will not have access to it or be made aware of its existence. That is typically done when the DA fears that a person will flee if they are made aware that an indictment has been filed against them. Your nephew is in jail so it is not likely that he will flee anywhere. The grand jury may absolutely rely on the word of two people who were involved - or even one person who was involved. Good Luck.  Robert D. Lewin, Attorney LEWIN & LEWIN, ATTORNEYS (Practice Limited to Massachusetts) Offices in Malden, MA and Andover, MA

Let me get this straight.  You're a mistress of a married man and he pays you $4,000 to $6,000 per month.  You would like to call this a gift.  An individual can gift you up to $14,000 per year with no reporting requirement on the donor.  If he gives you more than that amount, he must report it.  The real question you must ask yourself is whether the married man would give you $4,000 to $6,000 per month if he was not getting sex in exchange for the money.  If the answer is "no," you're being paid for services rendered, and it is highly likely that the IRS and FTB will view these payments as earned income and fully taxable as such.  The use of paypal or any other mechanism to avoid taxes is fraud and there is no statute of limitations on fraud and the penalties can be substantial.  Accordingly, I would highly recommend that you consult with a tax attorney at your earliest convenience.

If the judge did not continue the discovery cutoff with he or she continued the trial date you are likely well past the discovery motion cutoff.  That date was 15 days before the first date set for trial.  Unless expressly continued, it remains the same date regardless of the trial date moving.  The only way you can now bring a discovery motion is to first get court permission to file it by way of an ex parte application to extend the discovery cutoff for purposes of your motion.  If granted, you can then bring the motion.  If not, you are left with another option.  If it is a party you wish to get the document from, you can timely serve a demand under CCP 1987 for the production of the document at trial.  You need to reasonably particularize the document rather than asking for a broad category as you would in discovery.  On the first day of trial you can raise the issue of your demand with the judge and he or she will order the document produced to the clerk.  You can then look at it.  If the document resides in the possession of a non-party you can subpoena the records to trial.   Good luck to you.

If your intention is to drop it entirely, then it probably makes sense to file the DBA.   I would really just add that merely registering a business with the state or county conveys no right to use that name as a trademark in commerce. The states are really just concerned that no other business name is being registered with the exact same as another already on file. This is not a trademark analysis of course. For example, I could probably register the name of my new tech start up "Boogle" in the state of TX because presumably there is no other business already registered there with that same name. But this does not mean that I am not infringing on the Google trademark which I mostly would be.   Your trademark will be one of if not the most important and valuable business assets you will have and you will ultimately spend more money in support if it than you will anywhere else (advertising, marketing, PR, branding, packaging, etc.). So you owe it to your business and yourself to make sure you handle this properly upfront and the first order of business always starts with a proper and comprehensive clearance.   Whenever you endeavor into investing in a trademark it is very important that you conduct the proper clearance due diligence upfront and before you start spending any money in support of it or submit an application to the USPTO. In the US, this means searching under both federal (USPTO) as well as common law because trademark rights stem from use in this country NOT registration. This means that acquiring a federal registration does not necessarily mean that you are not infringing on another's intellectual property. See the link below for a brief article from Fox Business News on the importance of the due diligence process and our overview guide.   I suggest that you consult with a lawyer in private and discuss your objectives in more detail. You can start by calling around to several for a free phone consultation, get some insights then pick the best fit to work with.   Best regards,  Frank  Natoli-Lapin, LLC

Dear NYC Tenant:  Of course it is not legal to maintain a building anywhere in New York City in a slum-like condition. The New York State Multiple Dwelling Law requires an owner maintain a building in good condition at all times. So does the NYC Housing Maintenance Code. Any tenant in NYC may make a complaint about building conditions by a call to 311.  You cannot take care of the leaks for the last few years, but you can tale of the leaks now. NYC tenants may sue landlords for repairs in the NYC Housing Court.  Look at: http://www.courts.state.ny.us/COURTS/nyc/housing/startinghp.shtml  But what is the point? You are not a rent regulated tenant, and your landlord does not need a reason to choose to refuse a renewal lease. When this lease is up, you will need to move. You are legally free to move at the end of the lease. Since this is not a new event ( as you say "for years') what kept you living in deplorable conditions was your decision not to move out the last time your lease expired?  Old law tenement buildings may have antique utility services ( but is there a real difference with the gas meter in the kitchen or bathroom?) and so, unless there is a code violation or the condition is inherently hazardous, why now be concerned after all the years you lived with the gas meter in the bathroom?
