Although a lawyer can ensure you negotiate your way through an often complicated legal process, a request to change one's name should not be too difficult.  Both the probate and chancery courts in Davidson County handle name changes.  The form for a name change is on the circuit court clerk's website (under probate court - forms) and on the chancery court's website. There is a court fee imposed.  One should file the form and pay the required fee at the appropriate court clerk's office. One must appear in court to request the name change and to assure the Court that the change of name is not to avoid criminal prosecution, to evade creditors, or for any other improper purpose.  You will also need to take a copy of your birth certificate, photo identification (driver license, passport or some other id) and a copy of your social security card.

I can;t answer your question base on "hate crime" and you should not be putting your personal (case) information online.  Strill, as you did I looked and you were convicted of felony battery.  A conviction, for anything, not onyl cannot be sealed / expunged but it precludes you ability to seal or expunge anything else, ever.  Still, following is everything that you want / need to know about the subject...  Sealing is available in a case where you received a withhold of adjudication, and expunction is available in a case which was dismissed, nolle pros'd, no actioned or where you were found to have been not guilty. In Florida you can only seal or expunge one eligible (non-disqualified) offense in your lifetime.   If you look at the following website you will learn everything you ever wanted to know about the sealing / expunction process:   http://www.fdle.state.fl.us/content/getdoc/c83dd888-ef7a-448e-9a96-ba69fc4181f7/Seal-and-Expunge-Home.aspx   I also strongly encourage you to both read my AVVO Legal Guide on Sealing and Expunging Records in FL and watch my YouTube Webisode on Sealing / Expnging records as they both contain valuable information supplemental to this answer and should prove to be helpful to you.  For your convenience the both links follow and are attached at the bottom of this answer:  Please see:  http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/sealing-and-expunging-records-in-fl-a-legal-guide-by-michael-a-haber-esq-miami-criminal-lawyer?published=true  Please see: https://youtu.be/XtndMiwCP84  The procedure is both quite detailed and somewhat painstaking but is also far from being rocket science. You can attempt to navigate it yourself (FDLE has tried to simplify it - again I refer you to the website above) but, assuming your eligibility, any criminal defense lawyer (anywhere in Florida - this can be done remotely and does not necessarily require a local attorney, although a local attorney may or may not be less expensive) will be able to accomplish the task with greater ease and likely in a shorter time period.   That said I suspect that it doesn't much matter where you were arrested, what you were arrested for, what the final disposition was or whether or not you sealed / expunged the record. This is 2015 and we are forehead deep into the internet age, where nothing is private, sacred or truly hidden from public scrutiny.   Sadly, sealing (and expunging) only applies to certain (not even to all) government agencies (for example if fingerprints, mugshots, DNA or anything else - including crime statistics bearing your name or identifying information - were uplaoded to the FBI database then a local Order of Expunction would not effect the Feds) and that it has no effect whatsoever on private (er, extortionist) enterprise, who compile and maintain arrest information and then demand that you pay them off to remove your information from their database and public access. Worse still, after you "buy back your information", then you can count on there being another private company lurking, somewhere, sometime, somehow, just waiting for you to pay them off as well. Its a seemingly never-ending vicious cycle.   For better or for worse you are probably best advised to take the wind out of the sails by admitting your past issues / indiscretions to your present (or potential) employer, lender, landlord, etcetera, rather than waiting for them to find out on their own.   I hope that I have been helpful in answering your question.

If you litigate, under NJ law, in almost all cases the "cutoff date" for equitable distribution is the date that the Complaint for Divorce is filed (with certain exceptions).    However, the two of you can always agree on a different cutoff date. This is the advantage of mediation (as Mr. Lamont points out).    Another good non-litigation option which would allow you to do this is the Collaborative Practice approach.  This is different from (and often preferable to ) Mediation, because in Collaborative practice, each party has his/her own attorney from the outset to represent his/her interests.    Each attorney has been trained in the Collaborative approach, which emphasizes cooperation rather than unnecessary conflict, full disclosure and the exchange of all necessary documentation on an informal expedited basis rather than "formal discovery procedures" which takes a lot longer and cost each client a lot more money. If you want to learn more about the Collaborative approach, you can access the website of the New Jersey Collaborative Law Group, which is www.newjerseycollaborativelawgroup.com.    I believe that you should meet as soon as possible with a very experienced lawyer who devotes his/her entire practice to New Jersey Divorce and Family Law matters and is trained not only in the litigation approach, but also in Mediation and the Collaborative Practice approach.        Go over your situation in detail with the attorney, get educated answers to your questions, and obtain expert guidance as to the best course of action. In my opinion, it will be well worth the cost of the meeting.

You definitely need to contact a WA Attorney. However this may be a starting point.   Vacating Felonies. RCW 9.94A.640 provides for vacating some felony convictions. An offender who has been discharged may request, by motion, that the sentencing court vacate the conviction. But the record of conviction may not be cleared if:  Criminal charges are pending against the offender in any state or federal court;  The conviction was for a violent offense as defined in RCW 9.94A.030 or a crime against persons as  defined in RCW 43.43.830;  The offender has been convicted of a new crime in any state or federal court since discharge;  The offense is a class B felony and less than ten years have passed since discharge;  The offense is a class C felony described in RCW 46.61.502(6) or RCW 46.61.504(6);age 7 of 10 The offense is any class C felony, other than those described in RCW 46.61.502(6) or RCW  46.61.504(6), and less than five years have passed since discharge.   Forms to request that a felony conviction be vacated may be obtained from the courts, online at  http://www.courts.wa.gov/forms/, or from the Administrative Office of the Courts at (360) 705-5328.

People can be downright ridiculous sometimes and it sounds like your ex-husband is exhibiting child-like mean behavior that is likely a result of his own insecurities and feelings of inadequacy.  Nevertheless, I am sure it is exhausting and feels terrible to read nasty emails from someone you once loved and respected enough to have children with and marry.    You might be able to get a temporary restraining order but unless he is threatening harm you wont likely be able to get anything permanent.  You also probably want to consider the costs and hassle of legal action before pursuing the same, but you likely are already aware of those if you have battled this man for years.  Unless you have endless resources - time, money, and energy, cause as I am sure you know you often need all three when pursuing legal action, legal action might not be the route to take.      The easy solution might be changing your email address and not giving him the new email address.  Alternatively, if you dont want to change your email address, you could also filter his mail into a junk folder and only look at it when you feel like you can deal with it with a clear head and not let it influence how you feel about yourself.    One good side of this, it there is a record of what he is doing.  He is actually making it for you by writing everything down.  Make sure to very clearly and shortly telling him you do not appreciate what he is doing and you want it to stop.  Do it in writing so he knows you want his behavior to stop.  Dont engage in it or respond by defending yourself, simply tell him, in a written response, you dont want him to continue to write you emails like this, you dont want him to bad mouth you to your children (because you dont bad mouth him to your children) and that you will not continue to respond to his emails if they continue to be mean.  Thereafter, stop responding if the emails continue to be mean.    Also, print out the emails and keep them in a folder somewhere safe just in case you ever need them to use in court or anywhere else.  If the language gets abusive or threatening get a restraining order immediately.  In most cases you can initially do this yourself without getting an attorney just by going to the courthouse and asking for help at the self-help center.  The first step is often a temporary order which you then have to renew.    As far as your children go, maybe explain to them that daddy is mad at mommy right now and it has nothing to do with them and tell them they dont need to respond when he says bad things about you to them.  If it is very upsetting to the children or to you, it might not be a bad idea to seek out a professional psychologist to speak with and work through it all.    Good luck, and I hope your ex-husband stops this behavior promptly.

I am unclear what you mean by "business as usual" however.  When people appeal the wrong cases, they leave the door open for courts to write opinions like Pino. Many of the attorneys who purport to defend foreclosure cases should not be taking them, do not really understand the issues and potential issues in depth, and are inadequately complacent concerning those judges who are failing to follow the law. and accept a lack of due process afforded to foreclosure defendants.  There are many difficult and complex issues relating to proper defense of these cases, made all the more difficult by the attitude of many of the courts and then further compounded by shoddy defense practices in many instances, which help to convince the judges that defense is typically frivolous.  While there are usually legitimate and valid defenses that can and should be raised, that is often not the case.  We often see people who hired a different law firm initially, and once these people realize the 'defense' firm did not defend them, they come to us.  I am greatly troubled at what I often see was not done when we review these files..

A Pretrial Conference is a meeting between your lawyer (if you have one) and the prosecutor to see if the matter can be resolved without trial, i.e. a plea. This is the time and place where final negotiations take place between the parties. A case can be dismissed at the pretrial conference, but there would have to be good grounds for doing so. Usually cases are dismissed after a successful motion. There is always hope for resolution (either a plea or dismissal) after the Pretrial Conference. Motions can be made and should be made, but they have to be timely and properly filed. That is why it is crucial to have an experienced Michigan criminal defense attorney representing you.

Short answer, you will not be eligible for an expunction in Florida if you received a withhold of adjudication on a felony charge. As for whether your VOP will be dismissed, you mentioned subsequent thefts. I take it you were re-arrested while on probation for two additional thefts. I would be shocked if a judge dismissed a violation of probation based upon two new law violations (the same type of offense mind you - thefts) because you went to bible study, etc. Entering into bible study is not a defense to the new charges, nor is it a defense to a violation of probation. That being said, I am not telling you that no valid defense exists to any of the charges you are facing. Perhaps there is a defense to all of them. I wouldn't know, nor would anyone on this website, without having reviewed the entire case files for each accusation. An attorney would go over your case with a fine-toothed comb looking for defenses, technical or otherwise. Violating felony probation with new law violations based on the same or similar-type charge is treated very seriously by a judge. I think you need to take this seriously as you may very will be facing incarceration. Forget an expungement unless you were somehow able to "undo" the original grand theft and get that dismissed, and also get the two new theft charges dismissed, and also not have any prior criminal history. Your focus should not be on expungement but staying out of jail or prison at this point.

Any absence of more than six months is presumed to disrupt continuous residence required for naturalization. If the break is more than six months but less than one year, the applicant may overcome that presumption by showing unbroken ties to the U,S, such as employment, family, and unimpeded access to abode in the U.S.. If the absence is of more than one year, it will disrupt continuous residence, except for certain cases involving employment with the U.S. government or certain private institutions. In case of such break of more than one year, the applicant wishing to preserve continuous residence needs to file form N-470. No other travel document will preserve continuous residence for purposes of naturalization. The possibility of abandoning residence also needs to be considered but is separate and different. There can be disrution of continuous residence even if there is no abandonment of residence.  Apart from the continuous residence requirement, there is, of course the pysical presence requirement of thirty or eighteen months, depending on whether the applicant qualifies for five or three year naturalization.  A person who is denied naturalization because of disruption of continuous residence may reapply for naturalization four years after re-establishing residence in cases where five years are required, or two years when three are required.  There are other cases involving military duty, for example, where the requirements may be different but which are not pertinent to this particular question

While you and your grandmother may agree that it's time to move to unsupervised visitation, a Judge always decides if and when an order should be modified.  I do understand your confusion.  Usually when DCS opens a case like this, there are a few things going on.    First there is usually a CPS (Child Protective Services division of DCS)case where allegations of dependency and neglect are investigated.  If they are found and CPS believe they are serious enough to need a Court Order to change custody, an immediate change of custody may occur and an action will be filed in the appropriate court to sustain this.  At this point in time, the court will have control over all matters of custody and visitation, and this control will not change until another court is required to take control of the case for some reason or the child turns 18.  After the child has been placed in a home by the court, DCS may also keep an administrative case open (with a case manager called a Family Support Worker) to assist the family with transition and to help address the problems that led to court and DCS involvement.  If the legal custody of the child is placed with a relative, the administrative side moves very fast and is usually quickly closed since DCS isn't always able to pay and spend time to move a child around within the child's family.  (There are statutes and rules that govern this process).    However, the closing of a DCS case does not suspend the previous orders in effect from Court.  Whether DCS has an administrative case open has little-to-no impact on what is required under the Court's order's.  Always follow the current Court Order, regardless of what happened to DCS.  To reiterate, a Judge always decides when a visitation order can and should be modified.  Don't start thinking there are shortcuts to this!   You should contact an attorney in your area to discuss filing necessary pleadings to modify the Court's visitation requirements.  If your grandmother is in agreement with a reasonable proposal, it could be a great success story for you and your family.  Good luck!

Family law matters are purely a matter of state law.  The Hague Convention exists for the purpose of expediting issues arising in them.  If the marriage was lawful and properly performed in the country where it was solemnized--that is to say you have the equivalent of a marriage license and a certificate of marriage--then you can obtain the divorce here.    The sticky point is getting service of process on the other partner to the marriage, and that is where Hague comes in.  Over 20 years ago, and before Hague, I handled a case where the husband was an American contractor in Viet Nam during the conflict, married a Vietnamese woman according to the domestic law of Viet Nam, returned with him to the US as a part of the last-minute evacuation, and then decided she wanted to return, and did.  We filed the case here, obtained personal service of process using the graces of the Swiss Embassy and resolved the issues.  It was important because the parties had a child who stayed here with the father.  All this is to say it can be done, but it takes time and thorough attention to the issue of jurisdiction.

How frightening!  I must concur with Mr. Cogan.  Your first priority must be meeting with a criminal defense attorney for a potential defense to murder charges.  I noticed that you mentioned in  the comments section that you cannot afford an attorney.  First, if you are charged with anything,  you have a Constitutional right to have an attorney appointed to you at taxpayer expense.  But that won't be until you are actually embroiled in a prosecution.  For the moment, you should still consult with someone in a private confidential setting.  Many attorneys will offer low-cost or free consultations.  Nothing you say to your attorney can be used against you.  Even in the setting of a free consultation, the attorney will be ethically bound to keep all your secrets.  That's why you confine all your conversations to confidential settings.  As for how long the government may keep your things.  Unfortunately, the answer to that is that they may keep it for a "reasonable" period of time under the 4th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  What's reasonable?  Who knows?  You have to come up with arguments, from the case law I know, many years can be deemed reasonable depending on the facts of the case.  This can only be frightening and intimidating.  Best of luck to you!

I normally recommend that most people that are applying for Social Security should obtain an attorney to help them with the process. The Social Security Disability process is difficult, and part of what an attorney can do is advise you of the requirements of the program. My concern is that you say that you are at the fourth tier of the Social Security Disability process, if this means that you have already been denied by an Administrative Law Judge, even with the help of an attorney, it will be very difficult to be approved for benefits.  Social Security allows claims to be reviewed de novo at the initial application stage, reconsideration and at the Administrative Law Judge Hearing stage. This means that at each of these stages, the person deciding your claim can disregard the prior denials. They do not have to explain why it was wrong that you were previously denied. At the Appeals Council stage (the normal fourth step), Appeals Council can only determine if the Administrative Law Judge had substantial evidence to support the conclusion that was made. This means that even if Appeals Council would have made a different decision, if there is any support in the record for the conclusion the ALJ made, and the ALJ did a good job of documenting why the particular decision was made, Appeals Council cannot reverse the ALJ decision.   Typically, new evidence is not considered at the Appeals Council level. This means that if now an attorney can get an opinion from your doctors that you were disabled, if this same opinion could have been obtained prior to the hearing, it would not be considered when Appeals Council reviews your claim. Appeals Council is normally stuck with just the same evidence the ALJ had to rely on when the decision was made. (The rare exception is when Appeals Council determines evidence is new and material).  If someone contacts me after they have been denied at the ALJ level, it is normally very difficult to do anything to help. I consistently find that when the ALJ issued the decision, the potential client had not obtained supportive medical evidence, and there a very few medical opinions in their file. This is why it is important that you obtain an attorney at the earliest point possible (even before you apply). When I represent someone at an ALJ hearing, I do everything possible to get the most supportive evidence in the file before the hearing. This allows me to rely on this evidence even during an Appeals Council Appeal.  I would highly recommend that you contact an attorney immediately to discuss these issues. It is also important to note that if you are under the age of 50, it really doesn't matter that you cannot perform work you have performed in the past. When you are under 50, even if it is determined that you cannot perform your past work, you must still prove that your condition is severe enough to prevent you from performing all full-time work.  Even if you have a statement from one of your doctors indicating that you are disabled, these statements have little value in a Social Security proceeding. Disabled is a legal term in Social Security Disability Law. The finding of being disabled is reserved for Social Security. A conclusion from your doctor that you are disabled, has no meaning unless the doctor explains what that means. For example, for a physical condition, your doctor needs to explain how you are limited in sitting, standing, walking, lifting, bending, crouching, using your arms, using your legs, and concentrating. There should be a detailed explanation of these limitations, with references to the diagnosis that causes the limitations, and citation to test results that show the condition exists.   If you have not yet contacted an attorney, I would suggest that you do so immediately. Please remember that you usually only have 60 days from the date of the decision to file an appeal, if you have not yet appealed your decision, you will probably want to do so as soon as possible.

Yes.  They can rely on mistakes of fact (thinking your brake lights are malfunctioning when they are not).  They are not allowed to rely on mistakes of law (example: thinking your registration is incorrectly displayed when it is actually legally posted) and such a case would be thrown out.  You should talk with an attorney about the stop, and consider challenging the stop.  Officers generally are found credible if they testify that they believed something, but you may be able to challenge his assertions by presenting your own evidence that his stop was unreasonable under the circumstances.  For example, some stops are recorded by a patrol car video camera and you can request a copy of that video footage (not true in all cases).  Find a local attorney and request a consultation to discuss the options for challenging the police action.

At 22, you are an adult tenant; your parents are your landlords. Thus, they can't simply kick you out with only 3 days' notice. In Michigan, they must seek eviction. That begins with notice to leave within 30 days. After that, if you're still there, they'd have to go to district court to seek a writ of eviction.

Your suspicion is correct.  If you move forward, you will have to prove that the waxing center was negligent in the manner in which they sterilized and maintained their equipment.  You will also have to prove that their negligence was a "cause" of your injury and you have to specifically identify your injury.  You have focused on the primary issue, which is "causation."  As soon as you say "that person caused me harm," the defendant gets to explore all potential factors that could have caused the harm.  Here, since this is potentially a STD, the defendant will be able to explore the other avenues that might have caused  the disease.  This can feel quite invasive.  It might include a review of your medical records as well as a physical exam.  It may also include deposition testimony from your former partners.  The good new,is that you do not have to prove absolutely that the scissors were the cause.  All you have to prove is that the waxing center"s acts or omissions were more likely than not a substantial factor in causing your condition.  More likely than not simply means greater than 50% probability and substantial factor more or less means something that is not trivial or remote.  It would be an uncomfortable case for you to pursue, but you may have a good chance of success. Thank you for posting your question.  Best of luck to you.

The LLC is best treated as a disregarded entity rather than an S corporation.  It is cheaper to operate and only requires you to file a schedule C on your 1040 rather than the separate 1120S.  I truly think would be a big mistake to make an S election except under rare circumstances.  In order to make an S election you would have to file a 2553 form with the IRS within 90 days of formation.  There are a lot of reasons why the S election is not good.  Besides the extra cost for tax preparation and accounting, most states require you to pay disability and unemployment taxes on your own income even though you will not be able to collect it.  Please, instead of trying to do this yourself, contact a good tax and business attorney to help you with this.  Good luck!  Ron Cappuccio

Even though California is an "anti-deficiency" state, where a foreclosing lender can not pursue the deficiency after a non-judicial foreclosure sale, the laws of the state where the properties are located apply to the foreclosure situation, in this case Missouri. The strange thing is, I believe Missouri is also a anti-deficiency state, so you may have a good defense. You mentioned they are "attempting collection." Even when a creditor has does not have a legally enforceable debt, they often continue to collect nonetheless because they can often coerce people to give them money. This could be a situation of an overly aggressive collection agency with no valid legal claim simply trying to strongarm you with scare tactics and intimidation in order to get some money. It wouldn't be a bad idea to have an attorney take a closer look and analyze your situation. My office does this type of foreclosure defense and collection defense work, and we'd be happy to speak with you further. Please feel free to call my office anytime.

So long as you are within the traditional public forum, you CANNOT be punished for your decision to carry a provocative sign of the sort you describe therein.  Do give careful thought and planning if you intend to do what you propose.  The sidewalk leading to the front door of a courthouse is not, typically, treated the same as the sidewalk on the outer perimeter of the block, running adjacent to the street there.  So be sure that you are in a place that actually is treated, in First Amendment terms, as a traditional public forum property.  In a case in which i served as co-counsel at the US Supreme Court, US v. Kokinda, the Supreme Court held that Postal Service regulations WERE CONSTITUTIONAL in their application to the soliciation of donations on the sidewalk that led from the post office parking lot to the post office building.  The Court distinguished that walkway from the city sidewalk running along the streetside in front of the same post office.  So you can see that it can be a ticklish matter and one in which uncertainty can produce unexpected and unfortunate results.  I have included a link, below, to a legal guide on the exercise of First Amendment rights in public places.

Florida has 20 different Judicial Circuits, each of which deals with cases in its own manner. Moreover, each of those Judicial Circuits has a given number of criminal court Judges (each of whom is unique), as well as its own State Attorney's Office (each of which has its own policies and procedures), and a bunch of Assistant State Attorneys (who, although they operate on guidelines as established by their office, are each sentient and independent persons), and each case has its own set of variables ("free radicals" if you will) all of which combine to make it impossible to predict what will happen in a given case.   Not knowing anything (other than your proffer) about the relevant issues in your husband's case (i.e. the facts and circumstances of the case, of your husband himself, your family, the Assistant State Attorney and his Judge) I cannot offer you "realistic" advise or odds, but I can say that his original charges were serious, he faced a lot of time then and now, possession of a firearm ("possession" is loosely defined) is quick VOP (standard condition of probation "(m)(1)" is plain as day - for your convenience I have attached a link to the standard conditions of probation below) and that none of that looks good for him.  However, he should have earned some degree of good will over the past 7 years and he is apparently an otherwise good and supportive family man.  While that is far from any sort of guarantee of freedom it is also precisely what criminal defense attorneys deal with on a regular basis (if it were pretty then it wouldn't be criminal defense litigation).  In this case you have already hired a lawyer (presumably one who knows the facts and circumstances of the case, of your husband, your family, the Assistant State Attorney and hopefully the Judge), and s/he is the only person to whom you should turn and upon whom you should rely.  The simple fact is that no one else on the planet is sufficiently versed to give you a "realistic" answer.   I hope that I have been helpful in answering your question.

Dear Brooklyn Tenant:  If the apartment is Rent Stabilized, the landlord is under compulsion of law to offer a lease renewal to a tenant every cycle where the current lease is ready to end and to do so within a confined period beginning 150 days before the current lease expires and not less than 90 days before the lease comes to an end. If the tenant always chooses a one year lease, then the tenant faces for the next year of tenancy the legal rate of increase allowed for a one year lease. Usually, choosing a two year lease renewal moderates the rent over the term of the two year period, but does lock the tenant in for a two year lease when the tenant desires the ability to pack and move afforded by the shorter one year lease. But over time (five as you pointed out) successive one year lease renewals would increase the rent faster than taking a lease two years at a time.  Landlords should not skip the legal obligation to offer the renewal lease because there are penalties should a tenant challenge the landlord for failing to offer a renewal lease. There is no true process for a landlord to offer a renewal lease without providing for the rates for a rent increase for a one year lease or a two year lease. The landlord must register the new rent to maintain the trail of rent over time (the "Rent History") and comply with the process for rent registration. A landlord may offer a tenant a preferential rent (that is a rent lower than the legal rent) and if offered and accepted, the preferential rent does not reduce the legal rent and does not carry over to the next renewal lease unless specifically provided in the preferential lease rider.   If you are concerned whether your written documents (leases, riders and renewal leases) are "normal" gather your papers together and consult with an attorney.

Hello,  All of these questions should have been adequately addressed by your employer's attorney, the one who prepared and filed the I-140 on your and your employer's behalf.  In case your employer filed the I-140 without the professional help of an experienced business immigration lawyer (which is a scary thought), here are the answers you are looking for: 1.  Within a week to 10 days after USCIS having received the I-140 "package" at the "Service Center", a case filing "receipt" will be issued, namely a Form I-797 "Notice of Action", which will also include a distinct case number, which can be used for tracking and all inquiries.  Note that I-140's take approximately ("give or take") 4-6 months to be processed and the "trajectory" of the case can be followed by registering for email updates at www.uscis.gov.   2.  Your employer can check with his online banking statement whether the fee payment check has been cashed or not. Usually USCIS "cashes" that fee check within a week (7 days) from package arrival at the Service Center.  Should the fee be wrong, not enough or even too much, the entire package will be returned within 2-3 weeks, with instructions to place that Rejection Notice (which will already have the case number) on top and include the correct fee. Hopefully the employer has sent the "I-140 package" via Courier, such as FedEx for instance, and requested "confirmation" via "hard (albeit "indirect") signature. "

You should retain counsel as soon as possible, especially as there is a Motion for Summary Judgment pending.   A Motion for Summary Judgment is brought under 735 ILCS 5/2-1005(c) and states "[t]he judgment sought shall be rendered without delay if the pleadings, depositions, and admissions on file, together with affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law."        If you insist on proceeding pro se (representing yourself), then respond in writing and file  the response with the Clerk of the Circuit Court prior to the response deadline. Deny those facts which have been alleged that are untrue. Additionally, make sure you send a copy of your response to opposing counsel and file a proof of service swearing you served it properly. As to whether exhibits should be attached or presented in Court, that is the attorney's preference.   I again implore you to hire an attorney to fight this battle for your home. I have seen too many pro se litigants fail to follow the nuances of the law and prejudice their case. Best of luck to you.
You may use AVVO to locate an attorney able to help you or feel free to contact me.

As stated by Mr. Salcido, the terms of your agreement govern, insofar as they comport with the ethical rules of the Utah State Bar.  Hypothetically, if your attorney withdrew from your case and was not fairly compensated for work performed up to that point, he likely has a lien against your case. That does not mean, however, that he is entitled to 35% of the settlement. It means he is entitled UP to 35% of the settlement. He must show documented hours and costs put forward in your case, and charge a reasonable amount for those hours (the amount should be detailed in your agreement). It may be that you owe him for #X hours of documented work at $XXX.00 dollars per hour up to 35% value of your recovery. Hence, if he withdrew early, or cannot show substantial work, and the recovery is substantial, your attorney is likely owed less than that 35%. Do not, however, take the stance that you owe him nothing. He should be fairly compensated for work he can show he did on your behalf.

There are three separate ways to run the guidelines: 1) Where a  nonresidential parent spends less than one third of the time with his or her child, the guidelines are run once with the nonresidential parent as payor and the residential parent as payee 2) Where parents enjoy joint physical custody (50/50 time splitting), the guidelines are run twice, once the way outlined in paragraph 1 and once with the parents' payor/payee rolls switched.  The parent who owes more pays the other the difference. 3) Where the nonresidential parent spends more than 1/3 of the time but less than 50% of the time with the child, the average of calculation one and calculation two are taken.  When a parent spends SIGNIFICANTLY less than 1/3 of the time with a child, a judge is given discretion to deviate.  When a parent has EXTRAORDINARY expenses associated with travel to see the child, a judge is given discretion to deviate.  There aren't hard and fast or black and white rules about how the deviation is calculated, nor when it is warranted.  What is weighed most heavily is the best interests of the child and how to minimize the financial impact of his/her parents' maintaining separate households for the child.

When your employment with A terminates, you are immediately out of status and you may not re-enter US with the original O1.  Your new employer, Company B, must file a new I-129 Petition for you first, to transfer your O1 visa to them. Once the transfer is approved, you will receive a new approval notice for Company B.  You may then travel out of the country. I do not recommend that you travel before your O1 is fully transferred to the new employer. I would not do any travel during the pendency of the transfer period between companies (remember, you can file for the transfer EXPEDITED [15 business days] by using Form I-907 together with the usual I-129 for the visa transfer [called Request for Premium Processing] and paying the extra $1225 USCIS fee, but it's worth it).

It may appear as if you are seen conflicting answers here.  My take on the law is that the compensation disability payments are not payable for the first seven (7) days of disability unless you are disabled for 22 days or more.  If at any point from this accident, your days disabled reach 22, not necessarily consecutive, you are then retroactively paid workers' compensation disability benefits for the first seven days that were withheld.  Section 440.12, Florida Statutes (2013) provides in pertinent part "compensation is not allowed for the first 7 days of the disability‰Û_ However, if the injury results in disability of more than 21 days, compensation shall be allowed from the commencement of the disability."  Also note that by disability, we do not mean you have to have been taken totally off work.  The Florida Workers' Compensation Law, chapter 440 of Florida Statutes, defines "disability" as "‰Û_ Incapacity because of the injury to earn in the same or any other employment the wages which the employee was receiving at the time of the injury."  Therefore, if pre-accident you were working five days per week eight hours per day and because of your workers' compensation injury, your workers' compensation doctor limits you to four hours per day and you therefore work a four hour day and in doing so earn less than you did pre-accident working an eight-hour day, I believe that is a day of disability.

As has been stated, an ordinance violation means you are looking at a fine, not jail time.  An attorney such as myself who practices in Lake and McHenry Counties can help you if you so desire.  What to keep in mind with this, or any local ordinance violation is basically because the whole issue of going to jail is off the table, the Village or local municipality has a lower standard for proving their case.  The Supreme Court of Illinois has ruled that "[c]onvictions for municipal ordinance violation are to be established by a clear preponderance of the evidence and do not require proof beyond a reasonable doubt." City of Chicago v. Joyce, 38 Ill. 2d 368, 373, 232 N.E.2d 289, 291 (1967).    Keep this in mind if you take this matter to trial.  This does not mean you cannot win, just that the state has a lesser burden.  Good luck.

It is unfortunate that your ex-spouse has chosen to behave this way, as ultimately it is your children that get hurt by his behavior.  It is always important following a divorce where minor children are involved to keep records and document the behaviors of the other parent, if you believe custody or visitation will ever been in issue later on.  You should keep records contemporaneously of when he is missing his visitation, how and if you are notified, and your attempts to encourage and facilitate visitation.  If your ex-husband continues to willfully and intentionally not exercise visitation, you may be able to file a Petition to Terminate Parental Rights and have your husband adopt the children.  In Tennessee you cannot terminate a parent's rights until there is someone ready to step in and adopt.  If it has been more than four months without him providing support or visiting with the children, then you would have grounds to file a Petition to Terminate his parental rights; however, there is a high burden in these kinds of cases and the burden is on you to first prove grounds for terminate by clear and convincing evidence and then you must prove that it is in the best interests of the children for his rights to be terminated.  Also, he is entitled to representation by an attorney for this type of proceeding and the court will appoint an attorney for him if he cannot afford one.  I am not sure that Petition for Contempt is what you would want to file, as he could simply start exercising his visitation and then no longer be in contempt; however, if he has the ability to pay his child support and is willfully not paying it the Court can hold him in contempt and he may even be incarcerated for his contempt.  You could also file a Petition to Modify that parenting plan, although you may want to give him more time of not exercising his parenting time before doing so and continued efforts on your part to attempt to encourage and facilitate visitation.  You could then modify the Permanent Parenting Plan to reflect his willful and continued lack of visitation with the children upon a finding of the Court of a substantial and material change in circumstances and that the modification is in the best interests of the children.  Of course, you would want to make sure that you appear in the best light possible before the Court on such a serious matter as this and that you have done nothing to discourage or dissuade the father from exercising his parenting time, as the Court would take an unfavorable view if this were the case.  I wish you and your family the best of luck in this matter and am sorry that both you and your children are going through this.  I would advise you to speak with an attorney in your area to discuss your case in greater detail and evaluate your options on how you may proceed.

If I were you, I wouldn't listen to the prodding of the "free" public defender to "make a deal", would instead hire a reputable private criminal defense attorney in your town and threaten to take this all the way to trial if necessary...  As for the immigration law consequences, I wouldn't worry..  You will be able to renew your H-1B in the US without any problems - it will again be the "employer's" petition, nothing will be asked from you, aside from your passport validity date, as well as your educational and/or work experience qualifications, accompanied by your tax returns, W-2 and 3 latest pay stubs (and that too, only if you happen to be from the Indian subcontinent, otherwise forget about it).  The only "issue" of (possible inadmissibility) you will face when applying for the extension/renewal of your H-1B visa at your home country US consulate or in Vancouver, Calgary, Toronto or Ottawa (I dare not say Tijuana..)  But that too will be easily resolved, with your immigration lawyer providing you with one heck of a "Legal Memorandum of Law" explaining, with case decision citations to boot, why you should not be deemed inadmissible.   But for that, and to make sure to sustain as little immigration damage or injury as possible, Fight!!  Don't succumb to the temptation of a "free" public defender who will only give you 5 minutes of his/her time and urge you to "make a deal" with the prosecution..

Creating a game based upon the intellectual property of another could lead to copyright and/or trademark infringement.  Does your game look/sound/feel like the other game?  Would statements in the game, such as 'based on XYZ,' lead parties to believe the game is licensed or approved by XYZ?    However, nothing prevents you from creating your own game from scratch that deals with a similar theme/subject/etc. as a pre-existing game.    For example, a game where you create a world.    Bottom line, it sounds like you should have an intellectual property attorney review your game.

Dear 72 in Cincinnati:  RELAX.  Quit beating yourself up.  Read up on the archives here on AVVO and you will quickly learn that most AVVO attorneys would tell you to IGNORE the civil demand letter you will receive.  They threaten to sue you civilly if you don't pay, but they will not for a variety of reasons.  There is no benefit to paying other than if it relieves your guilty conscience.  I recommend that you NOT pay at all, or if you must, call them up and offer to pay only $50 because you are elderly and likely on a fixed income.  IF you have the emotional fortitude, simply throw the letters away.  IF and only IF they file an actual lawsuit (they won't) you can pay then.  IF the police were not involved you will not have to go to court unless you receive a notice to appear in court.  I doubt any prosecutor would want to file criminal charges agains a 72 year old woman for stealing $6.00 worth of groceries from Wal-Mart, 2 weeks ago.  Don't steal again, and you'll be just fine.  IGNORE the civil demand--they're trying to steal from you now.  Don't let them.

It sounds to me like you are currently in the middle of an court action in which you are requesting the court to allow you to relocate. In that regard you have followed the statute, asked the father first, he said no, filed your Petition for Relocation, gave notice to the father who timely filed a response objecting to your move, and a hearing was set. As part of your case you have to present evidence as to why it is in the "best interests" of your child for you to relocate, and you have decided to call your child as a witness at the hearing. So what do you do?  First you must file a motion called "Motion to Allow Child Testimony" and request a hearing on that motion PRIOR to your hearing date coming up. If there is not enough time to allow for it to be scheduled on the calendar before it, then you should ask for it to be heard/scheduled first on your hearing date. If the court hears your motion, you will have to show that the testimony is relevant, that the child has a certain level of maturity and can understand right from wrong, etc., It can be a very complicated process. Some judges have no issue speaking with a child, but they generally will do it in-camera. That means no one else is allowed in except the judge, the child and a court reporter. The judge asks the child questions he wants to about moving.  Rather than going on that, you should be preparing to show the judge why the move is in the best interest of the child. For instance, your moving for a job that is going to give you with the ability to better provide for your child. The move allows you to put the child in private school or a better school, or a magnet school which focuses on an interest of the child, the move allows the child to be closer to a family member (I.e., like a grandpa who is there to do father like things with him camping, fishing, playing ball) and become a positive role model while his dad is in prison.  All of these response are examples of how the move is beneficial to the child. It is likely you are going to have to bring up why dad is in prison. For how long? Does the child regularly visit the father. If so, how do you propose to continue that?  So you see, it becomes very complicated when one parent wants to move and the other doesn't agree. If you have not retained a lawyer you really need to do that as soon as possible. Good luck.

You may have a case for discrimination due to pregnancy and/or for violation of the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)'s non-retaliation requirement.  Pregnancy discrimination is unlawful under California and federal law.   FEDERAL RIGHTS:  In 1978, Congress amended the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII 42 U.S.C. å¤å¤ 2000e to 2000e‰ÛÒ17, by passing the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.   Under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, "discrimination" means to treat a pregnant employee differently from non-pregnant employees, and adversely. The employee must be able to make a connection between the discriminatory treatment and the protected status (being pregnant). In other words, the employee will have to show that her pregnancy is reason the employer is treating her adversely. There are various ways to do this. Negative comments from supervisors or management; a sudden change in treatment (for the worse) as soon as or shortly after the employer learns about the pregnancy or the effects of pregnancy; or other incriminating conduct. Note it is not unlawful for an employer to apply the same leave of absence policy to pregnant and non-pregnant employees.   For information on pregnancy discrimination, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/types/pregnancy.cfm   For information on the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/pregnancy.cfm   This law is enforced by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). www.EEOC.gov   Under federal law, leave taken for an employee's incapacity due to pregnancy, childbirth or related medical conditions is governed by the Family and Medical Leave Act, 29 U.S.C. section 2101 et seq. (FMLA), just like leave for any other "serious health condition" of an employee.  See my Avvo guide to the FMLA for more information: http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=family-and-medical-leave-fmla-summary-of-key-provisions.  CALIFORNIA RIGHTS:  California employers must comply with federal law, as above, and also must comply with state law.  The California pregnancy disability leave law, Government Code section 12945(a) (PDLL), is part of the California Fair Employment and Housing Act, California Government Code sections 12900, et seq. (FEHA). The PDLL requires employers to provide employees up to four months of unpaid leave for disability caused by pregnancy, childbirth or a related medical conditions.  Under some circumstances, an employer may be required to transfer an employee affected by pregnancy, childbirth or related medical conditions to a different job.  California has its own family and medical leave law, the California Family Rights Act, Government Code section 12945.2 (CFRA).  It is substantially similar to the FMLA, but an employee's incapacity due to pregnancy, childbirth or related medical condition is not included in the definition of "serious health condition."  This is usually beneficial to the employee because CFRA leave and pregnancy disability leave are two separate and distinct rights under California law.  They do NOT run concurrently, as they do under the FMLA.  Instead, an employee in California may take four months of PDLL plus 12 weeks of family leave, provided of course that the employee meets the other conditions of these laws.  Please look at my guide to unlawful discrimination:  http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=what-is-unlawful-employment-discrimination--california-law which should help you understand lawful and unlawful discrimination, how to enforce your rights, and time limits.    Employment law is complicated and fact specific.  You may wish to speak with an experienced plaintiffs employment attorney.  To find a plaintiffs employment attorney in California, please go to the web site of the California Employment Lawyers Association (CELA).  CELA is the largest and most influential bar association in the state for attorneys who represent working people.  The web site is www.cela.org,

The American Competitiveness in the Twenty-First Century Act, provides that approved I-140[1] petition for employment based green card would remain valid even when you change jobs, if:    Employment based Adjustment of Status(I-485)[2] has been filed and remained unadjudicated (pending) for 180 days or more; and the new job is in the same or similar occupational classification as the job for which the certification or approval was initially made.  If you have complied with the above statutory requirements, adjudicators shall not deny applications for adjustment of status on the basis that you changed jobs

The other attorneys on this question are mistaken. There is no requirement that a 3-day notice be served in the same fashion as a summons. All that needs to happen is the person serving it needs to "nail and mail" as they call it.  In terms of using your deposit as last month's rent... you have to imagine it from the Landlord's position. How does he know you're not going to destroy the place this month before you leave? That is why he is holding onto the deposit as a deposit and not last month's rent.  Unfortunately, the fact that you improved the unit doesn't help you much. It certainly helps you in terms of not having deductions from you deposit but in terms of trying to apply the deposit to last month's rent--that is prohibited in the lease. A violation of the lease means an unlawful detainer.  The good news is this: an unlawful detainer action can't happen when possession is no longer at issue. If you move out at the end of the month, the unlawful detainer will turn into a normal lawsuit. At that point, he can only go after you for damages... and assuming your deposit is enough to cover last month's rent... WALA! there you go. He keeps your deposit and indirectly you've accomplished what you've wanted. Just make sure you don't get an eviction or judgment on your record. Go to Court and say you've moved out and that possession isn't at issue. Also point out that he has money of yours so no judgment should be issued. I know if I were representing you--judges that know me would let you get away with that.  long winded, but I hope that helps.

If you mean that you are now losing your SSI because your husband was recently approved for Social Security Disability Insurance, and the only reason you are losing your SSI is because of the amount of his Social Security Disability Insurance, according to my research you should not have to repay SSI payments that you received before he was approved. As of the date that he was approved, and received the lump sum payment from Social Security, you may no longer be eligible for SSI.  The lump sum amount, even though it is payment for months in the past, is not counted against in you the month that you already received payments, but he was not yet paid, it is only counted against you beginning in the month that he actually received the benefit (if he only qualified for SSI, this would be slightly different as you would then qualify for couple's benefits, so both of your benefits would be recalculated for the past-due months).   So if he were approved for benefits in July 2014, and Social Security determined that he was eligible for Past-Due Benefits beginning July 2013, even though he is now going to receive a lump sum that includes the months from July 2013 until June 2014, since he didn't actually receive those payments until July 2014, based on my research, Social Security will only count the income in the month the money was actually received.  If you receive a notice of overpayment for the situation discussed above, I would suggest that you consult with an attorney to determine the accuracy of the information. If you are actually trying to ask a different question, please feel free to clarify in the comments, and I will try to respond accordingly.

A court can in fact grant you a guardianship over your grandson and granddaughter. The suggestion that you file an Application for Appointment of Guardian for your granddaughter now is probably a good one, since she has been with you all of her life. By the time that process is finished, you will be familiar with the requirements and it should be much easier to complete the process for your grandson.  I agree with Ms. Lowry that you should probably wait until your grandson has been with you for six months, although I do not see anything in the law that requires you to wait. You will want to be appointed guardian over the person (both your grandchildren) and their estates, which entitles you to manage any monies they may earn or receive, until they are 18.   There are reporting requirements that the Court will require however, so you should be prepared to comply with the Court's requirements. I am quite certain you will need the assistance of a lawyer to adequately complete all of the legal requirements. Best of luck to you.

Your child support is not affected by your purchase of a home.  He has no interest in the home, as it is not being purchased jointly and he is not contributing.  However, your purchase of a home does not provide you with a basis to decrease your child support obligation.  Child support is based on each party's income , overnight parenting time, and the cost of certain child-related expenses that can be included in the guidelines.  Even if you sell the house and realize a profit your ex will not be entitled to a piece of it unless there are child support arrears that exist at the time of the sale and child support is being paid through probation.   If any arrears exist through probation at the time of the sale those arrears will be satisfied to the extent possible by any net proceeds prior to any money being distributed to you at the closing.

25 years on a grand theft is pretty harsh. If this was a state case then she must have been charged with the 1st degree felony version of grand theft. This actually happens a lot. Prosecutors do not even have to make plea offers, but it is common practice.  As the other attorneys have stated it is the timing of the offer. If she was offered 10 and refused it or never accepted it, then come sentencing the State can ask for whatever they want. They are not bound.  If the state induced her to plea on the same date of her plea by stating that they would only argue for 10 years, she probably stood a chance of filing a motion to withdraw her plea, but the time to file that motion is long passed.  I think her only real option is to seek clemency through the governors office.

One of the eight elements of habitable housing is protection from the weather. See RCW 59 18 115(2). Your landlord has a duty to see that the drainage around your rental is not directing water into the basement and causing mold. If this is happening to you, your landlord may owe you relocation. There is a separate Seattle-specific ordinance that gets you an additional two month's rent on top of the State's damages. RCW 59.18.085(3) says what you are entitled to under these circumstances and it is a lot more than what your landlord is offering.   In order to invoke this remedy, you have to have proof that you advised your landlord in writing of the problems with the property. If you do not have such a letter, write one now.  Then wait ten days (see RCW 59 18 070, 090) and contact Jim Metz who is the lead in the City's Office of Code Compliance/Tenant Rights. Mr. Metz or one of his assistants will advise your landlord if the City is going to make him relocate you. Damaged moldy furniture is tough, but not impossible to value.  Remember that mold is just a symptom of water intrusion. And whether or not he is insured against mold damage is not your problem, and it does not shift the burden of proof.   Elizabeth Powell

Life insurance is payable to the designated beneficiaries.  Life insurance is also usually not a probate asset.  Probate would only be involved if there were a beneficiary who was a minor and whose trust and guardianship activities might have to be monitored to make sure Junior is protected.   You say there was a Will.  If there is no mention of Life Insurance in the Will then look at the beneficiary designations on the life policy.  If it just names people, then it is NOT a probate asset.    You should consult an attorney who is familiar with tax issues.  If this asset has been gaining interest for 24 years, that may be taxable to you, and you obviously don't want a severe case of bracket creep in a single year caused by a huge one-time surge of income.  An attorney-CPA or an LL.M. in Taxation is probably best.

Dear Glens Falls Home Owner:  Owners and tenant of homes in manufactured home parks have a bundle of special rights unique in many aspects to living in a MHP.  You should check the lease or sales contract to start. Most contracts provide that the purchase of the home is in an "as is" condition and the purchaser inspected the home prior to making the decision to purchase. You also must look to the rental agreement with the MHP. The obligation to pay the rent that your home sits upon, may have no connection with the habitability of the home, especially if you purchased rather than leased the home.  Consult with a local attorney. Meanwhile, read about the rights of New York tenants living in MHP at:  http://www.lawhelpny.org/issues/housing/mobile-home-park-tenants?location=all  http://www.nyshcr.org/Publications/housinginformationseries/mhpinfo.htm

Mr. Harvey hit on some good points, so I will just touch on a few key issues not addressed:  1) Do you have a lease? If so, then the Protecting Tenants Act of 2009 (federal law)  will provide some protection for you (you will be considered a bona fide tenant and the lease will have to be honored). If you do not have a lease, then under the Act you must be given 90 days prior to vacating the premises. So to answer your question about time to move out, yes you have time. The bank will have to re-schedule the sale and then proceed to sale. Once this happens, then they will begin the eviction process where the above will apply (your rights as a tenant). The intent of the law in FL is to prohibit exactly what you are worried about - not having time or notice to move out. Make sure you keep track of what is going on, including when the next sale date will be. This should give you a pretty good idea of how much time you are looking at (figure at least 90 days from the sale date assuming you do not have a valid lease - if you have been receiving foreclosure papers at the house, then you should receive the notice from Plaintiff's attorney of the new sale date). The eviction process will take time (at least a month, as a very conservative estimation) and the bank will have to obtain a writ of eviction against you and your family. So you have time, which is good. You need to start thinking about where you are going to move and will need money for moving costs (cash for keys discussed below will help in this regard!).  2) Generally speaking, you can negotiate for $ before your lease has ended (called "cash for keys"). Strategically, you should try to negotiate with the bank (or the attorneys for the bank) a decent amount of $ before your lease is up to get the most money possible, since the bank will not want to wait until the end of the lease and will be more likely to offer a decent amount of $ to vacate the occupants from the property. A good amount is anywhere from 3k to 5k - the idea being you want to receive enough to cover moving costs and first month rent and security at your new location. Be careful of some "eviction agents" that will try to persuade you that you have to move out right away. Know your rights and do not listen to these unscrupulous individuals.    3) If you gave your Landlord a security deposit, try to get this back from the Landlord prior to leaving. It will become harder to obtain the longer you wait.   4) In the event you are FORCED to leave prior to the expiration of your lease,  you may have a cause of action against the Landlord for breach of  the covenant of quiet enjoyment (depending on the amount of damages, this may be a small claims matter).   Do yourself a favor and contact the local bar association to go over your options as far as retaining an affordable attorney. It will make all this much easier for you to navigate and should provide ease of mind. Good luck to you and your family.

If you could provide a bit more information about who is disabled (SSI), as well as who is getting Medicaid (just the person on SSI or everyone, etc.) in your family it would help in giving more specific guidance.   Based on what you wrote here is some information that covers only the PA side of things.   SSI will go with the person (and usually comes with Medicaid for that person). In PA a person does get Medicaid with their SSI so that part is likely not an issue. However, SSI is income and asset based so that is always a constant issue to be aware of.   Your biggest issue is how you treat the sale of your home.   First and foremost, if you sell your primary residence and move to PA and buy a new home (and therefore do not have a lot of money in the bank), then yes, you can apply for Medicaid AND likely be found eligible in PA as well. Medicaid does not count a primary residence (unless it is a huge mansion worth $$$).   So, if you stay within the income and asset limits, and/of if the children (i do not know if you have minor children) are disabled you and they will likely get Medicaid.   Now, looking at it a different way.   If you move to PA and don't buy a home (you rent instead or live with someone) and you have a lot of money in the bank ($2000.00 or more), you might not be eligible for SSI (yourself or your spouse) or Medicaid (as both are income and asset based).   Minor children, if they have a disability, would be able to get Medicaid as your income and assets would not be deemed to them under special needs loophole.  Adult children with a disability (not on SSI) would also likely be eligible if they are limited in their ability to work and required medical care and/or medications. They will also be required to apply for SSI for themselves.   Adult children with a disability (and on SSI) would still be covered as long as they do not have assets over the limit in their own name. Mom and dad's assets and income are not deemed to them.   Minor children without a disability might not get regular medicaid but would likely get some form of CHIP as they are minors and are covered in PA (based on family income and assets). A copay may be involved depending on the income level of the parents.   Adult children without a disability and able to work might be able to get medicaid based on their own current income and asset level, but the threshold is different. They might need to get covered through healthcare.gov and get a subsidy.  Now, if you don't plan to buy a home and the money would be a problem for you, you may have an alternative based upon which person in the home is disabled.  If one of your minor children (or adult children) is disabled and on SSI currently, you could create a special needs trust (supplemental) for that child's benefit and then transfer/gift the excess money from the sale of the home into the special needs trust and that transfer would be an exempt transfer for Medicaid application purposes. So sheltering the money into the trust could help the adults get Medicaid.   But lets be clear. While it will help you shelter the money and get Medicaid, it does come with limitations that many people do not pay attention to. The sheltering of the money is a one way trip. You can not use the money for anything but for that child's benefit. You can't treat the trust as a checking account and take out what you want when you need it.   Always remember, this particular method of sheltering assets so a Parent can get Medicaid is what we call in my office "the nuclear option", it isn't pretty but it works.   In your case it would not likely be a viable option. I just wanted to mention it in case you did not intend to buy a home in PA and would be coming into the state with excess cash.   I do recommend that you consult directly with an attorney that does special needs planning/medicaid law so that you can plan out your move in more detail to make sure it is successful for everyone in your family.   I wish you well.

What you need to understand about suppression motions is that they are intended to remedy violations of your constitutional rights (generally your 4th amendment right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure), when the GOVERNMENT has violated your rights.  So, there has to be government action of some sort to support the suppression motion.  The question of prohibiting the introduction of the video evidence is a bit broader, because the court will allow only admissible evidence.  You may be able to argue at trial, or by filing, in advance of trial, a "motion in limine", arguing that the video evidence is inadmissible because it violates one of several evidentiary rules--hearsay, lack of foundation, lack of authentication, its prejudicial impact outweighs its probative value, etc.  In order to gain more time, look at Iowa Criminal Rule 2.11.  You have only a brief time to file pretrial motions.  Immediately file a motion seeking to extend the Rule 2.11 motion deadline.  Also ask to extend the deposition and discovery deadline.  These are difficult issues and only experienced criminal defense attorneys are well versed in handling such matters.  Few non lawyers will be able to successfully navigate these issues.  You really need to invest the time and money in a good lawyer who can help you through these issues.  And don't wait.  Once your deadlines pass, it will be more difficult for your lawyer to get the court to give you additional time, especially in Polk County.  Good luck.  Criminal Defense Attorney, George B. Jones.

As you evidently learned, the FMLA's one-year employment requirement does not have to be in the immediately preceding year. The same is true for California's similar California Family Rights Act (CFRA).  Because you are trying to conceive, you should know that California provides for leave due to pregnancy beyond what the FMLA provides, if an employee is eligible. Also, Federal and California law protect women from discrimination based on pregnancy.  FEDERAL RIGHTS:  In 1978, Congress amended the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII 42 U.S.C. å¤å¤ 2000e to 2000e‰ÛÒ17, by passing the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.   Under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, "discrimination" means to treat a pregnant employee differently from non-pregnant employees, and adversely. The employee must be able to make a connection between the discriminatory treatment and the protected status (being pregnant). In other words, the employee will have to show that her pregnancy is reason the employer is treating her adversely. There are various ways to do this. Negative comments from supervisors or management; a sudden change in treatment (for the worse) as soon as or shortly after the employer learns about the pregnancy or the effects of pregnancy; or other incriminating conduct. Note it is not unlawful for an employer to apply the same leave of absence policy to pregnant and non-pregnant employees.   For information on pregnancy discrimination, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/types/pregnancy.cfm   For information on the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/pregnancy.cfm   This law is enforced by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). www.EEOC.gov   Under federal law, leave taken for an employee's incapacity due to pregnancy, childbirth or related medical conditions is governed by the Family and Medical Leave Act, 29 U.S.C. section 2101 et seq. (FMLA), just like leave for any other "serious health condition" of an employee.  See my Avvo guide to the FMLA for more information: http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=family-and-medical-leave-fmla-summary-of-key-provisions.  CALIFORNIA RIGHTS:  California employers must comply with federal law, as above, and also must comply with state law.  The California pregnancy disability leave law, Government Code section 12945(a) (PDLL), is part of the California Fair Employment and Housing Act, California Government Code sections 12900, et seq. (FEHA). The PDLL requires employers to provide employees up to four months of unpaid leave for disability caused by pregnancy, childbirth or a related medical conditions.  Under some circumstances, an employer may be required to transfer an employee affected by pregnancy, childbirth or related medical conditions to a different job.  California has its own family and medical leave law, the California Family Rights Act, Government Code section 12945.2 (CFRA).  It is substantially similar to the FMLA, but an employee's incapacity due to pregnancy, childbirth or related medical condition is not included in the definition of "serious health condition."  This is usually beneficial to the employee because CFRA leave and pregnancy disability leave are two separate and distinct rights under California law.  They do NOT run concurrently, as they do under the FMLA.  Instead, an employee in California may take four months of PDLL plus 12 weeks of family leave, provided of course that the employee meets the other conditions of these laws.  Please look at my guide to unlawful discrimination:  http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=what-is-unlawful-employment-discrimination--california-law which should help you understand lawful and unlawful discrimination, how to enforce your rights, and time limits. BB guns are not considered firearms under Florida law.  To qualify as a firearm it must expel a projectile by the action of an explosive.  Provided the "BB gun" does not require explosive action then it is not a firearm  Here is a link to the controlling statute: http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0790/Sections/0790.001.html

The rule is stated differently by different courts but in all cases a corporate "officer or director is, in general, personally liable for all torts which he authorizes or directs or in which he participates, notwithstanding that he acted as an agent of the corporation and not on his own behalf."    Which means that, yes, if a person creates a corporation and then willfully engages in unlawful acts [such as copyright infringement] through that company then that person can be held DIRECTLY liable for the damages caused by those acts [not, as my colleague suggests, indirectly liable under the vicarious or contributory infringement theories].   Nonetheless, doing business through a corporation remains very smart for many other business and marketing reasons and, as applied to your infringement concern, if the infringement is done "innocently" as opposed to "willfully" then it‰Ûªs unlikely that the corporate officer who engaged in the infringement would be held personally responsible [though he or she would likely still be sued]. One of the business reasons for incorporating is that you can more easily procure insurance coverage to manage the risk of being sued for whatever it is that your company would be doing. Good luck.

It is unfortunate that you find yourself in this position.  I would agree with the Juvenile Court that this is not an emergency.  I am not sure if you still live in or near the county that the divorce was entered in, but if so you would most likely need to file a Petition to Modify Custody and Visitation along with an Ex Parte Restraining Order that gives you temporary exclusive physical custody of your son.  Although you would not want her to show back up demanding her parenting time under the plan, since she is out of the picture it is not actually an emergency situation.  If neither you or your ex-wife still live in the county the divorce was finalized in, then you may first need to file a Motion to Transfer the case to your current county of residence.  In order to be successful on a Petition to Modify you will need to prove that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the Permanent Parenting Plan was entered by a preponderance of the evidence.  Based on the facts you have listed there has been a substantial and material change in that her situation has rapidly devolved.  The Court would then look to the factors to determine the best interest of the child.  Given that you have remained a stable and loving father and have served as the primary caretaker for the child, it would seem that you are in a position to be deemed the primary residential parent for your son.  The Court would then have to decide what visitation with the mother is in your son's best interest.  That may be supervised parenting time, drug screens, every other weekend, etc. depending on her particular circumstances and what would be best for the child in light of her particular circumstances.  You should seek the advice of child custody attorney in your area.  It is very difficult for people to attempt to represent themselves in these types of cases.  Many times child custody matters are highly contested and you may find yourself having a trial before the Court where you would be held to the same standard as an attorney on Rules of Procedure, Rules of Evidence, etc.  This is an unfortunate situation and I wish you and your family the best of luck going forward.
