Parental rights can be terminated on several grounds, but it sounds like you're talking about abandonment because you reference time ("how long do you have to wait").  In California, abandonment can be found if the other parent has gone for at least one year without contacting the child OR one year without paying any money towards the child's support.  The devil is in the details, which I will give below.  ONE YEAR:  It can be any year, not just the one preceding the date you file for a stepparent adoption.  So if your child is 5 and the other parent didn't have contact from the time he/she was ages two to four, then abandonment can still be found. (Also, if the child was left with a non-parent, then you only have to wait six months to bring your action.)  CONTACT:  Token contacts do not count.  Say, for instance, that the parent has been absent for a year but sent a birthday card to the child or called once or twice -- those contacts would probably be considered token and you would still be able to tell the court the other parent had not had contact for one year "within the meaning of the statute."  Another word on contact:  you will probably have to prove you did nothing to frustrate contact.  Maybe you moved, and your phone number and address changed, and the other parent complains to the judge that he/she had no way to contact the child.  If you can show the other parent still had a way to contact you (for instance, your email address remained the same, or your parents still live in the same house with the same phone number, and the other parent didn't try to contact you using any of these methods), you will still probably be successful in terminating their rights.  MONEY/SUPPORT:  Oftentimes the other parent will stand up in court and say, "Judge, I was never ordered to pay support, so that's why I didn't send money!"  That argument won't fly.  The law imposes a duty on a parent to support their child to the best of their ability, so the absence of a court order to do so will not save their rights from being terminated.  Also, even if they did pay support, this will not automatically save them from having their rights terminated.  It all comes down to the bond the child shares with the absent parent.  Has there been enough contact for that child to care about the parent?  Does the child's bond with the absent parent outweigh the bond with the stepparent?    This is a tricky area of the law and all judges take it very seriously.  The Supreme Court has said the two most trying and important cases a judge will ever hear are death penalty cases and termination of parental rights cases.  Get an attorney who has done many of these so they can guide you through the process.  I personally love this type of case -- so often we are setting a child free from a truly neglectful or truly bad parent so they can fearlessly love the parent of their heart, their stepparent.  All the best.

Malicious prosecution is a tort.  The elements (ie, what is necessary to prove malicious prosecution) are rooted in common law, and so they may vary from state to state.  A federal Section 1983 claim based on malicious prosecution borrows the elements of the corresponding state law tort.  See Raysor v. Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, 768 F.2d 34, 39 (2d Cir.1985).  I don't practice in GA, but in New York, a plaintiff alleging malicious prosecution must show: (1) the defendant commenced a criminal proceeding against him; (2) the proceeding ended in the plaintiff‰Ûªs favor; (3) the defendant did not have probable cause to believe the plaintiff was guilty of the crime charged; and (4) the defendant acted with actual malice.  See Martin v. City of Albany, 42 N.Y.2d 13, 16 (1977).  Hope this helps.

California courts do have a program for dismissal in petty theft cases after completion of the two days of classes. If you did complete the classes and then gave proof of completion to the court within the proscribed time period, your case may have been dismissed. This is a deferred entry of judgment, and the court does not pass judgment if the defendant completes the two day class. Your fiance can write a letter to whomever would be responsible for probating grandpa's estate, using certified mail, to inquire as to the estate and demanding that he receive notices.  Or he may need to write such letters to all relatives standing to inherit.  You can check to see if a probate is opened, and if one is you can check the public file to see if there are any leads.  If grandma lived in a small town, he may be able to write letters to each bank in the town to inquire as to any accounts set up in his name.  Keep in mind that all he has is very old gossip about what grandma allegedly did many years ago.  Once grandma passed, if she didn't have things set up properly (assuming accounts were set up at all), it is entirely possible the accounts were closed out and the money spent.

Your question is solid, as it seems there are a few folks who knew or should have known. Regardless, you purchased a vehicle from dealer that was not what it seemed to be. That all said, since what you received was not what you bargained for, dealer is on the hook for the difference in value. IF you can prove fraud, then dealer can be in a much worse position. Since dealer did this "repair/fix" you note, dealer likely knew and did commit a fraud. Hopefully, for your sake, there is no arbitration clause in your contract which is also largely a fraud, IMHO, and you can sue in a court of law and get the justice you deserve instead of the justice that dealer pays for.   Get your story and related documents to an auto fraud law firm (like mine) that handles your initial intake at no charge and that will advise you of your rights, and that gets paid from the other side upon victory.

The normal rule is that an employee should not be required to work more than seven staright days without time off.  However, the exceptions to the rule are found in California Labor Code section is section 554, which states:  (a)Sections 551 and 552 shall not apply to any cases of emergency nor to work performed in the protection of life or property from loss or destruction, nor to any common carrier engaged in or connected with the movement of trains. This chapter, with the exception of Section 558, shall not apply to any person employed in an agricultural occupation, as defined in Order No. 14-80 (operative January 1, 1998) of the Industrial Welfare Commission. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent an accumulation of days of rest when the nature of the employment reasonably requires that the employee work seven or more consecutive days, if in each calendar month the employee receives days of rest equivalent to one day's rest in seven. The requirement respecting the equivalent of one day's rest in seven shall apply, notwithstanding the other provisions of this chapter relating to collective bargaining agreements, where the employer and a labor organization representing employees of the employer have entered into a valid collective bargaining agreement respecting the hours of work of the employees, unless the agreement expressly provides otherwise.  (b)In addition to the exceptions specified in subdivision (a), the Chief of the Division of Labor Standards Enforcement may, when in his or her judgment hardship will result, exempt any employer or employees from the provisions of Sections 551 and 552.  You are right that this may, in fact, also cause a hazard if you are getting fatigued and being required to work on a press that could cause bodily injury.  If you put in a WRITTEN request for time off for more than 7 straight days due to safety concerns and are terminated or retaliated against as a result, you may have a claim for wrongful termination.  My colleague is correct that you would also be entitled to overtime for any hours worked beyond 8 in one day and/or 40 in one week.  Make sure they are paying this.  Hope this helps.

The child's derivative benefits get added to the combined incomes of the parents.  From that total income base, the support guidelines determine the combined support obligation, then the derivative benefits are subtracted from the combined support obligation, leaving the remainder to be divided proportionally between the parties.  It is a somewhat difficult calculation to explain, but it is easier to show when using the actual figures.  I suggest contacting a family law attorney.

I am an attorney licensed in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and the States of Delaware and New Jersey.  My practice includes employment, business and health care law. Before I respond to your inquiry, I must state that we have not spoken, I have not reviewed the relevant documents and facts, and I do not represent you. Therefore, my discussion below is not a legal opinion, but is informational only. Finally, my discussion applies only to issues to which Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey or Federal law applies.  That being said, if your accrued vacation pay should be paid out to you per employer policy, then it is yours regardless of whether you sign anything, and there is no reason to swap it for severance.  Otherwise, even if you sign the document, you have still been terminated without cause ('not working out' is not cause).  You should make sure you put that in writing in an email to your employer - that you were terminated and did not quit.  You can use that email as evidence.  You may want to have the agreement state that the employer will not contest unemployment.  /Christopher E. Ezold/

It is difficult to know whether or not he will receive jail time upon being arrested.  That will depend on a number of factors. My colleagues are correct.  In District Court actions, the Court will enter a 3-507 dismissal most frequently when a Plaintiff has filed a lawsuit, but has not given notice to the court that it has successfully made the required service of process upon the Defendant nor has the Plaintiff timely requested a re-issue of the summons.  The Plaintiff has an opportunity to respond to the Court's 3-507 Notice of Dismissal within 30 days, to provide good cause as to why their case should not be dismissed.  If no response is given, the case is dismissed without prejudice, meaning that the Plaintiff may simply file the lawsuit again, if not barred by the applicable statute of limitations.

A will might be rejected because of undue influence, lack of testamentary capacity, fraud, or because it fails to comply with the legal requirements for a will. Generally, support is only retroactive to the date of filing of the request for support.  There are exceptions, so you do exactly what you have written, file a Request for Hearing for Support and check the box requesting support orders be made retroactive to the date of filing of the divorce.  It doesn't hurt to ask.  In your declaration attached to or filed with the motion, you can explain the facts including the default status and the failure of the other party to provide support during that 4 year period.  If the other party is paying support voluntarily and the support orders are retroactive to any date the court deems appropriate, then the paying spouse gets credit for monies they have paid during the time encompassed by the support orders only.    In some cases, such as those where one party is receiving public assistance, the Department of Child Support Services (DCSS) is a great resource and helps with filing, service and collection of support matters.  Retroactive support is available for reimbursement of public aide monies paid out by the State.  That is when DCSS has exclusive jurisdiction over support.    If you are just looking for some additional help filing or filling out your forms, you can also meet with the Family Court Facilitator's Office.  They cannot give out legal advice, but they can help you fill out paperwork to get your motion filed.  Time is of the essence, so please file as soon as possible.  If the court does not grant retroactive support earlier than the date you filed the motion for support, then you will want to have filed as soon as possible to help you and your child(ren) as much as possible as quickly as possible.

Time spent in jail awaiting trial and sentencing counts as against any sentence actually imposed on a 1 to 1 basis. The three day rumor you heard is likely a misunderstanding of the speedy trial rule.   If a person is in jail awaiting trial, that person has a right to a speedy trial. There are laws that say how long the government has to bring the person to trial. The length of time varies with the offense level and is commonly referred to as the speedy trial clock. Each day spent in jail awaiting trial counts as three days against the clock.   So, if we take a felony case as an example, the State must bring a person accused of a felony to trial within 270 days of charging them. See http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2945.71 If this person does not waive his or her right to a speedy trial, and cannot make bail, each day he or she spends in jail will count as three against the 270 clock giving the state 90 actual days to bring him or her to trial. Typically, the speedy trial clock is not an issue because the defense can waive the right to a speedy trial.

Without reading the entire Note it would seem that since you accepted prepayment of principal only the remaining principal balance should be amortized over the remaining term of the amortization schedule using the full payment stated in the Note.  The borrower has accelerated the term by making prepayment of principal which you accepted.  You now have to run a new amortization schedule using the remaining princpal balance with the monthly payments stated in the Note. The borrower is not in default since they made all the interest payments and prepaid principal thus accelerating the Note.  You can not raise the interest rate as there does not seem to be a default.  If you enforce the original payment amount under the original amortization term the loan would be repaid  sooner as the borrower has pre-paid 1/3 of the principal.  You should bring the Note to an attorney to review.  Chances are you can insist on the full monthly payment stated in the Note, however, there will need to be a new amortization schedule computed and the amount of interest from each payment would be greatly reduced with the amount of principal being greatly increased.  Your remaining term would be much shorter.

The short answer is:  your friend.  First, with respect to the additional tax, since the return is now presumably correct that is the tax your friend owes and that he would have owed originally if the return had been properly prepared so he will have to pay the tax in any event.  Unfortunately, your friend will also be responsible for the penalties and interest he will now have to pay because of the mistake.  He will at the least have to pay the failure to pay penalties and might also have to pay the accuracy-related penalties if the error was obvious.  He might be able to request the IRS to abate some of the penalties and interest because of the mistake by this company; however, if your friend wasn't really entitled to claim any deduction for education expenses the IRS will almost certainly not abate the penalties or the interest.  About the most your friend can do is to file a complaint with the IRS Office of Professional Responsibility about this company and the individual who actually prepared the return.  The IRS should investigate the complaint and might take action against them if they determine that the errors were done on purpose.

A Will cannot be changed by anyone other than the person who wrote the Will.  It follows, then, that the Will cannot be changed after the person dies.  If you believe that there will be problems when your father dies about identifying a valid Will or about fraudulent modifications of his Will, there are steps you can take now.  One of the best and most iron-clad approaches would be for your father to take out a life insurance policy naming you and your brother as the sole beneficiaries.  Life insurance passes outside of a Will and she would not be able to manipulate or control it as long as the Beneficiary Designations were not fraudulently changed.  But the insurance company has its own procedures to help ensure that only the insured can change Beneficiary Designations.  Another approach would be for your father to create and fund a By-Pass Trust right now--while he is alive.  A lot of people know of By-Pass Trusts being created through a Will or Trust after death.  But they actually can be created while he is alive.  He also can create Pay on Death (POD) designation for some assets that he owns in his own name--such as bank accounts, etc.  There are many other approaches that your father may take to ensure that you and your brother are not accidentally or fraudulently disinherited.  Please see an estate planning attorney in the state in which your father lives and please speak with your father about visiting the attorney with you.

Let me be the first to tell you that actions have consequences.  You apparently admitted that you wrote checks for goods or services totaling $458 and that the checks bounced and you never repaid the money.   That is called theft.  It is punishable by up to 6 months in the county jail and a fine of up to $2000.  Since you forced the District Attorney to file a case in court, you are also liable for paying part of the court's cost related to handling your case.  You AGREED to go on probation for a certain length of time so that you could pay that money back.   In return, the District Attorney agreed to NOT ask the judge to put you in jail.   You can ask the judge to reduce your probation fees.  It looks like you've already done that.   Normally, probation fees are around $60 per month. Is that what you are paying? Is it higher or lower?  I understand that you have trouble doing community service.  Did the judge tell you that you are excused from that or did he tell you that you need to do it over the next 12 months?  If he excused you, the only thing that he really wants is the $458.   He doesn't want this money for himself.  He doesn't want it so that he can give it to the state of Texas.  He wants it so that the people that you stole from can have their money.    If you want all of this to stop, you can stop it right now and you won't have to pay another dime to anyone.   Walk in and tell the judge that you'd rather just get convicted and go to jail.  I'm sure he probably won't sentence you to very many days.  I'm thinking 10 days or less.  It's not like you have to worry about anyone checking your record when you apply for a job or anything.    It is YOUR choice.  You can take care of your responsibilities on probation or do the time.

As other responses have indicated, you will not lose your benefits for part-time work alone. In other words, just because you are working and able to earn money, does not mean that your disability will be taken away. However, when your disability is reviewed, your work will be considered if Social Security is able to establish that you have reached medical improvement. If you have not yet been on disability benefits for 24 months when you are able to start making substantial money, your earnings can cause a Medical Review (see http://www.socialsecurity.gov/OP_Home/cfr20/416/416-0990.htm).  So if you have already been on benefits for 24 months or more, you are correct, Social Security will be most concerned about whether your earnings have exceeded Substantial Gainful Activity. This can only happen after you have already used all nine of your trial work months ( you use a trial work month in 2014 in any month that you make $770 or more in a month - it was $750 in 2013). If you have used all your trial work months, Social Security will only stop your benefit for work activity alone, if you then make more than Substantial Gainful Activity ($1070 per month in 2014). You can still be reviewed based on a periodic continuing disability review that normally occur once every 3-7 years.  When doing work, it is always important to consider whether your part-time work is evidence that you are not disabled. For example if you applied only because of your physical condition, but you are now doing work that regularly requires you to stand for extended periods of time, or to lift large amount of weight, even though you are only doing it on a part-time basis, it may be evidence that you are not as limited as you were previously. If you are receiving benefits for mental health, if you are able to do a position that requires attention to detail, focus, maintaining a regular schedule and working with the public on a regular basis, these types of things can also be proof that your condition is improving.

The burden of proof in a criminal case is beyond a reasonable doubt, which is drastically higher than in a civil case. In fact, think back to the OJ Simpson trial which is an example if a case where a criminal jury found the defendant not guilty but a civil jury found him liable in a wrongful death action. Plus unlike a medical malpractice case, this is a much cheaper case for a civil attorney to litigate.   The doctor should have retained counsel steady but if not, should do so immediately.  Setting up a strong defense lawyer could discourage and discredit the plaintiff.

Defense challenges to arrest warrants (and search warrants) are highly fact-specific, and it is truly not possible to evaluate a specific case in a public information forum, especially not based on the limited facts presented here.  Moreover, if a person is wanted on a warrant, and after arrest it is determined that the arrested defendant is indeed the wanted person, there may be little remedy for technical defects in the warrant.   On the other hand, if the person was mistakenly arrested, then he should obviously be released and may have a civil claim based on false arrest if the error was egregious.  If the arrest warrant was faulty or erroneous, and the service of the warrant resulted in additional evidence being seized as a result of the arrest, then there may be suppression issues.  General information in a public forum is obviously no substitute for advice of counsel in a confidential setting, after review of all the facts, as an attorney can best review all evidence and determine any defenses.

Probably not. Generally the type of background check the apartment complex is looking at is a credit check, and this kind of info isn't going to be there.  Employers in Alabama we access to  something known as the Alabama Criminal Justice Information System, ACJIS for short.  This system would disclose that there is warrant outstanding, but landlords don't have access to it.  The landlord  might be able to look you up on the court system's online database called "Alacourt."  But this system doesn't cover all courts, and it would be cumbersome and expensive, so I doubt they have that.  What you really need to worry about is your driver's license.  Generally, Alabama will suspend your driver's license if you fail to appear for a traffic ticket.  If you have a license from a different state your license will ultimately be suspended as well....it might take a while, but you will be suspended.  If you are already suspended, this might give you trouble in getting an apartment.  It will also be an impediment to driving around town!     Here's how you can take care of that ticket:  Get a lawyer in the city or county where you got the ticket.  (You knew I was going to say that, didn't you?)  The lawyer will find whether you can take care of a ticket without appearing and how much it will cost.  Even if you have to appear, the lawyer can probably arrange this so that you won't have to waste away in jail waiting on the judge to let you out.  Now, it this was a serious traffic ticket...say a DUI or something, it will be more difficult.  But you really need to resolve this ticket.

You have the basic ingredients required for a BIG case in workers' compensation: physical work your whole life, over 50 years old, restriction to sedentary work or less. The work comp law recognizes little cases and big cases - determined solely whether you can work or not. However, you need an aggressive claimant lawyer who knows how to document your inability to do sedentary work.  You are eligible for lifetime checks from work comp if you're permanently and totally disabled, and if so, your case can be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars! This matter does require an experienced estate administration attorney. The TONTINE WILL itself will need to be reviewed to determined: 1. If you are in fact the actual owner of the property at this time.If so, then 2. Is it fee simple absolute or are there conditions on the property (are you a temporary owner until you pass and then it goes to someone else?).  2. A. If it is all yours then it will naturally pass to your son if he is your only heir. If you have multiple heirs you need to address this issue in your will.  2. B. If it is not yours when you pass and instead goes to someone else, then you are likely limited on what you can pass down to your son.  2. C. If you keep it as long as you pay taxes on it then okay, but what happens if you do not pay the taxes (i am not referring to sheriff sale - i am asking if there are terms in the document that indicate it passes to someone else?).   If it is yours free and clear, you don't necessarily need to have your name on the deed, but it would be helpful to do so while you are alive and will make future transfers easier. Consult with your attorney about placing it into your name as soon as possible (have the attorney draft a new deed ASAP and have it signed (by the necessary party), or having it placed directly in your son's name immediately while you are alive.   If it is yours with conditions, make sure you talk with your son first as he may not be in a position to pay taxes on the property. You don't want to cause a burden on someone unless they are agreeable to it.   These are all questions you can start asking your attorney.   I wish you a positive outcome.

At-will employment is a doctrine in which an employee can be dismissed by an employer for any reason without having to establish "just cause" for termination, and without warning.  The basis for this rule is that an employee may be similarly entitled to leave his or her job without reason or warning.  This includes work hours, pay, policies and job assignments.     In workplaces with a trade union and a collective bargaining agreement, if you have an employment contract, and in many public sector jobs, the normal standard for dismissal is that the employer must have a "just cause".  Otherwise, subject to statutory rights, such as protections against discrimination and/or retaliation, the general principle is that an employee may be discharged without cause and without notice.  If you believe that you are being discriminated against or retaliated against because you are a member of a protected category, you might benefit from consulting with an experienced employment law attorney and having them evaluate your case.  The California Employment Lawyers Association maintains a list of employment law attorneys who represent employees against employers.  Follow the link to: www.cela.org.

The terms of the loan will guide you.  Generally, if the borrower isn't paying back per the agreement, you can sue for breach of contract and get the unpaid amount and perhaps more.  If the promissory note has an attorney fees clause, you can sue for the amount owed plus costs of suit and attorney fees (assuming you hire a lawyer to represent you).  You might want to write a demand letter to the borrower, reminding him or her that one or more payments have been missed and demanding the past due amounts.  If you have to sue, you can file a small claim for up to $10,000, a limited jurisdiction case for up to $25,000, and an unlimited jurisdiction case for anything over $25,000.  If there's anything mysterious about the promissory note or what you might do, make an appointment with a local lawyer to look it over for you.  Good luck.

In general, a Decision Maker does not have authority/jurisdiction to modify parenting time.  However, parties can agree to give a decision maker greater authority, including to modify current orders.  A decision maker can only be appointed by agreement of the parties and the appointment is limited by the agreed order of appointment.  If the order in your case does not specifically  allow the decision maker to do what he/she is doing, you can file a motion with the court to declare the DM is exceeding his/ her authority and lacks subject matter jurisdiction.    If the order allows what is being done, you can file for a de novo review.   Good luck to you!

This is called "mixing", and is what almost every seasoning maker does. It is legal provided you meet FDA labeling requirements and do not use any brand name in a way that implies they sponsor the bundled product. If you were to provide the name products in original packaging along with a recipe for mixing, then that would be called "bundling", and is generally also legal. Bundling is slightly more risky since one brand may not want to be associated with perceived inferior brands in that way. However, with mixing like you propose, you become the ultimate consumer since after you get through the product is not the original product so it cannot be reverse passing off. Normally you can use generic ingredient descriptions on the packaging, but you need to doublecheck your specifics with FDA labeling requirements. http://www.fda.gov/Food/default.htm

Legal fees are only awarded to attorneys hired by the parties.  When you, as a non-attorney represent yourself, you cannot obtain attorney's fees.  You are entitled to costs incurred.  That will be out of pocket expenses.  So if you paid for internet legal research, that is an allowable cost.  Copies and postage, may be awarded (within reason).  Travel to the court probably won't be awarded, but if you can document it and use the IRS mileage amount, there is no harm asking for it.  Your time, lost work, etc, however, is not something you will be awarded.

Overtime EXEMPT salaried employees generally must be paid their full salary unless they miss or or more FULL workdays due to illness or personal reasons.  Otherwise, the employer loses the benefit of the exemption and becomes liable for overtime.  An overtime exempt employee could not have PTO deducted for a partial day absence without compromising their exemption because they are already entitled to the full day's pay and so the PTO deduction is essentially a PTO forfeiture, which would be unlawful.  Non-exempt salaried employees, on the other hand, can generally have their salaries reduced for partial day absences if there is an agreement to that effect with the employer.  Really, this sort of arrangement is more akin to hourly pay, since the employee's compensation is determined by the total number of hours they work.  Nonetheless, since a non-exempt employee's "salary" can be reduced for partial day absences, there is nothing unlawful about requiring the employee to use PTO to fill in the hours they didn't work.

Contract law in Washington is specifically modified and restricted in residential tenancies. There are statutes that control how the contract can work. There are restrictions. See RCW 59 18 230, for example. If you were considering renting out the place to a tenant who is really a complete flake, and you did not follow the rules about taking their money, return the money and thank your lucky stars you get a new opportunity to screen a prospective tenant. There are companies that do this for you. You can make the tenant pay the cost of screening - provided you do so properly.   Most landlords I represent get a contract from a store or off the internet, and then the landlord believes that the tenant is obligated according to the terms of the rental contract. This is not true. It would save you untold grief and aggravation to have a consult with a local, well-regarded landlord tenant attorney so you get started correctly, rather than waiting to get sued because you feel you want to save money.   The penalty for taking a deposit incorrectly can be as much as two times the deposit, pre-judgment interest at 12% from the date you took the money, and ALL the tenant's reasonable attorney fees incurred getting their money back. Elizabeth Powell

Thank you for your question!  Ok, first off, did the subs provide you with any request to withhold the statutory retainage?  Basically, you have to withhold 10 percent of the total cost owed to the contractor, to cover the subs.  If you did not get any sort of document regarding this, you don't have to withhold that amount of money.  If you do get it, however, and you completely pay off the contractor, the subs can put a lien on your homestead.  This is one of the few ways that people can put a lien on your homestead, without your express permission.  So, have these subs given you written notice to withhold the money?  Simply because they have told you of the issue, doesn't mean anything, really.  Also, did they tell you in writing?  OR did they simply call you?  They are required to file an affidavit of lien and then serve both you and the contractor.  Basically, if there is nothing written that has been given to you, then you should be fine.  However, feel free to tell the contractor, that to protect your own interests, you will not be paying him the remainder of the money, until he has paid his subcontractors.  Also, there are VERY strict timelines that must be followed, to make any of this stick.  I have written a guide for subcontractors and contractors on my profile, that lays those out.  Hope this helps!

Creditors can't usually just seize assets, so they would have to file a lawsuit to gain title to the asset.  The answer thus depends on where your LLC is doing business. If you are doing business only in FL (since it will own real property in FL), then the LLC would have to be sued in FL. Conversely, if the LLC is doing business in CA  it could be sued in CA.  Because members of an LLC do not have personal liability for the company's debts (generally), your state of residence really doesn't matter in the case of a lawsuit.   If you personally guarantee a debt of the LLC, then the creditor could go after you in CA or wherever you live.   For cases involving real property, the general rule is that the proper jurisdiction is the jurisdiction in which the real property is located.     Once the creditor has a judgment, it will eventually end up in FL where the assets are located in order to enforce the judgment and collect assets of the LLC.   If the judgment is from a CA court, it could be entered in FL as a sister-state judgment and then enforced there.

The answer from the Missouri attorney is more correct.   The differences in the answers shows the differences in state laws. For non payment of rent cases, Missouri has no formal notice, or notice period, requirement.  If the rent is not paid, the landlord is permitted to file their action.  The tenant is permitted to pay the rent in full and defeat the possessory portion of the case. If a landlord wishes to terminate the tenancy, without tenant's opportunity to pay, THEN the landlord must give some sort of notice -- the kind and time period are determined by the authority under which the landlord is acting -- statutory or contract. As an answer to the question, if rent is due, without regard to the amount of time it is outstanding or promises to pay, then you can file a rent and possession case.  The amounts actually due might come into question  when determining the "work v. rent due" issues.

If USCIS decides to approve your application for permanent resident (green card) status based on your marriage to a U.S. Citizen, then, on the day of the approval, if you have been married for 2 years or longer, then you will receive a green card that is valid for 10 years.  If you have been married for less than 2 years, then you will receive a green card that is valid for 2 years and you will be a "conditional" permanent resident.  Regarding citizenship, if you do not have any other claim to U.S. Citizenship or naturalization, then you must first become a permanent resident before you are eligible to apply for naturalization.  If you are a permanent resident married to, and living with, a U.S. Citizen for at least 2 years and 9 months, then you may apply for naturalization.  Otherwise, you must a a permanent resident for at least 4 years and 9 months.  I suggest that you work with an immigration attorney for the best chance of success.

This is a very unusual situation. I handle both Immigration law AND divorces (contested & uncontested cases) extensively. First, you & your husband should not be waiting for so much time for an answer from USCIS. All of my permanent residency cases wherein a US citizen spouse (the sponsoring spouse CAN be a permanent resident but must become a US citizen before the beneficiary spouse is approved for permanent residency) files to sponsor his/her spouse have been approved on the very same day. The longest I've ever had to wait was a few weeks for the approval.  You should make an appointment via InfoPass to find out what has happened. However, I have another idea but I prefer to not discuss that via this website.  But if you & your husband are considering divorcing, YES it will affect you since you have not been approved yet. I have handled these situations before both on Long Island AND in New York City (26 Federal Plaza).  In fact, based on these facts, you will never receive either permanent residency OR conditional permanent residency if you & husband divorce now.

The law isn't clear regarding residences.  It says  that places of employment and jails are not required to accommodate usage,  however it is silent as to residences. I have linked to the Health and Safety Codes with the Medical Marijuana Act.  Section 11362.77 covers growing plants,  and Section 11362.785 deals with employment and jails. A drug test is an invasion of your medical privacy unless it is done under specific legal procedures and only in certain circumstances.  First, you can be subjected to truly random drug testing if the employer has a published procedure notifying you of such and the test is done in a manner that protects the privacy interests of the employee, both in the manner in which the test is administered and in how the results are maintained.  Second, you can be subject to a reasonable suspicion drug test if the employer has a published procedure notifying you of such and the employer has sufficient reasonable suspicion to give it the right to specifically test you.  Reasonable suspicion must be more than speculation.  The code defines several factors that could constitute reasonable suspicion.  With this kind of test, again, the test must be done in a manner that protects the privacy interests of the employee, both in the manner in which the test is administered and in how the results are maintained.  Third, you can be subjected to a post-accident drug test if the employer has a published procedure notifying you of such and you have very recently been involved in some kind of workplace accident.     Also with this kind of test the test must be done in a manner that protects the privacy interests of the employee, both in the manner in which the test is administered and in how the results are maintained.  If you believe your privacy has been invaded based on the above explanation it would be prudent for you to locate and consult with an experienced employment law attorney as soon as possible to explore your facts and determine your options.  I would suggest you look either on this site in the Find a Lawyer section, or go to www.cela.org, the home page for the California Employment Lawyers Association, an organization whose members are dedicated to the representation of employees against their employers.  Most employment attorneys who practice this area of law work on a contingency basis, meaning you can hire an attorney without paying any money until the matter results in a positive outcome for you. Many advance all the costs of the litigation as well. Do not let fear of fees and costs keep you from finding a good attorney.  Good luck to you.

Expungements do not reach FBI records--but you do not have a guilty finding, conviction, or anything other than a history of having been charged, and the fact that the charges were later dismissed.  Unless you were taken into custody by the police and transported to the police station before being charged and released, you were not "arrested".  Most shoplifting charges in Maryland result in the issuance of a criminal citation and/or a summons to appear at court, not by way of an actual arrest.  The record check will not show why the charge was dropped, so the fact that you did community service in exchange for that is not something they will know.  You are innocent until proven guilty, and in this case, the prosecutor's office dropped all charges and you remain innocent of this charge (in the eyes of the law).  My guess is, the real reason you were not hired was because you LIED on the application in response to the question about ever being charged with a criminal offense.  You were charged, but the charges were dismissed before trial.  That's how you should answer that question.  As far as you are concerned, you would have won the trial and been found not guilty of the charge had the case gone forward.  Lying on an application is worse than having a minor criminal charge which was dismissed.  It is also a felony to lie on a federal application for employment.  In the future, with respect to any federal employment, read the question on the application carefully, and disclose the fact that you were charged or accused of a crime if that is specified.

‰Û¢ Can chapter 13 protect me from properties debts after foreclosure?  The discharge that follows a successful chapter 13 plan would relieve you of any personal obligation to the mortgages.  You would have no remaining debts as to these properties.  ‰Û¢ Considering my income, is there any chance for me to pay off portion of my credit cards debt or I will need to pay off entire amount of debt via chapter 13?  A chapter 13 repayment plan is based on what you can afford to pay each month after meeting your necessary expenses.  The percentage that gets paid to your unsecured creditors varies depending on your income, expenses and total debt.  ‰Û¢ Is Chapter 13 good to save a property, which is not my case?  A chapter 13 can be a good strategy to help homeowners catch up on delinquent mortgage payments over time if s/he can afford the current payments in addition to catching up on the arrears.  However, chapter 13 can also be a good option for people who are not interested in saving secured property, but do not qualify for a chapter 7.  ‰Û¢ Can I simply negotiate pay off terms/amount directly with credit card‰Ûªs creditors and avoid chapter 13 procedures?  You could certainly try to, but it would require a great deal of coordination and cooperation with your creditors and may possibly still leave you with more debt to pay than you can afford.

As someone who has been representing injured workers in workers' compensation disputes in Pinellas and Pasco County since 1985, I think Mr. Schwartz has hit the nail on the head.  A lot, although not all, of the workers' compensation laws are substantive laws meaning that they apply only to certain dates of accident. When you say the settlement was reached years ago, I presume that you mean you settled your rights to workers' compensation disability money benefits but that settlement left open your rights to workers' compensation medical care benefits.  Florida law changed effective January 1, 1994 to allow workers' compensation settlement to settle the right to future medical care in addition to the right to future money disability benefits.  Prior to that time, a claimant (injured worker) was not allowed to settle his right to future medical care benefits even if he wanted to.  Effective January 1, 1994 and again October 1, 2003, the Florida workers' compensation laws changed the burden for the claimant to prove what medical benefits he was entitled to.  Your burden is easier if your workers' compensation accident was before October 1, 2003 and especially if it was before January 1, 1994.  Like Mr. Schwartz said, I suggest you contact an experienced workers' compensation attorney who has experience with Florida workers' compensation cases under the laws as they existed in the late 1980s throughout the 1990s.  A good place to start to find the right attorney is here on Avvo.

Sacramento does not have a rent control ordinance.  Therefore, theoretically there is no limit to the amount the landlord can increase your rent.  However, the increase would only be valid for a month to month tenancy or less, or for example where your lease is expiring in 30 days.   It's important to note that even if you're on month to month tenancy,  the landlord cannot raise the rent in retaliation for some action you took like making a legitimate complaint or for legally withholding rent.  Moreover, the landlord can't raise the rent as a discriminatory action.  If you suspect that you have been retaliated or discriminated against as a result of the increase, speak to attorney as soon as a possible.

You cannot become the trustee of a trust unless the instrument says so.  Hopefully you and your mother were on good terms, but trusts are sometimes set up for the express purpose of not allowing people to find out what is in them, especially people who the Grantor wanted to exclude, reduce or restrict.  Unlike Wills, which are public documents after probate, trusts are private.  On the "plus" side, if you are a beneficiary, and if the trusts are "irrevocable", you can get your distribution immediately, and without estate tax.  I have found that you can usually get copies of trusts by politely asking the estate attorney for copies.  If the attorney refuses, or ignores your request, you would want to hire your own attorney.  But if you can get what you want by asking nicely, it could save you some money.

The facts aren't quite clear to me.  If you gave her a standard notice to vacate (and my understanding is that it is not necessarily 30 days in Washington) and the tenant truly has a disability that reasonably requires a longer move-out period, then you may or may not have difficulty getting a court to uphold your termination of tenancy notice.  If however the tenant gave you notice with a specific date, that should be fully enforceable and not subject to the tenant later changing their mind.  Either way, you have a right to receive rent for however long they are in possession without having to touch the security deposit.  The issue, however, is if you accept rent for past the notice's move out date, you may waive your right to evict pursuant to the notice.  So all told, you may well want to review the entire matter with a local landlord-tenant attorney before doing anything further.  It can be very expensive to try to evict her but get it wrong.  Good luck.

Can a veteran file a claim for injuries suffered as a result of malpractice at the VA?  Yes.  There are two potential avenues of recovery.  If the physician was an "independent contractor" and NOT a federal employee then that physician can usually be sued under the laws of the state where the treatment occurred.  If the negligent doctor or health care providers WERE federal employees, then you cannot sue in state court, you must bring a claim under the Federal Tort Claims Act.    I do not know the law regarding medical malpractice in SC, but there are most certainly deadlines to file a claim in state court.  Under the Federal Tort Claims Act, however, you have to file Form 95 within two years from the date you knew (or should have known) that malpractice injured your husband.  Once that form is filed, the U.S. has six months to either pay your claim or deny it.  If they deny the claim, or if six months passes without a response, you can file suit in Federal Court.  The more complicated question is whether or not your husband's Arachnoiditis was caused by negligence.  That can only be answered by a qualified physician who has the time to conduct a thorough review of your husband's medical records and radiology studies.  Arachnoiditis can certainly be caused by improper medical care.  Some surgeons, however, will say that it can result from surgery even if the surgeon provided perfect medical care.  Feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.

The client's rights are to change attorneys. You should read Florida Statute 61,13001 the relocation statute before making your decision and possibly consult with a family law attorney near you.  Good luck.  Sincerely, B. Elaine Jones, Esq.

In almost all but the truly unusual defamation case, in which public figures are involved, or the damages are clear and quite substantial, lawyers accept these cases on an hourly rate basis, as opposed to a contingency fee. The obvious result is that the client spends significant funds for the lawyer to spend significant time in assembling the evidence and trying the case. In addition, most insurance policies do not cover intentional acts (such as libel or slander), and thus the defendant usually is someone or some entity that must have substantial assets, in order to satisfy any potential compensatory/punitive damages award. You should contact a local lawyer to discuss other available alternatives to a civil suit for defamation.

You certainly are free to make whatever decision is best for you and your family here, if you are unable to make mortgage payments due to financial circumstances, no one should judge you for that. Sometimes bad things happen to good people. Since you've already filed bankruptcy, your personal liability has been discharged, and therefore the only connection the lender has to you is the mortgage lien on the property. If you discontinue mortgage payments (for whatever reason), the lender will eventually foreclose. The non-judicial (most common) foreclosure process in California can take a year or longer. Your credit has already been damaged by the bankruptcy, I don't believe the foreclosure or short sale makes it significantly worse. I disagree that you won't be able to rent. If you are willing to show your prospective landlord bank statements and paystubs demonstrating you make sufficient income, and you explain the situation, most landlords still consider tenants with damaged credit. If you are willing to offer a little extra security deposit, you enhance your chances even more. If you wanted to be more in control of the process, you should do a short sale on the property which would function similarly to a typical real estate transaction, except the lender has to approve the "loss."

If Time Warner is indeed attempting to collecting an amount above and beyond what you agreed to pay, then Time Warner may be in violation of the California Rosenthall Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. By bringing a lawsuit under this statutory scheme, you may be able to cease the illegal debt collection and potentially receive compensation in the form of statutory or actual damages. If Time Warner is reporting false information concerning your account to the various credit reporting bureaus, then you may also have a cause of action under the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

The proper jurisdiction (Court) to determine child custody is usually the place where the child has lived the past six months.  That being said, if your son comes to Missouri, you may be able to get the Missouri Court to make a custody decision based on either the emergency need for a custody determination or on the fact that your ex has "unclean hands" because she abducted the child.    Even though you are on his birth certificate you should seek to establish paternity and custody through a court order as soon as possible because the court will consider continuity of life in your son's best interests and the longer he stays in Florida the harder it may be to get him back.    You may also want to request copies of the court documents giving your ex's father guardianship from the Florida court where they were issued.  If she lied about knowing your whereabouts and failed to properly notify you of the court date, you may have grounds to have the Florida judgment set aside.  I cannot advise you on that issue because I am not licensed in Florida.

All of these situations can cause problems for the officers testifying in Court.  You can look to hire an attorney to help represent you. If you were arrested and charged with retail theft, that arrest could show up on your record although you probably can have it expunged. As for the civil demand letter, hopefully you did not pay it. Please read: There is a law in the state of Illinois which allows for civil action collection when there is a retail theft. Most people choose to ignore the demand. This demand is for money over and above any fine you pay in compliance with a court order. People may get a few more letters, each time asking for more, and then they stop. While the retailer can sue you, it is extremely rare for anyone to actually be sued. You do not owe any money unless you are sued and the retailer wins. This is a common ploy. Do not pay. If you do, you will be in the national retailers database which could affect your ability to get a job and could impact your life in other ways. If you are uncomfortable, hire a lawyer and have the lawyer write a letter. That should be the end of it.   Here is a good article: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB120347031996578...   The National Retail Theft Database is actually a voluntary list put together by different individual retailers. Further, any member that published the information on the list, can thereafter, remove it. Therefore, if you wish to have the entry removed, as you apparently do, your best bet would be to write a letter to the manager of the particular store and inquire as to what it would take for them to remove the entry.   Please go to this link:  http://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/should-i-pay-the-civil-demand-letter

Defamation does not apply to statements of opinion and, by definition, employee performance reviews are opinion. Moreover, circulating among managerial staff an employee evaluation made by a manager is legally the employer communicating the statements to itself. Managers are not 3rd parties for purposes of meeting the publication element required for defamation claims.   There is no falsity of the evaluation proven by the fact that the manager used your work. Businesses often use (or start with) low quality work in constructing deliverables for the customer. Nor is falsity proven by the fact that the customer agreed with your work. That's just one more opinion.   You don't have anything near a sound defamation claim here, I am sorry to say. File for unemployment benefits and start drafting the next chapter of your career.

In Las Vegas on felony or gross misdemeanor charges, a standard condition of probation is to be employed full time (or be looking for work) and when you're not employed full time, do community service (usually 16 hours per month).  If you're disabled, maybe you can't work or do community service.  It sounds like you have a lawyer working to get you disability benefits, but that process can take some time, and until that goes through your PO is going to give you a hard time about not fulfilling the conditions of your probation.  Any time you're arguably violating your probation, you are subject to arrest and revocation.  So if you can, have a criminal defense attorney file a motion to modify the terms and conditions of probation and be prepared to provide the court with proof of your disability.  According to NRS 176A.400, the judge who sentenced you can modify the terms of your probation at any time.  But keep in mind, the fact that you are able to use the internet and ask this question is going to mean that there is at least some work you will be able to do, at least hypothetically, despite your disability.

Attorneys are not supposed to solicit business when responding to questions on Avvo. So you should not receive an offer to represent you based on this question. I would recommend that you use the "Find a Lawyer" section to locate an attorney that handles Social Security Claims in your area (http://www.avvo.com/search/lawyer_search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=Social+Security&loc=bakersfield%2C+ca&commit=). Once you find an attorney that you would like to potentially hire, call their phone number for more information, or use the email link to email them.   Most attorneys for Social Security Disability offer representation on a contingency fee basis with a free initial consultation. That means that you do not have to pay money to speak with them initially, and you do not have to pay to hire them. Contingency means that the attorney only receives a percentage of your past-due benefits if you are approved by Social Security. Past-due benefits are only those benefits from the initial date you are determined to be eligible for benefits until the date that you are approved (nothing out of monthly benefits).  Since you got an 827 in the mail, that would lead me to believe for some reason you have an active claim pending (maybe you started an application on Social Security's Website: www.ssa.gov). It is important that the 827 is sent in as soon as possible or your claim can be denied. An attorney will likely have a way of contacting the Social Security Administration to get information about your current claim status. Since you were denied benefits in the past, they can also explain the process in greater detail and help explain the types of information that you need this time to have a better chance of being approved.  I would highly recommend that you contact an attorney for help immediately. Good luck!

I am not clear whether or not the debt is related to the truck or just your own personal debt.   Any property you own once a judgment is issued could be subject to a creditor's efforts to collect on the judgment.  A jointly owned asset like your truck is going to be problematic for the creditor because the creditor has no claim against your girlfriend so I am not sure whether or not the creditor could levy against the truck in this situation.   But what I can tell you is that even if the creditor could levy on your 1/2 interest and order the truck sold, the creditor would be faced with paying your exempt amount that Oregon allows for a vehicle to you, which is about $3,000 just for your 1/2 interest.  So unless the truck is worth substantially more than $6,000 a creditor is not going to want to touch your truck.   (I am assuming that there is no secured vehicle loan that would also need to be paid - if there is a loan against the truck add the principle balance of the loan to $6,000.00 and that will be the number that the creditor will have to beat to net any profit.   Also there will be some expense involved in selling the car so add another $1,000 as the estimate of the sales cost.)  If the truck is held jointly with a right of survivorship, a creditor is not going to want to wait around to see if you die first and by that time the truck may have no value.  The best think to do is consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney as soon as you can.  The federal exemptions that you can use in a bankruptcy proceeding are more generous then the Oregon exemptions. so through a bankruptcy you can cancel out your debt and probably still keep a car worth far for then you would in the above example.  A bankruptcy  you do alone shouldn't effect your girlfriends interest in the truck or any other property she has in her name as long as you didn't recently transfer property to her for less then fair market value.  The federal bankruptcy exemption rules, that can now be elected in Oregon bankruptcies, allow you to exempt $3,675 for a motor vehicle but you can also add on a general exemption of $1,225 plus $11,500 of an unused homestead exemption if you don't own a home that needs this exemption.  So in theory you could exempt a car that your 1/2 interest is worth as much as $16,400.

If you're already on SSDI (and not SSI), then you don't need an attorney for this.  Just go down to your local Social Security office and tell them you want to file applications for "auxiliary benefits" for your kids.  Typically, a disabled person's children receive, together, about half of what the disabled person receives, no matter how many kids there are.  So if your benefit is $1,000 per month, and you have one child, that child will likely get a benefit of around $500 per month (on top of your own benefit).  If the same person has two kids under age 18, each will likely receive around $250 (for a total of $500).

An employer violates the law when it requires you  to work beyond the physical restrictions placed upon you by your doctor.  You can refuse to work beyond those restrictions or, if you choose to work beyond those restrictions and you are further injured by that, you can assert liability against the employer for those further injuries, and there would be no workers compensation exclusivity that would force you to address those workplace injuries in the workers compensation system.  Instead, you can sue for your injuries as a violation of the Fair Employment and Housing Act and there would be no limitation on the damages you can assert as there would be in the workers compensation system.  Your options are therefore few:  One, you can continue to work beyond your restrictions as long as you continue to inform the employer that doing so is in violation of those restrictions, and see what happens.  Two, you can refuse to work beyond your restrictions.  If you do and you are harassed or retaliated against for doing so, and the employer could reasonably accommodate your restrictions as stated by your doctor, then you would have a claim for violation of the Fair Employment and Housing Act, and perhaps a wrongful termination claim if you are fired.  Third, you can hire an attorney to write a demand letter for you indicating what will happen if they continue to engage in the conduct you have posted about.  This might make them follow the law.  If you are retaliated against for standing up for your rights in this way, it would be unlawful.  The issue would be whether you could prove it to be retaliation.  Good luck to you.

While New Jersey has a national reputation for having excellent special education offerings, simply moving to New Jersey does not guarantee that your child will receive an appropriate education.  You son's IEP will follow him from Pennsylvania to New Jersey and your new New Jersey school will be obligated to honor it.  Whether your new school would be open to additional testing and, thus, additional services will very much depend on how your child is performing under his current IEP, whatever new medical/other information you have gathered since his IEP was adopted,  and how willing the school district is to work with you.  It is impossible to predict a school district's response.  I've worked with some school districts who really worked with parents and were open to additional assessments even though the current IEP's was less than 3 years old, and I've worked with parents where their school district fought them every step of the way.   Regardless of what state you live in, if you believe that your school district is not providing appropriate education and/or related services, you have the right to initiate "due process."  This means initiating a complaint and getting a hearing though the state's administrative law process (i.e., before an administrative law judge in New Jersey or before a Department of Education Hearing Officer in Pennsylvania).  While "due process" means lots of different things depending on what area of law you are discussing, it is well defined in the special education world and refers to the complaint/hearing process.      Unfortunately, without having any records or more specific information, it is impossible to give you any legal opinion on your matter.

More or less the police need to do a welfare check on her (if they can find her) and so long as she is not in need of immediate medical attention, homeless, or starving then they generally will let a 17 year old be. If you want to start the meter on expensive lawyer time you are not without your options to lawfully get her back; though you might want to take a step back and think about what that might do to the already strained parent-child relationship.  Clearly there is some issue with the parent-child relationship if she would rather spend time with a drug addict than her mother; but if she is holding down her own job and performing well there, things are not as bad as they could be. The best option for you both might be to sit down with someone you both can trust, and start airing out the grievances. If you are a religious family then many of the spiritual leaders of congregations will offer a free service to sit down and talk with you both; if you both respect the leader then it really streamlines figuring out what the problem(s) are and then determining how they best can be solved. If you are not a religious family then there are many qualified counselors available in private practice - to convince her to go to one make it more about improving YOUR relationship with her, rather than making it look like she is the evil child that needs help. It's all about how you present these things, and it often needs to come with a lot of humility when you are dealing with teenagers.   As a parent I would consider all non-legal options first (such as therapy or "mediation" with a spiritual leader) before I go the nuclear route involving lawyers which could further fracture the relationship. Best of luck however you choose to handle your business though

I am sorry for your mother's injury. You need to know that slip and fall / trip and fall accidents are often very difficult personal injury claims to pursue. In a slip and fall / trip and fall claim, both the property owner and the injured victim can be held to varying degrees of responsibility, we often call this concept "comparative negligence."   As you have learned slip and fall accidents can cause serious / significant personal injury. it is estimated that slips, trips and falls kill more than 16,000 Americans each year. Under California law and generally in most states to be legally accountable for a personal injury a victim has suffered, such as your mother, the owner of the premises (or the entity in possession) or their employee or agent must have either caused the dangerous condition, which appears to be the case here.    Yyou should contact a personal injury attorney familiar with handling slip and fall / trip and fall cases. Most personal injury attorneys, including our firm, offer a free consultation. You should avail yourself of this very valuable and educational service  Don't delay in making a contact.

We need to know if the title was held in Joint Tenancy.  If so, you survived the other party, and all you have to do is file an Affidavit of Death of Joint Tenant, and record it at the county recorder's office with a copy of the death certificate. However, if it is held as Tenants in Common, or if there is no reference as to how the property is held, then your father's 50% interest stays with his probate estate.  So, it will go either by the terms of a Will or Trust, or if none, to his legal heirs through probate.

Either way, depending upon what you allege, you might have as little as one year from the date of the incident or far more.  For example, an allegation of either intentional or negligent infliction of emotional distress would generally have to be brought within two years.  I suggest you NOT do this yourself in small claims court. In order to be exempt, a firearm must be either manufactured in or before 1918 or be a "replica" thereof. Replica is defined as a reasonably exact reproduction of the object involved, that, when viewed, causes the person to see substantially the same object as the original. If the muzzleloader merely has an ignition system similar to that found on an antique firearm it is not a "replica" of a firearm manufactured in or before 1918 according to the courts.  If you possess a black-powder firearm manufactured after 1918 or one that isn't an exact replica of a firearm manufactured before 1919, then you have no legal protection in Florida. My advice - live without a firearm or risk jail time.

To answer your first question, yes they can charge you more than your security deposit even when you give proper notice of moving out. The security deposit is not a penalty for breaking the lease. It is a "cushion" for the landlord to have easily available money to repair any damages caused by the tenant. Sometimes the damages are more than the amount of security deposit held, and the landlord demands the remainder from the former tenant.   Even if the landlord failed to properly send the notices for the security deposit, he is still entitled to the money for the damages...provided the claim is accurate and reasonable. $1,100 to paint and clean seems excessive. Replacing blinds would not normally be a tenant expense unless you somehow damaged them to the point they needed replacing. Even so $1,100 still seems like a lot. The way to attack this is first to provide photographs of the state of the apartment when you moved in and the state of the apartment when you moved out. If you did not take photos, then your only option is to argue that the amount charged is excessive. That may or may not be the case if a lot of damage was done but many times landlords try to remodel their properties at the expense of the former tenants.

If you return to the US after an absence of that length, you likely will be told by US immigration officials at the point of entry that they are alleging that you abandoned your permanent resident status.  They likely will take your green card, issue you a temporary document, and will likely issue you a Notice to Appear in Immigration Court.  In Immigration Court, you would need to convince the judge that you had good reasons to be away and that you never intended to abandon your permanent resident status.  Alternatively, you could apply at the US Consulate where you are residing for a Returning Resident visa.  See http://travel.state.gov/content/visas/english/immigrate/types/returning-residents.html  It would be best for you to consult individually with an experienced immigration attorney.  Best wishes.

With much respect, Matt Catchick.

The general rule is that if you are an 'eligible offender,' the most that the judge can do is sentence you to 90 days.  You are an eligible offender if a) You are a NONVIOLENT offender, b) You have only a TECHNICAL violation of probation (like failure to report),  c) You have  no pending criminal charges, d) have not been convicted of a new offense, AND  e) You have not violated twice before...for any reason.  If you meet all these conditions then you are 'eligible' and the most that can be done is a 90 day sentence.    HOWEVERl...the fact that you had a 20 year sentence split 5 to serve makes me wonder if you are a 'violent offender.'  The list of violent offenses is lengthy, and even if it doesn't fit into that list, if the judge decides that your offense involved the infliction of physical harm to another, it could be considered a violent offense.

I believe, the rule is under section 523 of the BK code.  Contact a tax attorney today. Most clients want to avoid filing a malpractice suit and just want to work with a tax attorney to properly resolve the issue.  That can include putting you into currently not collectible status until the statute of limitations on collections runs or settling the matter with an offer in compromise or installment agreement.  I have clients all over the state that I work with remotely.  Best of luck.

I am sorry for your loss. His wife is incorrect. Assuming his wife is successor trustee (and that may be a BIG assumption) she has a duty to notify all heirs and beneficiaries of your father's death and that she is successor trustee. I agree you should immediately consult and retain counsel. If his wife is unwilling to provide you a copy of the trust, you should consider opening a probate estate. Prior to that time, you will want to investigate title to all real property. Title to property may indicate the existence of a trust. Hopefully, counsel can get the wife to cooperate so that your rights under any declaration of trust can be determined and enforced. If there is no will or trust, you have rights in your father‰Ûªs intestate estate.   Bottom line: retain counsel and do not delay. An uncooperative wife, under the circumstances you describe, may mean she is up to no good. Good luck.

Your problem started with the addendum to the contract, which should have been reviewed by your attorney before you signed it.  Typically, in order to protect a seller, I include a monetary cap or limit on repairs so that if they cost more than anyone anticipated, the seller can either elect to pay for them or back out of the deal. In this case, if you had put a monetary cap of say $500.00 on the repairs you'd be willing to do, you could have easily gotten out of the contract or the buyer could have agreed to pay the remaining $700.00.  Depending on the wording of the contract and the addendum, you may well be stuck with performing this contract, which the buyers could force you to do if they elect to seek "specific performance" of the contract through a court proceeding.  In the alternative, they could sue you for damages (if they didn't want the house), the basic measure of which is the difference between the value of the house and the contract price.  As noted, the buyers could have other additional damages, and the realtors may have damages too if you back out.  I think you should try to sweeten your offer to the buyers by offering the furniture plus some cash to apply toward the repair.  Finally, you cannot do much litigating for $1,200.00 so a settlement would be the best route for you. If you get the case settled, make sure you get a signed release of all claims from the buyer.  Consult with you attorney about any settlement and release.

This is yet another good example if why everyone must remember: You have a right to remain silent. Use it!  Here is additional information and some detail as to how and why it is important to invoke the right to remain silent, and not to discuss anything with anybody who is not your attorney.  Should you find yourself being interrogated, interviewed, or otherwise questioned by any government agent, you should decline to provide any answers, invoke your rights, and secure counsel immediately. You might consider saying only:  I want my attorney. I invoke my right to remain silent. I do not consent to a search of any kind, not of me, my effects, premises, immediate location, or vehicle. I hereby invoke all rights, including but not limited to those in the 4th, 5th, 6th, 9th & 14th Amendments to the US Constitution and the Declaration of Rights in our State Constitution. I want my attorney present before and during any questioning and before discussing any waivers.  If you can remember nothing else, remember these 4 words: "Talk to my lawyer." Say only that, and nothing more.  To understand more about why it can ONLY hurt you to speak to any government agent investigating a possible crime, see http://krazlaw.com/interrogation  So, if you are being questioned, asked to sign things, don't answer anything or sign anything, get an attorney, and, above all else, you have a right to remain silent. Use it!  In Liberty,  -- Michael Kielsky Counselor & Attorney at Law Kielsky Rike PLLC Tempe, AZ 85282 #lawballs  Legal Notice & Disclaimer: http://KRazLaw.com/disclaimer

As with many legal questions, the answer is "possibly" or "it depends."  State law will almost certainly provide for the possible involuntary discharge of a resident from a long term care facility.  You will want to consult with a California attorney who is experienced in local nursing home and long term care facility practice in order to get a definitive answer to your question.    The attorney will likely want to know the type of facility in question.  Is it a nursing home?  Is it an assisted living facility?  Is it characterized in another fashion?  After determining the type of facility involved, the attorney will know which state statute applies to potential discharge of a resident from the facility.  My guess is that California has very specific laws governing such matters.  In my jurisdiction, a resident could be involuntarily discharged from a nursing home for medical reasons or if the resident presents a danger to himself or others.  You have stated that this particular resident does not suffer from dementia.  That suggests his behavior is not a consequence of a medical condition.  Of course, other medical conditions could be causing this type of behavior.  While disruptive, the information you provide does not suggest that this person is dangerous.   If you have not discussed this resident's disruptive behavior with facility administration, you should do so.  Perhaps your mother's room can be moved within the facility.    Beyond that, I urge you to consult with an experienced lawyer in your jurisdiction about this matter.  It may be "possible" for the facility to discharge the resident, but it will "depend" on the resident's behavior, the nature of the facility and the applicable state laws pertaining to this situation.  The attorney will also be able to provide you with counsel regarding the rights of your mom and other facility residents pursuant to applicable state statutes.  Good luck.
