The answer my colleague has  given is absolutely correct.  Many people are confused as to what service is and when the time to answer actually starts so it may be helpful for me to take a moment to explain.          Anytime a lawsuit is filed, whether it be a Petition of Dissolution (divorce) or any other lawsuit, both the United States constitution and the California constitution (as do all other states) require that the person who is being sued or divorced actually receives a copy of the action in order to have adequate notice of what is being filed against them, and to have the opportunity to tell their side to the court.  The law requires that the notice include a summons and copies of every one of the documents that have been filed with the court.           With a few exceptions, these documents must be personally given to the person sued in person by an adult, but not by the person who is suing them.  In other words, in a divorce, it cannot be the spouse who has filed the petition who gives the copy to the person receiving the copy.            If you are out of the country, it is possible, but unlikely that you will be served until you get back into the country.  The time you have to respond (file your response in court) is 30 days in California and that time does not start until you have been served.  Hopefully this additional information was helpful to you.

To add to some of the other responses, at the hearing you might want to ask your attorney, on the record (in front of the judge) to agree not to assert a lien or to agree to formally waive rights to assert a lien on your case, this will make things less complicated if you recover anything later as you wont owe anything to  your former attorney.  An attorney that wants to get off your case, might voluntarily waive this right if asked nicely at the hearing and/or if asked to do so in exchange for you being less dramatic at the hearing for the motion to withdraw.  Also at the hearing, you should also ask the judge to allow you additional time on any pending issues  (to respond to motions, appear at any up coming hearings, appear for trial, etc.), continuing these dates and deadlines will allow you some time to find a new lawyer.  Finally, make sure you get your file from the lawyer that is asking to be relieved and make sure you know the contact information of the attorney on the other side of your case and confirm that attorney has your contact information.  Otherwise, see some of the other comments below and if your case is complicated or you don't think you can resolve it by talking to the lawyer on the other side, get another lawyer, quickly.

Anyone facing a probation revocation and new felony case truly needs to be working with retained or appointed counsel, and should direct questions and concerns about sentencing, possible defenses, and strategies to the attorney handling the cases.  General information in a public forum is not a substitute for advice from a lawyer on a specific case, and there are many sentencing possibilities that can only be fully understood after reviewing both cases, and all other facts.  As a general matter, a person on probation can face imposition of the entire sentence for the violation, for example two (2) years in the question here.  As a general matter, aggravated robbery is a serious felony in Tennessee, carrying 8-12 years for range I offenders, or a likely sentence of 3-6 years if convicted of facilitation or attempt as a Range I offender.  A court has the discretion to order a new term to be served consecutively to a probation violation term.  These are very serious matters, and Tennessee sentencing law can be complicated, so a person in this situation could be facing significantly more or less incarceration depending on the specific case and charges.  Anyone facing criminal charges should rely on advice of his or her attorney, rather than general public information from lawyers who don't know know anything about the specific case.

I strongly recommend against letting the summons and complaint go unanswered even if you move out before the deadline. Once you are out of the property -- completely out -- the court no longer has jurisdiction to entertain the case as an unlawful detainer (eviction) case, but does the landlord know that?  Does the court know it?  If you default, maybe the landlord will go ahead and file the summons and complaint anyway, hoping to get a money judgment against you. Maybe he's not supposed to, but defaulting on the summons is more your problem than his. There is precedent for converting an eviction into a regular lawsuit when possession of the property is no longer an issue, and maybe the landlord will try to convert this into an ordinary collection case. The court would be in error to let this happen if the only summons is a special hurry-up eviction summons, but if you default, you are inviting the error. When the landlord files, even if he's not supposed to, you will have the burden to make it right, and even if you win you will have "eviction" on your tenant screenings and credit reports in the future. If you are determined to handle this without a lawyer, answer the complaint by exactly following the directions in the summons and make it clear that you are not in possession of the premises and there are no grounds for the court's unlawful detainer jurisdiction. If the landlord tries to file anyway, after receiving your answer, you have a much better position for financial recovery for wrongful filing.

I think I would like to know a little more about the structure terms before commenting.  This is hardly a simple scenario as it is presented.  Usually, all liens are required to be accounted for, settled and/or to have hold harmless agreements executed for them before funds issue.  Further, liens are taken care of from up front money, normally, and not over time as lien holders rarely, if ever, will accept terms.    My first question, though, is why is he your agent for receiving structured payments?  They normally do not go through IOLTA accounts (IOLA in New York, anyway), but go directly to the owner of the structure (the client).    There are tax implications for everything, and one important aspect of setting up a proper structure is avoiding something called "constructive receipt," which triggers a taxable event.  This can occur when a structure is not funded directly by the defendant's insurance carrier (or, alternatively, through a SIR), but is actually delivered to an attorney f/b/o client Doe, who then funds an annuity contract.  This can have very negative tax consequences.    There are some open questions here.  You should gather some facts, such as all of the documentation you signed to close the case including general releases, waivers, hold harmless agreements, funding agreements and from before settling, lien assignments.  Liens from other states are valid liens (most especially if you acknowledged them), they are just more difficult for the lien holders to enforce.  There really isn't enough information here to provide a simple answer except to say that, normally, it would be exceptionally unusual for you to have an agent receiving your structured settlement payments.  It would be improper under normal circumstances for such an agent to withhold your payment unless the law imposed a higher duty upon him or her as one exercising his or her fiduciary duty as an officer of the court.  There may be an ethical dilemma raised as to duty to the client versus third party creditors, but the law might mitigate in favor of an innocent third party.  That, however, would be a question for the court to resolve upon a motion for disposition of funds.  There are many questions raised by this seemingly simple query.  With a few more facts, perhaps we might be able to shed some light on the question.

Short answer- Yes you can have multiple people serve as agents. If the original charge resulted in a conviction, then it cannot be expunged.   Only probation before judgment,  a stet,  acquittal,  or nolle prossequi can be expunged.   The first two require that you wait three years.   In addition,  you cannot have any pending charges or subsequent convictions at the time you file for expungement.   So,  if the new theft charge occurred before you filed for expungement and was still pending or resulted in a conviction,  then your Petition will be denied.   I recommend that you contact an attorney to discuss the chronology.   If the Petition was filed before the new charge,  you have an argument that you are still eligible.

No one else has raised this so I will. It sounds like your daughter, the parent of the 16 month old child, is willing to allow you to take care of the child.  Illinois law permits your daughter to appoint you as the Short-Term Guardians {see Illinois Compiled Statutes Chapter 755, Section 5/11-5.4 and for example the Duties of Short-Term Guardian of a Minor in 755 ILCS 5/11-13.2} of the child. If your daughter signs a document under this statute, you can function as the guardian of the child for up to a year. After that, your daughter could do the same thing for another year.  In order for your daughter to give you such authority for more than a year, a court guardianship proceeding would be necessary.

I don't believe its appropriate for a lawyer to sign the client's name to a document and then notarize it.  That creates two problems. The first is notarizing a document not signed in your presence is generally considered gross negligence or fraud; and second, a lawyer who signs a client's signature without authority has acted in excess of his or her authority.  I can see potential bar disciplinary proceedings, sanctions or contempt from a judge, and the potential for some personal liability as well as criminal liability.  Click on "Find a Lawyer" and locate an attorney who handles Probate/Guardianship matters to see if you can undo this mess for you.

You should call opposing counsel anyway to find out what his objection is to the subpoena and maybe you can come to some agreement about what the third party has to produce.

Speaking as a former magistrate: Yes. All that is needed is that the Magistrate finds probable cause, which the US Supreme Court has actually held to be less than 50%!  (Seriously, legal "probable cause" is less than mathematical probable cause.) Still, the Magistrate may have incomplete information, but so long as the magistrate believes the person and finds probable cause (which is easy), a warrant can be issued.  Still, sometimes a good defense attorney can show that the Magistrate should not have issued the warrant in the first place, which can be very helpful sometimes. For this, you will want to hire a local defense attorney with experience and knowledge in this field.  Also, If someone knowingly lied to a Magistrate to get a criminal summons issued, then that is a crime, and can even lead to a civil lawsuit for defamation, malicious prosecution, and other crimes. You should consult with an attorney on that as well.

I'd say gray area, probably not a violation. Keep in mind the big picture of what a credit report is. A credit report reports the status of "debts" (or accounts) to determine the debtor's credit worthiness. It is not about what the creditors/collector is doing or not doing. With any FCRA issue, the core question is whether the entry is inaccurate such that is misrepresents your credit worthiness. On a mortgage debt that "did initiate" a foreclosure, I don't know that you get a FCRA violation when a new entity inherits the mortgage claim and reports what is otherwise true about "that claim," that a foreclosure was initiated.   Now, if you are going to file for other FCRA violations anyway, might as well raise the issue.

You should put all the tenants on written leases using a form you are comfortable with because it will include the additional rules (like late fees) that you are accustomed to and can give you extra rights.  However, you are not required to do this.  It appears that your property is in Seattle, which means the tenants have some additional rights that non-Seattle tenants do not have.  The best practice would be to give a 60 day notice of change in terms (instead of the usual 30 days) that puts them on a written month-to-month lease and increases the rent to market rate.  Note there are also numerous attachments (including a summary of landlord-tenant laws) that must be included in the notice/lease.  This protects you and is easier legally and administratively than having two deadlines that give you only a minor increase in rental income.

Until you are properly served, you have no duty to respond to her request for a domestic violence restraining order. That being said, I would check on the following items:  I would suggest that you check the court website to see if the case has been taken off calendar or if the case has been heard. Generally court websites will indicate whether orders have been granted or not.  If you are unable to determine this online I would suggest that you speak with the court clerk to determine if there are any future hearing dates. I would also suggest that you review the DV-110 to see if any of the orders have been granted pending hearing. I would also suggest you to determine whether a hearing has occurred and whether the orders have been reissued. If they have been reissued there may be a future hearing date. I caution client's against responding until they have been properly served.

The correct answer to your question is YES. If your employment began in New Jersey, New Jersey will assert jurisdiction over your workers compensation case, so long as your employment was not interrupted for very long. The place of the making of the original contract of employment controls jurisdiction. You can establish a case in New Jersey by filing a claim petition in New Jersey. Remember that for certain types of cases, typically back, neck, head, and shoulder claims, you have the right to greater compensation in New Jersey than in New York, under many circumstances. Pick a CERTIFIED workers compensation attorney in New Jersey.

According to R.N.C., Inc. v. Tsegeletos, 231 Cal.App.3d 967, 972-73, 283 Cal.Rptr. 48 (1991), on an account stated complaint, the four-year statute of limitations period begins when credit is no longer extended on the account.  You would review your old account statements to find this date.  The lawsuit must be filed with the clerk of the court within four years of that date.  If you prove that the case as filed after statute of limitations period, you may also be able to get the debt collector to pay your actual damages, costs, and attorney's fees.  Also, there are many things that a debt collector must prove in court to win, even if they filed the lawsuit within the statute of limitations.  However, if the defendant or his/her attorney fails to properly object to inadmissible evidence and fails to present evidence showing the defects with the case, the court is likely to enter a judgment against you. I have been handling such cases for individual consumers since 1997.  Please contact me through my Avvo profile for a consultation.

The fact that there is a war in your native country does not necessary give you grounds for refugee/asylum status. Conditions of general strife that effect the population at large typically do not create grounds for refugee/asylum. In order to obtain refugee/asylum status in the United States you would need to establish you would be persecuted on account of your political opinion, race, nationality, religion, or membership in a particular social group.

Well, the purpose of a debtor's exam is to see if there are any non-exempt assets to pursue against your judgment debtor.  As you mention, you already have judgment...so you would next have to see if there was some basis to pursue an asset of the judgment debtor.  In this case, you seem to be implying that there might be a potential inheritance?  To answer your main question, no...there is no basis to pursue a possible future inheritance.  However, if there is a business, you may want to dig into that a bit deeper.  If it is a coporation, then it's likely protected from any kind of execution (unless the debtor has been commingling personal with business assets and liabilities).  However, if it is not incorporated (a dba)...then you may be able to pursue business assets.  If this judgment represents a large sum of money, you may want to consider hiring an attorney to collect.  Often they will do so on a contingency fee basis (25-40% of whatever they collect).   Good luck

The way to frame this for the judge is not that your rights are being violated, but that the PI trailing you and your child is not in YOUR CHILD'S BEST INTERESTS. What is in the "child's best interests" is the north star for the custody/visitation decisions of family law judges. Note that you probably can't get a restraining order against the PI, but you can request an order which restrains the mom from having a PI follow your child around (i.e. check the box on the FL-300 form for "other" relief and specify). In your declaration, state the fact that you stated in your question -- that your daughter knows of it and looks over her shoulder all the time (and other similar facts). Argue that that mom's actions causes your daughters' visitation experience with you to suffer and that is antithetical to a positive father/daughter relationship. Always present the argument to the judge "through the eyes of the child."

A motion to modify sentence must be filed within 90 days of the setence's imposition.  However, the  question is what happened to the original motion filed two days after trial.  Considering such a motion, let alone granting the relief requested, is within the sound discretion of the sentencing Judge.  I would first determine, from whomever filed the first, timely  motion on your behalf, what resulted from that filing.  It is possible it was denied without a hearing.  If no action was ever taken on the first motion, you might consider asking the court to reconsider the denial of your second motion on the grounds that it be amended to serve as a renewed request to have the original, timely submission, considered and ruled upon. Of course, engaging the services of a qualified attorney is the best means to sort through the actual facts and circumstances, and then arrive at the best approach to hopefully resolve the matter.

"Shouldn't we be splitting everything (income and debts) down the middle until the divorce is finalized?" There is no such law in WA that would require spouses, divorcing or otherwise, to split anything anyway unless there is a court order.  Even when the court orders a division of assets and debts, the division is just and equitable, not "down the middle". Depending on the facts, a spouse may get from 0% to 100% of the assets and debts.  If there is a family law petition filed with the court, you can ask the court for temporary orders.  If you believe the husband is spending all the savings, you need to act quickly before all the savings are gone. Unless there is a court order restraining the spouses from disposing of their assets, the court may not do anything if all the assets are gone by the time the court hears the case.  You should review the specific facts with your attorney to find out your legal options.

You are not bound to the terms of the notarized agreement since it is subject to court approval. There is a lot more required for an agreement to be binding than a simple notarized letter.  There is certain opt out language  that also must be included that probably is not contained in the letter.  The opt out language states the formula of what you would have been entitled to under the Child Support Standards Act.   There will be a presumption that you are entitled to a pro-rata share of 25% of adjusted gross income.  As you noted, that figure is approximately $100 per week, not $50 per week.  You also should tell the support magistrate about the difference in your ex's parenting time and additional expenses to you as a result of less parenting time to the mother.

The Code of Alabama in section 13A-6-70 states that a person is not capable of consent to sexual relations under certain conditions. These conditions are:  "(a) Whether or not specifically stated, it is an element of every offense defined in this article, with the exception of subdivision (a)(3) of Section 13A-6-65, that the sexual act was committed without consent of the victim. (b) Lack of consent results from: (1) Forcible compulsion; or (2) Incapacity to consent; or (3) If the offense charged is sexual abuse, any circumstances, in addition to forcible compulsion or incapacity to consent, in which the victim does not expressly or impliedly acquiesce in the actor's conduct. (c) A person is deemed incapable of consent if he is: (1) Less than 16 years old; or (2) Mentally defective; or (3) Mentally incapacitated; or (4) Physically helpless.  Therefore a person who is "mentally defective" cannot, as a matter of law, consent to sexual relations. Your best course of action is to contact the Office of the District Attorney and request to speak to the 'Victim Services Officer' for more information or, in the alternative, to contact the local law enforcement agency of the location where you reside and request to speak to a criminal investigator and provide this same information, or perhaps contact the Office of the District Attorney and local law enforcement at the same time.

If you have a family law order in place and one part is not complying with it, you need to return to the Family Court for your remedy. There are several options you may have, one of which would include filing a motion to hold the offending party in contempt (which, if successful, will typically result in the court taking action against the offending party to secure compliance in the future). To figure out the full range of options, you should speak with a family law attorney and explain what order is in place and how it is being violated. Many family law attorneys (including my firm) will provide a free initial consultation to let you know where you stand.

You and your family member need to get an attorney.  One attorney can represent both of you.  Yes, since the payment was made to you, they can sue you as well as the person that did the work.   Your family member should pay for the attorney, or cover any amounts that are owed, unless you also took some of the money.   It sounds to me like your family member did not have a contractor's license.  If that is the case, he will certainly lose, and could be required to pay back the full amount and possibly more.   If you cannot afford an attorney, you should at least consult with one.  You need to do that quickly, because you only have a limited amount of time to respond to a lawsuit or you will be in default. You would not be entitled to a public defender.  Those are only available in criminal cases. But, since contracting without a license can lead to criminal charges, if either of you end up being charged with a crime, you will then be able to get a public defender.  That is not good news for you though.  Better to hope that it just stays in the civil lawsuit.   You may also want to talk to a bankruptcy attorney.

I agree with my colleague.  There is a common misconception that if you are on disability leave then you are untouchable.  Meaning, that if you get fired while on leave then that somehow automatically triggers discrimination.  That is simply not true.  The law says that if an employer engages in adverse employment action (such as a termination) because of your disability then that is actionable.  However, you have to prove causation.  You have to prove that you were fired specifically because you are disabled.  That's not easy to do.  You need emails, conversations, witnesses, words or conduct that point to your disability being a significant factor in why you were fired.  Employment attorneys often give free consultations specifically for the reason to use that time to dig into the facts.  It is nearly impossible to know all the important details of what went on simply from this sparse post and as such a detailed analysis from an attorney should not be expected.  You need some one-on-one with an attorney in your area.  Good luck.

It is not illegal to "do something that really upsets" a child. If it were, then parents everywhere would be in jail. ("Terrorize"  has no legal meaning, and is such a value-loaded term that I'm not even going to address it.)   It is, however, illegal to impersonate a child welfare worker to gain a benefit for oneself. The law prohibiting this is ORS 162.365. ("A person commits the crime of criminal impersonation if with intent to obtain a benefit, to injure or defraud another or to facilitate an unlawful activity, the person does an act in the assumed character of: (a) A public servant; or (b) An active member or veteran of the Armed Forces of the United States.")  However, you asked about "standing." This is an acute question. You (or your daughter) have no legal standing to compel criminal charges. That is wholly the prerogative of the police and District Attorney. You can, however, call the police and report this (whether they'll do anything is an open question, but at least you can make the report, and it will look better coming from you than it will from the nephew's mother). I don't believe this gives you an independent basis for any sort of civil claim, either.   You can also notify the child's mother of this incident. Even if the police don't investigate, your testimony (or your daughter's) could be invaluable to her.

There is not a need to have co-trustees, but it is not prohibited either. As a practical matter, having three is going to be more difficult than having one or two. Any trustee is bound by the laws concerning fiduciary duties so technically any combination would have to abide by the same rules and administer the estate pursuant to the terms of the trust. The Trustee will have some discretionary power however, to make several decisions, it depends on what the Trust says. Ultimately it is not your decision, or your siblings, it is your mother's. I would suggest having her sit down with her attorney who drafted the trust, or any experienced estate planning attorney to discuss the pros and cons of each type of scenario and let her decide free from the influence of her children. Good luck.

It depends on any orders or hearings set by the court for your particular case.  When you filed the lawsuit, the clerk should have given you or your attorney service or mailed you a notice of OSC re Proof of Service, or something along those lines. That is the date when a hear will be held related to the status of serving each named defendant and filing a proof of service with the clerk of the court. If all proofs of service for all named defendants are filed, then the hearing should be taken off calendar, which you can verify online a few days after you have filed the last proof of service.  If a defendant is being difficult, you may need to get an extension. Easiest way to accomplish that is to file a declaration at least a week before the hearing explaining your efforts or the efforts of your process server(s), along with any related documentation, being careful not to post any account or other personal information, such as SSN, DOB, or DLN.  Then appear at the hearing and advise how much more time you need to complete service or get an order for service by publication.  The courts prefer the defendants all be served and proof of service filed promptly.  Failure to do it promptly, for some judges, may raise a flag that they need to keep a tight grip on the case, as serving the defendants is supposed to be a relatively simple procedure. Hire a professional process server who can do skip tracing, if you are having trouble serving or finding the defendants. The strategic considerations that affect the relationships between licensors and licensees are the subject of lengthy text books, academic journal articles, law review articles, and ongoing substantive debates among both legal practitioners and academics.  Most, but not all, licensors have one and only one primary objective---to maximize short term and long-term financial gain from exploitation of their inventions and other intellectual property, while at the same time minimizing risk such as the costs of being mandated to participate in litigation.  The debate about "patent trolls" is centered around whether it is appropriate for licensors to reap substantial financial rewards even though neither the licensors nor their licensees actually practice the patented inventions.  Where the invention covers a product that is dangerous or controversial, a licensor may prefer that licensees refrain from practicing the invention unless they provide indemnification to the licensor.  Licensees take such licenses mainly because they are value as part of their defense arsenal when patent disputes arise among competitors.   In other cases, licensors may believe that they will reap more benefits by licensing or selling their invention to a "non practice entity" (sometimes known as patent trolls") who generate revenue by accusing third parties of infringing the patents in their businesses.  In many circumstances, the licensors are universities, individuals or small companies who could not afford to practice the invention, but who expect to reap  meaningful profits by alleging that third parties are using the invention without authorization.  In short, sometimes it is more profitable to litigate than to license and/or practice the invention.  Finally, many companies will pay premium royalty amounts to gobble up patent rights that they can eventually use against competitors during the course of disputes over patent infringement.   Major companies have joined alliance for the purpose of purchasing rights to hundreds or thousands of patents that otherwise could be used by "trolls" to demand huge amounts of damages. Many Fortune 500 companies will purchase third party patent rights purely for defensive purposes---they want to have weapons to use in case one of their competitors sues for patent infringement.  These are complex, fact intensive matters, and there is no right or wrong answer as to the right overall strategy. Licensing attorneys deal with enormously complex strategy issues on matters such as this every day and in the final analysis, the devil is always in the details.

I like your question.  I hear it often.  The insurance coverage you have at the time of an incident (accident) is the insurance carrier that will handle everything related to the incident. This is true even if you switch insurance carriers before a claim is completed.  For example, let's say you have an accident on July 31, 2014 and your insurance carrier is State Farm. And let's say you think the other driver is at fault and the other driver says you are at fault. Now let's say State Farm decides to raise your insurance rates on Jan. 1, 2015 and the July accident is not settled (the other driver still claims you are at fault and wants State Farm to pay, but State Farm says no.)  You feel you  still think you are not at fault for the accident and so you shop for new cheaper insurance. You find a cheaper policy from Farmers. You can switch insurance companies and State Farm has a legal obligation to to defend you until the July 2014 accident matter is resolved (either by settlement, trial, arbitration or whatever.)   So in the situation you describe, even though you switched insurance carriers, you should contact Progressive regarding your additional damage. If Progressive agrees the additional damage is from the accident, they will pay (whether or not they agree is a different story so you should contact your mechanic to confirm the accident is the reason had the additional damage.)  Hope this helps.

I think the other attorneys answering this misunderstood the question.  This is not your case.  In fact, it is my case; I represented the applicant in Serrano v. General Motors.  In that case, my client was found by the Agreed Medical Examiners to be permanently, totally disabled due to fibromyalgia.  The trial judge subtracted 5% for a prior award to the left thumb, and awarded permanent disability compensation of 95% instead of 100%, a huge difference in dollars and cents.  On my petition for reconsideration, the WCAB commissioners correctly pointed out that fibromyalgia affects various regions of the body--the spine, upper extremities, lower extremities, and even the psyche and various internal systems.  Thus, the pre-existing left thumb disability of five-and-one-quarter percent did not "overlap" with the total disability to the other regions of the body caused by the fibromyalgia.  The section of the California Labor Code addressing apportionment to a prior award is section 4664, and it actually sets forth each of the separate regions of the body for purposes of that section.  Furthermore, pursuant to Kopping v. WCAB (2006) 7 Cal.Comp.Cas. 1229, it is defendants' burden to prove overlap, and in Serrano v. General Motors, no overlap was proven by defendants as to most of the bodily regions affected by my client's fibromyalgia.  I hope this helps you to understand the decision, and to apply it to your case.

There are a few things to consider with your question because it is not as straightforward as it seems. Lastly, if  after investigating these issues it is determined you are not responsible for these bills, you will have to decide if you want to saddle your son with this type of responsibility so soon after high school and what impact it may have on your relationship with your son.   I suggest contacting an attorney to discuss these issues, review the relevant documents, and advise the options available to accomplish your goals. If you have an attorney, by all means make an appointment to discuss this matter with him or her.  Otherwise, if you are this far into it, I wouldn't stop now. If you complete your case, since we are in a "conduit" jurisdiction where your trustee is paying your regular mortgage payments in addition to the arrearage, at the conclusion of your case you should receive an "order deeming current" which will tell the mortgage company that your mortgage loan is completely current, and they cannot add any additional "junk fees" like property inspection fees or BPO's (broker price opinions) or otherwise try to claim that your loan is not current.  On the contrary if you dismiss, you are pretty much at their mercy. They can add attorney fees and whatever fees and costs that they wish. The California lawyer is right that you should treat this situation with care, and I'm glad to see from your answer that you do intend to see that your sister addresses these cases.  That she is nearly 18 and has a new life mostly put into place in Colorado will help resolve the cases.  Perhaps the County/District Attorney will simply join defense counsel in recommending that your sister simply pay a fine and be released from the Court's jurisdiction if she is adjudicated of the offenses.  It is unlikely that she'll face adult prosecution for these offenses, unless she has several prior and has failed on juvenile probation, in which case the County/District Attorney might seek adult prosecution arguing that there is nothing left in the juvenile system that will work for her.  (That's unlikely, in my opinion, given the relatively "unsevere" nature of the charges.)  Kansas law requires the juvenile and a parent or guardian to appear at the hearings, so an attorney alone won't be able to resolve it without her attendance.  Normal procedure is for the Court to appoint a local attorney to represent the juvenile unless the family decides to hire counsel; so, it is likely that your sister already has competent counsel.  If the MJ charge is indeed "bogus," your sister's attorney should consider aggressively fighting it -- having a MJ adjudication follow her around for the next few years until it can be expunged might complicate her life.  (The Court could order treatment... She could be required to disclose it on college applications, student loan applications... It might cause ineligibility for loans... Lots of things to be aware of.)  You sister and family should check into whether your sister has appointed counsel in these cases and discuss your goals with them. Depending on how the stipulation is written, Mother may be able to.   She will have to show that there has been a "change in circumstances" since the last child support order was made.  Generally speaking, if the judge ordered a child support amount below the guideline amount, she can ask to change that amount at any time. You do NOT need to show a change in circumstances.  This is true even if your non-guideline child support order was reached by stipulation (agreement) between the 2 parents.  Some examples of changed circumstances are as follows:   The income of 1 or both parents has changed;  One parent has lost his or her job;  One parent has been incarcerated;  One parent had another child from another relationship;  There have been significant changes in how much time the child in the case spends with each parent;  The child's needs may have changed and there may be more (or less) costs for child care, health care, or education; and  There have been changes in any of the factors that are used to calculate child support. I hope this helps you, good luck. a

Joinder is a complicated subject and requires detailed analysis from an experienced litigation attorney.  However, it is difficult to successfully sue someone for contributory infringement unless some very specific facts can be proven at trial.  Contributory infringement for copyright law may be defined as this -   "One who knowingly induces, causes or materially contributes to copyright infringement, by another but who has not committed or participated in the infringing acts him or herself, may be held liable as a contributory infringer if he or she had knowledge, or reason to know, of the infringement."  Accordingly, you must be able to prove the the public figure had knowledge, or reason to know. of the infringement.  You need to contact a good attorney to help you make this decision before you spend your time and money pursuing a potentially fruitless activity.

You say no MOU was signed that day.  I assume that there was no written agreement at all.  There are three questions that I see:  1) Was an agreement reached?  2) Did it cover the current issue   and 3) Is it binding?  The last question is very fact specific.  An oral agreement can be binding if that is what the parties intended.  Sometimes an agreement can be enforced if one of the parties relies upon it.  I would start by contacting the mediator, and alerting him or her to the current problem.  See what the mediator advises.  If the mediator sees the current issue as something new, you can take it back to the mediator to try to work it out.    This time, I would get it in writing, signed by both parties.  If the mediator will not get involved again, and you cannot work it out with the other side, you may have to enforce the oral agreement.  If you need to do that, I would recommend that you contact a litigation attorney with experience in the area of the dispute, and get advice on the three questions I asked above.

In Massachusetts, as in other jurisdictions, there is no statute of limitations on first degree murder  so he could, indeed, be charged and incarcerated 27 years after allegedly committing the crime. If, however, the evidence were to point to his individual being charged with manslaughter it would be subject to a 6 year statute of limitations.  Unlike murder, though, arson in Massachusetts does have a 6 year statute of limitations. So this individual could not be charged with arson unless the statute of limitations has been "tolled," or extended, due to some act.

First, let me congratulate you on moving out of kansas. I am a bankruptcy attorney on the Missouri side of Kansas City and a partner at Upright Law which represents debtors all over the country. Yes, a bankruptcy can help you to discharge the kS fines and get your license back. You have 2 options:  1)  Chapter 7: This is the quick and easy type of bankruptcy that wipes out your unsecured debt and lets you move on with life after only a couple of months. Chapter 7 will not discharge the amount that you owe to kS but it will hopefully wipe out enough other debt that you will be able to pay it on your own after your chapter 7 is complete. 2) Chapter 13: This is the type that allows you to set up a payment plan. It doesn't require you to pay everybody back but it does require payments and takes 3-5 years to complete. Chapter 13 DOES discharge the fines that you owe to kS and allows you to get your license back now. We would then set up a payment plan to pay for your car or house or back taxes or whatever else you are already paying. Most people usually pay less each month to the Trustee than they would have been paying for the same stuff without the bankruptcy.

The easiest way to get the other closing documents is to contact your current mortgage servicer (who you send your mortgage payments to) and request the documents from them. Regulation X of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA), 12 CFR å¤ 1024.36, requires mortgage servicers to respond to written information requests within a certain time period. Because there is a lot of uncertainty as to what information the servicer has to provide under Regulation X, most mortgage servicers err on the side of caution and disclose more information that they legally have to so that they do not risk sanction by the federal government.   Read 12 CFR å¤ 1024.36, which sets forth specific requirements for the form of your written request for information, and and give it a shot. A copy of the regulation can be found at: http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=0cf26b06a11ea2423683b7e0b8f88f14&node=12:8.0.2.8.18.3.1.7&rgn=div8

The Child Support Guidelines set forth the categories of income utilized in the computation of child support, including but not limited to gross income reported or as should have been reported on the most recent federal income tax return, net investment income, voluntarily deferred income and income received from pension and retirement benefits and, at the discretion of the court, attributed or imputed income available from other resources. There are additional categories of income stated in the Guidelines.  Box 1 on Form W-2 represents total taxable wages or salary for federal income tax purposes. The social security wages stated in Box 3 are the total amount of wages subject to the Social Security tax.  Box 5 reports the amount of wages subject to the Medicare tax and typically represents the entire compensation from employment, including any deferred compensation, 401(k) contributions or other fringe benefits which are excluded from the federal income tax. The application of the Guidelines to your W-2 and any other income should be discussed with your lawyer and/or tax advisor.

If you suspect wrong-doing by your sister either under the POA or as executor of your father's estate, then you should consult right away with a Maryland attorney who handles fiduciary litigation. It has been almost three years since your father died; your rights might lapse soon or might have already lapsed.  Because your father was a resident of Maryland at his death, Maryland law will control what happens with his real property located in Maryland and all of his personal property. You could hire a Maryland attorney who practices estate planning, probate, or estate administration to represent you as a beneficiary and to protect your interests in that regard.  North Carolina law controls what happens with the real property in NC. Either you or your sister will need to open an ancillary estate in the county in NC where the property is located. The other of you will have to consent to this action. You could hire a NC attorney who practices estate planning, probate, or estate administration to represent you as executor of your father's ancillary estate in NC or as a beneficiary. The NC court will require an exemplified (signed by a judge) copy of the Maryland probate proceedings.  Good luck to you!

I believe that you address something commonly known as the "commerciality" doctrine - which prohibits a nonprofit organization from operating solely for a commercial purpose in direct competition with "for profit" businesses.  There are two ways that most nonprofit organizations get around this doctrine. The first is that they run the commercial activity as a "side" business that is not substantially large - claim the income as "unrelated business income" and pay taxes on that income.   The second way that they can avoid application of the doctrine is to RELATE the business activity in some way to their exempt purpose, i.e. educating & training students in the art of graphic design.  My guess is that the school has made the determination that their activity is substantially related to their exempt purpose (education) and reported that activity as such to the IRS.

The lien isn't automatically stripped. A motion needs to be filed, properly served, and the judge needs to enter an order that says the lien will be stripped at discharge. This normally happens before confirmation, near the beginning of the case. You need to show the court evidence of the house value, the senior liens, and proof that the lien to be stripped is completely unsecured.   The time at which the property is valued is typically upon the filing of the case in a chapter 13 (in chapter 11s some courts have been ordering that valuations occur at confirmation). But in any case, if you have a lien strip order, from a properly filed motion, the property rising in value won't affect the lien and won't cause it not to be stripped at the end. But it's not automatic, you need that motion to have been filed and the order to have been entered.  Hope that helps!

You may be disappointed to learn that there isn't a single right answer to this question. Like all legal rights, your rights to parenting time are only as good as your ability to enforce them. It certainly sounds like you have a good argument that you should see your daughter this weekend, under the terms of the court's order. By your own account, though, the other parent has already been violating the previously-existing orders. This shows you that having a court order, by itself, doesn't answer these questions.   Putting this in practical terms: You can contact your co-parent and say, Hey, according to the order which you yourself sought, I'm supposed to have our daughter every other weekend; I didn't have her last weekend, so when shall I get her for this one? If she refuses to let you do so, that's one more point to raise with the court at an enforcement hearing, which, as I understand it, you're already trying to arrange.   It's good that you're seeking an attorney's assistance with this - you should direct your questions to them. They're bound to be able to give you a better answer, knowing the whole case, than anyone can knowing only a few sentences over the internet.

Yes.  In Tennessee, in order for an adoption to occur, the parental rights of the parent must be terminated, either voluntarily or involuntarily.  To involuntarily terminate, the petitioners must prove at least one ground and that termination is in the best interests of the child.  There are several grounds on which to file and several factors that the court considers to determine the child's best interest.  The parents must be served with the petition, and if their whereabouts are unknown, they can be served through publication.  As long as service requirements are met, you may proceed without her consent in the event that she fails to appear or otherwise file pleadings as required by law.  The process will be similar for both children.  A name change is an alternative to adoption, and may be available in your case.  The process is substantially faster and less cumbersome than is an adoption.  In addition, a name change does not terminate the rights of a parent nor does it cut off the inheritance rights that arise from the parent/child relationship.  The statutory requirements for termination and adoption as outlined in Tennessee Code Annotated 36-1-113 and 36-1-116 respectively are very specific and must be met with no exceptions.  Therefore, you need to retain a seasoned adoption attorney to aid you in this process.

Residents in a Covenant community do not ever "sign" a HOA contract as it is part of the deed that the resident who purchases in such a community shall abide by the covenants "rules".  The HOA is permitted to sue anyone who fails to abide by the covenants or place a lien on someones property for fines,  unpaid fees, or costs for the HOA to take corrective action should the resident fail to follow the rules.  In addition, any resident may sue another resident for the same things as the rights in the covenants belong to each homeowner and HOA is just an part of the community with authority to act on behalf of the community as a whole.  If someone who lives in such a community does not like the rules or covenants, then their only options are to either move out of the community or try to raise enough support to vote in changes to the rules.

Previously asked and answered.  Again, simply means that USCIS has decided to "reaffirm" (restate again, repeat anew) it's previous approval of the petition in question (despite the fact that the US consulate overseas, in its infinite wisdom, had decided to "re-adjudicate" (take another deep look) at CIS' approval; decided something was wrong and that CIS should not have approved the petition, made them know why in their notes & conclusions to CIS, sent the petition back to CIS with a recommendation for CIS to revoke the petition. Now CIS, most likely after having issued a "notice of Intent to Deny" and giving you 30 days to respond, has decided to reaffirm its initial approval of the petition, most likely after having received a very thorough rebuttal from your attorney, and made its decision known to the consulate. Congratulations! Finally, the "ball "is now is in the Consulate's court of whether to reconsider its previous decision to deny the visa and issue it now, in light of the fact of CIS having reaffirmed its initial approval of the petition.  Best of luck!

Almost all debt incurred during your marriage here in Washington is community liability! That includes a student loan assuming you are not separated at the time of the debt but married.   As a result, if you divorce, you want the divorce decree to state your spouse shall pay that debt timely and not late and indemnify you from it.   Only assets obtained during a divorce are community assets. However, that may affect possible later child support if any kids and later modifications if the spouses money increases. It may also affect your maintenance if any.   Finally, you don't really say whether you want or need to file bankruptcy; if so, I strongly suggest you find an attorney who practices bankruptcy full time and is experienced as the issue is whether you file before you divorce is final and obtain a discharge beforehand..there are many issues related to that.   Some attorneys, like myself , do NOT charge to talk to you . Some can speak to you over the weekend like us also!  Good luck.

If you begin divorce proceedings in the middle of pendency of your JOINT I-751 Petition to remove conditions, you may ask to SWITCH the basis of your I-751 Petition with USCIS from Joint to Waiver. But, before you can switch - you must have proof that you started your divorce. Once you have the proof that divorce is on its way - you must call USCIS at 1-800-375-5283 and report that you wish to switch the basis for your petition to remove conditions. In addition, you must write a letter attaching the summons and index number for your divorce and request to switch the basis in writing (to the service center that's written on your I-751 receipt notice).  It's best to have this done with an immigration attorney. In addition, in certain situations where the beneficiary like yourself is experiencing abuse in their marriage at the hands of their USCIS spouse - I simultaneously file a VAWA (Abused Spouse Self Petition) and add a new basis to the I-751 waiver - the abuse basis for a waiver. We offer free consultations to clients - please feel free to call me directly.

Charges can be dropped, the prosecutor just believes that is not the correct thing to do.  This is why people need someone to defend their legal case.  This system is adversarial, meaning they try to convict, sometimes wrongly, and you need someone to defend, even if you know you did not do this.  Consider: the prosecution does not have the insight you posses of knowing your innocence, they go on what they think is the best evidence.  If you are right, and you have a competent attorney on your side, it should get dropped, but not perhaps as quickly as you think it should be or would like.  Defense attorneys investigate the case beyond what has been done already by exposing alleged victims, police, and witnesses to sworn depositions that hopefully will induce the prosecutor to drop and move on, and possibly forensic analysis where either none has occurred or results are not determinative.  Get an attorney, don't post actual facts on line, and good luck.  We offer free consults.

It could be a significant problem for you if your contract with this person is not in writing. There are a myriad of legal concerns with finding terms to enforce where those terms are "casual" or verbal, as your question suggests. There may not even be an enforceable contract at all, depending on the rest of the facts. That said, oral contracts can be enforceable, their terms are just far more difficult to prove. Consider looking for related correspondence that references the contract and the agreements (such as emails, text messages, or letters). Also consider sending confirming emails or letters to this person with the terms of your contract spelled out, and requesting that this person abide by that agreement. Not as good as evidence at the time of the contract formation, but depending on the response that could be helpful to help establish a contract.  You can sue for breach of contract for any payments past due. If there has been a material breach of the entire contract, or if there is an acceleration or similar clause in your contract, you may be able to sue for the full amount of the contract.  I hope that this is helpful. Good luck to you.

Absent a contractual agreement, most employment in New York is considered to be employment at will. In an employment at will situation, a person can be terminated at any time, without reason. However, there are a number of exceptions to an employment at will termination. If someone is being terminated and that person's civil rights have been violated in any way, such as age discrimination, sex discrimination, sexual harassment, race or gender discrimination, etc. Also, if termination is any way retaliatory for whistle blowing or some other act, an employer may be liable for wrongful discharge. There may be reasons why you have been terminate that your ex-employer would never state to avoid liability. If you think you have been discriminated against in any way, if there has been any form of whistle blowing or if you want to fully vet the facts that led up to your termination, it would be in your best interest to consult with a labor and employment attorney. Such vetting would give you a full understanding of your legal rights. Most Attorneys will give you a free initial consultation.   Best of Luck!  William J. Lasko  Law Office of Wm Lasko 482 Summer Street, 2nd fl Stamford, Conn.  06901 tel 203 3129-6602

You raise a very interesting question. Metoprolol is a beta blocker, used to slow down heart rate and lower BP. It has well known side effects that include dizziness, syncope (passing out), and low BP. In addition, fatigue and sexual dysfunction can be noted as side effects. Your doctor owed you a duty to remain vigilant for such adverse effects. Gather your medical records and consult a NC medical malpractice attorney for further clarity.

If the car you were driving is insured and you had permission from the owner to drive it, generally speaking you should be in good shape with the insurance (there are certainly exceptions to everything but "not being on the insurance" as a named insured does not necessarily mean you aren't covered). Next, the fault issue. Obviously, it is better for you if you aren't at fault. In Florida, adjusters (or ultimately a jury if there are injuries) can apportion fault between the parties based on the statements the parties give. It is kind of hard to tell from your facts if you checked your mirrors or looked over your shoulder to see if the lane was clear before moving into it. At the end of the day, it will probably be your version of the story against the other driver's, so you may want to reflect on the minutes before the crash and exactly what you remember about your actions and the other driver's actions. If there were any conversations about how it happened while you were still at the scene, maybe make some notes while it is fresh in your mind. If you have any questions or concerns, contact an attorney directly as soon as possible.

The last issued I-94 controls your status. The DMV may or may not use the Georgia prior against you.  It really depends on whether GA is a participant in the "Interstate Driver's License Compact" (Compact).  Under the Compact, participant states share your information and will use prior convictions or DMV suspensions to increase punishment.   A quick Google search indicates that GA is not a participant (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Driver_License_Compact#States_that_are_not_members).   This may be why the DMV told you that the GA prior will not be used against you.    As to your trial, the GA prior must be pled an proved, which means the DA in CA must (1) allege that you have a prior conviction and (2) obtain the certified records of your conviction to prove that you in fact have a prior conviction.  You should be on notice if they are going to allege your prior conviction because it should be alleged in your criminal complaint.    Prior convictions are potent character evidence in any criminal trial.  If the DA is going to allege your GA prior, you have the option of "waiving jury" on the prior conviction so that the jury does not hear evidence of your prior conviction.

If you're a resident of Washington, the Washington court will divorce you. If there's a child residing here, the court will enter custody orders. If there's property in Washington, the court will divide it. But if there's no jurisdiction over the husband, there can be no division of property outside the state and no determination of child support (unless he agrees to Washington's exercise of jurisdiction over him). Either way, you'll have to serve him (or have him accept service or join the petition).   So what to do next depends on what you're trying to accomplish. I suggest you invest in a legal consultation with a competent attorney as there's a lot to consider.

You are way ahead of the curve.   Judges in traffic courts see so many defendants who chronically procrastinate about resolving such matters. The fact that you took immediate action to resolve the out of state ticket shows incredible respect for the court system and a desire to be law abiding.  Judges like that.   Moreover, any documentation you can provide that shows the date of the AZ ticket citation as well as the payment date will help the Judge to put context around your claim of good faith.   It is amazing how being the motorist with a valid license and documentation of a history of proactive compliance with DMV and Court orders in a room full of naredowells tends to lead to good things.  You sound like a productive person so any evidence of your employment or family for the Judge to review probably would not hurt either.   An attorney may help you to put all of this together in a more persuasive presentation but you sound like you are on top of things.    As to your misdemeanor issue California Vehicle Code Sec 12500(a) driving without a license is an infraction and a lesser included offense of the suspended or expired license charge that you may persuade a prosecutor or judge to let you enter.  Also, some judges and prosecutors will allow you to continue the hearing for the purpose of completing some community service and will often agree to dismiss the matter outright when that happens. Bring with you suggestions of a location where such community service could be performed and you may be pleasantly surprised with the result.   Finally, just a point of art,  in your presentation I would leave out the part about "... the next day, I DROVE to Arizona..." as technically your license was still suspended/expired. "I immediately made arrangements to appear at the AZ DMV the following day..." has a much sweeter John Q. Citizen ring to it, wouldn't you agree?  Best of luck.   *Not intended as legal advice. All matters are unique. Consult a licensed attorney before implementing any legal strategy.

Aggravated Assault is heard at the Superior Court level, Simple Assault is heard at the Municipal Court level and typically gets heard sooner. It is part of a typical defense practice to file a charge against the person who foiled against you, to try to force a mutual dismissal or another type of favorable resolution. You should consult (and maybe retain) an experienced criminal defense lawyer to represent you, to argue that the charges need to be consolidated with the charges you filed against them. You do not want this moving forward without being consolidated. If you hit him, it may be self-defense, but it will likely be argued by his attorney as a separate assault and not self-defense. Alternatively you can call the victim-witness unit at the county prosecutor's office and ask if the prosecutor will move to consolidate since this may have been done to retaliate against you (in essence a type of witness-tampering type argument). I changed the category of law to criminal defense where I think you will get more responses from other lawyers.

Mr. Brinkmeier's statement that the "ban on possessing a gun is permanent" and is "not negotiable" is absolutely wrong.  Federal courts have repeatedly held that, in the case of state convictions, if the state grants a person a full restoration of civil rights, complete certificate of rehabilitation, or complete expungement, etc., that person is not prohibited from possessing firearms.  This question is answered by looking to the law of the State of Illinois, not federal law.  I would suggest contacting one of the Illinois criminal defense lawyers listed on Avvo to determine if Illinois has such a procedure.  Curt Crowley Jackson, MS Criminal Defense Lawyer curt@thecrowleylawfirm.com

Wisconsin is a community property state, although we call it "marital" property. This does not mean that everything becomes 50/50 after the marriage. Instead each spouse retains, as their respective individual property, what they brought to the marriage. The key is keeping it from getting co-mingled. If the father doesn't add new spouse on any of his accounts, she has no right to control them, and his daughter as POA would. The key is to never, ever, ever, ever mix or combine their accounts. In situations such as this I would have him set up an individual revocable trust and transfer all of his assets to the trust. The daughter can then serve as co-trustee. The trust can contain provisions to benefit new spouse, but she would not be in a position of control.

Yes, if a judge finds that marriage was fraudulent and annuls it, it will be disastrous for a petition to remove conditions.  I was involved in just such a case and it went on for nearly 10 years, including a trip to the Circuit Court of Appeals.  ICE argues in immigration court (because USCIS will almost certainly deny the I-751 and put the person in removal proceedings) that there is no need to readjudicate the fraud issue since it was already decided in the annulment case.  Very difficult and very, very bad.

If you are a party to a lawsuit and this is part of a discovery request, your attorney can make appropriate objections/motions and see what the court decides. If you are not a party to a lawsuit, absent a court order/subpoena, you do not have to comply with a request to turn over emails. If you have been served with such an order or subpoena, then you should get an attorney right away to review, object, and advise.   If this is your work email, in California, it's really the property of your employer, and you have no legal expectation of privacy in it. If it's your personal email, but you chose to log onto it through your work computer, you also lose privacy rights in the emails to a great extent in this state. California is an "at will" employment state, so you can also be terminated. If this has anything to do with your employer, it is imperative that you consult an attorney right away.

The time it takes to draft a Separation Agreement varies by firm.  However, you should have been made aware of the time frame in your initial meeting(s) with the attorney - whether you actually asked or not.  Two months is ample time for any attorney - heck, two months is enough time for some Tibetan Monk to hand engrave the Separation Agreement in triplicate for you!  For our firm, the initial appointment to gather all the information we need and the options you want in the Agreement takes about 20 minutes to an hour on average.  Once we have all the information we need the turn around time to draft the agreement for your review is 24 to 48 hours.  I don't know of any attorney who drafts a Separation Agreement from scratch any more but even if yours does, two months is more than enough time to do it.  Basically, for today's lawyer, the drafting part is simply cutting and pasting the parts that are applicable to your situation.  Our firm uses a in house custom Separation Agreement designed for Corel's WordPerfect program that is part database field input and part giant library of every conceivable separation scenario.  On average, our Agreements  can be done and customized to your unique situation in less than an hour for a flat rate fee of $250 and they are better in quality than others even if priced at $2,500.  How do we know ours are better?  Simple - other attorneys routinely copy our Separation Agreement word for bloody word to use themselves.  So, two months = too long, especially with no return call.

Regardless of that the law says and the fact that mother and father are supposed to be on equal footing, the answer is that barring material negative facts that adversely effect the child's well being in my opinion the younger the child, the more reluctant a judge would be to dramatically change things from the status quo. However, if you  are continually being jerked around and denied reasonable access that is a big factor that goes against the mother. Similarly, if you are not paying child support they will tune you out. You need to pay child support directly and the things that you mention about what you buy on your time is irrelevant to that determination. The sickness issue is usually an irritant to a judge and makes the complaining parent look petty. You do need good representation for sure. Best of luck.

Your family is not liable in any way for sap dripping from a tree.  Sap is really no different than tree leaves.  If a leaf fell from your tree onto a neighbor's car, you would not be liable.  Sap is a natural product of a tree and it drips.  If your neighbor does not want sap on her car, tell her not to park under the tree.  If a tree limb fell on the car, you might have liability.  But that would depend on various factors.   Trees are highly valued in California.  Personally, I would tell your neighbor to quit bothering you.  If she wants to trim the tree branches that overhang her property, she can, but if she damages the tree, she could be liable for up to three times the value. Next time she comes over to complain, ask her to never come on your property again, and give her some maple syrup as a goodbye forever gift.

A Notice of Continuance is a pleading that is prepared, not a form. Please note that the hearing is not automatically continued just because you are not available.  You will have to get your ex's consent since it is his hearing and then the permission from the Court before continuing the hearing.  If he is unwilling, you will have to appear on an ex parte basis to request that the Court continue the hearing.  You should speak with an attorney or someone in the self help center to obtain more information about continuances.

If there are existing leases in effect, you need to check those leases to see what they provide concerning security deposits by the tenants. You can also provide the tenants with a lease going forward and require a security deposit as a term of that lease.

In Maryland, where I practice, Prosecutors (called States Attorneys back East) frequently change in cases.  They retire, quit, and get promoted or transferred.  Someone else will enter or if no lawyer shows, his lawyer will ask for a continuance.  These things have always happened.  Before computers, no one knew about them.  This is a matter of State law.  I would strongly suggest that you consult with a local attorney (perhaps selected from the AVVO website resources) with experience in this area of law, to offer a free initial consultation and perhaps assist with the process. Cases against custodians are generally quite difficult unless you're able to show that the custodian was doing something other than acting as a run of the mill custodian.  There has been some movement on FINRA's part to compel private issuers and broker/dealers to do something more than just put "par" on a custodial statement, but such rules are not intended to be retroactive.  The other issue you have is that if the distribution was from a bankruptcy or receivership, you may be barred from pursuing the claim by court order.  If there was a broker that sold this investment to you, there may well be a cause of action you can pursue in FINRA arbitration, but time is not your friend and it sounds like some has passed since the fraud was discovered.  Happy to assist further.

Refusal without a doubt.  Once you blow .08 or higher, there is a rebuttable presumption that you were intoxicated.  It can be overcome, but the vast majority of judges will find the defendant guilty barring some unusual circumstances.  With a refusal you could still be convicted, but the heavy burden beyond a reasonable doubt rests solely on the prosecutor/officer, and you do not have to rebut a presumption of intoxication.

I once had a case where the couple, who was still legally married , filed a joint petition and said that the marriage had failed and they were living separately but the wife (USC) was still willing to support the petition.  USICS did everything they could to change her mind but she held fast in her support.  USCIS responded by doing nothing on the I-751.  They wanted them to divorce.  Five years passed and the wife wanted to divorce so she could remarry.  The did this without an attorney till this point (things may have gone differently had they retained counsel) .  The I-751 was eventually approved but only after we threatened a mandamus action in federal court.  So, the point of the above is to tell you that you could have a very long and painful road.  It may make more sense to divorce if that is what you want and then just prove that it was a good faith marriage that ended in divorce.  Whatever you do, I strongly suggest that you seek the assistance of an experience immigration attorney to advise and assist you with the I-751 filing.

(2) Yes, if you are found in possession of stolen goods, and you know the goods to be stolen, you can be arrested, charged, and prosecuted for possession of stolen goods. This is a HUGE problem and sadly you aren't the only person stuck in this gray area that appears to offer too few solutions . The date you filed on 7-8 stopped all legal proceedings. The landlord cannot obtain a future judgment against you assuming you complete your case and obtain a discharge. The landlords CAN obtain a judgment NOT for a monetary judgment but for a right to enter the property. But I advise my clients to give the landlord a letter with the keys indicating they are ABANDONING the property  if they want. Why? Because moving out is not enough, but abandonment is necessary for the landlord to regain possession. Proving abandonment  is hard as simply moving out is not enough as a tenant does not have the duty to live there, just pay for the right to. So a letter of abandonment makes it clear and then no further legal action is needed and thus no later judgment that might be misread. As a result of no judgment, he cannot garnish you either.   The above assumes you did NOT take action to intentionally damage the property in which case the landlord would have to file an adversary action against you in bankruptcy court! Good luck.   PS if you receive a motion for relief from stay the landlord is simply trying to make sure all is done correctly and wants a court order indicating he or she can continue obtaining back possession of the property, not a judgment for money against you!

Ultimately, this analysis depends on what the terms of the lease itself state. Without having more information, the likelihood is that giving you a signed lease agreement constituted an offer to you by your landlord. Offers are open until, amongst other things, they are rescinded.  As you acknowledge having received the offer but not having signed it, and thus not accepted it, prior to now having been informed by your landlord that he had changed his mind, the most likely technical legal scenario is that the landlord has revoked and rescinded the offer, and the un-executed agreement that you have (and are considering signing) is no longer legally adequate to create an enforceable contract, regardless of whether or not you now sign it. Ultimately, then, the decision at this point as to whether there is to be a new contract is, practically speaking, with your landlord.  A contract is a meeting of the minds; if you know that the terms and/or fact of the contract is against the landlord's will, then it is not enforceable.  Should you wish to agree to all its terms as previously drafted, you may be able to sign and return the contract to your landlord as-is, and then ask that he acknowledge and agree to its terms and the acceptance thereof in writing.  In short, this is you proposing a new offer to him, with identical terms to the offer he proposed to you but then rescinded.   Of course, do also keep in mind that your landlord is under no obligation to accept your offer.   Ultimately, a more detailed understanding of the facts and the history of the parties is necessary before one may full advise you on how to best present such an offer moving forward, with the hopes that it would be agreeable and enforceable.

If you make your child beneficiary of your will, the money will be held in a blocked account for the child until they reach 18 years old.  The money cannot be used for their care. [I have sat next to 16 year olds in court who could not wait for their blocked inheritance account to be distributed at 18 so they could buy the red sports car.] Then they receive the money to do with as they please.  A very bad idea.  Insurance policies have named beneficiaries and they will not pay to a minor child unless ordered to do so by the court.  Insurance policy with named beneficiaries are not subject to probate. The funds will be released at 18 to the minor. I suggest two approaches.  Have a lawyer prepare a trust and make the trust the beneficiary of your life insurance policy.  Your will and trust can nominate a guardian for your child till they reach 18 and can require payments for their care and well being before 18.  After 18, you can specify multiple payments over time until they reach an "age of reason" under the control of the trustee. The other approach is to create a will that creates a testamentary trust after your death but this may require court approval in probate.  The insurance policy would pay your estate as beneficiary. In either case your will can nominate a guardian for your child. I recommend you sit down with an estate planning attorney and discuss the option available to you.  This is not something to do yourself.

Short answer is - likely no.   We would need to know a bit more information on the will and the wording.   If the will simply gives the house to the three children (regardless of who can stay as a minor child) then all three own the property, including the one who is currently living there.   All three parties have to pay for the care and upkeep of the home in equal shares. All three have the right to live there. All three can do what they wish with their shares.   Eviction is not the legal process you are looking for here.   A Partition Action is. If one of the owners of the home does not wish to sell his share (whether or not he lives is not really a factor) the others can sue for partition and force the sale of the home.   Partition is a legal maneuver that requires a skilled attorney to handle.  I strongly suggest that you seek the services of a skilled attorney who has already done several partitions. In Avvo's attorney search, type type the word partition and then pittsburgh as the location.   I wish you a successful resolution to this matter.

If that is the case, The Florida Dept. of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles rules provide:  The driver of a vehicle involved in a crash resulting in injury to or death of any persons or damage to any vehicle or other property in an apparent amount of at least $500 shall immediately by the quickest means of communication give notice of the crash to the local law enforcement department;  however, if the crash involves damage less than $500, no injuries, the vehicles did not need a wrecker, and the crash did not involve an intoxicated or "hit and run" driver, you may download and complete the following report for insurance purposes.  http://www.flhsmv.gov/fhp/html/crashrep.html
