I assume that you are asking about section 404 of the Clean Water Act (CWA).  That section is presently codified at 33 U.S.C. å¤ 1344.  Section 404 of the CWA establishes a program to regulate the discharge of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States, including wetlands.  Activities in waters of the United States regulated under this program include fill for development, water resource projects (such as dams and levees), infrastructure development (such as highways and airports) and mining projects.  Section 404 requires a permit before dredged or fill material may be discharged into waters of the United States, unless the activity is exempt from Section 404 regulation (e.g. certain farming and forestry activities).  The permitting program is predicated on the premise that the CWA prohibits people from discharging dredged or fill material if a practicable alternative exists that is less damaging to the aquatic environment or if the nation‰Ûªs waters would be significantly degraded.  In other words, when someone applies for a permit, they must first show what steps they have taken to avoid impacts to wetlands, streams and other aquatic resources; that they have minimized the potential impacts; and that they will provide compensation for all unavoidable impacts that remain.  Even though the CWA uses the term "waters of the United States" in its definition of "navigable waters ("The term ‰Û÷navigable waters‰Ûª means the waters of the United States, including the territorial seas), the Act does not itself define the term "waters of the United States."  Instead, one must look to the Code of Federal Regulations for a definition:  The term waters of the United States means    (1) All waters which are currently used, or were used in the past, or may be susceptible to use in interstate or foreign commerce, including all waters which are subject to the ebb and flow of the tide;    (2) All interstate waters including interstate wetlands;    (3) All other waters such as intrastate lakes, rivers, streams (including intermittent streams), mudflats, sandflats, wetlands, sloughs, prairie potholes, wet meadows, playa lakes, or natural ponds, the use, degradation or destruction of which could affect interstate or foreign commerce including any such waters:    (i) Which are or could be used by interstate or foreign travelers for recreational or other purposes; or    (ii) From which fish or shellfish are or could be taken and sold in interstate or foreign commerce; or    (iii) Which are used or could be used for industrial purpose by industries in interstate commerce;    (4) All impoundments of waters otherwise defined as waters of the United States under the definition;    (5) Tributaries of waters identified in paragraphs (a)(1) through (4) of this section;    (6) The territorial seas;    (7) Wetlands adjacent to waters (other than waters that are themselves wetlands) identified in paragraphs (a)(1) through (6) of this section.  During the 1970s and 1980s, this definition was upheld and found to cover  "virtually all bodies of water" in the country.  Int'l Paper Co. v. Ouellette, 479 U.S. 481, 492 (1987).  Unfortunately (at least for people trying to find a firm definition), the Supreme Court has now ruled that this definition is too broad.  Rapanos v. United States, 126 S. Ct. 2208 (2006).  Even more unfortunately, in making that determination, the Court could not reach a majority opinion.  Instead, it issued five separate opinions that overlapped in part and conflicted in part.  Five of the nine justices agreed that the case should be sent back to the lower court for clarification of the facts, but they offered wildly divergent and contradictory rationales for the standard that the lower court should apply in determining what waters were subject to the CWA.

Truth is, you can sue your own dog if you want to--so as a technical answer 'yes' you can sue Congress.  As a practical matter--'no' you cannot successfully sue Congress.   You have no individualized harm, no legal grounds, no damages, no standing, no tort committed, no contract broken, no crime committed, no law violated (there is no law that says Congress must 'do their job' (whatever that means) and Congress would have to give you permission to so them--figure the odds.      Your opportunity to change the course of Congress' work is every 24 months at the ballot box. If you work together with like minded Citizens you MAY be able to impact Congress' efforts.  You might be able to find an unethical lawyer willing to take your money (likely a lot of it no doubt) and file suit as a stunt--nothing more.  You'd be out the dollars with nary a mention in the local paper.

Your landlord has a variety of options - and if you are on a month to month rental and been there less than one year, his smartest choice (assuming you are not currently behind on actual rent due) is to simply give you a 30 day No-Cause Termination of Tenancy Notice, which it sounds like he did.  He could have given you a 30 day For Cause Notice for failure to pay the late fee(s) but that would have allowed you to pay them within 14 days and continue living there - something he apparently no longer wants.  This way, he is assured he can get you out - if not within the 30 days on your own volition, then with a court's help.  If you are still there after the 30 days are up, he can (and likely will) go to the courthouse and file eviction paperwork.  You will be served a copy and must either get out or show up at court on the date/time specified in the paperwork you will be served.  If you continue to fight it and lose, or if you don't show up in court when/where you are supposed to, then the court will give the landlord a Judgment of Restitution, ordering you to get out.  If you still do not leave, then the landlord can have the Sheriff come out and physically remove you from the property.  If you come back without the landlord's permission, you will be subject to immediate arrest for trespassing.  Do understand that you will find it much harder to find a new place to rent if you make your existing landlord file in court to get rid of you and harder still if you make him go all the way through getting a Judgment of Restitution and/or having the Sheriff throw you out.  Potential new landlords will almost always do a check on such things prior to renting a new place to you and they normally refuse to rent to someone who did that to their last landlord.  Understand that the landlord will likely just deduct the late fee charges from your security deposit before returning whatever balance you have coming back or, if it is all used, he may still bill you for the late fees, even though you are out.  If you still do not pay them, if he thinks it is worth his effort, he can then sue you for the fees, presumably in small claims court.  All said and done, if you are late paying your rent 4 out of 5 months that you've been there and then fail to pay the late fees besides, you should not be surprised that the Landlord wants to throw you out.  Almost all landlords would and unless you change your behavior, you are likely to find it increasingly difficult to find a new landlord that is willing to rent to you and once that happens, it can take years to change that.

I guess I stand very much alone from the other lawyers in my answer to this question! Exempted assets will remain exempt from attachment after the case, even as to a debt determined non dischargeable, (with minor exceptions, discussed below).  Bankruptcy Code å¤522(c) provides that unless your case was dismissed, all assets that were allowed as exempt during your case will remain exempt after the case, with only a few sensible exceptions. The debtor does not need to rely on non bankruptcy exemptions to protect such property.  This is a very obscure section of the Bankruptcy Code. In my 35 years of BK practice, I think I have had to invoke it only one time. It is understandably overlooked practitioners.  The excepted debts this does boil down to domestic support , debts secured by liens against the exempt assets, student loans that were obtained fraudulently, and persons who were insiders at banks and who committed embezzlement or theft of institutional assets resulting in a debt they owe to the FDIC, or to other Federal regulatory agencies, and any resulting entity.

If a lawsuit seems likely, you should consult an attorney.  It's possible that the terms of your purchase agreement and/or the terms of the mortgage approval give you a way out of the purchase agreement.  However, assuming that's not the case, here are some principles of law that apply to this situation.  First, the seller is not going to be abe to get specific performance.  That works for a buyer of real estate because real estate is deemed to be unique.  However, the seller is getting money in exchange for the real estate, and that's not unique.  Instead, when the buyer breaches a purchase agreement for real property, the seller can sue for money damages, and the seller must mitigate damages.   That means the seller must make reasonable effort to find a new buyer, and then the damages are equal to the price the original buyer agreed to pay minus the price the new buyer agrees to pay.  And if the seller rejects a reasonable offer from another buyer, his damages will be limited to the difference between what the original buyer agreed to pay and what the other buyer offered to pay.  In addition, there may be some other incidental damages that accrue during the time the seller is looking for a new buyer.  Can you be forced to sell your house?  Well, that's an eventual possibility, but there are lots of other possibilities.  First, if the original buyer is sued and loses, all that matters is that the original buyer pay the damages owed.  It doesn't matter where the money comes from.  So, for example, if the orignal buyer doesn't have the cash, he or should could take out a second mortgage on the house to pay the damages.  Ultimately, if the damages aren't paid, it's possible for a judgment creditor to execute the judgment against assets owned by the debtor -- which could mean that the original seller could force a sale of the orginal buyer's house.  But it's a long way from where you are now to that point.  As I said, if it looks as if you are going to get sued, or if you are in fact sued, you should consult an attorney.

The landlord cannot use "self-help" measures to evict or lock out a tenant.  The landlord is required to serve a three day notice and then obtain a writ of restitution from the court in an eviction action.  Furthermore, the Landlord cannot change the rent amount in mid lease.  You will need to show you had a 12 month lease and had made your payments.  There is an exception for abandonment of the premises.  The landlord can retake possession of the rental unit if there is evidence the tenants abandoned the premises.  Utah law presumes abandonment if the rent is more than 15 days late, the tenants' belongings are in the rental but there is no other reasonable evidence the tenants remain living there.  In this situation the Landlord is required to safeguard the tenants' personal property for at least 15 days, although tenants are liable for moving and storage costs.  Because you and the Landlord dispute the lease terms you will need to provide the court a signed copy of the lease and proof your payments were timely and current at the time of the lockout.  A detailed and accurate property list will also be necessary to prove damages.

The city will probably not get involved in this situation as it is a civil matter.  You can have a surveyor come to your property and stake out the boundary line to determine if your fence encroaches onto the neighbors property.  These things usually come up when the neighbor decides to sell his land and the buyer does a survey which determines that the fence is in the wron place and he is possibly out of possession of a portion of his land.  Assuming thatyour fence does encroach onto your neighbors land, you could bring an action for adverse possession to try and obtain the land.  To do so you would have show open and notorious, continuous, and hostile possession and use of the land for a period of at least 10 years. Such a suit is diffucult to win and could be costly.  If your fence is encroaching onto the neighbors land you may be able to settle the dispute by entering into a boundary line agreement where you both agree that the fence is in the wrong place and you make no claim to ownership  of the land. That would effectively bar you claim to adverse possession of the land and allow the fence to remain in place.  On the other hand, if your fence does encroach onto your neighbors land he can bring an action to force you to move your fence.

Courts typically require both sides of the case to meet and confer regarding their respective pretrial documents, including pretrial motions, jury instructions, witness lists and exhibit lists.  Many courts require the parties to file jointly.  Check your court's local rules and contact the clerk of your department to determine your judge's particular requirements.  Whatever your courtroom's procedure is, each of your exhibits will be assigned its own number.  That number will be used for the duration of the trial, regardless of how you organize, introduce and present your exhibits.  You will need multiple copies of each, so that you, the judge, opposing counsel and any witnesses may view them during trial.  If you have your own internal way of organizing your exhibits for ease of use and reference during trial, all the better.  But just know that each one of your exhibits will have its own number.

In Prince George's County, you have two options: (1) trial, to try and prove you're not guilty of intending to steal the items you were stopped with after passing the sensors; or (2) have your lawyer cut a deal with the prosecutor to perform some hours of community service in exchange for the charges being dropped and without having to admit that you did anything wrong.  I do not include the third option of pleading guilty, because for a first offense, it should be unnecessary.  Getting the charges dismissed without cutting a deal would depend on the State's case and witness availability, and usually means you're proceeding to trial and are rejecting a community service deal. no matter what, you should avoid a conviction and will be able to have the charges expunged (erased) from your record.  Only the community service option, once arranged, offers a guaranty that you will be able to do that at the earliest time.  Going to trial risks conviction, and even if the judge grants you a "PBJ" disposition (which strikes the conviction), you would have to wait three years to get the charge expunged.  In order to be eligible for immediate expungement going the trial route, you'd have to be found not guilty.  Get a free consultation with a lawyer familiar with PG County and explore the strength of your defense as well as the best decision as to how to handle these charges.  You do not want a criminal record for life, as that will make finding a job much more difficult.

Your contractor is also required provide you with unconditional lien releases for all amounts that you pay him and for each subcontractor and supplier.  Your contractor should also supply you with the license information for any subcontractors being used. You may want to meet with a local construction attorney to make sure you are adequately protected.

A prosecutor cannot ethically put a criminal defendant in jeopardy of conviction based on testimony that the prosecutor knows is false.  That is called suborning perjury and carries very severe consequences for the prosecutor's life and career.  The cases where that happens are very rare.  Knowing this should answer the question you pose.  A prosecutor must reasonably believe that a witness' testimony is truthful to put them on the stand and a jury must later be able to be convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the statements were knowingly false in order to successfully prosecute a perjury charge.  It would be (and is) a rare case where the prosecutor has reason to believe the witness will testify truthfully when they call them to the stand and then obtains strong evidence that they knowingly lied after they present their testimony.  It occasionally happens that someone will actually lie in Court about something that can be easily and clearly established and in some of those cases the District Attorney will pursue criminal charges.  In most cases, however, things are not that clear and it is up to the defense attorney to point out the weaknesses in the testimony and expose questions about the witnesses' credibility.  It would be nice if everyone who intentionally lied could be put in jail, but safeguards are needed to avoid prosecution of people who honestly remember or see things differently.  The inability to establish what is in a person's mind beyond a reasonable doubt raises practical problems to most perjury prosecutions.

Your web forum needs proper terms and conditions of use. These are typically drafted giving wide latitude to the webmaster to remove accounts, content, etc. at their discretion.   As noted, they should also clearly note the contact person or entity responsible for handling take down requests pursuant to the DMCA. This contact is also required to be on file at the US Copyright Office in order to properly qualify for the safe harbor my colleague was referring to. The DMCA specifically speaks to copyright material, but you will not be held responsible if a user infringes on a trademark by using it in their username. Whether that even amounts to a trademark infringement is not even clear here.   I suggest that you consult with a lawyer in private and discuss your objectives with the site in more detail. You can start by calling around to several for a free phone consultation, get some insights then pick the best fit to work with.   Best regards,  Frank Natoli-Lapin, LLC

Basically, you need a Montana attorney to clear this up for you in Montana, or it will never go away. If Montana is alleging the person being held in custody had fled Montana to avoid prosecution, then there will be an initial hearing in Minnesota within a week or less of being arrested. At that hearing, the defendant can either waive extradition, meaning he or she agrees to be taken to Montana, or can fight extradition. If the defendant fights extradition, then bail will be set and the defendant will be allowed to remain in Minnesota. The bail usually only is good for the county the person was arrested in, however, and if the defendant goes to another county he or she may be arrested again because the Montana warrant will remain outstanding and open until the defendant sorts it out in Montana.  If the defendant is fighting extradition, then there will be a review hearing set for 30 days later, and if Montana has not dropped the warrant or the defendant has not voluntarily traveled to Montana and sorted it out by that time, another review hearing will be set for 30 days after that. At any time, Montana can get a governor's warrant to insist that Minnesota immediately send the defendant to Montana, but that is something they don't do in a lot of cases. If Montana doesn't get a governor's warrant by the time 90 days is up, then the defendant is free to go in Minnesota and the extradition is dropped. That does not mean the warrant is gone, however, and it could still be used to arrest the defendant in another state.  These answers are general information about the law and they are not legal advice about how to handle a specific case, since we don't have all the facts of your situation. You need to contact one of the Minnesota attorneys directly in order to get help with your actual situation. This helps you identify the important things you should discuss with the attorney who you contact. Feel free to ask follow up questions too, but remember that no attorney-client relationship is formed through Avvo unless you contact an attorney directly to sign an agreement for representation.

If this is an uncontested divorce where the parties have agreed to custody, parenting time and child support and will not be seeking spousal support, asset division or retirement plan division, the process can be accomplished in just a few weeks (depending on the Court's calendar). Judges, for the most part, are mortals.  They, with some exceptions, are fully human, with lives and brains and such.  You might be surprised to know, they actually make friends like anyone else! That is, they go to a bad setting like a bar or club or go see OPP or jail or a courtroom and start right there.  I note you put as topics, criminal, criminal charges, criminal defense and felony.  I am sure a judge is such a matter would be happy to be friends with someone involved with such a case.  The defendant is probably an innocent person and the victims and witnesses usually have NO connection at all to any of the situation and have NEVER done anything to place themselves in a bad position, and generally everyone in these cases are usually responsible, law-abiding people with great judgment, who get into these situations through no fault of their own.  I'm sure any judge would be thrilled to make new friends out of people who they meet in the context of such a case. I would just walk right up to the judge and announce your desired friendship!

The ninja character you've silhouetted, Strider Hiryu, and video games / comics in which it appears are protected under various U.S. copyrights.  The recognizable inclusion of Wolverine is another concern.  Further, most of the apparel appearing on SplitReason.com (and many other "mashup" style t-shirt printers) includes reproductions of protected characters.  No person should confuse the apparent availability of such items with their legality.  It is not impossible for one to create, in what would be a retroactively-legal fashion, mashup-style apparel using variations of protected characters in the absence of a proper license; however, such combinations need to be providing some sort of commentary or critical angle and should be carefully evaluated by an attorney.  Theoretically, the more straightforward approach would be to obtain proper licenses from the copyright owners.

The statute provides that domestic violence injunctions can be taken into consideration.  Florida does not have custody, it has time sharing.  In this instance you have "mild" violent behavior in a high conflict setting with the childr(en) not present.  It is not excusable behavior on his part, but I think it is highly unlikely that there will be any change in the time sharing arrangement because of this.  I think it is more likely that the judge would place restrictions on the interaction between the two of you in relation to the children - either in an injunction or in the divorce itself - than that it would prevent him from seeing his children based just on this incident.

I agree with my colleague Clifford Miller's answer.  In addition, the appellate process runs like this.  The appeal will be before the 5th District Court of Appeal in Daytona.  The stalker will get to file the first brief, which is technically due 70 days after the notice of appeal.  However, that deadline usually is extended by the fact that the clerk of court and court reporter need more time to complete the transcript of the hearing and the index to the record, which shows the 5th District what happened at the trial court level.  Once the record is finished, the stalker will have 20 days to file a brief.  Then your wife will have 25 days to file an answer brief (which can be extended if necessary), and the stalker will get the chance to file the last written submission, called the reply brief.  Either party can request an oral argument before a 3-judge panel of the DCA, which will probably take place 2 to 4 months after the reply brief is filed, if argument is granted.

If you have a mental exam you will have a basic mental status exam and possibly psychological testing. It is important that you are honest with the examiner.  They have access to your other medical records, so anything that you have admitted to your own doctor or during a hospitalization will be in your file, and if you are dishonest, that can have a huge impact on your chance of success.

You are now once again provided with the name of the ALJ prior to the hearing. It is normally on the hearing notice that you receive when your hearing is scheduled. There are rare occasions that an ALJ may not be available on the day of your hearing, and another ALJ can still step in at that time to hear your case. Although the name of the ALJ is no longer withheld, that does not mean that your case cannot be reassigned for other reasons, even after you have already received notice with an ALJ name listed on it.  You are also correct in that the Social Security Office of Disability Adjudication and Review is required to provide you with at least 20 days notice of your scheduled hearing date. However, you can voluntarily waive this 20 day notice. Most hearing office actually try to schedule hearings 2-3 months out, and normally only schedule unrepresented individuals with less than 30 days notice.   As an attorney, I have access to all my clients' files through an electronic system. As part of that system, I am given the name of every ALJ assigned to my cases after the hearings are scheduled. This helps me prepare my clients for the specific ALJ assigned to their claim.

Your father's estate can pursue this debt just the same way your father could have had he saw fit during his lifetime.  It's just a little harder when you're piecing together his evidence, but presumably it's not impossible to overcome the burden of proof, especially if you can show proof of payments.  The thing I would caution you, however, is that in cases like this (I have seen it more than once) the interest rate is usually usurious ("loansharking") and illegal.  The maximum interest rate in NY for a personal loan is 16% and if the interest rate your father was collecting amounts to more than that, a court will not only not enforce the agreement, it may void it as a matter of law.  Good luck!

As my colleague properly indicated, it's unlikely anybody will volunteer his or her time. The reason for this is the same as the reason for your challenges with completing the forms. These are generally developed as a "one-size-fits-all", and - as I'm sure you've realized - every family has different circumstances, and each circumstance may invoke a different area of the law . The reason this process can be difficult is because you need somebody who will view YOUR circumstances and ensure the final paperwork meets the requirements of YOUR divorce. In this situation, you now need to either: a) start over; or b) find somebody who will review all the documentation and make the necessary adjustments/corrections. Option B may actually be more costly. Most lawyers in your area would not charge for a consultation so I would recommend asking around. Good luck.

Most Swiss banks have branches or associated banks in the U.S.  You can visit one of those branches in the U.S. and inquire regarding granting access to or co-ownership of the box to  a second person.  The bank is really interested in assuring that the rightful owner of the box is authorizing the change in access.  They will probably require a signature guaranty from your local bank where you have an account and sufficient identification to assure they have the real owner.  Upon your death, your finance could visit the Swiss bank  in Switzerland and empty the box. To qualify for E-2 classification, the treaty investor must:  Be a national of a country with which the United States maintains a treaty of commerce and navigation Have invested, or be actively in the process of investing, a substantial amount of capital in a bona fide enterprise in the United States Be seeking to enter the United States solely to develop and direct the investment enterprise.  This is established by showing at least 50% ownership of the enterprise or possession of operational control through a managerial position or other corporate device. An investment is the treaty investor‰Ûªs placing of capital, including funds and/or other assets, at risk in the commercial sense with the objective of generating a profit.  The capital must be subject to partial or total loss if the investment fails.  The treaty investor must show that the funds have not been obtained, directly or indirectly, from criminal activity.  See 8 CFR 214.2(e)(12) for more information.  A substantial amount of capital is:  Substantial in relationship to the total cost of either purchasing an established enterprise or establishing a new one Sufficient to ensure the treaty investor‰Ûªs financial commitment to the successful operation of the enterprise Of a magnitude to support the likelihood that the treaty investor will successfully develop and direct the enterprise.  The lower the cost of the enterprise, the higher, proportionately, the investment must be to be considered substantial. A bona fide enterprise refers to a real, active and operating commercial or entrepreneurial undertaking which produces services or goods for profit.  It must meet applicable legal requirements for doing business within its jurisdiction.

The following is from a Bench and Bar article by Hon. Luise Dovre Bjorkman and David F. Herr, which discusses the "new rule."  http://mnbenchbar.com/2013/06/reducing_cost_delay/   Rule 5.04 is amended to require that any case be filed with the court within one year after its commencement against any party, unless the parties stipulate to extend the filing period.  This rule does not change the rule for commencement of actions‰ÛÓcommencement is still accomplished by service and filing is not required at that time.  But within a year after commencement, the action must be filed or it will be deemed dismissed.  Dismissal under the rule is with prejudice.  The goal of this rule is not to create more dismissals of actions, but to require that they be filed and placed under court management and scheduling within the first year.  Dismissal with prejudice occurs by operation of the rule‰ÛÓthe court doesn‰Ûªt act on it and nothing has to be filed to obtain the dismissal.  Passage of a year from commencement against the first party without filing would create a dismissal; it would essentially create an "estoppel by rule," much like the mandatory counterclaim provision of Minn. R. Civ. P. 13.  If a subsequent attempt were made to litigate the issue, either in another action or by the belated filing of the original action, the rule would create a bar to the assertion of the claims in the prior case.  The rule does not discuss whether relief from the dismissal would be available, but Rule 60 might be available to allow relief from the dismissal if the criteria of Rule 60 could be met.  The most likely basis under Rule 60 would be "excusable neglect," and the parties seeking to proceed with the case would need to establish both neglect (relatively easy to do) and excuse (perhaps not as easily established).  Counsel should not rely on this life-ring, however‰ÛÓRule 60 allows for relief from an "order or judgment," neither of which would arguably exist for a dismissal by operation of Rule 5.04.  Counsel should understand that the rule provides for dismissal of the action, not merely the complaint.  This likely means that counterclaims, cross-claims, and third-party claims would all be dismissed.  And all that will be necessary to prevent that is for any party to file any pleading with the court, so it should not be at all Draconian.

According to the IRS, In determining whether the person providing service is an employee or an independent contractor, all information that provides evidence of the degree of control and independence must be considered.  Facts that provide evidence of the degree of control and independence fall into three categories: 1.Behavioral: Does the company control or have the right to control what the worker does and how the worker does his or her job? 2.Financial: Are the business aspects of the worker‰Ûªs job controlled by the payer? (these include things like how worker is paid, whether expenses are reimbursed, who provides tools/supplies, etc.) 3.Type of Relationship: Are there written contracts or employee type benefits (i.e. pension plan, insurance, vacation pay, etc.)? Will the relationship continue and is the work performed a key aspect of the business? Under Colorado Law, 9 guidelines are established. If the worker is an independent contractor, then the employer must not:   1.  require the individual to work exclusively for the person for whom the services are performed; 2.  establish a standard for the individual; 3.  pay the individual a salary or an hourly rate instead of a fixed or contract rate; 4.  terminate the work of the service provider during the contract period unless the service provider violates terms of the contract; 5.  provide more than minimal training for the individual; 6.  provide tools or benefits to the individual, except that materials and equipment may be supplied; 7.  dictate the time of performance, except that a completion schedule may be established; 8.  pay the service provider personally instead of making checks payable to a trade or business name of the provider; and 9.  combine the business operations of a person for whom service is provided in any way with the business operations of the service provider instead of maintaining all such operations separately and distinctly Depending on all the facts of your situation, your employer may indeed owe you back taxes and you should see an employment attorney in your area as soon as possible for a closer analysis.  As for benefits, that is less clear, but you very well might be.  The United States Department of Labor is actively pursuing companies who violate labor laws by misclassifying employees as independent contractors:  http://www.dol.gov/whd/media/press/whdpressVB3.asp?pressdoc=Southeast/20130509.xml  You may also be entitled to back wages for unpaid overtime. A full analysis of your situation is necessary; get yourself an employment law attorney.  There are many good ones in Denver.

There is not a case holding that the responsible party pay for a replacement car that is better than the car that was totaled.  Rather, the defendant is responsible for paying you the 'Actual Cash Value' of your car at the time of the accident (taking into consideration many factors such as age, condition, etc.)  Moreover, the at-fault party is possible under insured for the property damage portion of this accident making you ability to settle with the insurance company significantly more difficult.  This is where having collision insurance would help you.  Your insurance would pay your damage now and they would have to try to collect against the at-fault party.  But, you write that you have liability only.  As a result, if the at-fault drive has insufficient property loss coverage (such as the state minimum of $5,000), then your approach should be different.  You should consult with an attorney as to how and why filing a small claims action for your property damage at this time may be your best bet even if your car was worth more than $10k. See:  http://www.dca.ca.gov/publications/small_claims/file.shtml and http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/ItemA9.pdf for $10k limit if NOT personal injury from a car accident.

if a company isn't actively trading, then no-one needs to work in it. If you need someone to do work in the company it cannot be you, and at that point you need to find someone. If all that is happening is that you are having occasional board meetings and planning the future course of your investment, you don't need to hire some one to sit there and do nothing all day. Remember that you cannot manage the company!!!!! If someone is acting under your direction on the day to day business of the company, you are working without authorization. Use the smell test. If it smells at all iffy, it probably is.

First, sorry to hear about your situation. I know it's VERY frustrating for homeowners trying to save their home when they keep getting the run-around like this!  Just to be clear, is there a foreclosure sale scheduled? If so, you will need to file an emergency motion to cancel sale immediately. I agree with my colleague and will suggest you retain an attorney to help you . In addition, since you submitted documentation recently, the new CFPB Regulation-Z prohibits foreclosure while the modification documents are pending. It's imperative that you or the atty include this point in your motion to cancel sale OR abate the proceedings (if the foreclosure sale has not been set) and attach a copy of the pertinent section of Regulation-Z to the motion. Hopefully this will help you and will force the bank to get their act together and review the documentation so they can provide you response to your modification efforts without moving forward with the foreclosure proceedings.  As mentioned by my colleague, if by chance this does not work, then a Chp 13 will stay the proceedings  (Automatic Stay) where you can workout a Chp 13 modification. Best of luck and hope it works out for you.

I'm glad to hear that she's at least gotten out of that situation. When analyzing the potential success of a VAWA-based petition, it's really important to have all of the factual details about the situation. A lot will depend on the severity and nature of the abuse she suffered, as well as information about her relationship and spouse (such as his citizenship/immigration status and whether the marriage was entered into in good faith versus for immigration purposes). If her abuser was a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, the fact that she's taken out a restraining order and involved the police could suggest that she's got a strong case, but she should seriously consider speaking to an immigration attorney to get a full sense of her case and what to expect moving forward. These can be difficult situations to talk about for someone who has suffered abuse, but it is important to make sure she knows what her options are, and what she needs to do to to maintain the best chance for success in her case.

You have asked asked several questions.   Disclosure:  most probation terms include "disclose your probation status and terms upon request of any peace or probation officer"   Search:  If someone in the car is in probation, that entire passenger compartment is probably fair game, but not the person of someone not on probation or subject to search.   Bottom line? You're risking a felony probation violation. Get ahold of your lawyer immediately and discuss this thoroughly.

Unless it was specifically provided for in the court order, your kid's Mom is probably not required to provide clothes for their vacation. Courts will modify custody and visitation orders but only if there is a "substantial change of circumstance," and if the modification is "in the best interest of the child/children." Courts do not typically like to spend time on this kind of minutia.  My practical advice to you is to not send the clothes you buy to Mom's house, but instead keep them so that you are prepared for these types of situations. The less bickering between you and Mom, the better it is for your children. I believe children are more often than not to be aware of these kinds of issues and the more you and Mom can get along, the less stress will be imposed upon them.  If Mom is that vindictive there is nothing you can say to get her to cooperate. Stop trying, and instead do what you can personally to make your kid's life better.

Not without nolle prossing the charge and having the charge reissued, which I have never seen happen with a reckless driving ticket so there's no need to worry about that.  For the most part, the charge is what it is.  Many officers will cut drivers with a good record a break by writing what could be reckless by speed (i.e. 20 mph+ over the limit) as general speeding tickets.  The advantage is that you avoid a potential misdemeanor.  The disadvantage is that you'll still get 6 demerit points from the VA DMV.  You may still be eligible for a reduction at court, so don't dismiss the idea of hiring an attorney if you don't want 6 points.  Good luck!

However, this may not be what happened in your case because your new lender would have attempted to contact the old lender directly to get a payment history and that is what could have caused the problem, not necessarily the credit report.  You have no legal contract to pay the mortgage personally, but if the loan is not paid according to the contract the home can be foreclosed on.  IF you pay off the loan, they will issue a re-conveyance of the deed of trust .  It has no affect on the title or the deed that you have, just the lien created by the deed of trust.

As a green card holder, your 19-year old child will be in the F2A category. You would only be able to file both the I-130 and I-485 concurrently if the F2A category were current. For December 2014, the priority date for F2A will be March 22, 2013. You can file the I-130, but you will have to wait until your priority date comes up on the visa bulletin before filing the I-485 (assuming your child does not age out, is still maintaining her status, or otherwise does not fall out of the F2A category).

The Prosecutor has the discretion to restore (re-open) the Marijuana case in conjunction with your criminal case on the new arrest. Therefore, you can essentially have two open cases in criminal court as a result of your new arrest.  Based on the little information we have, I presume that you are being charged with criminal possession of a weapon in the 4th degree (PL 265.01(1)), which is a class A misdemeanor and is punishable with up to 1 year in jail and a fine not to exceed $1,000.  PL 265.00 (5) defines "gravity knife" as:  "any knife which has a blade which is released from the handle or sheath  thereof  by  the  force  of  gravity  or  the application  of  centrifugal  force  which,  when released, is locked in place by means of a button, spring, lever or other device."  The Prosecutor must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that you possessed a "gravity knife."  I suggest that you reach out to an attorney so he/she can evaluate your case and give his/her honest opinion as to whether or not the Prosecutor can prove their case against you and what options are available to you in handling your case.  Best of luck,  Asaf

If your grandfather never lived in the United States, then even if his father was a citizen, he would not have transferred his citizen to his child.  There are probably too many residence requirements in the chain down to you to give you any benefit. And even if everyone except your great-grandfather were still alive, and your GGF was a citizen,  and everyone else wanted and could afford to change their lives and try to re-establish residence, you still wouldn't benefit for at least 5 years.  DACA might be a better opportunity for you if you are young. Or maybe our President might offer you some assistance soon.  If you are retracing your great grandfather's steps then learning more about him simply because of who he is could be valuable to you - but not to make you an accidental citizen.

Subpoenaing the officer used to be common practice and a good strategy in itself.  In many courts this is no longer the case.  Many agencies now direct their officers to show up and prosecutors are becoming more diligent in securing the officer's presence.  In addition, subpoenaing the officer often just gives he or she the opportunity to show up and fill in the missing information on the ticket with live testimony.  In my opinion, you should only subpoena the officer if you have a reason.  If you are challenging the law "as applied" it could backfire as the officer could testify to additional facts not in his report.  On the other hand, if you are challenging the law on the grounds of vagueness, there is probably nothing the officer can testify to that will change anything.  In general, most judges in this area are not going to hold subpoenaing the officer against you. The bigger question is "does the officer have more potential to help or hurt you if he or she appears?"  Since I don't know the facts of your case I cannot answer that for you.

I have great news for you! I am an immigration attorney. Sounds like you need me :) In this instance, there are a couple of considerations. You should expect to be placed in removal proceedings. It does not sound like you will be charged with an aggravated felony. First, this does not appear to be a crime of violence, and secondly, as you described it, it sounds like you received straight probation. As such, under sec. 1101(a)(48)(b), this probably wouldn't be an aggravated felony anyway (called "agg-fel" in our parlance). Now, if this is NOT an aggravated felony, you might qualify for various types of relief when put into removal proceedings. Most importantly, however, you are not disqualified from bond. That's really important -- as nothing is a morale crusher like sitting in the pokie for six months waiting for your immigration court individual calendar hearing (fancy term for trial on the merits). Various places in the country have differing bond amounts (i.e. each immigration court is different). However, for a typical offense of theft, you can probably count on at least a $7500 bond. Only an immigration judge can take away your LPR status -- so while CBP (custom and border patrol) may hold your card, the judge alone will make the final determination. What to expect at that 23 April meeting: Well -- a lot of sitting around. These things are reminiscent of a bad 'B' grade horror movie. Dark waiting lobby, lots of unhappy people, most of them confused, a person walking around calling for the next individual to "come back." You will be asked about your status, and you will be told that you are deport-able. Most likely you will get an NTA at that point (Notice to Appear -- that's the summons paper to immigration court). Occasionally, ICE will come take you from the airport. If that happens, you will held until either bond is set (ICE can do that) or you are seen by an immigration judge -- usually within 10 days. Give us a call if you would like to discuss this further -- but absolutely do it before the 23rd. We have extensive experience representing folks in removal proceedings and we can do a lot to put your mind at ease. Although you may wish to voluntarily depart, doing so is a death sentence to your LPR (legal permanent residency) status. That should be an option of last resort tied to post-hearing voluntary departure. You may have excellent equities arguing for your remaining in the US. You can reach us at 703-402-2723. A consultation on the phone is free. We practice up and down the East Coast.

Generally, having more exemptions gives you more after-tax income, which results in less support to you.  However, I have found that DissoMaster creates various changes that are not always expected.  You should be able to go to the courthouse or go online to the DCSS website and use their child support (and spousal support) calculator to run both scenarios and see how and if the difference in exemptions impacts your support.  You will also want to remember that other deductions including mortgage interest and property taxes can change the amount of support, as well as mandatory union dues, unreimbursed business expenses, hardship deductions, etc.  You may want to consult with a local family law attorney to run your support scenarios for you.  They can give you a more comprehensive analysis and possibly reveal more deductions that help you get the optimal amount of support in your case.  Hope this helps a little.

Please don't until you talk to an experienced bankruptcy attorney.  There are ways to spend whatever funds you have, but paying back rent is not one of them. I am attaching a link to some free videos that explain how bankruptcy works.  Most Arizona consumer bankruptcy attorneys offer a free consultation about the basics of bankruptcy.  Please take time to educate yourself about bankruptcy and to determine which attorney is the best to assist you in the process.  Don‰Ûªt assume the attorney is being completely honest about their experience and capabilities.  Check them out.  Beware of law firms who operate their companies like "mills".  Make sure to talk to the attorney you will be working with, not a staff person.  When interviewing the attorney ask them how long they have practiced bankruptcy law.  Ask what percentage of their practice is focused on consumer work.  Ask whether they are experienced in both chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases.  Ask the attorney for references.  Ask about their policy of returning phone calls.  They should be committed to answering specific questions about your situation and help you understand your options.  If, after talking with them you are still confused about the issues you raised, find another attorney.  Check them out with the various ranking sources: such as www.AVVO.com, and the State Bar.  An attorney is should be your guide through this process.  They should educate you, be there to assist you in how to avoid pitfalls and help you plan for your future after bankruptcy.  There are hundreds of "bankruptcy" attorneys in Arizona.  Of those just a few will fit the criteria set forth above.  Again, bankruptcy is a very complicated process and you want to use an attorney who will be there when you need them. I'm sorry your father has had to go through this. It sounds like an ugly situation.  First, it is not necessarily illegal for an employer to require an employee to work 7 days in a row or 20 hours straight through. However, employers must pay overtime for all work over 8 hours in one day, or over 40 hours in one week. Also, employers must pay overtime for the first 8 hours worked on the 7th consecutive day of work. This is pursuant to California Labor Code section 510(a) which states:   510.  (a) Eight hours of labor constitutes a day's work. Any work in excess of eight hours in one workday and any work in excess of 40 hours in any one workweek and the first eight hours worked on the seventh day of work in any one workweek shall be compensated at the rate of no less than one and one-half times the regular rate of pay for an employee. Any work in excess of 12 hours in one day shall be compensated at the rate of no less than twice the regular rate of pay for an employee. In addition, any work in excess of eight hours on any seventh day of a workweek shall be compensated at the rate of no less than twice the regular rate of pay of an employee. Nothing in this section requires an employer to combine more than one rate of overtime compensation in order to calculate the amount to be paid to an employee for any hour of overtime work.   There are some exceptions to Labor Code section 510 but they do not appear to apply to your father's situation.  If the employer did not pay your father overtime as required, then your father most likely has a valid wage and hour claim.  Further, if your father is owed any money for overtime, then he is also owed money for waiting time penalties:  California law requires employers to pay an employee's final wages at the time the employer ends the employment, or within 72 hours if the employee resigns without giving 72 hours notice.  "Final wages" consist of regular pay, overtime pay, accrued and unused vacation pay, PTO, commissions that can be calculated, some bonuses and perhaps other components.  It does not include unused sick leave.  If the employer does not pay as required, there is a penalty against the employer and in favor of the employee: the employee‰Ûªs pay continues as if the employee were still working, every day until the employer pays in full, up to a maximum of 30 days. The employee is entitled to interest at 10 per cent per annum on the unpaid amount. Also, if the employee must go to court to get his or her pay, then the employee is awarded reasonable attorney‰Ûªs fees and costs of suit.  You asked if it is legal for an employer to cut an employee's hours. Yes, it is, unless the REASON the employer cut the hours is based on illegal discrimination. For example, if the employer cut your father's hours because of his age, and your father is at least 40 years old, then it would be illegal age discrimination to cut hours. The comments about your father being "too old" could be evidence of illegal discrimination.  I suggest your father speak with one or more experienced employment law attorneys with whom he can discuss the details of his situation. To find a plaintiffs employment attorney in California, please go to the web site of the California Employment Lawyers Association (CELA).  CELA is the largest and most influential bar association in the state for attorneys who represent working people. The web site is www.cela.org. Click on "Find a CELA Member" and you can search by location and practice area. Many CELA attorneys represent clients throughout the state.  Good luck.

If your landlord wanted you to move out, he needed to provide you with a written notice terminating the tenancy. If you've lived there under one year, it needs to be a 30 day notice. If you've been there over a year, it needs to be a 60 day notice. In the City of San Diego, if a tenant has been living there for more than 2 years, the landlord cannot terminate the tenancy except for very specific, stated reasons. (However, this does not apply to lodger situations as you appear to be in.) If you and the landlord mutually agreed to terminate the tenancy, then the landlord has no right to unilaterally insist upon an earlier move-out date.  Landlords have 21 days after the tenant moves out to provide either: a) The entirety of the deposit back; or b) Less than the whole of the deposit back and an itemized statement and receipts for repairs.  If the Landlord in your situation does not do either of these, Small Claims Court would likely be an excellent venue for you.   Below I've included a link to the Landlord/Tenant Handbook put out by the California Department of Consumer Affairs. It contains a great deal of useful information.

You are doing the right thing by keeping records of your attempts to make the child available for parenting time.  There are two ways that a parent can ask the court for help with parenting time: first, the  parent can file a motion to enforce parenting time. This would require the other party to present evidence that you are not in compliance with the divorce decree.  Second, the parent can file a motion for contempt.  This would require the other party to prove by clear and convincing evidence that you willfully disobeying a court order.  Either way, if your ex files something in the court, he will have to prove that YOU are in violation of the court order.  However, the courts usually HATE micromanaging family matters.  If you two can find a way to work this out, do that.  Hire a private mediator if you need to. It's cheaper than hiring two lawyers and easier on the family as a whole.

Child Custody and Child Support are two separate issues for the Court to decide.  A parent nor the Court can prevent another parent from having access to his or her child purely because said parent is not financially supporting their child.    However, with that being said, because there is a current child support action filed against you, the Court does have the discretion to require you to pay child support retroactive from the date your child's mother filed for child support.  I would recommend making some payments to the mother (or showing proof (i.e. receipts, credit card statements, etc.) of what expenses you have paid for your child while he is in your care), otherwise it is possible that you can be hit with a large amount of arrears owed on top  of the regular monthly child support (depending on several factors, including but not limited to, the custody arrangement that is ordered and both yours and the child's mother income).    As for your income, if you are earning income, no matter how it is earned (i.e. it does not have to be earned from a day job), and you reported 0 on your financial statement, that can go against your creditability and the court can impute income to you, as well as places sanctions against you to include ordering you to pay attorney fees to your child's mothers.  I would recommend, at a minimum, to amended your financial statement to have the correct income you are receiving. This may allow you to save face when your case is heard in Court.

If your upper extremity pain, shoulder pain and neck pain are caused by repetitive keyboard work, you may have a viable claim for a repetitive stress injury under the Pennsylvania WC Act. First, print out the emails that you sent to your supervisor and HR. Save them. You may need them later.   Second, look in the lunch room or other common areas in your place of employment. Does you employer post employment law poster somewhere? Look for a poster about your WC rights. Does your employer have a panel of WC doctors? If so, you need to go see one of them for 90 days. If not, you are free to go to a doctor of your own choosing. A workers compensation lawyer can help you by recommending several doctors in the specialty you need to evaluate your condition.   Once you get a medical opinion that your condition is work related, send it to your supervisor and HR. Again, save the email. Ask for the contact information for the workers compensation insurance company. If it is not provided, a workers compensation lawyer can look that information up on line for you.  Your employer must promptly report your claim to its workers compensation carrier once you give adequate notice. Talk to a workers compensation lawyer to determine if your prior emails were sufficient to create this obligation. Once reported the carrier has 21 days to accept or deny the claim.  These types of claims are usually contested, so I highly recommend you call a workers compensation lawyer as soon as you can. The lawyer will guide you through the process step by step. The lawyer gets a percentage of what you recover, so there is no fee if there is no case. The only time there is a fee is if you win. All the advice you get before then is free.   If no doctor will say your problem is caused by work, your employer still has an obligation to accommodate you under the American's with Disabilities Act. You may also have medical leave rights under the Family Medical Leave Act. Talk to a workers compensation lawyer first and that lawyer will guide you to other lawyers, if needed, to address those issues.

The key underlying trademark law concept for you to understand is that in the United States tidemark rights are fundamentally founded upon the concept of use.  If a particular company has a priority of use and that use, over time, ahs been consistent and appropriate, then that company will, generally speaking, have enforceable trademark rights against anyone who comes along later and uses the same or similar trademark.  Although you have not provided details, there might be an argument that would allow multiple companies to use a similar (or even same) trademark if there is little or no risk of confusing the two marks.  After all, trademark law is intended to protect CONSUMERS, not companies.  It seems a more prudent course would be to use a different trademark for your won goods and services to avoid future headaches.

If you have proof, the first thing you need to do is to stop the bleeding.  The Court rules and the Estate and Protected Individuals Code simplify the means for an interested by which you can do that.  Under the relevant court rule, "the court may appoint a special fiduciary or enjoin a person subject to the court's jurisdiction under MCL 700.1309 on its own initiative, on the notice it directs, or without notice in its discretion."  MCL 700.1309, in pertinent part, provides as follows: "Upon reliable information received from an interested person, county or state official, or other informed source, including the court's files, the court may enter an order in a proceeding to do either or both of the following: (a) Appoint a special fiduciary to perform specified duties. (b) Enjoin a person subject to the court's jurisdiction from conduct that presents an immediate risk of waste, unnecessary dissipation of an estate's or trust's property, or jeopardy to an interested person's interest." So if you are an interest person, you can provide the court with reliable information, the court has the power to immediately appoint a special fiduciary and to order your cousin to not do anything that will dissipate the estate's assets.  If this is a real concern of yours, you should move on this quickly.  Good luck.

This question requires more characters to answer than I think are allotted.  Your question touches upon principles of stare decisis that are the subject of entire classes in law school.  Put simply, California appeals courts are broken up into geographical areas.  Decisions of the court of appeal are binding upon California superior courts but not upon other California appeals panels/courts.  Where you see a rejection (as in the Yvanova case) it is another appeals court making its independent (and valid) decision.  The legal basis for a lower court to not follow an appellate court opinion usually has to do with the specifics of a case.  For instance, the Glaski case allowed the Plaintiff's complaint to go forward and has some helpful language to others who would sue a bank and MERS regarding either one's ability to foreclose.  Where that can fail (and where the superior courts are finding their bases for not following the appellate court) is in the specifics of any new case.  In the Yvanova case, for instance, the court determined that the Plaintiff did not have standing to challenge the assignment and therefore could not make the argument made in Glaski (if the Plaintiff had standing, then presumably the court would have followed Glaski).  In other cases the superior court uses as its basis for declining to follow Glaski that the Plaintiff has admittedly failed to pay the mortgage and therefore any deficiencies in assignment does not negate that factual base - that foreclosure was proper because the Plaintiff did not satisfy the terms of the mortgage agreement.  The bottom line is that one appeals court in California can differ from/disagree with another appeals court (until the California Supreme Court weighs in and provides binding precedent for all) and superior courts can usually find a factual basis to differentiate their decisions from binding precedent if they don't agree with the appellate court decision.

There is a difference between granting you custody and determining paternity. The latter is more difficult. The child and you are in Texas. There is not any question that you are the child's mother. With or without the father's presence, the court may award custody.   The paternity issue is more difficult. Certainly if the putative father submits himself to personal jurisdiction in Texas by submitting to a blood test or signing an acknoledgement of paternity, the Texas court can determine paternity. That finding would be binding in New York under the Full Faith and Credit provision of the U.S. Constitution. On the other hand, a default would not advance your cause. Before awarding child support, the New York court would have to examine the extent of the Texas personal jurisdiction. A default in Texas is not going to support a finding of personal jurisdiction. Under the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act, you could try to rely on the Texas finding of paternity and an award of child support, but it would be very difficult.   Were you to have a default in Texas, nothing would stop you from going to New York, via counsel there, to establish paternity and obtain child support. You would have to go there for trial. But, its possible that the court might order, if the other side did not consent, that your pre trial deposition be taken in Texas while you remain there, caring for your child. At least, the court might order the other side to pay your expenses of traveling to New York. There are companies that specialize in setting up video and audio depositions. Once a blood test is ordered and positive results are in, it's really down to a question of how much child support should be ordered. Good luck with this

Well,  the PLF is not the final arbiter.  First, the PLF will review the issues and make a determination about the errors made.  Remember that the standard is that the attorney acted with the same average care and expertise as any lawyer practicing in that area - not that he is perfect or right all of the time.  But if the PLF said that there was no "malpractice" you can still sue the attorney for malpractice if you can find an attorney to take the case.    Its difficult to find someone to bring this kind of case but there are folks out there.  Its not that lawyers don't sue other lawyers, its that the standard is average level of competency sand the issues in your divorce are subjective (different people might see them in different ways)  so unless there was a dramatic wrong (like not showing up for court at all)  it will be difficult to find someone.     As to your specific issue regarding attorney fees, consider this.  In order for your ex wife to get an award of attorney fees, she has to ask the court for it and provide support for what her attorney did.  So if you figure that her attorney only charged $200/hour - which is low end of divorce work- then her attorney put in 20 hours of work.  That's way more time than just showing up and having a hearing - so its unlikely that the judge awarded the fees for any reason other than that is the time  her attorney put into the case.  He would more likely award attorney fees where he thinks that it took the (in your case) wife going to court to get an award of spousal support, child support, or a division of property.    so in assessing the case, i tend to agree with the PLF but to answer your specific question, the only way to  appeal is to find someone to sue the attorney on your behalf.

LLC wind ups require specific steps and formalities.  for a general overview, you should review Utah Code Annotated 48-3a et. sq regarding those subsections that discuss dissolution.  Then, you should consult legal counsel.    That said, the general rule is that only a contracting party is liable for the contract.  Thus if you are not personally part of the contract you would not be immediately liable for the debt.  However, if you fail to follow proper wind up procedure you could become liable for the debt under theories such as piercing the veil, or fraudulent transfer. Due to prior convictions for drug offenses, even a personal possession case of marijuana against you could be charged as a felony, thus this could become a felony charge if the mushrooms test positive for a controlled substance.  Psilocybin and Psilocin are not commonly tested for substances, so it may take the state crime lab months to complete an analysis of the substance.  It could have been charged earlier if you'd told the officer you believed them to be psilocin/psilocybin containing mushrooms or if the officer had conducted an initial Ehrlich's reagent test for indole alkaloids.    My guess is that the officer intended to write out a warning ticket, ran your license and discovered your prior offenses.  This is an issue you will deal with for the remainder of your life as every law enforcement check is going to turn up drug convictions and likely lead to officers doing what they can to search your vehicle.   There may ultimately be a way to contest the K9 search if the officer unreasonably detained you longer than necessary to write a ticket without reasonable suspicion to believe that there would be any drugs in the vehicle.    In addition, I've never heard of a dog being trained to detect mushrooms as they are relatively uncommon as far as the drug trade goes.  Though a K9 may detect marijuana odors long after there has been marijuana in a vehicle.  It may be possible, with an in depth records review, to challenge the reliability of the dog and thereby challenge the officer's probable cause to search the vehicle if you did not consent to the search. Judges differ in their settlement conference practices. The basic format, however, is for the sides to explain their views of the case and how they intend to prove any disputed facts. Typically, a judge will ask for a letter from each side spelling out that party's view of the case  (with a copy of any key documents). The letter is submitted before the conference and helps the judge become familiar with the case. If you have questions about what you need to submit before the conference, I would just call the judge's chambers and speak with an assistant. They are usually very helpful.   During the actual conference, most settlement judges will give an indication of their opinion about how the case will turn out. That "opinion," however, is not binding and is not part of the court record. Also, anything the parties submit is excluded from the court record. Unless the parties consent, typically the settlement conference judge will not preside over the trial.    Again, the most efficient way to be prepared for the settlement conference is to just call the judge's chambers and ask about his or her particular manner of handling the conferences.

You should speak to a local medical malpractice attorney in your area.  The attorney that you choose will likely need more information than you have provided above in order to evaluate your case. Please note that Florida requires that a medical provider in the same field that you are proposing to bring the suit file an affidavit stating exactly where the proposed Defendant fell below the standard of care. According to your summary above, it appears that your current physician is indicating that the blood clots are a direct result of the testosterone.  Try and see if your physician will also talk to the attorney that you will be consulting with.  Once you speak with an attorney, then decisions such as whether you qualify as a member of a class action or whether you have any claim at all can be determined. In addition, you do not have to take the opinion of just one attorney, if they believe that you do not have a claim, you can also ways get a second and third opinion.  Work quickly though, medical malpractice actions have a two year statute of limitations in Florida. Good luck.

The penalty for possessing less than 10 grams of marijuana in Maryland is currently 90 days and a $500 fine, or both.  The new law does not go into affect until October 1, 2014, and you cannot postpone your case until after that date and ask for that penalty.  The new law in Maryland is a civil citation and the first offense max fine is $100.00.  However, this may be deceiving in a couple of aspects.  1) It will still appear in the Maryland Judiciary Case Search and employers and schools will still be able to see the conviction for a civil citation.  2) most police officers still charge possession of paraphernalia, which is still criminal, and a must appear offense in Maryland. I would contact an attorney and have that attorney work with the State's Attorney's Office in trying to resolve the charges.  Your prior record may hurt that effort, but a lawyer can still help you.  The SCOTUS did rule that police now have to have a warrant to go into someone's phone, but the State would probably argue that your consented that the search.  Hire a lawyer and let him fight the charges, contact my office and I will discuss in depth your options.

Here are solid tips to help you to hire a lawyer.  By Alan Brinkmeier  1Check Background  Always check background, experience, and disciplinary record before you hire the lawyer. You should inquire about the specifics of a lawyer's background while you are trying to determine whether to retain the attorney or not. Check with the Board of Professional Responsibility to see if the lawyer has been publicly disciplined and why? Make sure you drill down into the details to make sure you know your attorney's record.  2 Do Interviews about Experience and CLEs   Consider interviewing more than one lawyer before you make your final choice. Ask if the lawyer has handled similar matters, and what the outcomes were. Also ask if the lawyer has taken any continuing legal education courses which relate to your problem. Going it alone, you can miss and say the wrong things if you are not represented by an advocate as your attorney. This is why experience is a necessary line of inquiry as you look for a skilled counselor.  3 Confirm Fees  Find out from the lawyer what you will be charged for the legal services provided. Just because a lawyer's fee is higher, that does not always indicate competence to properly handle your matter.  4 Seek Referrals  Ask your friends, family, business associates, or other acquaintances about lawyers they have used. Chances are you will come up with at least a few names.   5 Interview  Feel comfortable with your lawyer after you conduct the interview at the lawyer's office. Trust is essential.

All parties have the right to review the other parties' documents prior to any hearing.  There are two remedies for not serving the other party a document in the time prescribed by the rule.  The judge can allow a continuance so the other party has time to respond or the document can be excluded.  If you serve the document the day of the hearing the case will probably be continued with the temporary order remaining in place, but you do risk the chance that the document will not be adopted into the record and the permanent order will be entered.  Service must be done (1) in person, (2) by a person over the age of 18 and (3) by a person who is not a party to the case.  Having a process server deliver the document is the best way to do this so that you avoid any allegations of violating the temporary order.  Delivering any message, outside of your response declaration, through a third party may also be a violation of the order.   You can find a proof of service form on the Washington Courts website, along with declaration forms and other important documents.

Typically, a Motion for Default is filed when a biological parent has been served, either personally or by publication and they have not responded.  The Motion for Default is then heard so that the court can determine whether the parental rights of the biological parents can be terminated.  You need to ask your attorney whether or not you need to be present when the Motion comes up for hearing.    With regard to the Guardian ad Litem, every county has a slightly different procedure for GALs.  Again, your best resource for how this is to be handled is to consult with your attorney and get the answers that you need.

You need to review everything with a local landlord-tenant attorney. IF the rental truly is illegal as a dwelling, then that will be an absolute defense for failing to pay rent, since you owe no rent for an illegal dwelling - indeed, you may be entitled to recover everything you have paid to date.  Otherwise, you may or may not have a problem.  Habitability issues normally may qualify you for owing a reduced amount of rent but not excuse paying rent at all.  A landlord's failure to deliver what was promised may also be a breach of the agreement and allow you to get out of the lease or sue for damages but does not directly get you past a pay rent or get out notice.  All this, again, is best evaluated in your particular case by a local landlord-tenant attorney.  The unit was vacant for over a year but they still did not clean up the blood from a murdered tenant?  Something sounds either very fishy or in likely violation of housing, health, and/or landlord-tenant laws.  Good luck.  Greg Abbott Consumer Law Northwest 6635 N. Baltimore, #254 Portland, OR 97203 503-283-4568 gregabbott@consumerlawnorthwest.com "Practicing Landlord-Tenant Law in Oregon for Over 20 Years".

Your ex is not correct about your ability to be involved in the decisions about your children.  That is exactly what joint legal custody means:  both of you must be involved in any important decision.  You should be able to attend any appointment, school function, etc., and to take the children to any of these on your custodial time.  No court I know of will issue an order telling one party they can "never be able to" take the children on their appointments unless there is some abuse issue, which I gather there isn't.  I would probably suggest you file your own Request for Order and ask that these things be detailed, because obviously your ex thinks he can do it all himself.    Consult an attorney first.  Good luck.

On the same note, you also can't end the lease and move out before the 2 year term ends (unless you find another tenant to replace you etc etc.)

This is a good opportunity to cite to an old but important definition of income: any undeniable accession to wealth, clearly realized, over which the taxpayer has complete dominion. This definition has been used to tax in prizes, bartered goods, and in kind benefits. Determine whether you meet the three parts to the definition of income. Has your wealth increased? Can you identify the point in time when your wealth increased?  Do you have possession, dominion and control over the money? If so, you have income. Whether or not you have offsetting expenses to decrease the reportable amount of income needs more facts.
