Here is a summary of state and federal rights regarding pregnancy:  FEDERAL RIGHTS:  In 1978, Congress amended the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII 42 U.S.C. å¤å¤ 2000e to 2000e‰ÛÒ17, by passing the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.   Under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, "discrimination" means to treat a pregnant employee differently from non-pregnant employees, and adversely. The employee must be able to make a connection between the discriminatory treatment and the protected status (being pregnant). In other words, the employee will have to show that her pregnancy is reason the employer is treating her adversely. There are various ways to do this. Negative comments from supervisors or management; a sudden change in treatment (for the worse) as soon as or shortly after the employer learns about the pregnancy or the effects of pregnancy; or other incriminating conduct. Note it is not unlawful for an employer to apply the same leave of absence policy to pregnant and non-pregnant employees.   For information on pregnancy discrimination, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/types/pregnancy.cfm   For information on the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, see:  http://eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/pregnancy.cfm   This law is enforced by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). www.EEOC.gov   Under federal law, leave taken for an employee's incapacity due to pregnancy, childbirth or related medical conditions is governed by the Family and Medical Leave Act, 29 U.S.C. section 2101 et seq. (FMLA), just like leave for any other "serious health condition" of an employee.  See my Avvo guide to the FMLA for more information: http://www.avvo.com/pages/show?category_id=6&permalink=family-and-medical-leave-fmla-summary-of-key-provisions.  (continued in Comment below)

I am assuming your husband is either a green card holder or a US Citizen.  Your husband would NOT be eligible to file a family-based petition for you (under a law known as the Adam Walsh Act) if he was convicted of any "specified offense against a minor", i.e.: "kidnapping; false Imprisonment; solicitation to engage in sexual conduct; use in sexual performance; solicitation to practice prostitution; video voyeurism (use of a webcam to watch children); possession, production, or distribution of child pornography; criminal sexual conduct involving a minor, or the use of the internet to facilitate, or attempt such conduct; and any conduct that by its nature is a sex offense against a minor."  A felony domestic violence conviction that did not involve any of the above should not invalidate your husband's ability to file an immigrant petition for you, but I agree with my colleagues that you are best advised to seek a green card via a VAWA (Violence Against Women Act) self-petition based on the violence you suffered at the hands of your husband, which can be consular processed abroad.  Your husband has no involvement in the process.   I am attaching a link with more information on the VAWA process.  Good luck to you and please stay safe.

If you are being harassed BECAUSE of a serious medical condition or disability or BECAUSE you asserted your right to overtime pay in good faith, you may have a claim for unlawful harassment or discrimination.   IF you are a nonexempt employee (depends on your duties) and you worked over 8 hours in a workday or over 40 hours in a workweek (don't count meal periods), you may be owed overtime if your claim is not older than 3 and sometimes 4 years.   If you believe you have a claim, call an employment law attorney to discuss.   It is not unlawful for your boss to require that you keep track of all of your work time and they can insist that you don't work over 8 hours in a workday if they don't want to pay overtime.   Many of us offer a free initial phone consultation and you can find attorney contact info on Avvo.com.

No.  After the defense rests, you may call rebuttal witnesses, but limited to the scope of the defendant's case.  You cannot call a witness to support your case which reasonably could have been anticipated.  You may call rebuttal witnesses, after the defense rests, but the scope of a rebuttal witness's testimony generally is limited.  You may call a rebuttal witness to directly contradict the testimony of a defense witness.    Using a rebuttal witness to rebut an issue in the case is different than calling a witness to attack the defense witness's charter.    You will have a great deal of trouble introducing the testimony of a rebuttal witness that the defense witness has a reputation as a liar.  Most states have an equivalent to Federal Rule Evidence 608, which states:  (a) Reputation or Opinion Evidence. A witness's credibility may be attacked or supported by testimony about the witness's reputation for having a character for truthfulness or untruthfulness, or by testimony in the form of an opinion about that character. But evidence of truthful character is admissible only after the witness's character for truthfulness has been attacked.  (b) Specific Instances of Conduct. Except for a criminal conviction under Rule 609, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness's conduct in order to attack or support the witness's character for truthfulness. But the court may, on cross-examination, allow them to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:  (1) the witness; or  (2) another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about.

No, not a violation. Under FDCPA, there is no requirement that a letter be sent prior to initiating a lawsuit.  And even when the letter is sent, collection activity, including the filing of a lawsuit, can still be done during the 30 day period. Sorry.   Your state may have specific notice requirements as part of the foreclosure process, and you would need to speak to a local attorney, but under FDCPA, this does not sound like a violation.   Big picture, collection violations as part of a foreclosure don't stop the foreclosure.

If fair market value rent is $1,100 and your mortgage is $1,600, then you do have a financial hardship.  If you list the home for short sale and bring in an offer that Chase believes is at fair market value, you should have a good opportunity for short sale.  There are a lot of legal issues to be aware of, so I recomend that you speak with an AZ real estate attorney who has experience with short sales.  For example, if your home is 2 1/2 acres or less, a single family home, that has been lived in, then legally you can walk away from the entire loan balance with Chase (under Arizona's anti-deficiency statute), which gives you leverage in your short sale.  There are also tax consequences for investment properites in a short sale that you need to be aware of.

A trust is a private contract among the parties involved, the operation of law only comes into play when there is no provision in the trust relating to a certain scenario. If your trust was prepared by an estate planning attorney, it almost certainly addresses the issue you described and the answer lies in the trust document itself. Most likely the trustee is vested with the authority to manage assets and sell the property, there is very little the beneficiaries would be able to do to challenge this lawful action by the trustee. It is unlikely the trust requires all the beneficiaries to approve of a sales price for an asset, but of course anything is possible. You'd need to find the trust and have an attorney analyze it to know for sure. If you'd like to speak with an attorney about it, I'd be happy to talk to you further and analyze your situation.

I'm not licensed in CA and am not familiar with how your courts of limited jurisdiction handle matters like this, but it sounds to me like your judge is overreaching. Look at your court rules, there is likely an appeal process if this goes south on you to district court. Before you do, however, you should really consider what your lost opportunity cost and time will be on this if you don't resolve it. Exactly how much less than what you paid is $3,500, and is that difference worth the hassle of having to litigate this for an extended period of time on your own? I'll tell you what I tell all of my clients -- a case like this can't be about principle, it has to be about money (and the money value of your time) because you're only ever going to get money out of it, no one is going to pay you principle. This needs to be approached like a standard business deal, with as little emotion as possible. If the proposed resolution is close to what you paid out, consider taking it and moving on. As far as getting the materials to court, I'm sure you can arrange for them to be picked up or something if you explain to the court that they're simply too large to bring with you. Good luck.

AHCCCS is not Medicare, it is Medicaid, the state's health care insurance for people with low incomes.  Any health care provider that accepts AHCCCS has the option of enforcing a lien instead of taking what AHCCCS pays.  A good personal injury attorney can negotiate with the lien holder to get them to take an amount that is smaller than the full lien but still more than AHCCCS will pay.  Or you can negotiate with the lien holder yourself.  But you can not force them to bill AHCCCS.

Although it is not illegal to eavesdrop on a conversation among people who don't know you're listening, California Penal Code section 632 makes it illegal to use an electronic device to eavesdrop and/or record a confidential conversation without all parties' consent.  In order for a conversation to be considered confidential, it needs to occur under circumstances that reasonably indicate at least one person to the conversation (in this case the father) intends for the conversation to be private.  That's a hard sell given that (1) your daughter is a minor child speaking on your phone at your residence, and (2) you and father are involved in pending divorce proceedings where, as you've suggested indicated, you're monitoring each other's conducted.  Under those circumstances, father arguably has no reasonable expectation of privacy in his conversations with his minor daughter.  But if you want your recordings of their telephone conversations to be admitted into evidence in court, be sure each recording begins with a statement from you that you are recording the conversation, and father's statement authorizing and consent to the recording.

Congratulations!!  Sometimes it's so darn difficult to get an I-140 approved, due to "ability to pay" issues with the employer.. Now that you have filed your I-485 adjustment of status application, you must be patient and wait. USCIS is deluged with tens of thousands new applications every month and can never move as fast as you would like them to.  After all, they are only human, just like you and I and there is only so much they can move in any given day, week and month. If you look at USCIS' website, you'll probably read that employment-based I-485 currently take nationwide an average of 6 months to process.  Don't you believe it.  Some take less others take more, sometimes much more, for a myriad of different reasons, with each case (and fate) being individual.  You need to remain patient and keep close contact with the highly skilled attorney that got your employer the I-140 approved. Hopefully he or she is also the one who filed the I-485 package on your behalf.  The good news here is that employment based I-485s are, for the most part, approved by the CIS Service Centers without necessitating an interview at the local USCIS district office, like the marriage=based I-485s do. Thus, if everything works out according to plan you should be receiving your green card(s) in the mail, at home, some 3-4 months from now (or even before). Keep your fingers crossed.

In NC the Attorney General's office is not normally involved in this sort of matter, so I would find that highly unusual and suspicious.  Unless the case involved some very complicated matters of fraud or some other issue of particular interest to the AG's office they would not place such a call. You should hire a criminal defense attorney in your area, and particularly one that is familiar with the policies and procedures in your circuit's drug court.   The first order of business would be to have the capias (or bench warrant) withdrawn.  It is possible that you may have been charged with a subsequent felony for failing to appear for your next scheduled court date (if the underlying charge was also a felony, and I am assuming it was).  Transferring your supervision out of state is not likely in drug court.  While the policies differ from county to county, one of the common features is frequent court dates with local drug counseling providers who can provide accurate and up to date information to the court on your progress.  This cannot be accomplished effectively from another state.  You may be able to transfer, however, if you can "opt out" of drug court.  Make sure you fully understand all the implications of that decision before you make it.  It sounds like there will be some options for you here, but again, talk to a local criminal attorney.  I hope this helps - good luck.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) regulates the use of background reports, and provides you with several rights that are relevant to your situation.  For the sake of making this an easily readable list of those rights, I‰Ûªve outlined them in a short list below.  This list only skims the surface of your rights and potential claims.  What you‰Ûªre going through is very frustrating, and can be damaging in many ways.  Our firm litigates FCRA claims around the country.  We are more than happy  to speak with you in further detail.  1.  Accuracy of information in the report:  The FCRA requires that background check companies use reasonable procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of the content of a background report.  The use of two personal identifiers oftentimes does not meet this standard, particularly where the background check company could have reviewed additional information by pulling court records.    2.  Up to date information in the report:  The FCRA also requires that background report companies who report adverse public record information must either: (1) notify the applicant/employee that it will report such information about them; or (2) use strict procedures to ensure that the information is complete and up to date.  3.  Notices:   The FCRA requires employers to provide a "pre-adverse action notice" to an employee/applicant BEFORE taking an adverse employment action based on information in a background report.  The pre-adverse action notice includes a copy of the background report and a summary of your rights under the FCRA. The purpose of the pre-adverse action notice is to allow the employee/applicant an opportunity to clear up any misstatements in the report and to address any misunderstandings the report may have created in the employer‰Ûªs mind. For this reason, the pre-adverse action notice must be provided to the employee/applicant before the employer takes the adverse employment action (i.e., there must be some delay in time between when the employee is given the pre-adverse action notice and when the employer takes the adverse employment action).  If an employer does not provide you with a copy of the background report before it chooses not to hire you, then you may have claims to pursue under the FCRA.    4.  Damages:  The FCRA provides several different types of remedies, including actual damages, statutory damages, punitive damages, and attorneys‰Ûª fees.  Based on the circumstances you described, you should speak with an experienced FCRA attorney to discuss your potential claims.

I like the information that you have been given, but here is the long and short of it. IF you are an heir in your mother's estate and IF your share of the estate would be increased by the money your brother took being returned to the estate, you are an interested person.  If you are not an heir, or if the money comes back your share is not increased, then you are NOT an interested person.  One exception is that if you are the Executor of your mother's estate, you could also force the accounting even if you personally get nothing, but if the estate is enriched.  If you are an interested person, you can have an attorney who is experienced with the Philadelphia Orphans' Court petition the court to force your brother to account for all of his actions as Agent under the Power of Attorney.  We do these petitions regularly, as what you describe is not uncommon.  The Orphans' Court judges in Philadelphia are excellent, and they will force your brother to account for every penny of what he handled as the Agent.  If it turns out that he cannot explain why the money ended up in his account, then the judge will "surcharge" him, which means force him to return the money to the estate.  This process is not lightning fast, but the judges are good and in the end you will get your answer.  You need to speak to an Orphans' Court lawyer review the facts of this case and give you an opinion about the exact facts of your case and, if the facts look favorable, act quickly to file the Petition.

Unfortunately, even charges that have been dismissed and expunged will indeed remain in "non-public" federal law enforcement databases, and there is likely no legal way to remove them.  Indeed, many states (such as Tennessee) legally require the state Bureau of Investigation to maintain a "non-public" record of all arrests and expungements.  Moreover, expunged charges may also remain in other private databases.  When a person is arrested in the internet age, that information is often recorded by "private" background check companies and other keepers of information on the internet.  Expungement can certainly seal or destroy public court records, and other public government documents, which can certainly help with employers and others, so anyone with a dismissed case should pursue expungement with a local attorney.  However, private companies that recorded the arrest through public records at the time of the arrest are under no duty to destroy their records, and a person may be able to learn of the arrest through search engines, news reports, private companies, and other sources.  The best advice is to expunge all public records that can legally be expunged, after obtaining certified court records to prove the case was dismissed and expunged.  Then, if questions are later raised by employers or anyone, the person can prove that he or she was innocent, and that the case was dismissed prior to being expunged.

The new case that just came out that pertains to your issue is the 5th DCA Case of US Bank v. Bartram. Essentially, this case threw out the 5 year Statute of Limitation rule, but the the appellate court did recognize the matter is one "of great importance" and therefore certified it to the Florida Supreme Court for further review. However, there is language in the opinion indicating even though the bank can file a new foreclosure suit, it may not seek to recover any individual payment that is more than five years overdue. This will present significant challenges for bank who will need to figure out what they can sue for. In addition, some banks may find it impractical to "charge off" those months that are past the 5 year date - but don't count on this!) Its a good idea to consult with a foreclosure attorney familiar with the statute of limitations and how it will pertain to your issue.

Generally speaking a family law court cannot make a spousal support order that leaves the payor spouse without the means to support him or her self.     First question is: did you have an attorney represent you?  If so, you should run these questions by your attorney and ask if your attorney has appellate experience.  If not, you should consult an appellate lawyer.  If you did not have an attorney, you should seek the advice of a family law attorney immediately.     Depending on timing, you may still have the right to file a motion for reconsideration.  That motion is guided by strict standards, however, and you must be sure that you have grounds (other than the fact that the order imposes burdens on you).    You also have the right to appeal.  Whether an appeal will help you in the short term is a difficult issue, however, because an appeal alone does not suspend your obligation to make support payments,       You are best advised to consult with an appellate specialist who handles family law appeals.  You can find us on the AVVO find a lawyer feature.

I agree with Attorneys Straus and Reed.  If you have completed all your disclosures and discovery, you can file an "At Issue" memorandum.  If you have an upcoming Family Resolution Conference, and all parties have been served/appeared and discovery is complete and Preliminary and Final Disclosures are completed and sent out, then you can ask for a Mandatory Settlement Conference date and/or Trial date.  If the parties are in agreement as to all the issues of the case, you can prepare a stipulated judgment and marital settlement agreement and file it with the court.  Sometimes it takes a couple months for the judgment to process through the court system, but having the judgment entered is the best way to wrap up the case quickly.  If discovery is not finished, then you will need to finish it first.  It is unclear what is causing the delay in your case.  You will definitely want to go into more specific detail with a family law attorney in your area if you are representing yourself in the divorce.  You can also speak with the facilitator's office at the courthouse to help you process any paperwork that is needed to move your case along.  Hope this is helpful at least a little bit.  Good luck.

I am not sure what you are alleging. If by medical abuse, you mean that as a patient, you were mistreated, and injuries were not documented, any proof that you have showing that your condition was actually worse at an earlier point would definitely need to be considered by the Social Security Administration. If you are claiming that you were sent for a consultative examination, and a report was prepared without a full exam, again this is something that has to be considered when determining the validity of the report. If the physician was found to have committed fraud, Social Security should consider it in the disability process, but that doesn't mean that the report will hold no weight.  The most important thing is that any of your allegations are well documented by both you and any witnesses to the activities. I would suggest affidavits be signed if you are alleging fraudulent behavior during a disability exam. If you prove that the exam was not valid, it may not be used as evidence to show that you have the ability to work, but that doesn't mean you will be approved for benefits. In Georgia, if an original Will cannot be found and the Will was last known to be in the possession of the person who made it (in this case, your mother), then the fact that the Will cannot be found creates a presumption in the law that the person who made the Will later destroyed it with the intent to revoke it by doing so. That's what you will be facing if you try to probate a copy of the Will (conformed or otherwise). In order to overcome the presumption that your mother revoked her Will be deliberately destroying it, you need to come up with "clear and convincing evidence" that rebuts the presumption. That's not necessarily an easy standard. It may well be easier and less time-consuming to assume that she did revoke it and file a petition for administration of an intestate estate. One thing to check before you do that is to contact the probate court for any county in which your mother lived when she wrote that Will. Ask very specifically whether any Will was filed with the Court "for safekeeping" under your mother's name. The original may turn up that way. If not, well, then you will need to determine whether you think you can produce the needed evidence that the Will was not destroyed by her with the intent to revoke it.  However, whichever course you decide to pursue, you really do need to consult an experienced probate attorney. For one thing, the fact that you state you have to probate now because you discovered a stock certificate which was not mentioned in the Will is incorrect: either you have to probate because your mother's probate estate has at least one asset in it or the probate estate has no assets in it. A Will is not required, and in fact ideally should not, try to describe all of the assets, and just because the Will describes specific assets does not mean that it can control those assets without first being admitted to probate.  It's also not clear why time is of the essence. In probate matters, things don't normally happen quickly, nor, generally, should they. You need to make sure things are being handled correctly, and that should be the concern, not necessarily how quickly. The fact that your mother has been deceased since March 2014 and you are just now even thinking about whether the Will should be probated is a good sign that things may not be happening correctly. Please do yourself a favor soon, before you end up creating big problems for yourself, and hire a good probate attorney to help you with this.

Whether you are entitled to a return of your deposit depends on whether you met the financing contingency, if there is one. I suggest you call the mortgage lender and see if they can help you at all.  This can be a very frustrating process, so you will have to be patient.  However, the mortgage lender is the only party that can consent to your removal from the mortgage and deed.  If you are not removed, and your ex defaults on the mortgage, it is critical to know whether you signed the mortgage note as well.  A "mortgage" is often seen as a single document or commitment, but there are actually two different things going on.  The first is that one or more of the owners of the home sign a mortgage note, which is a personal promise to repay the loan.  The second is that all the owners (everyone named on the deed) sign a mortgage instrument, which grants the lender a right to foreclose on the house if the mortgage note is not repaid on time and in full.  If you DID NOT sign the note, then the lender has no right to come after you once they foreclose on the house. If you DID sign the note, you are technically liable for any amount of the note not repaid through the foreclosure.  However, many lenders will forgive this "deficiency" and not force you to repay it.  But not all - you should ask your lender this when you speak to them.  Keep in mind that if any of your debt is forgiven, there are income tax effects - the forgiven amount is treated as income to you in the year of forgiveness.  But it's better than having to pay the whole amount.   You ask if an LLC will protect your personal assets.  It is possible, but there are serious issues with doing this.  If you put truly personal assets into the LLC, they may not be protected from creditors, since they are not really used in your business.  Further, transferring these assets into an LLC knowing that you have outstanding debts may be considered a transfer in fraud of creditors, and the transfer could be voided.  If you are an owner of the house with your boyfriend, you may be able to seek to partition the house (i.e., sell it and split the proceeds).  You should consult a lawyer familiar with real estate litigation and tell him/her all the facts.

Additionally, Fla. Stat. 718.110(4) prohibits a COA from making a "change the proportion or percentage by which the unit owner shares the common expenses of the condominium and owns the common surplus of the condominium unless the record owner of the unit and all record owners of liens on the unit join in the execution of the amendment and unless all the record owners of all other units in the same condominium approve the amendment."  You can file a complaint with the Department of Business and Professional  Regulation (DBPR) against the COA and the property manager's license.  The link is below.  You might even want to consider submitting this to arbitration before DBPR, but you first have to send the COA a certified letter outlining your dispute, what resolution you want, how many days they have to provide that resolution and your intent to seek arbitration pursuant to Fla. Stat. 718.1255.

Congratulations!  Your H-1B status (not "visa", since only consulates abroad can issue and actual "visa") starts on October 1. Since yours was the approval of a change of status (COS) from F to H, on October 1 you will be able to start working for your H-1B employer without needing to depart and apply for an H-1B visa at a consulate abroad. As for your wife and kid, YES, by all means, they can apply or H-4 visas at a US consulate abroad. All they need to do is prove the family relationship and your having obtained H-1B status in the US.  Since your H-1B status has not gone into effect yet, it is best for them to apply sometime in September. The soonest they'll be allowed to come in on their H-4 dependent visas will be September 20th, 10 days before your H-1B status goes into effect.

Making an audio recording without the knowledge of at least one participant in the conversation is a criminal offense in Arizona.  A.R.S. 13-3005(A)(2) makes it a class 5 felony when someone "Intentionally intercepts a conversation or discussion at which he is not present, or aids, authorizes, employs, procures or permits another to so do, without the consent of a party to such conversation or discussion."

Emancipation is an uphill battle and there are many factors the court would consider before granting such a request.  In the information you have provided and your GF's fear of even filing for emancipation I have to say your chances are none.  RCW 13.64.020 governs Emancipation of a Minor. In a petitio for emancipation your gf would need to show:  (e) a declaration by the petitioner indicating that he or she has the ability to manage his or her financial affairs, including any supporting information; AND (f) a declaration by the petitioner indicating that he or she has the ability to manage his or her personal, social, educational, and nonfinancial affairs, including any supporting information. It sounds like what you received was a motion for summary judgment, with supporting papers. If so, what you need to do is respond (not appeal). You will need to file a response brief, which presents your version of the facts and your legal arguments for why the motion should be denied. The facts in your response brief need to be backed up by evidence that you will submit to the court through declarations of witnesses (including yourself) signed under penalty of perjury. That is how you will show the court what the truth is. Each witness must testify on the basis of their own personal knowledge. You can attach documents to the declarations. If you do, the witness must testify in the declaration that the document is a true and correct copy of whatever it is. Check the papers you received for the date of the scheduled hearing. Your response must be filed with the court and served on the other parties no later than 11 days prior to the hearing. Also make sure you show up for the hearing to argue your position. Your best friend in defending against a motion for summary judgment is a dispute of material fact. If you can show that there are facts in dispute that would affect the outcome of the case, that means the case needs to go to trial. The judge will have to deny the motion. If you have already had judgment entered against you, that is when it is time to consider an appeal. You have 30 days from the date of the judgment (there should be a document titled "Judgment") to file a notice of appeal. I recommend that you consult with an attorney to help you understand what you need to do and make sure you have the proper papers in order.

Thank you for your question!  Ok, first off, the landlord cannot put in brand new stuff, that is substantially more expensive than what was there before.  If they do this, then they are liable for the amount above the reasonable cost of replacement, not you.  So, if that affects their deductible, then that could be an offset for you, as far as their claim for damages.  They have to find a reasonably similar or, failing that, a reasonable cost of replacing the damaged property.  As for the washing machine, it depends on how it happened.  If the problem with the washer existed before you rented, wasn't readily discoverable by you, and you did not have knowledge of any defect, it may not be your fault.  However, if the problem arose, because you weren't taking care of the washer like you agreed, you caused the problem, or you knew about an issue when you moved in and didn't take care of it, you will be on the hook for the damage.  The landlord must have had no knowledge of an existing defect when you entered the premises and/or the problem was not caused by the washer, but by a condition existing in the pipes or other part of the house, that is out of your control or responsibility.  I recommend getting an attorney to look at this.

For the best information about how and why a federal sentence was imposed in a specific case, the best resource would indeed be the defense attorney who handled the case.  Attorneys will provide a defendant with his or her file, including information about sentencing.  Federal sentencing is complex, and is based on a variety of both statutory principles, possible mandatory minimum terms, and applicable guidelines, so the sentence may be based on more than simply a single guideline.  As a general matter, every federal defendant receives a "pre-sentence investigation report" which will contain guidelines estimates and other information, so that is one resource.  The sealed Judgment and Statement of Reasons filed by the court after sentencing will also be provided to the attorney and defendant, and it will provide information about the sentence and why it was imposed.  A defendant could also pay to obtain a transcript of the sentencing hearing, during which the Court would have stated the reasons for the sentence.  Finally, there are a variety of online resources at the US Sentencing Commission with information about general guidelines.

Using the intellectual property, be it trademarks or copywritten materials, of another generally carries liability and/or risk.  While criticism, news, and etc. can be areas where you would be permitted to use another's intellectual property, you may be using more than the amount permitted.  For example, it is almost certain a reviewer could write a review of a new BMW car and mention it is a BMW by name.  It is not so certain they could avoid liability if they used BMW's logo or advertising material, too.    So, while there may be "fair use" arguments to be made, an attorney will need to review the specifics of your blog to make that determination.

regarding custody - his court appointed attorney is not a family law attorney and his court appointed attorney is trying to do what is best for him, so do not take everything that attorney tells you as gospel.  If there is no custody order in place that says you have to let him see your child, then you are not violating any order or law if you do not let him see your child.  On the flip side - because there is no custody order in place, he would not be violating any order or law if he decided not to return your child to you.  Your best bet is to get a custody order in place before your child goes to stay with him again.  You can get a custody order entered in a custody action or in a civil domestic violence action.  It sounds like you are in the middle of a criminal  action regarding domestic violence, but you can still file an action for a domestic violence protective order (DVPO).  Regardless of the outcome of the criminal action, having a DVPO that says he needs to stay away from you, and which can establish an initial custody order, is usually a good idea.

There are many excellent attorneys based in S.W. Florida who will be able to handle the case.  I am located in North Florida.  While I handle cases throughouth the State of Florida, I think you would be more comfortable with an attorney based in your geographic area.   Here are a few things to keep in mind as you pursue your case through the services of an attorney:  1. Most cases take time to resolve - 3 to 6 months or longer unless there are some unique facts to the case that allow for a settlement in shorter time span.  2. Most injury victims require from both a medical standpoint and a legal standpoint a period of time to allow the victim to obtain treatment and diagnostic testing.   The effect and severity of the injury, in most cases, cannot be determined without the benefit of time and trial / error with the differerent treatment modalities.   3.  Insurance companies are businesses that make business decisions.   Most of these business decisions are based on practices and procedures.   Most insurance adjusters will require medical records, bills, diagnostic testing, and final reports before the adjuster will put a proper value on the case.   Even when all of this information is provided, insurance adjusters may have a different opinion as to the value of the case from you and your attorney.  In many of these instances, litigation will be required in order to attempt to obtain the client a fair value or resolution of the case.  4.  Beware of any attorneys who promise the moon and the stars.  Attorneys are not fortune tellers, prophets, or super heroes.   In most cases, it is difficult to estimate with certainty the result that will be obtained on a case.    5.  Be patient.  Cases often times proceed at a slower pace than desired by a client for a variety of reasons.    I wish you all the best with your case and hope that your case is resolved in a timely fashion to your satisfaction.

The issue is whether the mobile home is a "separate" property or "community" property. The general rule is that "anything" acquired during marriage through gift, inheritance, devise, or a will is the recipient spouse's separate property. If your mom paid for the mobile home "FULLY" (regardless of whether it was purchased at the time of your marriage or before marriage), it is a "gift". On the other hand, if your mom paid "partially" for the mobile home, and then during marriage, you paid for the mobile home with income from employment, then you paid for the mobile home with your marital income because that income was earned "during" marriage. As such, your spouse will have an interest in the mobile home. If this is the case, you should definitely speak to an experienced family law attorney. If however, this is not the case, then the mobile home is a "gift", and since your spouse's name was never on the title, there would be no presumption that the mobile home was "intended" to ever be partially her's. Good luck.

Technically, child support is money paid by one parent to the other parent, and so, generally speaking to the extent a parent pays college expenses directly to the college, that isn't considered "child support".  But even though it doesn't meet the definition of child support, that doesn't mean those college contributions aren't relevant:  in other words, if you and your soon-to-be ex are structuring a separation agreement, you have some flexibility on what you term things (child support, alimony, contribution to college costs, asset allocation, etc.).  This is much like what you were alluding to by recognizing that alimony has a tax implication while child support is tax neutral.  And so, whether a court would consider your proposal about proportional payment of college expenses as "fair" will depend on how that one piece fits into the entire financial puzzle.  In other words, it may or may not be fair based on how your assets are divided, how your debts are divided, and what, if any, support is paid (whether child or spousal).  One must also consider if your son is principally dependent upon one of you or both of you equally at this point as it appears that he isn't emancipated yet.  As an attorney-mediator, when helping a divorcing couple address finances, I find it helpful to look at the whole picture first and not overly focus on terminology.  In other words, I think it's helpful to first recognize what the salaries are, what the assets/debts are, and what the expenses are; second think about how those expenses will be met given the finances while being guided by the law on support and asset allocation; and third decide what to call each thing to maximize the amount of money available in light of tax implications.  With educational expenses (and health expenses), I also like to determine the involvement level of grandparents and their gift-giving since one can pay for educational expenses without it being a taxable gift, whereas otherwise, one must consider the annual exclusion and lifetime exclusion.  With a 24 year marriage, with at least one child, there is going to be a lot to consider, so it would be wise to involve professional guidance.  As an attorney-mediator, I find mediation to be a less expensive and emotionally burdensome way to address your divorce than litigation, but some couples aren't amicable enough for mediation.  Regardless, I think your first step would be reaching out to both family law litigators and mediators for an initial consultation.  Many of us offer free initial consultations.  After you get a better understanding of what the relevant laws are and how a court might decide this, you will be in a better position to decide how you want to proceed with your divorce whether it is mediation, litigation, or some combination or the two.  There is also collaborative divorce as well.  Best of luck.

There are several issues to consider.  Initially, the "Statute of Limitations."  Statute of limitations are laws that set time limits on how long one has to file a civil lawsuit.  These limits depend on the type of legal claim.  For instance, the statute of limitations for filing a personal injury lawsuit is two years from the date of the incident.  This doesn‰Ûªt seem to be an issue in your case as you have already settled your claim against the person who caused the crash.    You also have a potential claim against your own insurance company.  Your claim will be based on breach of contract, breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing (bad faith), and unfair business practice, against your insurance carrier.  The statute of limitations for breach of contract in the State of Nevada is four years.  You have plenty of time to file an action against your own insurance company.   Your insurance carrier has a duty to compensate you for damages caused by the negligence of someone else.  This includes consideration of two categories of damages.  Special + General Damages.  Special damages compensate an individual for quantifiable financial losses, such as medical expenses. General damages are non-financial / non-economic damages such as pain and suffering.  They are monetary remedies awarded to compensate injured persons for their noneconomic loss of life's pleasures or the loss of enjoyment of life. Your insurance company has a duty to consider both in evaluating your claim.  It gets a bit more complicated from here.  Consult with your counsel.

The application for R.E. Salesperson license will require you to disclose the pending case. That disclosure will cause B R E to delay approving your application.  If the case does not result in conviction, then you will likely not be denied license on that basis. If you are convicted, you will likely be placed on probation and you are likely to be denied the license. Most State licensing agencies will not issue professional/occupational license to an applicant who is presently on criminal court probation.   It is a fact that nothing that licensing  law legal counsel can do for you will be as effective for obtaining the R E license as is avoiding criminal conviction. Make the criminal case your first priority. Get outstanding local criminal defense counsel.  When the criminal case is resolved one way or another, you can assess your prospects for success with BRE. Worst case, you will need to finish your criminal probation before you apply. Maybe you can avoid the worst case.

You are allowed to get your own attorney at any time that you want to.  However, just because you are not a party does not mean that they cannot subpoena the things you are asking about.  If one party is alleging that you are providing substantial support to the former spouse that party is entitled to discover (that is what they are doing with the subpoenas, deposition, production etc.) any evidence which is or may be relevant to proving that allegation, because if it is proven it can result in alimony being modified or terminated.  If the discovery is done properly, even your medical records can be subject to discovery. HIPPA does provide a lot of protection, but it is not absolute and it does not mean that your medical records are never subject to being produced in a court proceeding.

You say you have no evidence of fraud.  Not true.  You do have evidence.  You know you did not sign any deed in front of a notary, so this is evidence. However, a notary public is required to keep a ledger of those person's signing in front of the notary.  Here, some notary has decided to cooperate with your father's fraud, or perhaps your father deceived the notary in some way.  There is usually a way to prove the truth of a matter.  The question is whether it is worth it to you to pay an attorney to fight this battle for you, or whether you have what it takes to fight this battle without an attorney.

The answer to your question is, yes. The other driver is allowed to sue. The question I would have is: Who was at fault in the accident? If your cousin hit the other driver, then she is probably responsible for the damages to the other car. The fact that nothing was done at the time of the accident is irrelevant. If the other driver is only claiming damage to their vehicle, this is likely a small claims case, and your cousin probably won't need an attorney. On the other hand, if the other driver is claiming physical injury in addition to the damage to their vehicle, your cousin would be better off seeking the advice of an attorney. More likely than not, she can find an attorney who will meet with her for a free initial consultation to go over the facts of her case and figure out which course of action she should take. Keep in mind, however, that for reasons of client confidentiality, unless you plan on paying her legal fees, your cousin will need to be the one to meet with the attorney.

This is not legal advice, but I will tell you what happened when I advised a family member on a very similar issue.  The dealer called saying they could not find a bank to finance the car with the person who had signed the loan documents and they needed a co-signer.  We looked at the contract that had been signed and it said nothing that allowed them to do this -- such as reserving the right to demand a co-signer (or in your case it would be to get you to take a different loan).  So I had the person tell them the contract he signed did not give them the right to ask for a co-signer after the fact.  Once he  told them that, they somehow found a bank to accept the original financing agreement with no co-signer.  If you search online for this kind of thing, you will see that it is a type of scam that car dealers pull on people and is actually not uncommon from what I've read.  If you feel you can understand the contract adequately, you can see what it says, or to be really safe, get an attorney to review it to see if there is any language that gives them the right to make you do what they are asking.  And if not, you can tell them so and you may get them to back down.

Don't worry! If your employer does not pay the prevailing wage upon you getting your green card, you can: 1. Quit your job and find a better paying one; and 2. No, no one will blame you for your employer's failure to keep his promise and take your hard earned, long awaited green card away.  All you need to do is preserve proof to have worked for that employer at least for a few weeks (or months) after having obtained your green card.  Pay stubs, W2 will go a long way to proving your having "complied with your side of the bargain" after obtaining the green card and having worked for the employer for a while, hoping that he would comply, and when finally realized that there was no hope anymore, you resigned and seeked greener pastures elsewhere. The law does not require you to continue working for the employer for an indefinite period or even for any definite period.  I once heard a CIS adjudicating officer in Los Angeles tell my client during a citizenship interview in a similar situation "if you worked for even one day for the employer after having received your green card, then you complied with the law" (and are OK).  When the time comes you will have much more than a few days of work with that employer to put down on your application for naturalization; don't worry!

Judging from your comments it sounds like the landlord kept your security deposit past 30 days without sending a 186 s15B-compliant letter (with invoices; signed under penalties of perjury; etc.)  I assume that the landlord has not yet returned all of your deposit.  If so, that is completely illegal. The landlord's action will result in automatic triple damages and attorneys fees, for the full amount which has not yet been returned to you. There is no functional defense if the law was not followed, as it is a strict liability statute. In fact, this is so obviously illegal that--at least in my experience--most of these cases are resolved through summary judgment or settlement, without ever going to court.    You would ordinarily sue both the individual and the trust and let them argue over who owes the money. But since the statute provides for attorneys fees, you'll find that you can usually get an attorney to help you.

The Department of Justice has declared that advertising online casinos constitutes illegal aiding and abetting of gambling activity, if the gambling services are offered to U.S. citizens.  An affiliate relationship is a form of advertising, so there is a legal risk. The DOJ's legal position is somewhat untested, and there may be First Amendment concerns with criminalizing commercial speech.  However, many large advertisers, such as Google and Yahoo!, have paid millions of dollars in fines based on their previous advertisements of online casinos.  The fact that the wagering occurs in BitCoin is not likely to make any difference, since it is a form of 'property' according to the IRS, and a form of 'money' or 'currency' according to at least one federal court.  Any 'thing of value' can trigger gambling violations, under state laws.

If the decedent died without a will, then the rightful heirs must be determined.  Your question does not state if the decedent left a spouse behind. You need to contact a probate attorney (with some real estate experience) to handle this for you. Once title is placed into the names of the proper people, then those people can set up a corporation or LLC or any other entity they feel comfortable with to run the property.

YES, the dispute would take one of several forms: 1) a third party prior art submission, done within 6 months of publication. See details at http://www.uspto.gov/web/offices/pac/mpep/s1134.html 2) an inter partes re-examination after the patent issues. See details at http://www.uspto.gov/aia_implementation/faqs_inter_partes_reexam.jsp That is basically like a mini-litigation and entail major expense, although less than civil litigation in Federal Court. 3) a civil declaratory judgment suit seeking to invalidate the patent in Federal Court. Expect that to cost upwards of $500K and more likely $3-5M if vigorously defended by the other side. 4) a derivation proceeding might be filed seeking to prove A disclosed to B before B filed. That is done at the US Pat. & TM Office and is very stacked against A due to the procedural rules that apparently do not include discovery of B's records by A. This is less expensive, likely, than inter partes re-exam or DJ suit, but still quite costly. Details can be reviewed here: http://www.uspto.gov/aia_implementation/faqs_derivation_proceedings.jsp 5) you might file your own patent application with an affidavit under Rule 130 to show prior disclosure that invokes 35 USC 102(b) exceptions. You can read details here: http://www.uspto.gov/web/offices/pac/mpep/s717.html#ch700_d1ffd2_235c5_25d Note: your challenge is likely to be unsuccessful unless you not have an AIA-expert patent attorney/litigator managing the challenge, but also evidence and lots of money, both unlikely given that you are here seeking free advice. 6) If your challenge is successful, you will likely want to counterattack with a patent infringement suit or a misappropriation of trade secret suit or both. That, however, might be a multi-million dollar expense for both sides, which often leads to prompt settlement and that often cuts the expense dramatically. Having the right litigator is often key to successful challenge and to favorable settlement.  If you have the money and desire to challenge this, review the answers and pick the attorney that seems to know the most on the subject and about all the options available to you. It won't be cheap! Good legal representation never is cheap.

The standard the court is going to use is if it is in the "best interest" of you. The parent is going to need to file the petition on your behalf, as Petitioner. If the other parent is currently living and has not had their rights terminated then they will need to be served, unless they also agree to sign as co-petitioner. In that case here is the pro se legal kit for an agreed minor's name change: http://texaslawhelp.org/files/685E99A9-A3EB-6584-CA74-137E0474AE2C/attachments/B99BE52B-6C93-41F9-AFCB-043FE7C24E05/name_child_kit_final.pdf - everyone needs to sign in front of a notary public. If you don't know one you can always go by a bank and they should notarize your documents free of charge.  If the other parent is going to have some problems with the name change then it is going to be a bit more complex. Here is some light reading on that: https://www.rocketlawyer.com/article/how-to-get-a-legal-name-change-in-texas-for-a-minor.rl#target - it is recommended that you have a lawyer assisting you if it is going to be contested.  Depending on your family income you might be eligible for pro bono representation through Fort Bend Lawyers Care, if your family income is low (such as one parent being on SSDI etc.) so if you think you might be eligible then get in touch with them at: http://www.fortbendlawyerscare.org/contact.html and let Holly know I sent you their way  Filing fees in Fort Bend Co. I believe are $277 for a name change, plus or minus, unless your family income level based on federal poverty guidelines would allow you to be eligible to file an affidavit of inability to pay costs, in which case the filing fees would be waived. Additionally you will need a copy of your SS card, a criminal history certificate of record search from the cops, recently taken fingerprints from either FAST or law enforcement, a copy of your birth certificate, and a sex offender registry search record. And then you will need to go in for the final prove up in front of the judge, so it will take some time out of a day to get through that.  If you need any assistance there are a number of good local resources for you in the area, don't hesitate to reach out to them at any time. Best of luck

There are multiple topics invoked by your question.    First is whether a CSLB-licensed engineering contractor ("A") may perform the same work as a CSLB-licensed general building ("B") contractor.  If the project requires specialized knowledge and skill, or if the task being performed by the engineering contractor falls within the engineering contractor‰Ûªs license scope, the engineering contractor may perform under the A license.  See Ron Yates Constr. Co. v. Superior Court (1986) 186 Cal.App.3d 337, 348 and Pacific Caisson & Shoring, Inc. v. Bernards Bros. Inc. (2011) 198 Cal.App.4th 681, 691.     Second, the lack of a written contract presents a problem for the contractor if the job is a home improvement project.  California Business & Professions Code section 7159 requires written contracts between homeowners and contractors containing disclosures and many specified terms, and is applicable to all but very sophisticated homeowners.    Third, it is highly improper and potentially illegal for a person to threaten to report the contractor to the government in an effort to exact unpaid change orders.  When a threat to report a crime or unfavorable information to the government is coupled with a demand for payment or services, it may constitute extortion as defined by California Penal Code 519.    The contractor‰Ûªs best strategy will be guided by the precise facts of the case beyond what is described in the question above.  Depending upon the facts the contractor could be subject to severe civil and criminal penalties for contracting outside his license classification.  This response is provided for general educational information only and should not be considered legal advice and is not intended to create an attorney-client relationship.  The Green Law Group and other firms offer free initial confidential consultations, which is the ideal forum for a party to disclose further details.

No, burglary or attempted burglary of a dwelling are crimes that are excluded from the list of cases you can seal, when adjudication is withheld.   Had the case been dismissed or otherwise dropped, the defendant may have been eligible to expunge the arrest and court records, if the defendant otherwise qualified.    If the case would have been reduced to a burglary of a structure, and adjudication was withheld, the defendant would have been able to seal the arrest and court records if he otherwise qualified.   It is important to have competent legal representation on a criminal case due to these minor nuances that attorneys that practiced criminal law every day know and can often negotiate for.

I essentially agree with Mr. Firth and respectfully (partially) disagree as to some of the other answers provided. If you have been domiciled in CA for the last 2 years, you may use the CA exemption system. You will have to use the 704's throughout your petition and cannot mix and match between the 704 and 703 systems.  "Under BAPCPA, a debtor who has moved from one state to another within two years of filing (730 days) the bankruptcy case must use exemptions from the place of the debtor‰Ûªs domicile for the majority of the 180 day time period preceding the two years (730 days) before the filing [å¤ 522(b)(3)]."  If you had been in CA for less than the past 2 years, you would need to apply the 180-day prior rule to see which state's exemptions apply.  There is another, more rare bankruptcy code section that you might want to be aware of: section(s) 522(o),(p), (q), etc. which might limit the homestead exemption to $155,675; However, I believe there is case law that may make that inapplicable. It is too complicated to explain here, but I can elaborate if you contact me. Best of Luck!! This question cannot be answered without a review of the contract and the addendum deadline agreement. This question is not one for the employment/labor lawyers and I will repost it for the lawyers who handle contract disputes.  Where a deadline is specified in the contract, you have a right to expect that the job will be completed by that date. As one court ruled some years ago, the conduct of the parties, while a delay continues, may be such as to indicate a purpose to  keep the contract alive; and such a purpose, once manifested, may not be suddenly abandoned. So, here you say that since the demolition in March there has been no other work.  If you did not provide the contractor with warnings that the work was advancing too slowly, that you were dissatisfied, and a demand to hasten the pace of the job,  you may not be able to tell him now (given the problem with the cabinets that was beyond the contractor's control) to stop work. In other words you may not be able to recscind the contract based on delays which you did not protest, and demand the return of all money paid to date. These cases are fact specific and the language of the contract is of paramount importance. Good luck to you.

I concur with the attorney answers below. Virtual offices can be a very effective means of growing your business. Provided you decide to move forward with a virtual office, here are  some considerations for you prior to contract signature: First, meet with the office manager (not the sales person) and the  receptionists. Determine if you trust these people. Their competence and conscientiousness in delivery of services will  allow your business to grow. Scour your virtual office contract and ask many questions. Interlineate with changes and signatures from both you and the virtual  office provider's representive if necessary. Clear up any vague language in the contract, get it in writing with a  signature as well. A few things to ask your virtual office provider: Once the contract is up, am I required to pay additional fees if I am  no longer using a virtual office here (mail forwarding...)? Do you anticipate any additional charges that I may not be aware of?  If the answer is no, get it in writing. If you wish to use the mail forwarding service, ask how frequently the  mail will be forwarded. Assess the frequency with your business needs. Ask about long distance charges. For example, if your virtual office  is located in the 415 area code and calls are forwarded to your home  number in the 510 area code, you'll likely incur long distance fees. Finally, virtual offices often provide a business with a local telephone  number. If you were to end the virtual office contract what would  happen to that number? If the answer is "lost for all eternity", plan  to retain your existing business number. Have an exit strategy. The assumption here is your business will be so  successful that one day you will outgrow this facility. Best of luck  to you in that regard.

Attorneys Goldstein and Raddatz are correct in their answers.  There is no mechanism for your having the father's parental rights terminated except if you are doing so thru an adoption proceeding.  In an adoption, you and your partner, spouse or fiancÌ© would file a Petition for Adoption and ask that the court terminate the father's parental rights in favpr of your new partner.  The biological father would have to be given notice of the adoption proceedings.  If he consents to the adoption, his rights will be terminated and if he does not consent, his rights could still be terminated on the basis of his unfitness.  You would have to present proof to the court and if the court agrees, then his rights would be terminated by the court.    If you are considering adoption, you should consult with an attorney who is well versed in adoption law and procedure.  Many attorneys, including me, offer a free consultation for such matters.

The Department of Child Support Services is required by the California Family Code (beginning with section 17000, to get the most accurate information before the Court.  This is done by asking both parents to provide information sufficient to run support calculations.  That being said, if you are paying support, you must immediately begin paying such support to the Department of Child Support Services (DCSS) NOT Mother.  Every dime of support that you pay Mother after she goes on welfare (TANF) may not be credited to you, especially if DCSS has served you with notice that payment of support is supposed to go to them.  As for modifying the support, if you wait until the court hearing to supply the Court with your information, you will likely end up with a continuance of the hearing.  If you send the documents with your current information (which would include your temporary income), DCSS will run support calculations based on that income and submit their findings to the Court.    It is your call whether you want to wait until there is a court date set for child support to supply any information to the Court and DCSS or  do so now.   However, remember that DCSS is a governmental collection agency that does not have your best interest at heart.  Their interest is in protecting the public interest.  They do not represent Mother and they do not represent the child.  Good luck.

Your question is two fold.   1.  You need not an employment attorney, but a CPA to advise you on how to cut the check, how much taxes to deduct, etc.  That's the job of a CPA or a tax attorney.  For this small a project, a CPA familiar with this type of employment should be sufficient.  2.    You need a real estate attorney to draft this contract for you.  Even though it is an employment contract, those who do this often either know the employment issues or consult with an employment attorney on their team.  The main issue here is that that there is no such thing as "ceremonial" when it comes to risk management and protecting yourself against lawsuits and discharging your duties under the law as a landlord.  If you know all that the manager needs to do, and you can do it yourself, you may be home free.  Otherwise, you need to hire someone who will help you fulfill your obligations.  And adding another layer of complexity is that certain laws apply to the conduct of property managers. So, if you hire someone who is a novice or a straw man, you may be potentially setting yourself up for liability.  Again, I do not have enough facts regarding your level of expertise.  But assuming you are a sophisticated landlord, I don't advise going down that road.  Sorry if the answer is not as cut and dried or great news.  But in today's litigious society, it helps to be aware of what laws apply to your conduct and/or hire an expert to advise you.  I've seen way too many lawsuits filed against small landlords who didn't know what they were doing, but were preventable, to counsel you otherwise.  Good luck.

Asker, I would not be concerned about this issue, during the adjudication phase of your claim the VA assessed your level of disability by considering the level of symptomology related to the service connected TBI (I'm going to assume for simplicity under the diagnostic codes for an acquired mental health disorder).  In almost all cases, that will continue in unless the evidence demonstrates a clear material improvement in the level of disability.  In the broader sense (for example, a veteran with a S/C depressive condition and a non-service connected Alzheimer's disease), the VA can attempt separate the symptoms related to the service connected disability versus the non-service connected disability.  In practice, I rarely see this done for mental health disorders.

The Executor has a fiduciary obligation to act fairly and in the best interest of all beneficiaries, even if he does not like a beneficiary.  The Court will have supervision over the actions of the Executor, so you will not be treated unfairly.  The Executor can also secure the estate assets, such as the personal effects.  I am aware that sometimes someone shows up and takes valuable assets when they do not have the authority, and it is hard to prove.  This would be unfair to the other beneficiaries.  Anything you gave your parents are part of their estate.  Your taking back of what you gave them, might be unfair to the other beneficiaries.  If the Executor is good, he will figure out a fair way to distribute the personal effects.  Regarding the loan, the Executor would have to have some proof that it was a loan and not a gift.  So, if he has a Promissory Note, or reference in the Will that your inheritance is to be reduced by the unpaid balance of the loan, then your inheritance can be reduced.  However, if there is no documentation, and your parents never enforced the repayment, then I think the Executor is not in a good position to enforce it.

If for some reason or another you leave the country before finalizing the divorce, and your case has been inactive for about 18 months, then your case will get administratively dismissed.

You can find out if his lawyer was licensed in Illinois via the Illinois ARDC website (I've attached the link), but it is highly unlikely that it would be a factor in your brother's appeal for at least two reasons.  First, as has been pointed out by my colleagues, the immigration court is federal and does not require that attorneys be locally licensed as long as they are licensed in some state.  Second, attorney errors or misdeeds are not grounds for an appeal unless they affected the outcome of the case.  If the outcome of the case was affected by something the lawyer did or did not do, then it's not going to matter where they were licensed because the error itself is going to be the basis of the appeal.    Your brother should hire an attorney to review the record of the proceedings and identify the issues on which to base the appeal.  Remember that the appeal has to be RECEIVED by the BIA within 30 days of the decision.  Good luck!

This is from the Florida Statutes - The court may modify an order of support, maintenance, or alimony by increasing or decreasing the support, maintenance, or alimony retroactively to the date of the filing of the action or supplemental action for modification as equity requires, giving due regard to the changed circumstances or the financial ability of the parties or the child.  The basis for a modification of child support in Florida is a substantial change of circumstances since the entry of the last order addressing child support. The change needs to be involuntary and permanent in nature.   There isn't a simple yes or no answer to your questions.  There are other factors that need to be considered. You should contact a local attorney for a full analysis.   Kendra Stephen | Supra Legal Group | Tel: 954-900-9709

It is more complicated than a "yes" or "no" answer. If DCS is involved in the case and they chose to remove the child, the Department generally has to create a plan of care (Permanency Plan) for the parent to follow. Part of that plan requires DCS to provide services to the parent to assist the parent in getting the child back. If the parent doesn't cooperate with the plan, DCS could then file a termination of parental rights.  Sometimes, DCS can ask the court to waive the requirement to provide "reasonable efforts" to help the parent if the abuse of the child was severe. In that case, DCS could file a petition to terminate once they were given custody after an adjudicatory hearing.  If the child in in the care of someone else, that person could file a petition for temination and adoption.  In any of those situations you would have the right to an attorney if you cannot afford one, so if that situation arises be sure to ask for an attorney.

What information they collect and require will depend on them. Some organizations keep detailed information on volunteers, others may not keep more than sign in sheets. The nature of what you plan to do as a volunteer may also come into play. Volunteer firefighters that I have known were covered by fire company provided insurance for certain things, such as life insurance or workers compensation, which would require a lot of information, but people who just wanted to help at events did not need to worry about that. Unfortunately, the nature of your disability may affect whether or not you are capable of performing the duties of what you want to volunteer for. Helping at fundraisers, like bingo, or washing trucks will have far different requirements than carrying a charged fire hose or cutting open a crashed car to rescue the occupants. You may just need to contact the Chief and ask what the process is to volunteer, and see if there are volunteer tasks available within any limitations you may have.

That is regardless of whether the A cancels their petition or not.

In California, you can video record public areas because people have no legal expectation of privacy in those areas. When people are in public, they can also be audio recorded. Even though CA is a two party consent state (which means you can not audio record someone without their consent), that statute actually applies to conversations in which there is a privacy expectation--contrary to popular belief, it does not apply in public areas, because nobody has a legal expectation of privacy when they are in public. However, your apartment complex may have its own rules on cameras on exteriors of units. So you may want to check. The statute of limitations for debt collection is 4 years in Texas.  That means a creditor or debt buyer must sue you within the 4 years following your first missed payment.  Making a payment in that period re-starts the 4 year calendar.  After 4 years, you can't be sued on the debt, but the debt buyer can continue collection attempts until you send them a proper cease and desist letter under the Fair Debt Collections Practices Act.

Texas is a community property state. Like California, New Mexico, Arizona and other states that follow community property law, the community is responsible for all debts incurred by one spouse either before or during the marriage.  However, once you divorce, debts incurred in the individual person's capacity as an individual are generally presumed to be his or her own. The exception is debt for necessaries (rent, food, medical bills, and the like) or other debts incurred for the benefit of the marital community.  The divorce decree usually divides debts, but if its silent on that point, personal debts are personal to the individual; community debts are joint debts.  That said, once you divorce, your individual debts are your own.  Now sometimes those debts can stick to community property that became separate property as a result of the divorce decree, but that is another story entirely.

The probate attorney's duties are to assist the personal representative in the administration of the estate. That includes filing all the necessary documents with the court and advising the PR as to their next steps.  Mostly, it is a matter of contract between the PR and attorney.  The PR has a long list of duties to perform in the administration of an estate and they can negotiate to have some or all of those done by their attorney - but, it will cost more to have the attorney do the PR's job.  The attorney is the legal advisor to the PR - not the PR.  The Florida Bar website has a wonderful pamphlet, as mentioned by Attorney Elder, that discusses the duties of the PR. It would be good to read that so you know what to expect of your attorney and what tasks you are responsible for taking on yourself.

First, the good news: it is by no means certain that you will go to prison.  That being said, your actions from now on can have a substantial impact on the outcome of this case.  You should not talk about this online and you should certainly not discuss it with police or anyone other than a lawyer.  This is a very serious charge and you should contact and hire an attorney as soon as possible.    Now the bad news: Assault II is a ballot measure 11 offense, meaning that, if convicted, you could receive a mandatory minimum sentence of 70 months in prison.  A good criminal defense attorney, however, could talk to you about possible defenses to the charge and mitigating evidence.  Even at this early stage, without having been charged, an attorney can contact witnesses, law enforcement, and the prosecutor to discuss your case and attempt to prevent charges from being filed.    Finally, without knowing more, no lawyer can tell you whether you will go to prison for this incident or what the officer was thinking when he elected not to arrest you.  A good lawyer, however, will begin working immediately to do everything possible to prevent you from going to prison.

Under Washington state law, you are probably not covered under Workers' Compensation. The Industrial Insurance Act provides for workers' compensation benefits to: :"each worker receiving an injury, . . . during the course of his or her employment . . . while on the jobsite. The jobsite shall consist of the premises as are occupied, used or contracted for by the employer for the business or work process in which the employer is then engaged. RCW 51.32.015 and RCW 51.36.040. The Act also defines when a worker is "acting in the course of employment." RCW 51.08.013(1) provides:       "Acting in the course of employment" means the worker acting at his or her employer's direction or in the furtherance of his or her employer's business which shall include time spent going to and from work on the jobsite, as defined in RCW 51.32.015 and 51.36.040, insofar as such time is immediate to the actual time that the worker is engaged in the work process in areas controlled by his or her employer, except parking area. It is not necessary that at the time an injury is sustained by a worker he or she is doing the work on which his or her compensation is based."  Feel free to call a workers compensation lawyer to discuss more fully. If the curb in the parking lot was an odd height, or there was some other hazard, you may have a claim against the owner of the lot. You can certainly investigate this as well. Good luck!

I have to diverge slightly from my colleague's view.  I agree there is no black letter confidentiality duty that applies to landlords.  However, at least here in Oregon, court's have held that there is a fiduciary and/or "special" duty between landlords and tenants and while I have not seen that applied in a confidentiality context, depending upon the exact facts, it might at least open the door to such an argument.  The other possibility that comes to mind depends upon exactly what is being revealed.  Management companies/managers have been held to be subject to and liable under the federal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) and are likely to be subject to the California version as well.  If the manager is complaining to others about debts, such as rent, that he alleges you owe, there might be some violations there that would be actionable.  If so, and you won, you would be entitled to not only your damages but also your court costs and attorneys fees.  Doesn't get you out of the lease per se but they are very likely in my opinion to be willing to let you out of the lease as part of a settlement of such a lawsuit if you otherwise had likely grounds of winning.  Good luck.
