Rule 35 is typically a motion to either reduce a sentence under subpart (a), due to some mitigating circumstance or overlooked circumstances. Under subpart (a), the Court is the only movant that can reduce the sentence.  Subpart (b) which is typically the part that is addressed, can only be filed on motion by the Assistant US Attorney on behalf of the Government. It is typically brought on for reasons of substantial assistance.   You do not have to personally be in court unless you're needed to testify.  Typically your attorney, or the AUSA will be present.  I've been totally out of the federal crimlaw scene for many, many years, but my suggestion to you is that you go offline and talk to your lawyer about the details. I say this because if you're presently incarcerated, there's a substantial risk that your personal safety will be compromised.  And if you are not incarcerated, you DO NOT want to be in a public forum like a court, where you will definitely be identifiable in the event whoever it is you offered substantial assistance against, determines that you happen to be the CI.

I agree with both of the attorneys who have previously posted. You have a few options. First, if he gave you a 3-Day Notice to Pay or Surrender Possession asking for rent for the next three weeks, he cannot evict you for non-payment of rent if you normally pay on the first of the month and you are currently paid up to date. He has the right to give you notice that you must vacate the property, however, that notice must be made at least 15 days prior to the beginning of a new month, in your case. So even if he gave you a 15 day notice to vacate the premises, it would not take effect until August 31st.   I would highly suggest calling a Landlord/Tenant attorney in your area for more information.

Short Answer - Yes.   This type of demand happens many times with stores like Walmart. A person is arrested for retail theft. They have a criminal court hearing etc and perhaps are found guilty/not guilty.   Then a civil demand letter shows up in the mail either while they are waiting for the criminal case or after the criminal case is over.   This letter is very serious!   It is usually a demand to pay some small amount $160 ish to $260 ish dollars for them to agreed to forego a civil lawsuit. The letter usually cites the particular statute in question.  The catch is, this specific statute does exist and does mention the fine amount specifically!  So i suggest taking the letter to an attorney who handles shoplifting/retain theft cases and consult with them on the civil side. You will probably find it is cheaper to pay the civil demand amount to skip the civil case. Unfortunate, but realistic.   Don't ignore the letter or it could get worse for you.   Now, how does it affect your credit?  If the civil demand actually becomes a civil case, and you end up losing and getting a money judgement against you, it ends up in the state databases showing you have a judgement against you.   The credit reporting agencies scour these databases and upload the judgment information in their databases. Then they cross reference with know factors such as your name, address, phone number and birthdate.   Then, magically, the judgement is now on your credit report and affecting your credit score!  The problem is, there is no regular reporting method to remove a judgement. Credit care companies regularly report updates to the credit agencies. This update affects you account ongoing. There is no such type of update in the civil judgment systems. So if it shows up on your credit report you have to basically prove you paid it off (separately - this is done with a filing of a satisfaction of judgement with the court after payment in full) by showing your filed satisfaction of judgement. And the worst part is, they simply update the database to show the judgement paid off, it still stays as a previous debt for years (it is not removed, simply updated to reflect a zero balance). So the harm to your credit report goes on and on and on.   So take the criminal charges seriously (try to fight and get it reduced or removed) and the civil demand letter seriously and consult with an attorney right away.   Hopefully this helps!

Two things: 1)  you should have known prior to the hearing how much it would cost to add your child to your insurance and then presented this evidence to the judge.  This amount would then have been factored into the child support calculation. 2) Cash medical support is ordered in cases where there is not some court order that addresses how the after-insurance/uninsured health care costs are to be divided between the parents.  If there was such a court order (e.g. a prior divorce judgment may contain such language) then you should have presented this evidence to the judge.  It sounds like child support may have been established through an administrative hearing and perhaps there are no other court orders between you and the other parent.  You may want to consider initiating a proceeding to establish a parenting plan (the amount of time you have affects the child support calculation), and to provide for a 50/50 division of uninsured health care costs, and to also modify child support/cash medical, based on these new factors.  Through this process you should be able to modify child support and eliminate cash medical, but there are some pitfalls and you should schedule a consultation with an experienced family law attorney to gain a better understanding of how all this works.

I a very sorry for your loss.  The first step if you believe your sister was the victim of negligence is to retain a lawyer.    In order to pursue any medical negligence case it is necessary to show a deviation from the standard of care--basically meaning the level at which the average, prudent provider in a given community would practice. It is how similarly qualified practitioners would have managed the patient's care under the same or similar circumstances. In order to find out if you were the victim of negligence, you need to retain a lawyer willing to investigate the claim. The lawyer will gather your medical records and have them reviewed by a medical expert who will be asked to offer an opinion as to whether 1. the care and treatment you received fell below the applicable standard of care and 2. caused an injury. There is no claim to pursue unless and until such an opinion is secured.

The agreement for the cell service is not between Friend 1 and Friend 2. What Friend 2 knew about Friend 1's mental capacity is not relevant to whether the contract is enforceable between Friend 1 and service provider.  It would be very difficult to void the contract between Friend 1 and service provider. To void the contract, Friend 1 would have to prove that Friend 1 was mental incapable and that service provider knew of Friend 1's mental incapacity. How would the service provider know that Friend 1 had taken narcotics?  Hiring an attorney likely will cost Friend 1 more in attorney's fees than just paying termination fees.  Friend 1 likely has no legal duty to provide cell phone service to Friend 2. Friend 1 can just terminate the phone service (and paying the termination fees) or switch the service to another phone that Friend 1 has control of.

If you do not have sufficient work credits to qualify for Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) there is a limit on assets and income for Supplemental Security Income (SSI). SSDI is an entitlement program that you earn an insured status for if you work, pay Social Security Taxes on your earnings, and become disabled while you still have sufficient work credits. Generally if you have worked and earned more than $5,000 in at least 5 of the last 10 years before becoming disabled, you meet the non-medical requirements for SSDI and you can qualify for benefits if you can prove that you Disabilty prevents you from working full-time. To determine if you meet the non-medical requirements of SSDI, obtain a Social Security Statement from Social Security's website by creating a My Social Security Online Account, or contact SSA and ask if you have enough credits to qualify for SSDI and ask for your Date Last Insured.   If you don't qualify for SSDI, SSI would consider your assets (the money in your bank account) before looking at whether you are medically disabled. As a single person, if you have more than $2,000 in assets you do not even qualify to apply. If your are married SSA looks at whether you have more than $3,000 in assets between you and your spouse. You are also disqualified, or only entitled to a reduce payment if you have any income from any source, and if you are married, all income from your spouse is also considered.    I would recommend that you contact an attorney or Social Security immediate to determine if you qualify for Disabilty benefits.

Under the rules of professional conduct you are only to pay one attorney fee. Meaning, if you had two lawyers and a 40% contingency agreement, your two lawyers are to be paid out of that 40%.  So, if your second lawyer knew about the lien before the distribution of funds, and he paid himself the full contingency, then he broke the law. It is that simple. He should have paid the first lawyer from his share of the contingency fee. The State Bar will not like this if a report were to be filed.   If however, the second lawyer did not pay himself the full contingency and the $100k represents the balance of the fee, it is not yours to claim. The two lawyers will sort out who gets what.   If the money is indeed in excess of the agreed upon contingency (40%) then the State Bar will investigate the case at no charge to you.

What your boyfriend is doing is a crime under Washington law, and he may be guilty of Cyberstalking or even Extortion is he is seeking to obtain something from you. If he is identifying these photos as you, or if that is clear from their context, then the fact your face is obscured has no bearing on whether he is committing a crime. If it is you then it is you.  Cyberstalking.  Under Washington law cyberstalking is when a person intends to harass, intimidate, torment or embarrass another person, and in order to do that makes an electronic communication (email, text, chat, etc.) to that person, either (1) using lewd, indecent or obscene words or images or language, or (2)anonymously and repeatedly whether or not a conversation occurs, or (3) threatening to inflict injury on the person or their property or any ember of their family or household. Cyberstalking is a gross misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in jail for a first offense. If it involves threats to kill a person or if the person has a prior conviction for harassing the same person in the past, it is a Class C felony punishable by up to five years in jail. Cybertalking is also one of the few misdemeanor offenses that require someone convicted to give a DNA sample.  Extortion. A person is guilty of extortion in the second degree if he or she commits extortion by means of a wrongful threat as defined in *RCW 9A.04.110(25) (d) through (j). A threat means, among other things:   (28) "Threat" means to communicate, directly or indirectly the intent:      (e) To expose a secret or publicize an asserted fact, whether true or false, tending to subject any person to hatred, contempt, or ridicule; or      (f) To reveal any information sought to be concealed by the person threatened; or      (j) To do any other act which is intended to harm substantially the person threatened or another with respect to his or her health, safety, business, financial condition, or personal relationships;  I would recommend you warn your ex boyfriend one time in writing that you want him to immediately cease sending these images to anyone. You need to put him on warning that you do not want these images distributed, period. Then at that point if he continues to make these threats or sends any images out you could  (1) seek a protection order from the Court to stop him from sending these images, stalking and harassing you, and/or (2) make a report to the Police about his activities. The filing of an amended complaint begins a new round of pleadings.  The amended complaint supersedes the previous complaint as the "operative" pleading.  The practical effect is that each party is required to file a new response to the new (amended) complaint, regardless whether that party answered the previous complaint.  Each party has 30 days (or however many days the judge orders) to respond to the amended complaint.  To be clear, even a defendant who filed an answer to the previous complaint must file another answer to the amended complaint.  So in your example, both defendant A and defendant B are required to file a response to the amended complaint.

If something is expunged, it is deleted from, wiped out from, erased from your record.  That means that it is no longer there.  I would not disclose something that is no longer there in a perfect world, but we do not live in one.  The issue that you could have by not disclosing is that, because the expungement will be new, it may not make its way into the NCIC database.  If that is the case and Idaho finds the conviction in a criminal background check, you would have some explaining to do.  You would likely want to show them a copy of the court order expunging the case, but it is a foreseeable risk.  Bottom line = that you should not have to disclose something that is not on your record, otherwise, why have expungements at all?  But you need to weigh the potential for Idaho to believe that you hid something, so you need to decide if you want to definitely explain up front or maybe explain later.    Good luck to you! When someone is alleged to have committed a crime, and there is probable cause that they did commit the crime, they are usually arrested and placed into custody to answer to those charges. Once in custody, they will remain in custody unless they are released on their own recognizance or they post bail. A bail setting is based on whether the person is a flight risk (the likelihood they will appear for court) and whether the person is a danger to the community at large (prior criminal history or violent nature of the offense). Once a person is placed on bail, that bail can be revoked by a judge for cause. I am not sure why your son was remanded, but if you believe his rights were violated in some manner you should consult with an attorney. Best of luck.

Bear in mind that the B1-B2 visa is a "visitor visa," which means that you are not coming to live and work to the US. You can only stay for as long as the I-94 says. There is a possibility to request a 6-month extension. But staying in the US for too long may make it look as if your intent is not to "visit" but to "immigrate," which creates a potential big problem for you.  On the F1 visa, you don't have to "exchange it" for a B1/B2. You could be granted F1 visa and hold on to the B1/B2, which remains valid as a matter of discretion. But if you abuse any of the two visas you could be denied entry at the border in the future.

I am an attorney licensed in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and the States of Delaware and New Jersey.  My practice includes employment, business and health care law. Before I respond to your inquiry, I must state that we have not spoken, I have not reviewed the relevant documents and facts, and I do not represent you. Therefore, my discussion below is not a legal opinion, but is informational only. Finally, my discussion applies only to issues to which Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey or Federal law applies.  That being said, if you will not be accessing, manipulating or transmitting patient data, then you likely have no HIPAA issue.  Simply because you create a tool that a customer uses will not create that liability.  If you are involved in the use of the tool, and have access to patient information, however, then you are a Business Associate and have your own HIPAA compliance obligations, and can be liable for civil money penalties for failure to comply.    If your design of the tool is negligent, then it is possible that the drug company could sue you for damages - you should make sure your contract limits your liability.  I suppose that a patient might be able to sue under a third party beneficiary/breach of contract  theory, but it seems unlikely to me.    There is no private right to sue under HIPAA, so affected patients would have to sue under state law for breach of privacy, etc.  You should look into whether you need HIPAA breach protection insurance; such insurance is available, but some of the insurers are new to that part of the industry.  I would recommend an established data privacy insurer.  /Christopher E. Ezold/

The enhancability of your current case is going to depend on 1) what degree felony  the offense is all by itself, 2) what prior felony convictions you have that your actually been to prison for, and 3) if those priors were for non-state jail felonies, how many separate times you went to prison for them (e.g., if you were sentenced on all 3 of those 2nd degree offenses at the same time, they effectively only count as one enhancement, but if you got sentenced on one of them, did your time, and then got out to commit two more that you then went to prison for, that scenario could result in two usable enhancements). Through the discovery process your attorney can have appraisals done of personal property in a home. Dealing with a self employed party requires a bit more diligence in ascertaining a persons true income. Often self employed people have a much higher standard of living on the same reported income as their W2 counterparts.  This can be because of certain tax advantages of self employment, payment of in kind expenses, and the ability to conceal cash receipts in certain cases.  By analyzing a persons standard of living and expenses you can make a case for the Court to impute income to a party.  It is often advisable to hire a good forensic accountant to help with this process.

I do not believe there is any truth to the idea that fathers are mistreated in family court. Instead, I believe that all taxpaying citizens are mistreated in family court.  For example, just yesterday, a Manhattan support magistrate (Weir Reeves) dismissed my client mother's paternity petition for her appearance yesterday morning. The case was on 11:30am time certain and my client mother was in the waiting area since 10:20am. I arrived at 11:20 and my adversary emailed me she was going to be late because she was stuck on a broken down bus. Weir Reeves' court officer never called out my client's name at any time while she was there in the waiting area. My adversary arrived at that point. When I approached the part clerk who stepped out from hiding to give another person some orders at 11:44am, he said the case was dismissed because no one showed up.  When the court officer (bailiff) badge #3065 came out, I asked what happened and this officer said no one was 'here'. My client mother said the officer never called her name. When I backed up my client who was telling the truth, badge #3065 said she could not believe how an officer of the court, me, could misrepresent the facts the way I was doing. I responded that indeed I was an officer of the court and I said I noted that at no time while I was there was the client's case called, not at 11:30am, not at all. I offered a simple fix -- let's all go in before the magistrate and stipulate to a restoration of the case to the calendar. Badge #3065 said the magistrate is not restoring any cases and I can file a motion to vacate the default and that I am a liar. Given the animosity exhibited by Badge #3065 and previously by the part clerk, I suspected that Weir Reeves wanted to commence her Labor Day week vacation early and that dismissing cases for peoples' non-appearance was an effective way to do that. Don't call the case, and dismiss it for petitioner's non-appearance.  I noted that despite a rather full calendar, the waiting area was nearly devoid of litigants at mid-day.  Ultimately, a little child has no father. So the family court shames and humiliates lawyers, both parents and the children it is charged to service and protect. The leadership environment in these courts is atrocious and its highest leaders must be fired and replaced. Court officers are rude and condescending to attorneys and are free to fabricate stories to protect their employment. Weir Reeves has used adjournments followed by dismissals in several of my prior cases and the only explanation I see for not expeditiously restoring a mistakenly dismissed case was that Weir Reeves wanted to lighten her daily work load and the case of an upcoming Labor Day weekend, clear up her calendar to start her holiday early.  Young fathers are not the only target. Everyone is a target and matters do not improve in Supreme Court. There, you will confront surly court attorneys and part clerks. User friendliness does not exist in Supreme Court and federal family policy is enforced with greater vigor in those courts, perhaps even more so than in family court which has compartmented courtrooms handling individual petitions and issues.

As surviving spouse you have a constitutional right to live in the home until you die.  Now you need to address getting the home in your name.  This may or may not involve going to court, but when someone dies with no will and they have children from a prior marriage, then those kids inherit half of his real property.  The surviving spouse inherits the other half.  If the children want to, they could sign a quit claim deed or a gift deed giving you their interest in the home.  If they don't want to give it, you can try to pay them for it.  Otherwise, you live in the home until you die and then your estate could potentially force a sale of the home to liquidate it and give your share of the proceeds to your estate and the other share to the kids.

After reading your questions to Ms. Alperovich, who gave you excellent advice, I think you are asking about the procedure for handing in an  agreement. All you have to do is file for custody and go to the first conference. At that conference, the two of you tell the officer about your agreement, and it will be written up for you to sign right then and there. The officer will give it to a judge to sign and will mail you both a copy. The benefit to doing this is that the officer will help both of you tweak the agreement so that problems do not arise later on. For example, the holiday schedule can cause upset if it is not handled properly. Long weekends, summer vacations, etc. can all be set up by the conference officer in a fair manner that will make both of you happier.

An appeal is not a do over to argue anew any and all points where one disagrees with the result in the court below.  The appellate court looks to see if the process was fair, including whether the lower court followed the law. And where the lower court has discretion in acting, it is only if the appellate court is persuaded the lower court abused that discretion will it overturn or modify a lower court ruling.  An appellate court does not tend to try and substitute its own interpretation of the facts in place of the lower court's interpretation.  Not many cases are reversed on appeal, which may be bad for particular appellants who do not get the relief they seek, but is a good indication that our trial court level process is not broken. If most appeals were successful, we'd have major problems at the lower court level.

Bottom line is that if you ever want to proceed with an eviction against a tenant, you need to have complied with Chapter 83, Florida Statutes, which requires you to deliver the 3-day notice.  Now, if you deliver the 3-day notice, and then accept payment from the tenant, you lose your rights to evict.  So, if you plan on going forward with an eviction in the event you do not receive payment from the tenant by a date certain, the 3-day notice must be delivered and you cannot accept the rental payment.  Per 83.56(4), you can mail, deliver, or if the tenant is absent from the premises, leave a copy of the notice at the premises.  I would err on the side of caution and comply with the statute in addition to e-mailing.  That's not an issue to litigate over.  I'd also recommend having a candid conversation with the tenant to be better advised as to the status and timing of the next few rental payments and then you can decide how best to proceed.   Good luck.

There is no such thing as legal separation in New Jersey. There is, however, a divorce from bed and board, which is the closest thing. This severs the financial ties between the parties, but is a good option for people whose religion prohibits divorce or who have other personal reasons for not wanting a divorce. There are drawbacks to a divorce from bed and board, including but not limited to the fact that both parties must  consent to a divorce from bed and board and it prohibits remarriage.   With respect to divorcing a person that has a disability and is unable to manage their own affairs ‰ÛÒ legal or otherwise, you may want to consider asking the court to appoint an attorney and/or a guardian ad litem for the person and guardianship proceedings in the probate part may actually be necessary if there is a question as to the person‰Ûªs capacity. An attorney will advocate for the client‰Ûªs wishes, but a guardian ad litem‰Ûªs job is to recommend to the court what he or she determines that person‰Ûªs best interests to be. They serve two different roles and in some cases, both are necessary and/or appropriate.  Divorces can be highly complicated, especially when one party suffers from a disability and requires court-appointed assistance. It is important that you discuss the specifics of your case with an experienced matrimonial attorney who also has experience with guardianship matters to determine what steps you will need to take to protect your interests in a divorce. With due respect to my friend Scott who is a great lawyer, this time I disagree.  The law says more that just providing the alcohol constitutes a crime.  You can be charged if you allow him to consume alcohol.  Here is the law:  Md. CRIMINAL LAW Code Ann. å¤ 10-117  (2014)  å¤ 10-117. Furnishing for or allowing underage consumption       (a) Furnishing alcohol. -- Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a person may not furnish an alcoholic beverage to an individual if:     (1) the person furnishing the alcoholic beverage knows that the individual is under the age of 21 years; and     (2) the alcoholic beverage is furnished for the purpose of consumption by the individual under the age of 21 years.  (b) Allowing possession or consumption of alcohol. -- Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an adult may not knowingly and willfully allow an individual under the age of 21 years actually to possess or consume an alcoholic beverage at a residence, or within the curtilage of a residence that the adult owns or leases and in which the adult resides.  (c) Exceptions. --     (1) The prohibition set forth in subsection (a) of this section does not apply if the person furnishing the alcoholic beverage and the individual to whom the alcoholic beverage is furnished:        (i) are members of the same immediate family, and the alcoholic beverage is furnished and consumed in a private residence or within the curtilage of the residence; or        (ii) are participants in a religious ceremony.     (2) The prohibition set forth in subsection (b) of this section does not apply if the adult allowing the possession or consumption of the alcoholic beverage and the individual under the age of 21 years who possesses or consumes the alcoholic beverage:        (i) are members of the same immediate family, and the alcoholic beverage is possessed and consumed in a private residence, or within the curtilage of the residence, of the adult; or        (ii) are participants in a religious ceremony.  Read this and make sure your actions take this law into account.  you can always be charged depending on how a prosecutor views your actions, but you should be able to take steps to demonstrate your efforts if you read this and follow it

I hope that you were successful at your recent hearing. The rules differ somewhat based on the program that you are qualified for benefits under. If you are approved, and only receive, Social Security Disability Insurance, their is an exact earnings limit called Substantial Gainful Activity (SGA). The amount of SGA changes in January of each calendar year, but in 2014, it is $1,070 of gross income per month. If you are able to make $1,070 or more, and you have used all your trial work months, you no longer qualify for Social Security Disability Insurance while you continue to make SGA. Luckily, you have 9 Trial Work Months to attempt work before this earnings limit is used. You use a trial work month if you earn more than $770 in any month in 2014 (this number also changes in January of each year). While you still have trial work months available, you can make any dollar amount without losing your benefit. However after you have went over the trial work amount in 9 months within a 60 month period of time, you must remain below SGA to keep your benefits.  If you are approved, the type of work that you do cannot cause a medical review of your claim, but if your claim is medically reviewed, the type of part-time work you do can be considered if medical improvement is proved. This means that if you are approved based on mental health/psychological functioning, but you perform work on a set schedule, that requires you to deal with the public on a regular basis, and requires attention to detail, focus and concentration, the ability to perform this type of work could have an impact on your keeping your benefits when you are reviewed for medical improvement.  If you only qualify for SSI, the earnings test is slightly different. For SSI purposes, you lose $1 for every $2 that you earn after your first $65 of income. You must report all income to SSI, and there is no trial work period. The good news is if you are able to work part-time, you can potentially make more money under the SSI program than you can under SSDI before losing your benefits. The bad news is that work does reduce your month SSI payment. Also, just like under SSDI, if you are medically reviewed, the type of work you are doing can have an impact on the decision of whether you remain disabled.  I hope this information helps. I would also recommend using Social Security's Ticket to Work program if you are approved. This way you are provided with job coaching, and with experts to advise on the impact that your work would have on your benefits.

First, you need to understand that if you do blow and the number is above a .08, you face (assuming this is your first DUI) a 6 month suspension of drivers license.  If you do not blow, you face a 12 month suspension. However, when you blow, you are providing evidence the courts will use against you. I only recommend people blow into any machine if they are certain they will blow below the legal limit (really, only if they are certain they will blow zeros).  The reason is that despite the longer suspension, the less evidence you provide the officer(s), the better your case might go.   Here is the basic advice I give to people who ask this question: 1) always ALWAYS be polite, courteous and respectful to the officer(s).  Attitude won't help and tends instead to hurt your case 2)  Upon request, tender your drivers license and insurance information. 3)  If you are inside a vehicle, decline to exit the vehicle respectfully unless ordered to do so, then comply fully (in other words, if asked out of a car, ask the officer if he is ordering you out of the vehicle or asking if you would voluntarily exit - usually, it's an order). 4)  Decline to answer any questions or make any statements without your attorney present (you must disclose biographical information, not what you've been doing, why you are there, if you've been drinking, where you are coming from, etc) 5)  Do not consent to any testing or any kind until you have spoken with an attorney. Bear in mind that an officer may arrest you if they believe you are under the influence of alcohol, but any field sobriety tests (including the breathalyzer, questioning, walk and turn, heel/toe, finger to nose, etc) is being done not to clear you of a potential charge, but to confirm the officers suspicion and to collect evidence for use against you.  To be clear, this means declining the one leg stand, the walk and turn, the HGN/VGN, the portable breathalyzer, and the breathalyzer offered in the station. 6)  Ask the officer to advise you if you are free to leave or not.  If not, remain compliant.  If so, thank the officer, wish them a nice evening, and leave. You have no right to an attorney until you are under arrest and being questioned.  If you are asked questions once back at the station that are not biographical in nature (date of birth, where you live, age, etc), decline to answer and immediately, but politely, tell the officer that you refuse to make any statement or answer any questions without your lawyer present.  The police may try to make fun of you, try to make you feel bad, or try to tell you that it is in your best interest to speak to them.  It very, very rarely is.  Ask to speak to your lawyer and no matter how much time has passed, no matter what the officer may say, remain silent save to reiterate your desire to have an attorney present prior to any questioning.  They are legally required to cease any interrogation. If you are arrested and processed, remain compliant, polite, and courteous.  Once released, schedule more than one consultation with an attorney that handles DUI regularly in the county where your case will be heard.  Speak with these lawyers candidly and expect them to discuss DUI law, your suspension, next steps, price (both with and without trial), and for them to answer your questions.  If your consultation consists of the lawyer telling you the cost and to meet them in court and nothing else, walk away. Find the right lawyer that you can trust and that you believe will work hard to defend your case. Best of luck.  Hope this helps.

Regardless, the requirements for the perfection of a lien claim are generally set forth in section 38-22-109, C.R.S.  There are important statutory deadlines for mechanics liens so you need to read the statute carefully and you'll need to do that immediately. Well, you've got a lien, which is probably junior to the first deed of trust.  If you want to then foreclose the lien, you'd have to pay off the liens in higher priority. You potentially run into a problem called "hearsay" with your friend's statement. Hearsay is "an out of court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted" and is generally barred from evidence. Here, you potentially have 2 layers of hearsay -- one is your father's out-of-court statement and the second being your friend's out-of-court written statement.  You will need to find "exceptions" to the hearsay rule to get this evidence in. For the first layer, there is an exception for statements made by a party to the proceeding (i.e your father). See California Evidence Code section 1220. For the second layer of hearsay (your friend's written statement), you probably don't have an exception to rely on. Although declarations (sworn written statements) can be presented as admissible evidence in some family law hearings, they cannot be presented at trials. A DVTRO hearing is essentially a "mini-trial." Thus, you would be safest to have your friend come in and testify (and you have that right!). All this being said, if the other party doesn't "object" to the written statement and the judge chooses to consider it, it would come in as evidence anyway -- I just wouldn't rely on this (and even if it was considered, the judge might give it very little weight). Regarding notarization, notarizing the statement would not have an affect on it being admissible as evidence. Hope this helps!

This is a great question. It is true that referral fees are not allowed in bankruptcy.   However, to understand the reason you have to back track through quite a few different sections of the Bankruptcy Code in order to find the answer. (If traffic signs were as confusing as the rules governing this question, I'm afraid that very few people would ever find their way to any destination.) However, it is kind of fun, so here we go:  Bankruptcy Code Section 504 (Sharing of Compensation), very clearly provides that compensation, (including lawyer fees), may not be shared with any persons outside of one's own firm. The only exception is for fees required to be paid to a bona fide public service attorney referral program operated in accordance with local state law, such as a county bar  sponsored referral panel.  Section 504 implicates the provisions of Section 503(b)(2), which leads you back the provisions of Section 330, which leads you back to Section 329 of the Bankruptcy Code which which covers any fees paid to a lawyer on behalf of a debtor!   Hence, no referral fees. So, there you are, legalized torture. Tell your cousin I said welcome to bankruptcy law.

The Arizona law regarding your question reads as follows:   14-2516. Custodian of will; duties; liability  A. After the death of a testator and on request of an interested person, a person having custody of a will of the testator shall deliver it with reasonable promptness to a person able to secure its probate or, if none is known, to an appropriate court.  B. A person who wilfully fails to deliver a will as required by this section is liable to any person aggrieved for any damages caused by this failure.  C. A person who wilfully refuses or fails to deliver a will after being ordered by the court in a proceeding brought for the purpose of compelling delivery is subject to penalty for contempt of court.

This is an example of how screwed up things are these days with people and convictions - it is not enough for us to convict people these days, we have to punish them over and over again to the point of making them unemployable. Then people wonder why those arrested and convicted of a crime so often wind up back in jail - mainly because they cannot put their lives back together because no one will hire them when they are through paying for their offense. Here you are with a minor (I presume minor) offense and you can't get work. This is ridiculous. First, you need to get in touch with an ex-con advocacy group. There are plenty of them around. In your area get in touch with http://ga.thebeehive.org/jobs/job-articles/ex-offender-job-search - they help ex-offenders find work. You need to find work to break your dependency on the person who put you in this predicament to begin with. Also if you work with Beehive, they will help you evaluate whether it makes sense to reopen your conviction to try and get it expunged. It may not make sense to do that - but if it does, they certainly can tell you. You can also contact the City of Atlanta Adult Services office - http://www.atlantaga.gov/index.aspx?page=758 - they work with ex-offenders as well. Contact these and others to help you work through this problem.

You can continue to be employed  at the 3  locations with the TN visas . The labor certification (PERM) application does not require that you occupy the actual full time position until such time that the resident process is completed. The PERM is a job offer for a position that you will occupy in the future. In certain cases the individuals may already be occupying the job position today but that is not an absolute requirement. However, you need to be very careful with the PERM application because you occupy a TN visa  which does not allow for dual intent. After your employer begins the PERM process and your employer files the FORM I-140, you will not be able to extend the TN visa.

What a terrible and scary situation.  I'm very sorry to hear that you're dealing with this.  The first thing you should do is take a big deep breath and go through with the testing (and/or getting any prophylactic medications that might be involved).  It's scary, but not knowing isn't doing you any favors and could actually cause you greater harm--some infections are easier to deal with the earlier they're caught, and others are diagnosed based on changes in your body's chemistry that can only be identified once you have a "baseline".  Your first priority should be your health (and whether you have a case will depend on whether you have any damages, so a lawyer will be useless if you're unwilling to go forward with monitoring and taking care of your health).  Go get whatever blood work that is recommended done and keep up with the monitoring--there are typically set schedules for testing for different possible infections after exposures like this (e.g. HIV tests in these situations occur several times over a course of months to be certain that you are negative).  Take the initial results, information on the ongoing testing, and the statement they want you to sign to an experienced attorney in your local area.

Be concise and to the point and if you have not run numbers, run them and bring them for support - LA uses Santa Clara method - find a copy of dissomaster or use the California Guideline Support Calculator.  You do not say whether you need child support.  http://www.childsup.ca.gov/Resources/CalculateChildSupport.aspx They judge may or may not have reviewed your case and you will not get more than 20 minutes (not likely).  Bring your paystubs an extra copy of your FL-150 and stay on point WHY you think you need support and have it backed up with a printout showing that you plugged in numbers using Santa Clara guideline for spousal.  The judge may ask questions, have your taxes as well - even if you've already submitted FL-150 - have it ready for the Judge in case he can't find it in the file.  You do not need a closing statement.  If you don't get what you want, you ask to speak and explain why you disagree.  DO NOT INTERRUPT YOUR SPOUSE OR THE JUDGE!  Be polite and courteous and strong in your argument.  If, however, the law is not on your side - e.g., you have a job, he has a job, you earn about the same amount, you have not been married very long - you cannot likely expect support.  You have to have a REASON and the reason needs to be valid in the eyes of the court.  Go to that particular courtroom and watch your judge - go to the early am motion hearings, sit in the back and watch how that judge handles in pro pers assuming you are representing yourself.  That will best answer your question.  Find out when the Judge hears RFOs and sit in from 8:30-10AM to get a feel.  Good luck!

I would need more information to answer this question.  In Indiana, a grandparent may petition the court for visitation if the child's parent is deceased, the marriage of the child's parents has been dissolved, or if it is a child born out of wedlock situation, once the biological father has established paternity.  You stated that your grandson may have to go to foster care.  If this is the case I would need to know where mom is.  And if this is a Child In Need of Services case then the department of child services would have to consider you for placement before the child could be placed in foster care.  Alternatively, you could petition the court to appoint you as a de facto custodian of your grandson.  however, you would need to establish that you were his primary caregiver, provided financial support for him and that he resided with you for a period of 6 months if he is less than 3 years of age or 1 year if he is at least 3 years of age.

It sounds like you are concerned about who will get your residence if you divorce. How long have you been married and living in the house? The general rule is that a party who inherits property during a marriage can keep that property in a divorce.  But, there are exceptions to the rule that allow the property or portions of the equity to be divided in a divorce.  There are legal arguments that you should discuss in detail with an attorney.    Your posts here are not confidential, but your communications with an attorney are. Consider contacting an attorney about your case to discuss it in detail.  If you have children, you will want to discuss child support.  You probably need to ask about the prospect of alimony too.  If you have any debts that you or he took on during the marriage, they will be an issue in the divorce also.  I recommend that you obtain a consultation with an attorney.  Many attorneys on this website offer free consultations where you can discuss these very important concerns in a confidential setting.

As one of my colleagues noted, it may be possible for your to "convert" your jointly filed petition into a "good faith marriage waiver" petition.  There is a USCIS memorandum that addresses this topic and states, essentially, that USCIS can issue a request for evidence letter asking for the final judgment of divorce.   This gives you time to secure the final judgment, provide a copy to USCIS, and then let them adjudicate the case as a good faith marriage waiver.  In that scenario, there would be no need to re-file the case.  Sometimes, however, the tricky part is getting a final judgment of divorce before the due date on the request for evidence letter.  Although rare, if still legally married at the interview (if USCIS schedules an I-751 interview [as they can waive that]) and so long as you and your estranged spouse both appear, the case can still be approved as a joint petition.  Unless your U.S. Citizen spouse expressly wrote to USCIS to withdraw the petition, it can still be adjudicated as a joint petition even though you are having marital problems.  It's not the viability of the marriage that counts; it's whether it was entered in good faith.  Concerning your "extension . . . expiring in six months"; so long as your I-751 remains pending, even beyond the 1 year of extended status granted by the I-751 receipt notice, you can get a temporary I-551 stamp (evidencing that you are still a permanent resident) at a local USCIS office.  You should likely consult with a competent immigration attorney who can discuss these things I have mentioned and other items.  So long as your marriage was bona fide, you have options.

California does not have a true "expungement" statute. What we do have is a dismissal under Penal Code 1203.4. If granted, it doesn't wipe the case off your record, but it adds a notation that the case was dismissed. That allows you to tell most employers that you have not been convicted of the crime, but it remains on your record and still counts as a prior conviction.   Not every felony (currently) can be reduced to a misdemeanor. Your friend may want to (if hey can) wait until after the election to see if the law changes and makes all simple possession charges "wobblers" that can be reduced to misdemeanors.  But to answer your question, no there is no limit on when you can file for a dismissal under 1203.4.  This may be worth a local criminal defense attorney's help. It's not complicated, so it should not cost much, but your friend should know all of their options.

I would recommend you seek an Order of Protection (or an OP).  An OP does essentially the same thing as a Restraining Order but they are two different things.  An OP is designed to deal with exactly these types of situations.  An OP is easier to obtain and the law provides for you to be awarded attorney fees if you are successful.  The problem is you would still have to appear in Court in order to obtain a 1 year Order of Protection.  While I understand this process can be intimidating and cause you a lot of discomfort, I cannot think of any way you can achieve the result you want without having to make a Court appearance.  If you are really unwilling to come to court, you might want to consider changing your telephone number, and you email address.  Hopefully that will be enough to keep him from continuing to harass you.  Consider speaking to an attorney who might be willing to help you.  You might find someone from your local bar association or Legal Aid might be able to assist you.  Good luck.

But I would ask them for accommodation specifically before things come to a head and ask for specific things that are reasonable and, of course, backed by your doctor who is presumably of the opinion you are not quite ready to work or work full time.

I am not a MN lawyer so I cannot comment on matters of MN law or procedure.    However,  were your fact pattern a matter of Florida law, then I, a 22+ year veteran Florida criminal defense lawyer, would tell you that, unless some extremely unlikely security issue exists, then your Affidavit in Support of the VOP Warrant is a matter of public record, it is in the Clerk of Court's file and is available for anyone to pull, inspect and copy, including you (if you are foolish enough to trek into the Courthouse and try to pull the file yourself).  I can also comment about the nature of warrants in general (again, limiting my commentary as a Florida and not a MN lawyer) and in that regard I would opine that the bottom line with warrants is that they suck (well that and that oftentimes they end up in untimely and inconvenient incarceration).    When it comes to the subject of warrants, anyone anywhere who has knowledge of the existence of the warrant has 2 choices:  Either they can deal with it proactively, in an offensive manner or they can live day to day, waiting until it is ultimately served, and then play catch-up (defense).   In this light warrants can be likened to cancer. If it exists (whether it is a warrant or cancer) then you have a problem. You can either choose to deal with the problem and hope for the best or you can wait for the problem to deal with you in its own natural fashion. In the former event it may or may not work out favorably for you, but, in the case of a warrant, at least the State and the Judge will have to acknowledge that you voluntarily chose to bring the matter to them (which is an undeniable fact that even an inexperienced lawyer should be able to use your advantage during the pendency of your case). In the later event, however, just as with cancer, the longer that you choose to wait (whether in denial, self-pity or simply because you are lost in hope, desperation and prayer that it'll heal itself / go away) then more time that it has to metasticize and destroy you from within.  You may well have defenses to your charge (as I said I am not an MN lawyer and I know less than nothing about MN law - you should certainly discuss the same with an experienced Mendota Heights, MN area criminal defense practicioner) but, right, wrong or indifferent I am confident that the warrant is a veritable cancer which will almost surely prejudice you, whether with the Court, the State or both, sometime down the legal pike.   I hope that I have been helpful in answering your question.
You have to have a witness period.  Sometimes you can get away with having them appear by phone or via the net, but you must have one

More information is needed to fully answer this question.  Generally speaking, if she is young, able bodied, and educated, other than perhaps some support for a limited period of time, it would not seem she would be entitled to anything long term.   The length of your marriage is in the moderate range.  The Court could consider some type alimony called "bridge the gap" which would be for a short period of time to meet specific goals.  The Court could consider durational alimony which would be alimony for a set period of time not to exceed the length of the marriage.  The Court could consider rehabilitative alimony if this is needed to re-educate your wife to get her back into the work force.  There would be no set guidelines currently existing for you to look at to ascertain an amount nor duration.  In sum, there is no simple answer to this question.

If they refuse to answer your question then California employment law provides a method for you to get a copy of you employment file, which should note your termination date.  Effective January 1, 2013, California law provides that current and former employees (or a representative) have the right to inspect and receive a copy of the personnel files and records that relate to the employee‰Ûªs performance or to any grievance concerning the employee. Labor Code Section 1198.5  Inspections must be allowed at reasonable times and intervals, but not later than 30 calendar days from the date the employer receives a written request. Upon a written request from a current or former employee, or a representative, the employer shall provide a copy of the personnel records, at a charge not to exceed the actual cost of reproduction, not less than 30 calendar days from the date the employer receives the request. To facilitate the inspection, employers shall do all of the following: (1) maintain a copy of each employee‰Ûªs personnel records for a period of not less than three years after termination of employment, (2) make a current employee‰Ûªs personnel records available for inspection, and if requested by the employee or representative, provide a copy at the place where the employee reports to work, or at another location agreeable to the employer and the requester. If the employee is required to inspect or receive a copy at a location other than the place where he or she reports to work, no loss of compensation to the employee is permitted, (3) make a former employee‰Ûªs personnel records available for inspection, and if requested by the employee or representative, provide a copy at the location where the employer stores the records, unless the parties mutually agree in writing to a different location.  A former employee may receive a copy by mail if he or she reimburses the employer for actual postal expenses.  An employer is not required to comply with more than 50 requests to inspect and receive a copy of personnel records filed by a representative or representatives of employees in one calendar month.  The employer may take reasonable steps to verify the identity of a current or former employee or an authorized representative.  Prior to making records available for inspection or providing a copy of those records, the employer may redact the name of any nonsupervisory employee. If a former employee seeking to inspect his or her personnel records was terminated for a violation of law, or an employment-related policy, involving harassment or workplace violence, the employer may comply with the request by doing one of the following: (1) making the personnel records available to the former employee for inspection at a location other than the workplace that is within a reasonable driving distance of the former employee‰Ûªs residence, (2) providing a copy of the personnel records by mail. If an employer fails to permit a current employee, former employee, or representative to inspect or copy personnel records within the times specified, or times agreed to by mutual agreement , the current employee, former employee, or the Labor Commissioner may recover a penalty of $750.00 from the employer.  A current or former employee may also bring an action for injunctive relief to obtain compliance, and may recover costs and reasonable attorney‰Ûªs fees in such an action through the court process. The right to inspect personnel files and records does not apply to records relating to the investigation of a possible criminal offense, letters of reference, or ratings, report

First of all your mother was apparently living in Texas when she died so you may need to contact an attorney in Texas and the local laws in Texas will apply.  You sister may be correct that probate is not warranted.  (In most states probate is not legally required when someone dies.   It is just an optional tool that can be used to settle up the final affairs of an estate.)  It is often the case that a person uses up their assets for their final care at the end of their life.  When this happens there may be no need to probate anything.  This still doesn't explain why your sister won't give you a copy of the will and an explanation of how your mother's money was managed in the end.  While you might need a Texas lawyer if you need to use Texas law to compel this type of disclosure and accounting, I suspect you could go and talk to a Portland Lawyer who could contact your sister and convince her to at least give you the information and accounting you are after.  Incidentally, the Power of Attorney is a different role then an executor of a will although the same person may be named for both roles.  Once a person dies the person that was acting as a Power of Attorney no longer has that power to act.  If they do anything after the death of the person they are most likely acting as the Executor of the Will.  However someone that previously acted under a Power of Attorney was acting as a fiduciary and they continue to be liable for accounting for how they used or spent funds during the period that they were empowered to act as a Power of Attorney and they can be liable for any mismanagement of funds.  Most states have laws that prohibit elder abuse which includes misusing the funds of an elderly or disabled person and this can have criminal penalties.  For these reasons I think a request from an attorney, either in Oregon or Texas should motivate your sister to be a little more cooperative.  You have to be prepared however to accept that even with the information disclosed, you may find that your sister is being truthful and there really isn't any money or property left over to be distributed.

Please do things the right way and see an elder law attorney who has a significant special needs planning practice. You want to be sure to draft estate plans which will allow an attorney-in-fact to transfer funds to your son's trust if you are alive but not competent and a will which will direct the inheritance to that trust.   Having your daughter simply hand your son money as need will definitely jeopardize his benefits, as such hand-outs will be considered "gifts" by most agencies. Besides, any money given to your daughter will be exposed to HER creditors. If she divorces or is sued, that money can be easily lost.  Additionally, you need to consider the possibility that asking your daughter to be in charge of these funds may become a significant burden on her, particularly if her family or job needs her attention.   You also need to give very careful thought to who will be trustee. You need to be sure that the trustee is truly trustworthy, knows the difference in the rules between the various public benefits programs or will take the time to learn them, is able to keep  very good records, and will be able and willing to work with an experienced special needs planning attorney. This is not a decision to be made automatically or lightly. If your daughter doesn't fit this description, then she shouldn't be the trustee. She could still take a role as a watchdog over the trustee, however.  Good planning isn't necessarily cheap; however, you have to consider the cost of what could happen to your son if things go wrong. Find someone who knows what they're really doing. You can start by looking for a member of the Massachusetts chapter of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, www.naela.org  Good luck!

An evidentiary hearing is a hearing at which evidence is presented and heard by the court.  That means the evidence has to be presented according to the Rules of Evidence, with witnesses testifying under oath from personal knowledge, etc.  I assume the court's order explains what issues of fact the district court must decide.  You should be prepared to present evidence within the rules so the district court can decide that factual issue.   Sworn written statements generally do not meet the rules of evidence.  You may want to reconsider having a lawyer represent you.  Also please realize that any testimony in this matter may be used as evidence for any potential criminal charges that are being considered.

The Illinois Right of Publicity Act, which eclipses the old common law misappropriation of likeness "invasion of privacy"-type tort, limits the prohibition to commercial uses (765 ILCS s 1075/30).  If this is a non-explicit and non-commercial use, the blog owner took the photograph, and the photograph was taken in public, your sister's recourse may be limited.  If contacting the blog's owner has been unsuccessful as a result of his/her anonymity, you may be able to uncover it through a pre-suit discovery action (e.g., Rule 224 Petition for Discovery, here in Illinois) and a series of orders/subpoenas.  Merely having to respond to the pre-suit discovery action once it got down to his/her person may motivate the blog owner to take the photo down.

Under Georgia law, if a person dies intestate (which means the person does not have a Will), then the title to any interest that person owned in Georgia real estate will pass in one of two ways: (1) if the real estate is owned jointly with one or more other owners as "joint tenants" (this is controlled by the deed), then the person's interest automatically transfers to the surviving joint tenants and his estate does not receive any interest. (2) If the person owns real estate in Georgia as either the sole owner or as a tenant in common (again, this is controlled by the deed - the default for joint ownership is tenancy in common, however, so if the deed does not clearly indicate a joint tenacy, it  doesn't created one), then the person's interest in the property is said to immediately vest in his heirs. However, if an administrator is appointed for the person's estate, then the heirs are divested of title. This does not make sense, necessarily, it's just the way the law works. I believe the intent was to allow real estate to be dealt with even if no administrator was appointed for an intestate person's estate, but to ensure that the administrator could control the real estate if one was appointed. Once the administrator is appointed, the administrator will eventually need to transfer the property back to the heirs, if it isn't sold to pay debts or for other purposes out of the estate.  So, if you are an heir to a person's estate, and that person had no Will, then you would have temporarily taken an interest in that person's Georgia real estate, but once an administrator was appointed, the interest you originally held is no longer held by you - the administrator has it.  Now - you mention someone serving as the Executor. If there really is an Executor, and not an Administrator, that means the person who owned the real estate DID have a Will. Under Georgia law, if the person HAD a Will, there is no immediate transfer of title to the heirs. Instead, the title is deemed to have remained in the person's probate estate, and the Executor, once appointed, can control the real estate interests. What's next is a series of pre-trial conferences, discovery, and motions. Trial is a ways off. It does seen like a fairly decent deal particularly given the top count is a high level felony. However, just because it seems a good deal on its face, doesn't mean it is a good deal.  You should really discuss this with his attorney. It's possible his lawyer is simply holding a hard line for negotiating right now as you are at the beginning of a lengthy process. Also, the lawyer may be planning a suppression motion or other pre-trial motion that may weaken the state's case and this improve the deal.   The jury cannot add on charges or make the charges worse. The prosecutor can add charges, if there is evidence to support other charges.   If he is convicted, it is likely he will do time. How much time depends on the what charges he is convicted of, his history, the specific facts, the judge, and a number of other factors. This is another thing to keep in mind about the lawyer's decision: the prosecutor can recommend 10 days jail and 5 years probation, but the judge is not required to follow that recommendation. The lawyer, being familiar with the judge, may suspect the judge will not follow the recommendation in this case.  You really should discuss this all with the lawyer handling the case. He or she is in the best position to answer your questions. If you have concerns about his or her handling of the case, you can always hire another lawyer.

There is no one size fits all answer to this question.  "What now" depends on what he wants to do about this.  There are often numerous defenses to foreclosure.  If your father wants to attempt to find a solution that might make a modification possible, or perhaps even to defeat foreclosure, he will need to retain experienced foreclosure litigation counsel.  He will also, as already noted, need to open an estate for his brother and have himself appointed his brother's personal representative, so that he can then properly defend and deal with the creditor.  The lien of the mortgage attaches only to the real estate, and to fixtures permanently affixed to the real estate.  Any personal property, including furniture, appliances that are not permanently affixed, or other non-real estate are not in any way affected by the mortgage or by the mortgage foreclosure.

This case illustrates the vital importance of any individual retaining an attorney prior to agreeing to cooperate with police, as the attorney will look out for the individual's interests, and evaluate the pros and cons of cooperating.  In many cases, especially minor ones, it will be advisable to simply deal with the case, rather than making the decision to become a "snitch".  When a person works with police without an attorney, police and agents have no obligation to tell the suspect the truth, and indeed, police frequently lie to suspects to secure cooperation and get confessions.  Moreover, the identity of cooperators is often revealed in the course of an investigation, regardless of police representations to the contrary.  Anyone in this situation should consult with a local defense attorney about options moving forward, so as to ensure resolution of the case that led to the cooperation in  the first place, and to protect the suspect's rights moving forward as a "snitch".

A criminal defense attorney, (including a Public Defender), may have a better chance of negotiating a deal such as community service, or home confinement in lieu of jail, (especially if this is your first time being involved with the criminal justice system). I have the utmost respect for Public Defender's, but with their extensive caseload, sometimes they do not have as much time to dedicate to individual cases when compared to private counsel.  And by all means, if you are innocent, and you know the District Attorney does not have sufficient evidence, do not plead guilty simply to have the matter go away. You know the truth, and if the evidence is there, negotiating a deal early will probably be your best offer. The longer the case goes on, typically the worse the deal from the District Attorney gets.

You may have to jump through some legal hoops before you can get to a termination of parental rights (TPR) hearing.  TPR hearings, no matter what circumstance, are very serious hearings that Judges do not take lightly.  The overwhelming consensus is that the relationship between child and parent is something that courts generally should not dissolve unless absolutely necessary.  As a result, before you get to a TPR hearing, you'll likely have to go through several court appearances in addition to meetings with CPS, social services, DFS, etc.  The best thing to do is that brace yourself for what could end up being a very long process.  Be sure to consult an attorney and speak with him/her in detail.  Good luck!

it is not clear from your question whether or not you signed a written contract.  If there is a written contract then the answer to your question will depend upon the obligations laid out for each party in that contract.   If the agreement was an oral contract, i.e. I will pay you money and you give me the van, with the understanding that you would pay the remainder within a reasonable time, then she should not be allowed to keep the van and the money.   Assuming you have not somehow breached your end of the deal, if for instance your payment is late according to the terms of the agreement, you have a couple of options.  She likely cannot refuse to let you finish paying for the van (once again as long as you are not in breach).  Instead, she likely has to take payment from you, give you the title, and allow you to keep the van, fulfilling the contract you made. You say in your question that you want to keep the van, so if she continues to refuse to accept payment you may need to sue for specific performance of the contract, meaning the court will make her accept the $150.00 and give you the van and title.   If you decide you do not want the van, then it is possible you could return it on the condition that she would need to give you your money back.  I do not see a scenario where giving the car back would also result in you not getting the $900.00 back, the only exception would if there is a written contract that specifically states she doesn't have to pay you back in these circumstances.     She very likely will not be entitled to $600.00 for "distress," so I would not entertain this threat. If you choose to sue for ownership of the van (or the monetary value of that ownership in the alternative), then it would be best to find an attorney that can help you put all of the evidence and facts in the best light possible for the case.  Good luck.

You should consult with a medical malpractice lawyer in Texas. Leaving a foreign object like a towel inside a patient during surgery is often considered medical negligence. In Texas, her pain and suffering damages will be capped at $250,000 under tort reform laws, but any medical expenses related to the second (otherwise unnecessary surgery) and any future medical care she needs is not capped. If she suffered any lost income due to this negligence, that may be recoverable also. Make sure you consult with someone sooner rather than later, because your mom has 2 years from the date of the negligence (sometimes extended by discovering the negligence later) to bring a case. The laws in Texas also require certain pre-suit notice requirements be met. You can give us a call if you like, because we take medical negligence cases all over Texas, and nationally in federal cases.

The best approach here is to mail two notices to them notifying them that if they do not pick them up by a certain date they will be discarded as abandoned.  Send one notice by standard first class mail and send a second one by certified mail with return receipt.  The reason for sending both is so you have proof it was sent, but if they don't pick up up the certified one, but the first class mail one isn't returned you can have reasonable assurance that it was received.  Don't rely on voice mail or texts to be enough.

In general, the license agreement should govern each party's respective responsibilities and it may also hinge on the type of license granted (i.e. exclusive or non-exclusive) and the particular costs involved.  For example, with exclusive licenses, it is not unusual for licensees to pay some or all of the cost of maintenance fees/annuities to keep the patent in force, since the licensee in that case "stands in the shoes of the patentee" relative to others.  So the question as to who pays for what is really a contract issue and what the parties were willing to agree to cover.  The paries to a contract can pretty much freely agree to anything that does not violate the law or is not void as against public policy.  That is what the law calls "freedom of contract."  In the absence of something in the license or further agreement, the parties would most likely bear their own costs.  In addition, in most cases, a patentee would not likely do any type of searches relative  to their patent, because there is no upside, only downside (you don't want to risk finding a reference that invalidates your patent).  If you are talking about clearance searches for a product/service offering by the licensee, again in the absence of something in the license, the licensee would generally bear the cost of clearing whatever product or service they are going to be making available.  There are two basic reasons for that: (1) the licensee is in a better position to do the clearance and control the cost because they know best what they are going to do, and (2) the licensor may not care whether the licensee can actually practice the licensed patent or not -- particularly if they have no indemnity obligation.  In addition, in general, if the license does not require you to pay, your refusal would not be a breach of the license, so the patentee would not likely have recourse against you.  HOWEVER, a close reading of the license agreement would be necessary to ensure that there is no implied obligation that could be argued to create a breach of the license.  Your best bet is to have a patent attorney who litigates look at the license agreement and advise you as to what you and the other party are respectively responsible for paying.  Good luck!

You can change attorneys without having to start over.  Unfortunately, your question failed to include the State of the location of the property.  The response may vary somewhat depending on the law of that state.  As a general matter, state law establishes the procedures for service of process on a plaintiff.  The state law has to meet certain requirements to be valid under the United State Constitution.  Most states have the kinks works out, and their procedures for service of process are Constitutional.  Some states, such as New York, have service of process which allow the a plaintiff who cannot find the defendant to fashion a different method of service of process, and to obtain an order from the judge in advance approving that method.  New York Courts have many times upheld service of process by printing and advertisement in the newspaper.  You need to consult an attorney in your state to see what flexibility the service of process statute(s) have to offer. That having been said, many attorney are under enormous pressure, and clients may take an attorneys cranky disposition personally, when the attorney may actually be manifesting his anxiety to get other things done.  I would make another approach to this attorney, and gently ask him whether he state law allows him to obtain court approval for a different method of service (if you are able and willing, also acknowledge that the motion will take more time than expected, and you will cover the additional cost).  If agrees to make the motion, you are set.  If he disagrees, ask him if he will sign a consent to change attorney if you find a different one.  If he is refusing to consider the viability of making such a motion, then he probably will not refuse to change a consent to change attorney.  Make sure your are prepared to square up with the attorney, if necessary, in order to make the transition occur most smoothly.

You should first have a tax attorney, or a bankruptcy attorney with a tax background, review the lien to see if it was properly recorded.  If improperly recorded, or if the lien is more than ten years old, you may be able to resolve it without needing to file bankruptcy.  A Chapter 7 filing will not automatically strip a tax lien from the property.  In fact, it may not even discharge the IRS' ability to garnish your wages and accounts unless it meets certain criteria under the tax code. You should contact the IRS to obtain a copy of a tax transcript for the dates the taxes were incurred, the date you filed a return, and for more info on the lien.

If you were in front of a master and it was less then 10 days since the Master made his or her recommendation you can file what is called exceptions.  However, if it has been more than 10 says since you were in front of the Master and depending on when the Order granting you custody was entered, you may be able to file a motion to reconsider (it has to be less than 30 days from the date the order granting you custody was entered).    I am not sure what you mean when you state that you have filed a Complaint and Amended Complaint?  For What?  Use and Possession?  If so, the Court is only going to consider Use and Possession during the Limited Divorce hearing and/or an Absolute Divorce hearing.    If you are looking to relocate since there is already a custody order in place you would have to file for a modification in said order (especially if your husband has regular (every other week, monthly) access to your daughter.  If you has no access or only summer access, then it may be easier for you to move without having to obtain a Court Order).  If you do file for a Modification of Custody you will first need to prove that you have a material change of circumstances that warrants the Court to modify the Custody Order.  However, even if the Court finds that there is material change in circumstance that warrants a modification, it does not mean that the Court will grant your request to modify.  The Court will weigh what is in the best interest of your daughter (like they did when they originally granted you custody).    The Court who ordered the first Order will continue to have jurisdiction over the matter, for so long as one party still resides in Maryland (i.e., you, your daughter, or your husband).    If no one resides in Maryland when one of you wants to modify the custody order, then where ever the child is living for 6 months or more will have jurisdiction (exception is if there is an emergency, then any state where the child is at that time will have the ability to enter a temporary order).  In addition, even if your husband still resided in Maryland (at the time you file for a modification), it is possible that the Maryland Court (or another Court) can determine that Maryland is no longer the appropriate state to have jurisdiction over your daughter if the Court finds that there is no longer a strong connection to Maryland (this can be requested by a party or determined by the Court itself, on its own).   As for being granted a Limited Divorce on the grounds of desertion, this can help you in obtaining an absolute divorce on the grounds of desertion, and if you are seeking alimony and/or a monetary award in the absolute divorce case, said grounds is a factor the court considers when determining, if they should order either (alimony and/or monetary award), and if so, how much (and for how long).   I strongly recommend that you contact an attorney if you are seeking to relocate your daughter out of state as relocation cases can be very difficult to argue to a Court.

When the Court hears a case about Domestic Violence and the request for a Restraining Order, they want to know if the person asking for the Order is in real fear for their own safety or the safety of others close by.  The fact that he did not get a temporary order shows that he did not make his case to the Court.  The further in time that the hearing happens from the incident that underlies the action, the less likely a RO will be granted.  If he really feared for his safety, there would have been no continuance. Even though you cannot ask for the case to be dismissed, it is unlikely that a RO will be granted after such a long time.

You ahve several options. As the previous commentator noted, you can raise the landlord's failure to make repairs as a defense to an eviction and negotiate or seek a Court order for a rent abatement.  You should the landlord notice by regular and certified mail that a repair is needed.  You can elect to use the rent money to make repairs yourself. You must first give the landlord notice, by regular and certified mail,  that repairs are needed and give him reasonable time to make the repairs. The cost of the repair must be reasonable. If the landlord fails to make the repair, you can deduct the cost from the next rent payment. You should also give the landlord a copy of the receipt for the repair.   You can also file a law suit in Court seek an order requiring the landlord to make the repairs.
